title: Dr. William Dobelle, Artificial Vision Pioneer, Dies at 62
description: Dr. William Dobelle, who developed an experimental system of artificial vision for the blind that involved the transmission of electrical signals to electrodes implanted in the brain, died on Oct. 5 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 62.

description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 - In the final hectic days of the American presidential campaign, the candidates have been no-shows in one battleground: Israel.

title: Concern Rises in Pakistan of a War Without End
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 29 - Seated in his plush new office at the heavily guarded headquarters of the Pakistani Army, Maj. Gen. Shaukat Sultan chatted amiably and boastfully about Pakistan's contribution to the American-led campaign against terrorism. But when the topic of American foreign policy arose, he bristled.

title: Two Favorites Return, With Violence and Lyricism to Spare
description: Thirty-four-year-old productions of incessantly repeated repertory are not likely to get the full attention of any major opera company. But it was a pleasure to discover, beneath the general onstage bellowing at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon, the Met orchestra and its conductor of the day, Dennis Russell Davies, playing Mascagni and Leoncavallo with exquisite sensibility.

title: A Gamble Pays Off for Theatergoing on the Cheap in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 31 - Nicholas Hytner, the artistic director of the National Theater here, knew it was a gamble. Slashing the cost of tickets for the Olivier, the largest of the National's three auditoriums, to about the price of a movie was either going to lure a whole new group of people who hadn't been to the theater before or it was going to lose a whole lot of money.

title: Afghan Militants Release Video of Hostages
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 31 - Militants holding three foreign United Nations staff members in Afghanistan released a videotape on Sunday showing their hostages, and they said the three would be killed if demands for the release of prisoners and the withdrawal of foreign troops were not met by noon Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cyclists Critical Of Arrests
description: Cyclists yesterday criticized police conduct during and after the Critical Mass bicycle ride on Friday evening, which was marred by confrontations and 40 arrests . One of the cyclists, Bill Schwartz, 60, said he was arrested on West 26th Street while walking down the sidewalk with his bicycle. Mandy Hu, 24, above, said that as she was leaving a post-ride party at a storefront on East Houston Street, an officer shoved her and then arrested her after she objected. Dozens of officers arrived at the storefront near midnight and shut down part of East Houston Street after a report of an officer's being assaulted. Cyclists said that plainclothes officers tried to force their way into the storefront without a warrant. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Good Things, Small Packages
description: A fund-raising sale in London is aiming big by thinking small. Tomorrow night at Sotheby's in London, the charitable will get the chance to buy original leather-bound miniature books by some of the world's greatest statesmen, artists and writers. Approached by a charity for the homeless, Geordie Greig, editor of the glossy magazine Tatler, came up with the idea of asking 25 famous people to fill these tiny books with words or pictures. Among the contributors are Bill Clinton, David Hockney, J.K. Rowling, John le Carr, Harold Pinter, Madonna, left, Paul McCartney and Muhammad Ali. Ms. Rowling returned her book filled with descriptions and drawings of the items Harry Potter needs for wizardry; Margaret Thatcher wrote out her famous speech including the lines "You turn if you want to: the lady's not for turning"; Harold Pinter wrote a love poem; and Madonna and Sir Paul both did drawings to match lyrics from their songs. PAM KENT

Lewis then hurried 16 yards to the Vikings' 22-yard line and, moments later, the Giants had a quick 3-0 lead that ignited a 34-13 rout of the Vikings yesterday.

Azeri could be among several notable Breeders' Cup starters who will be back next year, going against a trend in which many top horses are retired early to be bred.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Held In Slashing Of Officer
description: A man slashed a police officer on the side of the head with a knife and injured a second officer before he was subdued with pepper spray, the police said yesterday. One officer, James Sinnott, was on foot patrol at 550 Ocean Avenue in Flatbush just before midnight Saturday when Kwesi J. Ashun, 20, approached, according to the police. "As the guy passed, he tapped the cop and the cop's hat," said a witness who would not give her name. In that motion, the man apparently cut Officer Sinnott from his left ear to his neck, the police said. The officer ordered him to stop, but the man kept walking, she said. "In two minutes, there were a million cops on the block," the witness said. Officers Brian Risano and Matthew Koeth subdued the attacker with pepper spray and arrested him, with Officer Risano being struck in the head in the process, the police said. A butcher knife and a folding knife were recovered. Both officers were treated for injuries and released. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Music by Numbers
description: Concert No. 1 came in 1842. On Dec. 18, chalk up No. 14,000. The New York Philharmonic, which calls itself the oldest symphony orchestra in the country, said it would reach the milestone on that day, with a concert conducted by Sir Colin Davis. On the program is Britten's cantata "Phaedra," a Philharmonic premiere; Mozart's Symphony No. 31 and Haydn's Symphony No. 103. In recent decades, the orchestra said it has been reaching the thousand-concert increments every five or six years. No. 10,000 came in 1982. DANIEL J. WAKIN

The Best-Selling Post-Mortem
description: Robert Penn Warren knew well what fascinates readers: "In this century, and moment, of mania, tell me a story." The trick is that simple and rare, which makes it all the more remarkable that of all the bureaucratic entities in nonliterary America, the independent commission on the Sept. 11 attacks has produced a lean and stunning narrative out of its exhaustive investigation. The 9/11 report is a story first and last, an unbearably true tale some 585 pages long. And now the telling, by a hodge-podge of staff and commission members, is a finalist for the National Book Award.

title: Arts, Briefly; Keep Talking
description: The music world acted out its own version of a cliffhanger while the rest of the country waited for the presidential election. Three of the nation's premier orchestras, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Chicago Symphony and the Cleveland Orchestra, all had labor contracts with their musicians that expired at 12:01 a.m. Monday, but the deadlines -- already extended for weeks -- were prolonged yet again. The Chicago management said that because progress was being made, the two sides would give it another 24 hours. And according to local news reports, the Philadelphia Orchestra members were not prepared to strike and the Cleveland players and management had agreed to keep on talking past the deadline. DANIEL J. WAKIN

description: Civics books make voting look like a breeze, but it can be hard work. Voter rolls are inaccurate, ID requirements vary and are erratically enforced, partisans try to disqualify likely supporters of their opponents, and lines at the polls can be excruciatingly long. In 2000, as many as six million presidential votes were lost for technical reasons, and this year the number could be even larger. Voters, particularly in battleground states, should head to the voting booth prepared to fight for their vote to be counted:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEINE, LEONARD M. JR.
description: HEINE--Leonard M. Jr. The following e-mail was twice sent to Leonard on June 6, 2004, the 60th anniversary of the Normandy invasion. He repeatedly refused to acknowledge receipt and in so doing, only affirmed Tom Brokaw's insight into that generation. "Leonard: Nancy and I are, at this moment, flying over the Alps and peering down on a tranquil Europe. It is manifest that we and our sons are reaping what you had long ago sown with the currency of your youth. And for that, we will simply say, thank you." Our love to Sandy and the children. Robert and Nancy Englander

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Murder And Kidnapping Charged
description: Leonardo Almonte, the man accused of killing his girlfriend and leaving her 2-year-old daughter trapped in an S.U.V. for more than four days last week, was arraigned yesterday in Queens Criminal Court. The charges included second-degree murder and both kidnapping and reckless endangerment in the first-degree, said a spokesman for Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Police and prosecutors say that Mr. Almonte, a Brooklyn bodega owner, has confessed to killing 32-year-old Cesarina Colon by slamming her head on the floor and then strangling her on Oct. 24. He left her body and her daughter, Rosie Batista, in Ms. Colon's sport utility vehicle on 95th Avenue in Jamaica, the police said. When Ms. Colon's body was discovered four and a half days later, Rosie was alive but severely dehydrated. A spokeswoman for Schneider Children's Hospital in New Hyde Park said yesterday that the girl's condition had been upgraded from critical to stable. A service for Ms. Colon was held yesterday in Brooklyn. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

The course consists of watching "American Idol" twice a week and deciding what factors are important in music and music performance, said Jay Grymes, the assistant professor of music at the university who created the course. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, DR. BERTRAM D.
description: COHEN--Dr. Bertram D. Longtime resident of Warren, NJ, died Thursday, October 28, 2004. Born January 16, 1923, in Brooklyn, NY. BA, Brooklyn College, '44, and Ph.D., Clinical Psychology, University of Iowa '49. Emeritus Professor, Department of Psychiatry, UMDNJ and Rutgers University faculty member since 1962. He broke new ground with his "Double-T Group" therapy approach, which brings mental health professionals, students and patients together as equal participants. Taught students, edited journals including The Journal of Abnormal Psychology, published articles and co-authored two books on group process and international politics. Member of NIH and NIMH grant committee's '61-'72 and the Doe v. Klein Monitoring Committee, Greystone Park Hospital since 1986. Survived by his wife Betty; sisters Leona Rolnick and Sonia Jacobs; children Philip, Sarah, Matthew, Michael, Aaron and Andrew; and seven grandchildren. Also survived by a legion of devoted students and colleagues whose lives have been enriched by his insight and personal contact. A private burial was held Friday at Whitemarsh Memorial Park, Ambler, PA. Omit flowers; vote for John Kerry.

Kohr, was surprised and disappointed that he was one of four Jewish leaders who are quoted praising Mr. Bush in a flier last week. Josh Block, a spokesman for the group, said the committee is bipartisan and does not endorse candidates, so Mr. Kohr considered it "totally inappropriate" for the Republicans to use his words. Last week, the leaders of two other nonpartisan groups listed in the pamphlet -- the Anti-Defamation League and the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism -- also complained about being in the campaign literature. The State Committee said it would not use the names or quotations in future mailings. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

The Americans began the day trailing by three imps, and had built up a 30-imp lead with 14 deals remaining. But in the next 11 the Italians bid and played brilliantly, guessing well into the bargain. The Americans fought hard, but were not at their best. With three deals remaining the Italians led by 22, and held on to win by 12 in spite of an American gain on a slam deal.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Death In Hospital Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a patient at a Far Rockaway hospital in August was ruled a homicide yesterday after the office of the medical examiner determined that someone had turned off his ventilator. The patient, Jerome L. Grant, 61, who suffered from heart disease and lived in a nursing home, was admitted to St. John's Episcopal Hospital on Aug. 9 in cardiac arrest and in a coma. A nurse found him dead on Aug. 18, with the ventilator turned off, the police said yesterday. The ventilator was in working order. A hospital spokeswoman declined to comment on the case. "We have been informed of the result of the medical examiner's report, and we will cooperate fully with all authorities," she said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Mall For Dubai
description: The British builder Balfour Beatty won a 400 million ($733 million) contract to build the world's largest shopping center. The center, the Burj Mall in Dubai, is expected to attract 50,000 shoppers at peak times and will feature a three-story aquarium, an Olympic-size ice rink and the world's largest gold souk, a traditional Arab-style market. Work on the four-floor, 12 million-square-feet center will begin this month and is scheduled for completion by the end of 2006, said Marjorie Hooper, a spokeswoman for Balfour, which won the contract with three partners. The center is part of a complex that will include the 700-meter (2,300 feet) Burj Tower, which will become the world's tallest building. Balfour Beatty is based in London.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Refugee Chief Says Israel Incites Distrust
description: The director of the United Nations refugee agency for Palestinians, Peter Hansen, said Israel was seeking to discredit his relief workers by spreading false allegations of ties to militants and complained that he had not received a requested apology for an Israeli allegation, made last month but since withdrawn, that a stretcher being loaded onto an agency ambulance was a Qassam rocket, the type launched against Israel. "We want a retraction and an apology not out of pride but because 12 of our staff members have been killed over the past four years, so we are not talking about theoretical dangers at checkpoints," said Mr. Hansen, commissioner general of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency. "If soldiers at checkpoints believe these stories that their own government is circulating about us, there's real risk they would deal with us with even greater hostility than they do." Israel has feuded with the agency for years and has asked Secretary General Kofi Annan to investigate Mr. Hansen. Mr. Annan has replied that he has "full confidence" in him. Warren Hoge (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; Theft at the British Museum
description: Less than a month after thieves made off with more than $100,000 in jade objects from the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, the British Museum in London has also fallen victim to theft. Fifteen objects from its Oriental Antiquities Gallery were stolen Friday, it announced, although the loss was discovered by security staff on Saturday. The police said they believed the medieval Chinese jewelry, dating from 700 to 1400, was taken during normal opening hours because no alarms were activated. The easily portable items included hairpins, fingernail guards, earrings, left, and other decorative pieces, taken from a glass cabinet that was forced open. The museum said that the huge gallery was being guarded, but because it is long and segmented by various cases, someone was able to take advantage of an area that wasn't being monitored. PAM KENT

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Several Thousand Protest
description: Thousands of angry citizens marched in a rare public demonstration to protest against new import restrictions, Western news agencies reported. The demonstrators, who were reported to number from 8,000 to 10,000, marched to the center of the eastern town of Kokand but were reported to have dispersed without violence, although Reuters said they burned two police cars. The news agencies said the demonstrators were protesting a low domestic supply of gas and new regulations requiring licenses for all importers, who provide much of the goods used by Uzbeks. Demonstrations are rare in Uzbekistan, which is an authoritarian state. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank's Profit Rises
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding said profit rose 26 percent in the third quarter as a gain from the sale of a stake in the Bank of Asia made up for a decline in mortgage lending in the United States. Net income increased to 1.05 billion euros ($1.34 billion), or 62 euro cents a share, from 832 million euros, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. The chief executive, Rijkman Groenink, said operating profit this year would fall as higher interest rates lead to a slump in mortgage lending and refinancing in the United States. Total banking revenue decreased 1.8 percent to 4.74 billion euros, mainly from a drop of 287 million euros in mortgage revenue in the United States, ABN Amro said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Super Commander in Chief
description: In their daily lives, superheroes are millionaire playboys, doctors, journalists and more. In the "Masked Commander," below, a Meridian Arts comic book that made its debut last month, the Masked Commander, a new hero, is the president of the United States. Sound far-fetched? Not to John May, the creator. "The president, as the most powerful person in the world, is as close to being a superhero as we are likely to see," Mr. May said. The comic chronicles the life of President James Weston and his frustrations with the limits of the Oval Office. On the lighter side, the Masked Commander will be fighting foes like Anarchy, the Grand Jury and Deficit. Foreign Affair is the alluring femme fatale. "Masked Commander" made its debut on Amazon.com and won't be in comic-book stores until January, to coincide with Inauguration Day. A preview can be viewed at www.maskedcommander.com. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: CHURCH'S CHICKEN CHAIN IS BOUGHT BY CRESCENT CAPITAL

AFC, which sold Seattle's Best Coffee last year and agreed to sell its Cinnabon unit in September, said in June that it might sell Church's after three years of declining sales. Crescent Capital, based in Atlanta, is a private equity firm with investments including Loehmann's Holdings and the Caribou Coffee Company. AFC is also based in Atlanta.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fort Lee: Source Of Legionnaire's Disease Is Sought
description: State and local health officials are awaiting test results from a high-rise co-op to determine the source and strain of the Legionnaire's disease that sickened two residents and shut down the building's water system, forcing residents to use bottled water. A 78-year-old woman in the building, the Colony, was found to be infected with the disease last week, and it was diagnosed in June in a male resident, Stephen Wielkocz, Fort Lee's chief health officer, said yesterday. Both have recovered, he said, but a preliminary test found the bacterium that causes the disease inside a water heater, prompting officials to shut off tap water in the building. Test results were expected within 24 hours. John Holl (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Housewives' and Viewers
description: On Sunday night, the ABC hit "Desperate Housewives" had its biggest numbers of the season, bringing in 22.32 million viewers, according to the Nielsen overnight ratings. Repeats of the popular soap on Saturday nights have been averaging audiences of more than 7 million. Its Sunday lead-in, "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition," is also a hit: an audience of 14.86 million watched the remake of a house in Jamaica, Queens. On the strength of these two programs, ABC won the Sunday race among viewers 18 to 49, but CBS continues to attract more people over all, partly because ABC's 10 p.m. offering, "Boston Legal," loses nearly half of the "Desperate Housewives" audience. In the 10 p.m. hour, the NBC mystery "Crossing Jordan," currently in its fourth season, ranked first in total viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: The Long-Distance Treasure Hunt

Why was he mesmerized by tiny objects that Ximude didn't find all that significant -- a three-inch-long gold pendant in the shape of a crouching horse, or the miniature plaque, 21/2 by 4 inches, showing a female figure flanked by two animals?

title: A New Adventure in a Blink of an Eye

On one late-night flight to Hong Kong, I slept through a six-hour takeoff delay. When we landed in Vancouver for a stopover, I had no idea why it was daylight when it should have been dark.

title: From Page to Screen, an Impossibly Internal Novel
description: As "Enduring Love" enters a world of dark obsession, it lures viewers into a symbiotic dance between a stalker named Jed (the scruffy, blond, helpless-looking Rhys Ifans) and the man he is stalking, Joe (Daniel Craig as his opposite, a broodingly handsome, tough-minded intellectual). Yet this dynamic film is based on Ian McEwan's ambiguous, interior, apparently unadaptable novel. Just imagine all the bad movies that might have come from that. How the book became the film, without costing the novel its soul, is the story of a collaboration that doesn't even sound promising. There's a director who leaves few fingerprints, Roger Michell; a screenwriter best known as a playwright, Joe Penhall; and a novelist who realizes that, as Mr. McEwan put it in a phone conversation last week, "translating a novel to film is an act of controlled vandalism."

description: A lawyer for the family of 7-month-old Matthew Perilli, who suffocated under a pile of toys at a day care center in Queens in August, filed a wrongful-death claim yesterday. The lawyer, Brian W. Raum, of Manhattan, said that two inspectors were conducting an inspection "at the exact time" the child lay unsupervised in a crib upstairs but did not inspect the floor where the crib was located and failed to take action when they saw the center was "overcrowded and understaffed." Frieden, left, who fired the official in charge of health care inspections after the death and ordered a reorganization of the office that inspects child care centers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Lowers Forecast

Sales will be $445 million to $450 million, down about 18 percent to 19 percent from the first quarter, the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said. The company said on Sept. 9 that sales would decline 8 percent to 10 percent. Orders placed in the second quarter, ending Nov. 28, for delivery during the same period did not increase as expected, National Semiconductor said. Shares of National Semiconductor fell $1.29, to $15.40, in extended trading after falling as low as $14. In regular trading, shares fell 1 cent, to $16.69.

Bea grew up in her Jewish home in Nuernberg, Germany until her immigration in 1938 to the U.S.A. We had met in 1934 as teen-age students in Montreux, Switzerland, and I enjoyed her close, loyal friendship all these years. Bea was a practicing, professional baby-nurse for over 60 years. title: Faith in America
description: Florida's early polling was designed to make voting easier, but enormous voter turnout swamped the limited number of early polling sites. Over the weekend, people in some polling places had to stand in line for four, five, even six hours, often in the hot sun. Some of them -- African-Americans in particular -- surely suspected that those lines were so long because officials wanted to make it hard for them to vote. Yet they refused to be discouraged or intimidated.

title: No Vaccines? You Can Still Fight the Flu
description: There's an unfortunate twist associated with this season's shortage of flu vaccine. Now that many people who could be protected cannot be immunized, everyone seems to want the vaccine against this costly, debilitating and sometimes life-threatening viral illness.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rules Changed On Sharing Of Police Data
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed legislation yesterday that amends the city code requiring city agencies to transmit reports, records and various other documents to the city's Department of Records and Information Services. By law, many of those records are then disseminated publicly. Under the new measure, certain Police Department reports containing information "that could be used to undermine the security of New Yorkers" are not required to be transmitted in electronic format to that department or posted on its Web site. Examples would include training methods for police officers and documents that pertain to antiterrorism efforts. The new law does not remove the mandate to provide the information to the City Council. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Can Defend Himself
description: After bringing his 33-month trial to a near standstill, Slobodan Milosevic recovered the right to act as his own defense lawyer and question his own witnesses at his war crimes trial. The appeals judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal said the former Yugoslav president "will take the lead in his case," but they added that if his health problems force him to be absent, his current court-appointed lawyers may take over so the trial can continue. The trial is to resume Nov. 9. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Paging Rocky; Compiled by Lawrence Van Gelder
description: American Media, publisher of Men's Fitness, Shape and other magazines, has always had a thing for big guys with even bigger muscles -- Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California is executive editor of the company's Flex and Muscle & Fitness magazines. Now it has lined up another guy who will never be accused of being a girlie man. Sylvester Stallone, right, who immortalized the role of palooka in "Rocky," is getting his own monthly magazine, Sly, in partnership with American Media, which also publishes supermarket tabloids like The National Enquirer. The magazine will begin publishing in January with a circulation mainly from newsstands. It is intended as a lifestyle magazine for men 35 to 54 who are interested in fitness. "This is not Sly as big muscle-y guy, not the Sly of 'Rocky,"' said Carolyn Bekkedahl, president of the active lifestyle and entertainment group at American Media. "This is much more of a lifestyle magazine for what really is the best time of your life." DAVID CARR

title: LOCKHEED TO TAKE $110 MILLION CHARGE AFTER LOSING CASE
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it would take a charge of about $110 million in the fourth quarter because it lost a legal dispute over work cleaning up nuclear waste in Idaho. The United States District Court in Idaho upheld the termination of Lockheed's $180 million waste-cleanup contract on Friday. Costs related to the decision will be about 25 cents a share, the company said. The Energy Department awarded the contract in 1994 but terminated it in 1998 after a General Accounting Office report found the project was at least 26 months behind schedule and that it would cost at least twice as much. The contract involved a site at the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental Laboratory. Lockheed Martin is based in Bethesda, Md.

title: Vote, No Matter What
description: Urging Americans to vote on Election Day should be a motherhood-and-apple-pie editorial topic. But nothing is simple in the post-2000 political world. We all know the difference between a swing state and one that's long been consigned to the column of sure things. If you happen to be living in Ohio or Florida, nobody has to explain why it is important for you to go to the polls today. But citizenship is more complicated in places like New York and California, or Utah and Georgia, where electoral votes were all but conceded by last spring.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Latham: Head Of State Teachers' Union Is To Retire
description: Thomas Y. Hobart Jr., the longtime president of New York State United Teachers, the federation of union locals representing public school teachers, announced yesterday that he would retire when his term ends in April. Mr. Hobart became head of the group in 1973, when it represented 100,000 teachers, and helped it grow to more than 500,000 members. The union, part of the American Federation of Teachers, said Mr. Hobart's successor would be elected in April at a meeting of the union's Representative Assembly. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Maoists Attack Town
description: Ending a nine-day truce for a Hindu religious holiday, hundreds of Maoist fighters attacked a northwestern district capital and set several government buildings on fire, Reuters reported. The rebels, one of whom was killed, according to army officials, engaged in heavy fighting with government troops around the town of Gamgadi. Government troops said they suffered no casualties. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Baggage Thieves Bagged
description: BAGGAGE THIEVES BAGGED -- After police staged a months-long undercover sting, five baggage handlers at Kennedy Airport were charged last week with stealing laptop computers, cameras, compact discs and cash from the checked bags of passengers, according to the Queens district attorney's office, which estimated the total value of the stolen goods to be $23,000. The baggage handlers who were charged in the thefts were employees of Swissport USA, which transports luggage and cargo from terminals to aircraft. Some of the stolen goods were sold to undercover detectives or on eBay, the online auction house. Since April, about two dozen employees of the Transportation Security Administration have been arrested on charges of stealing from checked bags at six airports.

title: Lighting the Stove, Yankees Seem Interested in Milton

They were Democrats.

title: JUDGE RULES MCI CAN SUE ITS FORMER CHIEF OVER LOANS
description: A bankruptcy judge ruled yesterday that MCI, the long-distance carrier, can seek repayment of $408 million that its former chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers, borrowed from the company without going to trial. MCI is suing to recover the unpaid loans and to dismiss a $12 million claim by Mr. Ebbers. The company said that it would file a motion next week asking the judge overseeing its suit to order Mr. Ebbers to repay the money, an MCI lawyer, Marcia Goldstein, said. MCI, based in Ashburn, Va., needed permission from Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to file that motion.

title: Teenage Suicide Bomber Kills 3 in a Market in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 1 - A 16-year-old Palestinian blew himself up on Monday in an outdoor market here, killing 3 Israelis and wounding 32 others, three days after Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, left the region for medical attention in France.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Royal KPN Reports Profit
description: Royal KPN, the Dutch phone company, reported yesterday that third-quarter profit doubled as it cut costs and paid fewer taxes, but the company said profitability this year would be at the lower end of its forecasts as it invested in new businesses. Net income rose to 288 million euros ($368 million), or 0.12 euro a share, from 139 million euros, or 0.05 euro a share, a year earlier, the chief executive, Ad Scheepbouwer, said on a conference call with reporters. Sales fell to 2.95 billion euros from 3.01 billion euros.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Trade Gap Widens
description: Australia's trade deficit widened in September to 2.11 billion Australian dollars ($1.57 billion) as a 5 percent rise in imports outpaced a 4 percent increase in exports. Rising prices for fuel were partly to blame for the rise in imports, while the expansion in exports was the first in three months. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Rise 27%
description: Global sales of semiconductors rose 27 percent, to $18.4 billion, in September from a year earlier, helped by demand for chips used in mobile phones and personal computers, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday. Chip sales climbed 1 percent from August, the group, based in San Jose, Calif., said. Third-quarter sales rose 27 percent, to $55.2 billion, from the year-ago period, the group said.

World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Breakup Of Gas Venture
description: The Netherlands proposed to take sole control of the country's gas grid and its gas transportation concern by buying out stakes in the operation from the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Royal/Dutch Shell Group for 2.78 billion euros ($3.54 billion), the government said. The deal would split up Nederlandse Gasunie, a 41-year-old distribution and marketing venture, among the two companies and the government. The merchant business would remain a three-way venture, the Dutch economics ministry said. The proposal was sent to the Parliament by the economics minister, Laurens Jan Brinkhorst.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Tax For Yukos
description: The Russian Tax Ministry served the oil company Yukos with claims for an additional $10 billion in back taxes, which would bring the company's total tax bill to $17.5 billion. Tax officials with the ministry finished an audit for Yukos for 2002, and as a result demanded 193 billion rubles ($6.7 billion) for that year, the Interfax news agency reported. Earlier, Yuganskneftegaz, the main production unit of Yukos, received a $3.3 billion back-tax claim, $2.3 billion for unpaid taxes in 2001 and $1 billion for 2002. As part of the Russian government's campaign against the company, the country's largest oil producer, Yukos already faced total back-tax claims of about $7.5 billion for the years 2000 and 2001. The company has almost fully repaid the $3.4 billion for 2000. The founder of Yukos, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, is in jail facing trial on separate criminal charges, and his detention was extended on Monday to Feb. 14 from Nov. 14. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

description: No matter how bad a day Ralph Burkhardt has, he ends it with a chuckle. He could certainly use a good laugh after what he endured this year: so depressed that he almost flung himself off a rooftop, he checked into a psychiatric ward and wound up living in homeless shelters.

description: YOUNG--Robert. It is with profound sorrow that the employees of Day & Meyer, Murray & Young Corp mourn the loss of their longtime Chairman and friend for over fifty years. His 81 years were an amazing journey and his wit, humor and leadership will be missed by all he met along the way.

description: Leaving the Democratic National Convention on a bus for the start of his Believe in America Tour, Senator John Kerry rode trains, planes, cars and boats for the kind of grand tour that could come only in a presidential campaign.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Pack Rat With Plutonium
description: A retired physicist at a former Soviet laboratory has turned in eight small containers of plutonium-238 that he had kept for years in his garage, Russian news agencies reported. The man, Leonid Grigorov, gave the isotope to the police in the Altai region, near the Kazakh border, after reading a newspaper notice offering rewards for weapons, Interfax and Itar-Tass reported. The reports said that in 1997 or 1998 he found the material in a scrap heap at his former laboratory and wrote letters to the government about it but never received a reply. The laboratory closed in 1992. Plutonium-238 cannot be used for a nuclear blast, but many security agencies have expressed worry that it could be used in a so-called dirty bomb. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: She Has Worms in the Closet, on Purpose
description: Worms do not make Alixe Dancer squirm. There are at least 1,000 of them in her bathroom, nestled inside a purple five-gallon plastic bin.

title: Slam Chances Missed in Bridge Tourney
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 2 - Two quarterfinal bridge matches at the World Team Olympiad here on Tuesday hinged on a slam possibility on the final deal. Hundreds watched in the Vugraph theater as England and France contended in the Women's Teams. The English, with a small lead, stopped short, opening the door, but the French also missed their chance.

title: Jeter Wins His First Gold Glove
description: It is a pastime among baseball statisticians to malign Derek Jeter's defense. Two years ago, when Jeter said he wanted to win a Gold Glove at shortstop, he was roundly ridiculed.

title: Mahler's Old Wine Is Poured Into New Skins
description: In years, at least, Mahler was not old when he wrote his Ninth Symphony, a couple of years before his death at 51, but he was physically and emotionally spent. So the bright young faces of the students cramming the stage of Avery Fisher Hall for a performance of that valedictory work on Monday, and the vigorous look of the body as a whole, seemed a bit incongruous.

title: Macedonian church guards its identity : Bishop's struggle reflects wider Balkan rift
Japan's Recovery Hinges on Oil Prices
description: TOKYO, Nov. 2 - Like a Japanese compact car, the nation's economy is built to go a long way on a little gas. And so, Japan should be one of the best-prepared countries in the world to deal with rising oil prices. But as oil prices linger around $50 a barrel, economists now say Japan may be among the hardest hit.

title: DANA REDUCES SALE PRICE OF ITS AUTO PARTS UNIT
description: The Dana Corporation, a maker of light-truck axles, reduced the sale price on its automotive replacement-parts business 6.9 percent, to $1.02 billion. The sale, which was made to the Affinia Group, an affiliate of the Cypress Group will be for $950 million in cash and a $74.5 million note, Dana said. The price was reduced from $1.1 billion in cash when the transaction was announced in July. Dana put the parts unit up for sale to reduce debt and to improve the company's credit rating. Dana said it expected the transaction to be completed this month.

title: Would You Like an Extra Shot of Music With That Macchiato?
description: Starbucks is growing increasingly aggressive about marketing music alongside its macchiatos and madeleines. "Genius Loves Company," an album of Ray Charles duets that Starbucks' Hear Music division released in late summer as a joint venture with the independent label Concord Records, remained in the Billboard Top 10 for more than a month and recently went platinum. More than a quarter of the CD's sales were made in Starbucks coffee shops.

description: GATOF--Arnold. We are saddened by the loss of our dear cousin and friend. We will miss you. Love, Dorothy & Abe

title: Stern Warning for Sprewell
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Nov. 2 - N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern has no use for Latrell Sprewell's latest actions and threatened to respond if he did not hear an apology.

description: The baseball players at Samuel J. Tilden High School, desperate for a winner, say they only watch the Mets in games against the Yankees.

description: NEWARK - THEY came out of the polling place at the Camden Street School in Newark's Central Ward around 11:30 in the morning, Cynthia Desouza taking small steps in her walker, her 18-year-old daughter, Stacey, bounding out toward their car.

title: Sleaze-Free Times Squareas a New Financial Center
description: Times Square, a once-seedy area that was rife with crime and lowbrow entertainment, has been transformed over the last decade not just into a destination for tourists and shoppers but also a home for companies seeking office space. Increasingly, this includes financial businesses that might previously have set up shop downtown in the financial district.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is pushing for an independent monitor to scrutinize the books of the American International Group as the company seeks to settle an investigation into the sale of a product that helped a financial company manipulate its earnings, according to people briefed on the negotiations.

title: Waiting for a President
description: The American people know what to do in these situations: a painfully close division in the Electoral College, and at least one large state with a big pile of disputed ballots. We wait for the best possible count, ready to accept whoever wins by the rules of the game as the next chief executive.

title: Justice Lets Ohio Ruling on Monitors at Polls Stand
description: The United States Supreme Court declined early on Tuesday morning to accept an invitation to intervene in the 2004 presidential election.

description: For years, the State Senate district in the northern Bronx had been the domain of Guy J. Velella, the borough's Republican Party chairman and a power broker who was convicted of felony bribery charges earlier this year.

Volunteers Dig Deep for Bush
description: CHANHASSEN, Minn., Nov. 2 - Yes, they had already phoned 25,446 voters in this county in the past two days. Yes, they had already knocked on 9,796 doors. And yes, it was raining outside, a face-numbing blustery rain.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Posts $12.7 Million Profit
description: BMC Software, whose programs help manage corporate computer networks, had a second-quarter profit of $12.7 million on higher license revenue. Net income in the period that ended Sept. 30 totaled 6 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $13.2 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 6.4 percent, to $355.1 million, the Houston-based BMC said yesterday. Sales and profit this quarter may exceed analysts' estimates as the chief executive, Robert E. Beauchamp, added new functions to existing products and purchased Marimba.

title: G.I. Gets Light Sentence for Desertion in '65
description: CAMP ZAMA, Japan, Nov. 3 - Four decades after Charles Robert Jenkins disappeared into the mists of the Cold War, the United States Army sergeant, now a frail 64-year-old, received a light sentence today after pleading guilty in a court-martial here to desertion and aiding the enemy, North Korea.

title: Daschle, Democratic Senate Leader, Is Beaten
description: SIOUX FALLS, Wednesday, Nov. 3 - Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader of the Senate and a fixture of South Dakota politics for more than a quarter century, lost his seat Tuesday night in an historic political upset that stunned Democrats and gave Republicans around the country cause to celebrate.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Shipbuilders Win Contract
description: The shipbuilder Hyundai Heavy Industries and two other companies won an order that may be worth more than $3.2 billion to build the world's largest tankers for shipping natural gas, a Qatari official said. Hyundai, the Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering Company and the Samsung Heavy Industries Company will build eight tankers for shipping liquefied natural gas, with an option for eight more, said Ali al-Hamadi, board member at the Qatar Gas Transport Company. The Overseas Shipholding Group, a tanker owner listed in the United States, and Pronav Ship Management of Germany ordered the ships, Mr. Hamadi said.

title: A Fall Jam Keeps a Village in Step With Its Italian Roots
description: SAGAMORE BEACH, Mass. - I AM one of the lucky few who can still remember the Little Italy of Sagamore Village, just across the canal from here, where the mainland becomes Upper Cape Cod. It was a vibrant community of mostly Northern Italian immigrants, where one could hear regional dialects, where women made sweet ravioli for the holidays, and men, among them my grandfather, made their own wine. Little of the community exists today, but a few of us are keeping one of our village's autumn traditions alive: reserving kitchen time to make a versatile, dense fruit butter called savor.

title: Globalist : Winner's challenge:Rebuilding what's lost
European firms improving online disclosure
What Becomes Chocolate Most?
description: A tiny Scharffen Berger chocolate shop opens today at 473 Amsterdam Avenue (83rd Street), the company's third boutique and the first outside the San Francisco Bay Area. In addition to chocolate bars in various sizes and intensities, it sells elegant new candies with subtly flavored ganache or caramel centers and robes of milk or dark chocolate, at $1.85 each. Among the many flavors, fresh mint leaves season the mint filling, and tea leaves decorate the smoky Yunnan tea flavor. There is also a new line of chocolate-dipped fruits, including ginger bits, above.

description: For once, it was a safe day to be a hunk of leather on Jimmy Breslin's shoe. He quit yesterday.

title: On Alert for Terror Activity Timed to Disrupt Election, Agencies Find Little Reason to Worry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 - Terrorism command centers were activated in dozens of states and cities throughout the country on Tuesday because of fears of an election-year attack. Security authorities said emergency personnel were on standby alert, but there were no reports of any incidents.

title: They plan to accept any fraud-free result : Patient voters just looking for a winner
Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, EILEEN G.
description: GOODMAN--Eileen G. Beloved wife of Stanley L. Cherished mother of M.J. (Richard) Wolff and Lois (Marc) Richards. Adoring and adored Nana of Brett, Will, Sarah and Max. Eileen passed on as she lived, with grace and dignity, surrounded by her family. Services at Sharon Gardens on Wednesday, November 3, 1 pm. The family will be at the Wolff home on Wednesday evening and the Richards home on Thursday. For those who wish, the family would appreciate memorial gifts to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Mythmaker Confident in Her Memories
description: CIVITELLA DELLA CHIANA, Italy - Even at 86, with five botched operations on one hip and a successful one on the other, her eyesight troubling her and her hearing no longer perfect, Muriel Spark is still doing what every writer likes to do. Having just published her 23rd novel, "The Finishing School" (Doubleday), she is working on another.

title: Potato Fields Give Way to a New Crop: Cheese
description: Art Ludlow, above, has been making cheese in Bridgehampton, N.Y., for only about a year and a half, a venture driven by both passion and profit. He is a fourth-generation farmer on land once planted with potatoes but now home to 11 cows, mostly Jerseys, and a few Thanksgiving turkeys. He makes more than 150 pounds of cheese a week in the old potato barn. It sells fast at $20 a pound at a stand next to the farm at Mecox Road and Horsemill Lane. Mr. Ludlow's brother, Harry, a vegetable farmer, runs the stand.

title: Ex-Judge Leads 11-Way Race to Complete a Mayor's Term
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 2 - With 90 percent of the votes counted, Jerramiah Healy, a former municipal court judge, was leading a field of 10 other candidates Tuesday night in a race to replace Glenn D. Cunningham, the city's first black mayor, who died of a heart attack in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COON, MARGARET G.
description: COON -- Margaret G., of Bronxville, NY, on November 1 at age 69. Wife of Henry L. Coon. Mother of Scott T. Stroble, Suzanne S. Sitter and Andrew L. Coon. Stepmother of Emily Coon and Jennifer C. Kralyevich. Also survived by six grandchildren and her brother, Thomas M. Greene, Jr. Visiting hours at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, Thursday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, Kraft Avenue at Cedar St., Bronxville, Friday, November 5, at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Venice Is Flooded
description: Tides around Venice rose nearly a yard above normal, putting many squares and streets in the city under water for the seventh day in a row, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. On Sunday, tides rose four and a half feet above average, flooding about 80 percent of the ancient, slowly sinking city. Such flooding has been a growing threat to the city of 117 low islets, partly because the marshy region is subsiding as underlying peat compacts and because seas are rising as global warming melts glaciers. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: A Soup So Simple, No Corners Need Cutting
description: CHEFS have more time and kitchen help than home cooks do, but there is only so much space and time, and labor can be stretched thin during meal service. So even in great restaurants, chefs are famous for cutting corners, precooking and inventing shortcuts.

title: F.D.A. Releases Memo on Vioxx
description: Providing details from a report it had described broadly in August, the Food and Drug Administration published a memorandum yesterday that indicated Merck's Vioxx painkiller might have contributed to 27,785 heart attacks and deaths from 1999 through 2003.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Judge Says Soccer Stadium Was Terror Target
description: A group of suspected Islamic militants arrested last month and accused of plotting to blow up the national court building in Madrid was also planning to bomb the stadium of the Real Madrid soccer team, which can hold 75,000 people, said Baltasar Garzn, the judge investigating the case. The group, which the judge calls a cell and which includes some 30 North Africans detained across Spain during the past two weeks, also had plans to bomb train stations and the offices of the conservative opposition party, he said. Investigators say it is not clear if the group is tied to those who carried out the March 11 train attacks in Madrid, which killed 191 people. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: In Suburbia, Voters Agree to Spend $255 Million to Preserve Dwindling Open Space
description: Voters on Long Island overwhelmingly approved four referendums yesterday to buy and preserve some of its dwindling open space.

title: Campaign by the Numbers
description: Washington - So what just happened? While there are a million different ways to look at the 2004 campaign, those of us at The Hotline thought it might be a good idea to follow the numbers. Billions of dollars were spent in this year's race, on advertising, polls, mailings and campaign stops. To put Campaign 2004 in the appropriate perspective, we tallied the figures and crunched the spending in the battleground states and beyond. Here's a portrait of politics as it is today -- or at least as it was yesterday.

title: Another Lesson in Humiliation, Taught by British Nanny
description: As "The Weakest Link" and "American Idol" made clear, Americans love to be bossed around by prigs with accents. The latest televised exercise in British-American sadism comes tonight in the form of "Nanny 911," Fox's latest reality program, on which infantile American families are abused by prim, nasty nannies from Britain -- and end up begging for more.

title: THE WORKPLACE : Is U.S. vote distracting employees?
Around World, Praise and Resignation for Bush Win
description: LONDON, Nov. 3 - President Bush's electoral victory was greeted today with a mixture of praise, disappointment and pragmatic resignation as world leaders jostled to congratulate the president while also seeking to influence his foreign policy agenda for the second term.

title: Lehman to Be Named U.S. Ryder Cup Captain
description: When the next United States Ryder Cup captain is announced today, Tom Lehman is expected to be pleased.

description: PUSEY -- Anne Woodward. Memorial Service Saturday, 3PM, November 6, 2004 at St. James Church 865 Madison Avenue at 71 Street, NYC

title: Trial in '85 Jet Blast Nears End in Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 2 - Nearly 20 years after an Air India Boeing 747 from Canada exploded in the air and plunged into waters off the Irish coast killing all 329 people on board, the trial to finally resolve what happened entered its climactic phase this week.

title: Bush Holds Comfortable Lead as Voting Problems of 2000 Do Not Reappear
description: MIAMI, Nov. 2 - For all the predictions that Election Day in Florida would be a repetition of what happened four years ago, with a razor-thin margin, chaos at the polls and a disputed outcome, the results here on Tuesday were pretty much the opposite. With more than 95 percent of precincts reporting, President Bush was leading Senator John Kerry by a comfortable margin after a relatively trouble-free day at the polls.

title: Arts, Briefly; An Iraq War Drama Over There, Over Here
description: The award-winning producer Steven Bochco ("N.Y.P.D. Blue," "L.A. Law" and "Hill Street Blues") and Chris Gerolmo ("Mississippi Burning") have been asked by John Landgraf, the president for entertainment for FX Networks, to create a pilot for a new war drama set among soldiers in Iraq and their families at home. The drama, "Over There," will illuminate the war's effects on the seven or eight men in a unit in Iraq and their families. Casting for the new series will begin next week, with pilot production scheduled for December. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Daschle, Democratic Senate Leader, Is Beaten
description: SIOUX FALLS, Wednesday, Nov. 3 - Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader of the Senate and a fixture of South Dakota politics for more than a quarter century, lost his seat Tuesday night in an historic political upset that stunned Democrats and gave Republicans around the country cause to celebrate.

title: Paul F. Iams, 89, Developer of a Line of Premium Pet Foods, Dies
description: Paul F. Iams, a self-taught animal nutritionist whose pet foods bearing his name are sold in 70 countries, died Oct. 26 in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 89 and lived in Sun City West, Ariz. The cause was complications of a broken hip, said his daughter Barbara Iams Korein.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Insurer Eases AIDS Restriction
description: A South African insurer, the African Life Assurance Company, said it had dropped restrictions on burial policies for people with H.I.V. or AIDS. As many as 60 percent of African Life's 550,000 policies are burial policies that pay out up to 15,000 rand ($2,460) to cover funeral costs. Previously, beneficiaries of a principal policyholder who died of AIDS within six months of opening a policy would not have been paid.

title: Long Lines, Short Tempers, Little Chaos at Polls
description: Lines were long, tempers were short, some voting machines malfunctioned and a few polling places briefly replaced electronic wizardry with cardboard ballot boxes. But America's national election seemed to run smoothly yesterday, with no widespread reports of chaos, fraud or legal challenges that might affect the outcome.

title: Wilson Play Is Stalled, Awaiting New Money
description: Conceding what had become painfully obvious along Broadway, the producers of "Gem of the Ocean," a new play by August Wilson, said yesterday that they were postponing the show's first performance while they continued their hunt for financing. All performances through Nov. 14 have been canceled. The show was originally scheduled to begin previews tomorrow and to open on Nov. 11; no new opening date has been set.

title: An Early Night for Viewers Becomes a Cliffhanger
description: As of midafternoon, the likely outcome yesterday appeared clear.

title: Former White House Budget Chief Unseats a Democrat in Indiana
description: Mitch Daniels, the White House budget director under President Bush, won the Indiana governor's race last night, defeating the Democratic incumbent, Joseph E. Kernan.

title: Shays Survives Brutal Fight in Connecticut
description: Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut beat back a ferocious challenge yesterday by his Democratic opponent after one of the most bitter and closely watched Congressional campaigns in the New York City region.

title: The Danube Flows in Brooklyn
description: IMAGINE that a chef with a four-star review under his belt packed his bags and headed south to open an affordable bistro in Brooklyn. Imagine it served a democratized take on the cuisine that earned him those stars and had burger and fries on the menu. Imagine the media crush, the impossible reservations.

Classes in Judaic Studies, Drawing a Non-Jewish Class
description: FOR Shivani Subryan, the whole thing started with a wig. There was this guidance counselor at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, a woman named Kornhaber, and she wore a blond wig. And when Shivani was a junior or senior there in the late 1990's, she heard all the whispers from her classmates about the reason. Mrs. Kornhaber was bald. No, Mrs. Kornhaber had cancer.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 25 about Michael Grant, who wrote popular books on the ancient world, misstated the title of a text written by Ben Sira, the subject of an assessment by Mr. Grant. It was Ecclesiasticus, an apocryphal book of the Bible, not Ecclesiastes.

title: From Manhattan, Lawyers Monitor the Nation's Polls
description: The election swept through several of the city's law firms yesterday, with lawyers wearing headsets to answer phone calls from voters across the country who had questions that ranged from the banal, like registration problems, to the bizarre, like a Satanist who refused to vote in a church.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Joe Eula, a fashion illustrator, misidentified the county for the Hudson Valley town, Hurley, N.Y., where he spent much of his time at his home in his later years. It is in Ulster County, not Dutchess.

title: Leyland Balks at Job With Mets
description: The convoluted game of phone tag between Omar Minaya and Jim Leyland, which lasted nearly a month and intensified in the past week, ended yesterday with the understanding that they really did not have to talk to each other after all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBOW, HAROLD
description: DuBOW -- Harold. Beloved husband of Adeline, cherished father of Ronnie and Susan, Robyn and Eric Frohmann, Jeffrey, Shari and Kenny. Passed away on October 30. Shiva at the Frohmann's, 1611 East 5th St through Friday, November 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINSON, PAUL F.
description: ROBINSON--Paul F. Beloved husband/friend of Karrie, devoted, cherished father of David and Jennifer. A gentle man, an inspiration to many. Donations to Greenport F.D. Rescue, P.O. Box 682, Greenport, NY 11944 and Eastern LI Hospital, Manor Pl, Greenport, NY 11944 c/o Dr. L. Walser, M.D.

title: Cricket : Gilchrist leads surge as runs flow faster than ever
Paid Notice: Deaths   SACKS, ALEXANDER
description: SACKS--Alexander. Congregation Beth Sholom of Lawrence, NY records with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: In a Game of Shirts and Skins, They'd Be the Skins
description: CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 28 - At a rugby game at Middlebury College recently, cheerleaders had taken the field to urge on the home team with timeless perkiness when they were silenced by a drove of naked students running a parade line through the middle of the field. At Connecticut College, a tour of the campus was conducted in the typical formation, with the guide walking backward, pointing to everything from the library to the dean's office. The only wrinkle was that those taking the tour, both men and women, were without a stitch of clothes.

title: PFIZER BUYS RESEARCH SITE IN CALIFORNIA FOR $372 MILLION
description: Pfizer, the drug maker, said it bought a research center in La Jolla, Calif., for $372 million. The company bought the site from Slough Estates in Britain. Pfizer, which is based in New York, leased the center for three years and invested $150 million in improvements. The 33-acre campus contains about 1 million square feet of laboratories and offices and employs 1,500 people, Pfizer said. Scientists at the center are conducting late-stage clinical trials on medicines for kidney and stomach cancer and drug-resistant strains of H.I.V. and AIDS, said a spokesman, Tom Gable. La Jolla is north of San Diego.

title: In Connecticut, Dodd Easily Tops Orchulli for 5th Senate Term
description: NORWICH, Conn., Nov. 2 - United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd won a fifth term on Tuesday, overwhelming his Republican challenger, Jack Orchulli, a former fashion executive with no previous political experience.

title: Finish in sight, some are glad it's over : The weary and wary turn out to cast ballots
Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISCHMAN, HARRY
description: FLEISCHMAN--Harry, 90, socialist, labor and civil rights activist, biographer of Norman Thomas, and husband to the late Natalie Fleischman, died November 1, 2004, at the home of his son and daughter-in-law, Peter Fleischman and Louise Klebanoff of New York, NY, after a long illness. In addition to his son, he is survived by his wife, Ethel Kahn of West Caldwell, NJ, daughter Martha Mordin of Front Royal, VA, daughter Maria Fiene-LaManna of New Port Richey, FL, stepsons Ed Kahn of Kent, NY, Paul Kahn of New York, NY, and step-daughter Elissa Halperin of Basking Ridge, NJ, nine grandchildren and two great - grandchildren. From his work with the Socialist Party, to the Voice of America, to the American Jewish Committee, Harry fought the good fight for justice, equality and brotherhood. He was a kind and gentle man who was loved by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Workers Defense League or The Friends of Norman Thomas High School. A Memorial Service is planned for Sunday, December 5, 2004, at 11 am, at Crane's Mill, 459 Passaic Ave., West Caldwell, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, SUZANNE B.
description: KAPLAN--Suzanne B. Passed away peacefully on November 2, 2004. She was courageous and valiant in her struggle with MS. Beloved wife of Harvey. Loving stepmother of Caroline. Devoted aunt of Ann, David and Ariel. Dear sister-in-law of Louise. Suzanne was a woman of extraordinary integrity . Her spirit and presence was an inspiration for all who knew her. Services Thursday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Zayed bin Sultan, Gulf Leader and Statesman, Dies
description: Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, a Bedouin tribesman who became president of the federation known as the United Arab Emirates and one of the Arab world's leading statesmen, died yesterday. He was believed to be 86.

title: Strong Showing at Polls Catches City's Old System Off Guard
description: With a huge turnout testing New York City's antiquated voting system, voters complained of long lines, confusion and broken machines at some polling places yesterday, as election officials appeared overwhelmed and unprepared for the crush of people who showed up to cast ballots.

title: Arts, Briefly; At Least Temporarily, The Music Goes On
description: With yet another contract deadline come and gone, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra will keep on playing rehearsals and concerts. The musicians and management extended a midnight Monday strike deadline until midnight Sunday, the third extension since the contract was to expire on Sept. 12. Among the nation's major orchestras, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Cleveland Symphony are also struggling to come up with labor agreements in protracted and sometimes bitter struggles between the players and administrators. The New York Philharmonic and the Boston Symphony, the other two members of the so-called Big Five, have contracts. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Exports Rise
description: Russian crude oil exports to countries outside the former Soviet Union rose 17 percent in the first 10 months of the year to 168.5 million metric tons (4.05 million barrels a day), from 144 million tons in the period in 2003, the Industry and Energy Ministry said.

title: Transcript of John Edwards's Speech on Wednesday

title: Hostage Incident at Caterpillar Plant
description: A woman armed with a shotgun took three people hostage yesterday afternoon at a Caterpillar factory in Clayton, N.C., 17 miles southeast of Raleigh, but later surrendered to the authorities, Johnston County officials said.

title: A Brave Little Shop's New Cookie
description: Cookie Island, 189 Broadway (Cortland Street), was one of the first new stores to open downtown after the Sept. 11 attacks. At the time it sold only soft, warm homemade-style cookies. Now it has added a crisp cookie, an excellent preservative-free chocolate chip scented with cinnamon. The cookies are about $5 for a 7.4-ounce box at the store and are also sold at A. L. Bazzini in TriBeCa, at Garden of Eden and Citarella stores and at Morton Williams Associated Supermarkets. They can be ordered from (212) 608-5937 or www.cookieisland.com, two boxes for $15, four for $25 and six for $35, including shipping.

title: Rockport Harbor Has the Look of a Winner in His Stakes Debut
description: It did not take long for someone to give Rockport Harbor the nickname Smarty II. With the same trainer and the same jockey and two easy victories at Philadelphia Park that were reminiscent of Smarty Jones's early campaign, the comparisons were inevitable. That may be a lot to ask of a young horse who entered yesterday's Nashua Stakes at Aqueduct with only two lifetime victories over soft competition, but, so far, Rockport Harbor is having little trouble living up to the hype.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Buddhist Beheaded In Revenge
description: A Buddhist village leader was beheaded in southern Thailand and a note was left at the scene saying the killing was in retaliation for the deaths of scores of Muslims who suffocated in trucks or were shot to death by security forces during a demonstration last week. It was the second beheading of a Buddhist this year in the largely Muslim south of this mostly Buddhist nation. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Transcript of Wednesday's Speeches
description: Following are transcripts of speeches delivered on Wednesday after John Kerry conceded the presidential election to President George W. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDLER, HYMAN B., M.D.
description: HENDLER--Hyman B., M.D. 95, passed peacefully on November 1. Hy Hendler lived by these words excerpted from his favorite poem: "When you get what you want in your struggle for self And the world makes you king for a day, Just go to a mirror and look at yourself And see what that man has to say." A general surgeon for fifty years, practicing on the South Shore of Long Island, Dr. Hendler started a surgical group in Amityville as well as Hempstead, helped found Freeport and Brunswick General Hospitals and skillfully attended to countless patients. His arduous path to becoming a physician cultivated a profound empathy for patients and his family. Orphaned at 15, he graduated from Johns Hopkins and the University of Maryland Medical School despite many hardships. A determined self made man, he applied himself wholeheartedly to all aspects of life. His accomplishments and reputation as a physician were equally matched by his business acumen. Throughout his life many sought his council and few were disappointed by his honest, compassionate and forthright advice. Never one to boast about his own hard earned success, he was a modest man who loved making others laugh. He golfed and played gin as a member of Cold Spring Country Club, and Broken Sound. Hy put his family above all else and we are forever grateful for his profound contemplative generosity. He will be missed and fondly remembered by Ethel, his loving wife of sixty four years. His sons Fred and and Donald, daughters-in-law Nancy and Adrienne, five grandchildren, Ian and wife Debra, Noah and wife Nancy, Sarah, Kimberly and Clinton and three great grandchildren Natasha, Isaac and Julian will all carry on his legacy. Services will be held Friday, November 5th at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, Florida at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Boca Raton Hospital in honor of his caring physician Dr. Evan Goldstein.

title: An Indian Father Courage, Using and Losing Women
description: Sakharam Binder thinks he has the system by the tail. That system is the de facto enslavement of women in postcolonial India, despite the promises of democracy and modernity. Sakharam, a bookbinder, picks up other men's discarded women -- castoff wives who would otherwise be homeless, destitute or murdered with impunity -- and takes them in as domestic servants and sex partners.

title: WAL-MART TO OPEN AS MANY AS 15 STORES IN CHINA NEXT YEAR
description: Wal-Mart Stores plans to open as many as 15 new stores in China next year, competing for a foothold with Carrefour and Metro Group as the government lifts curbs on foreign retailers. Wal-Mart, which has 40 outlets in major cities like Beijing and Shenzhen, will focus on smaller provincial cities, said Joe Hatfield, chief executive for Asia. Wal-Mart was scheduled to open a store today in Guiyang in the southwestern province of Guizhou, Mr. Hatfield said. The company plans two stores for the northeastern city of Harbin this year and will add 12 to 15 nationwide next year, including one in Yuxi, in the southwestern province of Yunnan, he said. Wal-Mart has 35 Supercenter stores, 3 Sam's Club stores and 3 Neighborhood Market grocery stores in 20 Chinese cities.

title: CHUBB RECEIVES NOTICE FROM OHIO REGULATOR
description: The Chubb Corporation said yesterday that it had received an investigative demand from the Ohio attorney general, Jim Petro, as part of the state's investigation into possible antitrust violations. The company, based in Warren, N.J., said it received the demand on Monday, according to a regulatory filing. The company is an insurer of United States corporate executives and board members.

title: In Love Again With Chardonnay
description: EVERY field has its polarizing forces. Merely mentioning, say, a particular writer, a designer or even a car can set the best of friends at each other's throats. In wine, all you have to do is say, "California chardonnay," and lips are curled and lines are drawn.

title: When 'Fresh' Isn't a Selling Point
description: THERE are certain foods, like fugu and absinthe, whose notoriety far exceeds their culinary significance. Such is the case for the medlar, an unlikely candidate for the next food fashion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asbestos Cost Estimated
description: Insurers face as much as 10 billion ($18.3 billion) in British asbestos costs over 30 years as disease-related claims surge, a report by actuaries said. British asbestos claims may reach 200,000 by 2034, according to a study conducted by a committee of the Actuarial Profession, a professional organization.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday about the presidential campaign included an incorrect reference to the 2000 debates. Al Gore crossed the stage and approached George W. Bush in the third debate, not the first.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES DELAYS DEVELOPMENT OF MEDICINE
description: The drug maker Forest Laboratories said yesterday that it had delayed development of an experimental blood-pressure medicine because patients did not respond to the medicine as well as projected. The 60-patient two-month clinical trial of the medication, lercanidipine, was conducted in response to a 2002 Food and Drug Administration request for more data on the effectiveness of a proposed schedule of doses, Forest said. The company, based in New York, declined to provide detailed findings for the medicine, which is in the second of three phases of testing generally required for federal approval.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MULLANE, RICHARD
description: MULLANE--Richard. Its been 30 years and I have never stopped loving you, Terry. Tears still come to my eyes when I hear "Starry Starry Night". Now I am an old man "and just a breath away", Grant. Mass at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th St. on November 3 at 12:10 PM.

title: The Far Eastern Economic Review
description: For someone who grew up dreaming about swashbuckling journalists reporting from far-flung places, there was no greater model than The Far Eastern Economic Review, a weekly founded in Shanghai in 1946 and put out by a raffish staff of adventurers.

description: United States Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat from Brooklyn, won re-election to a second term yesterday by an enormous margin, outpolling the former top vote-getter in the state, the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, and fueling talk that he may soon become a candidate for governor.

description: Iraq Insurgents Blow Up An Oil Export Pipeline An Iraqi firefighter was among those fighting a blaze at an oil pipeline near the northern city of Kirkuk after insurgents blew up the line. The attack halted oil exports to a major port in Turkey and dealt a severe blow to Iraqi economic hopes. Other attacks around the country killed at least 12 Iraqis. PAGE A6

description: ZURICH, Nov. 2 - UBS, Europe's biggest bank, said Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell 1 percent as fees from managing finances for millionaires cushioned a drop in investment banking earnings.

title: Chief Plans to Leave Paramount Pictures
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 - Five months after assuming oversight of the movie division of Viacom Inc., Tom Freston, co-president and co-chief operating officer, is preparing major changes, including the replacement of the chairman of Paramount Pictures and the possible acquisition of an independent film company.

title: Solitary Pursuit by Bach Gets a Full Performance
description: There is important music from the past that we do not know quite where to put. Schubert's F-minor Fantasy for one piano and two pianists is perhaps happiest when listened to by its performers in an otherwise empty room or, at most, with a friend or two on hand to turn the pages. On a raised stage in a darkened hall with an audience, this great music does not work.

title: Northwest Airlines Loan Is Reworked
description: J.P. Morgan Chase, Deutsche Bank and Citigroup are restructuring a $975 million loan for the Northwest Airlines Corporation, a spokeswoman for the airline said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARANEVYCH, SANDY
description: SHARANEVYCH -- Sandy. Was a wonderful mother and beloved wife. An avid gardener, artist, dog lover and engaging hostess, Sandy died on October 31 at the age of 53. The cause was cancer. Sandy lived in Glen Ridge, NJ for 22 years. She helped fund and nurture GRAPA, co-chaired the Glen Ridge Arts Festival, was President of the South End Association and was active as a Sunday school teacher at the Glen Ridge Congregational Church. After graduation from Westminster College, Sandy moved to Manhattan to study art. She received her MFA from Hunter College and continued to work as an artist. Sandy is survived by her husband Oleh, daughter Amanda and her husband Joseph Zorumski, son Tyler and her parents Frank and Joyce Morgal of Hershey, PA. She will also be missed dearly by her friends and the family Wheaton Terriers Buddy and Lulu. There will be a Memorial Service on Friday, November 5 at 11 AM at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, NJ. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon.

title: A Different Sort of Mall for a California Town
description: RANCHO CUCAMONGA, Calif. - Visitors to Victoria Gardens, which its creator calls "a superregional lifestyle center," may have a sense of the uncanny. Within an area that encompasses 1.3 million square feet of retail and office space covering 12 blocks of this affluent suburb 50 miles east of downtown Los Angeles, they may feel as though they are in a city that has existed for decades. And yet it has actually been open only for less than a week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RONNER, IRVING H.
description: RONNER--Irving H. On November 1, 2004. Beloved husband of the late Gladys, devoted father of Madeleine Kaufman (Dr. Stephen Kaufman) and Dr. Hilary Ronner (Ronald Feiman), and revered "Poppa" of Justin, Craig, Kimberly, and Jed. Graveside service. Donations in his honor may be made to the Park Avenue Synagogue. Memories of his love and laughter persist.

title: AOL Is Said to Plan 700 Layoffs
description: America Online, the country's leading Internet service, is preparing to lay off as many as 700 of its 13,000 employees in the United States, according to an executive knowledgeable about its plans. AOL, a unit of Time Warner, is continuing to cope with a declining subscriber base and an advertising business that, while rebounding, trails industry leaders like Yahoo and Microsoft's MSN.

title: The Zombies Brought Him: George Romero Is Back
description: George A. Romero, grand master of the undead, was not pleased with the quality of fear showing on a pair of extras, costumed as security guards, in the face of an invading zombie army here last week. "These guys aren't acting like there's a war going on," Mr. Romero moaned, after directing perhaps the 10th take of what should have been a two-take shot. "Can we rehearse them, please?"

title: For the Mayor, a Quiet Day of Cookies and Ballots
description: The toughest decision faced by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the poll yesterday morning was not whom to support for president (he had already decided on President Bush), but which cookies to buy.

title: Jaguars' Leftwich Has a Left Knee Injury
description: Jacksonville quarterback Byron Leftwich, who once played a college game in such pain from a leg injury that his teammates had to carry him to the line of scrimmage after a play, may not have to miss a start after injuring his left knee during the Jaguars' 20-6 loss to the Houston Texans on Sunday.

title: President Seems Poised to Claim a New Mandate
description: From beginning to end, this election was about George W. Bush, and he can claim that an apparently insurmountable lead in the popular vote vindicated his policies, his persistence, his personal qualities and his political strategy. He bet that voters who had shared a traumatic terrorist attack and two wars on his watch would stand by him, and they appeared to.

description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 - President Bush spent an optimistic Tuesday evening watching election returns at the White House, but the cheer in the Bush camp turned into anger in the early hours of Wednesday when Senator John Kerry refused to concede the big prize of Ohio and the president found himself in limbo.
