title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Refiner Acquires Assets
description: The largest oil refiner in Asia, the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, agreed to buy chemical plants and gasoline stations from its parent company for 4.58 billion yuan ($554 million) in cash and assets. Sinopec, as the refiner is known, is buying the plants and 1,023 filling stations from the China Petrochemical Corporation. In turn, Sinopec, which is based in Beijing, will sell its oil field services business to China Petrochemical for 1.75 billion yuan. In addition to the gasoline stations, Sinopec will buy businesses making raw materials for plastic bottles and synthetic fibers, and chemicals to speed oil refining.

title: Anchors Make Call: Caution Carries the Day
description: On election night, news anchors repeated words like "caution," and "too close to call" with the neutrally pleasant expression parents don when telling their children some, but not all, of the facts of life. On CBS, where Dan Rather proudly told viewers that "I would rather be last than wrong," the most telling illustration on the electronic map was a big white splotch known as "insufficient data."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEN, ETHEL IHMING
description: CHEN--Ethel Ihming on October 30, 2004 at the age of 87. Born in China, the second daughter of the late Nationalist Chinese Ambassador, Chen Chieh. Educated in China and Europe, she accompanied her father on diplomatic missions in Germany, Mexico, Brazil and Argentina. Served as a French/Chinese translator at the United Nations in the 1940's. Joined E.F. Hutton in 1956 as a broker, followed by years at Hornblower Weeks - Hemphill, Noyes Shearson-Lehman and Prudential Bache. Retired in 1992. Survived by sister Hilda Chang, brother Chia-Dao Chen, son Robert Chang and grandchildren Spencer, Aubrey and Bobby and her beloved Bijon, Maurice. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 1076 Madison Ave (81st St) Thursday, November 4, at 1PM.

description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 2 - The Big East Conference said Tuesday that its officials made a bad call that cost Rutgers one last chance to beat West Virginia on Saturday.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israel Razes Bomber's Home
description: A day after a suicide bombing at an outdoor market in Tel Aviv killed 3 Israelis and wounding 32 others, Israeli soldiers kept a tight cordon around Nablus, the West Bank's largest city, and destroyed the family homes of the teenage bomber and of two Palestinian militants suspected of having dispatched him. Residents were not allowed out of the city unless they were in need of urgent medical care. Late on Monday, Israeli forces killed three militants in the city. The Palestinian bomber, 16-year-old Amr al-Far, above, was the latest of several teenage bombers to come out of Nablus in the past year. Some 10,000 Palestinians took part in the funerals, calling for revenge against Israel. Greg Myre (NYT)

description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska - AS Mary Ames dropped wedges of sweet potato into bubbling bear fat and readied strips of bear meat for the grill, she and her boyfriend, Ken Jouppi, gave me the back story on the beast before us.

description: Democrats captured at least two seats from Republicans in the New York State Senate yesterday and ran close in two other races, putting them nearly halfway toward their long-term goal of wresting control of that house after decades of Republican dominance.

title: The Flu Kills, but Documents Rarely List It as the Killer
description: The threat, not well understood outside the medical community, has been rendered with authoritative starkness since news broke of the flu vaccine shortage. Lives are at risk. Every year, we are told, influenza kills multitudes of vulnerable people, and the death toll is often repeated: 36,000 die annually in the United States alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, DR. RALPH
description: STEIN--Dr. Ralph. November 1, 2004, suddenly taken from us at age 77. Beloved husband of Lore. Devoted father of Janet and Jonathan Schultz, Vivian and Michael Dubin, and Lydia and Stuart Bernstein. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, David, Daniel, Marc, Lauren, Kari, Andrew, Mathew, and Simone. Stepfather of Drs. Minna and Steven Selub, Nancy and Mark Horton, and six grandchildren. Loving brother of Trude and Joe Pollack. Caring uncle of Dr. Ralph Rosenberg and Alan Rosenberg. Dr. Ralph Stein was predeceased by his devoted wife of 36 years, Simone. He was a compassionate pediatrician for over 40 years, a past-president of Queens Pediatric Society, a proud Veteran, and past-president of Congregation Habonim. He will be in our hearts forever. Services will be held on Wednesday, 1:00PM at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd., and 76 Road., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Police Arrest Two Men In Bar Stabbing
description: The police arrested two men yesterday in the killing of an Ecuadorian immigrant who was stabbed after an argument over a woman erupted in a violent frenzy early on Sunday, the authorities said. Two other men, including the dead man's brother, were critically injured in the fight, shortly before 2 a.m. at El Rodeo bar at 95-27 40th Road in Elmhurst. The dead man was identified as Patricio Guaman, 21. The police said that the men charged in the killing, Sergio Carrillo, 19, and Region Dominguez, 23, both of 34-12 Union Street, Flushing, were arrested about 4:30 a.m., after they made statements to detectives. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: MEDQUIST DOUBTS RELIABILITY OF '02 AND '03 RESULTS
description: MedQuist, a provider of transcription services for the medical industry, said its regulatory filings regarding 2002 and 2003 earnings were not reliable. The company, majority-owned by Royal Philips Electronics, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it cannot predict when its independent accountants will complete their 2003 audit. The previous filings "should no longer be relied upon," MedQuist said. A review of MedQuist's billing methods by Debevoise & Plimpton and PricewaterhouseCoopers found that the way MedQuist billed for services created ambiguities in how client accounts were calculated and led to incorrect billing. MedQuist is based in Mount Laurel, N.J.

Nearby, the leg's owner, Boubacar Traore, was hopping up and down two flights of concrete stairs, his arms outstretched as if he were walking a tightrope.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 24 about John McNamara, who wrote a history of the street names of the Bronx, referred incorrectly to the existence of other comparable histories and, in some copies, referred incompletely to the vice-presidential tenure of John C. Calhoun, for whom one street is named. Comparable histories indeed exist for at least one other borough, Manhattan, including "The Street Book: An Encyclopedia of Manhattan's Street Names and Their Origins," by Henry Moscow (Hagstrom, 1978), and "Naming New York: Manhattan's Places and How They Got Their Names," by Sanna Feirstein (New York University Press, 2001). Calhoun was vice president not only under John Quincy Adams but also under Andrew Jackson as well.

title: MCCORMICK PURCHASES DUTCH SPICE MAKER FOR $73 MILLION
description: McCormick & Company, the world's largest spice company, bought a Dutch spice maker C.M. van Sillevoldt for $73.7 million. The purchase will increase earnings by 1 cent, sales by $50 million in 2005 and profit by as much as 2 cents a share in 2006, McCormick said. The company bought the Zatarain's brand from Citigroup Venture Capital and other investors for $180 million last year. In 2000, McCormick bought Ducros, Europe's biggest maker of herbs and spices, from Eridania Beghin-Say for about 2.75 billion French francs ($379 million) in 2000. The Sillevoldt purchase gives McCormick the Silvo brand of seasonings in the Netherlands and the India brand in Belgium.

description: DUNCAN--John C. on October 29, 2004 at age 84. Beloved husband of the late Barbara Doyle Duncan. Father of Lynn Duncan, Craig Duncan, Gale Simmons and the late Wendy VanWinkle. Grandfather of Ed VanWinkle, Deirdra Singleton, Jennifer Grayson, Sarah Ashley Simmons, Julianna Simmons and the late Jouett Singleton. Great grandfather of Rocio Oyarzum and Barbara Lee Duncan. Brother of Bruce Duncan and the late Michael Duncan. Interment private. Memorial services at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave at 50 St, Friday November 5th, 1PM. description: A judge ruled yesterday that the former vice president of Adelphia Communications, Michael J. Rigas, must face a second trial on securities fraud charges. The first ended in a jury deadlock in July.

description: Republicans made significant gains in Senate races in the South yesterday, picking up seats in South Carolina, North Carolina, Georgia and Louisiana and beating back a strong challenge in Kentucky, which left them well-positioned to retain their majority control.

title: Pounding of Dolphins Puts Jets With the A.F.C.'s Elite Teams
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 2 - His team is once again shoulder to shoulder with the elite of the American Football Conference after Monday night's 41-14 rout of Miami. So Jets Coach Herman Edwards turned his attention Tuesday to something that is just as important as running at the front of the pack: staying there.

title: That Rare Gem, the Pistons Are a True Team
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Nov. 2 - A dazzling row of diamonds, including one to dot the i, spelled out Pistons, set in white gold in a band about the size of the face of a man's watch. It was the bling bling to end all rings. At the Palace, in the shadow of a landfill in suburban Detroit, the jewelry seemed to outshine the personality of its owners.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retail Sales Fall
description: Retail sales in Germany fell in September, amid concern about job losses and surging fuel costs, after rising the month before. Sales fell 0.4 percent in September from August, when they rose a revised 0.5 percent, the Federal Statistics Office said. Sales fell 1.4 percent from September 2003. Mail-order sales led the decline, falling 7.7 percent from September 2003. Sales of cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and home improvement goods rose from a year earlier, the report said.

title: Sentimental Time for Kerry and Election Day Tradition
description: BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 3 - It was eerily quiet here on Copley Square at 1 a.m. Wednesday. The drizzle that had dripped intermittently throughout the night had turned to a strong, steady rain. Scores of empty white folding chairs in the front section were dotted with droplets, a roll of blue Kerry-Edwards stickers on one a soggy mess. Umbrellas and Red Sox caps dotted the small, silent crowd that remained at what was supposed to be Senator John Kerry's victory party.

title: Kurds Enjoy a Calmer Corner of Iraq
description: ERBIL, Iraq - Truck drivers here say they are not worried about ambushes, shopkeepers report that security is not an issue and local residents shrug off questions about violence and kidnappings.

title: Technology Comes to a Village, but Complexity Is Old
description: "Still, the Children Are Here," a muddled documentary portrait of a small, isolated village in northeast India, has one laudable quality that is missing from most films with an ethnographic focus. The residents of Sadolpara, a village inhabited by the Garos, rice farmers of Tibetan-Burmese origin, emerge as careworn people who have the same psychological complexity as people everywhere.

title: Mourning Would Rather Be Elsewhere
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 2 - Alonzo Mourning knows he was not supposed to be back on the court so soon, certainly not in time for the Nets' season-opening game on Wednesday night. But Mourning worked harder than ever, dedicated himself to rehabilitation and came back less than 11 months after having a kidney transplant.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Plans High-Resolution Camera Phones
description: Nokia plans to introduce more than 20 handsets featuring cameras with at least one-megapixel resolution next year in a bid to regain lost market share. Sales of camera phones will exceed 200 million units this year, Anssi Vanjoki, who runs the Nokia unit that makes camera and game phones, said yesterday at an event in Monaco. Nokia previously forecast that camera phone sales would reach 200 million units. Nokia yesterday introduced the 3220 model, with a one-megapixel camera for higher-resolution pictures, the 6020 camera phone for business users and the 7710, a so-called smart phone, the company said.

description: JIMMY NORMAN has trouble remembering when he had his first heart attack. Nor can he recall exactly how many songs he has written, or how many times he visited the music publishers and record companies in Midtown and sold his songs -- and his publishing rights -- to pay the rent.

title: Arts, Briefly; Winners, on Field and Tube
description: Monday was a close night for the big three networks in total viewers. Though the rivalry between the Jets and the Dolphins has provided dramatic installments of "Monday Night Football" over the years, the 41-14 Jets victory, left, was not one of them. Despite the blowout, ABC edged out a victory in the ratings game for the night, with 13.67 million viewers tuning in to watch football, according to Nielsen's overnight numbers. The CBS lineup came in second over all, though it featured an evening of repeats. A repeat of the season premiere of "CSI: Miami" was the night's most-watched show, attracting an audience of 14.41 million at 10 p.m. But during that hour, NBC's special, "Saturday Night Live Presidential Bash 2004: The Great Debates," was No. 1 with the 18-to-49 set, bringing in 13.06 million viewers. NBC was also strong earlier in the night with "Fear Factor": A total of 12.15 million people watched the gross-out competition. KATE AURTHUR

title: Arts, Briefly; Potluck Postcards, Some From the Famous
description: How often does the chance arise to buy an original work by a famous artist for as little as $65? One such opportunity will be offered later this month by the Royal College of Art in London. Scattered in the exhibition and sale of 1,500 postcard-size works of art like the one at left in the popular annual RCA Secret event are contributions from the likes of last year's Turner Prize winner, Grayson Perry; the contemporary British artist Julian Opie; the film director Ken Loach; the fashion designer Hussein Chalayan; and the design guru Terence Conran. Buyers can purchase as many as five postcards, but the challenge will be to spot the works by the prominent artists -- 25 percent of the lot. The identity of a work's artist is revealed only after payment. The exhibition is open for viewing from Nov. 19 to 25, and the sale takes place on Nov. 26 and 27, but bargain hunters camp out for days in advance. PAM KENT

title: COURT RULING WILL GIVE GOODRICH A $145 MILLION GAIN
description: The Goodrich Corporation, a maker of aerospace components, said yesterday that a tax refund ruling by the United States Court of Federal Claims will probably result in a $145 million gain. The judgment orders the federal government to refund $82.8 million to Coltec Industries, a former Goodrich unit. Interest on those payments will be $30 million and a $32 million payment will be reversed, the company said. Goodrich bought Coltec in 1999 for $2.17 billion. It disbanded the unit by putting its landing gear, engine parts, fuel pump and gas turbine products into different segments of Goodrich and spinning off its industrial-products business in 2002 to create EnPro Industries. Goodrich, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., has not decided in which quarter the gain will be recorded, she said. The government has 90 days to appeal the ruling.

title: Arts, Briefly; Springtime in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has planned a varied spring season, with Laurie Anderson, dance from Canada, music theater with the Eos Orchestra, funk, spoken-word hip-hop and three British theater productions. The season's 13 engagements begin on Jan. 7 with "Winter Soul," a double bill of George Clinton's P-Funk All-Stars with the Brooklyn-based band TV on the Radio. Other musical presentations include Ms. Anderson's solo work "The End of the Moon"; the Eos Orchestra's "Three Classical Heroines," directed by Francesca Zambello, with music by Haydn, Berlioz and Britten; and "Songs of the Sufi Brotherhoods," an exploration of Islamic devotional music from the Middle East and North Africa, with Hamza El Din, Hassan Hakmoun and Rizwan-Muazzam Qawwali. The season also includes Theater Royal Bath's "As You Like It"; Matthew Bourne's "Play Without Words"; the Royal Shakespeare Company's "Hecuba," with Vanessa Redgrave, above; and a New York premiere by Mark Morris. Tickets go on sale on Nov. 15. BEN SISARIO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Death At Club
description: A Staten Island man was arrested Tuesday in the shooting death of Susan Boyce, 40, in a Bensonhurst after-hours club on Sunday morning, the police said yesterday. James Bonafede, 27, of Eltingville Boulevard, was charged with second-degree murder. Ms. Boyce, a receptionist at a car dealership, was in the club at 1739 West Seventh Street when her female friend got into an argument with Mr. Bonafede shortly before 7 a.m., and he pulled a gun and fired, inadvertently hitting Ms. Boyce, the police said. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sony BMG Merger Challenged
description: A group representing 2,500 independent record labels has challenged the European Union's approval of the merger that created Sony BMG. It filed an appeal with the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg. Sony BMG, which is based in New York, said the company was confident that the court would reaffirm the decision to clear the merger.

World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Narrows
description: Brazil's trade surplus narrowed to $3.01 billion in October from $3.17 billion in September as imports hit a record monthly level, the trade ministry said. Still, that brought the accumulated trade surplus so far this year to a record-breaking $28.12 billion, a 38 percent increase over the comparable period in 2003. Imports, which tend to peak at the end of the year, rose to a record $5.84 billion last month from $5.75 billion in September. Exports dropped to $8.84 billion from $8.9 billion. Economists expect Brazil, South America's largest economy, to finish the year with a trade surplus of almost $33 billion, up from $24.8 billion in 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Casino Contract Ratified
description: As the union had predicted, the members of Local 54 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify the casino industry's contract offer for better wages and health care benefits. In exchange, the union yielded on the industry's insistence on a five-year contract instead of the three-year agreement the union had sought. The final tally was 96 percent of about 6,000 votes cast, the union said. The strike, which began Oct. 1, was the longest in the city casino industry's history. The union also won limits on casinos' subcontracting of services to nonunion employers. Iver Peterson (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; Literary Laurels
description: An Irish author and an Israeli author, telling stories of their respective childhoods, were named winners yesterday of two of the most prestigious book awards in France. The Irish writer Hugo Hamilton picked up the Femina foreign prize for "The Speckled People," about his experience growing up in a family of Irish and German origin in Dublin in the 1950's. The Israeli writer Aharon Appelfeld won the Medicis foreign prize for "The Story of a Life," about his childhood during the Holocaust, and later in Israel. The Femina prize was awarded to Jean-Paul Dubois for his depiction of French society during the last 50 years in "Une Vie Franaise" ("A French Life"), while the Medicis prize went to Marie Nimier for her autobiography, "La Reine du Silence" ("The Queen of Silence"), which analyzes her relationship with her father, the novelist Roger Nimier. title: PENN NATIONAL WILL BUY A FELLOW CASINO OPERATOR
description: Penn National Gaming, a casino and racetrack owner, said that it had agreed to buy the Argosy Gaming Corporation for $1.4 billion. Penn will pay $47 for each share of Argosy, a 15 percent premium to its closing price yesterday. Penn will also assume $805 million in debt for a total transaction price of $2.2 billion, the companies said. The purchase will double Penn National's revenue to about $2 billion and give it casinos in markets including St. Louis, Cincinnati, and Joliet, Ill. Penn National is based in Wyomissing, Pa.; Argosy is based in Alton, Ill.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged With Faking Plot
description: A Pakistani man who was seeking political asylum was arrested yesterday on charges that he lied to F.B.I. agents, fabricating a story about a terrorist plot in an effort to ingratiate himself with the federal authorities. Tavneer Choudhry, 32, a gas station employee, told Special Agent Anthony Bivona on Oct. 1 about a plot to use two gasoline tanker trucks to blow up the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, but no such plot existed, according to a complaint and affidavit in support of an arrest warrant. Pending a hearing Friday, he was held without bail at his arraignment yesterday in federal court in Brooklyn. Mr. Choudhry, who lives in Sheepshead Bay, faces a maximum of five years in prison, said an assistant United States attorney. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Don Kennedy, Who Turned St. Peter's Team Into Contender, Dies at 97

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Riot Witness Recants Again
description: A prime witness in one of the main cases stemming from the Hindu-Muslim riots in Gujarat State in 2002 said that she had been pressured by rights activists and others to give false testimony against the Hindus accused of killing 14 Muslims at a bakery in the riots. The witness, Zakira Shiekh, was scheduled to testify today in the second trial stemming from her case. The Supreme Court ordered a retrial and moved it to Maharashtra State after Ms. Sheikh had earlier recanted her accusations, saying then that she was threatened by Hindu nationalists to do so. It is not clear how her apparent change of heart will affect the trial, because three other witnesses have identified some of the accused. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: IAC Says Earnings Rose Fourfold
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the Internet and television-commerce company controlled by Barry Diller, said yesterday that third-quarter profit jumped fourfold on increased Web sales of travel reservations. Net income increased to $89.5 million, or 12 cents a share, from $18.7 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier, the New York-based company said. Revenue declined 6.5 percent, to $1.51 billion, as IAC changed how it accounts for sales at Hotels.com, booking reservation fees rather than the full price of a room. IAC shares rose $3.01, to $25.01. Excluding amortization expenses and some other costs, profit rose to 24 cents a share from 17 cents a year earlier, the company said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brewer's Profit Falls
description: Companhia de Bebidas das Amricas, the Brazilian brewer, said profit fell sharply in the third quarter as increased spending and costs overshadowed strong revenue growth. AmBev, as the brewer is known, had net profit of 131.7 million reais ($46.2 million), down 61 percent from a profit of 340.4 million reais a year earlier. Revenue rose 46 percent, to 2.95 billion reais. AmBev, which is based in So Paulo, booked 332.7 million reais in operational costs in the quarter, mostly from expenses related to its foreign units. AmBev, whose acquisition by Interbrew of Belgium was completed in August, also spent more on promoting its brands at home, increasing sales 17 percent. AmBev finished the quarter with 67 percent of the beer market in Brazil. Todd Benson (NYT)

The new $10 million station at 303 Beach 49th Street will serve the Arverne, Far Rockaway and Rockaway Beach neighborhoods. It includes indoor and outdoor parking for ambulances and fire vehicles, offices, a kitchen, a gym and a supply room for life support equipment. Mayor Bloomberg said the structure "will greatly improve the working environment for our emergency workers and better serve the surrounding community." Winnie Hu (NYT)

McKenna of Federal District Court in Manhattan reaffirmed and extended a temporary injunction issued in January 2002, after the police rousted homeless people from the staircases on three nights before Christmas. The country remains, of course, divided. It is the point of a national election to illuminate divisions -- these days in stark blue and red. The 49 percent of the voting public who wanted a different outcome are disappointed, and in some cases crushed and frightened about the future of the country. Their first job is to accept the will of the majority. Then it will be time for everyone -- Mr. Bush, the victorious Republicans and the people who opposed them -- to decide what to do next.

Detectives are investigating assertions by gay-rights groups that lyrics by reggae artists including Bounty Killer, Buju Banton, Elephant Man and the Grammy Award-winner Beenie Man incite violence against homosexuals. title: WYETH FOUND LIABLE FOR $2.1 MILLION IN DIET DRUG CASE
description: Wyeth said yesterday that a jury in Philadelphia had found it liable for $2.1 million awarded to four Utah women who said they suffered heart damage from the fen-phen diet treatment. The state court jury found in the second phase of the trial that Wyeth was liable for failing to warn doctors adequately about the risks of heart-valve disease from the fen-phen drug that contained Pondimin, a Wyeth drug. Wyeth of Madison, N.J., said it was considering an appeal. The case was the ninth in Philadelphia since July in which a jury considered heart-valve claims stemming from use of the diet drug, which has been withdrawn from the market. Wyeth, which has set aside $16.6 billion so far to resolve diet drug suits, also said that it had settled a similar case in Los Angeles for $70,000.

title: Arts, Briefly; Saving Shostakovich
description: Dozens of recordings of works by Dmitri Shostakovich, above right, part of an archive of thousands of artifacts and materials stored in an apartment in Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, may end up on the street, according to the son of Roman Matsov, a conductor who worked closely with Shostakovich. "My father performed Shostakovich more than any conductor in the world," said the son, Mark Matsov, a writer who lives in Moscow. "He knew the real content of all of Shostakovich's works. This is a mystery not known to all." Debate continues among scholars as to whether the composer was a servant of the Soviet state or a dissident. Mr. Matsov said that the recordings needed to be restored and digitized and that he would like the archive to find a home abroad. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

Dennis Bingham had resigned as a director for personal reasons, that Barry M. Monheit was elected chairman and that Jeffrey D. Buchanan was appointed to the board. Smith & Wesson, which is based in Springfield, Mass., did not say why Mr. Cuny left the company.

title: Annan Urges Security Council to Act on Growing Violence in Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 3 - Secretary General Kofi Annan urged the Security Council on Wednesday to take swift action in the Darfur region of Sudan, where he said violence was on the rise, the number of refugees was growing and the government was making little progress in disarming fighters responsible for the mayhem and intimidation that have displaced about 1.6 million people and resulted in more than 50,000 deaths.

BAE said the company believed that it was not the target of the investigation and might be the victim of fraud itself. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES FACES REGULATORY SUPERVISION
description: Huntington Bancshares said yesterday that it expected to be placed under supervision by federal bank regulators amid a Securities and Exchange Commission accounting inquiry involving auto leases. Huntington, a regional banking company based in Columbus, Ohio, said it was negotiating an agreement with the S.E.C. and expected to pay a civil penalty. The bank restated 2002 profit to account for $3.2 billion in auto leases as loans rather than as automobiles it owned and rented out. Supervisory agreements with the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency will address corporate governance, financial reporting, and accounting policies and controls, the company said. Huntington said that its acquisition of the Unizan Financial Corporation would be delayed as a result of the federal oversight.

Mr. Bodner graduated from Wesleyan University and received a graduate degree from New York University, with additional graduate education at the University of Chicago and Harvard University. He retired from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as Vice President with supervisory responsibility for the Foreign Function, and subsequently became a senior officer of the Chemical Bank. Mr. Bodner ended his career as Chairman of the Board of Julius Baer Securities Inc. and Executive Vice President for North America of the Julius Baer Group. He was a former chairman of the European Warrant Fund, former chairman of the Institute for International Bankers, former member of the executive committee of the American Swiss Foundation, and a published author on foreign exchange and international monetary issues.

title: Arts, Briefly; Roger Rees to Williamstown
description: The Williamstown Theater Festival, which brings some of the best theatrical talent in the United States to its Massachusetts headquarters every summer, has chosen its new artistic director. He is Roger Rees, right, the Welsh actor and director who is probably best known to many audiences for his recurring turn as Robin Colcord, the snooty British millionaire on the series "Cheers." Mr. Rees, 60, started his career with the Royal Shakespeare Festival and won a Tony Award on Broadway in 1982 as the title character in "The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby." His association with Williamstown as a director dates to 1997, when he directed Jon Robin Baitz's "Film Society." Mr. Rees said yesterday that he had no set plans for the festival but felt a "responsibility to both sides of the curtain," meaning artists and audiences. "I've been taught by some great people," Mr. Rees said. "It's great to have an opportunity to pass that on." Mr. Rees, who takes over on Jan. 1, succeeds Michael Ritchie, who is leaving to become the artistic director of the Center Theater Group in Los Angeles. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Red and Blue, the Divided Electorate, in All Its Shades

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, CHARLES JEFFER SON, SR.
description: MURPHY -- Charles Jeffer son, Sr. Retired Vice President with Lebenthal & Co., dead at 81. Charles J. Murphy, a resident of Pelham Manor, N.Y. for over 50 years, died of heart failure on November 3, 2004 at Sound Shore Hospital, New Rochelle, N.Y. Born in Baltimore, MD in 1923 to Louis and Ella Murphy, he graduated at the head of his class from Baltimore Polytech Institute and graduated from Johns Hopkins University with a degree in Electrical Engineering. During WWII, he was trained at Bowdoin, MIT and Harvard in radar and served as an Ensign in the Navy. In 1944, he married Mada Jane Gail and this December they would have celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary. Charlie was the youngest Traffic Commissioner in the history of Baltimore. After receiving a Fellowship at Yale University, he began a career at the Auto Club of New York (AAA) where he went from Traffic Engineer to Treasurer and eventually President. Shortly after leaving AAA, Charlie began a new career selling tax free municipal bonds for Lebenthal & Co. and retired after 12 years as a Vice President. An avid fisherman, he was a member of the Huguenot Yacht Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. and New York Athletic Club as well as the Yale Club. He adored his wife Mada, and their family. A quiet and private man, he spent hours tending his roses and tomatoes. Aside from his wife Mada, he is survived by his sister Jean Funk of Baltimore, his son Charles, Jr. and his wife Jinny, his son Patrick and wife Maryjo, his daughter Gail Marie Clemens, ten grandchildren, one great grandson and numerous nieces and nephews in Baltimore. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, N.Y. Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, Friday, November 5th, 11AM. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: The 21st Century, Showing Off the 20th

The design of the new store, however, is all 21st century. The components were made with the help of a computer-controlled machine that translated the designs of its architect, William E. Massie, into laser-cut parts, like the 3,000 pieces of steel and acrylic that make up the airy staircase, top. The store's midcentury wares represent "a snapshot of the technology of their moment," Mr. Massie said, and 50 years later "that's what we're trying to do" with the store. Mondo Cane is at 174 Duane Street (Hudson Street); (212) 219-9244.

It will open Nov. 18 at the center, in a polycarbonate theater designed for the production by Michael Meredith, an assistant professor of architecture at Harvard. The officer and his partner, both in plainclothes, chased the teenager, whose name was not released because he is a minor, after seeing him grab a cellular phone from a woman standing on the street in Fort Greene. During a struggle to arrest the suspect, an officer's gun accidentally fired, the police said. The teenager, who was arrested on charges of grand larceny, received 10 stitches at Kings County Hospital Center. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: A Russian Couple, Reunited in Texas. Is It Time for Songs?
description: "The Immigrant," Mark Harelik's based-on-fact play about his grandfather's relocation to the United States, started life as a comedy-drama and was produced frequently in the 1980's and 90's. More recently, perhaps seeking two bites of the apple, Mr. Harelik and some collaborators have turned it into a musical. The songs, though, only occasionally enhance the underlying play; the rest of the time they underscore the thinness of the original tale.

description: ROME, Nov. 4 - Iraq's interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi, appealed Thursday to what he called the "spectator" countries in the war in Iraq -- specifically France and Germany -- to become more involved in creating peace and prosperity there.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: 12 Injured As Turbulence Shakes Plane
description: Twelve people aboard an American Airlines flight from Miami to New York last night were injured when the plane encountered turbulence, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said. Flight 952 had begun its descent and was flying at 22,000 to 23,000 feet, about 50 miles southwest of Kennedy International Airport, when it was shaken shortly after 8 p.m., Jim Peters, the spokesman, said. The plane, an Airbus 300, landed at 8:17 p.m. without further incident. Four passengers and two flight attendants with minor injuries were treated at the gate, and three passengers and three attendants were treated at nearby hospitals for injuries that included a dislocated shoulder and facial lacerations. Mr. Peters said an investigation of the turbulence was continuing. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Movement and Music, Both Jazz and Both Live
description: Just as jazz music comes in many sonic varieties, so jazz dancing can assume many shapes in space. That became clear on Wednesday night in "Jazz in Motion," a Jazz at Lincoln Center presentation with works by four choreographers, three of them offering premieres.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: New Report On Death Of Suspect
description: Three Cincinnati police officers should not be punished for restraining a man who suffered a fatal heart attack last November after they tackled and handcuffed him, City Manager Valerie Lemmie said in a report. Ms. Lemmie's ruling contrasts with a citizens' review panel that found the officers had used excessive force against the man, Nathaniel Jones, 41, left, and should be disciplined. An autopsy found cocaine and the drug PCP in Mr. Jones's blood and concluded that Mr. Jones, who weighed nearly 350 pounds, had an enlarged heart and high blood pressure, which contributed to his death. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: A Graduate of Law School and the Burrito Cart
description: SEAN BASINSKI moves quietly about, making the morning coffee in the communal office of the Street Vendor Project in Lower Manhattan. It is not easy to reconcile the many lives of this gentle-mannered 32-year-old with a shaved head, who is wearing scruffy Birkenstocks and jeans. He used to sell burritos from a vending cart in Midtown. He has a law degree from Georgetown University. And before that? He was a junk bond analyst on Wall Street, a preppy young Republican who wanted to make loads of money.

title: A Modern-Day Charmer Who Lives for the Chase
description: It's the year of the monkey in the Chinese calendar and the year of the hound in Hollywood. In films as radically different as "Sideways," "Ray" and now "Alfie," men are sniffing skirts with a single-mindedness that brings to mind Warren Beatty cruising through "Shampoo," a blow-dryer tucked in his jeans. Filled with womanizers who at once love too much and not quite enough, these films don't really resurrect the hound and, in truth, he never went away. They simply ask you to look deep in those puppy eyes and see the all-too-human man beneath, quivering with heartfelt need, not just animal impulse.

title: VORNADO-CRESCENT VENTURE BUYS AMERICOLD LOGISTICS
description: Vornado Realty Trust, which owns offices buildings and shopping centers in the Northeast, and the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, which owns office buildings and resorts in the Southwest, said yesterday that their joint venture, AmeriCold Realty Trust, had purchased AmeriCold Logistics for $47.7 million. The companies also said that they agreed to sell 20.7 percent of the shares in AmeriCold for $145 million to the Yucaipa Companies, a private equity firm based in Los Angeles. The sale of the stake in AmeriCold, which provides refrigerated warehousing, would result in about $20 million for Vornado, the sellers said. AmeriCold Realty Trust is based in New York. Crescent is in Fort Worth.

While leaving the benchmark rate at 2 percent, the bank's president, Jean-Claude Trichet, left, said inflation was a "worrisome development." He expressed only mild concern about the economic effects of the euro, which is trading near a record high against the dollar. Most analysts do not expect a rate increase until well into next year. title: Arts, Briefly; Honors in Jazz
description: Six musicians and a concert producer were named the 2005 National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters yesterday. They are the newest winners of an award that has existed since 1982 and was expanded last year, when Dana Gioia, the chairman of the endowment, increased the number of winners and added a touring and performance element to the awards. The musicians are the guitarist Kenny Burrell, the clarinetist and saxophonist Paquito D'Rivera, the arranger and composer Slide Hampton, the vocalist Shirley Horn, the big-band leader Artie Shaw, above right, and the organist Jimmy Smith. The seventh honoree is George Wein, president of Festival Productions Inc., which produces the international JVC Jazz Festivals, among many other live jazz events. Each winner is to receive a $25,000 fellowship at a ceremony and concert in Long Beach, Calif., on Jan. 7. BEN RATLIFF

title: Warplane Strafes a School in New Jersey
description: It sounded like somebody running across the roof of the elementary school in a New Jersey township Wednesday night, said the cleaning woman who called the police. No prowler was found. But yesterday, what had seemed a minor item in a police blotter touched off state and federal military investigations after it was disclosed that an F-16 warplane had strafed the school with cannon fire.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Atari Loss Narrows On Higher Game Sales
description: Atari said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed to $16.9 million as sales of games rose. The net loss declined to 14 cents a share in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, from $28.7 million, or 90 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 18 percent, to $71.4 million from $60.6 million. The per-share figure for the September 2003 period reflects a $39.4 million dividend payment. Shares of Atari rose 7 cents, to $1.80.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Court Backs President
description: The High Court ruled that a recount of the disputed presidential election last March had confirmed that President Chen Shui-bian won re-election. The court dismissed a Nationalist Party lawsuit contending that the election results should be overturned because of questions about a shooting incident in which the president was injured on the eve of the election -- an incident that may have elicited sympathy votes for him. Lien Chan, the defeated Nationalist candidate, vowed an appeal. Another Nationalist lawsuit, citing voting irregularities, is still pending. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Transit Agency Softens Its Plan to Increase Subway Fares
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority scaled back its dismal forecast for subway and bus riders yesterday, saying that while fare increases and service cuts were still necessary, they need not be as drastic as the agency had feared. The price of a 30-day MetroCard will rise to no more than $76 starting next year, the authority said in a proposal made yesterday.

title: MONICA SALMASO
description: In Brazil, as in the rest of the world, current pop is coming to terms with the jolts, the swagger and the aggressive present tense of hip-hop. Monica Salmaso, however, has other ideas. Her luminous voice, tinged with melancholy and calm sensuality, is made for quieter moments. On her albums, including her new one, "Iai" (World Village), Ms. Salmaso reaches into the boundless resources of Brazil's musical past. She rediscovers old songs and finds new ones in old styles: bossa novas, old sambas, ballads. Yet she treats them not as purist remakes, but as modern close-ups. Her voice hovers amid a handful of instruments, with flickers of percussion to hint at regional rhythms from across Brazil or woodwinds to recall old dance bands. She sings about a Brazil full of lovers and history, ancient deities and modern rascals, and the songs become intimate and indelible, turning cultural memories into private reveries. (Tonight at 9:30, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200; tickets are $20.) JON PARELES

title: Medicare Covers New Treatments With a Catch
description: For the first time in its history, Medicare has systematically begun to make payments for new and expensive treatments and diagnostic tests conditional on agreement by companies or other groups to pay for studies on whether these new methods actually work on the Medicare patients who get them.

title: Arts, Briefly; Producer Sues Paramount
description: The movie producer Martin Ransohoff ("Jagged Edge") has sued the Paramount Pictures Corporation for breach of contract. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, says that his production company struck an oral agreement with Sherry Lansing, the chairwoman of Paramount, in early 2003 to produce "The Long Ride" and that Ms. Lansing unreasonably stalled until her husband, William Friedkin ("Rules of Engagement") could become available to direct it. The suit asserts that Paramount now says it is not going to produce the film but nevertheless has refused Mr. Ransohoff permission to take the project elsewhere. Nancy Kirkpatrick, a spokeswoman for Paramount, called the suit "frivolous" and "without merit." She added, "At no time was Mr. Friedkin ever attached to the project." CATHERINE BILLEY

description: "Let me put it to you this way: I earned capital in the campaign, political capital, and now I intend to spend it."

title: On the Trail of Itinerant Teachers Who Strove to Escape the Ego
description: KATONAH, N.Y. - Miss Chasin is the high school English teacher I remember best. She was young and, I could tell, a little nervous about her new job. But she had a gift for saying difficult things in an easy way, for talking about literature as if she were talking about life, which in turn made life sound like art. I later learned she was a poet, though she had never said so.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Court To Weigh Bear Hunt
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court is scheduled to hear arguments on Tuesday in a lawsuit filed by a coalition of hunting groups seeking to hold a black bear hunt next month, despite the refusal of the State Department of Environmental Protection to issue permits. The state's Fish and Game Council approved the issuance of the permits in July, and about 3,200 applications have been received. But Bradley M. Campbell, the state environmental commissioner, has refused to honor them, and last week he closed land under his jurisdiction to a hunt. A department spokeswoman declined to comment on the suit, but said the state was using a public awareness campaign and contraception to curb the bear population. John Holl (NYT)

title: To Play Late, Play Well, Wilkens Tells Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 4 - If you excel early, you will get a chance to excel late. That was the message Coach Lenny Wilkens wanted to impart to his Knicks, young and old, about what will happen when the fourth quarter arrives.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Chvez Allies Take 21 Of 23 States
description: Election authorities said that the governor of Carabobo, a state that has been a bastion for anti-government forces, had lost his seat to a pro-government challenger in the regional elections on Sunday, cementing President Hugo Chvez's political dominance of the country. The victory by Luis Acosta, a former general, in the tight race against the incumbent, Henrique Salas, means that Mr. Chvez's allies swept nearly all the opposition candidates from important offices. Anti-government governors in six of eight states controlled by the opposition were voted out, leaving pro-Chvez allies in charge of 21 of Venezuela's 23 states. A pro-government mayor also took control of Caracas, which had been in opposition hands. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: British and French Leaders Differ on Impact of Bush Victory for Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 5 - As Europe's leaders came together for the first time since the American elections, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain urged them to adjust to the "reality" that George W. Bush would be in office for four more years and to put past disputes behind them in order to work on urgent challenges in Iraq and elsewhere.

title: Two Teenagers Die in L.I. Car Crash; Driver Is Charged
description: A late-night car ride by four 18-year-old Long Island women ended in the death of two passengers early yesterday when the driver, who the police said was intoxicated and lost in the dizzying highway interchanges of the island's South Shore, collided with a sport utility vehicle, the authorities said.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Move To Import Flu Vaccine
description: The state has joined an effort in Illinois to import flu vaccine from overseas. Gov. Bill Richardson said he planned to purchase 150,000 doses that had been found through European wholesalers. American Airlines offered to ship the vaccine, which was manufactured in France by Aventis Pasteur, from Europe to the two states at no charge. Illinois has purchased 300,000 doses of flu vaccine from European wholesalers in the last 10 days and is waiting for approval from the Food and Drug Administration to import them. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Invasive Breast Cancer Is Diagnosed in Elizabeth Edwards
description: BOSTON, Nov. 4 - Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of John Edwards, the former Democratic vice-presidential candidate, received a diagnosis of breast cancer on the day his running mate, Senator John Kerry, conceded the election, a spokesman announced Thursday.

title: U.S. Awards a Contract for Anthrax Vaccine
description: VaxGen, which shifted its focus to bioterrorism treatments after failures in H.I.V. research, has won an $877 million contract to supply the United States government with anthrax vaccine.

title: Why We Lost
description: Washington - On Wednesday morning, Democrats across the country awoke to a situation they have not experienced since before the New Deal: We are now, without a doubt, America's minority party. We do not have the presidency. We are outnumbered in the Senate, the House, governorships and legislatures. And the conservative majority on the Supreme Court seems likely to be locked in place for a generation. It is clearly a moment that calls for serious reflection.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 4 - In the floodlit gardens of the presidential palace, President Hamid Karzai promised Thursday in his first speech since he was declared the official winner of the election on Oct. 9 to bring security and stability to his people.

description: GRAND FORKS, N.D. - When the Red River rose and flowed across the flat land seven years ago, people fled and viewed the flood damage on television from miles away. They saw rooftops surrounded by rising water and downtown buildings burning. "Come hell or high water," said the headline. Who knew what would replace the devastation?

title: Arts, Briefly; Two Views of Strindberg
description: The first collaboration between two bastions of the arts on the South Bank in London was announced yesterday. A rare exhibition of the art of the Swedish polymath August Strindberg (1849-1912) will be staged in February at Tate Modern, where "Stormy Sea," below, will be on view. At the same time the National Theater will stage his "Dream Play" in a new version written by Caryl Churchill and directed by Katie Mitchell. Nicholas Hytner, artistic director of the National Theater said, "It is great to be able to coordinate our program to illuminate each other's work and to bring to each other's institution an audience that it might not otherwise have." Strindberg's art, less well known than his plays, has been compared to that of J.M.W. Turner and to artistic movements like Expressionism. The exhibition, from Feb. 17 to May 15, will include more than 60 paintings. Previews for "A Dream Play" begin on Feb. 4. PAM KENT

description: Sales at retailers rose 4 percent in October, signaling sustained growth in the face of record energy prices, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index released yesterday.

title: An Oligarch Goes Home to Lift Georgia's Economy
description: TBILISI, Georgia - Kakha Bendukidze, the new Georgian economy minister, points out his window in downtown Tbilisi to the shabby refugee hotel framed by a setting sun. "See that large building with the boarded-up windows?" he says. "It's going to be either a Four Seasons hotel, or maybe commercial office space."

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Black Investors Get Bank Stake
description: The South African banking company FirstRand agreed to sell a 10 percent stake to a group of black investors, including Kagiso Trust Investments and the company's staff, for 6.8 billion rand ($1.1 billion), the company said. Kagiso, an investment holding company, and the Mineworkers Investment Trust will hold 6.5 percent of the lender after the transaction, FirstRand said. First-Rand's black South African employees and nonexecutive directors will own 3.5 percent, the company said. South Africa's financial services companies agreed last year to sell a quarter of their businesses, including 10 percent direct equity stakes, to blacks to make up for discrimination during the apartheid era.

title: Ace Dismisses 2 Executives in Response to Inquiry
description: Ace Ltd., a big Bermuda insurer that is a subject of the New York attorney general's investigation into bid-rigging and price-fixing in the insurance industry, dismissed two executives yesterday, including the head of one of its main units.

title: Suicide Bomb in Iraq Kills Three Soldiers From Britain
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 4 - Three British soldiers whose regiment had recently moved northward to support an expected American-led assault on Falluja were killed in a suicide bombing on Thursday, British officials said. Meanwhile, the medical relief agency Doctors Without Borders announced it was ending its operations in Iraq because of deteriorating security.

Part of that coalition wants to tear down the legacy of Franklin Roosevelt, eviscerating Social Security and, eventually, Medicare. Another part wants to break down the barriers between church and state. And thanks to a heavy turnout by evangelical Christians, Mr. Bush has four more years to advance that radical agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLAUBER, GEORGE
description: KLAUBER--George, 81. Sailed away on September 14, 2004. Distinguished graphic designer and lover of life, art, and design. Beloved by his family, fellow faculty, legions of friends and students around the world. We are in deep sorrow of the final journey of this exuberant traveller. He will never be forgotten by anyone who knew him. Services are private. Contributions in his name may be made to The Vieques Nature Conservancy, Puerto Rico. Dear George, farewell, adieu, adios, gutenachte.

title: Search-Engine Serendipity and Frequent-Flier Miles

What might be most impressive about this often-exasperated Englishman is that he has turned the most mundane and common activity -- wasting time on the Internet -- into an art form.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOBB, ANNEMARIE R., NEE HILPERT
description: LOBB--Annemarie R., nee Hilpert, born in Berlin, Germany, in 1917, passed away peacefully after a brief illness in Greenville, NY on Monday, October 25, 2004. She was the daughter of the late Adolf Hilpert and Karolina Walther Hilpert of Berlin, and was preceded in death by brothers Adolf and Karl. Mrs. Lobb was married to the late Col. Anthony W. Lobb, with whom she served in the Peace Corps in El Salvador in the 1970s. She composed crossword puzzles for The Times in the 1960s and 70s. She is survived by her brother Hermann Hilpert, 99, of Mainz, Germany, and by three sons, Jens Gunther Lobb of Greenville, NY, Wayne A. Lobb of Sudbury, MA, and William A. Lobb II of Atlanta, GA.

title: Birds and Gregorian Chants Conjured Up by Organ Pipes

He also performed a handful of Bach works, some Mozart and a suite of French scores rooted in the sound of birdcalls.

title: Arts, Briefly; Flamenco Star Charged
description: A city prosecutor in Seville, Spain, has formally indicted the flamenco star Farruquito on charges of vehicular homicide in the hit-and-run crash that killed a man in September 2003. The dancer, whose real name is Juan Manuel Fernndez Montoya, could face as much as four years in jail. He was also charged with failing to come to the aid of his victim and with making a false crime report, said the prosecutor, Norberto Sotomayor, who issued the indictment on Wednesday. Farruquito, above, falsely testified that his younger brother, a minor, had caused the accident, Mr. Sotomayor said in a telephone interview. Farruquito has made no public comments since the indictment. After posting bail of more than $128,000, he may perform outside the country, but he must check in with the authorities regularly, Mr. Sotomayor said. The case will probably come to trial around February or March, he added. DALE FUCHS

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Profit Rises At Alcan
description: The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan said that third-quarter profit almost doubled as the company shipped more of the metal at higher prices. Net income jumped to $167 million, or 45 cents a share, from $87 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 77 percent, to $6.24 billion, helped by the purchase in February of Pechiney of France, Alcan said. Alcan benefited from a 21 percent increase in the average price of aluminum in the quarter, led by demand from China and global economic growth. Shipments of aluminum climbed 32 percent.

description: WASHINGTON - SINCE his death in 1681, at age 64, the work of the Dutch painter Gerard ter Borch has been consistently admired by artists, historians, dealers and collectors of the old masters, as well as by forgers. But he has been noticed only intermittently by nearly everyone else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIFFIN, KENNETH G.
description: GRIFFIN -- Kenneth G., a prominent business attorney and commercial litigator in Los Angeles for more than 35 years who developed a reputation as an expert on Japan, has died. He was 64. Griffin worked primarily for international clients, mostly in Japan. He spent years achieving fluency in Japanese, both spoken and written. He was a frequent visitor to the island nation. His keen interest in Japanese culture led him in the early '80s to author a series of practical books aimed at Japanese businessmen. Griffin studied at Duke University in North Carolina, and received both his undergraduate and law degrees from Stanford University. He graduated from the law school in 1964. He married Shirley Yap in 1969. He is survived by his wife, Shirley O. Yap Griffin; his sons, Glenn Thomas Griffin and Winston Churchill Griffin; his mother, Evelyn Griffin; his sister, Priscilla Shacklett, and his brother, George Griffin.

title: Experiencing the Divisions of Identity, All in One Man's Uncompromised Life
description: Caught between two worlds and two seemingly warring identities, the lead character in Rodney Evans's heartfelt film "Brother to Brother" wears the weary and worried look of a man divided. Young, gay, black and beautiful, Perry (Anthony Mackie) studies at Columbia University, works at a homeless shelter and aspires to something he cannot quite articulate. A part-time painter and full-time seeker, he pours his thoughts into a diary and into the ear of his one true friend, Marcus (Larry Gilliard Jr.), a sympathetic straight man whose one failing seems to be that he can't give Perry either the love or answers he so intensely desires.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Disgraced Atomic Expert Is Said To Be Ill
description: The health of Abdul Qadeer Khan, left, the disgraced former head of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, may be deteriorating, according to a petition filed with the Supreme Court. Hassamul Haq, the brother of a former aide, has asked for a medical board to be formed to look into the health of Dr. Khan, who is 68 and under house arrest in Islamabad. In February Dr. Khan, revered in Pakistan as the father of the country's nuclear bomb, confessed to running the largest nuclear proliferation network in history. American officials believe he ran a smuggling network that spanned decades and involved Iran, North Korea, Libya and nations still not identified. Salman Masood (NYT)

"Find-out-what-it-means-to-me!" sang Alice Tan Ridley in a tattoo of insistence that cut through the city's screech and hurry. Some passers-by stopped in their tracks and ripped off headsets that were playing their own private songs and reveries.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Warlords Walk Free For Demobilization
description: Arrest orders for three top paramilitary commanders, leaders of the right-wing United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, an organization responsible for cocaine trafficking and mass murder, have been lifted until Dec. 15 so they can travel the country to coordinate the disarmament of 3,000 fighters as part of negotiations with President lvaro Uribe's government. The plan is to demobilize the fighters by the end of the year, the first major step toward the eventual disarmament of 15,000. The safe-conduct passes were given to Salvatore Mancuso, who has been convicted in absentia for murder and is wanted in the United States for cocaine trafficking, and two other leaders, Ivn Roberto Duque and Ever Veloza, who is known as Hernan Hernandez. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: S.E.C. TO SUE ATLAS AIR OVER RESTATEMENT OF PROFITS
description: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings, a freight airline, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission intended to bring a civil lawsuit for possible violations linked to earnings restatements. Atlas said that it had received a Wells notice, stating that the agency's staff was proposing the action, which would not occur until Atlas responds. The company said that it was in talks to resolve the issue. The S.E.C. inquiry began in 2002 after Atlas said it would restate 2000 and 2001 earnings. Atlas, based in Purchase, N.Y., has said the results were restated because of errors in accounting for inventory, bad debts and maintenance. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January and emerged in July. Atlas is the parent of Atlas Air and Polar Air Cargo.

title: CYNTHIA DARLOW
description: John Cullum expertly plays the title role in "Sin (A Cardinal Deposed)," but the burden of providing this disquieting play with a persistent human heartbeat falls to his co-stars. Mr. Cullum plays Cardinal Bernard F. Law, and the centerpiece of Michael Murphy's play is a re-enactment of a deposition given by the cardinal in the course of a lawsuit brought against the archdiocese of Boston by victims of sexual abuse by its priests. Mr. Cullum's cardinal never lets slip his tight grip on his emotions, measuring out carefully considered responses to a lawyer's aggressive questions. Providing telling -- and touching -- contrast to the cardinal's cool are Cynthia Darlow and Dan Daily, the actors who portray numerous witnesses and relatives of victims. Ms. Darlow, in particular, brings admirable depth of feeling, as well as terrific variety, to her performance. The texts she is given are letters sent to the cardinal and his associates by relatives of victims. But the performance could never be mistaken for a dry reading. It is infused with palpable emotion, from feisty outrage to anguish to bitter disillusionment. It is Ms. Darlow's job to embody the devastating emotional cost borne by the victims and their families, a chilling contrast to the obliviousness of the cardinal. She rises to the challenge superbly. (Tonight and tomorrow at 8 and tomorrow at 2 p.m., Clurman Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200; tickets: $51.25.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit Up At Finance Concern
description: The insurance and banking concern ING Groep said that its third-quarter profit rose 63 percent, to 1.59 billion euros ($2.04 billion) from the period a year earlier, partly as a result of divestments. ING booked a onetime capital gain of 382 million euros connected to share sales in the period, which was up from 33 million euros a year earlier. The company's operating profit was up 28.4 percent, to 1.2 billion euros. The company's online banking unit, which is known as ING Direct and has customers in various countries including the United States, said its third-quarter operating profit rose 89 percent, to 117 million euros. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia To Cut Research Spending
description: Nokia, the world's largest maker of mobile phones, will cut research and development spending in a bid to bolster profit as global handset growth slows and prices fall. Nokia plans to cut spending on new products to 9 percent to 10 percent of sales by the end of 2006, it said yesterday in a news release to the Helsinki exchange before an investor meeting in New York. Nokia now spends about 13 percent of sales on research. Nokia's research and development spending will be about 3.7 billion euros ($4.8 billion) this year, based on Bloomberg calculations using the company's fourth-quarter sales forecast. title: PAUL CHAN
description: For his debut solo show, "My Birds . . . Trash . . . The Future," Paul Chan has pulled out the stops, offering up a double-channel 17-minute digital cartoon, projected on both sides of a hanging screen, along with charcoal drawings of owls, ravens, hawks and bats, prints and a toy gun with a radio inside that you hear by pointing the barrel at your head. The theme is the apocalypse. Mr. Chan, who's in the current Carnegie International in Pittsburgh and who first generated buzz in a group show here last year with a video riff on the darkling outsider artist Henry Darger, is clearly anxious to impress. Anxiety and war are his main motifs. His cartoon animation (a detail from above) is a bleak, seven-scene saga owing much to Goya, with nods to the Chapman brothers and Leviticus. Lynchings, vultures, orgies and a barren landscape slowly dissolve into a cataclysm of torpid color (from Goya to Rothko), with a soundtrack of hip-hop cellphone rings. The work has the jerky, low-tech quality of an early Nintendo game. It's hypnotic at first, then dull. Slow, it has a roughness that nonetheless sticks strangely in the mind, dovetailing with the subject matter. The accompanying drawings and prints, derived from the animation, are in different modes, as if demonstrating versatility for its own sake. All in all, a mixed bag, disappointing high expectations but worth checking out. (Greene Naftali, 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 463-7770, through Nov. 13; free.) MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

description: A week ago Wednesday night, the fourth and final game of the World Series, on Fox, beat every show during every hour. With a return to regular programming this week, ABC beat the competition, according to the Nielsen overnight ratings. "Lost" was the most-watched program Wednesday evening, with 18.6 million viewers following the mysterious doings of plane-crash survivors. During the 9 p.m. hour, people have been changing the channel from ABC's evaporating "Bachelor" in favor of "The West Wing," which is expecting a lift from the addition of Jimmy Smits, below right, to the cast. Wednesday's "West Wing" episode got its best numbers in a year, attracting 14.1 million viewers. Also at 9 p.m. was the debut of "Nanny 911," giving Fox a strong fourth place in a competitive time slot. With "Law & Order" showing a repeat, "CSI: NY" won the 10 p.m. hour easily. Under the tax-free spinoff, expected to be completed on Nov. 30, Kimberly-Clark shareholders would get one share of Neenah Paper for every 33 shares of Kimberly-Clark held as of Nov. 19. Neenah Paper was expected to incur new debt of about $225 million, Kimberly-Clark said. The spinoff was announced in June. The move allows Kimberly-Clark, based in Dallas, to focus on its Huggies diapers business.

title: California to the Rescue
description: When California voters enacted a lavishly financed stem cell program on Tuesday, they performed a valuable service that should help keep this nation in the forefront of one of the most promising areas of biomedical research. It was especially important given the big role that religious conservatives, who are strongly opposed to embryonic stem cell research, played in re-electing President Bush. There seems to be little chance that Mr. Bush will retreat from his limits on federal support for such research, and a Congress that has shifted rightward may try, once again, to ban therapeutic cloning, the most promising area of embryonic stem cell research. Now that California has enshrined stem cell research and therapeutic cloning in its Constitution and state law, it may be the engine that keeps the nation moving.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Komatsu's Profit Surges
description: The leading Japanese maker of construction machinery, Komatsu, reported that profit nearly tripled in the first half of its fiscal year on strong demand for bulldozers and other heavy equipment in North America and Asia. Komatsu's profit rose to 26.02 billion yen ($245 million), or 26.22 yen a share, from 9.41 billion yen, or 9.36 yen a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the period, which ended Sept. 30, rose 20 percent, to 683.98 billion yen from 567.67 billion yen. The company also raised its profit forecast for the year ending next March to 50 billion yen from an earlier forecast of 37 billion yen. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: Hinting at a lack of effective government action to quell an unexpected military crisis, Defense Minister Jos Viegas stepped down after a dispute with the army over a notorious case of rights abuses that occurred during the military dictatorship of 1964-1985. In his letter of resignation, Mr. Viegas said it was "unacceptable" that in a statement issued without his knowledge last month the army had tried to "deny or justify the deaths" of political prisoners during that time. He also criticized what he called "the persistence of authoritarian thought" in the armed forces. In a sign of the seriousness of the situation, Mr. Viegas, a former diplomat, will be replaced by Vice President Jos Alencar. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORFOGEN, CHRISTINE (NEE CHRISTAKOS)
description: MORFOGEN--Christine (nee Christakos), 91, of Fort Lee, formerly of New York, Teaneck and Glen Rock, passed away on Wednesday, November 3, 2004 at her daughter's home in Glen Rock. Beloved wife of the late James G. Loving mother of Elaine, George, and the late James Morfogen. Cherished grandmother of Kristine, her husband John Carlberg, and Alexander John Morfogen. Loving great grandmother of Cole and Samantha Carlberg. Adored sister of Theodore and his late wife Gladys, of Lakewood, N.J., Catherine and her husband Robert Taylor of North Carolina, and the late Stella, Chris, Gus and, George. Loved and adored by her many nieces, nephews, grand nieces, grand nephews, family and friends. Christine was raised in Pompton Lakes, NJ by her parents, Pauline and Peter and with her four brothers and two sisters. Christine was a member of the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, and was very involved in the fundraising campaign to erect this cathedral. Christine also attended the St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Wyckoff. Christine was a member of the Parthenon University Chapter of Eastern Star. She was employed by Lord & Taylor's flagship store in New York and worked in the Bill and Order Room for the Buyers from 1970 to 1990. Christine was a loving, caring, giving, gentle, and gracious lady. Always with a smile, always positive, she brought joy and happiness to all who knew her. She will be remembered for her love, kindness, generosity, guidance, support, and encouragement. Christine was an inspiration to all who knew her. She will be missed. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity or organization of your choice. Funeral service Saturday, November 6, 2004, 10AM at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church, Wyckoff, NJ. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. The family will receive their friends Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at the Vander Plaat Colonial Home, Inc., 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ.

Healy declared victory over 10 other candidates in the mayor's race, an unknown number of votes from 15 voting machines remained outstanding and more than 6,000 provisional and absentee ballots had yet to be counted, causing Mr. Healy's two closest competitors to refuse to concede. Assemblyman Louis M. Manzo remained in second place with 13,292 votes, 2,676 fewer than Mr. Healy's present total of 15,968, and L. Harvey Smith, the acting mayor who took over after Glenn D. description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company, the world's largest grain processor, said yesterday that it had entered a joint venture with Metabolix to develop and sell a new generation of plastics derived from corn and other renewable resources. Archer Daniels, which is based in Decatur, Ill., and the closely held Metabolix plan to build a plant to make and sell 50,000 tons of the plastic annually, the companies said. The plastic would be used in products like coated paper, film and molded goods, the companies said. Metabolix is based in Hayward, Calif.

title: Arts, Briefly; Masked Meaning
description: Kemo Sabe, the name given to the Lone Ranger by his American Indian sidekick, Tonto, below, in the popular westerns that ran on radio from 1933 through 1955 and on television from 1949 through 1957, is not a racist term, a Canadian court has ruled. The Nova Scotia Court of Appeal upheld a human rights board decision that said a Mikmaq Indian woman, Dorothy Kateri Moore, was not demeaned or offended when her boss at a sports store in Sydney, Nova Scotia, referred to her and others as "kemo sabe." The board came to its decision after dissecting a full day's worth of "Lone Ranger" television episodes and concluding that although Indians were treated in a demeaning way on the programs, Tonto and the Lone Ranger were in fact partners and friends. Ms. Moore's boss, Trevor Muller, said he believed that the word meant trusted friend. But the exact meaning varies greatly depending on context and the language being spoken. A Mikmaq witness at the hearing said the word meant sneaky. COLIN CAMPBELL

title: Have You Called Your Car Lately?

Tracking System to call your car from the terminal and have the engine running when you finally make your way to the hinterlands of long-term parking. Don't trust your teenager with the BMW? Use the same system to tell you when it goes over 45 m.p.h. Tied up in a warehouse rigged with explosives? Use the system to call the car to come -- wait, that's "Knight Rider." Directed may be pushing the envelope of technology, but it does have its limits.

title: TRULS MORK
description: Growing up in Norway, the cellist Truls Mork got mixed messages from his parents. His mother, a pianist, had great ambitions for him as a pianist. His father, a cellist, decided to teach him the cello, and cello won out. But his father cautioned him not to practice too much, lest he become a musician! Still, his father's challenging ways proved highly influential. Every time young Mr. Mork grew fixed in an interpretive idea about a piece, his father would make him think about it differently. This searching quality still characterizes Mr. Mork's adventurous artistry. He has championed contemporary music, but also founded (in 1991) and directed (until last year) an intensive chamber music festival in Stavanger, on the southwest coast of Norway. His playing can surprise you: one moment cool, articulate and classical, the next rhapsodic, throbbing and Romantic. On Sunday afternoon Mr. Mork performs as part of Lincoln Center's "Virtuoso Recitals" series, with the pianist Kathryn Stott, and his program is typically intriguing. He will place Prokofiev's Sonata for Cello and Piano in C in context by preceding it with the Sonata in D minor by Nikolai Miaskovsky, a friend and fellow student of Prokofiev's at St. Petersburg Conservatory. Next comes Janacek's "Pohadka" and finally Chopin's Cello Sonata in G minor, a teeming, restless work that would be played all the time if the piano part weren't so difficult. More power to Ms. Stott! (Sunday at 2 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; tickets are $40.) ANTHONY TOMMASINI

title: HUBBELL PLACES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER ON PAID LEAVE
description: Hubbell, a maker of electrical products, said its chief financial officer, William T. Tolley, had been placed on paid administrative leave amid an investigation into a restatement of his former employer's financial results in 2000. Mr. Tolley received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission that said the agency's staff was recommending that a civil injunction action be filed for violations of federal securities laws, the company said in an S.E.C. filing. The investigation does not involve Hubbell, the company said. Mr. Tolley is the former chief financial officer of the Chesapeake Corporation, which reduced 2000 earnings by $5.4 million because of accounting errors. Hubbell, based in Orange, Conn., named its chief accounting officer, Gregory F. Covino, as in interim successor to Mr. Tolley. Mr. Tolley could not be reached for comment.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about the re-election of President Bush and a front-page news analysis article that day referred incorrectly in some copies to the 1924 election of Calvin Coolidge, who, like Mr. Bush, won with a Republican majority in both houses. He became president in 1923 upon the death of President Warren G. Harding. Thus he was elected, not re-elected. The article also misstated the performance of the Republican Party in congressional elections that year. It did not gain seats; while it maintained its majority, it lost strength in both House and Senate.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Wal-Mart Opens Near Pyramids
description: A giant Wal-Mart discount store opened less than a mile from the ancient pyramids at Teotihuacn, just north of Mexico City, after months of protests, hunger strikes and a public relations campaign by locals and intellectuals who think the store will eviscerate small businesses and mar an important archeological site. Consumers, however, seemed unmoved by arguments that the concrete-block building bearing the name of a Wal-Mart subsidiary, Bodega Aurrera, is an affront to Mexican culture. More than 100 lined up hours before the grand opening, eager for bargains, and several told reporters that they were more interested in jobs and lower prices than in ancient culture. A handful of hardcore opponents held a vigil at the 1,800-year-old pyramids, built by an unknown culture. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

description: MBNA said yesterday that it had introduced a line of credit cards under the American Express brand. In January, MBNA became the first big Visa and MasterCard bank in the United States to agree to issue cards on the American Express network. Last month, it received a green light to do so when the Supreme Court decided not to hear an appeal by Visa and MasterCard to a court decision that gave banks permission to work with other networks. MBNA, based in Wilmington, Del., said that the first offers were mailed to members of 1,000 of the affinity groups for which MBNA issues cards. More than 300,000 people signed up for the cards in advance, MBNA said. Jennifer A. Kingson (NYT)
