title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Women Can Pass On Surnames
description: French children are now allowed to bear their mothers' surnames, under a law that went into effect this week. Previously, parents had to pass on the name of a child's father, under a law that dated to 1794. Now parents may pass on the name of the father or the name of the mother, or both surnames in an order they may choose. The surname chosen for the first child of a couple must also be given to any other siblings. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Sound Check at La Scala
description: After three years of little more than the clanking of hammers and the buzzing of drills, music returned to La Scala last week when the conductor Riccardo Muti, right, tested the new acoustics by leading the theater's orchestra in a 40-minute rehearsal of Antonio Salieri's "Europa Riconosciuta," which will reopen the famed opera house on Dec. 7. The verdict? A standing ovation. "They were very happy, both Mr. Muti and the orchestra," said Mariella di Rao, a spokeswoman for the city restorations office. "They said the acoustics were excellent, beyond their expectations." The renovations to the landmark theater, which first opened in 1778, cost around $67 million and forced performers to move to the Arcimboldi theater, outside the city center. Mr. Muti seemed to have suffered from a touch of homesickness. "It was very emotional to return to your home after a long absence and find it more splendid and more welcoming than before," he said. JASON HOROWITZ

title: SUN MICROSYSTEMS NARROWS ITS FIRST-QUARTER LOSS
description: Sun Microsystems completed its accounting of a settlement with the Eastman Kodak Company, resulting in a narrower first-quarter loss, the company said yesterday. The loss for the period ended Sept. 30 was $147 million, or 4 cents a share, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Sun, the maker of servers that run corporate computer networks, reported a loss of $174 million, or 5 cents a share, on Oct. 14. Sun agreed to pay Kodak $92 million after a jury determined that Sun's Java programming language infringed patents that Kodak bought in 1997 from Wang Laboratories.

title: FEDEX WILL RAISE DELIVERY RATES, STARTING IN JANUARY
description: The FedEx Corporation, the overnight shipping company, said yesterday that it would raise rates for air services and for ground deliveries next year and that it had adjusted fuel-related fees because of higher oil prices. FedEx Express, which moves parcels by plane, raised rates -- starting Jan. 3 -- an average 4.6 percent for United States and export shipments, and lowered its fuel surcharge by 2 percentage points, the company said in a statement. The net increase will be 2.6 percent, FedEx said. Rates for FedEx Ground and FedEx Home Delivery increased 2.9 percent, and the company is introducing a fuel surcharge tied to a price index. FedEx Ground moves packages mostly by truck and rail, and FedEx Home Delivery primarily ships goods ordered by consumers on the Internet. FedEx is based in Memphis.

According to Nielsen's overnight numbers, both "Survivor" and "Without a Trace" attracted more than 20 million viewers, and 30.14 million people watched "CSI" at 9 p.m. On NBC, which came in second over all, "Joey" is simply not a comparable replacement for "Friends" in the 8 p.m. slot. As of last week's totals for this season, "Joey" is ranked 16th; "Friends" was in the top five. Meanwhile, on Fox, "O.C." had its season premiere in its new time period, Thursday at 8 p.m., and an audience of 8.48 million watched Seth (Adam Brody), left, and Ryan (Benjamin McKenzie) come back to Newport. ABC's feeble Thursday night schedule is particularly weighed down by "Life as We Know It" in the 9 p.m. hour, which came in fifth in its time period, behind "CSI," "The Apprentice," the second hour of UPN's "WWE Smackdown!" and even the poorly performing return of "North Shore" on Fox. title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Domestic Security Center
description: Saying small cities and rural areas in the United States needed protection from terrorism, Representative Harold Rogers, a Republican, on Thursday announced creation of a domestic security center in Somerset with $4 million in federal financing. Mr. Rogers, the chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security, said the center would join the state's colleges and universities in research and development projects related to security and emergency situations. Mr. Rogers said the nation's security efforts had focused primarily on large cities and had ignored small communities. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dalai Lama Visit Is Weighed
description: The Foreign Ministry said it was considering allowing Tibet's exiled leader, the Dalai Lama, to visit Russia for the first time since 1992. Russia has denied him a visa at least three times in the last three years, citing diplomatic sensitivities with China, which considers him a renegade political leader. Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, president of the southern republic of Kalmykia, where roughly half of the 300,000 residents are Buddhists, announced earlier in the day that the Dalai Lama would visit the region's capital, Elista, for four days beginning Nov. 13. His announcement appeared premature. A spokesman, Mikhail Troyansky, told Interfax that the Foreign Ministry was still considering the possibility of what he emphasized would be a "pastoral trip," not a political one. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: ViewPoints:SORRY FOR BARGING IN

No, with Buffalo looming Sunday and a chance for the Jets to post a 7-1 midseason mark for only the second time, it is about this: How good can the Jets be this season?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASSIN, ALEXANDER, PH.D.
description: BASSIN--Alexander, Ph.D. An impasse had been reached by the early sixties. Long lines of this Town's young, addicted and lost, were filing into already crowded jail cells. With no end in sight, a lone Research Chief of the Brooklyn Supreme Court sounded the call for a new way-a revolutionary treatment alternative called DAYTOP. A prolific writer, he introduced DAYTOP to the world via a classical article in "Psychology Today" which captured the attention of the Nation. That New Yorker was Doctor Alexander Bassin who went onto God at 92 years in Tallahassee, FL where he served as Dean of the School of Criminology at Florida State University and Founder of a Daytop-Model, DISC Village in that city. Our prayerful support to his beloved Ann and the Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien Pres., Daytop Village, Inc.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 5 - After years of characterizing the human rights violations that occurred in Chile under the dictatorship of Gen. description: This week the United States came within about 136,000 ballots of having another president who was not the choice of the most voters. If John Kerry had done a little better in Ohio, he would have won even though George W. Bush got about 3.5 million more votes. It was another wake-up call to the nation that it's time to throw out the Electoral College.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Alarm Despite Assurances On Nuclear Plant
description: The unexpected shutdown of a power generating unit at a nuclear power plant in southern Russia sent ripples of worry through the region, even as the authorities insisted that there had been no release of radioactive contamination after what they described as a minor mishap. Rumors of contamination swirled after the stoppage of part of the Balakovo Nuclear Power Plant near Saratov, 450 miles southeast of Moscow. Iodine tablets promptly sold out in several communities, as residents feared a dangerous mishap had occurred, Interfax reported. Various Russian government agencies issued statements saying that radiation levels in the area were normal, that there had been glitch in a steam line, and that the line was being repaired. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

description: Music can be good for health in ways that might not be immediately obvious, concluded the first symposium organized by the Association of British Orchestras with health-care professionals at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital in London. The association, representing most of the leading orchestras in Britain, presented research to health practitioners, including an initiative called the Bronchial Boogies, which found that if children who suffered from asthma played wind instruments, their symptoms improved. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ODENCE, CHARLES LAWRENCE
description: ODENCE--Charles Lawrence, on Thursday, November 4, 2004, in Clearwater, Florida. Proudly born and raised in Boston, MA, he divided his time between his families in Clearwater, FL and Weston, MA. Beloved husband of the late Helen Lerman Odence and the late Lois Becker Odence. Loving father of Jeffrey Odence and his wife Sue, the late Jonathan Odence, Jon's wife, Joanne Odence Flackett and her current husband John Flackett; and his stepdaughters Barbara Lawrence Alfond and her husband Theodore, and Ruth Lawrence DuPont and her husband Thomas. Adoring grandfather of Jennifer Odence and Charlie Odence, John and Jill Alfond, Jennifer and Thomas Seeman, Katharine Alfond and Joseph Donahue, Jessica and Eric Thiel, Molly DuPont and Trevor Schaffer, and Sarah and Edwin Hendriksen. Proud greatgrandfather of nine. Cherished brother of Elaine and Arnold Richmond and muchloved brother-in-law of the Lerman family and of Carole and Alan Becker. Charles served with distinction in the European theater during WWII and had a distinguished career as a mutual fund broker in Boston with several well-known national firms. His warmth and passionate loyalty were a gift to all who knew him. Services at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Sunday, November 7th at 10AM. Memorial observance at the home of Barbara and Ted Alfond following the interment. Contribution in Charles's memory may be made to the Lois Odence Endowment Fund, C/O Morton Plant Mease Foundation, 1220 Druid Road South, Clearwater, FL. 33756.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Posts A Profit
description: Japan's biggest air carrier, the Japan Airlines Corporation, said it earned 82.96 billion yen ($79 million) in the first half of the year, reversing a loss from a year earlier as an increase in international travelers more than offset a rise in fuel prices. The loss in the 2003 period was 57.59 billion yen. Revenue in the period, which ended June 30, rose 14 percent, to 1.08 trillion yen ($9.5 billion), as the number of travelers increased after a slump related to the SARS outbreak last year. The company warned, however, that profit for the year would fall short of its forecast because of high fuel prices. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MUNGER, DOROTHY
description: MUNGER -- Dorothy. The house of Steinway & Sons notes with great sorrow the passing of the American pianist, Dorothy Munger, in Indianapolis on November 5, 2004 at the age of 89. Dorothy Munger was a member of our Steinway Artist family for more than fifty years. Born in Fostoria, Ohio, Mrs. Munger started piano lessons at the age of six and while in Junior High School provided music for silent films. She also regularly accompanied Charles Munger, an older boy who played trumpet, and years later she and Charlie married. Dorothy was for many years principal pianist of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, and she was one of the most beloved teachers and mentors in the country. Dorothy Munger was a member of the Steinway Artists' Committee for the Steinway Centennial in 1953, and she was a cherished friend to our firm throughout her life. We will miss her, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to Nancy, Jim, and her entire family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, VP, Worldwide Concert & Artist Activities

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Another Province Allows Gay Marriage
description: Saskatchewan became the seventh Canadian jurusdiction to legalize same-sex marriage when a judge ruled that existing marriage laws discriminated against homosexuals. Courts in British Columbia, Manitoba, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Quebec and the Yukon -- which account for 85 percent of Canada's population -- have already made the same ruling. description: The Indonesian government plans to sell its remaining stakes in several banks by the end of this year for 10.68 trillion rupiah ($1.17 billion) as part of a plan to finance the budget deficit. "The government is trying to sell minority stakes in banks to meet the deficit," the finance minister, Jusuf Anwar, left, said in Jakarta. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BINGER, JAMES HENRY
description: BINGER--James Henry. Born in St. Paul, MN May 16, 1916. Died peacefully at home in Minneapolis on November 3, 2004 at age 88. Graduate of Yale University, the University of Minnesota Law School and former CEO of Honeywell. He was a past member on several executive boards including 3M, Northwest Airlines and AT&T. A dedicated and passionate philanthropist, Jim served on the boards of The McKnight Foundation, International Peace Academy and Guthrie Theater. He was founder and chairman of Jujamcyn Theatre Company in New York City. He was an avid horse lover who enjoyed horse racing, playing polo and was founder of the Twin Cities Polo Club in Maple Plain and owner of Tartan Farms. Jim was a former part owner of the Minnesota Vikings and cherished cheering on his team. Preceded in death by his high school sweetheart and wife of 65 years, Virginia McKnight Binger, daughter Judy, sisters Beth Binger Harrison and Patsy McGrath. He will be dearly missed by his children Mac Binger and wife Pat and Cynthia Boynton, and grandchildren Erika Binger, Meghan Brown and husband Zeke, Ben Binger and wife Ann, Noa Staryk and husband Ted, great-grandchildren Olivia and Mac Staryk, Shayden Brown and Holden Binger; brothers Charles Robert Binger, Eugene Thomas Binger, and wife Rebecca. Memorial service 1pm Monday at St. Martin's by-the-Lake Epispocal Church, Minnetonka Beach. Reception to follow 3:30pm at the Minneapolis Club. Private entombment Sunset Memorial Park. Memorials preferred to Guthrie Theater, International Peace Academy of New York City or Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation, Minneapolis. For inquires call David Lee Funeral Home, Wayzata, MN 952-473-5577

Would we be documenting the life of the father of a nation, the man who, through a singular act of statesmanship, signed off on a final agreement that established an independent Palestinian state on almost all the land occupied by Israel in 1967? It is not often in history that someone's legacy can come down to one single defining moment, to one single critical choice. But such is the story of Mr. Arafat's life, and it is almost unbearably disappointing that four years ago, faced with the admittedly difficult choice of saying yes to Israel, Mr. Arafat said no.

title: Mother of Invention
description: Although my mother, Stella, is the best cook I know, she does not have a signature dish. Most cooks are known for, say, their perfect roast chicken or their famous chocolate souffl cake. But there's no marquee sensation that you can count on from my mother's kitchen, no big event specialties that are part of family lore or concocted only for the holidays. She does not view cooking, as so many self-conscious home cooks do, as a statement of personality. She never fetishizes food, never revels in its currency or the way it can confer coolness on its partakers. She is not, and never has been, interested in anything trendy. To her, cooking is about using everything at hand -- from leftover Halloween jellybeans to the leafy tops of beets that she bought at the farmer's market that morning to a bunch of marrowbones that the butcher was selling cheap. Unlike the home cooks who seem to be mostly concerned about the image their food projects, Stella is only really interested in pleasing herself. To her, cooking is a sensuous mystery -- a kind of delicious science project -- rather than a referendum on identity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHAIRER, GEORGE SWIFT
description: SCHAIRER--George Swift, 91, retired Boeing Vice President of Research, from complications of Alzheimers disease, October 28, 2004, in Kirkland, Washington. Born May 19, 1913 to Otto S. and Elizabeth Schairer, a graduate of Swarthmore College and MIT, he received a Doctorate of Engineering (Hon.) from Swarthmore in 1958. He worked for Bendix Aircraft and Consolidated Vultee Aircraft before moving to Boeing as Chief Aerodynamicist in 1939. He helped design Boeing planes from the B-17, B-29, B-47, B-52, KC-135 and 707 to the 767, and some Vertol helicopters. For Army Intelligence, he followed Allied troops into Germany after WWII, finding data on a swept back wing which led to the design of the B-47 and all subsequent Boeing airplanes. He became Boeing's Vice President of Research and Development and served on many military, scientific, academic and industry boards and advisory committees. Retired in 1978, he was a consultant to NASA, Boeing, Cessna, Stanford and Cal Tech. His awards include the 1959 Spirit of Saint Louis Medal, 1967 Daniel Guggenhiem Medal, election to the National Academy of Sciences in 1968, I.B. Laskowitz Award in 1979, and Museum of Flight's 1985 Pathfind Award. He belonged to AIAA, National Academy of Engineering, Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, American Helicopter Society, Sigma Xi and Sigma Tau. He served on the boards of Seattle Opera Association, Cornish College of the Arts, and ACT Theatre. He is survived by his beloved wife of 69 years, Pauline, who shared his love of music, sailing and travel, brother Robert, sister Julia Read, daughters Mary E. Richards and Sally Cantrell, sons George E. (Gus) and John O., eight grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Memorial services at Seattle Yacht Club, November 21st, 1:30PM. Remembrances to ACT Theatre, Cornish College, Alzheimers Association, or Evergreen Healthcare Foundation for Evergreen Hospice Center, Kirkland, WA.

title: Borges on the Couch
description: There's an unhappy paradox about literary biographies. The majority of readers who will be interested in a writer's bio, especially one as long and exhaustive as Edwin Williamson's ''Borges: A Life,'' will be admirers of the writer's work. They will therefore usually be idealizers of that writer and perpetrators (consciously or not) of the intentional fallacy. Part of the appeal of the writer's work for these fans will be the distinctive stamp of that writer's personality, predilections, style, particular tics and obsessions -- the sense that these stories were written by this author and could have been done by no other.* And yet it often seems that the person we encounter in the literary biography could not possibly have written the works we admire. And the more intimate and thorough the bio, the stronger this feeling usually is. In the present case, the Jorge Luis Borges who emerges in Williamson's book -- a vain, timid, pompous mama's boy, given for much of his life to dithery romantic obsessions -- is about as different as one can get from the limpid, witty, pansophical, profoundly adult writer we know from his stories. Rightly or no, anyone who reveres Borges as one of the best and most important fiction writers of the last century will resist this dissonance, and will look, as a way to explain and mitigate it, for obvious defects in Williamson's life study. The book won't disappoint them.

description: UTSCH--Annemarie Schuelein Utsch, died Oct. 14. She was a mother, stepmother, relative, friend, Quadrille charity volunteer and colleague of many, who all mourn her passing. Those wishing to make contributions in her name should send them to Doctors Without Borders.

title: On Waterfronts of the Present, Rail-Bridge Relics of the Past
description: AT two recently built waterfront parks, evocative industrial archaeology -- huge, rusting float bridges, once used for transferring freight cars to and from cross-river barges -- have been made integral parts of the design.

title: Chic Technique
description: Too busy to cook dinner? Then wear it.

title: From Asbury Park To Hoboken
description: Granian "On My Own Two Feet" (self-released)

title: Bidding on 'The Curse' in 7 Figures
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6 (AP) - A Louisville Slugger signed by Shoeless Joe Jackson sold for $137,500 on Saturday at a memorabilia auction at a museum at the factory where the bats are manufactured.

title: The Class Acts
description: A New Face of Self-Destruction

title: The Grass Is Way Greener on the Other Track
description: WHEN a neighbor pulls up in a shiny new car, it's hard not to be a little jealous. That's especially true if you're driving an old clunker that should have been replaced years ago.

title: Laissez Fare
description: After decades of mimicking the Europeans or experimenting with frantic oddities like "Nuevo Latino" cooking, American chefs have finally found their voice. They have done so by both following their own restless inclinations and by responding to diners' real hunger -- which is not just for stimulating food, but for an entire experience. It's for the cozy feel of the room, the communal table lined with benches, the handblown glass tumblers. We don't want restaurants with a view. We want restaurants with a point of view, restaurants that have an individual's touch. Gone are the constructs of fine dining -- the china, the petit fours, the intimidation of a matre d'htel stand. Ours is an age of dining that's relaxed, even casual, and more than a little idiosyncratic.

title: Wal-Mart to Lease Space In Downtown White Plains
description: Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, will lease two floors of a White Plains building formerly occupied by Sears, said Paul Wood, acting executive officer for the city.

title: Rake or Blow: A Divided Nation, Act 2
description: DESPITE three decades of skirmishes with antinoise activists, the leaf blower has become America's weapon of choice against fallen leaves and cut grass.

title: A Tricky Time
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Chance': What Are the Odds?
description: CHANCE A Guide to Gambling, Love, the Stock Market, and Just About Everything Else. By Amir D. Aczel. Illustrated. 161 pp. Thunder's Mouth Press. $21.

title: Stony Brook to Take Over Southampton Program
description: Marine sciences, the flagship undergraduate program at Southampton College, will be taken over by Stony Brook University in September in an unusual agreement between public and private universities.

title: Taxes and Consequences: The Second Term Begins
description: PRESIDENT BUSH began his first term with projections for $5.6 trillion in budget surpluses. Though he will start his second term facing at least $2.3 trillion in deficits, according to the Congressional Budget Office, his tax-cutting ambitions are even greater. Here are some of the initiatives that he's likely to push, and the unanswered questions that go with them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TERMAN, PEARL
description: TERMAN -- Pearl. Loving mother of Diane Felenstein and Dr. David Terman, adoring grandmother of Deborah, Jennifer, Erica, Joy and Brad, great-grandmother of Melissa, Jamie, Laura and Grant. She was an exceptional woman who lived with integrity, values, and strength. She will be missed. A private service will be held Monday, November 8th. The family requests that in lieu of flowers contributions in her memory be made to Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Stalin and the Czars Haunt Khodorkovsky in the Dock
description: MOSCOW - THE defendant begins his day by taking a seat in a small metal cage. A prosecutor in a blue uniform sits across from him in the courtroom and accuses him of criminally undermining the Russian state. On some days the defendant's image is transmitted on television throughout Russia's vastness.

title: Red Sox Fans Live Among Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Writing to the Test
description: Today's test consists of only one question, so think carefully. The "A" in SAT stands for: (a) aptitude; (b) achievement; (c) assessment; (d) all of the above; (e) none of the above.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YOU see them on the beach, at the bazaar, eating together at their seaside hotel. A group of American women waiting to adopt infants in South America are the stars of John Sayles's suds-free drama CASA DE LOS BABYS (2003), but the story concentrates almost as much on the struggles and inequities that affect the local people. They include a man desperate for work, a hotel manager fed up with her useless son and a sad young hotel maid who gave up a daughter for adoption four years ago. The plot is all about character, and the sterling cast includes Marcia Gay Harden, Mary Steenburgen, Lili Taylor, Daryl Hannah, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Susan Lynch and Rita Moreno. One of the women may be psychologically unfit for motherhood, and the ending is a devastating comment on randomness -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on WE.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PEREIRA, DEENA DOLORES
description: PEREIRA--Deena Dolores Secretary/Treasurer of City Lighting and President of Stedmar R.E. She was the daughter of Rose and Sam Sarnoff and sister to Leonard. She was married to Marvin 6 weeks shy of 50 years. She loved Steven and JoAnne, Arlene and Paul. Worshiped her grandchildren Amanda, Caitlin, Joshua and Matthew. A force in our little family. Honey you will be missed.

title: Impromptu Classroom
description: TO Brazilians, the boats that chug up and down the Solimes River are the Greyhound buses of the Amazon: the only affordable way to visit relatives or travel on business. In that land of few roads and expensive air fares, the Solimes, as the Amazon River is known there, is the local highway.

title: Cough, 102-Degree Fever, Lightheadedness
description: 1. Symptoms In the early hours of the morning, the small rural emergency room was quiet. Monitors beeped softly as the overnight nurses handed off the few remaining patients to the nurses coming on to the day shift. In a corner room a young woman moaned. Beside her an IV dripped fluid into her slender arm. Her mother sat beside her, her face heavy with fatigue, her clothes stylish but rumpled from her nightlong vigil.

title: Claire Lecomte du Noy, Eric Pakurar
description: Claire Elizabeth Lecomte du Noy, the daughter of Patricia and Philippe Lecomte du Noy of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Eric Pakurar, the son of Alice and Thomas Pakurar of Richmond, Va. The Rev. Dr. Gordon Mapes, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Brandermill Church in Midlothian, Va.

title: The Case for Musical Chairs and Movies on Demand
description: LOS ANGELES - IT has come to this: DaimlerChrysler is marketing its latest minivans not so much on ride, safety, styling, performance or quality, but mainly on how easily the furniture can be rearranged.

title: A Gift From Mexico
description: A Gift From Mexico

title: 'Brand' Is Not a Four-Letter Word
description: The American academy is a competitive market, so administrators must carefully cultivate their institution's identity to attract applicants, faculty, grants -- and attention. That means a logo suitable for bumper stickers and admissions brochures that reflects the campus's character, history and values.

title: DVD's to Put Under Trees; Beware of Low-Flying Nannies
description: MARY POPPINS 40TH ANNIVERSARY EDITION (Buena Vista, Dec. 14) -- The pictures that affect us as children may not always draw the same response after we've developed that set of benchmarks we so confidently call good taste. Don't peer too closely at Walt Disney's 1964 "Mary Poppins," or you'll end up fixating on its problems, not least of which is its sluggish pacing. But if the sight of a phonily realistic, pre-David Lynch robin landing on Julie Andrews's finger helped make you what you are today, then the flaws in "Mary Poppins" won't matter.

title: Dear New York: Some Feel Your Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Erin Wile, Marc Thomas
description: Erin Heather Wile and Marc Reginald Thomas were married yesterday. The Rev. Albert C. Mickel, a Missionary Baptist minister, officiated at Montegut House in New Orleans.

title: He Lives in a Pineapple, but Then What?
description: Burbank, Calif. - ELEVEN minutes: such a piquant unit of time. Shortish, but plenty long enough for SpongeBob SquarePants to bound out of his undersea bed; feed his pet snail, Gary; leave his pineapple house in Bikini Bottom; bid a cheery good morning to his imbecile buddy, Patrick the starfish, emerging from under his rock; and make happy tracks to the Krusty Krab, a fast-food restaurant where SpongeBob loves loves loves serving trademark Krabby Patties, even if the avaricious owner crab and killjoy squid co-worker find his happy-go-lucky enthusiasm for minimum-wage drudgery bizarre and annoying.

title: There Really Is No Business Like Show Business
description: MICHAEL S. OVITZ, the disgraced former president of the Walt Disney Company, got a chance last week to tell his side of the story about his controversial tenure at the company in the mid-1990's. Much has been made of how he exposed a dysfunctional relationship with Michael D. Eisner, his former best friend and Disney's chief executive, and of the $140 million that Mr. Ovitz was eligible to receive when he left after only 14 months.

title: A Red Blend Rich in Style
description: THE three cupolas adorning the roof at Bedell Cellars are richly metaphoric, in the same way that the winery's 2000 Cupola, a red Bordeaux-type blend, is rich in style and flavor.

title: Beyond 'Sweetie'
description: Lena Kagan, the first female dean of Harvard Law School, had an epiphany in the women's bathroom at a conference hall in Cambridge, Mass., last year. There, neatly stacked in a basket, was a supply of free tampons. "It's such a small thing, but it says a lot about whether a place cares about its women," she says. A few months later, every women's room at Harvard Law had a supply.

title: Borges on the Couch
description: BORGES A Life. By Edwin Williamson. Illustrated. 574 pp. Viking. $34.95.

title: One-Two Punch
description: Ever since I got in the habit of whipping up big bowls of mysterious, powerful punch, my parties have been more fun and less work. It has saved me from hustling as a bartender all night and has kept guests from draining my expensive Scotch. It has also led to some elaborate recipes, including one based on two kinds of fresh-brewed tea and another made several days beforehand to gather strength. When it came to nonalcoholic beverages, though, I'd rather plunk down a warm bottle of Diet Coke and call it a night.

title: Clueless in New Jersey, Or Refreshingly Out of Touch?
description: TRENTON - POLITICAL candidates in New Jersey, and especially Republicans, like to accuse each other of being "out of step" with voters, or "out of the mainstream," and therefore unfit for public office. But if the exit polls from last Tuesday's election are any measure, all of New Jersey is out of step with America. Even the Republicans are.

title: Toward a 24-Hour Downtown Hartford
description: Hartford - THE focus of Hartford's transition from staid insurance capital to diverse 24-hour city is shifting from revenue-producing commercial ventures like the Convention Center and Marriott Hotel at Adriaen's Landing, due to open in June, to the creation of downtown housing and retail activity.

title: Ardor in the Court
description: THE remarkable thing about the Shepards, a mother-and-daughter team who are New York's most distinctive courtroom artists, is that they ended up in a job where they have to sit still and in silence for large parts of the day. They are movers. And they are talkers.

title: Labor-Backed Third Party Emerges as Statewide Force
description: With all the attention focused on the re-election of President Bush and the record voting for New York State's senior United States senator, Charles E. Schumer, the hidden winner of last Tuesday's election may well have been the Working Families Party, which established itself as an emerging political force statewide by getting a little-known candidate elected district attorney in Albany County.

title: China's Moving Art Scene: Pushing Into Dark New Territory
description: Instead of misty landscapes and delicate Chinese figurines, the Shanghai Art Museum is offering something else entirely this fall. Through November, visitors can study a disorienting upside-down room, or examine photos of distant nudes on blinding, white ice, or visit a roomful of strange, troubling videos that could fit easily in a Guggenheim anywhere in the world. The exhibit is the 2004 Shanghai Biennale, the fifth offering of adventurous contemporary art reminiscent of the Whitney's biennales in New York City.

title: Growing Up With Mom and Mom
description: In the mid-1990's, I worked on Sandy Russo's election campaign for a Manhattan judgeship. (Unfortunately, we lost.) In my role, I grew to know the Russo-Young family. What I can tell you, and what I think is most important, is that they were a loving, supportive, close-knit family and that Ry and Cade were well adjusted. It didn't really occur to me that they were "trailblazing" as mothers. It's sad that there are some in our society who would seek to identify pathologies in a family that has raised such smart and interesting young women. I wish them the best, and I hope that soon an article about same-sex parenting (and marriage) will be too unexceptional to make the pages of your magazine.

title: At Last, After 85 Years, Baby Snookems Has a Stone
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Nov. 4 - The graves do not take up much room in the Baby Rest section of Rose Hill cemetery, where the ages on the markers are measured in months and the sentiments are achingly simple: "Our Doll Baby," "Our Little Man," "Our Girl."

title: Palestinian Line of Succession Answers and Raises Questions
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Nov. 6 - In the turmoil since Yasir Arafat fell gravely ill, many questions have risen about how his successor would be chosen.

title: Albeit
description: Disarmament Process Starts in Sadr City, Albeit Slowly" was a front-page headline in The Washington Post last month.

title: Europe, Seeking Political Unity, Stumbles Over Issue of Religion
description: ROME, Nov. 6 - For all the grandiose speeches about political unity at the signing of the European Union's first Constitution in Rome on Oct. 29, it was a bronze sculpture that spoke volumes about the bloc's current identity crisis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: !Hey, Cleveland: Don't Forget Seattle

title: When Less Is More
description: Since they began attracting attention on the New York scene in the 1980's, tapas and other small-plate restaurants have become increasingly popular, providing a welcome alternative to "supersized" meals.

title: Beef Jerky for the Discriminating Palate
description: The year was 1982. Robert Yee had an awe-inspiring recipe for jerky created by his great-grandmother in Hong Kong. Then there was his nickname: Cow. His destiny as a beef jerky man in Chinatown seemed clear.

title: Corrections
description: A signature on Page 14 of Arts & Leisure today for an article about the N cable channel misstates the writer's given name. He is Jon Caramanica, not Joe.

title: Filling Fred's Running Shoes
description: "I'm deaf in one ear and blind in one eye," explains Allan Steinfeld, chief executive officer of the New York Road Runners Club, pulling out two chairs at his conference table so he can sit close to a visitor. He's 58, and seems to have been born with a beard, but the protestation of decrepitude rings false, the first hint of contradiction in this most contradictory of men.

title: Afghan Militants Hold Talks on Hostages, but No Deal Yet
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 7 - Militants holding three foreign United Nations workers in Afghanistan said that they had held negotiations with officials from the Afghan government and the United Nations in southern Afghanistan today, but that the meeting had ended without result.

title: Kristen Bell: Into the Fast Lane
description: LOS ANGELES - A BLACK high heel flew through the air. Kristen Bell, the star of "Veronica Mars," was traversing Hollywood's streets in her boyfriend's Jeep and hurriedly changing outfits. They were heading to Lucky Strike Lanes to go bowling, and had just left the Guardian Awards, an animal activist gala on a recent Saturday where black-tie was de rigueur. She was excited -- hence the shoe's trajectory into the back seat. "In the last six months, I've probably had one night like this," Ms. Bell said, meaning a purely social one.

title: The Magnet Magnet
description: 'Support Our Troops' Magnet Arguably the most conspicuous vehicle of self-expression available to most consumers is, in fact, the vehicle. The Hummer driver projects an image to fellow motorists that is vastly different from that of the Prius driver. And even less remarkable vehicles often carry tacked-on messages, from the Christian fish symbol to "Think Globally, Act Locally" bumper stickers. To this brief list of auto-signifiers we can add a recent but increasingly ubiquitous option, the "Support Our Troops" ribbon-shaped magnet; many are yellow, although a red-white-and-blue variation is also quite popular, and lately they have even been made available in a camouflage design. Drive in light traffic for a mile or two, and you're bound to see one.

title: A Historical Look Back At Working-Class Housing
description: Correction Appended

title: Growing Up With Mom and Mom
description: As a 22-year-old lesbian in a serious relationship, with plans to have children, I was at first dismayed to see an article on the children of gay relationships. I thought society had moved past the time when we needed to explain these families as if they were some sort of freak show, though I soon found that the article was far from that: lyric and delightful. And yet it will take time before many Americans are willing to read something that is ultimately positive about gay families. My own theory? Being born into such a family allows these children the opportunity to be more accepting -- of themselves and others.

title: 'His Excellency': The Human Washington
description: HIS EXCELLENCY George Washington. By Joseph J. Ellis. Illustrated. 320 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

title: The Remix; ZEN AND THE ART OF FLOWER ARRANGING
description: "The best flowers are from the garden," says Noritaka Noda, the floral designer behind the dramatically minimal arrangements at Megu and Sugiyama, two restaurants in Manhattan. "You can see which way the wind has blown against them, how the rain has fallen on them. I try to give greenhouse flowers the not-perfect character of nature."

title: Far West Side Story
description: Correction Appended

title: Can History Save the Democrats?
description: A LITTLE more than a month before he was assassinated, Abraham Lincoln stood at the east portico of the Capitol and delivered his second inaugural address. It was a brief speech with a distinctly religious message: he twice cited biblical verses, and made a dozen references to God, most strikingly in assessing the opposing sides in the Civil War.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, DAVID I.
description: HIRSCH--David I., 78. Beloved husband of Ann, loving father, stepfather and father-inlaw of Peter, Amanda, Beth, Jean, Heidi, Michael, Fred and Ron. Doting grandfather of Emilie, Joshua, Ben, Nora and Claire. His humor will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations to East End Hospice, Westhampton Beach, New York.

title: Not Just a Nut With a Gun
description: I HAVE a soft spot for quiet writers like Archer Mayor, whose unassuming voice and down-to-earth style stamp his regional crime novels -- THE SURROGATE THIEF (Mysterious Press, $24.95) is the latest -- with a sense of integrity. Set in Brattleboro, Vt., and featuring a broad-shouldered homicide detective named Joe Gunther, these solidly built police procedurals don't trouble themselves with the theatrical antics of spree killers and serial murderers. (And wouldn't they look foolish if they did, since Vermont averages only about seven murders a year.) But over the course of 15 books, Mayor has devised a vivid overview of the kinds of criminal behavior -- from domestic violence to interstate drug trafficking -- that relentlessly wear down the social fabric in the postindustrial mill and factory towns of northern New England, giving people the uneasy feeling that they are losing control over their lives.

title: Organically Grown
description: When Fanny Singer was an infant, her baby food was pured duck confit and poached pears. When she was teething, her mother gave her quail bones to gnaw (don't try this at home), and she was often sent to high school with choices of salad dressing, like anchovy and red-wine vinaigrette.

title: Maybe Same-Sex Marriage Didn't Make the Difference
description: BOSTON - IN deconstructing the Democratic Party's Election Day failure, a number of fingers have been pointing to the push for same-sex marriage.

title: Upholding Teacher Standards
description: Most New Yorkers do not realize that the state has been at the forefront of the national school reform movement since the 1990's, when the Board of Regents began to carry out a sweeping package of changes involving everything from curriculum to testing to graduation requirements. The most far-reaching reforms were aimed at the state's colleges of education, which have historically served as diploma mills that produced income for the colleges but failed to prepare teachers for the classroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEARON, JAMES J.
description: GEARON--James J. On November 5, 2004. Beloved husband of Molly (nee Dassa). Loving father of Daniel and Jamie. Cherished grandfather of Matthew. Also a dear brother to Helen E. Garon and father-in-law to Dana Fields. Reposing Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 11 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Trash Trap Fights Mess In Harbor
description: MAMARONECK - YOU name it, if it floats, we get it," Fred Longacre, president of the newly formed Harbor Island Conservancy in Mamaroneck said recently, describing trash buildup on a village-owned site on Long Island Sound. "Dead animals, propane tanks, syringes. I've even seen bags of garbage that were carefully tied before someone upstream tossed them in."

title: The Remix; Asia Major
description: As French gastronomic temples like La Caravelle and Lutce shutter or downgrade to bistro level (La Cte Basque is now Brasserie LCB), the holy realm of haute cuisine is being seized by the Japanese. Where Nobu was once the ne plus ultra of Asian dining, there are now luxurious restaurants popping up all over, turning Manhattan into Little Tokyo. There are, of course, the three M's -- Matsuri, Megu and Masa, where Masayoshi Takayama works his Aritsugu knives over pristine pieces of fish for a few lucky (deep-pocketed) patrons. But there is also Riingo, where the chef, Marcus Samuelsson, mixes Swedish cuisine with Japanese and a pinch of American contemporary. And Geisha, where Eric Ripert, Le Bernardin's four-star fish master, consults.

title: The Originals
description: Not only do these iconoclasts entertain superbly, they also spend more of their waking hours thinking about food than any run-of-the-mill bon vivant.

title: The Spice Route
description: Very little of the world's great cooking takes place in restaurants. The fanatic home griller, the village bread baker, the man aging sopressata in his cellar, are all creating a wider variety of subtle and exquisite tastes than the chef in his whites searing hundreds of lamb chops. A recent trip I took to seven countries in Asia underlined this point. In Asia, where restaurants are not nearly as common as they are in the West, it is the street vendors who shine, defining the tastes of the culture and providing an immediate sense of place.

title: In Rarefied Napa, Good Food Without Attitude
description: AS fine dining is the natural partner to fine wining, it makes perfect sense that one should be able to eat extremely well in Napa Valley, the most renowned wine-producing region in the country. While elite chefs have not descended on Napa as if it were Las Vegas, they have opened a fair share of restaurants along the 30-mile corridor that runs from the city of Napa, on the southern end of the valley, north through Yountville, St. Helena and Calistoga.

title: The Neediest Cases; In Brooklyn, a Gift to Provide Comfort to a Grieving Family
description: Sarah Barker was a little girl who wanted to take care of everybody. So one evening in July, when her mother, Gratiana Eugene, asked her to go outside their Brooklyn apartment and fetch her older brother for dinner, she took a bottle of water and a packet of sunflower seeds to share with him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBUCH, JOSEPH
description: EISENBUCH--Joseph. Beloved uncle and brother. Died November 4, 2004, at age 90, surrounded by loving family. He was everyone's favorite, bright, charming, with a devilish wit. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Nibbles and Sips
description: THE COCKTAIL HOUR REVISITED

title: Greenwich Police on Alert Over Incidents With Children
description: The police in Greenwich and Rye, N.Y., say they have been on the alert for a man and a woman they suspect of trying to lure children into a green minivan or sport utility vehicle.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVIEN, DONNA
description: LEVIEN--Donna 11/7/43 to 11/8/03. Happy Birthday. Your family and friends miss you very much.

title: The Get; River Caf Society
description: Two of London's top tastemakers reveal their secret ingredients for easy living.

title: The Remix; Expiration Date
description: Food, like fashion, has a brutally short trend cycle, as the trickle-down from San Sebastin to Smith Street takes barely a season. So, this year's crudo could be next year's tuna carpaccio. Christine Muhlke

title: How Do You Get to Lincoln Center?
description: "MY philosophy," Peter Gelb said just after his appointment as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera was announced, "is that art can be both commercially successful and artistically successful."

title: The Top 10 in Israel
description: Israel's ballooning wine industry is explored expertly in "Rogov's Guide to Israeli Wine 2005," by Daniel Rogov, that country's top wine critic. This hardcover book (Toby Press, New Milford, Conn.) is a boon to fans of Israel's kosher and nonkosher wines, especially those from boutiques.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BIDDLE, NICHOLAS DUKE
description: BIDDLE--Nicholas Duke. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 8, at 3 pm, at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave at 66th St. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the International Rescue Committee, Boys and Girls Harbor, or the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENJAMIN, LEO
description: BENJAMIN--Leo. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, Pawling, NY, and Fort Lee, NJ, on November 3, 2004. Leo was born February 27, 1916, to Nathan and Lena. After Lena's premature death in 1918, he was raised and loved by his stepmother, Esther (Seinfeld). Cherished husband of Ethele (Selkowe). Predeceased by his older son, Leslie (Suzanne). Survived by Karen (Martin) and Andrew (Maxine). Beloved grandfather of Shira, Robin, Joshua, Nancy, Deborah, Todd, Rebecca, Matthew and David. Greatgrandfather of 15. Survived by loving sister Sylvia Weisbard of Portland, OR. Leo received his undergraduate and graduate degrees from Brooklyn College, where he met the love of his life, Ethele, with whom he shared 65 years of marriage. After military service in WWII, Leo became successful in the family curtain and drapery business, S. Lichtenberg and Co. In retirement, Leo enjoyed a second career in the jewelry business. As past president of the Prospect Park Jewish Center and his family fraternal organization, the Young Men's Aid Society, Leo's philanthropy and activism benefited all who knew him. He was a world traveler, an avid photographer, and a master coin and stamp collector. Leo will always live on in the hearts of the many lives he touched. Leo liked this quote, "No one ever dies who lives in the hearts of those left behind." Contributions in his memory may be made to the Prospect Park Jewish Center, c/o Rabbi Abraham Kelman, 1604 Ave R, Brooklyn, NY 11229.

title: New Voters, Same Patterns Result in Familiar Outcome
description: THE election of 2004 may be remembered for changing the way people feel about their role in democracy, for pushing them to the polls in numbers not seen in more than a decade. What it didn't change, for the most part, is the balance of power in Connecticut.

title: Rock's Diverse Pantheon
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Window to the Sea
description: "THE Sea Inside," Alejandro Amenbar's powerful new movie (Dec. 17), tells the true story of Ramn Sampedro, a Spanish quadriplegic whose fight for the right to die galvanized his country in the 1990's. Filmed mostly in a Madrid studio that recreated Sampedro's Galician farmhouse home, the movie envelops the viewer in the frustrations of a paralyzed man's circumscribed world.

title: Happy Barging
description: To the Editor: "Barging in France," (Q&A, Oct. 17), Florence Stickney's answer to the question of which companies offer canal trips in France on small barges, did not mention French Country Waterways, the company that the Travel section quite properly highlighted in "If Cleopatra Visited Burgundy," (Feb. 1) by Sarah Ferrell.

title: Working Stiffs
description: Correction Appended

title: The Remix; Gluttons A Go-Go
description: This jumbo steel drum of "sweeter than sugar" Bubba Gulp (above) contains the average American's annual corn-syrup intake: a whopping 63 pounds. The lid features a pig, while the label states some ugly facts: Americans eat 31 teaspoons of sugar a day; the Department of Agriculture recommends 10 to 12. Though buying something this huge is a Costco-induced reality, Bubba Gulp is art, created by Steve Sandstrom, an Oregon designer.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review last Sunday about the Iron Horse Grill in Pleasantville misstated the opening days and dinner hours. The restaurant is open Tuesday through Saturday from 5 p.m.

title: In Election's Wake, Some Democrats to Keep an Eye On
description: Here's a look at party leaders who are likely to play key roles in the coming years. Others not pictured are: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, who is expected to become the new minority leader, and Govs. Mark Warner of Virginia, Janet Napolitano of Arizona and Jennifer M. Granholm of Michigan. And one other senator: John Kerry of Massachusetts, who aides say will be reporting for duty when Congress convenes in January. ADAM NAGOURNEY

title: Plum Island Union Signs 3-Year Contract
description: In the final chapter of a bitter strike, the union representing maintenance workers at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center signed a three-year contract on Monday with the company that operates the laboratory for the federal government.

description: Weeks

title: RAPE CHARGES DROPPED IN MONTCLAIR
description: Prosecutors have decided to drop all charges brought last month against two Montclair High School football players accused of raping a fellow student. The acting Essex County prosecutor, Paula T. Dow, said in a short statement that was sent by e-mail to the news media that there was "no basis to proceed" in the case. "These charges were thoroughly investigated by my office and the Montclair Police Department," the statement said. "I am satisfied that the interests of justice require that the pending charges be dismissed and the investigation be closed." There was no mention of whether the accuser, a 15-year-old girl, had recanted, and no explanation of what exactly happened that night. The move was an abrupt end to a well-publicized case that began in early October. Jeffrey Gettleman

title: Bush Secured Victory in Florida by Veering From Beaten Path
description: Correction Appended

title: Georgia Gold Mine
description: There are truffles in Georgia -- not the chocolates you buy in a gold box, but the earthy fungi you shave over pasta. If it comes as a surprise to you that one of the world's most sought-after delicacies grows wild in the pecan groves of Georgia's coastal plain, then it comes as a surprise to Georgia pecan farmers that anybody would take an interest in something that looks like a mangled potato and smells up the whole truck.

title: Bridges Loom as Cash Cow That Nobody Dares to Milk
description: There they stand, glinting in the sun, hanging off the shore of Manhattan like fruit-laden branches of a money tree: The free bridges over the East River to Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Game Theory Posits Measure of Baseball Players' Value
description: Thresherman's Bakehouse, a coffee shop in Melbourne, Australia, would seem an odd spot for a baseball epiphany. Yet it was over down-under joe that Brian Lonergan, a young economist from Yale, and Ben Polak, his former dissertation adviser, took a bite out of the eternal apple of baseball statistics: determining a season's most valuable player.

title: Discussions of Crime at a Co-op
description: Q I am a board member of my co-op. At a recent board meeting we discussed some vandalism and attempted muggings that had occurred in the building.

title: Op-Art
description: Hart Seely is the editor of "Pieces of Intelligence: The Existential Poetry of Donald Rumsfeld." Emily Oberman and Bonnie Siegler are graphic designers.

title: NOT ROCKET SCIENCE
description: As a vulture investor and chairman of Beal Bank, Andrew Beal has always sensed opportunity where others see only risk. In 1997, for example, he pledged more than $200 million of his own money to Beal Aerospace, a reusable-rocket company. O.K., that didn't work out so well. The company collapsed three years later, before sending a single commercial payload into orbit.

title: Upside to a Dollar That's Falling
description: THE stock market is rising, but the dollar is falling. And the decline of the dollar is more likely to continue than the rally of the stock market.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.F.L.

title: Help From a Bad Source
description: I am a college student looking for a job to make some money for the school year. An acquaintance seems willing to help, but during our conversation, this person launched an uninhibited racist polemic. I found this disturbing and do not want to associate with this individual any longer, but I still want the job. Is it wrong to still accept help? L. B., Medford, Mass. Someone who recommends you for a job needn't have a spotless character, just an awareness of your abilities. This is straightforward enough if what you're seeking is verification of your technical skills -- an aptitude for writing computer code, for example, or repairing transmissions -- but if you want an endorsement of your moral fiber, then as a practical matter you should look elsewhere. The imprimatur of Vlad the Impaler is not an asset in today's job market. (Assuming that they're still not hiring at Enron.)

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Boston Red Sox' celebration after they won the World Series misspelled the surname of the New York Yankees pitcher who threw a perfect game in 1956, causing Yogi Berra to jump into his arms. He was Don Larsen, not Larson.

title: Cool as a Cucumber Roll
description: Since Cleopatra had her bath in donkey's milk, there has been no end to the items that have migrated from larder to dressing table: cucumbers on eyes, honey on face, egg yolk in hair. The restless minds of the cosmetics industry, eager to profit from this desire to nourish while bypassing the alimentary canal, have found ever more ingenious ways to use food. Early applications were desserty treats you could indulge in without worrying about calories: crme-brule soap, strawberries-and-cream bubble bath, pia-colada shampoo. Then there were the things made from the health foods you should have been eating but weren't -- oatmeal baths, green-tea face masks.

title: Seminars and Workshops on Co-ops and Condos
description: The Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums will hold its 24th annual housing conference on Nov. 14.

title: Footwear Darwinism: Doc Martens Evolve
description: I CAME late to the cult of Dr. Martens. I had never liked labels on my footwear. I was afraid of skinheads, who were the shoe's leading fans. Then in 1992, during the summer of the second Lollapalooza tour, I dropped into a store on Lower Broadway to try on a pair.

title: The Remix; Hidden Valley
description: About three hours' drive north of San Francisco, the Anderson Valley is to Napa what the North Fork of Long Island is to the Hamptons: smart and blissfully unpretentious, the land that yuppies forgot. Thanks to its remote location and a local economy favoring the barter system, this is where you can trade a few cases of your vineyard's pinot noir for midwife services. The valley's neighboring "towns" -- Boonville and Philo (combined population: 1,400) -- offer food and wine with a rich-hippie flourish. It's the ideal place to drop out and fill up for a weekend. Some local attractions:

title: This Time, 85-Year-Old Is Fighting for Herself
description: It is decidedly not typical behavior to enjoy a court fight with your landlord. Then again, Florence M. Rice is not a typical woman.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER--Richard. 39 years ago you left me. Ever remembered with love, my precious son. Mom

title: Vera Wu, Harold Spiegle
description: Vera Y-E Wu and Harold Mark Spiegle were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. J. Anthony Zito, an interfaith minister, at the Pratt Mansions in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the Election Party, an organization that seeks to encourage nonpartisan celebrations on Election Day, misspelled the name of the restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, that was the site of such an event on Tuesday. It is Madiba, not Mandiba.

title: Labor Contract for Orchestra in Chicago
description: The musicians of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra ratified a new three-year contract on Saturday that includes a reduction in the number of full-time members and a wage freeze the first year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, ALBERT L., ESQ.
description: LEVY--Albert L., Esq. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Albie, a gentleman, scholar and patriot. We will miss his wit, wisdom and humor. We grieve with his devoted wife Barbara. Maxine, Sam and Family

title: BEST SELLERS: November 7, 2004
description: Weeks

title: Scott Rudin's Three Ring Holiday Circus
description: TO the unpracticed eye, the unifying principle of this season's crop of movies might seem to be Jude Law: by the time Christmas rolls around, he will have appeared in six films this year. But behind the scenes, there is a less fine-boned hand at work.

title: The Search for Moe, Tattoo Remorse
description: NOBODY WAS HERE: 7th Grade in the Life of Me, Penelope By Alison Pollet Orchard Books ($15.95, hardcover)

title: Fitting Award: State Police Most Dapper in the Country
description: The Connecticut State Police was recently voted the best dressed force in the nation by the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers and Distributors, a nonprofit industry trade group. The department also won the honor in 1995.

title: Winner's Circle for Beef Fans
description: HEY, big spender, do I have a restaurant for you. Maxwell and Dunne's, a stylish new steakhouse, has recently opened on the ground floor of the Race Palace in Plainview. Upstairs is a luxurious Off Track Betting facility. There are hundreds of screens, a 120-foot video wall, carpeting and waitresses to serve drinks and bar snacks. On Sundays, football fans share the space and watch games on the big wall-size screen.

title: Bidding on 'The Curse' in 7 Figures
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 6 - The papers that sent Babe Ruth to the New York Yankees and began the legendary curse that kept the Boston Red Sox from winning the World Series are for sale on the Internet auction site eBay. By Saturday the bidding on the original contract that sold Ruth had exceeded $1 million.

title: Maryanne Coyle, Hilary Andrews
description: Maryanne Elizabeth Coyle, a daughter of Anne K. Coyle and Hugh F. Coyle of Brooklandville, Md., was married yesterday to Hilary Buckminster Andrews, a son of Elizabeth Scott Andrews of Hoboken, N.J., and the late Martin Andrews. The Rev. Kendrick J. Forbes officiated at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Cathedral in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Improved Suns Trounce the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 6 - The season has just started, but the Phoenix Suns already appear to be one of the most improved teams in the N.B.A.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday 31 about friends and informal advisers to State Senator Richard J. Codey, the Essex County Democrat who is the incoming interim governor, misidentified the most recent previous governor from Essex. He was Thomas H. Kean, who served from 1982 to 1990; Brendan T. Byrne, also from Essex, left office in January 1982.

title: When the Judge Sledgehammered The Gadfly
description: ELENA SASSOWER, a White Plains Hebrew-school teacher and judicial activist, is -- as even her staunchest defenders note -- something of a handful. Her conversational style can best be described as relentless, and her passions, expressed in long recitations, can exhaust the most earnest listener.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIZZ, RACHEL
description: SPIZZ--Rachel. Beloved wife of Reuben, mother of Norman and Mara, Michael and Donna, Gwendolyn, and the late Lynn. Grandmother of Marna, Helene, Austin, Hilary, Kellyn and Kelly. Best friend of Lucy. She will be deeply missed. Graveside services to be held on Sunday, November 7, at 1 PM, at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Wendy Rothschild, Jason Heltzer
description: Wendy Charlotte Rothschild, a daughter of Betty Rothschild and Judge James S. Rothschild of Short Hills, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Marc Heltzer, a son of Ruth and Lester A. Heltzer of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Michael P. Sternfield officiated at the Harold Washington Library Center in Chicago.

title: 'Fortress America': Just Like in the Movies
description: Surely one of the more bizarre initiatives of the Department of Homeland Security is its entertainment liaison office, designed, according to Matthew Brzezinski, to make it "look good in the movies." But if FORTRESS AMERICA: On the Front Lines of Homeland Security -- An Inside Look at the Coming Surveillance State (Bantam, $25) is any indication, much about protecting the nation against terrorist plotters already lends itself to dramatization at a theater near you.

title: Scented Sweats
description: Wondering what to wear for that big date at the gym? The new Active Cat line of workout wear from Puma is infused with a bracing but not overpowering ginseng scent, intended to mask body odors while delivering aromatherapeutic benefits (ginseng is reputed to simultaneously calm and energize).

title: 'Unforgivable Blackness': The Great Black Hope
description: UNFORGIVABLE BLACKNESS The Rise and Fall of Jack Johnson. By Geoffrey C. Ward. Illustrated. 492 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

title: A Dream Life Freud Would Have Envied
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y. - CLOTAIRE RAPAILLE, a French-born medical anthropologist and psychiatrist, is paid top dollar by American corporations to tell them what consumers want from their coffee, toilet paper, artificial sweetener, luggage, cheese and political candidates -- but most of all in their cars.

title: Bulls Rookie Keeps Ear on Telephone and Eyes on Court
description: Andres Nocioni was a nervous wreck last week, the first of his N.B.A. career. But his anxiety has nothing to do with basketball, the sport he has played professionally in his native Argentina and in Spain the last nine years.

title: Men of the Cloth
description: When did men's fashion become more dapper than rapper? After years of wearing clothes to express youthful athleticism and alienation, today's young buck wants to dress more like an English gentleman, it seems, than as a mad dog shooting hoops in the midday sun.

title: Two on the Aisle
description: The Samurai Shopper is itching to know: why can't you compare apples to oranges? There's an old Pink Floyd tune with the refrain: "Apples and oranges, apples and oranges." It was a flop. Why? Czanne fared better, slathering oil onto canvas and calling the stunning result, "Still Life With Apples and Oranges." A Ukrainian artist, Ludmila Bespruzhnaya, also painted a canvas with that exact name, but comparing her work to Czanne's is like, you know. . . Surely if you can croon about lowly fruits, or create masterworks sung and unsung by artfully juxtaposing apples and oranges, I can offer a measly comparison or two.

title: Domination Isn't Dull When There's Competition
description: Contrary to popular belief, in motor racing a dominating team or driver does not necessarily mean a boring show.

title: Maura Leeds, Richard Rosberger
description: Maura Beth Leeds and Richard Edward Rosberger, lawyers in Manhattan, were married there yesterday. Rabbi Ruth A. Zlotnick officiated at the Michelson Studio.

title: Ignorance Is No Obstacle
description: There was a time when students taking the SAT needed only two things: a sharpened No. 2 pencil and steady nerves. That day is long gone. Over the years, the SAT has generated a test-preparation industry that lives off the Educational Testing Service -- creators of the test for the College Board -- the way that tick birds live off the back of a rhino. A bewildering profusion of products and services promise desperate students that they can learn the secrets of the test and raise their scores. Help comes in the form of books -- some as thick as the telephone directory of a major city -- hand-held computers, compact discs, online tutoring services and face-to-face classes. The impending arrival of the new SAT has thrown the test-prep industry into a frenzy, inspiring a slew of revised test-prep products and a welter of snazzy new electronic games and devices.

title: The Confessions of John Patrick Shanley
description: How can you pass up a chance to attend a family reunion with an Oscar winner who got up and thanked ''everybody who ever punched or kissed me in my life and everybody who I ever punched or kissed?'' Think of the drama, the intrigue, the ice packs. But in a park in Rockland County, N.Y., on a September Saturday, there was nary an Irish temper in sight. The men in John Patrick Shanley's family toted bags of charcoal, raw meat and tongs. The women, like the Italian characters in Shanley's original screenplay for ''Moonstruck,'' unwrapped enormous bowls of pasta salad and oversize platters of deli sandwiches, more than enough for 40. Everyone shared, hugged, talked, showed pictures and yelled at their kids to stay out of the brook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOEL, MATHILDE (NEE MADY)
description: JOEL--Mathilde (nee Mady). 81, of Ft. Lee and Coconut Creek, FL, died Saturday, October 30, 2004. Born in Salonika, Greece, Mrs. Joel lived in the Bronx before moving to Ft. Lee 30 years ago and Coconut Creek, FL, for the past five years. She and her late husband, Manfred, were the founders of Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem, benefactors of an auditorium and many youth projects in Natanya, Israel, and active in the United Jewish Appeal of Bergen County. Mr. and Mrs. Joel were survivors of the Bergen Belsen concentration camp. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law Ralph and Rosalie Joel of Watchung, NJ, and two grandchildren, Jennifer and Haley. Services were held Monday, November 1, 2004, and burial was at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus. Memorial contributions can be made to the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, 333 7th Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

title: Roots
description: You don't ever want to drop a sweet potato," Dale Smith said, his cowboy boots half sunk in just-turned soil. "You just don't." At this early stage in the harvest, even the slightest nick can become an un-pie-friendly bruise by Thanksgiving. Short and square, in crisp jeans and a denim shirt, the 60-year-old Smith has been farming this Southern root crop for almost half his life. Back in the 1940's, his four uncles began planting sweet potatoes in the sandy loam of Van Zandt county in Texas, about 50 miles east of Dallas; today it's the state's top-producing county. As a boy, Smith helped them harvest, scrambling on the ground to collect the potatoes in the wake of a horse-drawn sled. He swore he would never go into the business.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Remix; Books for Cooks
description: Time to fill up your bedside table. This fall's food books are long on delicious words and short on ingredients. We've plucked our favorites from the racks and added a few from the archives.

title: The Week Ahead
description: MOSH EARLY AND OFTEN -- Eminem's "Mosh," a video screed against President Bush that has been racing around the Internet, may not have prompted a groundswell of youth voting but it created enormous interest in his forthcoming record, "Encore." The Detroit rapper moved up the record's release date four days, to this Friday, in part because the Bush video is not the only thing being downloaded. Much of the new album was on the Web last week, free for the grabbing.

title: Bush Prepares for Changes in Programs and Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - President Bush's aides are preparing the groundwork to move ahead with his plans to overhaul the tax code and Social Security, as cabinet members await signals from him about who will remain on his second-term team, Republican advisers and officials said.

description: PETER GELB may be taking over as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, but until Aug. 1, 2006, Joseph Volpe is still in charge. Last week Mr. Volpe spoke to Anne Midgette about his successor and his own 16-year tenure at the Met.

title: Like a Box of Chocolates
description: So many good things seem to happen to James V. Kimsey that he compares himself to Forrest Gump, the movie bumpkin who inadvertently became a hero in Vietnam, got rich in an unlikely business and found satisfaction through volunteer work in his hometown.

title: The Minimum Wage Is Just for Teenagers? Well, Not Exactly
description: President Bush has a lengthy to-do list for his second term, but it's a pretty safe bet that it does not include raising the minimum wage, which has stood at $5.15 an hour for seven years now.

title: DVD's to Put Under Trees; Remember When They Were Tall & Tan & Young & Handsome? Sigh...
description: BOB & CAROL & TED & ALICE (Columbia, Nov. 16) -- Paul Mazursky's "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice" is often thought of -- perhaps mostly by people who haven't seen it -- as a period piece. Much more than that, it's one of the great American movies. In this 1969 satire of the 60's self-enlightenment craze (and the self-righteous proselytizing that often came with it), Bob (Robert Culp), a documentary filmmaker, and his wife, Carol (Natalie Wood), trek to an Esalen-like retreat as research for one of Bob's projects. Although they're skeptical at first -- how could they not be, when one encounter-group denizen announces, "I'm Myrna -- I came because I want a better orgasm" -- they end up deeply affected, and return home to share their newfound enlightenment with their best friends, Ted (Elliott Gould) and Alice (Dyan Cannon).

description: Jessica Gail Young and Jed Weintrob were married yesterday evening. Cantor Richard Botton officiated at Cipriani 200 Fifth Avenue, a caterer in New York.

title: Hardcover Fiction
The Singer
description: Julie Roberts once lived a double life, answering phones for the chairman of Universal Music Group in Nashville by day and singing country-blues songs in bars by night. Last year, Ms. Roberts's boss played her demo tape and was smitten by her rich, earthy voice before he realized that it belonged to his assistant.

title: In Little Rock
description: Six bridges span the scenic Arkansas River in downtown Little Rock, but soon there will be a new bridge in town -- one that wasn't built to cross a body of water, but instead to connect Little Rock to the rest of the world.

title: The Remix; One-Two Punch
description: Ever since I got in the habit of whipping up big bowls of mysterious, powerful punch, my parties have been more fun and less work. It has saved me from hustling as a bartender all night and has kept guests from draining my expensive Scotch. It has also led to some elaborate recipes, including one based on two kinds of fresh-brewed tea and another made several days beforehand to gather strength. When it came to nonalcoholic beverages, though, I'd rather plunk down a warm bottle of Diet Coke and call it a night.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Oct. 24 with an article about the Creole Nature Trail in Louisiana misidentified a butterfly at the Peveto Woods Bird and Butterfly Sanctuary, just off Highway 82 along the trail. It is a Gulf fritillary, not a monarch.

title: I, Pee-wee
description: IT was two days before Halloween, and Paul Reubens was one of the few people in Los Angeles without a costume. Seated in his publicist's office, in flannel shirt and corduroy pants too big for his slender frame, the 52-year-old actor and comedian looked like someone without much interest in playing dress-up or pulling pranks. He looked an awful lot like an adult.

title: Skiers' Dream: A White November
description: Unexpected early and heavy snowfall in a few Western states means two things for skiers and snowboarders: some of the earliest opening dates in decades and limited-time discounts at many resorts. Just don't expect all their facilities, like ski schools, to be operating yet.

title: Spano's Future Hangs On Absentee Ballot Count
description: WHITE PLAINS - NICHOLAS A. SPANO, the Republican state senator from Yonkers, seemed nearly invincible. The third most powerful member of the Senate, Mr. Spano had won nine terms in a row, solidifying his hold on the heavily Democratic 35th Senate District with his good-guy aura, a raft of moderate positions and a hefty war chest.

title: Bickering Iraqis Strive to Build Voting Coalition
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 6 - With three months to go until Iraq's first democratic elections, established Shiite parties and powerful upstarts are feuding, prompting the leading Shiite cleric to try to pull them together to make sure that they clearly dominate the new government.

title: Macedonia's Ethnic Peace Faces a Test in a Referendum
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Nov. 6 - Macedonians will vote Sunday in a referendum that is likely to determine whether a three-year peace agreement to end ethnic violence in this former Yugoslav state will remain in place.

description: 'Elemental' Miranda Fine Arts, 6 North Pearl Street, Port Chester, (914)935-9362. Through Nov. 13.

title: As Manufacturing Fades, Commuters Fill the Gap
description: WEATHERED American flags flutter from the porches of nearly every home and many utility poles on Main Street in Sayreville, N.J. Streets have long, difficult-to-pronounce names, such as Wieczorkowski (that's vitz-ur-KOW-skee) Avenue, because for the last 40 years, the borough has named new streets after local soldiers who were killed in action or after families in which at least six members served in the armed forces.

title: Even Amid All the Violence, Israelis Keep the Games Going
description: During World War II, no matter how serious the battles, chess did not slow down in the Soviet Union. Indeed, far from the bombs and cannons, the best players were ensconced in Arkhangelsk in the extreme north. They left their mark: The Arkhangelsk Variation of the Ruy Lopez was hatched there.

title: Sticker Shock for a Former New Yorker
description: WITH a full six months before he needed to move to New York from Dallas, Scott Bernstein wasn't concerned about finding a place to live. Neither was his mother, Charlotte Bernstein, who would be taking charge of his apartment hunt.

title: Open Space Is an Election Day Winner
description: EXTENDING an unbroken history of support in elections for environmental measures, Long Island voters by lopsided margins Tuesday embraced a record $255 million in bonds for preserving farms, fields and other open spaces.

title: The Election's Over. Are You Still Losing It?
description: STEVEN STOSNY, a psychologist and anger specialist in Washington, began treating patients with political rage problems during the battle over President Bill Clinton's impeachment. After the presidential election on Tuesday, he started receiving calls once again from livid Democrats, including a Kerry campaign staff member who said she was furious with George W. Bush, and was taking it out on her husband.

description: LOVE is like war: easy to begin but very hard to stop," H. L. Mencken said.

title: The Reviews Are In
description: The attraction of study guides like Cliffs Notes is obvious: they promise you the ability to talk about or write about a book like, say, "Moby Dick" without actually having to read a book like, say, "Moby Dick." But study guides for movies? Who would rather read a summary of plot, characters and themes rather than actually watch "Casablanca" or "The Matrix"? Barnes & Noble is betting that there are film students, or perhaps development executives, who want just that: it recently added film study guides to the Shakespeare and math notes already available on its Web site SparkNotes.com. Here are excerpts from the 19 guides now available.

description: Ivory Coast jets attacked French forces, killing nine peacekeepers and an American civilian. The French later destroyed the aircraft, apparently at the order of President Jacques Chirac.
