Paid Notice: Deaths   DE WAHL, LOIS D.
description: DE WAHL--Lois D., of Vero Beach, Florida, wife for 51 years of David A., mother of David A. Jr., Duncan C. and Elizabeth La Vallee and grandmother of five, died October 30, at age 82. Born in Delaware County, NY, grew up on a dairy farm. Graduate of Delaware Academy, Delhi, New York, SUNY at Albany and Columbia University. Worked in publishing until birth of her first child, lived with her family first in NYC, then Briarcliff Manor, NY, Grosse Pointe Farms, MI, and, for about 20 years, HoHo-Kus, NJ. Always a tireless helper, often a self-effacing leader. Memorial service on November 13 at 11 AM at Community Church of Upper Ridgewood, Ridgewood, NJ.

title: After Mixed Results, Suozzi Presses On to Fix Albany
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 5 - For months, Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, has argued that the state is dysfunctional, and he has called for ousting certain incumbents. He formed the Fix Albany political action committee to support challengers, won backing from former New York City Mayor Edward I. Koch and raised $150,000 for the campaign.

title: Cleaner Water, Fewer Homes
description: Correction Appended

title: Cookie Master
description: Deceptive simplicity, while high praise in the fashion pages, is dirty pool in the kitchen. Anyone who has gnashed his teeth over a pie crust or baked a doorstop of a poundcake has crossed that fine line between the simple and the impossible. Even butter, sugar, flour and eggs, the most wholesome of ingredients, can behave deviously. Apply heat to sugar, and it melts. Keep going, and it gilds. Butter can be a cold, pure white paste or a liquid gold redolent of hazelnuts. No wonder that shortbread, with its four ingredients, can be more taxing than a tagine, which can have as many as 30.

title: Before Helping the Red Sox to a Championship, Schilling Helped Himself
description: CURT SCHILLING, who was instrumental in helping the Boston Red Sox win the World Series for the first time in 86 years, had a better year than people realize.

description: New Tumblers for every toast (stems not included).

title: Invading Maine
description: To the Editor: As recounted in "Through Artists' Eyes" (Sept. 19), about Monhegan Island in Maine, the writer, John Freeman Gill, may have introduced more than the off-season tourist as an invasive species along Maine's rugged coastline. He carried a fuzzy caterpillar from Manhattan on a 500-mile journey before releasing it on the island at the end of a weekend escape from urban life.

title: Officer Who Says She Was Raped at Base Is Classified as AWOL for Failing to Return
description: A lieutenant in the New Jersey National Guard has been accused of going AWOL because she has refused for the last two months to return to an Army base in Mississippi where, she says, a fellow officer raped her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENROD, SALLY
description: EISENROD--Sally. On November 5, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Loving mother of Michael and Nancy. Dear mother-in-law of Ginger Eisenrod and Howard Hartley. Adoring grandmother of Seth and Alexis. Greatgrandmother. Services Wednesday, 12:45 pm, at "The Riverside," 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Big Bucks Stop Here
description: New York got a sneak peek in recent days at what to expect in next year's city election. It was not a pretty sight. In exchanges reminiscent of the mud-wrestling that marked the last campaign, old rivalries flared up when members of the City Council used a vote on campaign finance reform to attack Mayor Michael R. description: Tucked in the heart of the Western Hemisphere's largest city is a food fanatic's died-and-gone-to-market-heaven: two blocks of the most authentic comida Mexicana that a peso can buy. The Mercado San Juan -- in the Centro neighborhood of Mexico City -- is to traditional Mexican markets what Citarella is to 7-Eleven. Located close to the Palacio de Bellas Artes, and not far from the Zocalo, the city's main plaza, it contains a spectacular collection of edibles so beautiful that they're almost a shame to eat (but eat them you will): vibrant chilies, lush mushrooms, strange tropical fruits and gulf shrimp the size of a boomerang. Step outside San Juan into the bustling streets surrounding the market to sample spicy-sweet moles, stock up on aged tequila and sip a leisurely caf con leche beneath the royal palms in San Juan park. Oh, and don't leave without picking up a lime juicer. KEN BENSINGER

title: DVD's to Put Under Trees; Frankly, It's Better
description: GONE WITH THE WIND (Warner Brothers, Nov. 9) -- DVD consumers are bombarded with so many special editions that it's easy for them to believe it's all a scheme to pick their pockets. This four-disc set marking the 65th anniversary of "Gone With the Wind" is the real deal, a stunning restoration that corrects decades of abuses made in the name of modernization. One of the extras, "Restoring a Legend," has its share of horror stories and heroes, like the music editor who ignored an order to throw out the old soundtrack. He deliberately mislabeled it, stuck it in a can at the back of a vault and kept track of it for decades. What he saved provides this DVD with the original monaural soundtrack (it can also be played in Dolby digital). But the real hero is the chief technology officer of Warner Brothers, Chris Cookson, who found a way to realign the three strips of film used in the Technicolor process. The result: a more crisply defined image, and a richer one, with luxurious colors and textures. And for once, the extras aren't just filler. They include mini biographies of notable cast members, newsreels of the 1939 Atlanta premiere and film of the 1961 Atlanta revival marking the centennial of the Civil War. And what of the movie itself? For all the weight of its classic status and its epic length, it remains a great feat of movie storytelling, and a hugely satisfying entertainment. And next to "Cold Mountain," with its genteel grotesqueries (Nicole Kidman offering to bring lemonade to the "Negroes"), the romanticism of "Gone With the Wind" seems much more honest. CHARLES TAYLOR

description: MUNGER -- Dorothy. The house of Steinway & Sons notes with great sorrow the passing of the American pianist, Dorothy Munger, in Indianapolis on November 5, 2004 at the age of 89. Dorothy Munger was a member of our Steinway Artist family for more than fifty years. Born in Fostoria, Ohio, Mrs. Munger started piano lessons at the age of six and while in Junior High School provided music for silent films. She also regularly accompanied Charles Munger, an older boy who played trumpet, and years later she and Charlie married. Dorothy was for many years principal pianist of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, and she was one of the most beloved teachers and mentors in the country. Dorothy Munger was a member of the Steinway Artists' Committee for the Steinway Centennial in 1953, and she was a cherished friend to our firm throughout her life. We will miss her, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to Nancy, Jim, and her entire family. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, VP, Worldwide Concert & Artist Activities

She became famous in her native England in 1998 with a simulated family portrait of Princess Diana, Dodi al-Fayed and "child" (right), an image included in her exhibition "Election Year 2004" at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea through Dec. 4. The show, which opened Oct. 21, is mostly about "George W. Bush": reading on the toilet, cavorting with belly dancers, putting a hand on the knee of "Condoleezza Rice." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURNBULL, ELIZABETH HOWE
description: TURNBULL -- Elizabeth Howe, 92, of Teviot Farms in Far Hills, died on Tuesday, November 2nd, 2004 at her home. She was born in Nashville, TN on December 22nd, 1911, a daughter of the late Harry and Elizabeth Thomas Howe. She had been a resident of Far Hills for the past 70 years. She was a graduate of Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA receiving a bachelor's degree in Art History in 1933. Mrs. Turnbull co-owned and operated an interior design business in Far Hills for many years. She was a member of the Colony Club, the Somerset Hills Branch of the Garden Club of America, a member and elder of the Lamington Presbyterian Church and a volunteer with the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills in Bernardsville. Mrs. Turnbull had a strong affection for nature and the outdoors. She traveled extensively with her husband, enjoyed sailing and was adept at navigation. She was predeceased by her husband of 68 years, William Turnbull, whom she married on April 2nd, 1934. He died October 23rd, 2002. She was also predeceased by her eldest son, William Turnbull, Jr. who died in 1997. She is survived by a son, Thomas Ramsay Turnbull of Carbondale, CO, two daughters Ellen Turnbull Edwards of Marshall, CA and Margaret Turnbull Simon of San Francisco, CA, two daughters-in-law Rosamond P. Turnbull of Carbondale, CO and Mary E. Griffin of Sausalito, CA, a sister Margaret Howe Sloan of Nashville, TN, twelve grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Private graveside services were held at the Lamington Presbyterian Church Memorial Garden on Saturday, November 6th. A memorial service at the family farm will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills, 12 Olcott Avenue, Bernardsville, New Jersey 07924 or the Upper Raritan Watershed Association, P.O. Box 273, Gladstone, NJ 07934.

That's a pity because, as a retrospective that month at Lincoln Center revealed, Mr. Brisseau, 60, who began making movies in the 1980's, is one of the major European filmmakers now working. He is also one of the hardest to get a handle on, perhaps because his films straddle opposites. Ostensibly naturalistic, Mr. Brisseau's movies also contain elements of the fantastic: in "Secret Things," a veiled angel of death, complete with raven, hovers in the corners of some scenes. Movies that appear at first to be sober-minded and coolly intellectual plunge into baroque, overheated scenarios that teeter on the ludicrous.

title: Behind the Writer Behind Peter Pan
description: LONDON - BECAUSE it is impossible to gain access to the closed set of a writer's imagination, filmmakers love to try. That there is perhaps nothing less cinematic than a writer practicing his craft means that movies about writers have developed their own set of clichs -- the gnawing of pencils, the throwing of endless balled-up drafts into overflowing wastebaskets, the feverish pacing in low-lighted rooms. In the movies, the solitary act of communing with the muse is often portrayed with the forced passion of an obligatory love scene. And the very idea that we want our literary idols humanized is challenged by the reality that it is almost always as disappointing to see a beloved author incarnated on screen as it is to meet him or her in real life.

With the belief that "living well is its own reward," Donna Wingate and Mary Ellen Carroll have created Itinerant Gastronomy (e-mail info@itinerantgastronomy.com), a road show that prepares gourmet meals wherever the opportunity is presented. Using portable hot plates, they've prepared crab cakes with aioli for a gathering of city planners, shopkeepers and artists atop the abandoned elevated railroad tracks in the meatpacking district. They've dished out osso buco for Italian villagers. Most recently, they've served six courses to engineers perched on the Goethals Bridge. "Humbly bringing people together around a table contributes to the feeling of connectedness so essential to our well-being," Carroll says. Comfort food coming soon to a cubicle near you. title: The Masterpiece in the Hallway

The studio still maintained rehearsal halls lined with mirrors and ballet barres, and little clouds of antique dust would explode from the floors with each heel-stomp of the time-step. My enthusiasm for the movie kept me tap-dancing to exhaustion, acting my head off (which I learned later in my career was not the best approach) and enthralled with the heady stream of visitors -- which included Cary Grant -- who would come by to see the nostalgically staged musical numbers. The director of the film, Herbert Ross, along with his wife, the former prima ballerina Nora Kaye, were highly regarded in the loftier circles of the New York dance scene, and it was they who took me to my first ballet.

title: Wonder Bread
description: Poor white bread. America's culinary ambassador has gone stale, and Atkins dieters may have driven the maker of Wonder Bread into Chapter 11. The term, synonymous with something middlebrow, is an insult in a culture that celebrates the high and the low. But there is white bread, and then there is white bread. "It took 50 years for Wonder Bread to come in and out and artisanal bread to come back into style," says Amy Scherber, of Amy's Bread. An advocate of healthful whole wheat when she began baking in 1992, she soon saw white's virtues; baguettes and rustic loaves are her best sellers. "The blank canvas for a bread baker is to make a perfect white loaf," she says. At a recent exhibition in Paris, it was the muse for Jean Paul Gaultier, who had bakers and pattern makers design everything from btards to Birkin bags. White bread also inspired the photographer Kevin Van Aelst. For his series "The Golden Spiral," he sliced a piece of Wonder Bread ("iconic of everything American," he says) into fractals to explore the philosophical question When does a fish cease to be a fish? Or a loaf cease to be a loaf? When it stops making us hungry . . . that will be the day. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: My Hands Are Tied
description: I can't get the man's cries for help out of my head. "Please help me, you have to help me, what will happen to my family?" I tried to get him to calm down, and it didn't work. I simply had to hang up. Then a woman called from her hospital bed at Columbia Presbyterian. She had been unconscious for several days. When she woke up, her friends told her that her husband had been taken by immigration. "I need him," she told me. These tragedies are haunting. I have one client whose parents, ethnic Albanians, fled Yugoslavia before she was born. She's been here for 35 of her 36 years. She was convicted of some drug felonies, went to prison, came out clean and stayed that way. But immigration authorities still arrested her, and she was ordered removed. There are too many of these stories every day.

description: An article on Oct. 24 about fading loyalty among fans and players of the New Jersey Nets, with the team planning to move to Brooklyn, misstated the surname of one of the team's new players. He is Rodney Buford, not Damon.

title: Two Airlines Try Out A la Carte Diversions
description: Continuing a pattern of  la carte pricing in the airline industry, at least two carriers are testing fee-based services for another amenity: in-flight entertainment.

title: Baghdad Airport: 5 Miles. Proceed With Caution.
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - THE first real sign that I was back in Iraq came about three miles down the road from Baghdad International Airport. On the north side of the highway sat the scorched hulk of an armored Humvee. It was mid-September, and I had flown in right after one of the insurgency's bloodiest days, with scores killed in attacks across Iraq. In one assault, guerrillas detonated a bomb next to an American military convoy along the airport highway.

title: The Other National Conversation
description: The United States is a prayerful nation. Eight out of 10 Americans say they pray daily, or at least weekly. Only 9 percent say they never pray. The most commonly mentioned reasons for prayer, according to a 2002 Christian Science Monitor survey, are to seek guidance (cited by 62 percent of the prayerful), to give thanks or praise (54 percent) and to beg for forgiveness (47 percent). Some Americans admit to asking specific favors from the deity they address, whether healing (45 percent) or something else (43 percent). According to a study by the National Institutes of Health, the use of prayer for healing easily outstrips other alternative medical therapies like acupuncture, yoga and massage.

title: How to Make Albany Behave
description: Talk of reform in Albany is everywhere these days. Indeed, recent developments have created what could be a "perfect storm" for legislative reform.

title: A Mundane Street Gains European Grace
description: ONCE a depressed stretch of nondescript small businesses, the four blocks on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn from Hoyt Street to Third Avenue have experienced a revitalization that even longtime residents of the surrounding brownstone neighborhoods find surprising, as if a dowdy neighborhood dowager had slipped away for a bit and come back with a Botoxed visage and a Prada-sheathed body.

title: Home On the Range
description: These state-of-the-art kitchens offer more than just creature comforts.

title: Knicks Embarrassed in Opener at the Garden
description: The masses descended again on Madison Square Garden last night, 19,763 strong, all humming with optimism and anticipation. There was a new Knicks era to cheer, or so they had heard, but the cheers never got past the first quarter.

title: Paving Paradise or Improving It?
description: KENT FALLS STATE PARK, which has more than 100,000 visitors each year, is perhaps a victim of its own success. Foot traffic on a rustic trail beside the picturesque series of waterfalls has warped parts of the trail into jagged and crooked obstacles, damaged a fish habitat and injured trees.

title: Dear Mr. President
description: COLLEGE students may be the hot demographic for politicians, but they're a tough group for pollsters to track down. The reason is simple: most lack the home phone number needed for random sampling. To get a sense of what the cellphone generation is thinking, Education Life conducted face-to-face interviews in October at 10 campuses: Princeton, Harvard, Ohio State University, Baylor University (Waco, Tex.), University of Texas at Austin, University of Florida, University of Georgia, University of California at Santa Barbara, University of Illinois at Chicago and City University of New York-City College. Interviewers questioned 112 women and 121 men, freshmen to seniors. The students were asked what personal and political issues mattered most to them, about the war in Iraq and about long-term job prospects. In general, they were a hopeful bunch; more than 80 percent were optimistic about their futures. The looming exception was jobs, which more than 40 percent thought would be hard to find after graduation.

title: Somewhere, Inside the Rainbow, Blue Boys Fly
description: THAT Todd is one colorful character. First of all, he's blue, which may be why he sees things a little differently than everyone else. He paints a world of fantastic ideas on an electronic drawing pad while wearing underwear on his head. And with the help of his friends -- Pickle, Sophie, Stella and Mitzi-- he has discovered that nothing is impossible. It simply may not happen the way he thought it would.

title: Alter Egos That Bark
description: I had known my boyfriend, Ira, only a month when his dog, Byron, a Cairn terrier, tried to take a nip out of the back of my pants leg as I was leaving a dinner party at his apartment. Nothing personal. "He doesn't like it when people leave," Ira said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 24 about the choreographer Ralph Lemon misidentified the dancer in the foreground. He was Darrell Jones; Mr. Lemon was visible at the far right.

title: Double-Deckers
description: To the Editor: Thanks for "Decline of London's Double-Deckers" (Correspondent's Report, Oct. 10). Alan Cowell quotes Nick Ferrari of LBC Radio: "Can you imagine what the citizens of San Francisco would do if their mayor suggested scrapping the cable cars ?"

title: Who's Bright Idea Was This, Anyway?
description: THE fall foliage season seemed particularly lovely and vivid this year. Hope you got a good look at it, because by the time Paul B. Israel and Theresa M. Collins get through, there may be no trees left. They will all have been turned into paper to print the impressive books these two scholars and others are extracting from the historical record left behind by Thomas Alva Edison.

title: Jordan Kenna, Lee Smith
description: Jordan Whidden Kenna, a daughter of Joan and James Kenna of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Dr. Lee Phillip Smith, a son of Carol and Steven Smith of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David Rees, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Biltmore Hotel in Miami.

title: Ashley Dodd, Ogden Phipps II
description: Ashley Bolan Dodd, the daughter of Kathleen P. Dodd of Boston, was married yesterday to Ogden Phipps II, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills Phipps of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Bill J. Leonard, a Baptist minister and the dean of the divinity school at Wake Forest University, officiated at the Gasparilla Inn in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: Why Your Stock Index Fund Is Lagging the Market
description: Correction Appended

title: Finding Her Brazilian Groove
description: Correction Appended

title: The Remix; Shovel It In
description: A new spoon is appearing on New York's best-set tables. The tiny, shovel-like utensil with a flattened tip, called paletta gelato in Italy and favored by serious gelatteria, has been spotted at Otto. Japanese chefs use a larger, spatulalike version called ichimonji for cooking and smaller ones for serving. At Masa, a flat-ended red-lacquer spoon goes with the minced toro and caviar, and a silver one is used for the exquisite grapefruit granita. Omen serves appetizers with a bamboo version. The spoons are not so easy to find here yet. The Nuovo Milano ice cream spoon by Alessi (shown here, second from right) is available at www.alessi.com; www.eurostyleimports.com; and Moss, 146 Greene Street, (212)204-7100. OLIVER SCHWANER-ALBRIGHT

title: The Enlightened M.B.A.
description: Cambridge, Mass. - IN an empty conference room at Harvard Business School, two students were redesigning the Ukrainian health care system. Dr. Ed Kanalosh, who trained to be a doctor in Ukraine, paced the room, keeping a tight grip on his Diet Coke as he practiced his pitch. He was explaining -- to an imaginary audience of judges -- how to fix his country's medical morass.

title: Bellowing Like Iron Maiden, but Very, Very Sensitive
description: WHEN quizzing Gerard Way about how he put together rock's latest best hope for revolutionizing geekdom, it's important to give him plenty of time before he wolfs out, slinks into his ticked-off rock 'n' roll skin.

title: State Officials Criticize Medicare Benefit Wording
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - The nation's insurance commissioners say the federal Medicare agency has made misleading statements about the new drug benefit in an effort to persuade people to sign up.

title: Leaders From Afar Bolstering a Gang
description: Correction Appended

title: A Twin Peek: What the Stars Do at N.Y.U.
description: WHAT might you study in college when you already have a $1 billion retail empire that includes your own clothing line, home video business and Cool Bubble toothpaste label?

title: Edie Falco, Unmarried to the Mob
description: THE cheery applause celebrities get as they make an entrance in a Broadway show has rarely been less appropriate than when it greeted Edie Falco at a recent preview of "'night, Mother," a play in which her character's first bit of business is to find towels so she won't ruin the carpet when she shoots herself 90 minutes later. The ovation was awkward and also late; she had been onstage for a full minute before anyone seemed to realize who she was. Maybe that was because of the way Ms. Falco moved, with none of the Carmela Soprano get-out-of-my-way hauteur that people expect. Maybe it was the relentlessly plain outfit -- a droopy cardigan, jeans, sneakers -- or the unsettling combination of downcast eyes and immobile smile with which she faced her mother, played by Brenda Blethyn, with the news of her impending suicide. Or maybe it was the sparrowy wig. Marsha Norman, who won a Pulitzer Prize for "'night, Mother" 21 years ago and has closely monitored this revival, said Ms. Falco became a different person -- the person in the script -- as soon as she put the wig on. "Edie has hair awareness," Ms. Norman said. "Anybody she plays, she really knows them from the follicle level."

title: Margot Mendoza, Joseph McGinley
description: Margot Yvette Mendoza, a daughter of Barbara K. Mendoza and Javier G. Mendoza of Jenkintown, Pa., was married Friday evening to Joseph Patrick McGinley, a son of Noreen T. McGinley and Patrick J. McGinley of Broomall, Pa. The Rev. James J. Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Philadelphia.

title: Dear Reader, Elizabeth Has Returned. And She's Wearing a Sari.
description: WHEN Jane Austen wrote "Pride and Prejudice," she struck a note that has been echoing through narratives ever since. Readers and moviegoers never tire of the lively Elizabeth Bennet as she wins, breaks and recaptures the heart of the haughty Mr. Darcy, whose vast estate and aristocratic connections, weighed against the vulgarity of her family, inspire what may be the rudest proposal in literature: "In vain I have struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you," he says, going on to dwell warmly on "his sense of her inferiority, of its being a degradation, of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination."

title: Easing Policies On Diapered Toddlers
description: JACKI SAMOLSKY still remembers how she felt almost seven years ago when she was getting ready to sign up her eldest child, now 9, for nursery school at the Greenburgh Hebrew Center in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULZ, NATALIE (NEE PLESSER)
description: SCHULZ--Natalie (nee Plesser). Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Hannah Schussel (Sandy), and Anita Goldman (Richard). Proud grandmother of Stefanie, Madeline, Jason and Selene. Dear sister of Blanche Berkman. Services today at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For information call "Sinai Chapels" 718445-0300 or 800-446-0406.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BINGER, JAMES HENRY
description: BINGER--James Henry. Born in St. Paul, MN May 16, 1916. Died peacefully at home in Minneapolis on November 3, 2004 at age 88. Graduate of Yale University, the University of Minnesota Law School and former CEO of Honeywell. He was a past member on several executive boards including 3M, Northwest Airlines and AT&T. A dedicated and passionate philanthropist, Jim served on the boards of The McKnight Foundation, International Peace Academy and Guthrie Theater. He was founder and chairman of Jujamcyn Theatre Company in New York City. He was an avid horse lover who enjoyed horse racing, playing polo and was founder of the Twin Cities Polo Club in Maple Plain and owner of Tartan Farms. Jim was a former part owner of the Minnesota Vikings and cherished cheering on his team. Preceded in death by his high school sweetheart and wife of 65 years, Virginia McKnight Binger, daughter Judy, sisters Beth Binger Harrison and Patsy McGrath. He will be dearly missed by his children Mac Binger and wife Pat and Cynthia Boynton, and grandchildren Erika Binger, Meghan Brown and husband Zeke, Ben Binger and wife Ann, Noa Staryk and husband Ted, great-grandchildren Olivia and Mac Staryk, Shayden Brown and Holden Binger; brothers Charles Robert Binger, Eugene Thomas Binger, and wife Rebecca. Memorial service 1pm Monday at St. Martin's by-the-Lake Epispocal Church, Minnetonka Beach. Reception to follow 3:30pm at the Minneapolis Club. Private entombment Sunset Memorial Park. Memorials preferred to Guthrie Theater, International Peace Academy of New York City or Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation, Minneapolis. For inquires call David Lee Funeral Home, Wayzata, MN 952-473-5577

title: Upholding Teacher Standards
description: Most New Yorkers do not realize that the state has been at the forefront of the national school reform movement since the 1990's, when the Board of Regents began to carry out a sweeping package of changes involving everything from curriculum to testing to graduation requirements. The most far-reaching reforms were aimed at the state's colleges of education, which have historically served as diploma mills that produced income for the colleges but failed to prepare teachers for the classroom.

title: Dear New York: Some Feel Your Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: The Confessions of John Patrick Shanley
description: How can you pass up a chance to attend a family reunion with an Oscar winner who got up and thanked "everybody who ever punched or kissed me in my life and everybody who I ever punched or kissed?" Think of the drama, the intrigue, the ice packs. But in a park in Rockland County, N.Y., on a September Saturday, there was nary an Irish temper in sight. The men in John Patrick Shanley's family toted bags of charcoal, raw meat and tongs. The women, like the Italian characters in Shanley's original screenplay for "Moonstruck," unwrapped enormous bowls of pasta salad and oversize platters of deli sandwiches, more than enough for 40. Everyone shared, hugged, talked, showed pictures and yelled at their kids to stay out of the brook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRACY, ROBERT
description: TRACY--Robert. Born November 7, 1937, in Winchester, WV. Died July 29, 2004. Survived by daughters Lydia Carlston of NY, Sonja Clarke of CA and four grandchildren.

title: Cin Cin!
description: Fashion, food and design meet in the kitchen, and never have they gotten along so well.

title: My Three Kitchens
description: With her asymmetrical clothes and shock of gray in her slicked-back hair, Li Edelkoort looks like an elegant evangelist. To many in the design world, that's exactly what she is. As a leading lifestyle forecaster -- more stylish than Faith Popcorn, more esoteric than Martha Stewart -- the 54-year-old Edelkoort offers prophecies on what we will be wearing, driving and eating in the future.

title: Our National Eating Disorder
description: Michael Pollan's article was salient and witty (Oct. 17). My husband and I frequently eat at local restaurants, and we have traveled and dined extensively, worldwide. Stateside, it is with amusement that we note a 2,500-calorie, fast-food meal is almost always accompanied by a diet beverage. When traveling, we join our hosts for three substantial meals per day, enjoy healthy between-meal snacks (if energy is an issue) and always drink local beer or wine with every meal except breakfast. Mealtime is a social occasion with nary a calorie tallied. Siestas are prudently alternated with reasonable exercise, and the result is always the loss of a few pounds reflected on our home scale.

title: Mexican Town Refuses to Abandon Fallen Hero's Dream
description: SAN JOS ESTANCIA GRANDE, Mexico, Nov. 1 - There is no doubt about who executed 39-year-old Guadalupe vila Salinas, a mother of four, a beloved community worker and a candidate for mayor who was gunned down in broad daylight just days before local elections on Oct. 3 in this village of corn farmers in the southern state of Oaxaca.

title: Voters Tell Fix Albany: Heal Thyself
description: IN a election in which reform was supposed to be so popular that even longtime incumbents declared themselves reformers, Long Island voters turned out in large numbers on Tuesday to send their state and national representatives a clear message: keep your day jobs.

title: The Get; The New Collectibles
description: Sit up and smell the coffee: a stylish kitchen starts in the knife drawer.

title: That Two-Nation Feeling
description: To the Editor:

title: Asking the 'What Ifs,' Case Study by Case Study
description: PURCHASE - CLUSTERED around their makeshift conference table, Allie Feiner and her seven teammates pushed aside breakfast and got down to business. Spread out before them were sheets of information about Model E, an Internet-based car leasing service: the company had been in development for almost a year; its corporate backers were lined up; and a half million dollars had been invested. A case study, Model E offered the team of students a chance to think as if they were company executives, challenging them to pinpoint problems and solve them.

title: Pittsburgh's Steel Mills Are Gone, but Cowher's Steel Jaw Remains
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 - The steel mills have moved away, taking the smoke and the blue collars with them. Office buildings rise high along the rivers now.

title: Brooke Gincavage, Cam Robinson
description: Brooke Larson Gincavage and Camenzind Gordon Robinson were married yesterday by the Rev. Henry C. Burdick III at Trinity Episcopal Church in Branford, Conn. Canon Patrick J. Miller, also an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: The Dancing King
description: Norodom Sihamoni, who replaced his father as king of Cambodia last month, joins an illustrious roster of artist-statesmen that includes Poland's Jan Paderewski (pianist and composer), the Czech Republic's Vaclav Havel (playwright), and the man King Sihamoni replaced, Norodom Sihanouk (filmmaker, composer and poet). But King Sihamoni, a choreographer and former ballet dancer, may be the only one to have performed in tights and a tunic. Here are annotated highlights from the 51-year-old ruler's artistic curriculum vitae. THOMAS CRAMPTON

title: Staring? Me?
description: MANY New Jerseyans prefer Hoboken for people-watching, or Ridgewood, or even Spring Lake. But my favorite vantage from which to spy on human (and inhuman) kind is New Jersey Transit's rail lines. Whenever I board a New York-bound train at Princeton Junction, early on a weekday morning, I enter a world bursting with more possibilities than afforded any cultural anthropologist. And for one hour, I become an observer of every (or at least every other) human foible.

title: Bethany Jones, Eugene Mollica
description: Bethany Lynn Jones, the daughter of Constance and Richard Jones Jr. of State College, Pa., was married yesterday to Eugene Joseph Mollica, a son of Sandra and Eugene T. Mollica of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Kimberleigh Jordan, a minister of the Dutch Reformed Church, performed the ceremony at Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: Our Electors, Ourselves
description: I was happy to see Christopher Caldwell's essay (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 17), but disappointed that he seems only to see one disadvantage to the Electoral College -- that it can pick a president not receiving the most popular votes and serves, as he puts it, as a threat to "thwart the will of the people." More specifically, the Electoral College is corrosive to the belief that every vote counts. Here in Georgia, we are pelted nearly every day with newspaper articles and polls predicting that John Kerry will get clobbered by George W. Bush. So why should I bother going to the polls to vote for the challenger? New York Republicans, of course, have the same problem.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It is almost surreal. You walk down the street and there are shoe stores, bakeries and here we're controlling some robotic mechanism on Mars."

description: SEVERAL residents of Stamford, Darien and New Canaan most affected by the shortage of flu vaccines are getting help from Stamford Hospital.

description: STEM CELL REVOLUTION -- California once again set itself apart from the rest of the nation, overwhelmingly approving a ballot initiative last week to devote $3 billion over the next 10 years to embryonic stem cell research.

description: Branded Nation: The Marketing of Megachurch, College Inc. and Museumworld

title: QUICK BITE/Closter; Breakfast-Time, and the Bacon Is Sizzling
description: There's something comforting about the classic lunch counter: the earthy smell of strong coffee, men of a certain age hunched over the sports pages, the crackle and pop of bacon and eggs frying. The Red Maple Luncheonette is firmly in this tradition. A fixture in Closter for more than 55 years, it has been owned by Charlie DiMaria for the last 13. Standing at the grill in his cook's whites, he proudly says that he has a "good place, good food and a good price." And that's a fair assessment. He works with two regular waitresses; one has been there 27 years. Guess he must be a good boss, too.

title: 'America's Game': The Real National Pastime
description: AMERICA'S GAME The Epic Story of How Pro Football Captured a Nation. By Michael MacCambridge. Illustrated. 552 pp. Random House. $27.95.

title: Airwaves Are Abuzz Over Wesleyan
description: IT'S 6 p.m. Monday. Benjamin Michael is at the mike at WESU-FM (88.1), Wesleyan University's radio station. Broadcasting from a modest studio over Broad Street Books in Middletown, he and his co-host, Garnett Ankle, knock around issues involving politics and equal rights. Then, as they do each show, they open up the phone lines.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Vision for Saving Iraq by Preserving Bits of Babylon
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y. - THERE was the Iraq of the presidential campaign, a place, almost an abstraction, that often seemed more about us than about them, where all the casualty figures were American and big ideas of freedom and democracy seldom seemed tied to the agony of a real place with real people.

title: THE GUIDE
description: By Open Invitation

title: Our National Eating Disorder
description: Michael Pollan might have mentioned the socioeconomic origins of fad diets and packaged food consumption. I grew up in a suburban Cleveland family with two working parents in the 1980's. Instead of the beef Wellington and boeuf bourguignon that Pollan's mother prepared, we were raised on such classics as Stouffer's frozen pizza. Our dad took weekly business trips; our mom worked days and went to law school nights. There was little alternative but to outsource dinner. We were alarmed when, following Oprah's lead, our mother stopped eating and went on the Optifast diet, drinking only formula until she crashed to a size 6. Of course she gained all the weight back. This imbalanced attitude toward nutrition, in retrospect, strikes me as a desperate attempt to gain control over a life of incompatible demands.

title: Emily Levy, Matthew Heimermann
description: Emily Claire Levy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram L. Levy of Atlanta, was married there last evening to Matthew Gregor Heimermann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dale L. Heimermann of St. Cloud, Minn. Rabbi Philip N. Kranz officiated at the Temple-Hebrew Benevolent Congregation. The Rev. Alberic R. Culhane, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

description: . . . ASIAN DINING . . . IKEBANA AND ICHIMONJI . . . AN ALTERNATIVE TO NAPA . . . L.A. FOOD DUDES . . . AFTERNOON TEA . . . AND FREQUENT-FLIER MEALS.

title: U.S. Forces Begin Moving Into Falluja
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Monday, Nov. 8 - Explosions and heavy gunfire thundered through the outskirts of Falluja on Sunday night and early Monday as American soldiers and marines swept toward strategic bridges, hospitals and other objectives in what appeared to be the first stage of a long-expected invasion of the city.

title: A Diamond Salvaged From the Dustbin
description: Millburn - USUALLY when a musical finds itself being performed rarely, there's a good reason: it stinks. But once in a while a work draws more dust-gathering duty than it deserves. When a theater of consequence decides to bring one of these half-forgotten gems back into the light and applies its full resources to the task, it's somehow doubly rewarding for the audience.

title: At Brookhaven Lab, Less Glass to Blow
description: BARRY LAFLER handcrafts the specialized glassware needed for research at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton: not the customary beakers, flasks and test tubes but funky, complicated gizmos and doodads that researchers use to perform experiments.

title: Some Special Spots in Shadow of Skyline
description: Among Manhattan's many secret delights, none appear to be lesser known than the opportunities for an evening's fishing after knocking off work.

title: Italian Fare That's All in the Timing
description: WHILE several visits to a restaurant are helpful -- even mandatory -- they can occasionally be confusing rather than clarifying. This was the case on three visits to Tenero in South Norwalk.

title: Shouldn't Have Had That Second Piece
description: A good advertising slogan sticks in the mind like the multiplication tables. Maxwell House, as virtually everyone knows, is "good to the last drop"; Nike implores you to "just do it"; and Jolt Cola has "all the sugar, twice the caffeine."

title: Good Swill
description: If you can remember back far enough to laugh smugly at the thought of Lambrusco, then you've probably never had the real thing. To Americans, it's the sickly sweet, mass-produced red sparkler that launched a million disco nights in the 70's, a smudge on the otherwise upright reputation of Italian wine. Firms like Riunite and Giacobazzi made a fortune on it, while effectively digging its grave for all time.

title: Don't Throw That Score Out Yet
description: SAT scores have been a key factor in college admissions for decades, but like a high school diploma, they could be safely retired to the attic once that acceptance letter arrived. In today's tight job market, however, prospective employers may ask to see the scores of recent -- and even not so recent -- college graduates.

title: Karen Graham, Jason Mann
description: Karen Lee Graham, the daughter of Ruth and Stanley Graham of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jason Patrick Mann, a son of Annette and Dr. Patrick Mann of Morgantown, W.Va. The Rev. Joseph Vetter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Duke Chapel in Durham, N.C.

title: A Watchdog, But for Whom?
description: People who are familiar with Graef Crystal's biting critiques of executive pay may not be surprised that he is expected to testify this week in the Disney trial - until they find out whose side he is on.

title: Nassau Campaign Donor: No Funny Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Kinsey's Very Special Colleague
description: Los Angeles - VISITING with Peter Sarsgaard is remarkably similar to watching one of his movies. Ambling through a hillside house in Nichols Canyon above Los Angeles -- or through a supporting role on film -- Mr. Sarsgaard looks very life-size. Baggy jeans and a half-buttoned denim shirt hang off his small frame; there's a couple of days of scruff on his face. He could be the pool man or the nephew sent to keep an eye on his rich uncle's place.

title: A Last, Lonely Dissident
description: As she strolls through Old Havana, wearing two-tone Jennifer Lopez-style sunglasses, Claudia Mrquez Linares seems like a member of Cuba's tiny elite. And in many ways she is. At 27, she is already regarded as one of the country's leading independent journalists. For her efforts, she has lost friends, effectively her husband and, perhaps soon, her homeland.

title: DVD's to Put Under Trees
description: Putting a Little Warmth Into the Cold War

title: How To Make Albany Behave
description: Talk of reform in Albany is everywhere these days. Indeed, recent developments have created what could be a "perfect storm" for legislative reform.

title: Going It Alone: Sailing Around the World, Nonstop, Without Any Sponsors
description: LES SABLES D'OLONNE, France, Nov. 6 - With less than two days to go before the start of the most dangerous and lonely race in elite sailing, Bruce Schwab's boat Ocean Planet was a sea of commotion. His multicultural, multitasking band of friends, financiers and fresh volunteer recruits raced the clock to install late-arriving equipment as a cool Friday turned into a chilly night.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 24 about services in Los Angeles that drive tipsy people home in their own cars misstated the precedent for municipal policies that allow the police to seize the vehicles of drunken drivers. A proposal before the City Council would make Los Angeles at least the second major city with such a policy, not the first. New York City has had such a program since 1999.

title: Starbucks Has Moved in, But It's Being Iced, Not Blended
description: First came the rumors. Next came the denials; it can't be happening here, people said. But then, construction started at the corner of Front and Main Streets, and a month ago, when residents saw the familiar green lettering go up, they knew it was true. Starbucks had come to Dumbo.

title: Where the Theater Is a Kibbutz, and the Kibbutz Is a Theater
description: ASHFIELD, Mass. - PLENTY of theater companies may profess as much, but the Double Edge Theater company truly believes that art is life. On the Farm, the group's 105-acre estate in Ashfield, Mass., the company has built the dramatic equivalent of a kibbutz: an intimate, utopian and self-sustaining community, where its seven members live and work together, integrating their onstage and offstage lives.

title: Jessica Behrer, Keith Dixon
description: Jessica Lee Behrer, a daughter of Cindy and Robert Q. Behrer Jr. of Cheshire, Conn., was married on Friday night to Keith Dixon, a son of Nancy Dixon and Dr. Richard Dixon of Bellefonte, Pa. The Rev. Paula Posman, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the couple's apartment in New York.

title: The Antiwar Right Is Ready to Rumble
description: AROUND 8 p.m. Tuesday, a gloomy mood was settling over the dozen conservative stalwarts gathered with martinis and glasses of red wine in an office in Arlington, Va., to watch the returns. Early exit polls showed President Bush trailing, and Richard Viguerie, dean of conservative direct mail, thought he knew who was to blame: the neoconservatives, the group associated with making the case for the invasion of Iraq.

title: Answering the Call a 2nd Time, a Former Major Dons Sergeant's Stripes for a Tour in Iraq

title: Editor's Choice
Inside the List
description: COMFORT FOOD: Diane Mott Davidson, whose novel "Double Shot" enters the fiction list this week at No. 12, writes the kind of mysteries that are called "cozies." In the decaffeinated world of the cozies, there's no gore, no steamy sex scenes -- nothing, really, that would feel too out of place in a rerun of "Murder, She Wrote." Blandness is a virtue here; so is feline companionship. ("Is the cozy mystery taking over," an exasperated Marilyn Stasio has asked in these pages, "or am I just imagining all these cats?") Davidson's novels, which are about a small-town Colorado caterer and amateur sleuth named Goldy, straddle another genre, too. Like Fannie Flagg in "Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Stop Cafe" and Laura Esquivel in "Like Water for Chocolate," Davidson smuggles recipes into her novels. (In "Double Shot," you can learn to make things like "Got-a-Hunch Brunch Rolls" and "Handcuff Croissants.") This novel is the author's 12th about Goldy and her Goldilocks' Catering company, and the fifth in this tepid, microwaveable series to make the Times hardcover list. Davidson's Web site has a short biographical sketch that notes that at Wellesley College "she lived across the hall from Hillary Rodham (now Clinton), who drafted her into the Young Republicans!" The site also includes news about her culinary hits and misfires. "There was Roquefort Pizza," she writes, "which I pawned off on our next-door neighbors."

title: No Requiem Yet for Vaccines
description: At a time when experts are wringing their hands over a huge shortage of influenza vaccines and blaming low profit margins and high risks that drive companies from the market, it is a pleasure to note two significant advances in developing other vaccines. An experimental vaccine developed by GlaxoSmithKline to prevent malaria has shown that it can save many children from infection or death, offering the first real hope for containing a disease that kills more than a million people every year. Another experimental vaccine, developed by Merck, has shown that it can provide long-term protection against cervical cancer, which kills some 225,000 women every year, mostly in poor countries where women do not have regular Pap tests. Both Glaxo and Merck have other vaccines in development, suggesting that laments about the withering of the industry are premature.

And through Nov. 14, the Crafts Council Gallery Shop in Islington is playing host to Teatotal, an exhibition featuring works from artists and designers on the theme of the tea party. The artist Marije Vogelzang spun a complete service out of sugar, the ceramicist Barnaby Barford reworked Fragonard-style figurines into kitschy works of art and the painter Charlotte Hodes spiffed up classic pieces from the venerable Spode factory. title: Growing Up With Mom and Mom
description: From a straight, happily married mom, kudos to Sandy Russo and Robin Young for raising two beautiful, responsible, creative and intelligent daughters (Susan Dominus, Oct. 24). Their commitment to raising their children and to sustaining their own relationship over the years is testament to the fact that loving families can transcend tradition. Ry and Cade's struggles to determine their own sexuality is not surprising given that their mothers are the two most important people in their lives. In loving families, it is common for children to want to emulate their parents to some degree. When your family is judged by a large segment of the community to be unacceptable and your parents vilified simply for having you and loving you like any normal parent, it has to hurt. Is it any wonder that filial loyalty would cloud the issue for a bit?

Young won the competition when the runner-up Julie Welles of Simsbury, Conn., and her horse, Otto, knocked down the third fence. The third-place finisher, Addison Phillips of New York and Ricochet crashed through the first jump. Alex Orr Jr.

Michel Fokine's "Sylphides" received a rightly expressive performance, George Balanchine's "Mozartiana" was danced differently by two ballerinas in separate casts and Christopher Wheeldon's "VIII," one of the season's premieres, benefited from a coherent leading trio.

title: U.S. Judge Halts Military Trial of Qaeda Suspect at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 - A federal judge today halted the GuantAnamo Bay trial of a Yemeni prisoner suspected of being a member of Al Qaeda, ruling that the special military tribunals like the one the suspect is facing at the naval base in Cuba are contrary to principles of American justice.

title: G.O.P. Plans to Give Environment Rules a Free-Market Tilt
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - With the elections over, Congress and the Bush administration are moving ahead with ambitious environmental agendas that include revamping signature laws on air pollution and endangered species and reviving a moribund energy bill that would open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to energy exploration.

description: Correction Appended

title: Afghan Militants Conduct Talks Over 3 Hostages
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 7 - Militants holding three United Nations workers as hostages in Afghanistan said Sunday that they had negotiated with officials in the Afghan government and United Nations mission but that the meeting had ended without result.

title: A Day That Shook the World Now Rattles Russia's Nerves
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7 - Russia celebrated a holiday on Sunday that under the Julian calendar was in October, that commemorates the beginnings of a state that no longer exists. It used to be called the Day of the Great October Socialist Revolution, but is now the Day of Accord and Reconciliation or, sometimes, the reverse. Anyway, neither was much in evidence.

title: Evolving Nature of Al Qaeda Is Misunderstood, Critic Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - The Bush administration has failed to recognize that Al Qaeda is now a global Islamic insurgency, rather than a traditional terrorist organization, and so poses a much different threat than previously believed, says a senior counterterrorism official at the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Even With Campaign Finance Law, Money Talks Louder Than Ever
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - The McCain-Feingold law, which did more to change how American political campaigns are financed than any legislation since the 1970's, got its first real-world test in this year's election. And now its critics are more emphatic than ever in arguing that the law has fallen short of its goals, and even some supporters are calling for revisions.

title: Mexico to Press U.S. on Stalled Migrant Plan
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7 - In meetings with the United States this week, Mexico will urge the Bush administration to pay more attention to Latin America in its second term and to move forward on proposals that would give legal status to millions of illegal migrants.

title: Justices Let Prisoners Sue to Regain Right to Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -The Supreme Court today allowed several current and former prisoners in Washington State to challenge a law there stripping them of their right to vote, a move that could have repercussions in a number of other states.

title: Miami Is Beach Country and Book Country, Too
description: MIAMI, Nov. 7 - Back in 1984, organizers of the first Miami Book Fair International had to persuade publishers to send authors to a city then better known as a sunny retirement haven than as a readers' paradise. Seventy writers came for the two-day event, which was immediately considered a success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TER KUILE, THE HONORABLE BARBARA J.
description: ter KUILE--The Honorable Barbara J. Beloved wife of Curtis R. ter Kuile passed away on Friday, November 5, 2004, at Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY. She was the devoted mother of Janice K. ter Kuile, Jacqueline A. ter Kuile and Curtis A. ter Kuile, and leaves six wonderful grandchildren. Born February 18, 1929, in Brooklyn, NY, Barbara raised her family in Litchfield, CT, during which time she served as the Representative from Litchfield to the Connecticut State Legislature.

title: Arts, Briefly; Munch Museum to Get Security Overhaul
description: The Munch Museum in Oslo, where Edvard Munch's masterpiece "The Scream" and another painting were stolen by armed robbers on Aug. 22, will remain closed until next summer while the museum spends up to $7.8 million on a security upgrade. Security measures recommended by Det Norske Veritas, an Oslo-based consulting firm, include improving the museum's video surveillance system and enclosing its most famous paintings in glass cases bolted to the wall. The company also recommended that the museum install metal detectors and build a labyrinthine passage in the lobby area to slow the escape of any future robbers. In a statement, city officials said they would "follow the recommendations from Veritas and start the necessary work immediately." Norwegian police have conducted a high-profile investigation of the robbery, but there have been no arrests, and neither "The Scream" nor the other stolen painting, Munch's "Madonna," has been recovered. WALTER GIBBS

title: Negotiators See New Hope for Intelligence Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - Congressional negotiators seeking a bill to create the job of national intelligence director say they are resuming their talks in earnest and believe the legislation can be pushed through Congress in this month's lame-duck session -- despite predictions that the bill would die if not passed before the Nov. 2 election.

title: For a Fill-In Aida, a Triumph Long in Coming

title: How Hispanics Voted Republican

Now, even though they claimed a majority of the Latino vote, Democrats suddenly find themselves in real danger of losing one of the biggest pieces of their base, one that had been counted on for loyalty approaching that of African-Americans. This happened, in part, because the Republicans went to church.

title: Prosperity vs. Peace
description: London - Earlier this year in Karachi, I overheard a fellow Pakistani say, "Of course Bush is a disaster for the world -- but he's good for Pakistan." It's conventional wisdom in Pakistan that President Bush's policies have transformed the country from a pariah state on the verge of bankruptcy to a strategic, and prospering, ally in American expansionism. John Kerry, viewed as less invested than George Bush in such expansionism (for that is how the "war on terrorism" is seen in Pakistan), was always the less popular presidential choice for those of my compatriots who feel that it's important to wrest as much economic and political advantage as possible from Pakistan's present usefulness to America.

description: No amount of additional soldiers can guarantee achievement of the ambitious political and military goals President Bush announced last week for Iraq. The overall situation is grim, with the insurgency continuing to grow in strength and audacity and credible elections in January anything but certain. If that dynamic cannot be reversed, Washington will ultimately have to consider radically scaling back its objectives there.

Wilson had noticed Reilly year after year among the marathon's sea of humanity because Reilly is easily noticed.

title: The Great Mentioner
description: Washington - The terrorists' Ramadan offensive escalated last weekend, inviting martial law in Iraq and our counterattack to oust the occupiers of Falluja. A pitched battle where firepower is decisive is a loser for guerrilla fighters. Iraq will then proceed to elections, the U.N.'s unhelpful Kofi Annan notwithstanding.

title: New CD's
description: Once upon a time, rockers -- especially punk-rockers -- had fun, or at least a bratty sense of defiance. No more. Now, the sound of young American manhood is a nasal tenor whine. Jimmy Eat World and Simple Plan, two bands whose new albums are on Billboard's Top 10 and whose video clips are inescapable on MTV, harness punk's techniques to adolescent self-pity, frustrated idealism and laments about their latest romantic setbacks. While they have absorbed the economy and tunefulness of punk, they have somehow immunized themselves against punk's ironic euphoria. Both bands are performing sold-out shows in Manhattan tonight: Jimmy Eat World at Webster Hall and Simple Plan at Irving Plaza.

(Boston had 38,708 starters for its 100th anniversary race in 1996, but now limits its field to half that.)

title: Warner's Mistakes Costly for Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 7 - Giants quarterback Kurt Warner walked off the field looking a bit like a chastened child, eyes cast down, licking his lips. He did not yet know that Coach Tom Coughlin had considered, then rejected, the idea of benching him during the game and inserting the rookie Eli Manning. But what he knew of his performance was enough to make him miserable anyway.

title: Bettis Is Back, and at His Age, It Hurts So Good
description: Pittsburgh - THE game yesterday between the undefeated Philadelphia Eagles and the surging, once-beaten Pittsburgh Steelers was a three-pronged attraction last week: Was Ben Roethlisberger, Pittsburgh's rookie sensation at quarterback, for real? Were the Eagles as good as their 7-0 record suggested? Was Terrell Owens the straw that would stir the Eagles' drink?

title: Music Channels Move Into Video and Messages Meant for You

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Angry Men' Persist on Broadway
description: "Twelve Angry Men" just keeps deliberating. The jury-room drama on Broadway by Reginald Rose has announced a second extension at the Roundabout Theater Company's American Airlines Theater, where it will now run through Jan. 9. It had originally been scheduled to close on Dec. 19, but mostly good reviews have a way of freeing up people's schedules. The extension was just one of several moves made by the Roundabout, including the hiring of a director for its much anticipated revival of "A Streetcar Named Desire," due to open in April at Studio 54 with Natasha Richardson, left,as the world-weary, man-hungry Blanche Du Bois. Directing her will be Edward Hall, the son of the famed British director Sir Peter Hall. With the angry men extending, the fools in love -- from Sam Shepard's "Fool for Love" -- will be delayed at bit. That production, to be directed by Ed Harris, will now begin performances at the American Airlines on Jan. 19. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Roads Lead to a New Way of Life for Rural Ethiopia

title: Are We There Yet?
description: ARE WE THERE YET? -- Flight delays increased in September, the federal Bureau of Transportation Statistics reported in its survey of 19 domestic carriers. The airlines' on-time arrivals averaged 83.9 percent in September, down from 85.6 percent a year earlier, the survey showed. September's figures, however, represented an improvement over the 78.3 percent on-time performance for August, the bureau said. AirTran Airways had the worst record, at 76.6 percent, followed by Delta, at 77 percent. Delta's Flight 1447 from Atlanta to Pensacola, Fla., was the most frequently delayed scheduled flight. The survey showed that it was late 84.6 percent of the time.

title: CUNY Seeking to Raise $1.2 Billion
description: The City University of New York is starting a $1.2 billion fund-raising campaign, reflecting both the new economics of public universities, which have faced shrinking public support, and the belief that CUNY has emerged from the troubled days in the late 1990's, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other critics charged that it was a third-rate university filled with students who could not read or write.

Arts, Briefly; A Mimi for 'Rent'
description: The actress Rosario Dawson, right, who is currently filming "Sin City," and will soon be seen with Colin Farrell and Angelina Jolie in "Alexander the Great," will star in the movie adaptation of Jonathan Larson's Tony Award-winning musical, "Rent." Ms. Dawson will portray Mimi Marquez, the Latina stripper afflicted with AIDS and a drug problem. Many of the show's original cast, including Taye Diggs, Anthony Rapp, Adam Pascal and Jesse L. Martin, are also under consideration to reprise their roles in the film version from Revolution Studios, which will be directed by Christopher Columbus (the first two "Harry Potter" films). "Rent" is an adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning rock musical based on Puccini's "Bohme." The film will be produced by Michael Barnathan, Jane Rosenthal and Robert De Niro and written by Mr. Columbus. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Old Is Everywhere, So a Charity Tries On the New
description: The day Grace Jones's hooded leather Azzedine Alaa dress comes through the door at a Housing Works Thrift store, both the dress and Eduardo Bennett, the charity's women's wear expert, are going to walk. That, anyway, is what Mr. Bennett said with a laugh last week, as he threaded his way through a maze of garments hung from overhead racks in a Queens warehouse down the block from a depot for the online food market Fresh Direct.

title: H & R Block Is Accused of Fraud in Bond Sales
description: Securities regulators accused H&R Block Inc. yesterday of defrauding individual investors by selling them $16 million worth of bonds in the Enron Corporation in the five weeks before it collapsed amid a major accounting scandal.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Nicaragua: Sandinistas' Strong Showing
description: The left-wing Sandinista Party made strong gains in municipal elections over the weekend, a further sign that the center-right party of President Enrique Bolaos has been undermined by allegations that he took illegal campaign contributions. With most of the vote counted, Sandinista candidates appeared headed for victory not only in the race for mayor of Managua, the capital, but also in 15 of the 17 provincial capitals, a gain of four positions over all. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Catholic-Run Health Plan
description: Federal employees in 27 counties in Illinois can start enrolling in a health insurance plan run by Roman Catholic nuns that excludes payment for contraceptives, abortion, sterilization and artificial insemination. The plan's sponsor, OSF HealthPlans of Peoria, is owned by the Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis. Officials said it was the first plan for federal workers with benefits tailored to church tenets and the first to be marketed as "faith-based." Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Ten Commandments Monument For Courthouse
description: A monument inscribed with the Ten Commandments was placed on the grounds of the Haskell County courthouse at Stigler in a ceremony attended by the three-member county commission that approved the installation. The granite monument, eight feet high and three feet wide, was paid for by local church youth groups, said Sam D. Cole, chairman of the county commission. The United States Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether displays of a religious nature on public property are constitutional. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: Progress in China is not easy to chart. Every step forward seems to be paired with a move back, in the direction of the hard Communist past. This pattern of advance and retreat requires constant analysis to determine whether the nation is moving, even generally, in the right direction toward more freedom, better laws and a cleaner environment. More recently, there have been a series of setbacks -- the bridling of Internet traffic, the arrests of journalists, including a New York Times researcher, the uphill battle of farmers trying to hold onto their land against those who are greedy for development or cheap electricity.

title: Germs, Germs Everywhere. Are You Worried? Get Over It.
description: I saw a television advertisement recently for a new product called an air sanitizer. A woman stood in her kitchen, spraying the empty space in front of her as though using Mace against an imaginary assailant. She appeared very determined. Where others are satisfied with antibacterial-laced sponges, dish soaps, hand sanitizers and telephone wipes, here was a woman who sought to sterilize the air itself.

title: Drinking Deaths Draw Attention to Old Campus Problem
description: BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 5 - Lynn G. Bailey, 18, a freshman at the University of Colorado here, spent his last night chugging whiskey and wine as part of an initiation ceremony with his fraternity brothers. Left by his friends to sleep it off, he died from alcohol poisoning.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Hinckley Seeks More Freedom
description: A lawyer for John W. Hinckley Jr. told a federal judge that his client should be permitted expanded travel privileges from the mental hospital where he has lived since he tried to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981. The judge, Paul L. Friedman of Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, ruled last year that Mr. Hinckley, left, could occasionally leave the hospital, but restricted his movements to the Washington area and called on his parents to supervise him. Mr. Hinckley, who was acquitted by reason of insanity for the shooting of Mr. Reagan and three others outside a Washington hotel, has asked the court for four-day, unsupervised visits every two weeks to his parents' home in Williamsburg, Va. Judge Friedman is expected to rule on the matter soon. John Files (NYT)

title: GERMANY: How the world saw America's election

description: SUMMERLAND, Calif. - President George W. Bush justifiably casts himself as the apostle of the Reagan Revolution begun by his father's predecessor. But Mr. Bush may find in his second term, as Ronald Reagan did before him, that he must overcome resistance as much from his friends as from his adversaries.

title: THREE STATES INCLUDE CHUBB IN THEIR INSURANCE INQUIRIES
description: The Chubb Corporation, a property and casualty insurer, said North Carolina was among at least three states to request information in the wake of an investigation of the insurance industry being conducted by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. Chubb, based in Warren, N.J., said it believed other insurers were receiving requests as well. Mr. Spitzer is investigating bid-rigging between insurance brokers and insurers and has obtained three guilty pleas from executives at American International Group and Ace, two of Chubb's rivals. Connecticut and Ohio have also sent Chubb subpoenas or requests for information, the company said.

title: CITIGROUP WILL BUILD A CALL CENTER IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Citigroup will build a call center in South Carolina for its CitiFinancial consumer-credit business and may hire as many as 1,000 people to work at the site, the company said yesterday. The 165,000-square-foot center will be located in Fort Mill, S.C., six miles south of Charlotte, Citigroup said. The new site will eventually employ about 1,600 people, who will mainly collect payments and provide customer service. Some workers will move to the new site from CitiFinancial offices in Charlotte and other nearby locations, the bank said. Citigroup is based in New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Nov. 1 about a malfunctioning television set that emitted distress signals misattributed a comment about the owners' change in routine after the set was removed and before it was replaced. It was Chris van Rossman, the owner, who said a few weeks of TV-free living had been liberating -- not Ajay Mehta, program coordinator for the satellite search and rescue system that monitors distress beacons.

title: Report Heightens Pollution Dispute at Indonesian Bay
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 8 - A government panel presented a bitterly fought-over report on Monday showing that sediment in the equatorial bay where the world's biggest gold producer, Newmont Mining Corporation, deposited mine waste is polluted with significant levels of arsenic and mercury. But the panel found the water quality met Indonesian standards.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Auditor Says Pelosi Spent Lavishly
description: Daniel Pelosi spent $15,000 on cigars, lavished hundreds of thousands on family members and spent nearly three-quarters of a million dollars at casinos, an auditor told the courtroom where Mr. Pelosi is being tried for murder in the death of R. Theodore Ammon. Christine Lusak, an auditor for the Suffolk County district attorney, said yesterday that Mr. Pelosi's former wife, sister and others received hundreds of thousands of dollars from him after he married the victim's widow, Generosa Ammon, in January 2002, three months after Mr. Ammon's death, and after she transferred $1.2 million into Mr. Pelosi's checking account. Peter C. Beller (NYT)

title: Vote Awaited on Choice of Firm to Restore Fiterman Hall Near Ground Zero
description: The fate of Fiterman Hall in Lower Manhattan, which has been unclear since the building was badly damaged during the attack on the World Trade Center, may be settled this month with a choice of architects to design its replacement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVID, KATHERINE ANNE BRODIE
description: DAVID--Katherine Anne Brodie. We announce with great sorrow the death of Katherine Anne Brodie David on November 5, 2004, at the age of 59. She is survived by her husband Keith David, her daughter Elizabeth (Bicky) Brodie David and her brother Michael Brodie. Kate was a graduate of Smith College and, before her marriage and treasured motherhood, a lexicographer editing dictionaries at Macmillan. A celebration of Kate's life will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, at 4 PM, on November 11. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Have A Chance, Inc., 26 Schoolhouse Lane, Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: Newsday Expected to Announce Replacement of Its Top Editor
description: The publisher of Newsday is expected to announce today that he is replacing Howard Schneider, who has served as the paper's editor since August 2003, with John Mancini, an assistant managing editor, according to an editor at the paper who insisted on anonymity.

title: ONEX PARTNERS TO BUY LARGE STAKE IN COSMETICS MAKER
description: Onex Partners, a fund operated by the Onex Corporation, a Canadian buyout firm, agreed to buy most of BMP/CEI Holdings, a maker of fragrances, creams and cosmetics, for 135 million Canadian dollars ($113 million). Onex Partners, a $2.2 billion fund based in Toronto, will buy 90 percent of BMP/CEI from Brockway Moran & Partners Fund, gaining a company with annual sales of more than $250 million. Onex, which owns 25 percent of the fund, also runs health care, marketing and electronics companies. BMP/CEI is based in Morganville, N.J. Onex said it expected to complete the acquisition in the fourth quarter.

title: Miniature People Add Extra Pieces to Evolutionary Puzzle
description: The miniature people found to have lived on the Indonesian island of Flores until 13,000 years ago may well appeal to the imagination. Even their Australian discoverers refer to them with fanciful names. But the little Floresians have created something of a headache for paleoanthropologists.

McGreevey Apologetic but Proud at Farewell
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8 - In a farewell address tinged with soul-searching and regret, Gov. James E. McGreevey apologized Monday to the people of New Jersey for the sex scandal that led him to resign, but said he was proud of his administration's accomplishments and relieved that he no longer had to conceal his identity as a gay man.

Paid Notice: Deaths   WARNER, CHARLES H. JR.
description: WARNER--Charles H. Jr. Of Upper Nyack, NY died peacefully on November 2, 2004 at age 93. A graduate of Choate, Wesleyan University and Columbia University, he was founder and senior partner of the architectural firm Warner, Burns, Toan & Lunde. He designed numerous hotels, university buildings and conference centers in the US and abroad. Of special interest to him was designing "in context" with the local environment. He also taught architecture at Cornell and Columbia Universities. He is survived by his son Mark, daughter-in-law Susan, two grandchildren, Mark and Amy and three great-granchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Gladeview Healthcare Center, 60 Boston Post Road, Old Saybrook, CT, 06475. A memorial service will be held on November 20, at Grace Episcopal Church, 130 1st Ave, Nyack, NY, 4PM

title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear 2 Cases Weighing the Right of Felons to Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 - The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear cases from New York and Washington State on whether states violate the federal Voting Rights Act when they strip felons of the right to vote. But with 48 states, all except Maine and Vermont, disenfranchising millions of people who have been convicted of crimes, the issue remains very much alive in the lower courts, and the justices' action did not foreclose accepting a future case.

title: Diana's Park Memorial Today: A Font of Faultfinding
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 - Impassive as a marine, the guard patrolling the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fountain put down his industrial-size leaf strainer and began to describe the many aspects of his job.

description: WESTAD--Marjorie M. on November 5, 2004, of Port Washington, NY. Devoted wife of Per for 58 years. Graveside service Wednesday at 10AM, Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Pt Washington. Donations in her name may be made to the Lakota Indian Children, C/O St. Joseph's Indian School, Chamberlain, S.D. 57326.

title: What the Mullahs Learned From the Neighbors
description: WASHINGTON - A quarter-century ago this month, several hundred Iranian students seized the American Embassy in Tehran, taking our Marines and diplomats hostage, and leaving Americans fuming and asking, "Why do they hate us?" Now, as the Bush administration prepares for its second term, Iran is again at the top the agenda, and we seem equally clueless as to how to approach it.

title: Whitney's New Plan: A Respectful Approach
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art's on-again, off-again expansion plan has been lurching along for more than two decades now. In that time, the museum has gone through four directors and flirted with ill-fated designs ranging from the bold to the grotesque. The worst, a 1985 proposal by Michael Graves, would have smothered the existing building in a pastiche of pseudoclassical references. A more promising proposal by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas was dropped a year and a half ago amid post-9/11 uncertainty and a growing sense that the design was inappropriately aggressive. To many, it seemed as if the museum had simply lost its nerve.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 8 - Christopher Mattaliano, the general director of the Portland Opera, opened his first season of artistic leadership on Saturday night with a display of vocal fireworks and personal courage.
