description: An article on Oct. 28 about Internet sites that criticize mainstream news coverage of political campaigns referred imprecisely to the use of a liberal Web site, DailyKos, as tracked by another site, The Truth Laid Bear. DailyKos receives about 500,000 visits each day, a figure that may include multiple visits by some users. The site is not necessarily viewed by 500,000 visitors a day.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Mcgreevey Aide Joins Port Authority
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey's chief of staff, James P. Fox, has been named deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Mr. Fox, left, a veteran Democratic political operative who served as state transportation commissioner during Mr. McGreevey's first year in office, began his new duties yesterday and will earn a yearly salary of $206,000. Mr. Fox was a chief of staff for former Senator Robert G. Torricelli. Josh Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens Makes Purchase
description: Siemens, Germany's largest engineering company, agreed to buy a stake in VA Technologie, another engineering company, and made an offer for the rest in a transaction valuing VA at 842.5 million euros ($1.09 billion). Siemens's chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said the company would offer VA shareholders 55 euros a share, 7.8 percent more than Friday's close, after taking control of 17 percent through the purchase of an investment company, Victory Industriebeteiligung. Talks between Siemens and Victory about a joint takeover bid for VA Tech collapsed in September after the Austrian government, which holds a 15 percent stake in VA Tech, said an offer was not welcome. VA Tech's chief executive, Klaus Sernetz, above, said he still had reservations.

title: Virtuoso of the Pan Flute Fills a Niche All His Own
description: Damian Draghici had had enough. On a brisk afternoon last month while on a short tour break, Mr. Draghici was wandering around the East Village with his two publicists, looking for a music shop that stocked his instrument, the Romanian pan flute, so he could demonstrate his virtuosity. When no flutes were found, Mr. Draghici made a quick dismissive gesture.

title: Plan to Shift New Jersey Pension Funds Approved
description: The governing council for New Jersey's state pension fund voted yesterday to shift to a much more aggressive investment strategy that would include hedge funds and other so-called alternative investments as part of a broader plan to give some responsibility for investing the fund to outside money managers.

title: General Electric Sells 60% of Indian Back-Office Unit
description: BANGALORE, India, Nov. 8 - The General Electric Company said on Monday that it had sold a 60 percent stake in its pioneering back-office unit in India to two private equity firms for $500 million.

title: Arts, Briefly; Goofing Off
description: It's a temporary setback for fans of the sublimely goofy. The Umbilical Brothers, below, the Australian duo known for highbrow slapstick, have delayed a planned fall run at Dodger Stages as a result of scheduling conflicts. David Foster, the producer of the show, "Speedmouse," said that the brothers might still land in New York before the end of the year but that they were currently working on two other projects, including a possible show with the Children's Television Workshop. "We're looking into some other spaces," he said. The Umblical Brothers is the second show this fall to cancel an engagement at the Stages, a five-theater complex on West 50th Street that opened in September; the new musical "Bare" was also scheduled to play there this fall, but its financing fell apart. The space is currently home to shows by Basil Twist and Mandy Patinkin and a new musical, "The Immigrant." JESSE McKINLEY

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about the prospects for President Bush's judgeship nominations in the Senate Judiciary Committee, and the likelihood that Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, would become chairman, misstated the number of years a Republican senator can head a committee and misstated the source of the limit. The limit is six years, not eight. The rule was adopted by Republicans and applies only to their senators; it is not a Senate rule.

description: "Frontline" decodes advertisers' latent meanings and manufactured responses in "The Persuaders," an ambitious report leavened by the puckish narration of Douglas Rushkoff. Once we were in Puerto Rico for a spa retreat I was planning at the Wyndham El Conquistador, and our luggage was lost. My husband really likes sleeping in pajamas, but it was too late to buy them. The concierge had a brainstorm: chef's outfits are kind of like pajamas. They're baggy, have drawstrings and are comfortable. We thought she was crazy.

description: LONDON, Nov. 8 - British Airways reported a 26 percent increase in its fiscal second-quarter profit on Monday but warned that it expected a tough winter because of high fuel prices and stiff competition.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 - The American offensive in Falluja will test the administration's belief that the Iraqi insurgency can be subdued in time for the country's elections in late January, current and former government officials said Monday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Making Merry at Michael's
description: Michael's, the Midtown Manhattan restaurant that has served as a compound for the media elite, is having a birthday party tonight, celebrating 15 years of operation. The original Michael's opened 25 years ago in Santa Monica, Calif., and Michael McCarty, the owner, decided an East Coast version of the Hollywood industry lunchtime sandbox would probably work as well. But tonight, the twin imperatives of Michael's in Midtown -- table number and territory -- will be a bit difficult to sort out. As many as 1,000 privileged attendees will be fighting for a place to stand. "We will probably have some hysteria based on requests for customers' traditional spots," said Steve Millington, the general manager. "But I expect everyone will play nice in honor of the feel-good spirit of the event." DAVID CARR

title: As the Arctic Warms
description: OPENING WATER -- The Arctic Climate Impact Assessment, a study commissioned four years ago by the United States and the seven other countries with Arctic territory, projects that rising global concentrations of heat-trapping emissions will drive up temperatures particularly quickly at high latitudes. Some benefits are predicted. For instance, expanding areas of open water in summer could be a boon to whales and cod stocks. The ice retreat could also create summertime shipping shortcuts between the Atlantic and Pacific and allow oil and gas exploration in previously ice-cloaked waters. But a host of troubles lie ahead as well. The loss of sea ice, for example, could hurt both polar bears and Inuit seal hunters. Details are available on the Web at www.amap.no/acia. ANDREW C. REVKIN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Senate Race Narrows In Recount
description: The race between Senator Nicholas A. Spano, who is Republican, and his Democratic challenger, Andrea Stewart-Cousins, narrowed to fewer than 200 votes yesterday, the Democratic Party reported, as election officials began the recount of ballots cast on voting machines in the 35th Senate District. Jonathan Rosen, campaign director for the New York Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, said Ms. Stewart-Cousins picked up about 1,400 votes in the recount of machines from 6 of 12 wards. The machine recount was expected to continue through tomorrow. Anthony J. Mangone, counsel to Mr. Spano, said he could not confirm the Democrats' tally, but said the day's recount "did cut down the lead considerably." Carolee C. Sunderland, the Republican chairwoman of the county's Board of Elections, said she would not discuss tallies until the recount was complete. Kirk Semple (NYT)

description: Investors in Microcell Telecommunications have accepted a takeover bid by Rogers Wireless Communications Inc., creating the largest wireless company in Canada, Rogers said yesterday. Rogers Wireless offered 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.17 billion).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Baykeeper Sues Suffolk County
description: The Peconic Baykeeper, a conservation group concerned with marine issues, filed suit yesterday in federal court in Central Islip, charging Suffolk County with running a mosquito control program that violates the Clean Water Act. Kevin McAllister, the group's executive director, said violations included discharging pesticides into coastal waters, illegally ditching wetlands and causing pollutants to discharge through the ditches into the Peconics. A spokesman for the Suffolk County executive said officials had not seen the suit. John Rather (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Several Sheep Die In Turnpike Crash
description: A collision between two trucks on the New Jersey Turnpike last night killed at least 22 sheep in one of the trucks and left others running along the turnpike in a panic, said a spokesman for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. The accident, which caused no human injuries, occurred about 11 p.m. in the northbound lanes near the interchange to Route 8A, said the spokesman, Joe Orlando, who said he did not know how the crash occurred. Animal control officers were called to help round up about 16 sheep that had escaped. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: State Overseer Approves Nassau Budget
description: The Nassau Interim Finance Authority, the state agency overseeing Nassau County's finances, gave final approval yesterday to the 2005 budget of $2.5 billion that the County Legislature adopted last week. The agency said County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi's administration continues making progress in restoring Nassau's fiscal health. But it cautioned that the county-subsidized Nassau Health Care Corporation needed to reduce deficits, and that the county had to do better at property assessments to avoid costly refunds. It also approved new borrowing estimated at $500 million, about a third of it for tax refunds and the rest to refinance existing debt, saving about $32 million. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: For Blood Pressure, Normal May Not Be Optimal, Study Finds
description: A new study of heart disease patients finds that "normal" blood pressure may not be low enough. By reducing their pressure still more, patients were protected from heart attacks, cardiac arrest, angioplasty, hospitalization for chest pain, and death.

title: Kerry Advisers Point Fingers at Iraq and Social Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 - In a glum post-mortem to the presidential campaign, senior advisers to Senator John Kerry said Monday that Mr. Kerry lost because he had failed to turn the election into a referendum on the economy, a problem they attributed to a barrage of foreign policy news and the success of the White House in wielding cultural issues.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Al Gore Helps Start A Fund
description: Al Gore, the former vice president, and David Blood, a former chief executive of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, are forming an investment fund that will select stocks after considering a company's social, environmental and political activities. The fund, which will be based in London, will be marketed to pension funds and wealthy private investors and will focus on long-term investments. It will be called Generation Asset Management. Mr. Gore, Mr. Blood and four other founding partners have contributed the fund's start-up capital, and it will begin managing money in early 2005. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: BT Group Agrees To Buy Infonet

description: The European Union threatened to take action through the World Trade Organization against the United States and Canada unless they drop $126 million in tariffs imposed on European exports in retaliation for a ban on hormone-treated beef. The United States and Canada have levied duties on European goods including textiles and Roquefort cheese since 1999, after the W.T.O. found the European Union had not proved a health risk to consumers from hormone-treated beef.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Daughter Charged In Man's Death
description: The daughter of a 67-year-old man who was found beaten to death with a hammer on Friday has been charged with his murder, the authorities said yesterday. The woman, Laura Martin, 43, fought with her father, John Martin, last Wednesday in their Long Island City housing project and struck him with a hammer, the Queens district attorney's office said. The next day, prosecutors said, she placed a plastic bag over his head and a blanket over his body, cleaned up the blood, dropped her 5-year-old daughter at school and smoked cocaine for several hours. On Friday, she acted as if she had discovered the body, neighbors said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB WILL PURCHASE A STAKE IN MEDAREX

Bristol-Myers will buy a $25 million stake in Medarex and pay another $25 million in cash, the companies said. Medarex may receive as much as $205 million if regulatory goals for the medicines are met and another $275 million for reaching sales targets. The companies will share the cost of developing the products in Europe and the United States. Bristol-Myers, based in New York, will pay for development in other countries. Medarex is based in Princeton, N.J.

title: ALLIANCE CAPITAL IS ASKED FOR DATA ON SALES INCENTIVES

The agencies are investigating programs in which mutual fund companies make undisclosed payments to brokers in exchange for preferential treatment. DION AGREES TO PURCHASE STANDARD COMMERCIAL
description: Dimon, a tobacco-leaf dealer, agreed to buy a smaller competitor, the Standard Commercial Corporation, for about $255 million in stock, the companies said yesterday. The transaction values Standard Commercial's 13.7 million outstanding shares at $18.66 each, a 13.8 percent premium over the closing price on Friday. Including Standard Commercial's debt, the transaction is valued at about $670 million. Dimon shareholders will control 52 percent of the new company, which will be called DimonStandard. The company expects to save $40 million in annual costs and to increase earnings beginning next year. Investors will receive three Dimon shares for each share of Standard Commercial. Dimon is based in Danville, Va., and Standard Commercial is based in Wilson, N.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CREAGHAN, GEORGE B.
description: CREAGHAN--George B. was taken to his rest today by those who loved him, his magnificent wife Ellen, his son Dennis, daughters Patricia and Georgina, son-law-law Mark Tillinger and brother and sister-in-law Charles and Phyllis Ponsford. Mr. Creaghan, an entreprenuer, was born in London, England in 1909 and emigrated to the United States in 1953. In World War II, during the many months of the bombing of London, he served in the Air Raid Precautions Division. He faced this heavy and dangerous work with composure and fortitude as night after night he rescued the living and recovered the dead. He succumbed to Alzheimer's Disease Saturday, November 6th, 2004 after waging a long and gallant fight over the last 10 years. God have mercy on his soul.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unibanco Sells Credit Card Stake
description: Citigroup and the Brazilian bank Banco Ita Holding Financeira said they had agreed to buy out Unibanco's one-third stake in Credicard, Brazil's biggest credit card issuer. The deal, if approved by regulatory authorities, will give Citigroup and Ita each a 50 percent stake in Credicard, which has 7.6 million clients and assets totaling 3.3 billion reais ($1.17 billion). Unio de Bancos Brasileiros, as Unibanco is formally known, said it would earn a pretax profit of about 1.4 billion reais ($494 million) from the sale. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Sharon Weathers Showdown Over Gaza Withdrawal
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 - Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel succeeded Monday in facing down an ultimatum from his finance minister and party rival, Benjamin Netanyahu. Israel radio reported that Mr. Netanyahu had withdrawn his threat to resign on Tuesday, despite Mr. Sharon's refusal to schedule a national referendum over his plan to withdraw all Israeli settlers unilaterally from the Gaza Strip and a few hundred from the West Bank.

It was the first major personnel decision made by the president since his re-election, and it suggested that Mr. Bush did not intend any major shakeup of his most senior White House aides.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Industrial Expansion Slows
description: Malaysia's industrial production grew 9.8 percent in September from the month a year earlier, the slowest monthly expansion in a year, according to preliminary data released by the country's Department of Statistics. A primary reason for the slowdown was a marked decline in growth in Malaysia's mining sector. Economists called the data additional evidence that Asian economies are slowing as global demand cools. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Citigroup In Loan Acquisition
description: Citigroup agreed to buy a 16.4 percent stake in Silver Grant International Industries, a Chinese specialist in nonperforming loans, for 845 million Hong Kong dollars ($109 million). Citigroup also plans to set up a venture with Silver Grant, a real estate investor listed in Hong Kong and controlled by the China Cinda Asset Management Company, to buy bad loans in China. "This is a major opportunity for us," said Joseph Draper, a managing director at Citigroup's global markets unit. Silver Grant's shares rose 15 percent on the news.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Voters Defeat Pension Change
description: Voters defeated a proposition that would have changed the city's charter to make the mayor and other city officials eligible for pensions. The measure had been opposed by the police union, which held a protest march on Stamford's government center and handed out leaflets mocking Mayor Dannel P. Malloy. Opponents objected to the phrasing on the ballot, which asked whether voters favored making the charter "conform to current practices and labor law." The measure failed, 14,114 to 11,259. Mrs. Louis was a member of the national Board of Directors and of the Southern California Chapter executive board. She was actively involved with the chapter for three decades and was instrumental in its growth. A recognized philanthropist committed to many Jewish causes, Mrs. Louis and her late husband, Norman, became Technion Guardians, reaching the highest level of support for the ATS, Technion and Israel. They generously supported many Southern California Chapter projects and established the Norman and Trudy Louis Chair in Materials Engineering. Mrs. Louis was a recipient of the Albert Einstein Award, the highest honor bestowed by the ATS, and of a Technion honorary fellowship. She was an honorary member of the Technion International Board of Governors. We extend our sincere condolences to her children, Jerry and Jeffrey Louis; brother, Harvey Mandel; and the entire Louis family. title: Arts, Briefly; Fickle Viewers
description: The November ratings sweeps continue, and, according the Nielsen overnights, a different network won each weekend night. Friday was dominated by NBC, which has found a winning combination with "Dateline," "Third Watch" and "Medical Investigation," to the detriment of CBS's "Joan of Arcadia," which is down from its first-season numbers. Saturday night belonged to Fox, with its reality crime show lineup, "Cops" and "America's Most Wanted." The only original drama on Saturday, television's graveyard, was an episode of CBS's low-rated "Clubhouse" in its new 8 p.m. time period. It performed significantly worse than the "Survivor" repeats that occupied the slot in previous weeks. On Sunday, when millions more people turn their televisions back on, ABC won the night over all, and "Desperate Housewives" got its highest number of viewers yet: 24.89 million. On Fox, the return of the Emmy-winning "Arrested Development," above, improved over its ratings last year, attracting 8.03 million viewers. But in Fox's 9 p.m. hour the series premiere of "My Big Fat Obnoxious Boss" lost more than 3 million of those viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Arts, Briefly; Fiddling Around
description: So who's going to be the next Tevye after Alfred Molina's run in the Broadway revival of "Fiddler on the Roof" comes to a close in early January? The word along Broadway yesterday, as well as on its Web sites, was that one of the industry's best known and bankable stars -- Harvey Fierstein, right -- might well be in line for the role. Producers weren't saying, but one member of the production team confirmed that Mr. Fierstein was "a name on the list" to play Tevye, the family-beleaguered, tradition-bound patriarch in that 1964 musical by Jerry Bock, Sheldon Harnick and Joseph Stein. And indeed, yesterday the crocodile-voiced Mr. Fierstein was seen eating with the director of "Fiddler," David Leveaux, at the popular Broadway bistro Angus McIndoe, on West 44th Street. While some "Fiddler" purists might be bewildered by the idea that the world-weary Tevye could be played by Mr. Fierstein -- most recently a Tony Award winner for his colorful turns as Edna Turnblad in "Hairspray" -- the show could use the buzz. At the 1,710-seat Minskoff Theater, where several shows are said to be interested in being the next tenant, "Fiddler" played last week to just 52 percent of its capacity. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Arts, Briefly; The Boss Back Home
description: Bruce Springsteen, left, made a surprise appearance at the Stone Pony nightclub in Asbury Park, N.J., on Saturday night, taking part in a benefit concert for the Parkinson's Disease Foundation and the Muscular Dystrophy Organization. The performance was his first since President Bush's election victory. Mr. Springsteen had campaigned for Senator John Kerry and teamed up with other performers for a MoveOn-sponsored "Vote for Change" tour of major swing states. But, he said on Saturday, "I'm just here to play music tonight." At about 1 a.m., during a set by Joe Grushecky and the Houserockers, Mr. Springsteen hopped onstage with a blond electric guitar. Hair combed back, with a soul patch on his chin, denim shirt unbuttoned to his chest and hanging out of his denim jeans, he joined in on "Idiots Delight," one of Mr. Grushecky's songs. He remained onstage with the band until 2:30 a.m., performing several songs, including "Johnny 99," "Code of Silence," "Murder Incorporated" and "This Hard Land." Mr. Springsteen made some light stage banter, and thanked everyone for coming but made no anti-Bush comments as he did on his tour. JOE BRESCIA

title: Do You Hear Sleigh Bells? Nah, Just Tom Hanks and Some Train
description: Based on the 32-page children's book by Chris Van Allsburg, the new animated feature "The Polar Express" has already received attention for the advanced technology employed to make the film and the heart-skipping amount of money reportedly spent to transpose the story from page to screen. I suspect that most moviegoers care more about stories and characters than how much money it took for a digitally rendered strand of hair to flutter persuasively in the wind. Nor will they care that to make "Polar Express" Tom Hanks wore a little cap that transmitted a record of his movements to a computer, creating templates for five different animated characters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOFFLER, STEPHEN A.
description: KOFFLER--Stephen A., adoring husband to Enid, and loving father to two daughters, Samara and Debra, passed away on Friday November 5, 2004 after a long, courageous battle with cancer. Born in Providence, Rhode Island in 1942, Stephen earned his doctorate at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in solid state physics and material science engineering. He resided with his family in Pacific Palisades, California for 32 years. Stephen was deeply loved and respected by his family, friends and business associates as a warm-hearted, honest and incredibly generous individual. He will always be remembered for his intelligent wit, offbeat sense of humor and an endless spirit and passion for life. Stephen A. Koffler was a Managing Director at Barrington Associates and formerly a Managing Director with both Smith Barney and Merrill Lynch & Co. He also launched his own firm Koffler & Co., which was eventually acquired by Barrington Associates. "Steve was a valuable partner and a dedicated family man," said Jim Freedman, Managing Director of Barrington Associates. "His guidance and presence at our Firm will be greatly missed." After a successful career on Wall Street, Mr. Koffler joined Mattel, Inc. as a senior financial executive, and went on to run the west coast operations of several firms, including Smith Barney, Merrill Lynch & Co, and Sutro & Co. He was well known as one of the leading investment bankers in the country, pivotal in highprofile deals including the sale of Jenny Craig to Deutsche Bank in 2002, Midas Rex to Medtronics, and Avia to Reebok, as well as many others. Mr. Koffler served on the Board of many organizations including Saint John's Health Center Foundation, the Greater Los Angeles Zoo Association, Sandel Medical Industries, and the Los Angeles Music Center Opera. A memorial service will be held at the Leo Baeck Temple 1300 North Sepulveda Blvd. in Los Angeles, California on Thursday, November 11th at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: St. John's Nurse Endowment Fund 1328 22nd Street Santa Monica, CA 90404; St. John's Health Center, 1328 22nd Street Santa Monica, CA 90404; Conscious Youth Media Crew -Stephen A. Koffler Scholarship Fund c/o Debra Koffler, 349 San Jose Avenue San Francisco, CA 94110

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Lesbian Couple Challenges Marriage Rebuff
description: The High Court in Dublin said that a lesbian couple who married in Canada last year could challenge the country's tax authorities for refusing to grant them the tax benefits of a married couple. The couple, Katherine Zappone, a public policy consultant and a member of the government's Human Rights Commission, and Ann Louise Gilligan, an academic, are Irish citizens who own a house in County Dublin and have lived together for 23 years. They argued that a heterosexual couple living in Ireland who had married in Canada should be recognized. Dr. Zappone said outside the court that their application to file their tax returns as a married couple and pay less tax would be "the first steps to seek legal recognition for our lifelong love." It is also the first move for same-sex marriage in Ireland. Brian Lavery (NYT)

15 Years After the Wall Came Down, the Ghosts Abound in Berlin
description: BERLIN - The wall has been gone for 15 years now, but the ghosts are not. Photographs of Hitler stare down from ubiquitous fliers advertising the hit film of the fall, "The Downfall," an account of the last 12 days of Hitler's life. Near the site of the bunker in which he killed himself, by the Brandenburg Gate, a field of 2,700 concrete blocks is nearing completion as the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe. The Reichstag building stands farther on, its gleaming new interior still displaying the graffiti of victorious Russian soldiers (minus the obscenities).

The partners, associates and staff of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP mourn the tragic and untimely passing of Conor Reilly, our friend and partner in the firm's New York office. Conor was well known and highly respected in the legal community for his brilliance, energy and wit. He was an exceptional lawyer whose legal skills knew no bounds. He was as comfortable closing a corporate deal as he was litigating a court case, and later in his career, he became a leader in the New York bankruptcy bar. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Margaret and his two children, Kate and Mike. Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP

title: Two Bushes and the Everglades
description: Four years ago, Congress set in motion the biggest and technologically most ambitious environmental initiative in the country's history: an $8 billion project to restore the Florida Everglades, which is dying for lack of fresh water. The idea is to capture much of Florida's abundant rainfall, which is now flushed out to sea, and reroute it to Everglades National Park through a system of reservoirs, levees and canals. It's a 50-50 deal, with the federal and state governments sharing costs and governance. One important reason for Washington's involvement is to make sure that Florida, whose politicians are notoriously vulnerable to special interests, does not hijack the project and give all the water to the developers and the agricultural interests, chiefly Big Sugar.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chip Maker's Profit Falls
description: The computer chip maker Infineon Technologies said fourth-quarter profit fell 10 percent from the year-earlier period, to 44 million euros ($57 million), falling short of expectations. Much of the decline reflected 138 million euros in one-time charges, but the chief executive, Wolfgang Ziebart, above, who took his post in September, said that the company expected first-quarter sales and profit to decline as well because of a slowdown in the semiconductor industry. Sales in the fourth quarter, which ended Sept. 30, rose 13 percent, to 1.99 billion euros. Infineon is based in Munich. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | People: Conexant Names Chief Executive
description: Conexant Systems has named its chairman, Dwight W. Decker, as chief executive. Armando Geday, who succeeded Mr. Decker as chief executive in February, resigned for personal reasons. The company will cut quarterly operating expenses by $15 million and move its headquarters to Newport Beach, Calif., from Red Bank, N.J., Mr. Decker, 54, said yesterday in a conference call with analysts.

title: Yasir Arafat, Palestinian Leader, Dies at 75
description: Yasir Arafat, who died on Thursday in Paris at age 75, was the wily, enigmatic father and leader of Palestinian nationalism for almost 40 years and symbolized his peopleAs longing for a distinct political identity and independent state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZHARNEST, DAVID
description: ZHARNEST--David. 45, of New York City, N.Y. and Manalapan, N.J., passed away on November 9, 2004 at Englewood Hospital, Englewood, N.J. David is survived by his wife Lauren and his three adoring children, Michael age 18, Andrew age 13, and Jessica age 8. He was the beloved husband and father who was the rock and center throughout their lives. David is also survived by his loving father Fred, who served as confidante and life line; a devoted son and grandson to the late Marcia Zharnest and Esther Lerner. David is also survived by his sister Cheryl and niece Marisa age 16 and nephew Jordan age 8. David was the best brother, uncle and friend in the world to them. He will be missed deeply. David was the Executive Vice President of Wachovia Securities formerly Prudential Financial. Respected by his many business associates for his strong work ethics and leadership skills; friend to all who knew him. Funeral services Wednesday 1pm "Schwartz Bros-Jeffers Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd and 76th Rd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Cisco Profits Are Higher,but Investors Want More
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 - Cisco Systems, the largest maker of Internet networking equipment, reported Tuesday that its first-quarter profit rose 29 percent, squarely in line with Wall Street forecasts. But the earnings report disappointed investors hoping for stronger signs of a comeback in corporate technology spending.

title: JETBLUE TO RAISE $500 MILLION TO BUY 15 NEW PLANES
description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it planned to raise nearly $500 million to finance the purchase of 15 new Airbus jets. The airline, in a regulatory filing, said that it would issue three classes of enhanced equipment trust certificates, also known as pass-through certificates, which are a common aircraft financing tool. The purchase would increase JetBlue's outstanding debt by about one-third. The airline will take delivery on the first of the jets in January. JetBlue's chief executive, David Neeleman, canceled an appearance yesterday before a Smith Barney Citigroup transportation conference, where he had been expected to discuss the outlook for the low-fare airline. JetBlue, based in New York, reported a decline in third-quarter earnings last month, missing analysts' estimates, and warned that it might post a small loss for the fourth quarter. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: J.P. MORGAN MAY BE DISCIPLINED OVER MUTUAL FUND TRADES
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that it might be disciplined by NASD for failing to detect and prevent improper trading of mutual funds. NASD staff members recommended disciplinary action against the Bank One Securities Corporation, a unit of the Bank One Corporation that J.P. Morgan purchased in July, for lacking the supervisory system and written procedures needed to prevent so-called late trading of its funds, J.P. Morgan said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. J.P. Morgan is based in New York.

title: Olives? Yes. Stuffed? Yes. There the Resemblance Ends.
description: They may look like ordinary pimento-stuffed olives -- to nibble with a drink, drop into a cocktail or use as a garnish -- but Ybarra green olives are far from the usual. For starters, they are excellent green Manzanillas, and they are stuffed with slightly piquant strips of roasted Spanish piquillo peppers. The olives, in 10-ounce jars, are available from the Spanish Table in Seattle at www.spanishtable.com for $11.99 plus shipping for three jars. They are $3.99 a jar at the Spanish Table's retail shops in Seattle; Berkeley, Calif.; and Santa Fe, N.M.

title: HONDA TO BUILD TRANSMISSION PLANT IN GEORGIA
description: The Honda Motor Company said yesterday that it would spend $270 million to build a transmission plant in Georgia and expand operations in Ohio and Alabama. The expansion will add 600 jobs in the United States, 400 of them at the new plant in Tallapoosa, Ga., 40 miles west of Atlanta. The Georgia plant will be Honda's 13th manufacturing operation in North America; it is scheduled to open in the fall of 2006. The other 200 jobs will be added at existing plants in Russells Point, Ohio, and Lincoln, Ala. Honda is based in Tokyo. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda's Profit Rises
description: Profit at the Mazda Motor Corporation increased 68 percent in the first half of its fiscal year on robust sales in Europe and companywide cost-cutting. Mazda reported that net profit rose to 18.73 billion yen ($177 million) for the six months ended Sept. 30, from 11.15 billion yen in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 9 percent, to 1.32 trillion yen, on strong sales of the Mazda6 and Mazda3 sedans in Europe. The company, which is one-third owned by Ford Motor, also raised its profit forecast for the full year ending next March to 37 billion yen, from an earlier forecast of 34 billion yen. Mazda's rising profit is partly a result of a campaign to cut costs by sharing more parts and components with Ford. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Eyes on the Prizes
description: Some familiar names turned up yesterday when the short lists for the 2004 Whitbread Book Awards were announced, most clearly in the category for best novel: Kate Atkinson for "Case Histories"; Louis de Bernires, right, for "Birds Without Wings," his first novel since the best-selling "Captain Corelli's Mandolin"; Alan Hollinghurst for "Line of Beauty," already the winner of this year's Booker Prize; and Andrea Levy, for "Small Island." One of Britain's major literary awards, the Whitbread was established in 1971 to recognize the best contemporary British writing. This year's winner will be announced on Jan. 25. Last year's overall winner, "The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time" by Mark Haddon, has sold more than a million copies since its publication in paperback in April 2004 and has received 17 prizes worldwide since it was first published in May 2003. Plans are for a ground-floor bakery with food to go and a lower-level market with produce, meat, fish and Mr. Bouley's own products. Mr. Bouley said the demonstration kitchen will have guest instructors from France, Italy and Japan.

title: North Korean at U.S. Consulate in Russia Tests New Asylum Rules
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 8 - Ten days after President Bush signed into law a bill easing the way for North Koreans to win political asylum in the United States, a North Korean man jumped from a neighboring building onto the roof of the American Consulate in Vladivostok, Russia, entered the building and asked for asylum.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Scare At Courthouse
description: Federal marshals in Atlanta said they briefly sealed the Federal District Court chambers of Judge Clarence Cooper, who is hearing a case on the teaching of evolution, after his secretary opened a suspicious letter containing white powder. The ventilation system in his wing was shut down, but the trial was not disrupted. The letter, which bore a return address and name, did not appear to be related to the case, said Richard V. Mecum, a United States marshal. The powder, which passed sensors at the courthouse intended to detect toxic substances, was being tested, and the secretary seemed to suffer no ill effects, Mr. Mecum said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Final Piece of Trade Center Project May Involve Battle With Real Estate Clan
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is preparing to acquire the last block needed for an expanded World Trade Center site. But it may have a fight on its hands.

title: Beltran to Yankees Could Be Only a Matter of Time
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Nov. 9 - Center fielder Carlos Beltran, the most attractive free agent this off-season, has supposedly been fitted for Yankee pinstripes. Several major league executives have said that the Yankees will end up signing him to a mammoth deal.

title: Rebels, Guns and Money
description: Fairfax, Va. - The Marine and Army forces now entering Falluja, Iraq have prepared for this fight for some time, and not just since the collapse of Saddam Hussein's regime last spring. Our military has a long history of training for and battling against unconventional enemies -- the Revolutionary War, the Indian wars, Vietnam and, in particular, a battle few American think much about: the invasion of Panama City in 1989.

title: A Fable of False Hope, Hubris and Tinseltown
description: In 1997 Troy Duffy, a transplanted New Englander working as a bartender in Los Angeles, became a minor celebrity when Miramax offered him $1 million for a screenplay. News of the deal, which reportedly included a promise that Miramax's co-chairman Harvey Weinstein would help Mr. Duffy purchase the bar where he worked, made headlines not only in the trades, but also on local television news and even on the front page of USA Today. It was another heartwarming Hollywood success story about a scrappy, talented outsider hitting the big time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RADIN, THE HON. ROYAL S.
description: RADIN--The Hon. Royal S. Of Staten Island. On November 8, 2004. Beloved husband of Faye (nee Reiman). Dear father of Dr. Laura RadinBarber, Jana Staffaroni and Kathleen Garzo. Brother of Sanford Radin and Beatrice Margulies. Grandfather of Michael, Adam, Tyler and Louis. A funeral service will be conducted at Temple Israel Reformed Congregation, Forest Ave, S.I., Thursday, 11:30AM. Interment Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, N.J. Visiting Wednesday 2-4, 7-9PM Meislohn Silvie Funeral Home, 1289 Forest Ave, S.I., N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions to S.I. Institute of Art and Sciences would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENAKER, MARTIN
description: MENAKER -- Martin. The partners and staff of Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield extend their deepest condolences to the family of our longtime advisor and friend, Martin Menaker. Martin consulted with and advised our firm brilliantly for many years and we are deeply indebted to him for his sage advice and wise counsel. Our sympathy is extended to his wife, Saundra, his daughters, Melanie and Ellen, his son, Lawrence and his many grandchildren. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield MENAKER -- Martin. The partners and staff express deep sorrow at the death of our retired senior partner and friend. His judgment and skills helped to guide us for many years. Our sympathy to his wife, Saundra and the rest of their families. Eisner & Lubin LLP MENAKER--Martin. It is with deep sorrow that I mourn the passing of Marty after 45 years of friendship. With sincere condolences to Saundra and the children. Love, Al

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Moody's Upgrades State Bond Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service upgraded New York State's weak bond rating yesterday for the first time in 14 years, reflecting recovery in the state's economy and rebounding tax collections. Moody's raised the rating on the state's general obligation bonds one notch, to A1. Although the A1 rating is still among the lowest in the nation, Moody's cited improving economic conditions in New York City and a move by lawmakers in Albany to raise income and sales taxes last year, over Gov. George E. Pataki's objections. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Some Schools Grow and Suffer as System Favors the Small
description: SENSELESS as the decision would ultimately seem, Lisandra Noboa actually chose to attend Washington Irving High School. That was back in the spring of 2001, when she was 13 years old and already intent on a career in fashion design. Lisandra had heard that Washington Irving offered a specialized program in the field, and that opportunity was worth the 45-minute subway trip from her home in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx to the school just off Union Square in Lower Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Hostage Taker Is Shot
description: A man with a message for the news media held a clerk hostage at the Mexican Consulate in Los Angeles before he was shot and wounded by the police. The man was hospitalized in critical condition. The clerk was unharmed. The police chief, William Bratton, said that the man appeared at the consulate about 8:30 a.m., and said: "Call 911. I want the media here." When the man emerged from the building with his arm around the neck of the woman he had taken hostage, he was wearing several handmade placards whose message was not legible on television. John Broder (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Plan To Improve Education
description: Gov. Ernie Fletcher has outlined a multistep plan to improve education by raising teacher salaries, improving reading programs, designing programs to prepare more high school students for college and using universities to advance economic development. Mr. Fletcher, a Republican, wants to see teacher salaries on par with salaries in nearby states. He told lawmakers at a hearing that increasing state revenues would pay for the changes. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Chides the M.T.A. for Its Failure to Control Costs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sharply stepped up his criticism of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday at a hearing on its plans to increase fares and cut service, accusing the agency of presiding over "bloated payrolls" and "out-of-control spending."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEDY, MARY ELIZABETH
description: KENNEDY--Mary Elizabeth, 49, of Fairfield, CT, died Monday after a valiant struggle with cancer. Ms. Kennedy was a Sales Executive at Mottahedeh Inc. prior to becoming a Social Worker. Survivors include her beloved parents, John M. and Yvonne Kennedy of Fairfield; 7 loving siblings and many adoring nieces and nephews. Memorial Mass November 13th, 11:00 A.M. at St. Augustine's Cathedral, Bridgeport. Donations to Special Olympics of CT, 999 Oronoque Lane, Stratford, CT 06614

title: Marketers Plan Holiday Blitzes
description: LEADING national retailers -- worried about the size of their coming holiday haul -- are intensifying efforts to find the right advertising to entice jaded shoppers into opening their wallets and purses before Dec. 25.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
description: DEALS LIKE THE $208 MILLION SALE of a skyscraper in downtown Chicago are a sign that the commercial real estate market is dangerously overpriced, some investors and analysts say. [C6.]

title: Dutch Arrest 2 Men Suspected of Links to Islamic Terrorists
description: THE HAGUE, Nov. 10 - The Dutch police arrested two North African men here today following a daylong siege that began when three officers were injured by a hand grenade during a predawn raid on an apartment suspected of harboring Islamic terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHASSIN, ROSLYN (NEE ROSSETT)
description: CHASSIN--Roslyn (nee Rossett). Died peacefully on November 5, 2004, in Tempe, AZ. Honey cherished and was cherished by her husband of 68 years, Dr. Maurice R. Chassin, her sister Marcia Cohen, daughters Marla, Laurie and Terri, sons - in - law Charles, Clark and Douglas, grandchildren Andrew and Patti, Susan and Nathan, Nora, Daniel, David and Matthew and great-granddaughter Amanda. She will be greatly missed. Contributions to New York Hospital and Medical Center of Queens. Services at Schwartz Bros., 1403 Queens Blvd, Wednesday, November 10 at noon.

title: The Rule of Law at Gitmo
description: A prosecution before the first American military commission since World War II was halted this week, just as it was getting started, by a federal judge in Washington who ruled that the proceedings lacked the basic elements of a fair trial and violated the Geneva Conventions. It was the latest in a series of court decisions that have taken the Bush administration to task for trampling on the law in the name of fighting terrorists. The administration should bring its policies into compliance with the law.

title: 1904:Why Republicans Won : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
Simply French: Comfort Food With Style
description: WHEN I was a child, anyone who wanted to show off cooking skills cooked French food. I don't mean that disparagingly. But then, the sort of French food that was current in those innocent days was more bistro than the sort of fancy, frilly plate decoration that has done such a lamentable public relations job for the reputation of la cuisine franaise. The food of France that I love is the food that Julia Child introduced to America and Elizabeth David to Britain.

title: Buy a G.M. Car at 0% Now, Get the Same Deal in 5 Years
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9 - Can fear of the Fed sell cars?

title: Corrections
'We have already passed the high point' : Infineon to cut costs as chip sales cool off
A Russian Rarity Written Before the Deluge
description: Truls Mork's cello sound has always been warm, rounded and richly lyrical, and his interpretive sense continues to find new depths. In a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, Mr. Mork, supported by Kathryn Stott, the pianist, gave beautifully focused performances of works by Miaskovsky, Prokofiev, Janacek and Chopin, and if a singing Romanticism was pervasive, there was also sufficient nuance to give each composer a distinct sense of style.

title: MAYTAG FORECASTS A SHARP RISE IN PROFITS NEXT YEAR
description: The Maytag Corporation, the home appliance maker, said yesterday that it expected a sharp increase in net income next year as a result of job cuts, plant closings and price increases. The news set off a 9 percent gain in Maytag's share price. The company, based in Newton, Iowa, said it expected to earn $1.50 to $1.60 a share next year. It has forecast a profit of 11 cents to 16 cents a share for the current year. Maytag's stock rose $1.74, to $20.27 a share.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 20 about an announcement by Yukos, the Russian oil company, that it would reduce some exports to China misstated the ownership of the Interfax news agency, which reported the development. (The error also occurred in articles on Sept. 25 and Oct. 9.) The agency is part of the Interfax Group, a privately held corporation established in 1989 as the former Soviet Union's first nongovernmental news organization; it is not part of a state-controlled enterprise. This correction was delayed for research into the ownership structure.

title: Youths know little of Communist era : Bulgaria struggles to remember its past
Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 25 about allegations of favoritism by the Army Corps of Engineers in awarding large contracts to the Halliburton Company in Iraq and the Balkans misstated the age of the corps' chief contracting officer, Bunnatine H. Greenhouse, who made the allegations. She is 60, not 62.

title: Wary of Regulators' Scrutiny, Reinsurer Ends Berkshire Deal
description: Responding to heightened scrutiny of a once-common insurance industry practice, Platinum Underwriters Holdings, a Bermuda-based provider of property and casualty reinsurance, said yesterday that it was scrapping an insurance contract it had bought from Berkshire Hathaway because the deal might not meet regulatory standards.

description: In percent

title: U.S. says it is 'ready' for new Mideast effort
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Sought In Rapes
description: A man who attacked and raped a woman in Greenpoint last week also committed an earlier sexual assault in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The most recent attack occurred last Thursday, the police said, when the man, dressed in a beige jacket, beige hat and clean-shaven, entered a cellphone store in Greenpoint and raped the 22-year-old clerk, the police said. He then stole cellphones and $3,000 from the register. The police said that in September, the man, wearing dark clothing and a moustache and goatee, entered a store in Williamsburg where a 20-year-old woman was working alone. He beat her in the head with a gun, then led her to the back of the store where he tried to rape her, they said. She struggled and he fled, robbing the cash register as he left, the police said. The police described the man as in his 20's, about five-foot-seven, and weighing about 150 pounds. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Safety Board Faults F.A.A. Over Risks on Runways
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - The Federal Aviation Administration is moving too slowly to reduce the risk of planes colliding on runways, the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday.

title: Too Many Cooks, Too Few Affordable Spaces
description: WHEN Hakan Swahn, the owner of Aquavit, began looking for a new home for his renowned restaurant two years ago, he was determined to find space that was within a five-minute walk of its longstanding home at 13 West 54th Street.

title: After Arafat, Hope
description: WASHINGTON - The only lifelong terrorist to win a Nobel Peace Prize lies comatose in Paris, with his well-heeled wife -- for years unwilling to share his privations in Ramallah -- screaming at Palestinian leaders on Al Jazeera television that "they're trying to bury [him] alive!" More likely, they may be trying to learn in what secret accounts he buried millions of dollars.

title: U.S.-Led Assault Marks Advances Against Falluja
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Wednesday, Nov. 10 - After two days of street-to-street fighting, the American-led assault on Falluja had wrested at least a third of the city from insurgents on Tuesday, capturing the mayor's office, two mosques, a commercial center and other major objectives in the heart of the downtown and advancing past the main highway through the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TREEGER, HELEN
description: TREEGER -- Helen. The Board of Directors and staff of VISIONS/Services for the Blind and Visually impaired records with great sorrow the passing of Helen Treeger. She was a most dedicated supporter of VISIONS and Vacation Camp for the Blind and member of the Board of Directors and Advisory Council for 58 years. Mrs. Treeger served with distinction on the Public Relations Committee and as editor of the newsletter and annual report. She was an avid fundraiser and participant in development activities. Our heartfelt sympathy is expressed to her husband Clarence, who is a former VISIONS Board President, and her entire family. Nancy T. Jones, President Nancy D. Miller, Executive Director TREEGER--Helen F. Her neighbors at 125 W. 76 St., where she lived for over 65 years, mourn her passing and extend to her husband Clarence and to her family our deepest sympathy. Rolf Meyersohn, President

title: The Roh era : A social revolution shakes South Korea
New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: Leaders in Nassau and Suffolk Vow to Try a Little Diplomacy
description: MELVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 9 - The top officials of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, meeting in a building overlooking their geographical border, agreed Tuesday that they had far more in common than their boundary and pledged to find ways to work together on mutual problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAPPORT, LEONA
description: RAPPORT--Leona, 93, of Bayonne, NJ on October 19, 2004 of natural causes. Beloved mother of Betty Goretsky. Grandmother of four, great grandmother of seven. Donations in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice. Services will be private.

title: The French Are Snared, but This Struggle Is Ivoirian
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 9 - The news reports streaming out of Abidjan, Ivory Coast's once shining metropolis, seem like a throwback to a bygone era: white men and women cowering in their homes, black men and women rampaging through the streets, European soldiers swooping down in helicopters and plucking Europeans to safety.

title: Not To Be Confused With Saltines
description: Silvana Nardone, left, the owner of Fanciulla Specialty Foods, a wholesale bakery in Red Hook, Brooklyn, has a new savory, herb-flecked cracker with a touch of sweetness from dried fruit. The crackers, called Wine Flats, come in currant-fennel, cherry-peppercorn and fig-rosemary flavors, all addictive on their own or with a spread of some kind. She uses New York State chardonnay from Rivendell Winery in New Paltz in the dough, so Robert Ransom, an owner of the winery and of the Vintage New York stores in SoHo and on the Upper West Side, is selling them at the stores. Gourmet Garage stores, Dean & DeLuca on Madison Avenue, Di Palo's in Little Italy and the Bedford Cheese Shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, are also selling them, for about $8 for a 6.5-ounce bag.

title: Here Comes Ramen, The Slurp Heard Round the World
description: AS a Tokyo-based jazz musician, Shigeto Kamada used to book gigs for his band in remote towns in Hokkaido (the Japanese equivalent of, say, northern Wisconsin), just so he could taste the ramen there. "I would hear of a place with a special broth or a new topping, and I just had to taste it," Mr. Kamada said.

title: Surgery Is Set, and Strahan Vows to Return
description: Giants defensive end Michael Strahan will have surgery today on the torn pectoral muscle he sustained against Chicago on Sunday, and he said the injury did not signal the end of his 12-year career.

title: Corrections
Hazing Still a Problem
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association does not specifically address hazing in its bylaws, but maybe it should consider it, given recent incidents in college hockey.

title: Rebel Fighters Who Fled Attack May Now Be Active Elsewhere
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Wednesday, Nov. 10 - Insurgent leaders in Falluja probably fled before the American-led offensive and may be coordinating attacks in Iraq that have left scores dead over the past few days, according to American military officials here.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pregnant Woman Struck By Car Dies
description: A pregnant woman struck by an out-of-control S.U.V. outside a Chinatown church on Oct. 28 has died of her injuries, a spokesman at Bellevue Hospital Center said yesterday. The woman, Zheng Bi Xiang, 34, was crossing Rutgers Street when a Toyota RAV4 drove onto the sidewalk and struck her before flipping on its side and sliding into a group of mourners outside a funeral at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church. She was five months pregnant. The fetus died last Wednesday and the woman died on Friday, the hospital said. The police said that the driver and a passenger, who ran away, turned themselves in later. No charges were filed. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, THOMAS B.
description: ALLEN--Thomas B. The Officers and Members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member, Tom Allen. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: New Study Links Pfizer's Bextra, Similar to Vioxx, to Heart Attacks
description: The incidence of heart attacks and strokes among patients given Pfizer's painkiller Bextra was more than double that of those given placebos, according to preliminary results of a study presented yesterday at the American Heart Association meeting in New Orleans.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Budget Airline Posts Profit
description: The budget airline Gol Linhas Areas Inteligentes said third-quarter profit was flat at 96.9 million reais ($34 million), but market share increased and revenue rose 28 percent. Higher costs offset the increased sales, which totaled 517.2 million reais. Gol, which went public this year, increased its market share to 21.5 percent from 19.8 percent a year earlier, according to the country's civil aviation agency. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Investigations of His Office Part of McGreevey's Legacy
description: TRENTON, Nov. 9 - Though he will have served less than three years in office, Gov. James E. McGreevey still managed to earn the dubious distinction of becoming one of the most thoroughly investigated governors in New Jersey history.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Plea In Terrorism Case
description: Imam Fawaz Damra, a Cleveland mosque leader who was stripped of his citizenship after being convicted of concealing his ties to Middle East terrorist organizations, wants a judge to delay his four-month prison term until January because his wife is ill. In June, a jury convicted Mr. Damra, 42, of Strongville, Ohio, of lying about his terrorist connections when he applied for United States citizenship a decade ago. Mr. Damra, who is Palestinian-born, heads the Islamic Center of Greater Cleveland, the largest mosque in Ohio. Prosecutors say they oppose Mr. Damra's request and want him to report to prison on Nov. 22. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Italy, and All Things Mediterranean
description: NEW YORK CITY does not lack for Italian restaurants or want for pasta, which has charmed its way into kitchens of many ethnic affiliations and managed to maintain favored status in carbohydrate-phobic times. Pasta greets me at every turn. I eat pasta perhaps every third night. At this point it takes a pretty saucy, sexy pasta dish to give me pause. It takes the bucatini at Tempo.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about the show "In Noah's Footsteps" at L'Antiquaire & the Connoisseur in Manhattan, misstated the former title of Dr. Edgar Munhall, who contributed to the catalog. He was chief curator at the Frick Collection, not its director.

title: Daily Bread, Every Day for 75 Years
description: BY the time you read this, the St. Francis Breadline will most likely have vanished for the day. It is one of the daily apparitions of Manhattan: there and then not; flesh, blood and hardship, then nothing.

title: Lennox Miller, Olympic Medalist in Track, Dies at 58
description: Lennox Miller, who won Olympic sprint medals for Jamaica in 1968 and 1972 and watched his daughter Inger win one for the United States in 1996, died Monday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 58 and had been a dentist in Pasadena for 30 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cisco Profits Are Higher, But Investors Want More Cisco Systems, the largest maker of Internet networking equipment, said its first-quarter profit rose 29 percent. The report disappointed investors hoping for stronger signs of a comeback in corporate technology spending.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Forrester To Run For Governor
description: Doug Forrester, a wealthy businessman who ran an unsuccessful self-financed campaign for United States senator in 2002, announced yesterday that he would join six other Republicans vying for the governor's office in 2005. Mr. Forrester, left, has maintained a public profile in recent months by spending more than a million dollars on television and radio advertisements addressing a range of topics, including one ad urging support for American troops abroad and another denouncing what he contends is the liberal bias of the CBS News anchorman, Dan Rather. Josh Benson (NYT)

title: Fed Raises Rates Again, to 2%, and Sees No Reason to Stop
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 - The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates today for the fourth time this year and suggested that it would continue to raise them gradually over the next year.

description: BONHAM--William R. 1921-1987. True love never dies. You are still my true love. Mo

title: At Least 20 People Are Hurt as a Private Bus Runs Amok
description: A runaway bus carrying 15 mentally disabled adults crossed a lane of traffic, sideswiped two parked cars, jumped a curb and barreled into commuters waiting for a city bus at a busy Brooklyn corner during the morning rush yesterday, sending glass flying and injuring more than 20 people, witnesses and the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about the Virsky Ukrainian National Dance Company misstated the decade in which it first came to the United States. It was the 1960's (when the troupe was known as the Ukrainian Dance Company), not the 1970's.

title: Turkey and Stuffing? Yawn. We're Jumping Ahead to Christmas.
description: Richard Ahn still had one tree to assemble -- he had already put together two, and the lights and ornaments were at hand. The trees' home for the next six weeks, just inside the big plate-glass window along Amsterdam Avenue, had been cleared out to make room for them. A shiny red background had gone up.

title: How 'Lost' Careered Into Being a Hit Show
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 - The speed with which ABC's Wednesday night breakout hit drama "Lost" went from a network executive's half-baked suggestion to one of the most elaborate and expensive pilots ever filmed was brain blurring.

title: Gazing Upon a Landfill, the Mayor Sees a Park of Olympic Dreams
description: Somewhere out there, beyond the rumbling trucks, chain-link fence and old tires poking up from the Fresh Kills muck, city officials tried yesterday to conjure a vision of Olympic mountain-bikers going for the gold atop the world's largest garbage dump.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Records Track Calls To Victim's Home
description: Verizon representatives testified yesterday at the Daniel Pelosi murder trial that phone records show someone dialed the modem of a secret surveillance system at the East Hampton mansion of the victim, R. Theodore Ammon, 14 times during the evening of Oct. 20 and early morning of Oct. 21 from the Center Moriches home of Daniel Pelosi's sister. One connection at 1:40 a.m. on Oct. 21 lasted 16 minutes. The sister, Barbara Lukert, has testified that her brother logged onto the system using a laptop computer to monitor the surveillance system and that when he left her at 2 a.m. on Oct. 21, she felt a hard object under his jacket, an object that prosecutors contend could have been used in the murder. Peter C. Beller (NYT)

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATING BRISTOL-MYERS UNITS IN GERMANY
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an informal inquiry into the company's German subsidiaries. The inquiry may involve violations of a United States anti-bribery law, Bristol-Myers said in a filing with the S.E.C. Bristol-Myers is based in New York.

title: Digital Subscribers Help Cablevision Cut Loss
description: Cablevision Systems said yesterday that its loss in the third quarter was 41 percent smaller than in the period last year as demand for its digital television, high-speed Internet and phone services offset higher operating costs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Delaware trial in which shareholders of the Walt Disney Company have challenged the $140 million severance package for the former president, Michael S. Ovitz, referred incorrectly in some copies to the executive whose failure to report his expenses became a crucial issue in the case. He was Mr. Ovitz, not Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive.

title: If Mom Made Baked Ziti
description: LIKE most dedicated American cooks, I have integrated Northern Italian cooking into my repertory. But there are times one hankers for Mom's spaghetti and meatballs, the kind of Italian-American cooking on which many of us were at least partially weaned.

title: Marks & Spencer, British Retailer, Sheds 6 Top Executives
description: LONDON, Nov. 9 - Six top executives will leave the troubled British retailer Marks & Spencer, its chief executive said on Tuesday, as the company reported plummeting profits and a dip in sales in its home market in the latest six-month period.

title: Trade Deadline May Move
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 9 - In a straw vote taken on Tuesday to determine whether there is an impetus to delay baseball's trading deadline, general managers voted about 50-50.

description: WEST

title: Bush Visits Wounded G.I.'s and Families at Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - As thousands of American-led troops continued their attack on the city of Falluja on Tuesday, President Bush spent two hours with wounded service members at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center and afterward wished godspeed to the troops in Iraq.

title: Deli Clerk Is Killed in Robbery Attempt
description: A 44-year-old clerk at a deli in the Morrisania section of the Bronx was shot and killed last night during a robbery attempt by two assailants, the police said.

title: Rightist Militias Are a Force in Colombia's Congress
description: CAUCASIA, Colombia, Nov. 5 - Here in the humid cattle pastures of northern Colombia, Congresswoman Roco Arias says she feels at peace. She needs no bodyguards, as she does in Bogot.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Glossy Alumni Magazines Seek More Than Graduates
description: Their readers may still value the "class notes" most (the Wellesley Magazine section fostered a kidney transplant between graduates), but alumni magazines these days are revamped, glossy and offering an impressive array of more worldly topics. The subjects can be as varied as the educational value of art forgeries or the culture of S.U.V.'s, low-carbohydrate diets or gunshot wounds, the most important man in football or the vanishing young voter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIRSCHNER, ANDREW C.
description: KIRSCHNER--Andrew C. It is with deep sorrow and affection that The New York Times mourns the death of our colleague, Andrew C. Kirschner, on November 8th. Andy's grace, perseverance, strength, and perspective throughout his long illness inspired us all. He was a hero and a friend, possessing a determination and optimism truly extraordinary. All of us at The Times extend our sympathies to his wife, Barbara, who was his inspiration, their two daughters, Hallie and Alexi and their family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Says City Shortchanged On Heat
description: New York City receives a disproportionately small share of federal money to help poor families pay their heating bills, says a study released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office. The city accounts for 42 percent of the state's population but receives only 13 percent -- or $32 million out of $244 million -- of the state's share of the Home Energy Assistance Program. This is because the program, developed by the state, favors homeowners over renters in apartment buildings, as well as renters paying their own heating bills. State officials have defended the program, saying that it has helped many people, particularly in upstate New York, who lived in bigger homes in colder areas. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Water Safety On Planes
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and 12 domestic airlines signed an agreement to establish a system for testing and disinfecting water on planes. The deal grew out of random tests of water on 158 airplanes that showed evidence of harmful bacteria in 12.6 percent of samples. Officials said the pact would remain in place for two years while regulations for permanent testing standards were developed. The airlines that signed on are Alaska, Aloha, America, America West, ATA, Continental, Hawaiian, JetBlue, Midwest, Northwest, United and US Airways. Two other airlines, Delta and Southwest, entered into separate agreements with the E.P.A. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Reaping and Writing

The poet W.S. Merwin will receive the foundation's lifetime achievement award, carrying a $200,000 prize. Three literary awards of $125,000 each will go to Rikki Ducornet, a novelist in residence at the University of Denver and author of "Gazelle," a novel set in Cairo in the 1950's (Alfred A. Knopf, 2003); Peter Reading, a British poet; and Lus Alberto Urrea, for his nonfiction work, including "The Devil's Highway" (Little, Brown, 2004), an account of a group of Mexican men who died in the desert while crossing illegally from Mexico into the United States in 2001. The Lannan Foundation also awarded literary fellowships to Edwidge Danticat, above, a novelist and author of "The Dew Breaker" (Knopf, 2004); Thomas Frank, a social critic and author of "What's the Matter With Kansas?" (Metropolitan, 2004); Mavis Gallant, the Canadian novelist and short-story writer; Micheline Aharonian Marcom, born in Saudi Arabia and author of "The Daydreaming Boy" (Riverhead, 2004), a novel about a survivor of Turkey's Armenian massacres; and Rebecca Seiferle, the author of three books of poetry, including "Bitters" (Copper Canyon Press, 2001). title: Arts, Briefly; Max and Leo Conquer London
description: In London, it looks like dj vu all over again for "The Producers." The West End version of the Mel Brooks Broadway hit, which opened at Theater Royal Drury Lane on Tuesday night, drew raves from most of the critics who reviewed the show overnight; by lunchtime yesterday $372,000 in fresh ticket sales had brought the total advance to $9.3 million, said David Ian, a co-producer. Nicholas De Jongh of The Evening Standard said, "The show hits the West End with the force of a revelation, not to mention Nathan Lane and Lee Evans, right, who strike up a razzle-dazzle comic partnership as play producers Max Bialystock and Leo Bloom, in pursuit of a dishonest million." Michael Billington of The Guardian said, "At its simplest, it puts the comedy back into musical comedy." Striking one of the few dissonant notes, Quentin Letts of The Daily Mail said he felt that "something was missing at last night's top-octane opening. My soul, like some broken down Land Rover, stuck in the country mud and refused to budge." PAM KENT

title: Ellen Meloy
description: Last week, a writer named Ellen Meloy died suddenly in her sleep beside her husband at their home in Bluff, Utah. She was 58. Like many people who truly know the desert Southwest, Ellen spent a lot of time thinking about perception. She worried about "progressive lunacy" and was told by a Navajo acquaintance to "go ahead and stay crazy." That she did. "I dream hard," she wrote in "The Anthropology of Turquoise." Knowing her, I find it easy to imagine that on the night she died, Ellen came to a waterfall in her dreams -- a stream pouring over the edge of the slickrock -- and jumped and simply kept falling.

The 17th installment of the series, with songs by Ciara, Ashlee Simpson, the Beastie Boys, Nelly, Switchfoot, Franz Ferdinand, Bowling for Soup and 13 others, has reached the top spot in its first week of release, with just over 400,000 copies sold -- about 100,000 less than Vol. 16 sold in its first week of release, in August, but still more than recent chart-toppers by Rod Stewart, George Strait and Rascal Flatts. The full series has sold just over 44 million albums. Jay-Z and R. Kelly's album "Unfinished Business" (Jive/Def Jam) was at No.1 last week, despite the ugly public breakdown of the duo's tour -- quickly followed by a lawsuit -- but this week the effect of those troubles has become clear: the album plunged to No.10, with just 71,000 copies sold, a 67 percent drop from last week. The rock group A Perfect Circle's "Emotive" (Virgin) reached No.2, and Ray Charles's posthumous duets album, "Genius Loves Company" (Concord), continues to sell well, reaching No.3 with sales of 118,000. BEN SISARIO

title: After Sidestepping a Power Play, Tuberville Is Thriving at Auburn
description: AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 9 - Despite five losses last season, when Auburn was expected to contend for the national championship, Tommy Tuberville kept his job as the Tigers' football coach. He had been in the crosshairs of the university president and a powerful trustee, and yet he not only survived, but also received a one-year contract extension.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brazil: Industrial Output Flat
description: Industrial production in Brazil rose in September at its slowest pace in six months, suggesting that the country's economic recovery is starting to cool after a recent surge. The government's statistics agency said production rose less than 0.02 percent from August. In the first nine months of the year, output is up a cumulative 9 percent, helping Brazil's economy grow at its fastest pace since 1996. Most economists expect the economy to expand about 4.5 percent this year; initial growth forecasts were for 3.5 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

CANADIAN NATURAL BUYING PROPERTIES FROM ANADARKO
description: Canadian Natural Resources, a natural gas producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy assets of the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation in three provinces for 698 million Canadian dollars ($584.5 million) to increase output. The sale was one of two divestitures announced yesterday by Anadarko, which valued the transactions at $715 million. Anadarko, which is based outside Houston, said in June that it would sell assets to reduce debt and pay for share buybacks. Canadian Natural's president, John G. Langille, said his company could pare operating costs at the acquired assets by at least 10 percent. Canadian Natural is based in Calgary, Alberta.

The next day, she said, he threatened to do the same to her.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: G.E.D. Exam Funds Scarce
description: By the end of December, New York State will run out of money for administering the G.E.D. exam to obtain a high school equivalency diploma, Assemblyman Steven Sanders warned yesterday. In July, federal officials ruled that the state could not use $2.1 million in federal aid that it had planned to spend on the G.E.D. exam, about half the money that New York State spends each year in administering 55,000 to 60,000 of the tests. State education officials confirmed yesterday that they were working with the Pataki administration and the Legislature to replace the money, but they would not comment on whether all state residents who want to take the test will be able to do so. Michele Cahill, New York City's top education official in charge of alternative programs, said she was confident the money would be found. "Preserving G.E.D. is a really critically important matter," she said. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Softbank First-Half Loss Narrows
description: The Softbank Corporation, Japan's second-largest provider of high-speed Internet access, said yesterday that its first-half loss narrowed after it added users to its Yahoo BB broadband service. The net loss narrowed to 6.05 billion yen ($57 million), or 17.20 yen a share, in the six months that ended Sept. 30, from 77.3 billion yen, or 229.81 yen a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales gained 35 percent, to 303.7 billion yen from 225.5 billion yen. Softbank's founder, Masayoshi Son, is improving earnings with the help of new subscribers to his company's high-speed Internet services. After acquiring the Japan Telecom Company to offer fixed-line phone services, Mr. Son is trying to enter Japan's $73 billion mobile phone market. He has also offered to buy a professional baseball team. Softbank's operating loss, or sales minus the cost of goods sold and administrative expenses, totaled 6.79 billion yen in the first half, narrowing from 39.4 billion yen a year earlier. In the second quarter, Softbank posted net income of 11.8 billion yen, compared with a 42.6 billion yen net loss in the same period a year earlier.
