title: Go for the Stores (Maybe a Peek at the Art)
description: WITH the opening of the new Museum of Modern Art Design and Book Store this week, West 53rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues has become something of a museum mall. There are now four museum stores (and three museums) on the block, making it a promising destination for shoppers as the holidays approach. Those trawling for gifts will find art books, contemporary jewelry and tableware, hand-woven throws and handblown vases. The block is also a fine place to look for furniture. Each shop has a distinct personality, with some items not available elsewhere and something for most budgets. All offer discounts to museum members.

title: Arts, Briefly; In Country
description: After years of coming close, the fan favorite Kenny Chesney, below, won the big prize -- his first Country Music Association Entertainer of the Year Award -- on Tuesday night in Nashville. His "When The Sun Goes Down" also earned top album honors. When the Australian Keith Urban unexpectedly captured the male vocalist prize, it was clear that this was a break from recent tradition, in which George Strait and Alan Jackson dominated the male awards. Tim McGraw's bittersweet "Live Like You Were Dying" won song and single of the year. It was not at all surprising that Martina McBride was named top female vocalist for the third consecutive year, or that the "Redneck Woman" singer Gretchen Wilson took the Horizon Award as best new artist. Mr. Jackson and Toby Keith were both shut out. Next year's C.M.A. Awards show will take place in New York in a one-time departure from Nashville. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: The President's Millennium Challenge
description: Two years ago, President Bush opened the Millennium Challenge Account, a new approach to development aid that links American assistance to a poor country to its progress in key areas. One of the criteria to receive money from the account is that a poor country must spend nearly 2 percent or more of its economic output on primary education. In addition, it must demonstrate that nearly two-thirds of its girls, or more, complete primary school. As recently as last Thursday, in his postvictory press conference, the president said, "We have an obligation in this country to push forward on the Millennium Challenge Account."

description: An obituary on Sunday about David Shulman, who traced the origins of many words for the Oxford English Dictionary, misstated the derivation of the word shyster. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Violin Collector To Plead Not Guilty
description: Herbert R. Axelrod, the violin collector who fled the country in April shortly after being charged with tax fraud, returned to New Jersey yesterday and is scheduled to appear before a federal judge tomorrow morning, according to a statement issued by Chris Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Axelrod, 76, had been in Germany since he was arrested on June 15 at a Berlin airport. The former owner of a pet products company in Neptune City, N.J., he was indicted on tax fraud charges in April and accused of using a Swiss bank account to conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars. His sale last year of rare violins, violas and cellos to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra at a discount drew the attention of Senate committees. The I.R.S. allowed Mr. Axelrod a substantial tax deduction for selling the instruments at a loss. Yesterday Mr. Axelrod's lawyer, Michael B. Himmel, said that his client would plead not guilty. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Controls On Journalists Tightened
description: Parliament amended media-control legislation to require all journalists to secure a government license or face a fine and up to two years in prison for working illegally, the state-controlled radio reported. The nation's information minister, Jonathan Moyo, said the new restrictions were in line with those existing in other nations and were intended to "protect the state from attacks by enemies of the country." The amendment appeared aimed at foreign journalists, some of whom have entered the country as tourists to report on conditions there. Zimbabwe already requires local journalists to be registered by a state commission. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A New Bar Where the Patrons Are as Chilled as the Drinks
description: The new Icebar in Milan (top), based on the original Icehotel built in northern Sweden in 1989, is one of a planned chain of at least 15 such places from Icehotel and Absolut vodka. While the hotel was made from ice and snow, Milan's version is more a giant freezer, with walls, furniture and glasses made of ice from the Torne River in Sweden. Patrons must make reservations and are allowed 30 minutes in the 23-degree bar. Each is given a padded silver parka and rubber boots to keep warm and minimize scratching of the ice. Icebar is at Piazza Gerusalemme 12, Milan. Reservations: www.townhouse.it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 'Pizza Connection' Assets May Be Freed
description: The considerable assets of Gaetano Badalamenti, the Sicilian mob boss who masterminded the 1980's ring known as the Pizza Connection, which smuggled $1.65 billion in heroin into the United States and distributed it through pizza parlors in New York and across the country, may be returned to his family after his death in an American prison. While he was serving a 45-year sentence in the United States, Mr. Badalamenti was never convicted of mob association in Italy, although the Italian government confiscated his property. That technicality could force the government to give the assets back to Mr. Badalamenti's survivors. Included are large swathes of Sicilian countryside. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Study Says Defibrillators Are A Bargain
description: Implanted electrical shock devices called cardioverter-defibrillators are a relative bargain compared with many other life-saving technologies used in medicine, according to data presented yesterday at an American Heart Association meeting in New Orleans. Dr. Daniel B. Mark of the Duke Clinical Research Institute reached that conclusion based on a review of the costs of implanting the devices in patients who were part of a previously reported clinical study. That study established that use of the devices in patients with moderately weakened hearts cut death rates by 23 percent in the year after the implant. Defibrillators detect disruptions in the rhythm of the heart and jolt it back to a normal pattern before a full-scale heart attack occurs. Dr. Mark said the devices in the clinical study cost an average of just over $33,000, well below the $50,000 level widely used as a benchmark for cost-effective life-saving therapies. Although Dr. Mark's study has not yet been reviewed by independent researchers or published, doctors who attended the presentation said the study could encourage cardiologists to embrace the implants more rapidly. The implants are made by companies like Medtronic, Guidant and St. Jude Medical. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: DELPHI DELAYS AN S.E.C. FILING, CITING AN INVESTIGATION
description: The Delphi Corporation, the auto-parts maker, said yesterday that it had delayed filing its third-quarter report to the Securities and Exchange Commission because the agency is investigating the company's transactions with suppliers. Delphi, which is based in Troy, Mich., said it would not be able to file the report "without unreasonable effort or expense" until the internal review is done, but it did not say when that might be. Delphi said in a filing Sept. 29 that the S.E.C. was investigating the accounting treatment on $86.5 million in transactions with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in 2001 through 2003. Delphi also said the S.E.C. was examining $3.5 million Delphi received from another supplier that it did not identify.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: 5 Die At Train Crossing
description: Five adults who were car pooling home from the night shift at Avondale Mills in Graniteville were killed when their 1994 Buick collided with a train in Graniteville, according to the State Highway Patrol and a spokesman for the textile company. Although there were no crossing gates at the intersection, warning lights were flashing, and two other cars beat the train across the tracks before the victims tried to do so, said a spokesman for the patrol, Sid Gaulden. No crew members on the three-car train, which was measuring track conditions, were injured, Mr. Gaulden said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Gabrielle, grandfather of Sebastian and Jansikwe. Interred at Cedar Hill Cemetery, Suitland, MD, in traditional American Indian ceremony on November 5. Contributions to Piscataway Indian Nation, PO Box 312, Port Tobacco, MD 20677, Uncle Joe's Kitchen.

description: LONSHEIN--Martha. Beloved wife of the late John. Devoted mother of Howard and Rosalyn, and Robert and Marlene. Loving grandmother of Laura, Jonathan, Alison, and Nancy. Services at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, Friday 11:30am.

title: Go for the Stores (Maybe a Peek at the Art)
description: WITH the opening of the new Museum of Modern Art Design and Book Store this week, West 53rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues has become something of a museum mall. There are now four museum stores (and three museums) on the block, making it a promising destination for shoppers as the holidays approach. Those trawling for gifts will find art books, contemporary jewelry and tableware, hand-woven throws and handblown vases. The block is also a fine place to look for furniture. Each shop has a distinct personality, with some items not available elsewhere and something for most budgets. All offer discounts to museum members.

title: Offering Beethoven With Crisp Lines, but Softened by 'Moonlight'
description: When Soheil Nasseri played his New York debut recital just over two years ago, his varied program showed him as both an inventive, technically precise interpreter of standard fare and a virtuosic performer of contemporary works. Since then Mr. Nasseri has played nine more recitals in New York, all balanced similarly. But with all that experience behind him -- he is now all of 25 -- Mr. Nasseri decided on a new approach. He devoted his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Monday entirely to Beethoven, not the most startling programming, of course, but one that forced him to focus on variety of expression rather than style.

description: CAIRO, Nov. 10 - When an Islamist member of the Parliament in Bahrain on Tuesday proposed condemning the United States-led assault against Falluja, one of his 39 colleagues angrily rejected the idea as supporting "terrorists" in Iraq, and a heated debate ensued. In the end, a compromise was reached: a statement censuring the death of innocent civilians.

title: Delta Pilots Vote to Accept 32.5 Percent Pay Cut
description: Pilots at Delta Air Lines overwhelmingly approved a new five-year contract today with $1 billion in annual concessions sought by the airline, which had threatened to file for bankruptcy if the pilots did not acquiesce.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Terror Alert Level Lowered At Financial Locations Federal officials lowered the terrorist alert level for the financial services sector in Washington, northern New Jersey and New York, saying that financial institutions in the three regions had taken significant steps to better defend themselves in the event of an attack.

description: NEWARK, Nov. 10 - Calling it a "new vision" for the Meadowlands sports complex, State Senator Richard J. Codey, who will take over as New Jersey's acting governor next week, is exploring a plan that would allow the New York Giants to build a new stadium there.

title: No Fare Rise, Commuters Tell M.T.A.
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10 - A handful of commuters showed up at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority public hearing here on Wednesday to tell the agency that no fare increase -- no matter what size -- was acceptable.

Church Aide Was Censured for Law Work
description: When the New York Archdiocese was looking for someone to lead its Safe Environment Program, a special screening and monitoring project to help protect against child abuse, it turned to Robert G. Whiteman. He was not only an ordained deacon but also a practicing lawyer.

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber and James Earl Jones Plan Broadway Returns
description: As a composer and producer, Andrew Lloyd Webber has had a rough go on Broadway in the last few years, including a poorly reviewed revival of his "Jesus Christ Superstar" in 2000; his short-lived musical, "By Jeeves," in 2001; and the still wobbly fortunes of "Bombay Dreams," the Bollywood-inspired musical that he originally produced successfully in London but that has had lackluster sales in New York.

title: Tapping the Work Ethic in Fading Rural Towns
description: Across the Great Plains, farm towns are dying, their downtown shops going dark, their young people forsaking failing family farms and sputtering local economies to make a living elsewhere. Enter (or, rather, re-enter) the entrepreneurs Tom Galloway and Carl Kelly, who came back to help breathe some life into the communities of their youth.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Passes Safety Bills
description: The City Council passed three school safety bills yesterday seeking to increase the number of security cameras, identify the number of safety officers and expand requirements for reporting violent crime. Aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he was likely to veto the bills calling for the number of safety officers and for expanded crime reporting, since officials have said the requirements may be hard to carry out and may contradict state education law. As for the security cameras, the mayor said: "They keep passing laws. We'll put cameras where we can afford them and where we think necessary." Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Omnicom Unit Gains 2 Michelob Campaigns
description: The Anheuser-Busch division of the Anheuser-Busch Companies in St. Louis has added to its agency roster the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, which will create campaigns for Michelob and Michelob Light beer. Spending for those brands, which had been handled by various agencies, was estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: 'Minimalism Meets Guernica' in the Form of a Fruit Bowl
description: The War Bowl (left) is part of "Brits and Pieces," a collection of products by young designers working in Britain, now on sale at the Future Perfect, a store in Brooklyn. The bowls, by the design team of Mosley Meets Wilcox, are made of melted plastic toy soldiers. (Knights, shown, in silver, $199; also available in black ninjas.) "It was a subtle way of bringing thought of the current geopolitical situation to the show," said Charlie Marshall, a founding partner of Fugg Design in London, the exhibit's curator. "They are also just beautiful -- minimalism meets Guernica." Other products include a full-length mirror by Afroditi Krassa in the shape of her body, sweet yet creepy knit dolls by Donna Wilson and a walnut side table with bird-shaped marquetry by Sam Johnson.

title: Vodafone seeks 3G breakthrough in Europe : Mobile phones' new tune
Iran in Deadlock With Europe on Halting Production of Uranium
description: PARIS, Nov. 10 - Iran and European negotiators have become deadlocked in their effort to reach a final agreement for Iran to suspend its production of enriched uranium in exchange for possible economic and political incentives, European officials said Wednesday.

title: 'Groundhog Day' in Iraq
description: I got a brief glimpse of Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld's news conference on Monday, as the battle for Falluja began. I couldn't help but rub my eyes for a moment and wonder aloud whether I had been transported back in time to some 20 months ago, when the war for Iraq had just started. Watching CNN, I saw the same Rummy joking with the Pentagon press corps, the same scratchy reports from the front by "embedded reporters," the same footage of U.S. generals who briefed the soldiers preparing for battle about how they were liberating Iraq.

title: UNITED AIRLINES ASKS CARRIERS TO BID ON ROUTES
description: United Airlines, which is trying to reduce costs to exit bankruptcy, said yesterday that it had asked for bids from commuter carriers to operate as many as 70 jets on United Express routes now flown by the Air Wisconsin Airlines Corporation. United, the operating unit of the UAL Corporation, said that it had asked for lower-cost proposals from 10 commuter carriers, including Air Wisconsin, SkyWest, the Pinnacle Airlines Corporation, and Independence Air. Independence, which is struggling to avoid its own Chapter 11 filing, served as a regional carrier for United until it severed ties and became a low-fare airline. UAL, which is based in Elk Grove Township, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, is trying to cut about $670 million in annual operating costs and to eliminate about twice that amount from labor expenses.

description: More than one door slams in Thomas Ostermeier's slick new staging of Henrik Ibsen's "Doll's House," but you have to listen carefully to hear the impact. Mr. Ostermeier, a highly regarded, provocative German director making his American debut with this production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, pumps up the volume in more ways than one in his brash contemporary gloss on Ibsen's essential modern drama.

SEARS IS DEFENDANT IN EMPLOYEE DISCRIMINATION SUIT
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Sears, Roebuck & Company for discriminating against workers who spend more than one year on extended disability leave. The suit was filed in federal court in Chicago on behalf of an employee who, the suit contends, was injured at a Sears store in Bannockburn, Ill., in April 2001 and was fired after a year on disability. Sears refused to find tasks he could perform while injured and fired him because he could not return to his old job, the commission said. A Sears spokesman said he had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment immediately.

title: Pick a Number, It's Sequel Season
description: THE sequel is king, and games with titles like The Sims 2, Burnout 3 and Myst IV receive far more attention than those increasingly rare games with no pedigree. Nothing seems to work gamers into a frenzy of anticipation quite as effectively as the promise of a game that will give them the same thrilling experience they remember from a game they were obsessed with a year or two ago.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Scientist Denies Reports Of Ill Health
description: Abdul Qadeer Khan, the disgraced former head of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, says he has no health complaints, contrary to concerns expressed by his supporters, according to a written statement filed on his behalf with the Supreme Court. In a petition filed with the court last week, a brother of a former aide to Dr. Khan asked for a medical board to be formed to look into his allegedly deteriorating health. But in a written statement yesterday, Dr. Khan, 68, said the petition had been filed without his knowledge or consent. He has been under house arrest since February, after he confessed to running an illegal nuclear proliferation network. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: The Cluttered but Valiant Sound of a Space-Age Trip to the Stars
description: The most winning part of Chick Corea's artistic personality is that he seems to believe entirely in whatever he does, and undeniably, incontrovertibly, almost hungrily, enjoys himself. (Louis Armstrong was similar.) Pared-down art, gloppy art -- he likes them both. He is a rebuke to the bulky superego that floats above jazz.

title: Just a Whisker Away From Full-Blown Celebrity
description: Isaac Brock took a moment during Modest Mouse's set to look around Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night. "This place seems a little fancy for us, but it's real nice," he said. After years on the club and college circuits, Modest Mouse is suddenly above the pop horizon, with video clips on MTV and over a half million sales of its current album, "Good News for People Who Love Bad News" (Epic).

title: Hard Lesson in Battle: 150Marines Meet 1 Sniper
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Nov. 10 - American marines called in two airstrikes on the pair of dingy three-story buildings squatting along Highway 10 on Wednesday, dropping 500-pound bombs each time. They fired 35 or so 155-millimeter artillery shells, 10 shots from the muzzles of Abrams tanks and perhaps 30,000 rounds from their automatic rifles. The building was a smoking ruin.

title: Fallen Soldiers, Remembered in Their Own Words
description: The most heartbreaking moments may be the stories of how family members dealt with the knock at the door. Specialist Holly McGeogh's mother, Paula Zasadny, at first refused to let the officer into her house: "I opened the door and I seen the man in the dress greens, and I knew. I immediately knew. But I thought that as long as I didn't let him in, he couldn't tell me, and none of that would have happened." Pfc. Jesse Givens's wife, Melissa, pleaded with the chaplain to say he was lying. "I told him that if he was lying to me, it was O.K.," she recalled, "and he could walk away, and I would just forget and I wouldn't say anything to anybody." Pfc. Raheen Heighter's mother, Cathy, had a simpler reaction: "I went crazy."

title: Testimony From Colleague Helps Lawyer in Terror Trial
description: Testifying yesterday at the trial of Lynne F. Stewart, a lawyer accused of abetting terrorism, former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark said he had frequent encounters with the news media on behalf of a convicted terrorist whom they both represented, much like press contacts she had.

description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 10 - As Omar Minaya recreates a typical conversation with a fellow general manager, he starts out sounding like so many other baseball businessmen, speaking in sports platitudes and corporate clichs.

After John Ashcroft
description: Having just emerged from a campaign season in which President Bush constantly reminded the public that he was a war president in the never-ending fight against terrorism, it felt a little peculiar to hear John Ashcroft resign as attorney general with the announcement that "the objective of securing the safety of Americans from crime and terror has been achieved." Mr. Ashcroft, however, is yesterday's news. Now that he's leaving, we hope that Mr. Bush will take the opportunity to put the Justice Department back in the business of enforcing the laws evenhandedly and upholding Americans' constitutional rights.

description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 - Despite significant gains in medical science, disparities in public health persist between rich and poor countries, the World Health Organization said in a report released here on Wednesday.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 - Arthur Finkelstein, a Republican consultant known for hard-edged campaigns that helped conservatives in the United States and Israel, has said in an interview published in Israel that President Bush's campaign strategy to court evangelical Christians had divided the country as never before, to the possible detriment of the Republican Party.

Bianchi also makes backpacks, belts and accessories. Bianchi, based in Temecula, Calif., had $36 million in sales for the 12 months ended Sept. 30. That's an easy enough order, but I'd also like software that will synchronize it with my large Windows desktop computer the same way I synchronize my Palm. Does such a thing exist?

title: A Kickbox Pas de Deux Over Drinks
description: Smack! Pow! Ouch! Punch! Choke! Expletive, expletive, expletive! Ah, the gentle sounds of courtship as presented by John Patrick Shanley, a man who has never shied from the notion that love hurts. As the fond revival of Mr. Shanley's "Danny and the Deep Blue Sea" at the Second Stage Theater reminds us, foreplay in the world of this gymnastically romantic writer tends to resemble a main event from World Wrestling Entertainment.

title: The Things They Wrote
description: A year ago the Op-Ed page marked Veterans Day by publishing excerpts from letters written home by soldiers who lost their lives in Iraq. At the time, fewer than 400 Americans had died in Operation Iraqi Freedom. This year Veterans Day takes place during the battle for the Iraqi city of Falluja, where at least 11 Americans have been killed this week. Since the beginning of the war, the number of American dead in Iraq, according to the Pentagon, stands at 1,149. Thousands more have been wounded.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Company's Profit Rises
description: Profit at the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation rose 3 percent for the six-month period that ended Sept. 30, helped by the sale of shares in its mobile phone affiliate, NTT DoCoMo. Net profit for the company, the largest telecom provider in Japan, rose to 344.6 billion yen ($3.26 billion) for the period, from a revised 334.3 billion yen for the period last year. Revenue fell 1.7 percent, to 5.32 trillion yen. NTT earned 319 billion yen from the sale of stock it held in NTT DoCoMo, the nation's top mobile phone company. NTT's stake in DoCoMo fell to 62.4 percent from 63.6 percent as a result of the sale. NTT's core fixed-line business has been deteriorating because of mobile phone and Internet-based competition. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Physicist Accused As Spy Taken Into Custody
description: Valentin V. Danilov, a physicist facing espionage charges, was taken into custody, even as his case continued, his lawyer said. A jury convicted him of treason on Friday in a second trial that followed a previous jury's acquittal. The court has yet to rule on the central question of whether the information he was accused of passing to a Chinese company included state secrets. Mr. Danilov, who has remained free during his second trial, was arrested during a hearing in Krasnoyarsk, in Siberia, where the trial is being held, after prosecutors accused him of continuing to contact foreigners, including journalists, the lawyer, Yelena V. Yevlinova, said in a telephone interview. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Arafat Dies at 75; No Successor Set; West Bank Burial
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Thursday, Nov. 11 - Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, died early Thursday morning in a Paris hospital, a French military spokesman announced.

title: Prosecutors Say an Injured Man Turned a Blind Eye Into Treasure
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10 - Brian Calen was blinded in his right eye in 1985 when he suffered a burn on his retina after a filter dropped out of a telescope he was using on a one-day cruise. That was a legitimate accident, investigators said on Wednesday -- made worse by the fact that Mr. Calen apparently had no insurance at the time.

title: Russia Salutes Father of the Rifle Fired Round the World
description: IZHEVSK, Russia, Nov. 10 - Russia's most famous general arrived promptly at 10 a.m. The doors to the ceremonial chamber of a presidential palace swung open, and there he stood. He wore a green dress uniform with gold epaulets. Medals lined his chest.

title: Arts, Briefly; Donmar Doings
description: The Donmar Warehouse, the 250-seat nonprofit theater in London that has a reputation for showcasing fresh and bold plays and musicals, has announced its roster for next spring and summer. Its splashiest offering, a collaboration with the Ambassador Theater Group to be presented early next year in the West End, will be the musical "Guys and Dolls," starring the film actor Ewan McGregor (Obi-Wan Kenobi of "Star Wars II -- Attack of the Clones"), above, as Sky Masterson. The Donmar lineup begins with an adaptation of "Day of Wine and Roses," J.P. Miller's plunge into alcoholism, running from Feb. 17 through April 2, followed by a revival of David Greig's play about two Soviet explorers orbiting in space, "Cosmonauts Last Message to the Woman He Once Loved," from April 7 through May 21. The season will wrap up with "This Is How It Goes," Neil LaBute's exploration of race and infidelity in small-town America, from May 26 through July 9; and a new version of Friedrich Schiller's classic "Mary Stuart," about the relationship between Queen Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots, from July 14 through Sept. 3. LIZETTE ALVAREZ

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway To Introduce New PC Models
description: Gateway said yesterday that it would revamp its E-Series line of desktop PC's for businesses with three new models, including a 6300 with a new motherboard design called Balanced Technology Extended, or BTX, that helps machines run cooler and more quietly than other Gateway desktops. BTX, originally created by Intel and made into an industry standard, works to remove a PC's heat more effectively. It arranges the PC's three hottest components -- its processor, chip set and graphics card -- in a row to place them inside an airstream flowing from the machine's front to its back. Other components, like memory, are also repositioned to aid air flow. The airstream -- which Gateway calls the wind tunnel and creates in its 6300 desktop by locating a fan on either end of the chassis -- cools the processor and other components more effectively than that of an ATX motherboard, today's standard board design. The company says that reducing the temperature inside a PC's chassis can increase the lifespan of its components, which can fail if they overheat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COUNTS, DR. ROBERT M.
description: COUNTS--Dr. Robert M., on November 3, in New York City. Born in Rossville, Kansas in 1924, he practiced psychiatry in Massachusetts and the greater New York area for five decades. Dr. Counts earned his medical degree from Washington University in St. Louis. He was the first director of the Children's Psychiatric Center of Monmouth County, NJ and founded the Center for Marital and Family Therapy in New York City. He was also a member of the voluntary faculty at NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Counts served tours of duty in the Army during World War II and the Korean War. An avid traveler, photographer and squash player, his first priority was always his family and friends. He is survived by his loving wife Norma Hakusa Counts, his brother Jim, his children Pamela, Douglas, Alexander and Michael, and a network of caring extended family and friends. A private memorial service will be held in New York City on November 22. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Earnings Drop at Big Bank in Australia
description: Once a standout as Australia's largest and most influential lender, the National Australia Bank reported earnings yesterday that made it a disappointing exception in an industry thriving amid the country's housing boom.

title: INSIDE
description: Federal Reserve Raises Interest Rate to 2% The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the fourth time this year, and suggested that it would continue to raise them gradually through much of next year. The stock market had little reaction to the move. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

title: Sprucing Up the Storefront When the Address Is EBay
description: Dedicated eBay sellers looking to jazz up their online storefronts may be interested in a customized version of Macromedia's user-friendly Contribute 3 program that has been created just for users of the popular auction site. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lodi: Itchy Rash Hospitalizes Children
description: Thirty-six children at a Boys and Girls Club in Lodi were taken to the hospital yesterday afternoon after reporting that they had contracted an itchy rash, the police said. None of the affected children were seriously afflicted, Lt. Joseph Quatrone said. At an emergency meeting last night, a public health worker said the cause of the rash was most likely viral rather than environmental, but Lieutenant Quatrone said that as a precaution the outbreak was treated as a hazardous materials emergency. All schools in Lodi will be closed today as authorities seek the cause of the rash, he said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Go for the Stores (Maybe a Peek at the Art)
description: WITH the opening of the new Museum of Modern Art Design and Book Store this week, West 53rd Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues has become something of a museum mall. There are now four museum stores (and three museums) on the block, making it a promising destination for shoppers as the holidays approach. Those trawling for gifts will find art books, contemporary jewelry and tableware, hand-woven throws and handblown vases. The block is also a fine place to look for furniture. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Expects Strong Handset Sales
description: Motorola, the maker of mobile phones, expects "very strong" handset sales this quarter, an executive said yesterday. Sales of new types of phones are helping the company meet its handset sales forecasts, Ron G. Garriques, who runs the company's phone unit, said in a conference call with analysts. Motorola has overcome component shortages that hampered production last year and is able to meet demand for phones with built-in cameras and color screens, Mr. Garriques said. The handset unit accounted for 38 percent of Motorola's 2003 revenue. Motorola shares rose 51 cents, to $17.18.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's current-account surplus shrank 13.6 percent in September as rising oil prices increased the value of imports and as shipments to overseas markets fell. The surplus, the broadest measure of a country's global trade, fell to 1.5 trillion yen ($14.2 billion) from 1.73 trillion yen in August, seasonally adjusted, the Ministry of Finance said. Exports fell 1.4 percent, and imports rose 2.4 percent. The trade surplus, which excludes trade in services, fell 12.4 percent, to 1.12 trillion yen.

The girl had been arrested at her home in Coney Island by officers of the Brooklyn Juvenile Crime Squad on a warrant for marijuana possession. When the patrol car stopped about 8 a.m. on Beverley Road, in Kensington, to pick up a second youth, the girl slipped a hand out of her handcuffs, used them to hit an officer and escaped. title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Impeachment Move Fails
description: President Lucio Gutirrez, battered by political opponents and low popularity ratings, survived an impeachment effort in Congress. Four parties determined to topple him gathered 48 votes, 3 shy of what was needed, for the first step -- a hearing on whether the president used public funds to help his allies in recent elections. Mr. Gutirrez, who denies the charges, has the public support of the United States. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: President Gets Torture Report
description: An official commission investigating the systematic practice of torture and political detention under the 1973-1990 dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet delivered its long-awaited final report to President Ricardo Lagos, left. The yearlong inquiry heard testimony from 35,000 victims and contains specific and detailed documentation of the types of torture that the military government employed against suspected opponents between 1973 and 1990. But at the request of Mr. Lagos, the full text of the report will not be made public until he has had a chance to read all three volumes, which should take "two or three more weeks," according to a commission member. Mr. Lagos praised the commission for its work, saying, "How many countries have dared to get to the bottom of what occurred?" Anticipating the report's conclusions, the current army commander, Gen. Juan Emilio Cheyre, last week acknowledged his service's "institutional responsibility" for "morally unacceptable acts" during the Pinochet era. Larry Rohter (NYT)

They will be open to the public after school each day. The first two schools to get new playgrounds, scheduled to open next fall, are Public School 180 in Harlem and Junior High School 220 in Borough Park, Brooklyn. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Writing of War
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced yesterday in Washington that Andrew Carroll (below) would edit its anthology of present day wartime stories and reflections, "Operation Homecoming: Writing the Wartime Experience." The collection, which the organization is planning to publish by spring 2006 to sell in bookstores and make available at military installations, schools and libraries, will preserve firsthand experiences from the battlegrounds of Iraq and Afghanistan. Mr. Carroll, who edited the best-selling book "War Letters: Extraordinary Correspondence From American Wars," is the director of the Legacy Project, a national initiative that seeks to preserve wartime correspondence before such letters -- and now e-mail messages -- are lost or destroyed. The endowment said it would hold about 20 writing workshops at military bases, with writers including Jeff Shaara, Tom Clancy, Tobias Wolff and Richard Bausch taking part. Mr. Carroll said that the troops' perspective "on war, combat, and life in the military represents the most authentic and insightful voices we have on these subjects." JOHN FILES

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Hot 97' Aims to Be No. 1 in New York Radio
description: There will be a change at the top of one of New York's most popular radio stations, WQHT-FM (97.1), the hip-hop and R&B station that calls itself Hot 97. The trade paper Radio & Records reported yesterday that John Dimick, a 25-year radio veteran currently working in San Diego, would take over as WQHT's program director in mid-December, succeeding Tracy Cloherty, who has been at the station for 15 years and will now become its programming consultant. In New York's fiercely contested radio wars, WQHT, owned by Emmis Communications, was tied for second place with two other stations in the October Arbitron ratings. Clear Channel's adult contemporary WLTW-FM (106.7) holds the city's No. 1 spot. Mr. Dimick has a history of success in pitting smaller companies like Emmis and his current employer, Jefferson-Pilot, against giants like Clear Channel and Infinity. Emmis, which is based in Indianapolis and owns fewer than 25 stations nationwide compared with Clear Channel's 1,200-plus, has 3 of New York's top 15 stations. Arbitron says the New York radio market has more than 15.3 million listeners 12 and older, far and away the most in the country. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: The Listings; STEVE REICH AND MUSICIANS
description: The textures and rhythms that drive Steve Reich's music have changed considerably (if gradually) since the 1960's, but his style has always been immediately recognizable, and distinct from that of others in the increasingly misnamed Minimalist school. Presiding over his ensemble, Steve Reich and Musicians (above Mr. Reich, left, and Russ Hartenberger), he is presenting a three-concert series at the Metropolitan Museum that should allow listeners to take stock of his career. One could also, of course, do that by way of "Steve Reich: Works 1965-1995," an extraordinary 10-CD set from Nonesuch, but the Met series includes works composed since that set appeared -- including the fantastic "Three Tales" (2002), a music and video work with which the series ends in April. Plus, there is a visceral quality in live performances of Mr. Reich's work that recordings never entirely capture. A centerpiece of the first installment of the series, tomorrow evening, includes the opening section of one of his true classics, the hypnotic and rhythmically involved "Drumming" (1971). Somewhat less celebrated, but just as important in Mr. Reich's canon, is the "Sextet" (1984), a work for percussion, piano and synthesizer, and one of several works in which Mr. Reich began to take a fresh look at harmonic movement (in addition to his earlier rhythmic layering). Also on the program are "New York Counterpoint" (1985), for clarinet and 10 more taped clarinets; "Nagoya Marimbas" (1994), a short work for marimba duet; and the American premiere of "Dance Patterns," a 2002 work for two xylophones, two vibraphones and piano. (Tomorrow at 8 p.m., the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 570-3949. Tickets: $35.) ALLAN KOZINN

Revenue at Pixar, based in Emeryville, Calif., rose 47 percent, to $44.5 million from $30.2 million. Pixar's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, is still capitalizing on the success of last year's undersea adventure "Finding Nemo," which brought in more than $860 million in theaters worldwide. Last weekend Pixar grossed $70.5 million with "The Incredibles," the second-to-last release that will be distributed by the Walt Disney Company. The company's shares rose $2.68, or 3.5 percent, to $79.94. title: The Listings; LARS ARRHENIUS
description: What if the blocky universal symbols for man and woman, like those designating public restrooms, had lives of their own? In his New York debut at Feigen Contemporary, the Swedish artist Lars Arrhenius provides the answer: They would do the same stuff we do, only in two dimensions and without words. Working with cartoonlike storyboards, on maps or in digital animation, Mr. Arrhenius explores the narrative possibilities of international sign language, pushing it into new, often subversive territory. He gets an amazing amount said about life in general and in particular. His animation "The Street" (stills, above) chronicles a day and a night in the life of a crisp black-and-white universe where people live, die, give birth, watch television, go to work, make love and walk the dog, all with machinelike regularity. Much messier narratives unfold side by side in "A-Z," which makes brilliant use of the street map of London; in "Habitat," which depicts the standard daily occurrences in an apartment building, from personal crises to neighbor problems; and in "The Man Without One Way," which spells out the possible risks of walking home in vivid detail. (You don't always get there.) "WWW" uses a map of the world to comment on the state of the planet and confirms its title's double meaning: World Wide Web can also mean World Wide War. (Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-0500, through Dec. 23; free). ROBERTA SMITH

Frederick was the fourth and youngest son of the late Theodore E. Steinway and great grandson of Henry Engelhard Steinway, founder of Steinway & Sons. Fritz was born in 1921 in New York City and graduated from Bard College. During WWII, he saw active duty as a Navy ensign in the Pacific Theatre. Upon separation from the service, Fritz attended Harvard University where he received a Master's degree in Business Administration. In 1948, Fritz joined Steinway & Sons and in 1958 he was appointed Concert & Artist Manager, a position he held with great accomplishment until his departure from the firm in 1963 to pursue a career in Artist Management. Fritz is survived by his wife, Mary Kathryn, and three sons, Frederick E., Robert C., and Christian T. and four grandchildren. title: In Downtown Los Angeles
description: UNTIL a few years ago, downtown Los Angeles's mix of bustling ethnic enclaves, homeless encampments, towering high rises and derelict Deco hotels mostly seemed ancillary to the city: your average Angeleno rarely visited and tourists were as rare as dodo birds. But that was then. Thanks to a massive revitalization project based around new architectural landmarks -- the Walt Disney Concert Hall and the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels -- and a growing underground art scene in Chinatown, downtown is quickly becoming a destination for culture hounds and lovers of the avant-garde. Artists are crowding into newly renovated lofts, and the music and theater crowds buzz in at night to dine at new restaurants and catch a show. And for sheer diversity -- from the mirrored edifices of its skyscrapers to the moldering grand theaters of Broadway, the serenity of Little Tokyo to the chaotic garment district -- no other district of Los Angeles can compare. A mentor and friend to generations of Met dancers, he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his family and friends. Joseph Volpe, General Mgr. James Levine, Music Dir.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Terror Cell Broken Up

title: World Briefing | Africa: Lesotho: Rise In H.I.V. Babies
description: The government and Unicef reported that up to one in seven babies born in the country -- 5,000 to 7,000 a year -- becomes H.I.V. positive, either during birth or by transmission in breast-feeding. title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Emissions Testing To Resume
description: The state plans to resume testing vehicles for emissions today, more than six months after the program was suspended because of technical problems with tests conducted by Agbar Technologies, the contractor that runs the program. Agbar sued the state for suspending the program but settled the lawsuit last month. The state's Department of Motor Vehicles has sent notices to about 70,000 drivers whose vehicles require testing, which will be done at about 260 private service stations throughout the state. Once the program is under way, about 40,000 drivers will receive notices each week. The cost for drivers is $20 per vehicle. William Yardley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Delays Restatement Again
description: The telecommunications equipment maker Nortel Networks said yesterday that it was delaying for a third time a restatement of its results dating back to 2001 and that it had found additional errors that would result in reductions in revenue for 1999 and 2000. Nortel said it expected to reduce revenue for 1999 by $600 million and for 2000 by $2.5 billion. The company, which is based in Brampton, Ontario, said that if it was unable to provide its restated results by Dec. 15, the New York Stock Exchange might begin taking steps to delist its shares. The Toronto Stock Exchange could also delist its shares, Nortel said. Some of the revenue that will be erased from the 1999 fiscal year will be shifted to subsequent years, the company said. title: The Listings; JOSHUA REDMAN
description: The jazz saxophonist Joshua Redman has recently decamped from Warner Brothers for Nonesuch records, which, generally, is a prudent thing to do right now for any musician who wants to be heard by broad-minded adult listeners. His first Nonesuch album will appear early next year, and his concert tomorrow night at Zankel Hall is part of "In Your Ear," a weekend full of programming by John Adams, a fellow Nonesuch artist. One hopes Mr. Redman isn't planning a genre-crosser, yet another argument that jazz can coexist with pop music. He's done that a few times already -- and so have many others, without much to show for it. Perhaps this concert indicates what's to come. It features a new trio, including the bassist Reuben Rogers and the drummer Ali Jackson -- guarantors of good, lean swing. Anyway, Mr. Redman, at his best, has a naturally sunny improvisational flow; he's got the spirit of a pop musician even in his deepest, most serious jazz mode. (Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tomorrow at 8:30 p.m.; tickets are $42.) BEN RATLIFF

title: A Never-Impolite Land Where One Never Grows Up
description: STEEPED in melancholy, the strange story of J.M. Barrie, the Victorian who wrote "Peter Pan," has the makings of a marvelous tale and one doozy of a case history. Born in Scotland in 1860, Barrie was a playwright and novelist who, after meeting a family stuffed with young boys, created in 1904 a classic of children's literature. In the years since, "Peter Pan, or the Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up" has been revisited numerous times, as in the splendid 1952 Disney animation, and has become an emblem for everlasting youth, both healthy and less so.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron And U.S. Reach Pact On Price-Fixing Inquiry
description: Micron Technology, the world's No.2 maker of computer-memory chips, struck a deal with the Justice Department to shield it from sanctions after an inquiry found some employees engaged in price fixing. The investigation found evidence of collusion by Micron and competitors in the $16.7 billion market for dynamic random access memory, or DRAM, chips, Micron said yesterday. Micron, based in Boise, Idaho, will not be subject to criminal sanctions or fines under the agreement. The Justice Department is investigating whether Micron conspired to fix prices with Infineon Technologies, Samsung Electronics, Hynix Semiconductor and other makers of the chips, which provide the main memory in personal computers. Infineon, based in Munich, set aside 212 million euros ($274 million) to cover the cost of settling with the Justice Department. Infineon will pay a $160 million fine for its part in the conspiracy. Shares of Micron rose 15 cents, to $11.65.

title: ALLSTATE HALTS MOST HOME INSURANCE SALES IN FLORIDA
description: The chief executive of the Allstate Corporation said yesterday that the company had stopped selling new homeowner insurance in most Florida counties because it had $1.1 billion in hurricane-related costs this year and the state was discussing laws that might increase expenses after future storms. The freeze will last at least until Florida lawmakers hold a special session next month to discuss prohibiting insurers from charging separate deductibles for each storm in a given year, Allstate's chief executive, Edward Liddy, said at a news conference in New York. Claims from the four hurricanes that struck Florida this year erased all the profit Allstate, based in Northbrook, Ill., has earned from Florida homeowners insurance in the last dozen years, Mr. Liddy said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tax Bill For Oil Concern
description: A British-Russian oil company, TNK-BP, received a back-tax bill for 2001 totaling 2.5 billion rubles ($87 million), not including possible penalties and interest payments, a spokeswoman confirmed. The spokeswoman, Marina Dracheva, said the company was contesting the tax claim, which stemmed from a routine check by tax authorities. "Our intent is to consult with relevant tax authorities to regulate the matter to mutual satisfaction," she said. The claim is small compared with the company's overall tax bill; TNK-BP expects a tax bill of $6.5 billion for 2004, consistent with Russia's 24 percent rate on corporate profits, Ms. Dracheva said. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Up
description: Inflation in Brazil rose in October on surging fuel prices, reinforcing expectations that the central bank will increase interest rates next week for a third consecutive month. The government's statistics agency said its IPCA consumer price index rose 0.44 percent last month, up from a 0.33 percent increase in September. The reading brought the accumulated inflation rate this year to 5.95 percent, overshooting the government's year-end target of 5.5 percent. In the 12-month period that ended in October, the index rose 6.86 percent. Most economists expect the central bank to raise its benchmark lending rate, currently at 16.75 percent, by at least a quarter of a percentage point next Wednesday. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEIBACHER, SUSAN L.
description: NEIBACHER--Susan L. The Board of Directors and staff of Care for the Homeless note with great sadness the death of our founding Executive Director on November 5, 2004 and express our condolences to her mother Laura, her brother the Reverend Albert L. Neibacher Jr. and his family, and to her community at Saint Peter's Lutheran Church at Citicorp Center. A native New Yorker and 1969 graduate of Columbia University School of Social Work, Ms. Neibacher dedicated her professional career of more than 30 years to poor and homeless people. She was a consummate social worker who taught at several social work schools in New York City and was active on the Board of the National Health Care for the Homeless Council, the New York City Council Legislative Advisory Commission on the Homeless, and several other boards and coalitions. All who had the priviledge of knowing her well will miss her for her wise counsel and warm friendship. In recognition of her many contributions to New York's homeless people and of Susan's persistant leadership in developing a new women's shelter and drop-in center, the Board wishes to announce its intention of naming this facility on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx in her honor. A Mass of the Resurrection and Committal Service will take place at Saint Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue (enter 54th Street) on Thursday, November 18, 2004 at 7:00PM. At Susan's express request, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Saint Peter's Church or to Care for the Homeless (Susan L. Neibacher Fund). Kent D. Wakeford, President G. Robert Watts, Acting Executive Director Care for the Homeless

The Listings; KOREAN FILMS
description: Over the last decade, South Korean cinema has gone from relative obscurity on the world stage to hotter than hot, at least on the film-festival circuit. Unfortunately, festivals and venues like universities have also often been the only places you could catch up with this rapidly emerging national cinema since many of the best Korean films never secure distribution here. All of which makes the series "The Newest Tiger: 60 Years of South Korean Cinema," which opens today, a must-see event for committed and casual cinephiles alike. Cutting across genres and themes, the 40-film program reaches back to 1949, a year after the establishment of the two separate governments, and works up to the present with the United States premiere of "Low Life," the latest (his 99th!) from the leading auteur Im Kwon-taek. Among other delights not to be missed are "The Power of Kangwon Province" (2002) from Hong Song-soo, one of the more essential filmmakers working in movies, and "The Housemaid" (1960), a blast from the past from Kim Ki-young, a legendary B-movie maestro whose nom du cinema was Mr. Monster. ("The Newest Tiger," which includes "Take Care of My Cat," above, written and directed by Jeong Jae-eun, runs through Dec. 7 at the Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5600. Admission: $10; $6 for Film Society of Lincoln Center members; $5 for 65+ at weekday matinees.) MANOHLA DARGIS

An endless stream of dog owners, in town for the simultaneous Pet Appreciation Weekend, walked pugs and Chihuahuas and lumbering Labs. Two potbellied men in cowboy hats led a pair of dachshunds, each dog wearing its own mini cowboy hat -- and, inexplicably, its own Barbie doll strapped to its back. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, DR. LESTER LAUDY
description: COLEMAN--Dr. Lester Laudy. Death came peacefully on November 11th. A man beloved by the patients whom he served in a career that spanned 70 years. Dr. Coleman was a graduate of Johns Hopkins University and Long Island College of Medicine. He held the position of Attending Surgeon in Otolaryngology at both Manhattan Eye and Ear and New York Hospitals and was a Clinical Professor at Albert Einstein School of Medicine in New York City. He was a diplomate of the American Board of Otolaryngology and a Fellow of the American Triological Society and past Vice President of the American Academy of Psychosomatic Medicine. Dr. Coleman trained and guided the careers of many medical students. He was a nationally syndicated columnist for King Features Syndicate writing the "Speaking of your Health" column for more than 25 years and the author and narrator of "A Guide to your Health" a nationally syndicated radio program. Dr. Coleman created and produced "Here's to your Health" an early television series for the Medical Society of New York County and the National Broadcasting Company. He authored several books including "Freedom from Fear" which was translated in 12 languages and another widely used children's book "A Visit to the Hospital" intended to allay the fears of children facing surgery. Shortly before his retirement in 1999, Dr. Coleman spoke of how gratifying his life in medicine had been made by his patients and how grateful he was to them for their devotion to him. Dr. Coleman is survived by his wife Elizabeth, daughters Lynn Dale and Lisa and his beloved grand-daughter Sarah Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, November 16th at 2:00 PM at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Ave at 81 St. COLEMAN--Dr. Lester Laudy. If we can somehow apply just little bits of what we've tried learning from Lester, all of our lives and everyone we touch will be far more enriched. Lester taught me what a hemi demi semi quaver is; the sound between the notes. "Pay attention to that sound" was something he told me. "Trust Elizabeth and me and love yourself" was another. Lester painted twinkling stars on the dark skies of life's ordinariness. Goodnight sweet prince. Goodnight Dad. Alex COLEMAN--Dr. Lester. The Chapman family mourns the loss of their cousin, Dr. Lester Coleman. Of service to everyone, he was loved by so many.

Mullah Omar, who is widely believed to be living in Pakistan and directing an insurgency against American and Afghan government forces, said that the United States was trying to impose a puppet regime but that it would fail. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIERNAN, TERENCE C.
description: KIERNAN--Terence C. 63, of Trumbull, CT, formerly of Brooklyn, died peacefully in the Connecticut Hospice on Thursday, October 21 after a brief illness. Terry had retired to Teresian Towers in Trumbull in August 2003. Terry grew up in Stratford. He graduated from Fairfield Prep, earned a Bachelor's degree from Fairfield University and did graduate studies in Spanish at the University of Connecticut. In a career spanning 40 years he taught high school Spanish for 20 years and spent the next 20 as an executive assistant to presidents of several non-profit organizations in NYC. Terry's interests in diverse cultures led him to travel to other countries including Russia, Chile and Holland. While there he established friendships that enriched the lives of his family and other friends and which lasted for the rest of his life. Terry was a person of quiet warmth, strength and compassion, qualities consistently lived in every facet of his life. These were specially reflected in his ministry to persons with AIDS and his support of the Nature Conservancy. Along with Julian of Norwich and her cat, Terry shared with others the peace and grace at the center of contemplative prayer as well as his own love of cats. Terry's serenity in approaching his untimely death will forever serve as an inspiration to family and friends. He is survived by his sister, Celeste Mahmood and her husband Robert of Stratford, a brother, Jeffrey and his wife Barbara of Bridgeport, an aunt, Margaret Eleanor Kiernan of Stratford, a cousin, Nicholas Viner of Westport, and seven nephews, Sean, Brendan, Timothy, Randy and Christopher Kiernan and Michael and Nicholas Mahmood. Those who especially touched his life included William Strom, a decade's long friend; soul mate, Janet Waterston and spiritual companion Sr. Meg Holden FSP. In keeping with Terry's wishes there were no calling hours. A memorial mass will be celebrated at noon on Saturday, November 20, at St. James Church, 2070 Main St, Stratford, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to St. Joseph's Manor, 6448 Main St, Trumbull, CT 06611. For further information contact Dennis and D'Arcy Funeral Home, 2611 Main St, Stratford, CT.

title: Emotion and Intellectualism in a Quartet Drawn From Four Corners of Europe

A Romanian, a Londoner, a Pole and a Scot -- two young women and two young men -- work intently at Beethoven's technically daunting, intellectually demanding and spiritually draining String Quartet in A minor (Op. 132). Instrument cases, jackets and bags of snack foods are strewn around a windowless practice room in the Imperial College, in the South Kensington district, but physical surroundings count for little as the musicians experiment, suggest, correct, adjust and try to find one another's musical breathing rate and pulse.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Charges In Black Reparations Fraud
description: A federal jury in Oxford has convicted a former candidate for governor of Georgia in schemes to defraud more than 6,000 blacks of $431,000 by convincing them that they were entitled to reparations or settlements for past racial discrimination. The defendant, Morris James, 65, was convicted on Thursday of 23 counts of mail fraud. Prosecutors said that Mr. James and his company, the National Resource Information Center, charged elderly black farmers a fee to help them enter a class-action settlement from the Agriculture Department, though entry had already been closed, and that he charged to prepare tax returns for blacks who improperly claimed refunds for slavery reparations. The case received much attention after two other Native men were found dead in a field outside Saskatoon in 2000, leading to reports that the police were abandoning Natives in freezing temperatures. title: Arts, Briefly; Shakespeare's Health
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company kicks off its London season next week in good shape after the announcement yesterday of better than anticipated financial results, the best in 10 years. A combination of cost-cutting and healthy box office in the last fiscal year has allowed the company to reduce the accumulated deficit to $736,000, from $5.15 million. The artistic director, Michael Boyd, who took over from Adrian Noble last year, said, "If we're going to innovate and experiment onstage, we need to balance the books." The West End season will run at the Albery Theater from Thursday through May 7, beginning with "Hamlet," the first production directed by Mr. Boyd since he became artistic director. Toby Stephens plays the title role. Other productions in the season are "Romeo and Juliet," with Matthew Rhys and Sian Brooke; "King Lear," with Corin Redgrave; "Macbeth," played by Greg Hicks; and Euripides' "Hecuba," with Vanessa Redgrave, above, who last appeared with the company 40 years ago, in the title role. title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shrine Visits Said To Hinder China Ties
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's annual visits to Yasukuni Shrine, the resting place of the souls of war criminals and a symbol of Japanese aggression to its neighbors, is an obstacle to improving ties with China, the Japanese foreign minister, Nobutaka Machimura, said. Top-level talks between the countries have not taken place since Mr. Koizumi visited Beijing in 2001 because of Chinese anger over his visits. "It is very clear that the largest reason reciprocal visits have not been realized is the issue of Yasukuni visits," Mr. Machimura said at a parliamentary session, according to Kyodo News. Tensions between the countries rose this week after what appeared to be a Chinese submarine wandered into Japanese waters. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Closing Arguments On Evolution Stickers
description: Closing arguments were heard in a federal suit against the Cobb County school district, which placed stickers in science textbooks that discuss evolution. The stickers do not mention creationism but call evolution "a theory, not a fact" and say it should be "critically considered." Michael Manely, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union who represents five parents, argued that singling out evolution as "not a fact" was untrue and sent a religiously motivated message disparaging it and that students might not understand the difference between the popular and scientific meanings of a theory. A lawyer for the school board, Linwood Gunn, argued that the stickers were neutral, encouraged discussion and created "an atmosphere of tolerance." Judge Clarence Cooper of District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, in Atlanta, said he would try to rule quickly. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: A British Internet auctioneer, QXL Ricardo, said it was in talks that might lead to a takeover bid. The company, which operates in nine European countries, disclosed the talks in a statement to the Regulatory News Service but did not identify the possible buyer. A purchaser of QXL would acquire Web sites on which users bought and sold goods worth 20 million ($37 million) in the three months through June. The company, which is based in London, was founded by Tim Jackson, a former Financial Times journalist.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Obstacle To Turkey's European Bid
description: Cyprus's president, Tassos Papadopoulos, said his country would support Turkey's drive to join the European Union if Ankara agreed to a string of conditions, including recognizing his government. European leaders are to decide next month whether to open talks with Turkey. Cyprus has been split into Greek Cypriot-controlled and Turkish-occupied sides since 1974. The Greek-dominated Republic of Cyprus joined the European Union in May, technically representing the entire island. It has, at times, threatened to veto Turkey's candidacy. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: SAKS FIFTH AVENUE PROMOTES TWO EXECUTIVES
description: Saks Fifth Avenue Enterprises, which runs the flagship department-store chain Saks, promoted two executives, Andrew Jennings and Ron Frasch. Mr. Jennings, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, added chief operating officer to his title, the company said. Mr. Frasch was named vice chairman and chief merchant and will report to Mr. Jennings. Mr. Jennings and Mr. Frasch, both 56, joined Saks Fifth Avenue earlier in the year. Mr. Jennings was president of the Canadian retailer Holt Renfrew & Company. Mr. Frasch, who was working on Saks's international business and private brands, is a past chairman and chief executive of the Neiman Marcus Group's Bergdorf Goodman chain.

In a statement to the Interfax news agency, Mr. Bagapsh, above, said he and his supporters were not seeking control of the president's office but wanted to have possession of offices necessary for the transition to what he described as his inauguration in December. He said he would not try a coup. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

The company, which is partly owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and run by his son James, serves 7.4 million subscribers, mostly in England and Ireland. The increase was less than British Sky's initial goal but was better than market analysts expected, and the company's stock rose 5 percent. Shareholders approved a plan for the company to buy back 5 percent of its outstanding stock, a move that would increase News Corporation's stake to 37.2 percent, from 35.4 percent. title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Owns Thursday
description: In recent years, Thursdays belonged to NBC's "must see" lineup, but with the anchor of "Friends" gone, CBS now owns the night. According to the Nielsen overnight ratings, all three CBS shows from Thursday evening, "Survivor," "CSI" and "Without a Trace," drew more than 20 million viewers. The second-place NBC's audience increased over the course of the night, with a heavily advertised, real-time "ER" bringing in 19.82 million viewers. The "ER" episode, featuring Ray Liotta, right, as a dying man, received the show's best numbers since its season premiere. On Fox, "The O.C." was down slightly from last week, but is doing much better than the time-travel mystery "Tru Calling" did in the 8 p.m. hour last season. ABC's unedited broadcast of "Saving Private Ryan" yielded better numbers than the network's regular Thursday programs, but its gains were hampered because many affiliates, saying they feared Federal Communications Commmission fines for indecency, chose not to show the film. KATE AURTHUR

title: Bollywood Confidential
description: Why do I love Bollywood movies? To an Indian, that's like asking why we love our mothers; we don't have a choice. We were born of them. Though Hindu gods are the obsession, even Muslims genuflect before the screen when they see their heroes walk on. It is significant that, except for Satyajit Ray, there isn't much of an internationally known Indian art cinema; the shadow of Bollywood is too long. Bollywood, and its cousins in the South Indian film industry, have beaten Hollywood at its own game: matching success at the box office with equal success in the battle for the hearts and minds of the audience -- conquering their very dream lives. Kitschy, illogical, often defying common sense, these movies have made me who I am. They shape the way I conduct my love affairs or think about religion or treat my elders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARK, DOROTHY C.
description: STARK--Dorothy C. 91, died November 8, 2004 in Denver, CO. A gracious woman with a strong intellect, raised in Wheeling, WV she lived most of her adult life in NYC. Upon graduating from the University of Chicago Mrs. Stark went to work in Washington, D.C. through the end of WWII. After a successful career in the corporate world in New York she became an accomplished painter and sculptor and invaluable partner/editor-in-chief to her late husband of 47 years, acclaimed arbitrator Arthur Stark, to whom she was devoted. They shared a passion for world travel, music, theater, dance and the fine arts. A loving mother and grandmother, she is survived by sons Peter C. Jacobson of Denver and Jeffrey G. Stark of New York, daughters Laura S. Steele of Ellicott City, MD and Margo D. Stark of Arlington, MA; brothers Arnold Copeland of Allentown, PA and Herbert Copeland of Baltimore and Naples, FL; cousin Robert Natkin of CT; four grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, nieces/nephews, great nieces/nephews.

title: Why Isn't Maggie Cheung a Hollywood Star?
description: Having spent the greater part of the day indoors, giving back-to-back interviews about her latest film, "Clean," at the Toronto International Film Festival, the actress Maggie Cheung exited the InterContinental Hotel to meet a spectacularly sunny early fall afternoon. As she strode through the doorway, she ran into a friend from a film shoot, and Cheung, possibly the most famous woman in China, chatted gaily in Cantonese with her colleague, casually standing on the sidewalk as if no one would notice. Close to a minute ticked by before one of the photographers lingering outside the hotel spotted her, possibly because Cheung was wearing Gucci sunglasses so large they were more like small, reflective plates perched on her fine face. Once one photographer was up and snapping there were suddenly 2, then 4, then 16, until a swirling cloud of microphones and flashbulbs formed around her, gathering as if by some centripetal force, sucking in ever growing numbers of fans and quote seekers and photo snappers, most of them Asian cineastes in town for the festival.

description: Montville High School is considering having a rifle team to compete in target shooting.

title: The Horses Are at The Gate
description: TRENTON - IT had not been a particularly good week for Senator Jon S. Corzine, who spent much of the past year crisscrossing the country -- palms up and legs crunched on countless plane trips -- trying to recruit Democratic candidates and raise money. Yet for all his effort as head of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, Mr. Corzine had managed to preside over a net loss of four seats.

title: Welcoming Graffiti as a Partner in Promotion
description: Roll-up shades, the heavy metal shutters that many storekeepers roll down at closing time, have become the latest frontier in advertising. And the ads that have been painted on them in the last few weeks look exactly like the thing they were always most vulnerable to: graffiti.

title: What Is an American Movie Now?
description: Is the Face of America That of a Green Ogre?This year's Cannes International Film Festival epitomized the extraordinary global reach of American films -- sometimes to the point of absurdity. There were thrilling movies at Cannes -- movies that told original, compelling stories about life in Senegal and upper-middle-class Paris and the jungles of Thailand. But those movies (and many others) contrasted sharply with the American films spotlighted at the festival, whose chief purpose, it seemed, was to please the widest possible audience.

"My phone started ringing nonstop," says Mr. Medina, who was then days from staging the Latin Music Fan Awards in Los Angeles. "Hundreds of people were calling and asking: 'Is Gloria going to be there? Oh my God, I can't wait to see her. Is she going to sing?"'

description: Amy Michelle Dotson, the daughter of Linda Puckett Dotson and Bob Dotson of New York, is to be married today to Adam Lucas Wogan, a son of Joan Mallon Wogan and Robert T.
