description: Rule No. 1: Always know where he is on the field.

title: What Is a Foreign Movie Now?
description: One night during the Toronto film festival earlier this fall, I slippedinto a buzzing multiplex theater decked out with all the amenities of 21st-century moviegoing -- stadium seating, molded plastic cup holders, digital surround sound, decent concession-stand cappuccino. I was there, along with a gratifyingly large number of curious and enthusiastic Canadians, not to catch an early glimpse of possible Oscar contenders but to see a new movie from China called "The World," directed by Jia Zhangke. I'd seen Jia's two previous films, "Platform" and "Unknown Pleasures" -- films that have won him a devoted following among critics and festivalgoers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, DR. LESTER LAUDY
description: COLEMAN--Dr. Lester Laudy. Death came peacefully on November 11th. A man beloved by the patients whom he served in a career that spanned 70 years. Dr. Coleman was a graduate of Johns Hopkins University and Long Island College of Medicine. He held the position of Attending Surgeon in Otolaryngology at both Manhattan Eye and Ear and New York Hospitals and was a Clinical Professor at Albert Einstein School of Medicine in New York City. He was a diplomate of the American Board of Otolaryngology and a Fellow of the American Triological Society and past Vice President of the American Academy of Psychosomatic Medicine. Dr. Coleman trained and guided the careers of many medical students. He was a nationally syndicated columnist for King Features Syndicate writing the "Speaking of your Health" column for more than 25 years and the author and narrator of "A Guide to your Health" a nationally syndicated radio program. Dr. Coleman created and produced "Here's to your Health" an early television series for the Medical Society of New York County and the National Broadcasting Company. He authored several books including "Freedom from Fear" which was translated in 12 languages and another widely used children's book "A Visit to the Hospital" intended to allay the fears of children facing surgery. Shortly before his retirement in 1999, Dr. Coleman spoke of how gratifying his life in medicine had been made by his patients and how grateful he was to them for their devotion to him. Dr. Coleman is survived by his wife Elizabeth, daughters Lynn Dale and Lisa and his beloved grand-daughter Sarah Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, November 16th at 2:00 PM at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Giving Owners Access to Nature
description: A HOUSE in East Quogue whose roofline evokes the motion of the ocean has won major honors for residential design in a competition of Long Island architects.

title: Hardcover Fiction
New Democratic Leader in Senate Is Atypical Choice
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 - He is a teetotaling Mormon, a former Capitol Hill police officer who opposes abortion and was a cosponsor of the constitutional amendment banning flag-burning. He is a little-known senator from a red state whose considerable skills do not include being a compelling presence on television or behind a lectern.

title: Japanese Pioneer More Than a Novelty
description: One quiet Saturday morning in New Jersey, 7,000 miles from an alter ego appearing on television dribbling basketballs for beer or gas or shoes, Yuta Tabuse was just a gardener's son playing a game.

title: Store Mannequins Can Now Breathe Out
description: IN his Manhattan workroom, Ralph Pucci is putting the finishing touches on his latest mannequin collection for department stores, "Goddess." As the name suggests, Goddess is no waif. Mr. Pucci said he wanted hot and sexy, so she is two to two and a half inches more curvaceous than his standard form and takes her cues not from runway models but from Beyonc and Jennifer Lopez.

title: Can Bush Deliver a Conservative Court?
description: WASHINGTON - AT a press conference two days after his re-election, President Bush was asked about what sort of Supreme Court justice he might nominate if and when the ailing Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist retires. Mr. Bush repeated the pledge he made in the presidential debates: "I would pick people who would be strict constructionists."

title: The Mouse That Plans to Roar
description: GAYDON, England - TWO of the three renowned British subsidiaries of the Ford Motor Company are in trouble. Land Rover has suffered from quality problems and low productivity. Jaguar is plagued by lackluster sales, more capacity to build cars than customers to buy them, and a disappointing downscale model, the X-Type.

title: DataBank; Autumn Rally Continues as Blue Chips Improve
description: Investors extended the market's autumn rally last week as the Dow Jones industrial average moved back into positive territory for 2004 for the first time since July.

title: These Days, the College Bowl Is Filled With Milk and Cereal
description: Perhaps it is an effort to counter those dense ideas they are force-fed in high school and college with something light and refreshingly mindless. What, for instance, could be less taxing after poring over the philosophy of Michel Foucault than a bowl of Lucky Charms?

title: Pass Go, Collect a Ticket to Paradise
description: FIVE hundred years before Nintendo sent the Mario Brothers hopping around the world, Japanese artists were creating sugoroku, or games in which players zoom across a grid or track. The earliest surviving examples, hand-painted for aristocrats, mix Chutes and Ladders with Buddhist cosmology; die rolls determine whether someone ascends to the paradise known as Pure Land or faces Emma, the guardian of hell. By the 18th century, advances in printing made sugoroku a popular pastime, and the games took on secular themes like sumo wrestling and kabuki drama.

title: Jersey City's Library Is a Land of the Lost
description: Jersey City - HOW bad are things at the main branch of the Jersey City Public Library?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWIMMER, BEATRICE OSGOOD
description: SCHWIMMER--Beatrice Osgood. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died November 7, 2004 in Santa Monica, CA at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Bertram. Survived by her son Arthur and daughter-in-law Arlene and grandchildren Elinor and David. Retired concert pianist and piano teacher, proud and loving mother and grandmother, intellectually curious and filled with wonder at the world she experienced for nearly a century, she was cherished by her family and friends, and will forever remain in our hearts.

title: Cleaner Los Angeles Air? Don't Hold Your Breath
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 - Air quality in the Los Angeles basin this year has been the best in 25 years, largely because of a fluke in the weather. But by virtually all measures, the region, the bowl-shaped home to 17 million air-breathing humans, remains the nation's capital of bad air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKS, SYLVIA
description: MARKS--Sylvia. Beloved wife of Benjamin Marks. On November 2 at age 87. Sylvia will be greatly missed by her many devoted friends and her loving son, Alan, his wife, Martha, and her grandchildren, Betsy, Ben and Lee. Memorial service November 21, 2 PM, Town & Village Synagogue, 334 E. 14 St., NYC.

title: In a Downtown War of the Roses, a Garden Loved, and Unloved
description: It is remarkable that the Liberty Community Gardens, a small garden in Battery Park City, has survived. The garden, much like the homes of its 29 volunteer caretakers, was blanketed in ash and debris after 9/11. One gardener recalled collecting parts of a half-buried Mr. Coffee machine.

title: Army Sets Hearing on Rape Accusation
description: An Army lieutenant will face an investigative hearing next week concerning an accusation that he raped a female officer from New Jersey who has refused to return to duty, the Army said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KINDMAN, JERRY
description: KINDMAN--Jerry. With deep sorrow and affection we mourn the passing of Jerry Kindman on November 12, 2004, at the age of 67. He was surrounded by family and friends. Beloved husband of Gloria, devoted father of Hillary, Jennifer and the late Stewart. He was both an intellectual and an adventurer, with an encyclopedic mind and a gentle soul. He was a connoisseur of life, and will be missed by all who knew him. A memorial service celebrating the life of Jerry will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th St., on Sunday, November 14, at 1 pm.

title: Transporting Beauty
description: "There was always a relentless effort in American cinema to clean up American women on-screen as opposed to their European sisters, who could remain more dissolute. There's been a line of Hollywood stars back to Greer Garson, Grace Kelly and Doris Day. A lot of the younger actresses have inherited that mantle of being decent, not being Frances Farmer, which is sort of what these pictures of Julia court. She's not dressed for going out; she's not dressed for anyone seeing her. These are really haunting pictures. It moves her image in a direction that can speak to me as a connoisseur of New Wave cinema or of the more outsize beauties of the 50's or 60's. They gave me a little dj vu in a way that was more personal almost than historical. When I saw that first one, I said, 'Oh, I know her.' Not as Julia Roberts, not as Sophia Loren or Jeanne Moreau, but there was a kind of uncanny familiarity." Wayne Koestenbaum, poet and writer

description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, LEA W.
description: GROSS--Lea W. On November 11, 2004, after a long and fruitful life. Beloved wife of the late Jess E. Gross. Devoted mother of Susan and Arthur Degen, Pamela Gross, and William and Cheryl Gross. Beloved grandmother of Bennett and Michelle Degen, and Meryl Degen. Loving great-grandmother of Joshua, Eliana and Alexandra. Cherished sister of the late Joseph Wohl, the late Honey Josephson, Sylvia Feldman and Bernard Wohl. A pioneer and advocate in the education of the blind and the transcription of literature to braille. Funeral services were held on Friday. Contributions in her memory may be made to Fight for Sight, 381 Park Ave So, NYC 10016, Suite 809.

title: Easier Airport Access In Vienna and Tel Aviv
description: New train services have been added in Austria and Israel to ease travel between airports and cities.

description: Back in the day, Rupert Murdoch rarely hesitated to use hostile takeovers to build the News Corporation -- and bristled if his prey, like Warner Communications, used "poison pill" defenses.

title: Manzanilla, and Be Quick
description: Nonvintage manzanilla sherry, from Sanlcar de Barrameda on the Atlantic, is Spain's finest aperitif. Barbadillo's Solear extra dry -- salty, nutty, redolent of green apples -- is ethereal. It enlivens olives, walnuts, tapas, Serrano ham, Manchego cheese, anchovies, seafood and caviar. Drink Solear icy and fresh. Manzanilla fades fast; finish the bottle in two days. Windsor, 474 Third Avenue (33rd Street), asks $10 for 500 milliliters. (Frontier Wine Imports, in Dover, N.J., is the distributor.) HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

description: Q Our co-op board, without consulting the shareholders, is considering changing the house rules so that people with baby strollers must take the service elevator. Ours is a family building, with most apartments having three bedrooms. Given the safety issue of unpredictable babies sharing an enclosed space with contractor equipment and pets, will this rule make our units more difficult to sell, and will it affect the price? . . . Sandra Kuhach, Manhattan.

description: WHEN President Bush and Congress get around to grappling with a rewrite of the tax code, much of the focus will be on closing loopholes to raise revenue so tax rates can be lowered.

I haven't read Schutt's work, but I am grateful that the National Book Award judges do not share the outlook of well-connected critics and authors -- that only by their grace and the grace of publishing houses like Knopf shall the public ever hear new voices.

title: Growing Up With Mom and Mom
description: For Ry Russo-Young's sperm donor to claim paternity is offensive, in exactly the same way as adopted children seeking out their "real" parents is (Susan Dominus, Oct. 24). As one whose husband was the sperm donor in the conventional way and who went through the months of pregnancy with each child, I am here to say that all that was trivial in determining parenthood.

title: She Cast a Ballot, And Won a Vote From Her Mother
description: AS parents, we treasure our children's firsts. We delight in every stage of development, from the first time they roll over to the first prom they attend, and beyond. This was brought home yet again to our family this month, when our daughter cast her first vote for president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAKLA, WAGUIH
description: TAKLA--Waguih. Our very dear friend passed away on November 12, 2004. Beloved by people all over the world, Waguih will be in our hearts forever. He had a profound love for life and brought joy & peace to all who knew him. Merle and Herb Rein and Family

title: Paperback Fiction
The Smart Sport
description: EVERY Friday at 3 p.m., a flood erupts from the doors of Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics High School in Spanish Harlem and surges down East 116th Street. It is composed of teenagers in every manner of dress, yelling, laughing, jumping on each other, flirting, eating cheeseburgers, and playing catch, consumed with the joy that is the arrival of the weekend.

title: The Artists' Architect, Building for Art's Sake
description: ELLSWORTH KELLY, his shirt hanging over his paint-splattered jeans, stood in the doorway of his snow-white gallery and flipped some switches. Slowly, louvers in the pitched skylight shifted and the six new paintings on the walls blazed with color.

title: Free Ranging
description: Back in 1996, an ice-wine maker in Niagara, Ontario, decided that he had had enough of overpriced and marginal balsamic vinegars. So he made his own vinegar from eight varieties of grapes -- all picked when temperatures dipped below 8 degrees Celsius and pressed while frozen. The resulting vinegar, which he called Minus 8, is dark like a raisin, has a soft sweetness and glows with fruit. It is remarkable enough that enthusiasts began calling the vinegar maker's parents, trying to track him down and showing up at his house in hopes of buying some more. This is why he asked that we not use his name for this article.

title: The Guide
description: Sunday 11/14

title: THOSE HMO BLUES
description: New Jersey's largest health insurer, Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield, has announced that a computer error caused more than 600 physicians to be overpaid for heart procedures and have asked the doctors to give back nearly $15 million dollars. The payments, which date back nearly two years, were paid above contracted rates for reimbursement for cardiac catheterization procedures, a company spokesman said. John Holl

title: Letting the Internet Knock on the Door
description: Do you know your neighbors? Probably not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BASCH, RANDY
description: BASCH--Randy. 55, formerly of Ozone Park, Queens passed away Thursday, November 11 after a brave fight against cancer. As a Project Manager for 32 years he was involved in the construction of the former Twin Towers and LaGuardia Airport parking garage, amongst others. His passions were his family, birding, motorcycle riding, inkwell collecting, tropical fish and model trains. He will be missed by his beloved companion Karen Vastarelli of Cheshire, CT, lifelong friend Shelby Basch Landesberg of Hamden, CT, sons Adam Hechler of East Hampton, CT and Jason Hechler of New York, NY and grandson Michael Sweeney of Wallingford, CT. He is survived by a brother, Steven Basch of Fairlawn, NJ and sister, Judy Basch of Davie, FL. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 21, 2004 at 10 AM at Truman School, 114 Truman St. in New Haven, CT. Randy asked that those attending his memorial service wear purple. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Rd., Branford, CT 06405.

title: Plant Shortage Leaves Campaigns Against Malaria at Risk
description: A Chinese herbal drug that is strikingly effective against malaria is in critically short supply because of rising demand, public health officials and pharmaceutical executives say.

title: To the Lighthouse
description: Long Island, as the name suggests, is essentially horizontal. We live in a land of slabs and lawns, ranch houses and beaches. We don't do tall; we sprawl.

title: Auburn Speeds Ahead; Wisconsin Stumbles
description: Auburn, 10-0 but No. 3 in the B.C.S. ranking, appealed to poll voters with a dominating 24-6 victory over Georgia. Michigan State handed Wisconsin its first defeat, and it was a doozy, a 49-14 dismantling of a top defense.

title: Does Gum Lose Its Flavor in a Photo?
description: Philadelphia - WHAT is one of America's foremost fashion photographers doing photographing twisted, flattened wads of chewing gum? That's the question raised by the Philadelphia Museum of Art's new exhibition, "Underfoot: Photographs by Irving Penn," containing three dozen of the internationally celebrated (and Plainfield-born) artist's latest prints.

title: A Spate of Attacks Has Women Looking Over Their Shoulders
description: The man's face, blank and square-jawed under a knit hat, peers out from "Wanted" posters along Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He is being sought by the police in connection with a recent sexual attack in the neighborhood and a rape in nearby Greenpoint, and he is making women in the area nervous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOONE, DIAN
description: BOONE--Dian, a Philadelphia based interior designer of international reputation, died on Monday, October 18, 2004. A Connecticut native, Ms. Boone also maintained a residence in Nantucket, MA. A memorial gathering will occur at 4 PM on November 20 in the Arthur Ross Gallery of the University of Pennsylvania at 220 S. 34th St. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Nantucket Conservation Fund, Inc., PO Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 17 about the role of religious faith in George W. Bush's presidency omitted a source for a quotation from a speech by David Rubenstein, co-founder of the Carlyle Group, an investment firm based in Washington, who placed Bush on the board of a company established by Carlyle investors in the late 1980's. It was from an article by Suzan Mazur in Progressive Review.

title: Guy Velella, Free for Now
description: In all his 28 years as a state legislator in Albany, Guy Velella was never able to achieve anything with the potentially far-reaching effect of what he may soon accomplish because of the public outcry over his premature release from jail: the reform of a system that willy-nilly allows criminals like Mr. Velella to go free.

title: Palestinians Schedule Election for Jan. 9
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 14 - Palestinians have scheduled presidential elections for Jan. 9 to replace Yasir Arafat, officials said today. Meanwhile, the favored candidate, Mahmoud Abbas, escaped injury as Palestinians waged a deadly gun battle during a mourning service for Mr. Arafat in Gaza City.

title: 'I Have Seen My Greatness Flicker . . . '
description: Speaking of Governor McGreevey's farewell speech, he borrowed liberally from some of the most powerful oratory in the history of the English language, including quotations from Martin Luther King Jr. and Rudyard Kipling.

title: Even Silent, a Piano Performs
description: LET'S be pretentious for a moment, hmm? What is the truer art: painting or music? Whether 'tis nobler to suffer the oils or the ivories?

title: Letters
description: Russell Shorto's cover article on evangelism in the office prompted strong, provocative mail, for and against the introduction of this kind of activity at work. Many cited past precedents in both secular and religious realms. Others weighed in on the National Book Awards and a finalist's fiction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REISS, ARTHUR
description: REISS--Arthur. Beloved husband of the late Jean. Cherished uncle and great-uncle. Services at Beth Moses Cemetery, 1:00PM, Sunday.

title: 'America the Beautiful,' and 'Liberty's Journey': From Sea to Shining Sea
description: AMERICA THE BEAUTIFUL By Katharine Lee Bates. Illustrated by Chris Gall. Unpaged. Little, Brown & Company. $16.95. (All ages)

title: Ski Trends: Superpipes and Miniparks
description: THE country's major mountain ski resorts are more determined than ever to be all things to all people this winter -- whether they are fans of Lincoln Logs, Linkin Park or Lincoln Navigators. That means skiers will find new lifts and programs devoted to children and beginners, souped-up terrain parks for hot-shot Generation Y "freeriders" and a commitment to the kind of services -- from spa treatments to ski caddies -- that ease the ski experience for aging baby boomers.

title: Judge Backs Bars That Allow Smoking
description: THE way Jack McCarthy sees it, if you walk into his pub on Middle Country Road in Centereach and light up a cigarette, you're the one breaking the law, not him.

title: A Mountain Bike Zips Through It
description: TIME truly waits for no one -- it's never even once paused for me. The passage of time is inexorable; it is that long, inscrutable march into an unknown number of tomorrows. It is, in other words, a tedious prospect. But at 54 years old, I find myself happily riding my Moots titanium mountain bike backward into another time with newly-found joy, flying through fertile and fragrant fields of hay, noticeably timothy here in these Somerset Hills, furtively cruising along the edges of horse trails and fox-hunting coverts, only to suddenly cut unobserved onto a deer path on my way to the stream.

title: For Iraqi Leader, Political Risks of Attack on Falluja Grow
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 13 - As Ayad Allawi, Iraq's interim prime minister, starts to position his party for the coming national elections, rising public denunciation of the invasion of Falluja by prominent Iraqi groups has put his political support at risk when he needs it most.

title: No Play Space for Kids? Keep Them Moving
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Republican World, State Democrats Gain
description: IF the election of 2004 is remembered for a great wave of Republican victories, then Connecticut felt the undertow, which tugged the state gently to the left and opened up new majorities in the state Senate and House.

title: On 'Moral Values,' It's Blue in a Landslide
description: FAREWELL to Swift boats and "Shove it!," to Osama's tape and Saddam's missing weapons, to "security moms" and outsourced dads. They've all been sent to history's dustbin faster than Ralph Nader memorabilia was dumped on eBay. In their stead stands a single ambiguous phrase coined by an anonymous exit pollster: "Moral values." By near universal agreement the morning after, these two words tell the entire story of the election: it's the culture, stupid.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Cablevision's Revenue Rises 20% for Quarter

title: Hospital Given Grant To Expand Emergency Care
description: Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco has been awarded a $250,000 state grant for an expanded emergency medicine department, it has announced. Joel Seligman, the hospital's president and chief executive, said the hospital was treating increasing numbers of people seeking emergency care.

title: INSIDE
description: Arrival of Chief Causes Discontent at the C.I.A. Tensions between new leaders and senior career officers at the Central Intelligence Agency are threatening to set off a rebellion within the agency's clandestine service, current and former intelligence officials say. They also say that discontent has reached a point not seen at the C.I.A. in more than 25 years, and they expressed concern that the ill will might distract the agency. PAGE 24

title: Sticker Shock at Gas Pump and Oil Tank
description: ROBERT PASTORELLI of Dix Hills pulled his Lincoln up to the self-service island at the DJM Service Station in Deer Park, handed the clerk $25 and began pumping.

title: Faith at Work
description: I found it interesting that within two weeks of each other, two cover articles addressed religious issues ("Without a Doubt," by Ron Suskind, Oct. 17). I was surprised, though, that Russell Shorto's article made no mention of Stanley Tam, who in 1955 made God the owner of his company, United States Plastics Corporation, as he describes in his book "God Owns My Business." Other well-known companies, like J.C. Penney, are also Christian-oriented in their foundation. Could it be that what many considered lunacy by Stanley Tam is becoming commonplace today? Or is faith-based business a component of American culture that has always been with us?

title: The 21st-Century Cinephile
description: Our entertainment-industrial complex operates as if the only movies that matter are a handful of studio blockbusters with the same toothy stars. Yet in March 2003, one movie-rich month out of many, a Los Angeles cinephile could go to a university theater, an art-house cinema and a cinematheque and watch a Chinese martial-arts film from the 1940's, Jean-Pierre Melville's 1970 policier, "Le Cercle Rouge," and the latest from the Mexican auteur Arturo Ripstein. That same month, a committed cinephile could have purchased newly released DVD's of films from Austria and South Korea and attended one of numerous film festivals in states from Maine to Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELEON, DOROTHY
description: DeLEON -- Dorothy. The Smith, Winograd and Birke families express deep sorrow on the passing of Dorothy (Babe) DeLeon who was a dear sister, mother, grandmother, aunt and a devoted wife of Ted DeLeon. Dorothy had style and grace and she brought a beautiful presence and quick wit to all occasions. Dorothy and her husband Ted formed a lasting and loving bond and cherished every moment together. Our families will greatly miss her and always remember her youthful spirit that matched her nickname of "Babe".

title: Melissa Rochester, David Rosen
description: Melissa Jill Rochester, a Congressional aide, and David F. Rosen, a political consultant, were married last night. Rabbi Daniel Friedman officiated at the Sofitel Chicago Water Tower hotel.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about Santa Catarina State in southern Brazil misstated the location of the Confraria das Artes nightclub. It is in downtown Praia da Joaquina, not on Lagoa da Conceio.

title: Virtual Warriors Have Feelings, Too
description: ON Nov. 9, after three years of development, months of frenzied fan speculation and $75 million in pre-orders, Microsoft launched Halo 2, the sequel to the top-selling title for the Xbox video game console. And from the moment Halo 2 finally went on sale, gamers have burned countless hours mastering Halo 2's fancy new weapons and exploring its expanded humans-repel-alien-invaders narrative. But for filmmakers like Burnie Burns, who work in the emerging medium of machinima, these features are a mere starting point. Instead of playing Halo as intended, Mr. Burns and a crew of machinima peers exploit the game's software quirks to create their online comedy series, Red vs. Blue, within Halo's virtual world. Since its debut in the spring of 2003, Red vs. Blue has rivaled Halo itself in popularity; fans download new episodes (www.redvsblue.com) at a rate of over 900,000 a week. GREG ALLEN

title: Rennie Harris: Popping, Locking and Healing Afterward
description: SUGA POP, a longtime member of the hip-hop group the Electric Boogaloos, has a soft, red-brown fleece of hair that shakes like strands of cotton candy when he dances. Now 40, he has been performing since he was a boy, when a Los Angeles group called the Lockers started letting him tag along on their gigs. They were led by Don Campbell, the inventor of the Campbellock, the dramatic, freeze-frame pose that is the basis of locking. Soon after, a dancer named Sam Solomon came up with popping, which refers to an exaggerated and abrupt action of the joints, reinforced with a popping mouth noise.

title: The Terrorist as Auteur
description: When you turn on the television news these days, you often see a new kind of home video: hooded men with guns and knives in the background and, in the grainy foreground, figures on their knees begging for their lives. They plead, they weep, they bow their heads and then, more often than not, they die. It has been like this since Daniel Pearl was made to repeat "My father is Jewish. My mother is Jewish. I am Jewish" before being decapitated. Thanks to the news editors, we rarely if ever see the footage to its gruesome conclusion, but the full versions of these films, reproduced on CD's, sell by the thousands in the marketplace in Baghdad. Apparently the executioners wear gloves. They do not want to stain their hands with the blood of infidels.

title: Racial Segregation in Prison
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments recently in a challenge to California's policy of segregating inmates by race in their first 60 days of incarceration. Prison officials argue that the practice reduces racially motivated violence. But government-imposed racial segregation should be permitted only in extraordinary circumstances, if at all. The court should strike down the policy.

title: Saving 'Saving Private Ryan'
description: No one ever accused broadcast executives of being profiles in courage. But the pre-emptive timidity of a score of them was a sorry spectacle last Thursday when they decided not to show "Saving Private Ryan" on Veterans Day because they were afraid of the Federal Communications Commission. Station executives were openly fearful that the movie's realism in depicting the carnage and vulgarity of war might offend that newly righteous bureaucracy, whose blue nose was bent out of shape by the flash of Janet Jackson's breast during the last Super Bowl and, later, by Bono's casual airing of an obscenity assuredly in use among soldiers in Iraq.

title: Packed Powder Via Your PC
description: WHEN Walter DeTour, of New Canaan, Conn., logged on to Weather.com last December and saw yet another snowstorm forecast for New England, he did what any responsible parent would do: He put his son, Tyler, into the car and drove five hours north to Stowe, Vt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, TONI M.
description: DIAMOND--Toni M. With deep sorrow we mourn the loss of a champion in MDA's fight against neuromuscular diseases. Our valiant Toni lost her battle with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis at age 46 on November 11. She was the inspiration and drive behind MDA's Wings Over Wall Street, which annually raises millions of dollars for MDA ALS research efforts. Our hearts go out to Warren Schiffer, Toni's husband and love of her life. To Warren we vow to continue our intense efforts to defeat ALS. Muscular Dystrophy Assn Robert Ross, Pres & CEO Victor Wright, Treasurer John Tognino, Board Mbr John Walsh, Asst Director Field Organization Jerry Lewis, Natl Chairman

title: Big in Japan, but Made in the U.S.A.

Their enthusiasm wanes, however, when they find Harmony hiding in their sock drawer. Yumi tosses the sycophantic stalker out the window of their (moving) tour bus, but Harmony keeps turning up with predictably wacky results.

It was broadcast exactly once, during the 1984 Super Bowl, and signaled the company's bid to reclaim leadership in personal computers from I.B.M. and its tiny, little-known software partner, Microsoft.

title: History Was Just the Half of It
description: LAST year, the Oxford University historian Robin Lane Fox, the author of a much-admired 1973 biography of Alexander the Great, found himself astride a horse, carrying a wooden lance, thundering through the desert dust with scores of mounted companions as Alexander's greatest conquest unfolded.

title: Saving the Sound
description: Long Island Sound is one of America's great estuaries. Rich in marine and bird life, ringed by bays and wetlands, it provides jobs, recreation and aesthetic pleasure. It is also under constant stress. Flanked on one side by Long Island, on the other by Westchester and Connecticut, the Sound extends 110 miles through the densest population corridor in America; if it is rich with nature's bounty, it is also poorer for the contaminants generated by the 20 million people who live within 50 miles of its shores.

title: To Avoid Divorce, Move to Massachusetts

title: QUICK BITE/Bloomfield; Nostalgia, With a Cherry on Top
description: In a previous review, I mentioned a family that stopped at the same doughnut shop after church every Sunday. There are variations on this tale, because here in these United States we enjoy freedom of religion and snack selection. My friend Sue's father, for example, breaks the annual Yom Kippur fast at Holsten's ice-cream parlor in Bloomfield. But Morris Macy is not a once-a-year customer. Sue reports that her father has been a Holsten's regular for 50 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 17 about the role of religious faith in George W. Bush's presidency omitted a source for a quotation from a speech by David Rubenstein, co-founder of the Carlyle Group, an investment firm based in Washington, who placed Bush on the board of a company established by Carlyle investors in the late 1980's. It was from an article by Suzan Mazur in Progressive Review.

title: Questions for Christine Schutt
description: Deborah Solomon (Oct. 31) has done a deft job of putting words in Christine Schutt's mouth. I certainly did not damn Schutt's doubtless excellent book without reading it. I didn't comment at all about the quality of the finalists' work, some of which I know and admire. My skepticism was aimed only at the likelihood of the five best books all being the work of New Yorkers. I suppose, to be fair, that stranger things have happened. It's just that I don't think so. In any case, why be so huffy about calling it the Municipal Book Awards?

title: Milton Cohen, 93, a Lawyer Who Inspired Market Reform, Dies
description: Milton H. Cohen, a securities lawyer whose insights into the stock market became the basis for innumerable regulatory proposals over the last 40 years, died Oct. 30 at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 93.

title: German Fears Grow That Far-Right Party Will Return to National Stage
description: BERLIN, Nov. 14 - After a string of electoral successes, there are growing fears that a far-right party could be elected in 2006 to Germany's Bundestag, or Parliament - the first time since World War II.

title: 'What We Owe Iraq: War and the Ethics of Nation Building'
description: LATE ONE NIGHT IN MAY 2003, I WAS IN A MILITARY transport plane somewhere over the Mediterranean, on my way to a stint as constitutional adviser to the American occupation authorities in Iraq. In the dozen or so rows of seats that had been jerry-rigged in the open belly of the aircraft, most of the passengers-all in various aspects of the advising business-were dozing, shivering slightly for the last time before we hit the Baghdad heat. The adrenaline pumping through me, I was rereading the best modern book on the Iraqi ShiA and hastily trying to teach myself some Iraqi colloquial dialect.

title: No Longer the Leader in Lyme Disease
description: LYME disease has been called "the big masquerader" of diseases, its stubborn pathogens able to mimic a host's DNA to avoid detection and cause symptoms in a human patient often mistaken for other illnesses. Now some complain the spread of the malady is being further disguised with help from the state Department of Public Health.

title: Wolfe's World
description: When Tom Wolfe invented a fresh form of journalism in the 60's, none of us could have imagined what a novelistic fop he would turn out to be. The fact that Charles McGrath (Oct. 31) lingers on Wolfe's fastidious dress and idiosyncratic choice of typewriters does little to obscure the lingering doubts about Wolfe's fiction-writing abilities. How far can a snappy white suit with pinstripe shirts carry an aging author?

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday showing how Americans voted in the presidential election misstated the breakdown for men and women. Men made up 46 percent of the voters, not 51; women were 54 percent, not 49. The chart also misstated the percentage of Asians who voted for President Bush. It was 41 percent, not 44.

They called in air support. A 500-pound bomb slammed into a blue-tiled tower, obliterating a signature part of the Khulafa Al Rashid mosque, the city's most celebrated religious building.

Two white police officers peered at him from their squad car, he said, and one of them told him he looked "suspicious." He claimed the policeman then forced open the car door and dragged him outside, handcuffed him, patted him down and searched his car.

For good reason: a lot more people are heading out into the backcountry on their skis, ratcheting up both the excitement and the danger factors.

description: THE dramatic soprano Deborah Voigt returns to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday as Elisabeth in Wagner's "Tannhuser," and opera buffs are abuzz with anticipation over this popular American artist's first foray into the role at the house.

title: Cara Egan, Gibson Reynolds III

Shawn Tracy, a cousin of the bride and a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Patrick's Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. J. Emmett Carroll, a cousin of the bridegroom and also a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Lexicographer
description: I've wanted to be a lexicographer since I was 8. (A lexicographer, as those of you who read this space regularly well know, is someone who writes or edits dictionaries. The word "lexicographer" is one you'll find in even the smallest dictionaries -- call it a point of professional privilege.) I read an article in a newspaper about the late Robert Burchfield and the making of the second edition of the Oxford English Dictionary, and after that, you might say, my path was defined.

title: Help Wanted (for a Better Way to Count Jobs)
description: THE presidential election has not ended the debate over jobs -- or the debate over jobs numbers. In fact, different employment statistics continue to provide sometimes incongruous snapshots of the economy, as relatively new measures based on Internet surveys often conflict with the trends shown by traditional measures compiled by the government.

title: The Bishops, in Codey, Have a New Target
description: IN the coming days, you can expect to hear a great deal about the differences between Richard J. Codey, and James E. McGreevey, the man whom he will be replacing as governor on Monday.

title: Reciting a Rosary, but in Sonata Form
description: THE commemorations of the 300th anniversary of the death of Heinrich Ignaz Franz Biber have not exactly swamped the concert calendar or jammed ticket hotlines. But Biber's brilliant "Mystery" Sonatas, for violin, have received a sudden flush of attention with three new recordings and a live performance by Yuval Waldman that is to take place on Friday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Manhattan.

title: A Final Count (With Many Accounted For)
description: OF the more than two million registered voters in the state, 1,604,375 of them -- or 78.81 percent -- turned out for the Nov. 2 elections, according to the office of Secretary of State Susan Bysiewicz. The percentage of voters was almost unchanged from the 2000 elections.

title: For a Gray Season, Coats That Are Anything But
description: Forget unobtrusive pea jackets and neutral meltons that disappear into the throng. This season, coats are making a statement, in eye-catching colors, patterns, cuts and fabrics. Many don't cover up an outfit so much as make it, using elements like paillettes, crystals and ribbon sashes. Here are eight that will speak for themselves all winter long.

title: Sergei Prokofiev's Peter and the Wolf' and 'Carnival of the Animals': The Sight of Music
description: SERGEI PROKOFIEV'S PETER AND THE WOLF Retold by Janet Schulman. Illustrated by Peter Malone. Unpaged. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. (All ages)

title: New Owner, Old Obligation?
description: When my friend bought a car dealership that had gone bankrupt, he refused to honor a promotion of the previous owner offering free oil changes for life for all cars bought there. A local newspaper promptly named my friend Rogue of the Week. When he acquired the income-producing potential of this business, didn't he also assume the duty to honor the previous owner's promises? Anonymous, Portland, Ore. Your friend need not fulfill his predecessor's promises or take his predecessor's wife out to dinner. He's not the previous owner; this is not the previous dealership.

title: A Little Congee May Make The Medicine Go Down
description: AS Maurice Sendak once said, all seasons of the year are nice for eating chicken soup with rice. That's pretty much the attitude at one Brooklyn hospital, where Chinese patients can have congee, a rice porridge in broth, for breakfast six days a week. The exception is Sunday, which, as anyone who has ever eaten in Chinatown knows, is reserved for dumplings.

title: Whose Moral Values? The Debate Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Rent Stabilization Survives in Long Beach
description: Tenants of some 1,500 rent-stabilized apartments in Long Beach are breathing a sigh of relief over a recent Appellate Division decision that disallowed $6 million in damages against the city and threatened to end rent stabilization.

title: Lawmakers Divided on C.I.A. Chief's Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 - Amid reports of serious turmoil in the Central Intelligence Agency under the new leadership of Porter Goss, legislators differed sharply today over whether Mr. Goss was bringing needed change to what one Republican senator called a "dysfunctional" and a "rogue" agency or was, as a Democrat said, recklessly driving out capable intelligence veterans.

title: Autolux: Sweet Music (and Sour Notes)
description: LOS ANGELES - YOU can tell a lot about people by their modus operandi at a museum. The band Autolux, for instance, upon arriving at the Museum of Contemporary Art in downtown Los Angeles recently, made for the Ed Ruscha retrospective and promptly scattered like a bead of mercury dropped to the floor.

title: The Banks of the Gowanus Put the Gleam in a Builder's Eye
description: There is a strange beauty to sunset on the Gowanus Canal, when the blue film on the surface of the notorious waterway catches the sunlight streaming past the elevated trains at just the right angle. For a second, an optimistic visitor can ignore the pungent aroma and the odd plastic bag floating by -- after all, the waterway is much cleaner than it was a few years ago -- and begin to imagine staying awhile.

title: Northern Exposures
description: I have found the work of Alice Munro deeply moving (Daphne Merkin, Oct. 24). So much so that a few years ago I wrote to tell her that. It was in response to one of her stories -- about a young woman who is molested on a train. It struck a nerve. After a while, a handwritten response came to me from Munro. She thanked me warmly and expressed concern that people might find her work depressing. I was deeply impressed by her generosity with her time and spirit.

title: The Gifted Ones
description: Swiss Legend Watch It makes intuitive sense that movie stars and other denizens of the alternate universe of global entertainment and celebrity own all the coolest stuff, and well before you do. After all, they're lavishly paid, their work takes them all over the world and it is often part of their jobs to be stylish. But the international celebrity -- and even the considerably-less-than-international celebrity -- has another advantage besides piles of money and cutting-edge taste: getting stuff free. In fact, so many companies are so eager to give stuff to celebrities that there is an elaborate mechanism to see that this happens in an efficient manner.

title: Fate of Lawyer in Terror Case Hinges on Sheik's Words

Until now, New Jersey's $66 billion pension fund -- one of the nation's largest -- has been managed by state employees, who have kept it solely in stocks and bonds. Mary Williams Walsh

title: Saving the Sound
description: Long Island Sound is one of America's great estuaries. Rich in marine and bird life, ringed by bays and wetlands, it provides jobs, recreation and aesthetic pleasure. It is also under constant stress. Flanked on one side by Long Island, on the other by Westchester and Connecticut, the Sound extends 110 miles through the densest population corridor in America; if it is rich with nature's bounty, it is also poorer for the contaminants generated by the 20 million people who live within 50 miles of its shores.

title: Will Meets Resistance in Deadly Logic of War
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Nov. 13 - The geese came in from the north, flying in a slightly broken V. When they flew above the booms and crashes of southern Falluja, it was as if they had hit a force field -- the V dissolved into a tangle of confused circles, the migration stopped, the birds veered past each other in the sky, seemingly trapped above a sliver of apocalypse.

title: In Jackson Hole
description: Jackson gets a lot of the credit (or, some might say, the blame) for inventing cowboy chic. While other winter resorts like Vail strive for a kind of European Old World coziness, Jackson and the surrounding valley, called Jackson Hole, feel wide open, as though a bustling tourist destination with challenging ski slopes and a hundred ways to spend time and money somehow just moseyed up off the open range.

title: Restoring the Hudson
description: Restoring the Hudson TUESDAY -- Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will be the host and Dan Aykroyd will be the master of ceremonies at a photography auction at Boylan Studios, 601 West 26th Street, to raise money for Riverkeeper, the organization that works to restore the Hudson River. Drinks, hors d'oeuvres and a silent auction begin at 6:30, with the live auction to begin at 8:30. Tickets, $100, from (845)424-4149, ext. 243.

title: Microbe Hunting, Up Close and Personal
description: About a year ago, after learning that Fox was looking for procedural medical shows, David Shore, another executive producer of the series, created Dr. House, named as a homonymic tip of the hat to Sherlock Holmes. "I came up with this investigating-the-diagnosis thing, but to be honest, that didn't particularly excite me until I started developing the House character," said Mr. Shore, whose producing credits include "Law & Order," "Hack" and "Family Law." "He's the anti-Dr. Welby in the sense that he doesn't care about bedside manner but only cares about results." Dr. House's scathing patient evaluations, Mr. Shore said with a laugh, are informed by "my paranoia about what my doctors say behind my back after I leave the room, when I've come to see them with my lame complaints."

title: Those Devils on Fat Wheels
description: ON Saturday afternoon, Nov. 6, a day before tens of thousands of runners and spectators descended on Central Park for the New York City Marathon, a group of young men on steel-framed, fat-tired bicycles had a corner of the park all to themselves. They were perched atop a jagged gray outcrop overlooking the bridle path. To geologists the ancient rocks of Central Park are metamorphosed Paleozoic and allochthonous bedrock of the Taconic Sequence, but urban downhill riders like Mike Jawien, 18, use simpler terms for their favorite rock formations in the park, words like "sick" and "ridiculous."

That fact, along with thousands of others, will be on display Thursday when Mr. Clinton cuts the ribbon on his $165 million presidential library, right, in Little Rock, Ark. The building, the 11th presidential library, will house two million photographs and 80 million pages of documents.

title: Inside the List
description: THE SMILING PREACHER: "Think big. Think increase. Think abundance. Think more than enough." That's not Dr. Atkins telling you how much bacon and cheddar you can pound down on his counterintuitive diet. That's America's hottest young pastor, Joel Osteen, explaining in his new book, "Your Best Life Now: 7 Steps to Living at Your Full Potential," that God does not want you to be poor. Osteen's book is at No. 5 on this week's hardcover advice, how-to and miscellaneous list. Osteen, who is 41, runs the Lakewood Church in Houston, which in the last five years has become America's largest church -- some 25,000 people attend services there each weekend. His television show, seen in 150 countries, reaches millions more. Osteen definitely thinks increase: he plans to move his church into the Compaq Center, formerly home to the Houston Rockets, sometime next year -- after he has fitted it out with twin waterfalls. Osteen describes Lakewood as "a nondenominational charismatic church." There's no fire-and-brimstone here, or in his book. Osteen has become known as "the Smiling Preacher," and among the themes he hits regularly is the need to shed your "poverty mentality." Having trouble at work? "God may intervene in your situation," Osteen writes, "replacing your supervisor so you can be promoted. One day, you may run that entire company!"

And there, in marked contrast for everyone to see, is Ms. Ensler's all too human belly: a pale, round, intractable protuberance, the cause of undying -- and yet artistically fruitful -- shame.

title: 'Runaway': Alice's Wonderland

At the risk of sounding like a pleader on behalf of yet another underappreciated writer -- and maybe you've learned to recognize and evade these pleas? The same way you've learned not to open bulk mail from certain charities? Please give generously to Dawn Powell? Your contribution of just 15 minutes a week can help assure Joseph Roth of his rightful place in the modern canon? -- I want to circle around Munro's latest marvel of a book, "Runaway," by taking some guesses at why her excellence so dismayingly exceeds her fame.

The daybreak rush to the lifts that infuses ski resorts around the world with early energy is notably absent in Bormio, where the cobblestoned streets stay quiet until midmorning.

title: Faith at Work

He acknowledges that "when it comes to writing about religion, objectivity is a false god," which is undoubtedly true. Yet as a participant in the movement, I recognized his portrayal as true -- sympathetic and critical and honest and respectful of his subjects. My perspective is somewhat different from his, yet I felt the way you feel when a good tour guide introduces you to an interesting locale. He discovered and pointed out the prominent landmarks, described the most important social and cultural realities and gave the lay of the land in a way that prepares you to further explore the landscape intelligently on your own.

title: Fantasy Series: Of Trolls and Men
description: ALL good children's fantasy epics are alike; every unsuccessful fantasy epic fails in its own way. Despite settings that range from a land inhabited by water waifs and goblins to a futuristic Europe, the middle installments of five continuing fantasy series look more the same than different. Somehow the authors orchestrate a conflict between good and evil. The good can't be too good, lest the story become too preachy and dull, and the evil can't be too evil, lest the story become too violent or frightening. And, for all the magic, the talking animals, the imaginary creatures and imaginary worlds, a good fantasy must also be original and startle the reader into a new thought or two.

title: June 16, 2005
description: In more than four decades of steady stage work, Vanessa Redgrave has played 'em all, more or less. Her Chekhov roles have ranged from Nina in "The Seagull" to Ranevskaya in "The Cherry Orchard." She's portrayed Shakespeare's Rosalind and Cleopatra and even Prospero. Last year she tackled one of the American theater's most formidable challenges, Mary Tyrone in Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night," winning her first Tony Award. But her stage rsum, intriguingly, doesn't feature much Greek tragedy. (She was Katharine Hepburn's co-star in Michael Cacoyannis's 1971 movie of Euripides' "Trojan Women.") It's fitting, then, that for her return to the Royal Shakespeare Company after a four-decade absence -- itself a somewhat historic occasion -- Ms. Redgrave has decided to add a tragic heroine to her repertory. Now 67, she is perhaps beyond the proper age for Euripides' most famously enraged females, Medea and Electra. Instead she'll play the title role in his "Hecuba," a lesser-known but no less bloody tale of a woman exacting vengeance for the loss of her throne and the murder of her children. The production arrives at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on June 16 for a 10-day run. Subscriptions to the academy's spring season go on sale tomorrow, and single tickets for "Hecuba" will go on sale Jan. 3; ticket services, (718)636-4100. CHARLES ISHERWOOD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN RIPER, HAASE, EDITH
description: VAN RIPER-HAASE--Edith, of Manhasset, Long Island, died on November 8 after a long battle with ovarian cancer. She was a lifelong resident of Long Island and past owner of Douglas Van Riper Realty, a residential real estate firm established in 1926, that she took over at the death of her husband in 1974. After growing it to a most prosperous business, she sold it to Douglas Elliman as the perfect fit with tradition, unparalleled prestige and superior marketing ability being shared commitments. Her involvement in the business and community life of the area included acting as President and Treasurer of the Manhasset Real Estate Board and as a board member of the Family & Children's Association. She held a dual degree in Sociology and Social Work which served her well in preparing her for the challenges of creating and maintaining a successful business that depended on her "people skills" of being both a good listener and advisor to her customers. Her charitable giving contributions won her the coveted North Shore Junior League Daisy Award for volunteerism which she treasured all her life. Services were held on Thursday, November 11 at The Congregational Church in Manhasset. The family request that contributions be made to the NSLIJ Health Systems for Ovarian Cancer Research, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, LI 11021. Her family included her beloved husband, George F. Haase; her children, Douglas R. and Jan Van Riper and Elizabeth Miller; her step-children George and Lisa Haase, Robert Haase, James Haase, Thomas and Bonnie Haase and Margretta and Michael Franklin plus her fourteen grandchildren.

title: Fringe Beneficiaries
description: ADRIANO SHAPLIN has a long history of precocity. At 15, he was writing and performing solo shows and acting with community theater groups in Burlington, Vt. At 17, when he was at Sarah Lawrence, he founded the Riot Group with two other students, Stephanie Viola and Drew Friedman. They put on their first shows in dorm rooms, basements and cafes. In the summer after sophomore year, the Riot Group scored a stage at last, at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, where it performed "Why I Want to Shoot Ronald Reagan." The group returned in 1999 with "Wreck the Airline Barrier," which won a Fringe First. The group has since won twice more. So it is not surprising that at 25, Mr. Shaplin has two plays running off Broadway, "Hell Meets Henry Halfway," an adaptation of Witold Gombrowicz's "Possessed," and "Pugilist Specialist," a taut psychological drama about American marines involved in a "black op" in the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, JOE R.
description: BROWN--Joe R. Rochester, MN, died Saturday, October 30, 2004 at Charter House. A pioneer in Neurology and a passionate liberal, Dr. Brown graduated from the University of Iowa Medical School, MD (1937). Married Rebecca Frisbee, 1937. Mayo Clinic fellowship, MS 1943. Served in WWII, Medical Corp 1943-46. Served at University of Minnesota Hospital and VA Hospital - Chief of Neurology where he developed the first program of rehabilitation and physical therapy for disabled veterans, 1946-49. Joined the Mayo Clinic in Neurology, 1949; section head 1954-66; Professor of Medicine, 1963, senior consultant 1966-76, Emeritus, 1976, consulting neurologist at San Diego Medical School from 1978-85. He was honored in 1998 as a founding member and first Secretary-Treasurer (1948-56 and President (1971-73) of the American Academy of Neurology. Other honors: MS Hope Chest Award, AMA Bronze Medal, 54 year member of the First Unitarian Church. He is survived by his Wife, Rebecca (Becky) Brown, who resides at Charter House in Rochester, MN; sons, Hugh and Stephen (wife, Pamela); daughter, Carolyn Zniewski (husband, Zachary); five grandchildren, three great grandchildren. Physician, family man, and friend. For information, Ranfranz and Vine Funeral Homes in Rochester, MN.

title: The Age of Ettlinger
description: I HAVE on my shelf a first edition of Garry Wills's "Bare Ruined Choirs," a 1972 book of essays that examined the role of prophecy and social commitment in a declining Roman Catholic Church. In his photo for the book, a bespectacled Wills is sitting in a backyard or park, his shirt open and his sleeves rolled up, two pens clipped to a slightly sagging shirt-pocket, the author looking off to the side with almost embarrassing eagerness -- he might be waiting to be invited to mix it up with the other boys. The camera has ineptly caught just one dimple and, on the other side of Wills's face, what is either a long sideburn or one half of a straplike beard unaccompanied by a matching mustache. The picture is charming, though its subject might just as well be an early software engineer or a polymath cabdriver. That indeterminate relationship between appearance and reality is what makes it charming.

We live on the Upper West Side. My office is in TriBeCa. I have one child in school on the Upper East Side, the other on the Upper West, and limited baby-sitting. Only one of my children's friends lives anywhere near a direct subway line to our apartment. Neither is old enough to take public transportation alone. And like many middle-class Manhattan families, hanging white-knuckled onto their two-bed/two-baths, we can't afford to keep a car in the city.

title: Box Office in a Box
description: I. Get Me Gene Hackman For the past few years, Hollywood's weekend box-office tallies have come to represent a tidy bit of wisdom about American culture -- cold, bare numbers relayed around the world every Monday morning that tell us which stories and which celebrities are resonating with the moviegoing public. There is, however, another set of Hollywood statistics of enormous significance, and Tuesday is their day. How important are these numbers? Every Tuesday at lunchtime, Mike Dunn and Peter Staddon, the president and executive vice president, respectively, of 20th Century Fox's home-entertainment division, take the elevator from ther 25th-floor offices at Fox Plaza in Los Angeles down to their cars in the underground parking garage and from there drive out into the noontime traffic on their way to Best Buy, Target, Costco and Wal-Mart. Tuesday is the day new DVD's are released, the day Dunn gets a sense of whether the discs that his team has worked on for months -- or sometimes years -- will sell as well as planned. So the Fox executives wander the aisles of the big retailers. They eavesdrop. They size up the clientele. They take note of what's moving through the cash registers. Tuesday, not Monday, is their day of reckoning.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: CHARLIZE THERON may have won an Oscar for playing Aileen Wuornos in "Monster," but she didn't quite pin down the wild look in Wuornos's eyes. The real thing is on view in AILEEN: LIFE AND DEATH OF A SERIAL KILLER (2003), Nick Broomfield and Joan Churchill's scary documentary, filmed in the months before Wuornos's execution by lethal injection in 2002. Wuornos was convicted of seven murders committed while she made her living as a prostitute on Florida highways. Having contended that she had killed only in self-defense, she changed her story near the end. Mr. Broomfield's conclusion is that she had lost complete touch with reality at that point. In her last interview, she tells him, "They've been using sonic pressure on my head since 1997" and confides that she expects death to be like something from "Star Trek" -- Monday at 10 p.m. and Thursday/Early Friday at 2:35 a.m. on HBO.

title: The Foreign Legion
description: There will always be an appetite for classic American blondes, but one of the most thrilling aspects of the global movie business is the emergence of actresses of varied nationalities. A mix of audacity, talent and, of course, beauty characterizes each of the women photographed here, but it is the complexity of their performances that ultimately sets them apart. Take the English actress Emily Mortimer, who first garnered attention for a scene in "Lovely and Amazing" in which she asks her lover to critique her naked body. It is a riveting moment that illustrates Mortimer's ability to balance comedy and pathos -- traits that also define her character as a single mother in the forthcoming "Dear Frankie." The Argentine actress Mia Maestro, who stars in "The Motorcycle Diaries," will play a deeply religious teacher who seems haunted in "The Holy Girl"; it's as if devotion had taken possession of her entire being. Similarly, when Marilou Berry, the ignored daughter of a self-absorbed author, breaks into song in the French film "Look at Me," her character is transformed. Aishwarya Rai, the highest-paid actress in Bollywood, dazzles as Lalita, the Elizabeth Bennett character in the U.S.-distributed film "Bride and Prejudice." The Beijing-born actress Zhang Ziyi ("Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon") can next be seen as a blind, knife-throwing courtesan in the sumptuous "House of Flying Daggers." The Spanish television actress Beln Rueda gives a precise, heartbreaking performance as a terminally ill lawyer in "The Sea Inside." And in "Spanglish," Paz Vega ("Talk to Her") plays a Latino maid with a child who disrupts the lives of her wealthy employers. Lynn Hirschberg

title: Saving the Sound
description: Long Island Sound is one of America's great estuaries. Rich in marine and bird life, ringed by bays and wetlands, it provides jobs, recreation and aesthetic pleasure. It is also under constant stress. Flanked on one side by Long Island, on the other by Westchester and Connecticut, the Sound extends 110 miles through the densest population corridor in America; if it is rich with nature's bounty, it is also poorer for the contaminants generated by the 20 million people who live within 50 miles of its shores.

title: PAPERBACK ROW
description: CITY ROOM, by Arthur Gelb. (Berkley, $17.95.) In a graceful, absorbing memoir of his life at The New York Times, Gelb recalls arriving at the newspaper's old city room as a copy boy in 1944: "It was where I wanted to stay forever." Forty-five years later, he retired as managing editor, having worked as a police reporter, drama critic and metropolitan editor along the way. Gelb reminisces affectionately about the changing culture of The Times and vividly recounts the major news events of the past 50 years. Our reviewer, Ward Just, praised the book's "sheer exuberance," calling it "a wonderful evocation of what the newspaper business was like in the postwar years."

title: A Photograph as Lovely as a Tree
description: Tall trees are tricky to look at. They can almost never be seen whole; from the ground they fade away into the sky, and from the sky they hide beneath their own branches. For "Tree: A New Vision of the American Forest" (Barnes & Noble Books), James Balog photographed 92 superlative specimens in novel ways: swathing Texas live oaks in white nylon to make their ropy torsos stand out in stark relief, and turning a saguaro cactus into a bleary dream of ridges and spines by shooting it with a $16 plastic Holga camera. But it was his full-length images of the big guys -- Stagg, a 242-foot giant sequoia, and Stratosphere Giant, a 369-foot coast redwood that is officially the world's tallest tree -- that required every bit of Mr. Balog's ingenuity.

title: Arts, Briefly; Marley Musical in London
description: London's theatergoers already have big-budget musicals based on the music of Queen and Abba. Now they will be getting a new West End production honoring another 70's musical icon: Bob Marley, right. Clear Channel will produce the show, which has not yet been written but is scheduled to open in 2006, the chief executive of Clear Channel Europe's theatrical division, David Ian, told the British daily The Guardian. Mr. Ian said the show had the backing of Marley's widow, Rita, as well as Chris Blackwell, the founder of Island Records, which released most of the reggae star's music. Marley, who was born in Jamaica and died of cancer in 1981, was named an honorary member of Britain's Music Hall of Fame this month and has long been one of the music industry's biggest posthumous earners. His greatest-hits album, "Legend," has sold more than 20 million copies, and Forbes recently reported that Marley's estate made about $7 million in the past year. HEATHER TIMMONS

description: BOURKE--Rev. Msgr. Myles. M. Pastor Emeritus of Corpus Christi Parish in New York City died peacefully on Novmember 13, 2004. A renowned scripture scholar, Msgr. Bourke held teaching appointments at St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, Fordham University and the Pontifical Biblical Institute in Rome. He was Presdient of the Catholic Biblical Association of America (1967-1968), and Chair of its Board of Trustees from 1971-1993. Msgr. Bourke is survived by his beloved sister Gloria, and countless students and friends. Reposing Monday, at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121st St, from 2 pm, concluding with Vespers at 8 pm. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cause Of Rapper's Death Awaited
description: It will take about a week to determine why Russell T. Jones, the rap star known as O.D.B., died suddenly, a spokeswoman for the New York City medical examiner's office said yesterday. An autopsy was performed yesterday, and investigators are awaiting the results of toxicology and tissue tests, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the office. Mr. Jones, who would have turned 36 today, was one of the founding members of the Wu-Tang Clan. He collapsed at a recording studio at 545 West 34th Street late Saturday afternoon after complaining of chest pains. He could not be revived and was pronounced dead at the scene. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Vetoes School Nurse Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill on Friday that would require city health officials to provide a nurse to every public and private elementary and middle school that has at least 200 students, saying the bill does not make the best use of resources and curtails the authority of the mayor. In September, Mayor Bloomberg announced that the city would allocate up to $8 million to hire more full-time nurses in parochial and other private schools. "The legislation before me is therefore unnecessary," the mayor wrote in the veto message. But the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, immediately pledged to override the veto, calling the mayor's efforts in this area "a Band-Aid on a gaping wound." Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Why the Democrats Need to Stop Thinking About Elephants
description: If George Lakoff had his way, the Kerry campaign would have run a commercial attacking the "baby tax." Dr. Lakoff, a Berkeley linguistics professor and Kerry campaign adviser, wanted to divide the interest on the national debt by the number of Americans born each year. The result, $85,000 per newborn, say, would have been handed to a baby in the form of a bill, and the baby would have started to cry. That, Dr. Lakoff says, "frames" the issue "in a way people can understand."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Elmont: Electrical Shock Kills Worker
description: One man was killed and another was in critical condition yesterday after they received an electrical shock while putting siding on a house in Elmont, a spokesman for the Nassau County Police Department said. The men, both workers in their 30's, were raising a scaffold at 2140 Leighton Road about noon when it made contact with power lines near the house, said the spokesman, Officer Michael Aronsen. The men were thrown from the scaffolding by the shock, he said. Santos Garcia, 34, of Hicksville, was killed instantly. His co-worker, Jose Alvarenga, 33, whose address could not be determined late yesterday, was taken to Nassau University Medical Center, where he was in critical condition, Officer Aronsen said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

His plastic tools were arrayed on his wheelchair work tray, and with a screwdriver he pried the tracks off his yellow toy bulldozer. Ignoring visitors to his apartment, he grumbled to his grandfather, "This screwdriver's not very good."

title: The Larger Battle in Iraq

American commanders understood that, and for months hoped to avoid the attack that began a week ago. Since then, the military advance has been relentless, but the political reaction in the Sunni Arab community has been highly negative. If Sunni hostility continues to deepen, Falluja could turn into a very costly victory.

The girlfriend, Ebony Oden, 21, had been visiting the man, Chance Kemar, at his apartment at 1487 Nostrand Avenue in Flatbush when Mr. Kemar accidentally fired a Mac-10 machine pistol and grazed her leg, the police said. Ms. Oden was treated at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center and released. Mr. Kemar was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. He has no previous criminal record. title: Arts, Briefly; The Incredible 'Incredibles'
description: Disney-Pixar's film "The Incredibles" dominated the box office for the second weekend in a row, taking in an estimated $51 million to bring its box office total in two weeks to a stunning $144 million. The family film appeared to draw audiences away from Warner Brothers' computer-animated Christmas fable, "The Polar Express," right, which had a disappointing first weekend, taking in just $23.5 million for a total of $30.8 million since opening on Wednesday. Other new films had moderately successful openings. New Line's thriller starring Pierce Brosnan, "After the Sunset," took in an estimated $11.5 million, and "Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason," a sequel to the surprise hit "Bridget Jones's Diary," took in $8.9 million in just 500 theaters. The cult horror film "Seed of Chucky" made $8.7 million in its first weekend out. In the art-house market, Miramax's "Finding Neverland," starring Johnny Depp, and Fox Searchlight's "Kinsey," starring Liam Neeson, both opened in a handful of theaters but had strong receptions, taking in $241,000 and $175,000, respectively. SHARON WAXMAN

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dispute Over Voice-Dialing
description: The New York City public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, called on Verizon yesterday to reverse its plan to discontinue a voice-dialing service that helps visually impaired people use the telephone. The service, costing about $5 a month, allows callers to dial a number by speaking into the phone. Verizon says that because a manufacturer no longer makes parts for equipment related to the service, it will discontinue voice-dialing in February. At a City Hall news conference, Ms. Gotbaum, above, said Verizon should provide customers with an alternative, and she faulted the company for announcing the change using a letter to customers that she said was printed in small type that was difficult to read. Jim Smith, a spokesman for Verizon, said that for about $200, customers could purchase a voice-dialing device that attaches to a phone and does not require a monthly fee. He said that the letters the telephone company sent were in "normal size" type. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAABIN, NORMA HESSE
description: RAABIN--Norma Hesse. 97, died peacefully on November 13, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Lewis D. Raabin. Loving mother of Edie and Eddie Scheurer. Adored grandmother of Lynne and Andrew. Cherished great-grandmother of Sarah and Noah. Devoted sister-in-law of Elizabeth Hesse. Predeceased by her brother Stanley Hesse. Caring aunt, cousin, teacher and friend. Her warmth, charm and grace endeared her to all whose lives she touched. She was devoted to community and charitable causes. She was a trustee of the Jewish Guild for the Blind and a member of the Board of the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El. She was active in English in Action through the English Speaking Union. She cared deeply for her students. Family will receive at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St, Monday, November 15th, 6:30-9:00 pm, with services Tuesday, 11:30 am. description: The Regis Corporation, a beauty salon operator, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Hair Club for Men and Women, which sells hair restoration services, for $210 million. Regis said that the acquisition would add about $50 million in revenue and enhance earnings modestly during the second half of the fiscal year, which ends in June. Regis projected that Hair Club, which will operate as a subsidiary, would add $115 million in revenue and $2.8 million in net income, or 6 cents a share, in fiscal year 2006. Regis, which is based in Minneapolis, owns or franchises more than 10,000 salons under names like Supercuts, MasterCuts and Vidal Sassoon. Hair Club is based in Boca Raton, Fla. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Recruiting for the Arts
description: The country's largest nonprofit arts advocacy group, Americans for the Arts, said yesterday that it planned to enlist 100,000 "citizen activists" to help lobby local, state and federal officials to adopt policies more friendly to arts and arts education. The citizens' campaign -- announced by the playwright Wendy Wasserstein, left, at a news conference at the American Airlines Theater on West 42nd Street -- is part of an effort to stem what the group describes as a serious decline in public and private contributions to the arts across the country. Over the past two years, the group says, state arts councils have lost 40 percent of their financing, and over the last decade the share of private giving to the arts has also declined by more than 40 percent. The lobbying effort, called the Arts Action Fund, has recruited actors and celebrities including Robert Redford, Paul Newman and Meryl Streep to help. RANDY KENNEDY

General Electric will get "significant" cost savings, said William Woodburn, chief executive of GE Infrastructure, the unit buying Edwards. SPX, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., said that it would use the proceeds to pay debt and buy back stock. General Electric will be able to broaden its security offerings and tap what it estimates is a $15 billion industry for fire and building-system products. General Electric is based in Fairfield, Conn.

McGreevey's executive order forbidding state contractors from making campaign contributions -- a practice known as "pay to play" -- moved one step closer to becoming law yesterday when it was released from committee in the State Senate. title: National Briefing | Washington: Man Sets Himself Aflame Near White House
description: A man set himself on fire near the White House, screaming "Allah" before Secret Service officers restrained him, a service spokesman said. The spokesman, Tom Mazur, said the incident occurred on a stretch of Pennsylvania Avenue that last week was opened to the public for the first time since January. He said the man was treated by White House doctors and Secret Service personnel before being taken to a hospital. He had burns on 30 percent of his body, officials said. The Washington Post identified the man as Mohamed Alanssi, 52, of Falls Church., Va., and said he had worked as a federal informer on terrorism. John Files (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Heir to the Nickelodeon
description: British music lovers will be able to download songs from vending machines starting next month. Inspired Broadcasting, which makes jukeboxes and pub games, is installing kiosks in London railroad stations that will have libraries of 2 million singles. The company plans to have 20,000 machines operating throughout Europe in two years. Inspired is going to retrofit about 12,000 game terminals and jukeboxes already in pubs to allow music downloading, said the chief executive, Norman Crowley, in a telephone interview. Users will be able to download a song for about a $1.85 onto any mobile phone or Creatives Lab music player, Mr. Crowley said. Apple has not yet approved the downloads for the iPod, he said. HEATHER TIMMONS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Calls Before And After Killing
description: A Sprint representative testified yesterday that Daniel Pelosi's cellphone went silent for seven hours on the morning that prosecutors say he murdered the financier R. Theodore Ammon, despite a flurry of calls before and after that show him moving around Suffolk County. Records show that Mr. Pelosi traveled to his sister's home in Center Moriches early on Oct. 21, 2001, phoning his friend Christopher Parrino just before 1:30 a.m. Seven hours later, he made calls that indicate he was at or near the homes of Mr. Parrino, who has been charged as an accomplice, and another friend. Peter C. Beller (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Putin Indicates Kurile Deal Is Not Likely Soon
description: President Vladimir V. Putin played down comments made in a television interview by his foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, on Sunday that suggested Russia would recognize a promise made by Khrushchev in 1956 to return two of the four southernmost islands of the Kurile chain, which Russia occupies and Japan claims. The Soviet Union's seizure of the islands, known in Japan as the Northern Territories, at the end of World War II has kept the countries from signing a formal peace treaty and been a perpetual thorn in relations. Russia would act on the 1956 declaration only "within the parameters our partners are prepared to honor," Mr. Putin said at a government meeting, adding, "So far we have not managed to reach an understanding on these parameters." Mr. Putin is to visit Japan early next year. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the city will begin arbitration hearings today in which a three-person panel will make binding recommendations on wages and benefits. The city has offered the police a raise of no more than the 5 percent over three years received by several other city unions, saying it would offer more only if the union agreed to cost-saving measures. Saying that the city was having difficulty recruiting and retaining officers, the association, which represents more than 22,000 officers, is seeking raises of more than 10 percent to help catch up with suburban pay scales.
