On Sunday, Sho Nakamori, 19, of Bethpage, died after the 1994 Acura she was driving slammed into a pole after rounding a curve on Stewart Avenue in Bethpage. The police said the car was speeding. title: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' Second Time Around
description: The rebroadcast of "CSI: NY" on Friday night tipped the scales in CBS's favor -- 10.15 million viewers watched the program, which was interrupted near its ending on Wednesday by an announcement of Yasir Arafat's death. ABC came in first on Saturday with "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." ABC generally wins the ratings game on Sunday nights, also, on the strength of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" and "Desperate Housewives." But this Sunday, its three-hour broadcast of "The American Music Awards" didn't do as well, though it did place first in the 18-to-49 category. According to the Nielsen overnight ratings, CBS won the night over all, with 19.42 million viewers tuning in to watch a superstorm hit Chicago in the first part of "Category 6: Day of Destruction." NBC's "American Dreams" and "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" did better than usual in the absence of the ABC competition, but the once-mighty "Criminal Intent" is weak when compared with last season. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Rebel Leader's Trial Off Again
description: The retrial of Abimael Guzmn, the leader of the Shining Path rebel movement, collapsed after two of the three presiding judges stepped down, saying their impartiality in the case could be questioned because of previous rulings. The annulment of the trial was the latest twist in the chaotic proceedings, which began this month with Mr. Guzmn and his fellow defendants chanting communist slogans in court and raising their fists in victory salutes. Mr. Guzmn, a former provincial university professor, was captured in 1992 and convicted by hooded judges in a secret military tribunal. But new trials were ordered for Mr. Guzmn and other rebel leaders after the country's Constitutional Tribunal ruled that the secret courts were unconstitutional. Shining Path, which began its war against the state in 1980, was officially blamed by a Truth and Reconciliation Commission for a majority of the 70,000 deaths Peru suffered in the 20-year conflict. No date has been set for a new trial. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAABIN, NORMA HESSE
description: RAABIN--Norma Hesse. 97, died peacefully on November 13, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Lewis D. Raabin. Loving mother of Edie and Eddie Scheurer. Adored grandmother of Lynne and Andrew. Cherished great-grandmother of Sarah and Noah. Devoted sister-in-law of Elizabeth Hesse. Predeceased by her brother Stanley Hesse. Caring aunt, cousin, teacher and friend. Her warmth, charm and grace endeared her to all whose lives she touched. She was devoted to community and charitable causes. She was a trustee of the Jewish Guild for the Blind and a member of the Board of the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El. She was active in English in Action through the English Speaking Union. She cared deeply for her students. Family will receive at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St, Monday, November 15th, 6:30-9:00 pm, with services Tuesday, November 16th, 11:30 am. Gifts to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, Women's Auxiliary Temple Emanu-El, or Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation would be greatly appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Builder To Sell Water Unit
description: A French building company, Bouygues, plans to sell its water unit, Saur, to a buyout firm, PAI Partners, for 1.04 billion euros ($1.35 billion) to focus on construction and on telecommunications, the company said. PAI, together with Saur's managers, made an offer for 85 percent of the utility, said Blandine Delafon, a spokeswoman for Bouygues, which would retain a 15 percent stake. The deal excludes Saur's African and Italian assets. The water unit employs 21,000 people in 17 countries, deriving 70 percent of sales from France, 10 percent from other European nations and 20 percent from the rest of the world. PAI is also based in Paris.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To End  a Monthly Fee
description: Verizon Wireless, the nation's second-largest mobile phone carrier, will eliminate a 40-cent monthly fee it has been charging customers to cover costs associated with a rule that allows clients to keep their phone numbers when switching service providers. The company's 42.1 million customers will continue to pay 5 cents a phone number each month for regulatory fees in the United States, a company spokesman, Jeffrey Nelson, said. The reduction will begin with billing cycles next week, Verizon Wireless said. Sprint, the nation's third-largest cellphone carrier, lowered its monthly regulatory fee rate to 25 cents from 40 cents on Nov. 1. Verizon Wireless, which is owned by Verizon Communications and Vodafone, has been collecting about $15 million a month with its fee. Under a November 2003 rule by the Federal Communications Commission, mobile phone users can keep their numbers when they switch providers. Verizon Wireless, which is based in Bedminster, N.J., has said about three customers switch to its service and keep their phone numbers for every one who leaves for another provider.

description: Investor, the investment company of the Wallenberg dynasty in Sweden, said its chairman, Claes Dahlbaeck, would step down in April, permitting the family to tighten control. Jacob Wallenberg, left, currently vice chairman, will succeed Mr. Dahlbaeck as chairman, Investor said. His cousin Marcus Wallenberg will remain as Investor's chief executive. title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Scansoft To Buy 3 Companies For $63 Million
description: ScanSoft, a maker of speech-recognition software, said yesterday that it would buy two closely held Israeli companies and one Scottish one for a total of at least $63 million to gain access to technology and customers. ScanSoft said it would pay at least $35 million for Phonetic Systems, an American-Israeli maker of speech-recognition software. ScanSoft said it might pay as much as another $35 million based on future profits and other factors. It agreed to buy ART Advanced Recognition Technologies of Tel Aviv, a maker of speech recognition software for cellphones, for $21.5 million. It will also pay $6.7 million for Rhetorical Systems, a maker of text-to-speech technology, which is based in Scotland. All the purchases will be made in cash, it said. ScanSoft, based in Peabody, Mass., whose software converts paper documents and photos into digital documents and images, has been buying rivals to attract more customers to its programs for translating the spoken word.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nikon Profit Rises
description: Profit for the Nikon Corporation more than tripled in the first half of its fiscal year on strong sales of equipment used to make computer chips. Nikon, which is better known for its cameras, reported net profit of 7.81 billion yen ($74 million) for the six months ended Sept. 30, compared with 2.05 billion yen a year earlier. Revenue rose 30 percent, to 312 billion yen, helped by an increase in orders for machines used to etch circuits on silicon wafers. Profit in Nikon's core camera division fell compared with last year, as a sharp decline in sales of traditional film cameras more than offset a rise in sales of digital cameras. Sales of film cameras are expected to continue falling, and Nikon also warned that it expects the pace of growth in digital cameras to slow later this year. Still, the company kept its profit forecast for the year ending next March unchanged at 28.6 billion yen, compared with 2.4 billion yen last year. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing's 3rd-Quarter Loss Widens
description: Global Crossing said yesterday that its third-quarter loss widened by 28 percent as pricing for global networking services remained weak. The international network operator, in the midst of talks to get up to $400 million in much-needed financing, also said its reorganizing activities would cut revenue by $40 million to $60 million in the fourth quarter, but would improve its earnings. The company's net loss widened to $102 million from $80 million a year earlier, when it was in bankruptcy. Earnings per share were not provided. Revenue fell 11 percent, to $617 million, mostly because of continuing price pressures for long-distance voice calls. Global Crossing, based in Bermuda, said most of its previously announced revamping costs of $16 million to $20 million would fall in the fourth quarter. The company has said it will cut 600 jobs and reduce or exit a number of businesses, mostly in voice services, to focus on selling Internet and data transport.

His name will be an indelible part of our history, and his commitment will inspire us to perpetuate the Institute's mission, which he held in such high esteem. We wish to offer children, Carole and Richard, grandchildren Alexandra, Jeffrey, Vicki and Seth, and the entire Malamut family, our most heartfelt condolences. Rosenblut, President and Chief Executive Officer

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Outlets Converted
description: Starting today, all AT&T Wireless retail outlets will be converted into Cingular Wireless stores. The move comes three weeks after Cingular, a joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth, completed its $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless to become the largest cellphone carrier in the United States. The 1,055 company-owned stores formerly run by AT&T Wireless will now have Cingular phones and accessories and Cingular signs. An additional 10,500 stores operated by agents representing AT&T Wireless will be converted during the next month. Cingular, which now has 46 million subscribers, has already introduced new advertising plans that integrate AT&T Wireless into the Cingular brand. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: FORD SELLING FORMULA ONE RACING TEAM TO RED BULL
description: Red Bull, a closely held Austrian drinks maker, agreed to buy the Ford Motor Company's unprofitable Jaguar Formula One team to expand in the car racing business. Ford, based in Dearborn, Mich., put Jaguar Racing up for sale to cut costs after five winless seasons. Ford absorbed $300 million in expenses in the third quarter to write down the team's assets and good will. Terms of the sale were not released. The acquisition is the biggest in motor sports by Red Bull, which makes energy drinks and sponsors European and United States teams. Ford also said yesterday that it had sold its Cosworth Racing unit, the maker of race engines, to two United States entrepreneurs.

title: Pollution in Buyat Bay
description: Indonesia's natural resources are among the most bounteous in the world. They are also among the most abused. Desperate for foreign investment and plagued by corruption and weak regulation, Indonesian governments over the years have virtually invited multinational corporations -- and, for that matter, their own citizens -- to clear-cut the country's incomparable rain forests, foul the air and pollute the water. Now more than 80 percent of the country's 19,700-square-mile reef system, the world's largest, is at risk.

title: TYSON FOODS SAYS EARNINGS DECLINED 55% IN QUARTER
description: Tyson Foods, the world's biggest meat processor, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit decreased 55 percent on rising costs, on losses on commodity futures and expenses related to plant closings. Net income fell to $66 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 2, from $147 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose 8.8 percent, to $7.1 billion. Tyson, which is based in Springdale, Ark., said that it paid more for cattle, and that the cost of grain fed to chickens rose by $106 million. Losses on commodity futures included $29 million related to hedges on beef sales and $20 million on grain contracts. The company forecast that profit in the new fiscal year would rise to a range of $1.15 to $1.45.

description: Norma Gonzalez Snchez, 44, pleaded guilty to involvement in a human smuggling operation in which 19 illegal immigrants died of heatstroke after they and more than 50 others were abandoned in a sealed trailer at Victoria, Tex., in May 2003. Ms. Snchez was the fifth of 14 people charged in the case to plead guilty. Sentencing was deferred; she could receive life in prison and be fined $250,000. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Fighting Over Food
description: FOOD FIGHT -- Each year, a group called the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine issues a report, widely cited in the news media, listing which domestic airport terminals offer the healthiest food at their restaurants. The new report, released yesterday, gives Miami International Airport the highest score among the top 12 airports for "healthy entrees." Miami topped the rankings with "85 percent of its restaurants offering healthy choices," said the report, which defined healthy as low-fat and vegetarian. But in a statement yesterday, another group, the Center for Consumer Freedom, criticized the committee's emphasis on vegetarian fare, calling it an animal-rights group with well-documented ties to the activist group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. The center described itself as a "nonprofit coalition supported by restaurants, food companies and consumers." Colleen Young, a spokesman for the physicians committee, said that the center routinely criticized its reports because they were "basically threatening to their clients." She denied that the committee was associated with PETA, but said it had received some PETA funds in an unrelated campaign some years ago.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Dutch Radicals Deported In June
description: Members of a group of suspected Islamic militants associated with the man accused of killing the Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh were arrested in Portugal in June and deported to the Netherlands because of fears that they were planning a terrorist attack. The men were part of a group that was being tracked by the Dutch intelligence service and had traveled to Portugal ahead of the European championship soccer tournament there, Euro 2004. The Dutch authorities notified the Portuguese police of the group's presence, and they were arrested, according to a Dutch government report to Parliament last week. Portugal's former national police chief, Adelino Salvado, was quoted in the newspaper Dirio de Notcias as saying he feared that the group would try to assassinate the prime minister, Jos Manuel Duro Barroso. The group was reportedly driving a car registered to Muhammad Bouyeri, the Dutch-Moroccan accused of murdering Mr. van Gogh in Amsterdam this month. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Steel Maker Posts Profit
description: The steel maker Arcelor said that price increases helped it earn 629 million euros ($817 million) in the third quarter. The company also forecast that demand from automakers and packaging companies would rise further next year. Net income was up from 101 million euros a year ago. Sales rose 22 percent, to 7.15 billion euros. Third-quarter sales of flat carbon steel used in cars and washing machines rose 20 percent, to 3.77 billion euros, Arcelor said. Shipments rose 6.7 percent, to 6.03 million metric tons. Sales of long carbon steel used in construction rose 41 percent, to 1.64 billion euros. Shipments increased 12 percent, to 3.28 million tons. Stainless steel sales rose 27 percent, to 1.02 billion euros. Arcelor is based in Luxembourg.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Court Says Judge Was Wrong To Dismiss Case
description: A state appellate court ruled yesterday that a controversial Queens judge was wrong to dismiss attempted murder charges against William Hodges, a Queens man accused of shooting a police officer in the leg in 1999 during a scuffle. Justice Laura D. Blackburne of State Supreme Court in Queens ruled in December 2002 that Queens prosecutors had taken more than their allotted six months to bring Mr. Hodges's case to trial and dismissed the attempted murder charges against him. The Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, who appealed her decision, said yesterday's ruling "corrects what would have otherwise been a gross miscarriage of justice" and declared that his office would begin prosecuting Mr. Hodges. The also judge came under criticism in June, after she let a robbery suspect in her courtroom elude detectives by letting him out a back exit. She was then transferred to a civil court from a criminal court. Phone messages left yesterday at her chambers and home were not returned. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Shares Soar After Patent Ruling
description: Shares of Rambus, a designer of high-speed memory chips, rose as much as 21 percent yesterday after a federal judge issued a ruling defining terms in a patent dispute with Hynix Semiconductor. Judge Ronald Whyte of Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., issued a ruling late Monday that defined terms of the disputed patents in favor of both companies, according to the decision posted on the Rambus Web site. The judge accepted definitions suggested by Rambus at least eight times and adopted at least three others recommended by Hynix. Hynix, based in Icheon, South Korea, sued Rambus in 2000, seeking to invalidate the company's patents. Rambus shares rose $2.63, or 14 percent, to $21.47.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINTZ, WALTER
description: MINTZ--Walter. Died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday, November 16, 2004 after a long illness. He was the dearly loved husband of Sandra Earl Mintz. Born February 23, 1929 in Vienna, Austria the son of the late Maximillian and Ilse Schueller Mintz, he came to the United States with his family in 1938. After attending public schools in the Bronx, he graduated from Reed College in Portland, Oregon in 1950, and then did post-graduate work in economics at Columbia University. He was an Associate Editor at Barron's before he began his career in the investment business at Shearson Hammill Co. in 1956. There, he was the Director of Research, 1962-69, and Executive Vice President of their Investment Division, 1965-70. In 1970, he co-founded Cumberland Associates, an investment management company in New York. He retired as a Managing partner from that firm in 1982, remaining a special limited partner. Mr. Mintz was a Trustee of Reed College for 33 years, 1971-2003. He was Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, 1991-98, and Chairman 1998-2002. He established the Walter Mintz Economics Scholarship for students, and co-sponsored a Chair in Economic History. In New York, he was a Trustee of The Manhattan Institute, 1990-2003, and served as Vice Chairman, 1994-2003. He was also on the Boards of Merrill Lynch Phoenix Fund and Federal Security Trust, 1982-2001; on the Board of the Citizen's Union Foundation, 1985-2003, and was a member of the N.Y. Society of Security Analysts, where he served on their Board of Directors, 196975. In addition to his wife of 33 years, he is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Marjorie and Dr. Joseph K. Perloff, and their two daughters, Nancy and Carey, all of California. Services were privately held, but it is hoped that all who knew him will set aside some time to remember his great ability to think and reason fairly; his enjoyment of life and his work; his good nature, compassion and generous spirit. He cherished his friends and was grateful for them. MINTZ--Walter. The Members and staff, past and present, of Cumberland Associates LLC mourn the passing of our co-founder, Walter Mintz. His professional accomplishment, his wisdom, and his friendship serve as an inspiration to us all. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Sandra.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Trying To Limit Health Spending For State Workers

description: The last time Eli Manning made a debut as a starting quarterback, his coach had no doubts beforehand. And after that first game, the coach, David Cutcliffe of the University of Mississippi, had goose bumps.

title: Rangers' Lundmark Agrees to Deal
description: Jamie Lundmark, the 23-year-old center who was the ninth pick in the 1999 draft, agreed to terms yesterday with the Rangers' top minor league affiliate, the Hartford Wolf Pack. Lundmark, who had 2 goals and 8 assists in 56 games with the Rangers last season, was the leading scorer for H.C. Bolzano in the Italian League during the National Hockey League lockout. He had 10 goals and 9 assists in 14 games. Jason Diamos

title: Bill Bennett, 73, Aviator Who Championed Hang Gliding, Dies
description: Bill Bennett, a pioneer aviator and entrepreneur who helped introduce the fledgling sport of hang gliding to America in the 1960's and 70's, died on Oct. 7 in an accident during takeoff at the airport in Lake Havasu City, Ariz., where he lived. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COSTABILE, VENERA GRAZIA (NEE LAIMO)
description: COSTABILE--Venera Grazia (nee Laimo) aged 90, on November 16, 2004. Devoted wife for 44 years of the late Albert, beloved mother of Rita Costabile Tobin and JoAnn DiMaggio, loving grandmother of Austin, cherished sister of Stellario, Francesca and the late Pasquale, caring mother-in-law of Austin and John, admired "Zi Zi Vee" of nine nieces and nephews. Many great-nieces and greatnephews and a great-great niece and two great-great nephews. Until the last months of her life, a resident of Brooklyn, N.Y. She was a loyal and skilled office worker at Macy's N.Y. for 28 years, a consummate homemaker and a wise and dear mother who encouraged her daughters through college and graduate school. Her girlhood hero was Amelia Earhart; she was "the wind beneath our wings." Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. NY, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 10am at Our Lady of Guadalupe Church, 7201 15th Ave., Brooklyn, N.Y. 718-236-8300. In lieu of flowers, donations to Macular Degeneration Foundation, Inc. PO Box 531313, Henderson, NV 89053

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the arrest of a homeless man in the fatal shooting of a worker painting a highway overpass in Queens misidentified the government agency in charge of the project. It was the state's Transportation Department, not the city's.

title: Ex-Prisoner Says Pelosi Told Him of Beating Millionaire to Death
description: RIVERHEAD N.Y., Nov. 16 - Daniel Pelosi told a fellow inmate that he had beaten R. Theodore Ammon to death and had then begun smoking crack to lose weight so no one would believe he could kill the taller and more athletic Mr. Ammon, the inmate, Clayton J. Moultrie, testified on Tuesday.

title: For O.D.B., Fun Was Too Much or Not at All
description: Ol' Dirty Bastard first roared into view 12 years ago, howling a wild threat: "Bite my style, I'll bite your " -- well, never mind the rest. The track was called "Protect Ya Neck," and it was the epochal first single from his group, the Wu-Tang Clan, which swiftly became one of the most important hip-hop acts of the 1990's and certainly one of the strangest. Somehow an entropic octet obsessed with obscure kung fu movies and even more obscure neo-Gnostic theology became one of the decade's most visible pop-culture brand names.

title: Technology Briefing | People: IAC Names Financial Chief
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the Internet and television commerce company controlled by Barry Diller, appointed the chief executive of its HSN home-shopping network, Thomas J. McInerney, to be IAC's new chief financial officer, succeeding Dara Khosrowshahi. The company, based in New York, said last week that Ms. Khosrowshahi would become chief executive of IAC's travel division. Erik Blachford, the current head of IAC Travel, might leave the company.

title: Arts, Briefly; Shortlist Prize
description: It has been a long trip for a short list. The Shortlist Music Prize, which recognizes innovative and underground groups, announced 73 nominees in August and narrowed them to 10 finalists a month later. On Monday night a winner was chosen at a concert in Los Angeles. The lucky recipient of the $10,000 award was TV on the Radio, a Brooklyn-based art-rock group that wowed critics this year with its debut album, "Desperate Youth, Blood Thirsty Babes" (Touch and Go). Highlights from the concert will be shown on MTV 2 on Saturday at 9 p.m. Eastern time and 6 p.m. Pacific time. BEN SISARIO

title: Bringing Back Ashton's Nymph for a Lesson in Love
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 - The Royal Ballet is restoring a bit of its choreographic past. This fall the company is honoring the centenary of the birth of Frederick Ashton, its great founding choreographer, with "Ashton 100 Celebrations" featuring his ballets.

title: Royalty collectors accused of hindering online music services : EU takes on those who call the tune
Loose weapons in Iraq : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
California Settles Lawsuit on Juvenile Prisons
description: STOCKTON, Calif., Nov. 16 - The problem-ridden youth correctional system in California will focus more on rehabilitation and less on punishment under a legal settlement announced here on Tuesday by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger.

title: Group Says Iran Has Secret Nuclear Arms Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - An Iranian opposition group says it has new evidence that Iran is producing enriched uranium at a covert Defense Ministry facility in Tehran that has not been disclosed to United Nations inspectors.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BAKER, JACK
description: BAKER--Jack. 1994 Dear Dad, we are missing you and loving you always. Love Paula, Beau and Bobb

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Polanski Seeks the Lords' Blessing

title: As French as Apple Pie
description: Laurent Tourondel likes American pies. "When I go into diners, I always order pie, but then I think that maybe I can do them better," said Mr. Tourondel, the French-born chef at BLT Steak, 106 East 57th Street, and Union Pacific, 111 East 22nd Street. No diner dessert can match his praline-dusted pumpkin pie, above center, with its silky filling hinting of dark caramel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORMAN, JUDITH
description: CORMAN--Judith. The directors, staff, and residents of Phoenix House mourn the loss of a dear friend and colleague. Judy Corman was an officer of Phoenix House, who started and ran our volunteer program and headed our national communications department. She believed passionately in our mission and relished her work with young people struggling to start new lives. She went on to pursue a brilliant career in public relations but remained forever devoted to Phoenix House and her friends here. Loyalty was Judy's strong suit, for she would do anything for a friend. We will miss her--her wit, her humor, and her good sense. Edward D. Miller, Chairman Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D., President Kevin E. McEneaney, Executive Vice President CORMAN--Judith A. Senior Vice President Corporate Communications and Media Relations, for Scholastic Inc. A veteran media strategist, who brought tenacity and passion to promote the company's businesses and literacy mission. A wide ranging career in public relations in the business and non-profit worlds steered her to Scholastic, where she led the charge for the unprecedented Harry Potter phenomenon, for which she received a 2001 Matrix Award from New York Women in Communications. Her creativity, intellect, warmth, and professionalism will be fondly remembered by her staff, colleagues and friends at Scholastic. Family and friends will celebrate Judy's life at 9:30AM on November 17 at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W 68 St, NYC. CORMAN--Judy. The Board and staff of City Parks Foundation mourn the passing of Judy Corman, wife of Avery Corman, one of our founding trustees. Judy was a great lover of parks and of New York City and arranged the donation of thousands of books every summer to kids who attended our free reading series. We will miss her deeply, and we send our condolences to Avery and her entire family. CORMAN--Judy. Judy was wonderful. A warm sun for her family and legions of friends. We are so sorry. We will miss her so much. Our love to Avery, Nicky, Matt, Dawn and Marcio. Peggy, Lizzy and Gordon CORMAN--Judy. The staff of Goodman Media International, Inc. mourns the loss of a dear friend and extraordinary client. We will miss Judy immensely. Tom Goodman, President

title: Baker Becoming Squeezed for Time
description: SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 16 - Vin Baker beat back his demons and overcame the betrayals of his body only to find himself, unexpectedly, in the one place he could not escape through sheer willpower: the Knicks' bench.

title: A Victory, But Little Is Gained
description: Hanover, N.H. - The textbook urban assault on Falluja reflected well on the dedication, training and equipment of the American military. Unfortunately, it has not brought the United States appreciably closer to achieving its political objectives in Iraq. In fact, history suggests that America has slim hopes of defeating the insurgency, and that our best chance for "success" depends on redefining what we would consider a victory.

title: U.S. Troops Move to Drive Out Rebels in North of Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 16 - The American military raced Tuesday to contain a spreading insurgency, sending hundreds of soldiers and armored vehicles into the streets of Mosul to root out bands of rebels who commandeered parts of the city last week as the Americans were battling their way through Falluja.

title: Teen pleads guilty in first Madrid attacks trial
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Insurance Investigation Leads to More Guilty Pleas Two employees of Zurich American Insurance have pleaded guilty to criminal charges related to bid-rigging that investigators say was organized by a unit of Marsh & McLennan.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch Bias Case Is Settled
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, one of the nation's trendiest retailers, settled race and sex discrimination lawsuits yesterday, agreeing to alter its well-known collegiate, all-American -- and largely white -- image by adding more blacks, Hispanics and Asians to its marketing materials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATSON, OLIVE CAWLEY
description: WATSON--Olive Cawley, at the age of 86, passed away peacefully in her home on November 13, 2004 in Greenwich, CT, surrounded by her family. She was the wife of the late Thomas J. Watson, Jr., former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of IBM and an ambassador to the Soviet Union during the Carter administration. She will be deeply missed by her children: Thomas J. Watson, III, Jeannette Sanger, Olive F. Watson, Lucinda Watson, Susan Watson and Helen Blodgett; her grandchildren: Katherine Watson Shiatis, Thomas William Watson and Bonnie Watson Underwood; Ralph Watson McElvenny and Andrew and Matthew Sanger; Wiley and Flynn Grover/Watson; Christina Kew and Annabel and Alexander Mehran; Blake, Skye and Lily Whitman; and Oliver, Natasha, Whitney and Cosimo Blodgett; and her greatgrandchild, William Watson Underwood. Born in New York, NY, she had a career as a successful model, appearing on the cover of Vogue and other magazines. She was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, and loved skiing and sailing. She supported many civic and charitable organizations during her life, including the Greenwich Hospital, the Watson Institute for International Studies at Brown University, the New York Botanical Garden, the YWCA International Council, the New York City Mission and the Montclair Kimberly School in New Jersey. Funeral services will be held on November 18 at 2 PM at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Rd., Greenwich, CT, with a reception to follow at the Round Hill Club, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Greenwich Hospital Bendheim Cancer Center, 5 Perryridge Rd., Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAILY, BARBARA KISSLING
description: DAILY--Barbara Kissling, of Rye, NY died on November 14, 2004 at Greenwich Hospital after a long and courageous battle with cancer. A loving wife, mother, a compassionate friend, and a steadfast competitor, she is survived by her husband, John; two children, Craig and Leigh; and daughter-in-law Happy. She also leaves her brother Lou Kissling of Scottsdale, AZ, her mother Janet Kissling of Hilton Head, SC, and her aunt Naomi Fortune of Rye, NY. She will be remembered for the unconditional love she gave her family and friends, her sense of humor and her joy of life. Barbara Daily was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 27, 1943 to Janet Paulson Kissling and Louis Leland Kissling. She gradauted from Monmouth College in 1965, met John Daily on a blind date in 1966, and they were married in Manhasset, NY on March 1, 1969. As a long-time resident of Rye, Barbara was actively involved in the Junior League, the Youth Counseling League, and the Rye Twig. She volunteered at United Hospital and was an enthusiastic participant in multiple sports and activities at the Apawamis Club. She will be greatly missed by all who loved her. In lieu of flowers, friends may make a donation to Integrative Cancer Care Research Foundation, 235 Glenville Rd, 3rd Fl, Greenwich, CT 06831. A memorial service will be held at Christ's Church in Rye, Saturday, November 20, 11:00 am.

title: Left or Right, a Place to Be Centered
description: WE often wind up associating restaurants with the life dramas and junctures they guided us through. I will always associate Devi with the 2004 presidential election. And I will always credit Devi with making the campaign seem less ugly than it was, with making it recede, if only for the duration of a plate of pyramid-shaped rice puffs, too golden, crunchy and airy to permit unpleasant thoughts.

title: MONSANTO UNIT BUYS A RIVAL SEED COMPANY, CHANNEL BIO
description: Monsanto, the seed and agricultural products company, said yesterday that a unit had acquired the seed company Channel Bio Corporation, for $120 million. Channel Bio, based in Kentland, Ind., has 2 percent of the United States corn seed market, Monsanto said. The purchase raised Monsanto's share of that market to 16 percent, a company spokeswoman, Lori Fisher, said. Monsanto said the acquisition was made by American Seeds, a holding company created by Monsanto to invest capital and genetics technology in regional seed companies. Monsanto is based in St. Louis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLSON, STEVENS G., JR.
description: NICHOLSON--Stevens G., Jr. Graduate of Columbia University Law School, practicing attorney in NYC, resident of New Rochelle for 38 years. In Chapel Hill, NC November 14, 73 years old. Beloved husband of Ruth, beloved father of Abbye, Sherry, Jeffrey, Andrew and Keith, beloved brother of Mary, George and Christopher, beloved grandfather of Jesse, Emily, Novella, Andrew and Gloria, beloved uncle, beloved friend to so many. He leaves us all with so many joyful memories. Memorial service on Sunday, November 21, 2 PM at Community Unitarian Church, White Plains, NY. Donations may be made to NYU Brain Injury Day Program send to Dr. Ben-Yishay, 660 First Ave, 3rd Flr, NYC 10016.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: In November 1979 DAVID and KAREN WALTUCK , left, were SoHo pioneers when they opened CHANTERELLE on Grand Street. Then, 10 years later, they packed up the French armoire and forged on down to TriBeCa, where Chanterelle is now, at 2 Harrison Street. For their 25th anniversary, the Waltucks commissioned ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG to design this fall's menu cover, in a tradition that began with CY TWOMBLY in 1980.

title: Congress Urged to Conduct Its Own Insurance Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, said Tuesday that his investigation into the insurance industry had revealed inadequate oversight by the states, and he urged Congress to begin its own inquiry.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Network Appliance Income Rises
description: Network Appliance, whose computers and software both store and distribute data for customers including the Vatican, said yesterday that second-quarter net income gained 14 percent on higher sales. The shares rose as much as 11 percent. Net income increased to $55.3 million, or 15 cents a share, from $48.4 million, or 13 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales in the quarter ended Oct. 29 rose 36 percent, to $375.2 million from $275.6 million. Sales have grown for 10 consecutive quarters as corporations and governments buy Network Appliance machines to store and back up data. Shares of Network Appliance, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose $2.37, or 9.5 percent, to $27.39 and earlier reached $27.68 in extended trading after results were announced. They fell 44 cents, to $25.02, in regular trading.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Cigarettes Seized At Airport
description: A cargo plane carrying 150,000 cartons of cigarettes suspected was detained at Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning by federal agents who said that many of the cartons were intended for illegal sale, a spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said. The operation was part of a crackdown on sales of untaxed cigarettes in the city and state, the spokesman, Joseph Green, said. After the seizure, officials said the cargo company was complying with the authorities and no charges were filed. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: For the ECB, a building to reflect Europe's rich tapestry
Appeals Court Reinstates Bear Hunt in New Jersey Next Month
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that New Jersey's environmental commissioner overstepped his authority by trying to block this year's planned bear hunt. It ordered him to issue hunting permits in time for the opening of a six-day bear season on Dec. 6.

title: Putin Tells Businesses to Get Used to Paying Taxes
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16 - President Vladimir V. Putin warned Russia's business elite on Tuesday to "get used to paying taxes and observing the law," but he also sought to allay investor fears that the Kremlin might be preparing new attacks on Russian business.

title: Jeep May Try to Revive Market for Smaller Trucks
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Nov. 16 - The Chrysler Group said Tuesday that it was considering building its first new Jeep pickup truck in more than a decade as part of a broader effort by automakers to rekindle interest in small to midsize pickups.

title: What's That Smell in the Park? It's Dinner
description: RYAN BECZE, a grill cook at Masa, was standing in Central Park, beneath a ginkgo tree at the edge of Strawberry Fields. The ground was covered with the rank flesh of fallen fruit. "I hope you wore shoes where the bottoms can be washed," he told me.

title: Condoleezza Rice
description: BORN Nov. 14, 1954, Birmingham, Ala.

title: For Palestinians, a Sense That Arafat's Era Left Them Empty-Handed
description: QALQILYA, West Bank, Nov. 14 - As a boy, Azzam al-Nasser loved his bicycle and soccer ball. But those are not the kind of toys he finds himself selling, with regret, from his small shop here.

title: Some Democrats Believe the Party Should Get Religion
description: Bested by a Republican campaign emphasizing Christian faith, some Democrats are scrambling to shake off their secular image, stepping up efforts to organize the "religious left" and debating changes to how they approach the cultural flashpoints of same-sex marriage and abortion.

description: Adapted from Tom Colicchio, Craftbar

title: Nuclear Deal With Iranians Has Angered Hard-Liners
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 16 - Iran's hard-line Parliament reacted angrily on Tuesday to a complex deal reached with Germany, France and Britain over the nation's nuclear activities.

title: Budget-Power Tug of War Is Waged for a Day in Court
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16 - It has been more than 75 years since Gov. Alfred E. Smith, the happy warrior, pushed for an amendment to the State Constitution that took budgeting power away from the Legislature and gave it to the governor.

title: Cabinet Choices Seen as Move for More Harmony and Control
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - President Bush has instructed his new national security team to end the running battles between the State and Defense departments and the Central Intelligence Agency, and intends to extend his personal control over agencies he has suspected of impeding his foreign policy aims, according to current and former administration officials.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the filming of "The War of the Worlds" in Bayonne, N.J., misstated the size of the film's budget. It is $128 million, a spokeswoman for Paramount Pictures said, not $200 million.

title: Bush Administration's Biblical Exodus
description: WASHINGTON - Lord knows I have tried, over the years, to keep Colin Powell on the grammatical strait and narrow. And yet, announcing his resignation, the departing secretary of state said that after the president and he had "fulsome discussions on it, we came to mutual agreement. "

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Oil supply I : The Arabs look to the East
Senior Democratic Senator Won't Block Confirmation of Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 - President Bush's nominee for attorney general, Alberto R. Gonzales, was all but guaranteed Senate confirmation today when a leading Democrat expressed fondness for the nominee and signaled that he would not stand in his way.

title: SBC in Deal With Microsoft to Provide TV on High-Speed Lines
description: SBC Communications, as part of its effort to compete head-on with the cable industry for television subscribers, plans to announce today that it will pay $400 million to Microsoft for software used to deliver TV programming over high-speed data lines.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Suffolk County: Officer Charged In Burglaries
description: The police officer who stood nearby the King Kullen grocery store, the Jiffy Lube and a bar and restaurant called Parsnips while each was burglarized was not on patrol, but actually working as the burglars' accomplice, Thomas Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney said yesterday. Raymond Montefusco, 36, a former Suffolk County police officer, was indicted in Riverhead yesterday on charges that he participated in three burglaries at the grocery in Bay Shore, the Jiffy Lube in St. James and the restaurant in Lake Ronkonkoma in 1999 and 2000, and other charges. If convicted, Mr. Montefusco, who allegedly served as a lookout for the burglars, could face up to seven years in prison for the burglary charge. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Mine Bid Deadline Passes
description: Canada's largest mining company, Noranda, said that its period of exclusive takeover negotiations with the China Minmetals Corporation had expired. While Noranda will continue to negotiate a possible sale to Minmetals, which is owned by the Chinese government, the company said that it was again open to other bids. The proposal prompted debate in Canada over allowing a foreign government to take control of a major natural resources company. Noranda is for sale because Brascan, which owns 42 percent of it, decided to shed businesses based on natural resources. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: The U.S. and Europe : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, RUTH G.
description: ADLER--Ruth G. On November 15, 2004, Ruth G. Adler of Bethesda, Md. and Lake Worth, Florida. Survived by husband Alexander, daughters Alison and Linda (Steven Fischer), and grandchildren Jonathan and Jocelyn Fischer. Funeral services Thursday, November 18, 1PM at Washington Hebrew Congretation, 3935 Macomb St., NW, Washington, D.C.

description: In percent

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fighter Jet Scrambled To Intercept U.S. Navy Plane
description: The Air Force said that a fighter jet was sent to intercept a United States Navy surveillance aircraft that was flying along the Black Sea coast of the Caucasus, just six miles from the Russian border. The American Orion aircraft failed to respond to inquiries from the ground, and after the Su-27 fighter was sent up, the Orion gained speed and altitude and flew away from the border, the Interfax news agency said. The Air Force said reconnaissance planes have been carrying out missions above Georgia and the Baltic states in the interests of NATO. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: What to Serve When Marshmallows Are Not Invited
description: WITH turkey my personal preference is for red wine, though a white with some body and richness would be welcome. But when it comes to first courses, side dishes, salads and such, the cook's task is to try to avoid the cloying food for which Thanksgiving is known. The wine, whatever it may be, should not be suffocated in a cloud of marshmallow.

title: Sears Turns to Kmart in Hopes of Regaining Past Glory
description: In the world of retailing, there is no such thing as "too big to fail," as investors have often learned to their sorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEMORE, ARNOLD
description: NEMORE -- Arnold. Passed away unexpectedly late October in Washington D.C. He was a well respected, nationally renowned independent healthcare consultant. He counted among his clients many physician groups, hospitals and health plans across the country. No immediate services are planned, however, at a later date, his friends from across the country will organize memorial services in his memory. Charitable contributions in his name should me made to the MakeA-Wish Foundation.

title: House Republicans Move to Protect Their Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Fresh from election gains, House Republicans moved Tuesday to consider a change in party rules that would prevent their majority leader, Tom DeLay, from having to step down from his leadership position should he be indicted in an investigation in Texas.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Detroit Schools Plan To Shrink More
description: The Detroit public school district plans to drop up to 4,000 jobs and close up to 40 of its 255 schools at the end of the school year to help eliminate a $198 million budget deficit, officials said Monday. The district had already reduced a projected $274 million shortfall by $76 million through other closings and reductions in jobs and spending. The district has lost more than 35,000 students since a high of 175,000 in 1996, costing the district $250 million in aid. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Velella's Lawyer Says Controversy Over Early Release Is Product of 'Political Forces'
description: In a 22-page letter filled with sometimes fiery language, the lawyer for former State Senator Guy J. Velella chastised a mayoral board for forcing Mr. Velella to reapply for his release from jail several weeks after he was set free, and accused Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of improperly injecting himself into the matter.

title: Steinbrenner and Martnez Meet: Let the Intrigue Begin
description: Pedro Martnez, who has reveled in his role as a villain to the Yankees while pitching and chirping for the Boston Red Sox, met with George Steinbrenner yesterday in Tampa, Fla., in a potential bid to dramatically change his status in the Bronx and in Boston.

title: Counting Continues Upstate for 435th Seat in Congress
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 16 - Two weeks after the presidential election was decided, the vote counting is continuing here in a race that was one of the most closely watched Congressional contests in the nation. The battle is over the seat held for six terms by Representative Jack Quinn, a Republican who decided not to seek re-election, and as workers pore over paper ballots, Democrats think they have a good chance of winning.

title: Conferees Resume Talks on Sept. 11 Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - House and Senate negotiators renewed talks on Tuesday on a long-stalled bill to enact the major recommendations of the Sept. 11 commission and create a cabinet-level job of national intelligence director. Congressional aides said a fresh White House lobbying effort had created some optimism that a bill could be worked out before Congress adjourned for the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, ALAN
description: KATZ--Alan. Beloved husband of Harriette. Devoted father of Andrea Eduard, Bruce, Cathy, Mili and Karen. Cherished grandfather of Lara, Alex, Evan and Amelia. Loving brother of David, Sue, Selma and Sherwin. A man of integrity and wisdom, he practiced law for 47 years in NYC. He lived a just life and was adored by all.

title: Life Is Getting Sweeter in Dumbo
description: At Almondine, a newcomer at 85 Water Street (Main Street) in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, Herv Poussot is turning out excellent croissants, fancy pastries, muffins, cookies and whole-grain breads, including some made with spelt flour. His approach combines French and American traditions. For Thanksgiving Mr. Poussot, the former pastry chef at Le Bernardin, is baking the usual threesome: apple, pecan and pumpkin pies ($18 for a 10-inch), but his small rustic apple tarts ($3.50) are also worthy of the holiday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARY, GUY
description: CARY--Guy. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society are saddened by the death of our long-time friend and generous benefactor. Guy Cary joined the Board of Trustees in 1968 and was named an Honorary Trustee in 1999. He served on many important committees and in particular was a highly valued and respected member of the Investment Committee; additionally, he was a key advisor on the CIRS Pension Benefits Plan. His wise counsel and dedication provided strong leadership for WCS. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. David T. Schiff, Chairman Steven E. Sanderson, President & CEO

title: Trying to Cross a Composing Chasm
description: Some soloists appear to suffer for their music, like prophets preaching painful but essential truths, but not Gil Shaham. He seems to realize that compared to the cubicled masses among us, musicians like himself have a pretty nice gig and why pretend otherwise.

title: Bush Makes It Official, Naming Rice to State Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Praising her for helping to guide him through a tumultuous first term, President Bush made official on Tuesday his nomination of Condoleezza Rice to succeed Colin L. Powell as secretary of state. The president said the world would see in Ms. Rice "the strength, the grace and the decency of our country."

title: Regulators Plan to Step Up Union Pacific Safety Checks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - The federal agency that regulates railroads is stepping up safety enforcement at the biggest railroad, Union Pacific, after a number of crashes and derailments that killed seven people in Texas and New Mexico over the last year, agency officials said Tuesday.

title: You Can Thank Asia for This Pie
description: NEARING Thanksgiving, as most pastry chefs ponder the annual what-to-do-with-a-pumpkin quandary and wax nostalgic about pies past, Pichet Ong, the pastry chef at Spice Market and 66, contemplates kabocha squash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWENTHAL, ANNE
description: LOWENTHAL--Anne. On November 13th, at 89. Dearly loved by family and friends. Memorial service on Friday, 11:30AM, Park Slope Jewish Center, 1320 8th Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Bush's Tutor and Disciple - Condoleezza Rice
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - President Bush introduced her in the Roosevelt Room on Tuesday as "America's face to the world," already known to most Americans and much of the globe. But mysteries remain about Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser nominated to be secretary of state in a second term that some administration officials assert will be characterized more by diplomacy than confrontation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'DONNELL, J. LEONARD
description: O'DONNELL--J. Leonard. On November 14, 2004. Beloved husband of Lillian. Mr. O'Donnell was a past treasurer of The American Stock Exchange, a member of The West Side Tennis Club for 50 years, a member The Seventh Regiment Tennis Club, council member of St. Vincent Ferrer Church and WWII Veteran. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday 7-9PM and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Thursday 11AM. Interment to follow at Maple Grove Cemetery. O'DONNELL -- J. Leonard. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Viruses Infect Computers In 150 Schools

ABC continues to have no luck at 8 p.m.; "Life of Luxury" was down from its already paltry premiere numbers last week. But at 9 p.m. the network's "Monday Night Football" drew an audience of 16.08 million to watch the lopsided victory of the Philadelphia Eagles over the Dallas Cowboys; that number is on the high end for the game. Paid Notice: Deaths   FERRER, M. IRENE
description: FERRER--M. Irene. The Columbia University Medical Center community mourns the loss of one of its cardiology pioneers, Irene M. Ferrer, professor emeritus of clinical medicine. Dr. Ferrer was a graduate of and long-time faculty member at the College of Physicians & Surgeons (P&S). After graduating from P&S in 1941, she completed her internship at Columbia's Bellevue Hospital division and was the first woman to serve as chief resident in medicine there. As a faculty member, she worked with the Nobel Prize winning team that developed the cardiac catheter. She used the catheter to define the mechanism of action of several important cardiac medications, including digitalis, and outlined the pathophysiology of cardiac disease. During her 33 years as director of Presbyterian Hospital's electrocardiographic lab, she worked with IBM to develop the first software for the computer interpretation of the electrocardiogram. Influential in her field beyond Columbia, she had been editor in chief of Current Cardiology and the Journal of the American Medical Women's Association. Her legacy continues through the M. Irene Ferrer Professorship in Gender Specific Medicine at Columbia. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President, Columbia University Medical Center Dean, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Motorola To Acquire MeshNetworks
description: Motorola plans to buy MeshNetworks to gain technology that bolsters wireless connections for data, video, Internet-based telephone and other services. Terms were not disclosed. Through its investment arm, Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., already owns an unspecified stake in the closely held MeshNetworks. MeshNetworks now sells its technology to police and other agencies, providing far-reaching wireless communications that work even if part of a network breaks down. Motorola said the purchase might allow it to enhance cellphone service and wireless entertainment systems. "If you have bad coverage on your cellphone, this can allow you to connect through someone else's phone who happens to be near you," Juergen Stark, vice president for commercial government business at Motorola, said in an interview. The purchase is expected to be completed next month.

title: Sidney Goldring, Advocate for Brain Procedure, Dies at 81
description: Dr. Sidney Goldring, a neurosurgeon and educator who was an early advocate for a brain operation that he helped to develop for patients with severe epilepsy, died on Nov. 3 at a nursing home in Chesterfield, Mo. He was 81.

title: Syracuse Barbecue Goes South
description: BY 7 p.m. on a recent evening at Dinosaur Bar-B-Que in Syracuse, the waiting list was more than five pages long.

title: Enron Inquiry Turns to Sales by Lay's Wife
description: Federal prosecutors are investigating whether the wife of Enron's former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, engaged in insider trading in a sale of company stock shortly before it collapsed into bankruptcy, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Revlon Decides to Put Its Account in Review
description: Revlon yesterday unexpectedly placed in review its account, which has been handled by Deutsch in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, since 2001. Spending was estimated at $120 million.

New Nuclear Weapon to Surpass Others, Putin Says
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 17 - President Vladimir V. Putin, meeting with Russia's defense officials and military commanders here, said today that the country would soon deploy new nuclear missile systems that would surpass those of any other nuclear power.

title: Boston Scientific Will Invest in Developer of a Plastic Stent
description: Boston Scientific, the leading supplier of metal devices known as stents that hold blood vessels open, said yesterday that it would invest in Reva Medical, a private start-up company, and help develop its novel plastic stent. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Turkey Has Left The Building
description: OVER the last 30 years I've cooked turkey using just about every technique contrived by human ingenuity, from baked with sliced truffles under the skin (a remembrance of my cooking school days in Paris) to roasted under a veil of butter-soaked cheesecloth (in the manner of Julia Child). I've braised turkeys, deep-fried them and roasted them upright on an open can of beer (a very large can manufactured by Foster's). I even once cooked a turkey under a metal trash can (a clean new can of course): a sort of outdoor oven dreamed up by a seasoned out-of-the-box thinker, the leader of a Boy Scout troop.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a proposed $1.47 billion budget for Westchester County misstated its source of revenue. It would be financed by existing taxes at current rates; it includes no new taxes or tax increases.

description: Money talks, in any currency, in any language, in any business, including a locked-out National Hockey League.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISL, BARBARA BUTLER
description: WEISL--Barbara Butler. On November 14 suddenly after a short illness. Beloved wife of Edwin L. Weisl Jr. Loving stepmother of Angela Jane Weisl. Fond sister of Rowene Oltorf. Also cherished by nieces and nephews. Funeral services Thursday, 12:15pm at Church of the Resurrection, 119 East 74 St. WEISL--Barbara Butler. My closest and most cherished friend. I miss her terribly. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Barbara's loving husband Edwin and their families. Dede and Irwin Levinson

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 6 Years For Teenager In Train Bombings
description: In the first trial related to the March 11 train bombings in Madrid, a teenager pleaded guilty to helping to provide the explosives used in the attacks and was sentenced to six years in a juvenile detention center. The defendant, 16, is a Spaniard who has been identified just by his initials, G.M.V. Prosecutors said he knowingly delivered a backpack filled with dynamite from the northern region of Asturias to Madrid, where he gave it to the suspected leader of the group that carried out the train attacks, which killed 191 people. Eighteen other suspects, mostly Moroccans, have also been charged in the case. Dates have not yet been set for other trials. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Executives Resign
description: Three executives at Aer Lingus, including the popular chief executive, Willie Walsh will leave the government-owned Irish airline next May. Mr. Walsh, left, was joined by Seamus Kearney, the chief operating officer, and Brian Dunne, the chief financial officer. The men did not disclose their future plans. They leave Aer Lingus in a healthy financial position -- it has forecast a profit of more than 100 million euros ($130 million) this year -- but with a lack of top-level management. The Irish government has been considering how to sell Aer Lingus, but rejected a proposal for a management buyout by the three executives last summer. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: What Becomes a Turkey Most
description: IT may have been a few weeks early, but the Dining section's tasting panel gathered recently for Thanksgiving dinner, complete with turkey, sweet potatoes and all the traditional components. In a novel but fitting division of labor, we all brought the wine.

title: Manslaughter in Stabbing of Bouncer in Nightclub
description: A computer administrator from Queens was convicted yesterday of first-degree manslaughter for fatally stabbing a nightclub bouncer last year during an argument that began over a lighted cigarette, a case that focused attention on the city's broad new smoking ban.

description: The chairman of the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch, may be telling investors and the media that his relationship with his counterpart at Liberty Media, John C. Malone, is friendly, as he did yesterday at an annual meeting.

description: LONDON, Nov. 16 - By time-hallowed tradition, the English pub evokes an image of low beams, warm ales and the toxic swirling smog of tobacco smoke. But not, perhaps, for much longer.

title: Keeping It Cool In a Hot Kitchen
description: Making a flaky pie crust or tart shell is easier when the dough is rolled on a cool surface. That's why professionals and some home cooks install marble slabs. Now there is a pastry board, the Big Chill by Kuhn Rikon, that comes apart so frozen gel inserts can be placed in the bottom half. Replace the top, and you have a board that stays cool for nearly two hours. It's not only useful at this time of year, when kitchens are often toasty, but on a hot summer day, when a fresh peach pie tempts. The board is big enough for a 12-inch round of dough and has a slightly pebbled surface that inhibits sticking. It's $30 at Zabar's and from www.cooking.com.

title: Aides Say Senator Clinton Seeks 2nd Term
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has decided to run for a second term in the Senate in 2006, despite arguments by some Democrats that such a move could complicate her potential bid for the presidency in 2008, her advisers said on Tuesday.

title: Pomegranate as Fruit Of a Vintner's Labor
description: Pomegranate wine from Armenia has plenty of peppery tartness and a sweet fruitiness that enriches the naturally winy taste of pomegranate. It would pair well with a Thanksgiving turkey, venison or chocolate desserts, or make an alluring punch base. Some bartenders mix it with sparkling wine, gin or tequila. Labeled simply Pomegranate, it's about $10 a bottle in the Wine Store at Whole Foods; Grand Wine & Liquor, 3005 31st Avenue, Astoria, Queens; and Heights Chateau, 123 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street), Brooklyn Heights.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Recall For Exercise Machines
description: The company that makes Bowflex fitness machines, the Nautilus Group of Vancouver, Wash., has recalled 800,000 of them because of mechanical problems, federal officials said. About 680,000 Bowflex Power Pro and 102,000 Bowflex Ultimate Fitness machines with faulty seats and backboard benches are involved, the company said. The machines were sold at fitness stores and through direct mail and television advertisements beginning in 1995. John Files (NYT)

description: Two of the largest institutional shareholders of PeopleSoft are taking opposite positions on Oracle's latest takeover bid, indicating that the battle for control of the company is still far from over.

title: MetroStars' Goalies Up for Grabs
description: The MetroStars have left both of their goalkeepers -- Jonny Walker, who started 28 games last season, and Zach Wells, the 21st player picked in last year's college draft -- unprotected for Friday's Major League Soccer expansion draft. The 10-round draft will stock the league's two new teams, CD Chivas USA and Real Salt Lake, which begin play next season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EBERHART, PAMELA S.
description: EBERHART--Pamela S. 59, of Greenwich, CT, died Monday after a lengthy illness. Born June 30, 1945 in Bethlehem, PA, Mrs. Eberhart was the daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. James L. Shearer of Bethlehem, PA. She was the wife of the late Mr. Walter M. Eberhart, Jr. She is survived by her two daughters Julie Eberhart and Caroline Eberhart Grubb, a granddaughter, two sisters, four nieces and four nephews. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on Friday at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWAB, BETTY B.
description: SCHWAB--Betty B. 78, passed away peacefully November 13, after a five-year, courageous battle with ovarian cancer. Beloved wife of Martin for 55 years. Adored mother of Jeffrey and Magdi, Sally and Sam Honig, Steven and Susan, sister of Elizabeth and Richard Fuld. Devoted grandmother of Jay, Katie, Julie, Adam, Alex and step-grandchildren Szonja and Krista. We will miss you, Mom. Services Wednesday, November 17, at 11 am, at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to charity of choice. SCHWAB -- Betty B. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Nathan Miller Center for Nursing Care extend our condolences to our longtime Board Member, Martin Schwab and family on the death of his wife Betty.

description: In London one of the National Theater's most ambitious projects, a six-hour adaptation of the Philip Pullman fantasy trilogy "His Dark Materials" (right) is being revived in a reworked version and with a mostly new cast after a sold-out run last year. Previews start on Saturday, and the show runs through April 2. Nicholas Wright, who wrote the stage adaptation, has revised the six-hour play, which is performed in two parts. Nicholas Hytner, the National Theater's artistic director and the director of "His Dark Materials," said, "We brought it back because so many people who wanted to see it didn't get to." PAM KENT

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Troop Pullout Begins
description: India began reducing its troops in the disputed territory of Kashmir today, army officials said. The reduction -- the first declared cutback since an anti-Indian insurgency began in 1989 -- coincides with the start of a visit by the prime minister, Manmohan Singh, his first since taking office in May. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Final Step for Kyoto Pact to Take Place at U.N.
description: United Nations officials said that the final step leading to the enactment of the Kyoto Protocol, the first treaty restricting heat-trapping pollution linked to global warming, is scheduled to take place Thursday, when Russian officials deliver ratification papers signed by President Vladimir V. Putin to United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan. The handoff will take place at a special meeting of the United Nations Security Council in Nairobi exploring the conflict in Sudan. After President Bush rejected the climate treaty in 2001, the only way for it to gain sufficient support to take force was with Russian participation. Only four industrialized countries have not ratified it: the United States, Australia, Liechtenstein and Monaco.

Moments later, her movement is observed by Alan Bragg, the local police chief, standing in a windowless control room more than a mile away.

Jerry Ciauri was sentenced for involvement with the Colombo crime family. Sean Johnson alone served time for drug possession, bail jumping and forgery.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No Choosing Alphabets
description: The Constitutional Court ruled against the semiautonomous republic of Tatarstan, which had been seeking to legitimize the use of the Latin alphabet to convey the sounds of Tatar, a Turkic language. Ethnic Russians are outnumbered by Tatars in the Volga River republic, which switched from the Latin alphabet to Arabic script in 1927 before being forced to adopt Cyrillic letters in 1939 as part of Stalin's Russification campaign. Tatarstan passed a law in 2000 readopting the Latin alphabet, but a 2002 federal law called for the nationwide use of Cyrillic. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Drug Dispute Snags U.S.-Australia Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - Nine months ago, the United States and Australia completed negotiations on a landmark trade agreement that won unusually broad bipartisan support in Congress. But a dispute over drugs, both prescription and generic, is threatening to delay the effective date of Jan. 1.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Bad Education' = NC-17
description: "Bad Education," the new film by Pedro Almodvar, right, about two young boys who meet and fall in love in Franco-era Spain in the 1960's and are subject to abuse by a priest at school, has been given an NC-17 rating (no one 17 and under admitted), the Motion Picture Association of America announced yesterday. The two-second scene that elicited the rating appears early in the film and involves the head movements of a transvestite, played by Gael Garca Bernal, while performing oral sex. A publicist for "Bad Education," Jessica Uzzan, said that the director and producers had been alerted early on that this was an issue and argued it with the M.P.A.A. but that they had never considered cutting the scene. "It's a film for adults," Ms. Uzzan said. "Bad Education," loosely based on Mr. Almodvar's upbringing and life, is to open in three theaters in New York on Friday and in Los Angeles on Dec. 10. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: COMMUNITY BANKS TO BUY PENNROCK FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: Community Banks, a bank holding company, agreed yesterday to buy PennRock Financial Services Corporation for about $326 million in stock. The acquisition will allow Community to add branches in south-central Pennsylvania. Community will exchange 1.4 shares of its stock for each share of PennRock, valued at $44.06 a share, a 49 percent premium based on Monday's closing price. The combined company will have assets exceeding $3 billion. Community, based in Harrisburg, Pa., has 50 branches. PennRock is the parent of Blue Ball National Bank, which has 17 branches. It is based in Blue Ball, Pa.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pension Benefits For Some Same-Sex Partners
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would seek to extend pension benefits to same-sex partners of city workers who are wed in Vermont and other places where gay marriage is performed. Domestic partners, who have been granted other benefits that the city offers its employees, do not qualify for pension benefits, because a change in the state law is needed for the city to extend them. Mr. Bloomberg said in a written statement that he would support state legislation that would create that change. "All of our city employees deserve to be treated equally, regardless of the sexual orientation, and I hope these measures will ensure that they are." Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Research In Motion Reports Subscriber Growth
description: Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry e-mail pager, said yesterday that the number of subscribers who use its e-mail system had increased 21 percent since Aug. 30. The BlackBerry was introduced in 1999 in North America and it is now offered on more than 70 wireless networks in 30 countries in Europe, the Asia-Pacific region and Latin America, according to the company, which is based in Waterloo, Ontario. Research in Motion said on Sept. 30 that it had 1.66 million subscribers at the end of August. To expand that base, it is making deals that let it offer e-mail services on devices sold by competing mobile phone makers. Shares rose $5.51, or 6.7 percent, to $87.34. The company had one million subscribers in February.

title: ENBRIDGE TO ACQUIRE SHELL UNIT FOR $613 MILLION
description: Enbridge, a Canadian pipeline company, agreed yesterday to buy Shell Gas Transmission for $613 million to gain pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico. Enbridge, based in Calgary, Alberta, said the purchase would provide it with stakes in pipelines that carry about half the deepwater gas production in the gulf. Shell Gas, a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, owns or has an interest in 11 pipelines with capacity of about 4.7 billion cubic feet of gas a day, the companies said. Enbridge said the pipelines would increase 2005 profit by as much as 0.14 Canadian dollar (12 cents) a share.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cisco To Acquire Jahi For $16 Million
description: Cisco Systems signed an agreement yesterday to acquire the network management start-up company Jahi Networks for $16 million. Jahi, a privately held company based in San Jose, Calif., develops interfaces that help networked devices communicate with each other more efficiently. "A major challenge in providing network management applications is the lack of consistent means of communicating with the variety of devices that comprise an end-to-end network," Cliff Meltzer, Cisco's senior vice president, said in a statement. Jahi's technology provides a virtual view of devices connected in a network. This overview reduces complexity and cuts down on overall costs, Cisco said. Customers writing their own scripts and applications can use Jahi's technology to interact with various Cisco products in the network. Cisco says it hopes to complete the acquisition of Jahi in the second quarter of 2005. Jahi was founded in 2003 and has 20 employees in San Jose and Hyderabad, India.

title: To Get Ahead, Own the Store
description: Hispanic women are opening businesses at a rate far higher than the national average, a new study shows. To Tina Cordova, a Hispanic entrepreneur, the reason is obvious: economic desperation. While white women in the work force make about 77 cents to every dollar earned by white men, according to data from the 2000 census, Hispanic women are paid 53 cents.

title: Fighting for Gay Rights in Full Cry
description: AT Councilwoman Christine C. Quinn's homey, rent-stabilized Chelsea apartment, the threshold bears a New York Yankees doormat. The television is tuned to Lifetime, the often-weepy network for women. The family dog, Sadie, a mutt with two doting human mommies and no daddy, wears her political heart on her sleeve: a Kerry bandanna and a button that reads, cheekily, "I Pee on Bushes." Who says partisan politics has to be humorless? Or confined to people? Not Ms. Quinn, bustling out to the kitchen in high heels to grab a diet soda for herself and a restock of kibble for Sadie, who is claiming a prime corner of the sofa.

title: Conferees Pass Compromise for 6.5 Million Special Education Pupils
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 - A House-Senate conference committee gave near unanimous approval to major changes in the law that governs special education for 6.5 million disabled students, charting new ways for schools to identify children for extra help more swiftly, reduce legal challenges by dissatisfied parents and make it easier for schools to remove disruptive students whose misbehavior is not caused by their disability.

title: India's Offer for Peace Talks on Kashmir Is Sweetened With Aid
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Nov. 17 - India's prime minister, Manmohan Singh, came to Kashmir on Wednesday offering unconditional talks with anyone willing to renounce violence and a $5.3 billion economic package intended to "win the hearts and minds" of residents of the insurgency-ravaged territory.

title: A Computer Draws, a Laser Cuts And Women Get Frayless Designs
description: In October, the MAK Center, the Los Angeles arm of the Austrian Museum of Applied Arts, presented Showdown, a fashion show featuring designs by artists, architects and fashion designers, at the center, a house designed by Rudolf Schindler. One of the sensations of the evening was a collection of dresses by Elena Manferdini, an Italian-born, Los Angeles-based engineer and architect who has designed products for Alessi and Guzzini and has worked with the architect Greg Lynn. The dresses were modeled after butterflies and were designed entirely by computer; they feature laser-cut patterns, inset and below. The fabrics, cotton-polyester and silk-polyester blends, do not fray when cut because the heat of the laser melts the polyester, sealing the cut edges. Available wholesale from www.ateliermanferdini.com (from $250 to $1,000) and, in December, retail, from Mameg in Los Angeles, (310) 826-4142.

World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Shrinks
description: Singapore's econ-omy shrank at a 3 percent annual pace in the third quarter, more than initially estimated, as waning demand for computer chips and printers slowed growth in manufacturing. Exports resumed growth in October. The contraction in gross domestic product in the quarter, which ended Sept. 30, compares with the seasonally adjusted 2.3 percent pace of decline reported by the government on Oct. 11 and growth of 11.9 percent in the second quarter, the trade ministry said.

title: EASTMAN KODAK TO ELIMINATE 500 JOBS IN BRITAIN
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would cut 500 jobs in Britain because of declining demand for conventional film processing. Five overnight photo-finishing labs and a head office and call center in Britain will be closed by October 2005, Kodak said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said it would have $16 million in cash costs, including $10 million in severance pay, for closing the sites, and $27 million in noncash expenses. Kodak announced a three-year plan in January to cut 12,000 to 15,000 jobs to cope with falling demand for conventional film. The company, based in Rochester, said it expected film sales to fall about 20 percent worldwide in 2005.

title: Arts, Briefly; Runnicles Flip-Flops
description: It seems that the well-regarded conductor Donald Runnicles, below, can live with President Bush, after all. After being quoted by an Austrian newspaper in August to the effect that he might have to leave the United States if the president won re-election, Mr. Runnicles has agreed to a three-year extension of his contract as music director of the San Francisco Opera. The contract was to have ended in 2006. Mr. Runnicles told the newspaper, Der Standard: "I would really have to think about whether I could stay there if Bush wins a second time. The American public can be wrong once, but if they re-elect him, that means they really want him." The remarks caused a ruckus in Georgia, where Mr. Runnicles is principal guest conductor of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra distanced itself from his words, and the Scottish-born Mr. Runnicles, who lives in San Francisco, apologized. Through a spokesman at the opera, Mr. Runnicles said he had no further comment. The remarks have apparently had little effect on his reputation in California, where the San Francisco Opera presented a 50th-birthday concert and gala for him on Tuesday night. He was presented with the insignia of an Officer of the Order of the British Empire, granted by Queen Elizabeth II in June. Mr. Runnicles is also principal conductor of the Orchestra of St. Luke's. DANIEL J. WAKIN

The group's interests run from medieval church music to contemporary scores, although the trio devoted its program this time entirely to 13th-century sacred works.
