title: Arts, Briefly; Having Sung, Wemba Walks
description: The Congolese-born singer Papa Wemba, below, known as the King of Rhumba Rock, has been sentenced by a criminal court in Bobigny, a Paris suburb, to 30 months in jail and a $13,000 fine. But 26 months were suspended, and because he spent four months in jail after his arrest in February 2003, Papa Wemba will serve no more time. He admitted last month that he had taken part in a plot to smuggle hundreds of Africans into France using his band, Viva la Musica, as cover. But he argued that he had played only a small role in the smuggling ring, which secured visas for Africans claiming membership in his band, and was unaware of all that was happening. In December 2001, the French police grew suspicious when 90 Congolese claiming to be part of Papa Wemba's group arrived in Paris without instruments or stage costumes. CAROLE CORM

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Sales Rise
description: Retail sales in Brazil rose in August for the 10th consecutive month, climbing a better-than-expected 8.9 percent from the year-earlier period, the government's statistics agency said. Sales of big-ticket items like furniture and home appliances continued to lead the surge, jumping 20 percent in September from a year ago. Over all, retail sales are up 9.3 percent so far this year, bolstered by an upswing in consumer confidence now that Brazil's economy is growing at its fastest rate since 1996. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Race' Wins Ratings Sprint
description: CBS won Tuesday night's ratings match by a smidgen, but according to the Nielsen overnight numbers, NBC came in first among the 18-to-49-year-old audience, which advertisers value most. CBS's two-hour premiere of "The Amazing Race" established a good villain immediately by focusing on the screaming Jonathan, and drew 11.8 million viewers, bettering its summer-episodes norm by more than a million. From 8 to 9:30 p.m., NBC's "Biggest Loser," the weight-loss reality show, featured tempting cupcakes and back-stabbing, drawing 10.55 million people, its biggest audience yet. Interestingly, for the second week in a row, the last 30 minutes of "The Biggest Loser" had a ratings spike, indicating that some viewers tune in only to watch the weigh-in and subsequent elimination. UPN's broadcast of "The Vibe Awards" nearly doubled what the network does on a regular Tuesday with "All of Us," "Eve" and "Veronica Mars." But any curiosity seekers who watched the show to see the stabbing and melee that preceded the hip-hop artist Dr. Dre's receiving an award was disappointed, as the violent interruption was edited out of the program. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORMAN, JUDITH
description: CORMAN--Judith. The directors, staff, and residents of Phoenix House mourn the loss of a dear friend and colleague. Judy Corman was an officer of Phoenix House, who started and ran our volunteer program and headed our national communications department. She believed passionately in our mission and relished her work with young people struggling to start new lives. She went on to pursue a brilliant career in public relations but remained forever devoted to Phoenix House and her friends here. Loyalty was Judy's strong suit, for she would do anything for a friend. We will miss her--her wit, her humor, and her good sense. Edward D. Miller, Chairman Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D., President Kevin E. McEneaney, Executive Vice President

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Bombs Rock 3 Banks
description: A security guard was killed and a bomb squad officer was injured when homemade bombs exploded at three banks in Buenos Aires, the capital, including two Citibank branches owned by Citigroup, the American financial services giant. The police said it was not immediately clear who was responsible for the attacks, which also singled out an Argentine bank, Banco Galicia. Several banks in Buenos Aires, mostly foreign-owned, have been hit by small bombs in recent years, but no one has claimed responsibility for any of the explosions. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Sainsbury Posts Its First Loss and Arms Against a Takeover
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 - Once ranked as Britain's leading supermarket chain, J Sainsbury posted a net loss on Wednesday, the first since it was founded 135 years ago, and said it had talked to the banker Morgan Stanley about warding off potential takeover moves.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Bush Won State By 10,059 Votes
description: President Bush defeated Senator John Kerry in Iowa by 10,059 votes, less than one percent of the 1.5 million votes cast, according to unofficial election results released by the secretary of state. The count, less than the roughly 14,000 cited earlier, will remain unofficial until certified Nov. 29. The secretary of state, Chet Culver, said more state residents voted this year than ever before, and 191,344 more people voted than in 2000. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Showing Their Resolve, Rebels Mount Attacks in Northern and Central Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 17 - Ambushes and bomb attacks jolted central and northern Iraq on Wednesday as insurgents pressed a campaign against American and Iraqi forces after the American-led offensive that left swaths of Falluja in ruins.

title: Politics and the C.I.A.
description: When President Bush rushed to appoint Porter Goss, a partisan Florida congressman, as director of central intelligence before the election, the choice raised concerns about how serious Mr. Bush was about fixing one of the central problems with American intelligence: that the president was being told what he wanted to hear to confirm his policy choices, rather than what he needed to know. Now that Mr. Bush has been safely re-elected, Mr. Goss is only heightening those fears.

title: Lame Duck Confit
description: Having let the people's business stew for nearly a year, Congress is back in session this week, pledging to complete what the Republican leadership deemed too politically fraught to handle before the election. With time expiring, the lawmakers must raise the federal debt limit -- the Senate approved an $800 billion increase yesterday, and the House is expected to follow suit today. The move will allow the government to borrow up to $8.2 trillion. Congress must also pass nine overdue spending bills totaling $355 billion.

Highlights of its feature list: zero start-up time, near-zero shutter lag, three-shots-a-second burst mode and a long-life battery. It isn't cheap ($1,000, not including a lens; nikonusa.com), but cameras of this caliber cost $25,000 only four years ago. CNET Review: Nikon D70 Check PricesREADY, STEADY, GOImprovements in zoom lenses mean many photographers can use a single lens in nearly any situation. But at telephoto settings, zooms can produce blurry photos. The Canon EF 28-to-135-millimeter I.S. zoom lens ($480; canonusa.com) uses electronics to overcome the problem. Sensors in the lens trigger motors that counteract shake. The lens, available online, is compatible with Canon single-lens-reflex cameras. All Canon ProductsVIDEO VERSATILITYNo larger than an iPod and weighing only 4.2 ounces, the Panasonic D-snap (more specifically, the SV-AV50) retains many of the features of bigger camcorders. The D-snap records in television-quality MPEG-4 at 30 frames a second. The camcorder ($400; www.panasonic.com/d-snap) is also a two-megapixel still camera, an MP3 music player and a voice recorder. All Home Video ProductsSHOWOFFThe Epson P-2000 gives photographers an easily portable 40-gigabyte hard drive for offloading images from a camera or card. But its small, bright liquid-crystal display also displays photos with the quality of a good computer monitor. The $500 unit (www.epson.com) has built-in readers for Compact Flash and Secure Digital cards. It can also be used as an MP3 song player for times when the photos don't tell the whole story. All Digital Camera ReviewsSPOT ONHere's a midrange camcorder (about $520; www.sonystyle.com) with a lot to like. When focusing manually, for example, you turn a ring on the lens, rather than fussing with a menu or a button. The flip-out screen, at 3.5 inches, is the largest available, which makes reviewing video more pleasant. It's also a touch screen, which you use for some advanced controls (a design that can be a blessing and a curse). As long as the light is good, the captured video is bright, colorful and sharp. All Camcorder ReviewsQUICK DRAWIf your digital camera's shutter lag has condemned you to missing photos of pet tricks and soccer goals, you need one built for speed, like this un-aerodynamic but rewarding camera, the EX-P600 Exilim ($550; www.casio.com). It's ready to shoot in three seconds, which includes the time it takes to extend its 4x zoom lens. And the autofocus and shutter-lag times are as close to zero as you'll find in a digital camera under $1,000. All Casio Exilim ProductsSNAPSHOTS NOWA ritual after some family gatherings is the printing and mailing of digital snapshots. The Hewlett-Packard Photosmart 375 printer (www.hp.com), however, can go along to the party. When closed for travel, the $200 inkjet printer looks like a small toaster. Opened, it produces borderless 4-by-6-inch prints. PictBridge-compatible cameras can be plugged into the printer using a U.S.B. cable. A liquid-crystal display allows users to preview images. All HP Photosmart PrintersCOPY SHOPWith that new DVD recorder on the home entertainment shelf next to the old VCR, wouldn't it be fun to turn your musty videotapes into DVD's? Just connect the Sima GoDVD ($150; simacorp.com) between the two machines to dub enhanced stabilized video to disc.  CNET Review: Go Video R6640  Check PricesMEGA MEGAPIXELSKodak's Pro SLR/n (for Nikon lenses and accessories) and its cousin, the Pro SLR/c (for Canon users), have been designed so their image sensors and electronics can be updated. But their 14-megapixel imaging sensors won't be needing an overhaul soon. Kodak (www.kodak.com) estimates that the sensors produce images that are superior to its best color films. Since the Pro SLR is $5,000 without a lens, it's just as well that they won't become instantly obsolete. All Kodak Cameras

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Global-Warming Pact On Its Way To Annan
description: United Nations officials said that the final step leading to the enactment of the Kyoto Protocol, the first treaty restricting heat-trapping pollution linked to global warming, would take place today in Nairobi, the capital, where Russian officials are to deliver ratification papers signed by President Vladimir V. Putin to Secretary General Kofi Annan. The handoff will take place at a special two-day meeting there of the Security Council on the conflicts in Sudan. After President Bush rejected the climate treaty in 2001, the only way for it to gain sufficient support to take force was with Russian participation. Only four developed states have not ratified it: the United States, Australia, Liechtenstein and Monaco. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: The Right Tools To Keep You Untethered
description: <!--.anchor { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 13px; color: #333333}.title { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 18px; line-height: 25px; color: #333333}.subhead { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; color: #333333}--> function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } On the Road, Small Is Better (and Often Just as Powerful)HANDS ON If ever a palmtop could tempt you to leave your laptop behind, this would be it. The iPac H4155 has 56 megabytes of free memory, a 400-megahertz processor, Bluetooth for connecting to laptops and cellphones, Wi-Fi for hopping onto Internet hot spots, and a bright screen. There aren't as many programs available for the PocketPC operating system as there are for the Palm OS, but this $450 beauty () is a sweet option if you're in a Microsoft state of mind.FORM AND FUNCTION Logitech's V500 Cordless Notebook Mouse not only makes an artful statement, but speaks volumes about clever engineering. The $70 optical mouse (www.logitech.com) links to a laptop through a small receiver that plugs into a U.S.B. port. When not in use, the receiver stows neatly inside the mouse.The V500 runs on two AAA batteries and features a four-way scroll panel rather than a typical scroll wheel.MEMORABLE PalmOne's latest palmtop lacks a voice recorder, vibrating alarm and Wi-Fi for wireless Internet, but it does something no other palmtop can do: when connected to a Mac or PC by a U.S.B. cable, the T5 ($400) becomes a 160-megabyte flash drive to transfer any kind of file. The bright, crisp screen has the highest resolution of any palmtop, and you can rotate it 90 degrees to read spreadsheets and Web pages.SHARP STORAGE The SwissMemory U.S.B. has the familiar blade, nail file, screwdriver and tiny scissors you would expect in a Swiss Army knife, but it also has a 128-megabyte U.S.B. flash storage drive. More information on the SwissMemory, which has a list price of $82, is at www.victorinox.com. For air travel, the flash drive is detachable so the knife itself can be stowed in a checked bag.CELL CINEMA Why settle for plain old pictures on your wireless phone when you can get them up and moving? With LG's VX7000 phone, you can take 15-second videos and send them to your friends. The phone ($200 at www.verizonwireless.com) has four megabytes of storage space for games, ringtones and other goodies.COOL RUNNING Turning the 12-volt DC power from a car's auxiliary outlet into 120-volt AC for a laptop or cellphone charger usually involves a bulky metal box. Most of that bulk is there to draw off heat from the electronic components. The $45 Xantrex XPower Micro Inverter 175 (www.xantrex.com) uses a tiny cooling fan, making it small enough to plug directly into most car outlets.THUMB CANDY The BlackBerry is a hit with white-collar types. But why should corporate America have all the fun? This new model, offered by T-Mobile, is designed and priced for consumers ($200; www.t-mobile.com). It offers the same real-time e-mail features but looks more like a conventional phone. A complete alphabet is on just 20 roomy keys. You can watch the bright screen as the smart software deduces the word you're trying to type and finishes it for you.NO STRINGS The thumb-size Air Station 54 Mbps wireless adapter from Buffalo Technology brings Wi-Fi connectivity to PC's and laptops, but with an extra measure of portability: plug it into a U.S.B. port and it installs the necessary drivers and software. No installation CD is needed. Available at buy.com for $61, it is compatible with Windows-based PC's and the 802.11g and 802.11b Wi-Fi standards.WHAT AND WHERE Most electronic maps and travel guides online and on CD's are designed with motorists in mind, not tourists making their way on foot. Fodors has bundled electronic versions of nine of its city guide books with maps designed for walkers. Guidebook listings like restaurants are linked to the maps. The packages, which cost $20 and are available for download from www.fodors.com, can be viewed on most PocketPC and Palm OS hand-held computers.STREET SMARTS Computerphobes need not fear the Garmin 2620 StreetPilot - a Global Positioning System navigator that comes with maps of the United States and parts of Canada loaded on its 2.2-gigabyte microdrive. The device can tell you where you are, map a route to your destination, and issue audible directions as you go. Garmin now offers a $100 rebate on the 2620, which can be found online at prices ranging from $950 to $1,500.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Extinction Threatens 15,000 Species
description: A fresh assessment of the state of the world's plants and animals concludes that more than 15,000 species, including nearly a third of all known amphibians, are at risk of going extinct in coming decades, mostly as a result of habitat destruction, hunting or other human activities. The assessment was released in Bangkok at a meeting of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, a consortium of private conservation groups and government agencies. The tally of species listed as critically endangered, endangered or vulnerable grew by 3,000 since 2000. Some species are pulling back from the brink, the report said, including the Mallorcan midwife toad, above, which was shifted from the critically endangered to vulnerable because several hundred captive-bred tadpoles and toads have been reintroduced to the wild. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquiry At Weapons Maker
description: The European weapons manufacturer BAE Systems said that it was being included in an investigation by the Serious Fraud Office of Britain over contracts with two travel agents related to the sale of military equipment to Saudi Arabia. The company, which is based in London, said it would cooperate with the inquiry. The company said when the investigation was announced this month that it was not the target and that it might have been the victim of a fraud.

title: California Dreamin' Melts Away Fashion Student Stress
description: When the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising in downtown Los Angeles hired the local architect Clive Wilkinson to design an annex nearby, it asked him for a space that would give its many out-of-state students "a California experience." Mr. Wilkinson, who is now designing headquarters for Google in the Silicon Valley and for J. Walter Thompson in New York, chose water, a scarce resource that dominates this city's imagination, as a primary theme for the project. He transformed ground-floor spaces with 18-foot ceilings in a 1926 building into varied study and meeting spaces. His design includes the aqueous blue pod, top, for design meetings, and a sort of abstracted waterless "swimming pool," above left, with a giant lampshade adorned with palm trees. The walls are lined with a cactus design fabric by Marimekko. Taking suggestions from the young architects in his office, Mr. Wilkinson designed seating that he thought would appeal to the school's students, including the swimming pool itself, for relaxing; the lounge chairs around it, with computers on movable trays; and the flat Japanese-restaurant-style cushions and low tables, above right. His aim, he said, was to project himself "into the world of the students" and design from there.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi's Profit Rises
description: The French entertainment company Vivendi Universal said that it earned 776 million euros ($1 billion) in the third quarter, up from 131 million euros a year earlier, mostly as a result of a change in its tax status. Excluding assets that Vivendi sold in the last year, the company's revenue rose 6 percent, to 4.7 billion euros. Vivendi, which is based in Paris, said the French government changed its tax status in August, giving the company savings of 750 million euros by Sept. 30. Vivendi's Universal Music unit posted a profit that fell short of analysts' estimates and its computer game unit posted a loss.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ronkonkoma: Turkey Thrown Through Windshield Injures Woman
description: A 44-year-old woman driving through Lake Ronkonkoma early Saturday morning was critically injured by a 20-pound turkey that was hurled through her car's windshield, the Suffolk County Police said yesterday. The woman was driving west on Portion Road when someone in an oncoming car threw the turkey. A passenger in her car was able to steer it to the side of the road. The woman, whose name was not released, was taken to Stony Brook University Hospital, where she was in critical condition last night. The police said several teenagers used a stolen credit card to buy the turkey at a nearby supermarket earlier that evening. They are being sought. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Making the Outdoors a Bit Greater
description: <!--.anchor { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 13px; color: #333333}.title { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 18px; line-height: 25px; color: #333333}.subhead { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; color: #333333}--> function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Recreational Tools to Get the Most Out of Mother NaturePARALLAX VIEWWhen Bushnell (bushnell.com) decided to marry a 2-megapixel digital camera with its famous binoculars, it went one step beyond the competition. In most binocams, the camera uses its lens rather than the binoculars' for zeroing in on subjects. That can lead to framing errors. In Bushnell's $600 Instant Replay, the camera is integrated into the binoculars. The camera can also record short low-resolution videos.MULTITASKERThe TotalFit from Bell, the maker of protective helmets and other safety gear and accessories, has a double identity. Mounted on a bicycle, it is a speedometer, but clip it to your belt and it becomes a pedometer. It keeps track of the calories you've burned during your walk, run or ride. The $20 device, available at sports and toy retailers and at sites like fogdog.com, has an easy-to-read display and can be set to English or metric units.TIME CHECKThe Casio Atomic Solar G-Shock (GW700A-1V) wristwatch gets its power from the sun and its accuracy from the government. The $100 watch's solar cells convert light into electrical energy. Several times a day it receives a wireless signal from an atomic clock operated by the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Colorado, keeping it calibrated with official government time. It is shock and water resistant, it has a calendar feature, and it can handle up to four daily alarms and one snooze alarm. More information is at casio.com.DAS BOTWhy not put a robot to work keeping the swimming pool sparkling while you relax in the chaise? The Aquabot Bravo senses a pool's design, taking account of odd areas like stairs. It then calculates the most efficient cleaning pattern. Aqua Products, its maker, says it can scrub and vacuum a pool clean in an hour. The Aquabot Bravo ($1,400; aquaservicedist.com) can be ordered from dealers recommended by Aqua Products (800-221-1750A).TRACK MATEWireless heart rate monitors have long been used by runners to gauge athletic performance. But most of them don't also keep track of distance. The Polar S625X running computer ($350; polarusa.com) comes with a wireless distance sensor that attaches to the runner's shoes. The device also measures elevation changes during a run and, with optional accessories, can double as a bicycle computer. HEAR, HEARBy amplifying sounds, the Brunton Nature Ear II ($280; brunton.com) does for bird watchers' ears what binoculars do for their eyes. The device concentrates on frequencies commonly associated with birdcalls, thus minimizing other sounds. SKY KINGThe Meade ETX-90AT Astro Telescope with Autostar Computer Controller requires little knowledge of astronomy to find stars and other night sky objects. Unlike earlier computer-controlled telescopes, the ETX-90AT ($600; meade.com) even automatically orients and levels itself. Its database contains more than 30,000 objects.

title: Turn the Home TheaterInto a Multimedia Empire
description: <!--.anchor { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 13px; color: #333333}.title { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 18px; line-height: 25px; color: #333333}.subhead { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; color: #333333}--> function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } Entertainment Doesn't Have to Stop With TV and Movies. Investigate Some New Ways to Store, View and Display. LOUD AND CLEARWhile more digital high-definition television programs are being broadcast, rabbit-ear antennas are not ideal for capturing them. The Terk HDTVi ($40; www.terk.com) is an indoor antenna for apartment dwellers and others who cannot use a rooftop aerial. It is meant to be highly directional, unlike rabbit ears, to ensure clean reception of digital signals even in urban areas. A All Terk AntennasCOMMAND AND CONTROL Multiple TV's, computers, sound and home theater systems - each with its own remote control - are complicating leisure time. Logitech says its Harmony 676 universal remote ($230; www.logitech.com) can unravel such messes with a single touch. Once connected to the Internet (through your computer's U.S.B. port), the controller quickly evaluates which components need control and how to do it. It can manage up to 255 operations and has three interchangeable faceplates. A All Logitech Remote ControlsPOCKET VIEWINGTune in to "The OC" on your Pocket PC wherever you may be with the TVCF Card from EOps Technology. The card is a television tuner that plugs into most Pocket PC's with CompactFlash slots (a list of compatible models is at www.eopstech.com); users can watch local broadcasts, toggle between landscape and portrait views and bookmark favorite channels. It costs $129 plus shipping and is available from EOps, which is based in Hong Kong. MAXIMUM FORCEJedi Knights worldwide waited a long time for George Lucas's landmark space opera to hit DVD, and the four-disc "Star Wars" box set ($50; www.foxhome.com) has not disappointed. All three films are remastered and a fourth disc is stuffed with documentaries and even an Easter egg. (Hint: on the Video Games and Stills screen, press 10+ on the DVD remote, then 1, then 3, then 8 to unlock a hidden blooper reel.) AGE APPROPRIATEConceived as a portable media player for the ages - preteens, mostly - Juice Box from Mattel is a rugged, brightly colored box that plays digital video, music and pictures. The $70 box (www.juicebox.com) has a three-inch color liquid crystal display and lots of easy-to-use buttons. It plays video features from special cartridges ($10 to $25). An optional $40 kit lets users import pictures and music. WATCH THIS SPACEIf you have a high-definition TV, you have spent a lot of money for something that is probably turned on for a few hours a day at most. With the slim $300 Roku HD1000 media player attached, however, your screen can also be a breathtakingly high-resolution picture frame that (if you buy the optional Art Paks, at rokulabs.com) displays works of art, animated nature scenes or an animated tropical aquarium. Best of all, the Roku serves as a high-definition display for your own digital photos, loaded either from a memory card or over a home network, complete with musical accompaniment. A All Roku ProductsTHE ENTERTAINERYou will be hearing a lot about Microsoft's software for Portable Media Centers. You will probably hear very little about how they cannot record video directly. You have to buy videos online or install a TV tuner card in your PC. The much smaller, slimmer Archos AV420 ($450; www.archos.com), however, can record from a TV, DVD player, VCR or whatever, even on a timer. It works with Macs and PC's, and even offers a built-in microphone for live audio recordings and a card slot that lets you offload photos from a digital camera. (The AV480 holds four times as much and costs $650.) A CNET Review: Archos AV420STREAM LANDInstead of dragging friends and family over to the computer to see your vacation photos or hear the latest song you have (legally) downloaded, let them relax and experience your collection through your home entertainment center, courtesy of your networked streaming media server. The EyeHome from El Gato ($200 at www.elgato.com) works with Macintosh computers. Windows users can do the same trick with the Media-Link from ADS Technologies at www.adstech.com. ROOM TO SPARETiVo owners know the ecstasy of pausing, rewinding or effortlessly time-shifting their favorite shows - and the agony of running out of space on the hard drive. Toshiba (www.toshiba.com) has solved that problem by adding a DVD burner to its TiVo. A couple of button presses saves any program (or a batch of them) on the model RS-TX20 onto a DVD. The unit's 120-gigabyte hard drive ($470) holds 40 to 120 hours of shows. (Model RS-TX60, about $550, holds about 35 percent more.) A All TiVo ReviewsOFF THE DESKThis black brushed aluminum box looks more comfortable on a shelf with home entertainment components than on a desk next to a computer monitor. And that's the way it should be: the $2,000 HP z545 Digital Entertainment Center (shopping.hp.com) is designed to store all your media files and integrate and control your entertainment devices. The Lowepro Monaco Collection (www.lowepro.com), however, brings some color and visual appeal to the business of hauling music around. Prices range from $15 for a case that can hold 12 CD's to $33 for one that can hold a player and eight discs.A All Carrying CasesIPOD OUT LOUDOn those rare occasions when an iPod is resting at home, it can still be the musical center of attention with the Bose SoundDock ($300; www.bose.com). Put an iPod into the device to produce well-balanced, room-filling playback of tunes stored on the music player's hard drive. There is a remote control for volume, track skipping, play, pause and power. (One thing the remote cannot do is browse songs stored on the player.)A CNET Review: Bose SoundDockFASHION SENSEWith a candy-colored aluminum shell on the outside and room for 1,000 songs on the inside, Apple Computer's iPod hits the sweet spot for music lovers looking for a digital audio player with svelte style. Like its big white sibling, the Mini ($249; www.apple.com/ipodmini), which comes in five colors, stores and displays contacts, calendars, text notes and can even deal a hand of solitaire while spinning tunes. A See All iPod ProductsPICK A COLORThe Zen Micro, a cellphone-size audio player no more than two inches wide that's available in 10 colors, is the work of Creative Labs ($250; creative.com). The player, which has a built-in FM radio from which it can record, can store 2,500 songs on its five-gigabyte hard drive and play them back for 12 hours between battery charges.A See All ZenMicro ProductsFLASH MUSICThe silver Digital Audio Player from SanDisk uses a gigabyte of flash memory to store tunes or other data loaded by a U.S.B. 2 connection or captured with a built-in microphone. The player can hold up to 60 songs in MP3 format or 120 in WMA. The player ($200 at sandisk.com) is also available in 256- and 512-megabyte versions ($90 and $150); it is sold at Best Buy and other stores.A See All SanDisk ProductsADAPTATIONOfficially known as the Sony MiniDisc and Discman Cassette Adapter CPA-9C ($20; www.sonystyle.com), this inexpensive device is compatible with any music player that accepts standard portable headphones. By effectively tricking the car into thinking that it's dealing with a cassette tape, the adapter provides an easy way to play portable music players in most vehicles. (Just make sure the car has a cassette player.)A See All Sony ProductsSECOND SKINThe oPod case from OtterBox ($50; otterbox.com), which makes armored cases for hand-held devices used by the military, keeps the iPod's looks and main function buttons on display while preserving it from shocks and the elements.A See All OtterBox ProductsSMALL APPETITENoise-reduction headphones make it easier to shut out the rest of the world, but they have two drawbacks: price and the rate at which they consume batteries. The Koss QZ50 uses just one AAA-size Abattery, and at around $40, it costs about a quarter as much as some other noise-reduction headsets, including at least one model from Koss (koss.com) itself.A See All Koss HeadphonesRED ON THE RUNDigital music to go doesn't have to cost an arm and a leg. Go Video's bright red Rave MP Sport AMP128 music player has a nice price ($100; www.rave-mp.com), plays MP3 and WMA tracks, uses flash memory and won't skip as you run. Flip on the FM radio or pop in an optional memory card full of new tracks to keep you going.A See Rave Music PlayersDRIVE TIMEThe TransPod FM from Digital Lifestyle Outfitters ($100; everythingipod.com) solves three problems for motorists who want to take their iPods on the road. title: The Right Tools To Keep You Untethered
description: <!--.anchor { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 13px; color: #333333}.title { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 18px; line-height: 25px; color: #333333}.subhead { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; color: #333333}--> function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } On the Road, Small Is Better (and Often Just as Powerful) HANDS ON If ever a palmtop could tempt you to leave your laptop behind, this would be it. The iPac H4155 has 56 megabytes of free memory, a 400-megahertz processor, Bluetooth for connecting to laptops and cellphones, Wi-Fi for hopping onto Internet hot spots, and a bright screen. There aren't as many programs available for the PocketPC operating system as there are for the Palm OS, but this $450 beauty () is a sweet option if you're in a Microsoft state of mind. CNET Review: iPac H4155 Check Latest PricesFORM AND FUNCTION Logitech's V500 Cordless Notebook Mouse not only makes an artful statement, but speaks volumes about clever engineering. The $70 optical mouse (www.logitech.com) links to a laptop through a small receiver that plugs into a U.S.B. port. When not in use, the receiver stows neatly inside the mouse.The V500 runs on two AAA batteries and features a four-way scroll panel rather than a typical scroll wheel. CNET Review: Logitech V500 Cordless Notebook Mouse Check Latest PricesMEMORABLE PalmOne's latest palmtop lacks a voice recorder, vibrating alarm and Wi-Fi for wireless Internet, but it does something no other palmtop can do: when connected to a Mac or PC by a U.S.B. cable, the T5 ($400) becomes a 160-megabyte flash drive to transfer any kind of file. The bright, crisp screen has the highest resolution of any palmtop, and you can rotate it 90 degrees to read spreadsheets and Web pages. Full NYTimes.com Review: Tungsten T5 CNET Review: Tungsten T5 Check Latest PricesSHARP STORAGE The SwissMemory U.S.B. has the familiar blade, nail file, screwdriver and tiny scissors you would expect in a Swiss Army knife, but it also has a 128-megabyte U.S.B. flash storage drive. More information on the SwissMemory, which has a list price of $82, is at www.victorinox.com. For air travel, the flash drive is detachable so the knife itself can be stowed in a checked bag. CELL CINEMA Why settle for plain old pictures on your wireless phone when you can get them up and moving? With LG's VX7000 phone, you can take 15-second videos and send them to your friends. The phone ($200 at www.verizonwireless.com) has four megabytes of storage space for games, ringtones and other goodies.  CNET Review: LG's VX7000 Check Latest PricesCOOL RUNNING Turning the 12-volt DC power from a car's auxiliary outlet into 120-volt AC for a laptop or cellphone charger usually involves a bulky metal box. Most of that bulk is there to draw off heat from the electronic components. The $45 Xantrex XPower Micro Inverter 175 (www.xantrex.com) uses a tiny cooling fan, making it small enough to plug directly into most car outlets. THUMB CANDY The BlackBerry is a hit with white-collar types. But why should corporate America have all the fun? This new model, offered by T-Mobile, is designed and priced for consumers ($200; www.t-mobile.com). It offers the same real-time e-mail features but looks more like a conventional phone. A complete alphabet is on just 20 roomy keys. You can watch the bright screen as the smart software deduces the word you're trying to type and finishes it for you.  Full NYTimes.com Review: BlackBerry 7100t CNET Review: BlackBerry 7100t Check Latest PricesNO STRINGS The thumb-size Air Station 54 Mbps wireless adapter from Buffalo Technology brings Wi-Fi connectivity to PC's and laptops, but with an extra measure of portability: plug it into a U.S.B. port and it installs the necessary drivers and software. No installation CD is needed. Available at buy.com for $61, it is compatible with Windows-based PC's and the 802.11g and 802.11b Wi-Fi standards.  CNET Review: Air Station 54 Check Latest PricesWHAT AND WHERE Most electronic maps and travel guides online and on CD's are designed with motorists in mind, not tourists making their way on foot. Fodors has bundled electronic versions of nine of its city guide books with maps designed for walkers. Guidebook listings like restaurants are linked to the maps. The packages, which cost $20 and are available for download from www.fodors.com, can be viewed on most PocketPC and Palm OS hand-held computers. STREET SMARTS Computerphobes need not fear the Garmin 2620 StreetPilot - a Global Positioning System navigator that comes with maps of the United States and parts of Canada loaded on its 2.2-gigabyte microdrive. The device can tell you where you are, map a route to your destination, and issue audible directions as you go. Garmin now offers a $100 rebate on the 2620, which can be found online at prices ranging from $950 to $1,500.  All Garmin Products

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANE, JASPER HERBERT
description: KANE--Jasper Herbert, 101 years old, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Shelter Island, LI, NY, passed away peacefully on November 16, 2004. He is survived by his sister, Evelyn Kane; son-in-law, Walter C.A. Schrader, and grandsons, W. Kurt Schrader, Mark J. Schrader and Scott K. Schrader, and great-grandchildren, Clare, Maren, Steven, Ryan, Danielle, Craig and Sophia Schrader. Dr. Kane was a pioneer in the field of microbiology and chemistry. He started working for Charles Pfizer and Company at age 16 and retired as vicepresident in charge of research and production. Dr. Kane received his degree at Brooklyn Polytechnic University by attending evening classes. His citric acid fermentation process revolutionized the industry in the 1920's. It was Dr. Kane's Pfizer team that developed the process to mass-produce penicillin during World War II and made it available to treat everyday Americans and wounded GI's, thus saving thousands of lives. As head of the Research and Development team at Pfizer he was also responsible for the discovery and development of the antibiotic Terramycin. Dr. Kane's funeral mass will be held Thursday, November 18, 2004, at St. Lucy's Church, 3510 S. Ocean Blvd., Highland Beach, FL. He will be buried Saturday, 10 A.M., November 20, 2004, in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York, next to his wife Isabel Kane.

title: Iraq at the Tipping Point
description: CAMP FALLUJA, Iraq - Every time I visit Iraq, I leave asking myself the same question: If you total up all the positives and negatives, where does the balance come out? I'd say the score is still 4 to 4. We can still emerge with a decent outcome. And the whole thing could still end very badly. There's only one thing one can say for sure today: you won't need to wait much longer for the tipping point. Either the elections for a new governing body happen by the end of January, as scheduled, and the rout of Saddam loyalists in Falluja is consolidated and extended throughout the Sunni triangle, or not. If it's the former, there are still myriad challenges ahead, but you can be somewhat hopeful. If it's the latter, we've got a total fiasco on our hands.

description: Stelmar Shipping, owner of one of the world's largest tanker fleets for oil products, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Stamatis Molaris, had resigned, citing personal attacks against him in connection with a failed takeover attempt by the Fortress Investment Group. Stelios Haji-Ioannou, Stelmar's founder and largest shareholder, led opposition to the $703 million offer, which was rejected by shareholders on Tuesday. Mr. Haji-Ioannou demanded the dismissal of Mr. Molaris and the chief executive, Peter Goodfellow, as a condition of his joining the board to lead a new search for a buyer, Stelmar said yesterday. A panel of four independent directors rejected the demand, and Mr. Molaris subsequently resigned, the company said. Amazing sister, devoted aunt, and cherished friend of so many in so many places, after a decade of bravely battling the demon of breast cancer, succumbed peacefully Sunday morning, November 7. To the end, surrounded by a steady stream of visitors, she cheerfully played gracious and engaging hostess of festivities. Her generous presence, her adventurous spirit, her endearing independence, and above all her infectious laughter will remain her indelible legacy. title: Opportunities for LearningUnder the Cloak of Play
description: <!--.anchor { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 13px; color: #333333}.title { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 18px; line-height: 25px; color: #333333}.subhead { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 15px; color: #333333}--> function pop_me_up(pURL, features) { new_window = window.open(pURL, "popup_window", features); new_window.focus(); } A Toy Box Full of Gadgets for Honing Skills or Just UnwindingTRAINING WHEELSCrayola, best known for low-tech childhood amusements, has lent its name to game systems intended for children too young for most electronic play. The Crayola My First Electronic Game is actually two different hand-held players that sell for $8 each: Crayon Racer and Paint Splat. The Crayola My First TV Play system ($20) plugs into televisions and offers games and a digital coloring book. The products are by Techno Source toys (www.technosourceusa.com).A More Game ReviewsFULL IMMERSIONThe Sony EyeToy digital camera system, which works exclusively with Sony PlayStation 2 game consoles, is a $50 U.S.B. camera that puts players virtually inside a video game. While the camera has not changed since its introduction last year, the range and sophistication of the games with which it can be used has. EyeToy: AntiGrav, for example, permits players to control a futuristic hoverboarder by acting as if they were on the board themselves. More information is at www.us.playstation.com/games.A All Game ReviewsRHYTHM MACHINEIf wrapping a video game controller in a death grip is not your idea of fun, Nintendo (www.nintendo.com) offers a different path to play one of its newest games: a set of plastic bongos. The drums plug into the controller port of a GameCube and transmit your drumming and hand claps back to the game, aptly titled Donkey Konga. The point is to correctly respond to symbols on a television screen that cue the appropriate taps and claps to music. Sold as a package, the game disc and drums cost $50.TOY CAPERDoubtless to the relief of most parents (to say nothing of the police), the Wild Planet Spy Gear Spy Safe Cracker does not actually teach children how to break into vaults. The $33 toy (www.wildplanet.com) can be used as a tiny safe, opened by punching a code into a keypad. It contains three games that make opening the door more difficult: an electronic maze, a sound-matching game and a code-matching challenge.LIGHT TOUCHLogitech sometimes sacrifices function for style, but this year it got things right with the Cordless Precision Controller for the Xbox. Small and light, requiring two AA batteries, the $50 controller fits easily in your hand. With no wires to tether you to your console and all the buttons just where you want them, this is the least obtrusive of controllers. It looks good, too.A All Wireless Logitech GadgetsIN TOUCHGraphics are not the only thing that has improved in computer games; the sound quality has, too. Plantronics, a maker of audio headsets, hopes serious gamers will reach for its GameCom Pro 1. The $80 headset (www.plantronics.com/gaming) offers real-time equalizing Digital Signal Processing and maximum bass. A noise-canceling microphone ensures that opponents in a Doom 3 melee will clearly understand the taunts.HEADPHONES OF SILENCEMany technological wonders were packed into the Nintendo Game Boy Advance SP, but its designers apparently forgot a headphone jack. Majesco (www.majescogames.com), a game and accessory maker, has an answer in the form of headphones that plug into the game console's recharger jack. The Game Boy Advance SP Neckband Style Headphones cost $10 and can be found in many stores that sell Game Boys.A All Headphone ReviewsAIRBORNEThe VrRoom Zoom is a remote-control model airplane intended for use indoors by children. The $40 plane has a fuselage made from carbon-fiber wire and lightweight styrene wings with a 14-inch span. It flies in circles to a range of about 40 feet, according to its maker, Jasman Toys. A tiny lithium polymer battery powers the plane; a five-minute charge is enough for five to eight minutes of flying time. The VrRoom Zoom, widely available online and in toy and hobby stores, operates in 27- and 49-megahertz frequencies, so two can be used at once.GROWN-UP FUNThe latest Nintendo hand-held game console is not a tot's toy, although the youngest devotees of the Game Boy will probably be eager to give this dual-screen, flip-top device a go. The Nintendo DS, which costs $150, plays a new, advanced class of games (Game Boy games, too) that take advantage of both back-lit screens, one of which is touch sensitive. There is a Wi-Fi connection for wireless communications and multiplayer gaming. New games and tricks are at www.nintendods.com.A All Nintendo ProductsIN TOUCHGraphics are not the only thing that has improved in computer games; the sound quality has, too. Plantronics, a maker of audio headsets, hopes serious gamers will reach for its GameCom Pro 1. The $80 headset (www.plantronics.com/gaming) offers real-time equalizing Digital Signal Processing and maximum bass. A noise-canceling microphone ensures that opponents in a Doom 3 melee will clearly understand the taunts.A All Audio HeadsetsINTERACTIVEPublications International says its ActivePoint series of books teaches children about numbers, colors, letters and sounds as they interact with cartoon characters. Each 24-page book has a plastic frame with a speaker and an attached stylus. An electronic voice prompts children to tap spots on each page to answer questions, solve problems and play small games. More information, including a store locator, can be found at www.pilbooks.com.A All Game Reviews

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINTZ, WALTER
description: MINTZ--Walter. Died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday, November 16, 2004 after a long illness. He was the dearly loved husband of Sandra Earl Mintz. Born February 23, 1929 in Vienna, Austria the son of the late Maximillian and Ilse Schueller Mintz, he came to the United States with his family in 1938. After attending public schools in the Bronx, he graduated from Reed College in Portland, Oregon in 1950, and then did post-graduate work in economics at Columbia University. He was an Associate Editor at Barron's before he began his career in the investment business at Shearson Hammill Co. in 1956. There, he was the Director of Research, 1962-69, and Executive Vice President of their Investment Division, 1965-70. In 1970, he co-founded Cumberland Associates, an investment management company in New York. He retired as a Managing partner from that firm in 1982, remaining a special limited partner. Mr. Mintz was a Trustee of Reed College for 33 years, 1971-2003. He was Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, 1991-98, and Chairman 1998-2002. He established the Walter Mintz Economics Scholarship for students, and co-sponsored a Chair in Economic History. In New York, he was a Trustee of The Manhattan Institute, 1990-2003, and served as Vice Chairman, 1994-2003. He was also on the Boards of Merrill Lynch Phoenix Fund and Federal Security Trust, 1982-2001; on the Board of the Citizen's Union Foundation, 1985-2003, and was a member of the N.Y. Society of Security Analysts, where he served on their Board of Directors, 196975. In addition to his wife of 33 years, he is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Marjorie and Dr. Joseph K. Perloff, and their two daughters, Nancy and Carey, all of California. Services were privately held, but it is hoped that all who knew him will set aside some time to remember his great ability to think and reason fairly; his enjoyment of life and his work; his good nature, compassion and generous spirit. He cherished his friends and was grateful for them.

Until the last months of her life, a resident of Brooklyn, N.Y., she was a loyal and skilled office worker at Macy's N.Y. for 28 years, a consummate homemaker and a wise and dear mother who encouraged her daughters through college and graduate school. Her girlhood hero was Amelia Earhart; she was "the wind beneath our wings." Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM at "The Riverside" 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. NY, NY. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, ADAM
description: YOUNG--Adam, 91, died on November 15, 2004 of a stroke, at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, FL. He was a native of New York City. Adam Young, a page for the National Broadcasting Company while in his teens who then went on to co-found Young Broadcasting, Inc., one of the country's 25 largest television station groups. A broadcast pioneer who worked in both radio and television during their formative years, Mr. Young spent his entire professional life in the industry, having begun his career at NBC radio at the age of 17. The oldest of eight children, his income was needed to help support the family. During this time he also served as a page for the grand opening of Radio City Music Hall and was involved in NBC's move to its new Rockefeller Center headquarters. He eventually moved from the position of Head Page, through the Programming Department, and on to the Research and Promotion Department, where he developed a flair for mathematics which he successfully applied throughout his career. At night, Mr. Young managed the New Amsterdam Theater for NBC where many of the popular Big Bands of the era performed for live radio broadcasts. In 1936 he left NBC Radio and went into the advertising industry. Within eight years, he started his own business, Adam Young, Inc., representing radio stations in the United States, Canada and around the world. Eventually, with the development of a new broadcast technology, the focus of the Company shifted from representing radio stations to representing television stations. In 1986, Mr. Young co-founded Young Broadcasting Inc. with his son, Vincent, which began with the purchase of two television stations. Today the NASDAQ - traded company owns and operates 10 television stations across the United States. The Young Broadcasting station group includes ABC, CBS and NBC affiliates, as well as the nation's largest independent station--KRONTV in San Francisco. Mr. Young continued to be fully active in the business, and at the time of his death, he was the Treasurer of Young Broadcasting Inc., and President Emeritus of Adam Young Inc. In recognition of his achievement of starting with nothing and building successful radio and television businesses, Mr. Young received the Horatio Alger Association award in 1957. He was a founder of the Station Representative Association and went on to serve as President of the Association from 1955-1957. He served on the Board of Directors of the Television Bureau of Advertising from 1977-1980, and for many years he headed up its Research Committee. He was a board member of the Radio Advertising Bureau and also served as ViceChairman of the Standards Committee of the International Advertising Association. Mr. Young served as president of the Westhampton Country Club; and until recently, he was president of BioMotion Foundation, a medical research organization based in West Palm Beach, FL, dedicated to improving the technology of artificial joints. He was constantly selfeducating and he was also an avid painter. Mr. Young is survived by his wife of 68 years, Margaret Kelly Young, a daughter Sharon Conroy of Palm Beach, FL, a son Richard of Greenwich, CT and a son Vincent of Bedford, NY. A daughter, Susan Quinn, predeceased him. He also leaves nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren. There will be a viewing at Quattlebaum Funeral Home in West Palm Beach, FL on Thursday from 6:30 to 8:30 PM; and a service at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach on Friday at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to BioMotion Foundation, P.O. Box 248, Palm Beach, FL 33480.

The Listings; ANIMAL COLLECTIVE
description: Over the last few years, the musicians known as Avey Tare, above, and Panda Bear have emerged at the center of a scene that prides itself on not having one. The two are the most prominent members of Animal Collective, a loose-knit group made up of singers and noisemakers who are exploring a joyful -- and joyfully light-headed -- mutant strain of folk music. Earlier this year, Animal Collective released "Sung Tongs" (Fat Cat), a marvelous CD full of sing-along songs that sound instantly familiar but tantalizingly unrecognizable. Stray voices float by in the distance, guitarists strum energetic but asymmetrical rhythms, small choruses cohere around repeated phrases you can't quite translate. Every once in a while there's a buried joke: "College" is a 53-second song in which wordless harmonies give way to a bit of advice, as the singers intone, "You don't have to go to college." The Animal Collective empire is expanding. Panda Bear recently released his second solo album, a hushed elegy for his father called "Young Prayer" (Paw Tracks). And last month, the group's Paw Tracks record label released its first non-Animal CD, "The Doldrums," by an oblique California singer-songwriter who calls himself Ariel Pink; he dumps dirt on his bruised and warped 70's-style rock ballads, then dares them to shine anyway. You won't be shocked to learn that Animal Collective's live shows can be enthralling or exasperating, depending upon your mood and theirs. But if everything goes pear-shaped, you can always stop by the merchandise table, grab a handful of CD's, go home and get lost. (Animal Collective: Sunday night at 8, with Gang Gang Dance and Oakley Hall; Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006; tickets are $12. Ariel Pink: tomorrow night at 8, with Signer and Greg Davis, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503; tickets are $10.) KELEFA SANNEH

description: A man and a woman in a green minivan who have tried to coax children into their vehicle in recent weeks turned more brazen yesterday when the man tried to grab a fleeing 10-year-old boy, the Rye police said. In other encounters, in Rye and in nearby Greenwich, Conn., the man did not try to force children into the van, but the police called this latest incident an attempted abduction. The boy, who got away, told the police that the van approached him as he walked along Rye Road in the afternoon, and that a white woman with blond hair was driving. A white man with dark curly hair and yellowed teeth occupied the passenger seat, the boy said. The descriptions matched those of earlier incidents, including ones in Rye on Monday and Tuesday. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINTZ, WALTER
description: MINTZ--Walter. Died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday, November 16, 2004 after a long illness. He was the dearly loved husband of Sandra Earl Mintz. Born February 23, 1929 in Vienna, Austria the son of the late Maximillian and Ilse Schueller Mintz, he came to the United States with his family in 1938. After attending public schools in the Bronx, he graduated from Reed College in Portland, Oregon in 1950, and then did post-graduate work in economics at Columbia University. He was an Associate Editor at Barron's before he began his career in the investment business at Shearson Hammill Co. in 1956. There, he was the Director of Research, 1962-69, and Executive Vice President of their Investment Division, 1965-70. In 1970, he co-founded Cumberland Associates, an investment management company in New York. He retired as a Managing partner from that firm in 1982, remaining a special limited partner. Mr. Mintz was a Trustee of Reed College for 33 years, 1971-2003. He was Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, 1991-98, and Chairman 1998-2002. He established the Walter Mintz Economics Scholarship for students, and co-sponsored a Chair in Economic History. In New York, he was a Trustee of The Manhattan Institute, 1990-2003, and served as Vice Chairman, 1994-2003. He was also on the Boards of Merrill Lynch Phoenix Fund and Federal Security Trust, 1982-2001; on the Board of the Citizen's Union Foundation, 1985-2003, and was a member of the N.Y. Society of Security Analysts, where he served on their Board of Directors, 196975. In addition to his wife of 33 years, he is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Marjorie and Dr. Joseph K. Perloff, and their two daughters, Nancy and Carey, all of California. Services were privately held, but it is hoped that all who knew him will set aside some time to remember his great ability to think and reason fairly; his enjoyment of life and his work; his good nature, compassion and generous spirit. He cherished his friends and was grateful for them.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Rice Will Have Minor Surgery
description: Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser who has been nominated to be secretary of state, will undergo minor surgery today to treat uterine fibroids. A spokesman for the National Security Council said Ms. Rice would have a uterine fibroid embolization, a minimally invasive procedure that shrinks the fibroids, which are noncancerous growths, by blocking their blood supply. Ms. Rice, 50, plans to return home tomorrow and expects to be back at work on Monday, officials said. Uterine fibroids, which are most common among women 35 and older, usually require no treatment. But if they grow large enough or appear in sensitive areas of the uterus, they can cause problems including heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort and possibly infertility and miscarriage. description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 - After two years of polling, market testing and up-close demographic scrutiny of American voters, the manager of President Bush's re-election campaign, Ken Mehlman, offered another way Thursday to view the divide between the American electorate.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fox-Hunting Ban Passed
description: Parliament invoked special legislation to approve a law banning hunting with dogs. It will be in place by February. The Parliament Act was used for only the fourth time to break a deadlock between the House of Commons, which supports the hunting ban, and the House of Lords, which opposes it. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Executive Quits
description: Carlos Lessa, the president of the National Bank of Economic and Social Development in Brazil, resigned after repeatedly clashing in public with several cabinet members over economic policy. Mr. Lessa, a left-wing economist and former university provost, will be succeeded by Guido Mantega, left, the planning minister and a longtime adviser to President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva. Mr. Lessa's resignation, which was widely expected, was a victory for the finance minister, Antonio Palocci, whose conservative fiscal policies Mr. Lessa had harshly criticized. The development bank, which finances industrial and development projects, has an annual budget of more than $12 billion. Nelson Machado, the planning ministry's executive secretary, will fill Mr. Mantega's post until a successor is named. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press on Tuesday about a rare televised debate between the Ukrainian presidential candidates misattributed a quotation. It was Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych, the Kremlin-backed candidate -- not his Western-leaning rival, Viktor Yushchenko -- who told viewers, "I came to tell you the truth, looking into your eyes." The article also translated a word incorrectly in a statement by Mr. Yushchenko. He said, "We have a choice: To live according to criminal laws or as free, well-to-do people" -- not "honest, well-to-do people."

title: Israel Regrets Killing 3 Egyptians at Border
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 18 - The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, apologized to Egypt on Thursday after an Israeli Army tank crew fired on an Egyptian patrol near the border with Gaza, killing three Egyptian policemen.

title: ASBESTOS SETTLEMENT MOVES CLOSER TO APPROVAL
description: A bankruptcy judge ruled yesterday that a proposed $1.5 billion settlement of asbestos claims between two subsidiaries of the Halliburton Company and insurers was "fair and reasonable," moving closer to the approval of a fund for victims. Judge Judith K. Fitzgerald of United States Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh gave parties in the case until Tuesday to contest the proposed agreement. She said that the agreement would be considered approved if there are no objections. Court approval would clear the way for Halliburton, which is based in Houston, to complete a $4.8 billion plan to settle all current and future asbestos claims as soon as year-end. The agreement involves insurers and Halliburton subsidiaries Kellogg Brown & Root and DII Industries.

title: Greenspan Warns That U.S. Deficits Pose Risk to Dollar
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 19 - Alan Greenspan came to the home of the euro on Friday and suggested that the relentless decline of the dollar might well continue, offering little relief to those here who worry that the United States is seeking to gain a competitive advantage for its industries from a weaker currency.

title: The Listings; BENJAMIN EDWARDS
description: With each passing day, it seems, our world drifts further from nature and envelops us more and more tightly in a seamless fabric of human design. Benjamin Edwards, a painter having his second solo exhibition in New York, envisions the exciting and bewildering complexity of our brave new artificial paradise. Working like an unusually ambitious and ingenious architectural illustrator, Mr. Edwards creates expansive, kaleidoscopic fusions of Renaissance perspective, Cubism and Pop that measure as much as 11 1/2 feet across. As in "Immersion," above, layered and intersecting architectural structures, streets and corporate logos spread out across the surface and recede into deep perspectival space. On one level the paintings convey feelings of utopian euphoria: the well-designed world is a supremely efficient machine for living; commodities, information, energy and money flow smoothly from place to place; peace and harmony reign. Behind that luminous scrim of beneficently rationalized order, however, lie shadows of anxiety and terror. Such perfection is a fascist's dream. The messy inefficiency of ordinary humanity is overcome. Corporate sterility extends as far as the eye can see. And we are left to wonder where, when and how the bottled- up energies of real life will next erupt. (Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 445-0444, through Dec. 30; free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Residency Plea For 9/11 Relatives
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has asked the Bush administration to allow relatives of immigrants who died in the Sept. 11 attacks to remain in the United States while they seek permanent residency status. In a Nov. 11 letter to the administration that was released by the mayor's office yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg said a reprieve from deportation that had been granted by the USA Patriot Act of 2001 had "long expired, leaving families again deeply vulnerable." The letter continued, "Approximately 100 spouses and children are in this desperate condition and need immediate immigration relief to move forward with their lives." Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: F.D.A. Approves a Pill for Lung Cancer to Be Sold by Genentech and OSI
description: Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals won federal approval yesterday to sell Tarceva, a pill to treat lung cancer.

title: Arts, Briefly; Don't Just Look. Buy!
description: Aspiring collectors of contemporary art in Britain can take advantage of Own Art, a new interest-free loan program from Arts Council England, which distributes government and national lottery money to the arts. Research by the council found that although 4.9 million people in Britain have bought contemporary visual art, a further 5.9 million hope to buy. Now, anyone spotting a work of art in the Arts Council's approved list of 250 galleries can apply for a loan of $3,700, to be paid back over 10 months. The loans are available for paintings, photography, sculpture, glassware and furniture created by living artists. Sir Christopher Frayling, the chairman of the council told The Guardian, "Our aims in the visual arts are to help provide a sustainable economy for artists, develop new audiences and make sure that the infrastructure of art, including galleries, is helpful." PAM KENT

title: I.R.S. Audits More of the Wealthy and Fewer Small Companies
description: The Internal Revenue Service, in the midst of a crackdown on aggressive tax shelters, is auditing significantly more wealthy individuals and large companies, but is increasingly shying away from scrutinizing smaller businesses.

title: Chirac Hints France Will Help Rebuild Iraq
description: LONDON, Nov. 18 - President Jacques Chirac crossed the English Channel to say on Thursday that France was ready to cooperate with the United States and Britain to make the world more stable, just and prosperous.

title: Afghan Poppy Growing Reaches Record Level, U.N. Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 18 - Poppy cultivation in Afghanistan, the source of most of the opium and heroin on Europe's streets, was up sharply this year, reaching the highest levels in the country's history and in the world, the United Nations announced on Thursday.

description: A lengthy and hard-fought Congressional race in western New York came to an end last night, when Nancy Naples, the Erie County comptroller and Republican candidate, conceded to Assemblyman Brian Higgins, the Democratic candidate.

PMK/HBH, the agency she had helped lead for two decades, has ousted her over differences reflecting the potential difficulties in directing traffic at the intersection of Hollywood Boulevard and Madison Avenue.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - The United States and Australia announced on Thursday that they had resolved the remaining disputes in a free trade agreement reached earlier this year.

title: Three Visions Compete for European Bank's New Home
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 18 - Choosing a German city to be the home of the European Central Bank and its new currency, the euro, was a diplomatic challenge worthy of Talleyrand. Choosing an architect to design a new bank headquarters here is proving no less tricky.

title: Mr. Sharon, You're Up at Bat
description: After four years of gloom and doom for those who seek peace in the Middle East, the last few days, with the baby steps toward some modicum of civility between Israelis and Palestinians, have been downright heady. First, the new Palestinian leaders offered Israel a burial site it could accept for Yasir Arafat. Then President Bush, prodded by the British prime minister, Tony Blair, actually said he was willing to "spend the capital of the United States" on creating an independent Palestinian state. And finally, Mahmoud Abbas, the new head of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the likely front-runner to replace Mr. Arafat, set a date for elections: Jan. 9. What's more, Mr. Abbas has thus far resisted any urge to toughen up his image with Palestinian hard-liners through unnecessary anti-Israel speeches. If this were baseball, President Bush would have hit a single, and Mr. Abbas a double. Now it's time for Ariel Sharon to step up to the plate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Plans Bioscience Center
description: The city plans to create a large bioscience research and development center on the city-owned campus of Bellevue Hospital Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The city has requested proposals from developers to create the East River Science Park, which would encompass about 4.5 acres, with more than 870,000 square feet of floor space for research and development. The park would be between 28th and 29th Streets, First Avenue and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. New York City has tried to lure biotechnology companies but has lost ground to Boston and the Bay Area of California. Henry Kravis and Russell Carson, co-chairmen of the New York City Investment Fund, would give $10 million toward the project. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

The series, dedicated to popular American song and its singers and songwriters, begins on Jan. 6 with a performance by Audra McDonald at the Rose Theater in Frederick P. Rose Hall in the Time Warner Center. . . . A guitar played by George Harrison on the Beatles album "Revolver" and by John Lennon on the "White Album" will be auctioned, with more than 400 other lots of rock and show business memorabilia, by Christie's in New York on Dec. 17, Agence France-Press reported. Put up for sale by a private collector, the instrument, a solid-body Gibson SG electric guitar, could fetch as much as $500,000, according to Christie's. . . . Eleven pieces of jewelry once owned by the soprano Maria Callas have been sold for $1.87 million at a Sotheby's auction in Geneva, Reuters reported. The bidding for the emeralds, diamonds and rubies, most of them given to Callas in the 1950's by her husband, Giovanni Battista Meneghini, and sold by an unnamed Callas heir, tripled the presale estimate.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Low Interest Rate Policy Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan maintained its low interest rate policy by keeping short-term interest rates at zero and said it would continue to provide ample cash to money markets to promote economic growth. The bank, in its monthly assessment of the economy, warned that the country's production and export growth was slowing, but said it did not expect the lull to derail a recovery now in its second year. Japan's economy continues to recover as a whole, the bank said. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Accused Of Raping Girl At Studio
description: The police arrested a suspect yesterday on charges that he raped a 14-year-old girl at a Midtown modeling agency twice in August. The suspect, Charles Green, 35, of Marlborough Road in Brooklyn, turned himself in to the police yesterday morning and was charged with second-degree rape, engaging in a criminal sexual act and endangering the welfare of a child. The crimes occurred on two visits the girl made to the agency, in a rented office in 255 West 36th Street, the police said. A spokesman for the landlord said the agency was no longer there. He was a graduate of The Buckley School, Groton School and Harvard University, class of 1946. He was a Veteran of World War II, serving in the Army Air Corps. At the time of his death Mr. Cary was an associate at H.G. Wellington. He was pre-deceased by his sister, Eileen Burden Maynard Robins. title: ARTS GUIDE
Paid Notice: Deaths   KANE, JASPER H.
description: KANE--Jasper H. The Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, students and alumni of Polytechnic University mourn the passing of Dr. Jasper H. Kane, alumnus, generous benefactor and 1995 Honorary Doctorate of Science recipient of the University. Dr. Kane's vision and enormous contributions to the field of chemical science are legendary. A retired vice president and director of Pfizer Inc, he headed the research team that discovered terramycin and also helped develop the process of mass producing penicillin, streptomycin and other antibiotics during World War II. His gentle humor and generous spirit will be very much missed. We extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Stewart G. Nagler, Chairman David C. Chang, President Polytechnic University

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Vivendi To Buy 16% Stake In Maroc Telecom
description: Vivendi Universal, the owner of the French mobile phone company SFR, agreed to pay the Moroccan government 1.1 billion euros ($1.4 billion) for a 16 percent stake in Maroc Telecom, raising its holding to 51 percent. Vivendi, based in Paris, already holds 51 percent of the company's voting rights through a 35 percent equity stake, the company said yesterday. The additional stake will add to net income beginning in 2005, Vivendi said. Vivendi said it paid a premium for continuing control of the company. The Moroccan government plans to sell a further 15 percent stake worth about $900 million in an initial public offering, people close to the deal said earlier this month.

title: In Savannah, Ga.
description: IN 1733, a Yamacraw Indian leader named Tomochichi agreed to the plans of James Oglethorpe, founder of the colony of Georgia, to create an agricultural settlement on the Savannah River. Oglethorpe set to work, laying out an unusual town based on an elaborate system of 24 public squares. Today the squares, shaded by live oaks and surrounded by stately houses, churches and the columned houses of government, define old Savannah, where shops and cafes occupy mansions and town houses, and tourists and locals stroll at a leisurely pace. Nearby is Bonaventure cemetery, where John Berendt, author of "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil," sipped martinis as his friend Mary Harty told tales of the departed. While Savannah's builders carelessly flattened a burial mound holding Tomochichi's ancestors, they set aside ample acreage for the city's own dead, and in those graveyards, beneath long gray beards of Spanish moss, restless spirits are said to walk. Most of Oglethorpe's city has passed on to the ghostly realm, too, but his urban-planning legacy remains: a walkable, bikable, town, one of the loveliest haunts in the South. CHRIS DIXON

The dismissal of the lawmaker, Carolyn Parrish, who represents a heavily Muslim district in the Ontario city of Mississauga and has made a series of strongly anti-American comments, was intended to demonstrate Mr. Martin's desire that President Bush, widely unpopular in Canada, receive a respectful reception when he arrives for a visit on Nov. 30. description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about big-screen televisions with liquid-crystal displays, misstated the comparison of their depth with that of plasma sets. It is LC-45GX6U in the United States; LC-45G1H is its number overseas.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - After nine weeks of testimony but with months to go, the federal judge presiding over the trial of the government's conspiracy suit against the tobacco industry invited lawyers for each side on Thursday to sum up their cases so far.

title: Reed Irvine, 82, the Founder of a Media Criticism Group, Dies
description: Reed Irvine, the founder of Accuracy in Media, a watchdog group dedicated to exposing, challenging and at times bullying those he accused of slanting news coverage from a liberal perspective, died on Tuesday at a hospice in Rockville, Md. He was 82. A longtime resident of Silver Spring, Md., Mr. Irvine had recently moved to Gaithersburg, Md.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 18 - A court-appointed monitor told a federal judge Thursday that officials of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection, which runs the city's vast water supply system, recently tried to impede investigations of possible violations of federal health, safety and environmental laws.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: No Rise In Power Rates
description: Despite fluctuations in prices for the oil and gas that fuel its generators, the Long Island Power Authority expects no rate increases for its electricity customers through next year. Barring an unforeseen "worldwide energy crisis," rates will be frozen for 2005 and are likely to stay stable the next few years, the power authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, said yesterday as he proposed a $3 billion budget. "We're one of a handful of utilities in the nation that is not increasing customers' bills," he said. Instead, the authority is cutting expenses and absorbing fuel costs. The Long Island Power Authority serves nearly three million people in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Rockaways in Queens. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: With Title on Line, Hendrick Teams Haven't Got Time for Pain
description: These are busy days for the Hendrick Motorsports race teams. There is another championship to be won, perhaps a first points title for Jimmie Johnson or a fifth for Jeff Gordon. Winning requires focus, and for that many at Hendrick are grateful right now.

description: HOUSTON, Nov. 18 - Mark Aguirre never played a game in the imposing brick monument that now houses the Dallas Mavericks. But every time he walks its corridors, it feels a lot like home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIZZO, ALBERTO
description: RIZZO--Alberto, 73, an art and fashion photographer, died of leukemia on October 9th in Miami. Rizzo was born in Rome. His first career as a ballet dancer brought him to the US in 1965 when he moved to California to dance with Fred Astaire. At 30, he picked up a camera for the first time and headed to NYC where he helped set in motion the graphic photography movement. His long list of clients included Harper's Bazaar, Italian and French Vogue, Domus as well as Revlon, Bulgari and Piaget. His work is in the permanent collections of museums around the world including the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Most recently he had a one man show at Carla Sozzani Galleria in Milan, which will publish a retrospective volume of his 40 year career. Rizzo is survived by his daughter, Albertina, his son, Paolo, their mother Cristina and his fiancee Robin Narvaez. There will be a memorial to celebrate his life at St. Patrick's Cathedral on November 22nd at 10:30 AM.
