title: JUDGE ORDERS THREE HOLLINGER DIRECTORS REMOVED
description: An Ontario judge yesterday ordered Hollinger Inc. to remove three directors, depriving the controlling shareholder, Conrad M. Black, of most of his allies on the company's board. Judge Colin Campbell of the Ontario Superior Court faulted the directors, Mr. Black's wife, Barbara Amiel Black; Jack Boultbee; and F. David Radler for failing to disclose promptly a loan of 1.1 million Canadian dollars ($913,000) to the Ravelston Corporation, a separate company also controlled by Mr. Black. The ruling is open to appeal. Their removal leaves the co-chief operating officer, Peter White, as the last of Mr. Black's long-time associates on the board. Mr. Black is fighting allegations that he pocketed $7.2 million of payments that Hollinger International, Hollinger Inc.'s United States subsidiary, never authorized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, MAX
description: GREENBERG--Max died on November 15th in the company of his wife and daughters as his friend, poet Michael Riordan, was reading Max's own poetry to him. A Veteran of World War II Max was a member of the 7th Signal Liaison Team, an intelligence unit taking part in the liberation of Paris, the Battle of the Bulge, and the capture of Hitler's Black forest retreat, Berchesgarten. He attended the Sorbonne and received a B.A. (1951) and M.S.S. (1956) from NYU. As he turned 60, an early talent for poetry returned and he left social work to write poetry. He published two collections, Country of the Old and Battletough. He twice received a New Jersey Council of the Arts award for poetry, (1983 & 1985). He is survived by his wife, Dr. Estelle (nee Filker Greenberg), three daughters, Elizabeth Greenberg, Ann Dery, and Charlotte Kerwick, four grandchildren Jeremy, Emily, and Jonathan Dery, and Max Jacob Greenberg, and a sister Dorothy Adler. Services were held at Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, NJ.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hard Rock Cafe To Move
description: The Hard Rock Cafe, a fixture on 57th Street for 20 years, will move by next fall to the former Paramount Theater at 43rd Street and Broadway in Times Square, the cafe's owner, Hard Rock Cafe International, said yesterday. The company had announced earlier that it would be part of joint venture to take over the Paramount Hotel, on 46th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, creating a new Hard Rock Hotel by the end of next year. Although Times Square has proved a risky business location for theme restaurants, including one operated by World Wrestling Entertainment that closed a year ago in the former Paramount Theater, Hard Rock executives said Times Square had far surpassed other Manhattan locations. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Briarcliff Manor: Speed Limit Lowered After Crash
description: Police officials yesterday indefinitely reduced the speed limit to 30 miles an hour from 45 along a small stretch of Route 9A in Westchester County where a gasoline tanker flipped over in a fiery crash Wednesday night. Investigators were still trying to determine the cause. The accident triggered a large fireball around 7:35 p.m. near the Pleasantville Road overpass. The driver of the 4,700-gallon tanker, Henry Tulloch of Brooklyn, was being treated for burns at Westchester Medical Center and was listed as stable. A small car also became engulfed in flames, but the Briarcliff Manor police chief, Norman Campion, said he was uncertain whether the vehicles had collided. title: The Listings; JENNIFER HOPE WILLS
description: This is the woman who has been assigned the forbidding chore of making Brooke Shields look like the dog's dinner. In the triumphantly recast revival of "Wonderful Town" at the Al Hirschfeld Theater, Ms. Shields -- she of the high-fashion cheek bones and statuesque frame -- is playing the awkward, romantically unalluring Ruth Sherwood, who believes she would always be the loser in any beauty contest with her beloved younger sister, Eileen. Which is where a largely unknown actress named Jennifer Hope Wills steps in. Ms. Wills's previous Broadway experience has been limited to appearing in the ensemble of "Beauty and the Beast," while understudying one of the title roles. (Guess which.) But without being obnoxious about it, she here exudes the natural confidence of a girl whose dance card was filled before she learned to walk. Her optimistic easiness turns out to be the ideal foil for the charmingly arch mannerisms of Ms. Shields's would-be sophisticate, just as Ms. Wills's lithe soprano melds in sweet sororal harmony with the older actress's straightforward alto. When this Eileen sings, "mmmm . . . I'm a little bit in love," with the relaxed contentment of a cat in mid-stretch, it's unlikely that anyone in the audience doesn't feel the same about Ms. Wills. (This weekend's schedule: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $51 to $101.) BEN BRANTLEY

Like "Lost in Translation," Mr. Corneau's film concerns a young strawberry-blond woman undergoing a comical and painful process of self-discovery in a Tokyo high rise. Unlike Scarlett Johansson's character, though, the protagonist of "Fear and Trembling," whose name is Amlie, is not entirely a stranger to Japan. Three Americans have died after taking the pill since it was approved, during a heavily politicized process by Congress and the Clinton administration, in September 2000. The new announcement suggests that the F.D.A. still hasn't learned its lesson -- and that this drug should be taken off the pharmacy shelves.

title: The Listings; MEREDITH MONK
description: Meredith Monk has been sidling through New York dance for four decades now. An elusive creature, she has managed not to be categorized as the performer, choreographer, composer or filmmaker that she has been over her rich career. But her roots are in dance, or at least in performance art before it was known as such. No one has ever quite matched the intensity of the hyper-real dreamscapes she created from the mid-1960's on, using film, her own vocal music, movement and plain but shimmeringly evocative props to create pieces that existed on several levels of the everyday. A believer in total theater, Ms. Monk combined her dance group, The House, with a new Meredith Monk Vocal Ensemble in 1978. And that seemed to open the floodgates of her prodigious imagination to pour out into film, opera and theatrical productions. Eventually she identified herself as a composer first and foremost. But dance is a persistent lover. If it couldn't have Ms. Monk, it could have her music, which has been a cool, eerie and bizarrely evocative staple of avant-gardish choreography ever since. This weekend, in "Dance to Monk: Choreographers Celebrate the Music of Meredith Monk," six dance artists will pay tribute to Ms. Monk in her 40th anniversary season with new and repertory pieces set to scores that include her "Dolmen Music," "Volcano Songs" and "St. Petersburg Waltz." They are Ann Carlson, Sean Curran, Molissa Fenley, the now rarely seen Dana Reitz, Doug Varone and Bill T. Jones (on film), all as fiercely individualistic as Ms. Monk. (Tonight through Sunday at 8:30 p.m., the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $20 or TDF voucher.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Drugs Could Fight Brain Infection
description: A deadly brain infection that kills up to 5 percent of AIDS patients may theoretically be prevented by several drugs already in use, a new study has found. The study, being published today in Science magazine, was conducted by researchers from Brown University and Case Western Reserve University's medical school. The disease, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, or P.M.L., is caused by a virus that can invade the brain of patients with severely compromised immune systems. Half of those with such infections die within 18 months; most of the rest are severely brain-damaged. The virus was shown to gain access to the brain through a receptor that can be blocked by several drugs that already have Food and Drug Administration approval, said Dr. Walter J. Atwood, the Brown microbiologist who led the study. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

Italians arrested with even small amounts would face punishments, like the confiscation of a driver's license or passport. Under the current legislation, possession of the drug is rarely penalized when it is for personal use, and last year a 17-year-old student convinced an Italian court that the 40 hashish cigarettes he took on a school trip were for his own use. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Native Groups Win Land Ruling
description: In a decision that may complicate logging, mining and other natural resource projects, the Supreme Court of Canada said that governments must consult native groups before allowing major changes on land involved in ownership disputes. The decision came out of a case started by the Haida Indians after the province of British Columbia transferred a logging license covering about 25 percent of the Queen Charlotte Islands to the Weyerhaeuser Company of Federal Way, Wash. Those islands and the water surrounding them have been the focus of a century-old ownership claim by the Haida. Much of Canada's resource activity, like Weyerhaeuser's logging, takes place on land owned by provinces. In its unanimous decision, the court said that only governments, not users like Weyerhaeuser, must consult aboriginal groups. While it did not spell out the nature of those consultations, the court turned down a similar appeal yesterday by another native group in British Columbia opposed to the reopening of a mining road. In that case the court found that making the native group part of an environmental review was enough. Ian Austen (NYT)

But try not to miss this small show, the 82nd incarnation of a series devoted to new art or design. The work, which the museum commissioned four years ago, is a kind of roots tour that resonates well with this historic occasion. It time-travels through several layers of the Modern's (and Manhattan's) past and renders in modest but poetic terms one of the basic truths of urban life: new structures inevitably erase the old.

New greatest-hits packages from Shania Twain (530,000 sales for the week) and Toby Keith (435,000), both performers on the show, helped the surge. Sales of LeAnn Rimes's latest album rose more than 75 percent. Kenny Chesney, left, who won the award for entertainer of the year, joined Gretchen Wilson, Keith Urban, Billy Currington, Big & Rich and Terri Clark with increases of 50 percent or more in sales. Many on Music Row in Nashville will be watching sales carefully after the awards show visits New York next year: they anticipate that the move will generate far more mainstream media coverage than when the ceremonies originate in Nashville. title: Arts, Briefly; Dancing Into New Shoes
description: Peter Boal, right, a longtime leading dancer with the New York City Ballet, has been named artistic director of the Pacific Northwest Ballet in Seattle, effective July 1. Mr. Boal's final performance with City Ballet, which he joined in 1983, will take place on June 5 at the New York State Theater, in a gala tribute to him. Pacific Northwest, founded in 1972, is currently directed by the former City Ballet dancers Kent Stowell and Francia Russell. It is considered a major American ballet troupe, both artistically and in terms of its performance schedule and repertory. Mr. Boal, 39, was chosen from a field of nearly 50 applicants after he worked with the Seattle dancers in October. He is one of City Ballet's purest and most intelligent classicists, though he has performed in modern-dance works, most notably by Molissa Fenley. Mr. Boal is also a popular boys' teacher at the company-affiliated School of American Ballet. JENNIFER DUNNING

description: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan said he had been given reports of sexual abuse of women and children by United Nations peacekeepers in Congo and was dispatching an investigative team immediately. "I am afraid there is clear evidence that acts of gross misconduct have taken place," he said in a statement. "This is a shameful thing for the United Nations to have to say, and I am absolutely outraged by it. I have long made it clear that my attitude to sexual exploitation and abuse is one of zero tolerance, with no exception." There are 10,000 peacekeepers in Congo, and Mr. Annan's spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said 70 complaints had been lodged, about 20 of which had been found to be "actionable." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Kerry Pledges To Stay The Fight
description: Though he lost the race for president, Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, told supporters he would remain a strong voice challenging President Bush and the Republican majorities in Congress. "Despite the words of cooperation and moderate-sounding promise, this administration is planning a right-wing assault on values and ideals we hold most deeply," Mr. Kerry said in an e-mail message to supporters. "Healthy debate and diverse opinion are being eliminated from the State Department and C.I.A., and the cabinet is being remade to rubber stamp policies that will undermine Social Security, balloon the deficit, avoid real reforms in health care and education, weaken homeland security and walk away from critical allies." On the first day of the new Congress, he said, he will introduce a bill to provide health insurance to "every child in America." Suzy DeFrancis, a White House spokeswoman, declined to respond to the e-mail message's specifics. "The election is over and now is the time to put aside differences and work together for the good of the American people," she said. Steven A. Holmes (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; TV Ratings: CBS on Top
description: A CBS sweep must mean it's Thursday night. And so it was, according to Nielsen's overnight ratings, that CBS's "Survivor," "CSI" and "Without a Trace" each won in its time slot on Thursday, as each typically does. On ABC, "Primetime Live" got a bump from its usual number because of Diane Sawyer's interview with Prince Harry. Fox's trendsetting "O.C." dropped nearly a million viewers from its previous two episodes. After more than two weeks of sweeps, CBS is far ahead, which is no surprise. But no one could have predicted that the season-to-date ratings would have NBC, Fox and even the formerly underestimated ABC in such a close race for second place. Through last week's numbers, the three networks are separated by only three-tenths of a ratings point, and Fox is in the running only because of its successful weeks of postseason baseball. January cannot come quickly enough for Fox, as that will bring the return of last season's No. 1 show: "American Idol." KATE AURTHUR

description: The South Korean economy grew at a rate of 4.6 percent in the third quarter, down from 5.5 percent the prior quarter, the Bank of Korea said. The rate is probably too slow to enable the country to reach the government's goal of growing 5 percent for the year, Lee Hun Jai, the finance minister, said at a news briefing. Export growth fell to 0.4 percent from 1 percent and private consumption showed a slight decline. The bank, which is the nation's central bank, cut interest rates last week to encourage consumption, but Mr. Jai forecast that the growth rate would drop in the fourth quarter. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Kinsey' Ads Nixed From WNET
description: Adding to the controversy surrounding Fox Searchlight's "Kinsey," WNET, New York City's public television station, has declined to broadcast ads for the film about Alfred C. Kinsey, the sex researcher of the 1940's and 50's. According to a spokesman for Fox Searchlight, the station rejected the spot because of the content of the film and fear of viewer backlash. But Stella Giammasi, a spokeswoman for WNET, Channel 13, said: "We turned down the spot because it was too commercial and too provocative." She declined to elaborate on what "too provocative" meant. "It was not because the movie is controversial," she said. "We deal with controversial material every day." The ad is the same one being shown on network and cable stations. KCET, the Los Angeles member station of PBS, will begin broadcasting the ad on Monday. Though public stations do not carry traditional ads, they broadcast "enhanced underwriting spots," which do not explicitly sell products. WNET has broadcast such spots for movies in the past, including two dozen 30-second spots last summer for Fox Searchlight's "Clearing," for which the station received $45,000, according to the studio spokesman. After its initial release in New York and Los Angeles last weekend, "Kinsey," starring Liam Neeson, opened yesterday in 11 additional cities. JOEL TOPCIK

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Rules Province Need Not Finance Autism Treatment
description: The Supreme Court ruled that British Columbia is not obligated to provide autistic children with an intensive and costly form of early treatment known as Lovaas therapy. The decision overturned two lower-court rulings that sided with a group of parents who argued that denying their autistic children full public financial aid for the treatment is discriminatory. The case had raised concern among provincial governments, which argued that paying for such treatment could cost hundreds of millions of dollars each year, overwhelming the public health care system and opening the door to lawsuits by people with a variety of disabilities. In its decision, the court said the treatment was not a core service guaranteed under Canadian law. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; A Puffy Gift From Jerry Seinfeld
description: In Washington the uniform is generally a dark suit, a white shirt and a quiet tie. So the newest donation to the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History -- Jerry Seinfeld's puffy shirt, right -- will probably draw some attention. Mr. Seinfeld went to Washington on Thursday to deliver a piece of television history, the foppishly ruffled shirt he wore in episode 66 of "Seinfeld." In the show, Jerry unwittingly agrees to wear the shirt on the "Today" show and is told by Bryant Gumbel during their interview, "You could be the first pirate comedian." Mr. Seinfeld, 50, also gave the museum the script of the episode, called, fittingly, "The Puffy Shirt," written by the show's co-creator, Larry David. The shirt will go on display on Wednesday in the exhibition "Icons of Popular Culture," alongside Kermit the Frog and Dorothy's ruby slippers from "The Wizard of Oz." The DVD editions of the first three seasons of "Seinfeld" go on sale Tuesday. JOHN FILES

description: With nearly all the votes counted in the San Diego mayor's race, the incumbent, Dick Murphy, is holding a slim lead over Donna Frye, a maverick member of the City Council and co-owner of a surf shop who ran as a write-in candidate. As of yesterday morning, Mr. Murphy, a Republican, held a 2,749-vote margin over Ms. Frye, a Democrat, out of more than 310,000 certified ballots. But Ms. Frye and her supporters argue that several thousand votes clearly intended for her were discarded because the ballots were not properly filled out. A lawsuit filed by Frye supporters challenging the method county elections officials used to tally the votes will be heard on Monday. A second lawsuit, filed by Murphy backers, questions the legality of Ms. Frye's write-in candidacy; it will be heard on Nov. 30. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Not Every Picture Tells a Story
description: Cambridge, Mass. - All of life seems to be about denial the denial of death, the denial of reality, the denial of everything that it is convenient for us to deny. Photography, because of its causal relationship to the world, seems to give us the truth or something close to the truth. I am skeptical about this for many reasons. But even if photography doesn't give us truth on a silver platter, it does make it harder for us to deny reality. It puts a leash on fantasy, confabulation and self-deception. It provides constraints and borders. It circumscribes our ability to lie -- to ourselves and to others.

But what is clear is that less than a month after Hewitt and the Belgian tennis star Kim Clijsters announced the end of their engagement and relationship, Hewitt is playing here in the Masters Cup with the sort of precision and controlled fury reminiscent of much better days.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: $4.25 Million Settlement In Bonfire Lawsuit
description: The families of four students who were killed and three who were injured when a pile of 5,000 logs for a bonfire at Texas A&M University collapsed five years ago will share a $4.25 million settlement, a lawyer for some plaintiffs in the resulting lawsuit said. Claims by other victims or their estates against the university, its officers and contractors are in mediation. A consultant's report blamed faulty assembly of the nearly 60-foot-tall woodpile and inadequate supervision for the accident. Most of the 12 people killed and the 27 injured were students. A huge bonfire before the A&M-University of Texas football game had been a campus tradition, but was suspended after the 1999 accident. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the industrial designer W. Dorwin Teague on Sept. 26 credited an innovation to him erroneously. Mr. Teague invented a fully reclining dental chair, which was first manufactured in 1959 and received patents in 1961 and 1962, but it was not the first such chair. At least one appeared ahead of his: In 1958, John Naughton marketed a reclining dental chair of a different design. He received a patent in 1965. Mr. Naughton's son alerted The Times to the error last month, and this correction was delayed for research.

title: HUD Audits Housing Group in Newark
description: NEWARK, Nov. 19 - Investigators from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development are reviewing the Newark Housing Authority's finances after reports earlier this fall raised questions about spending at the agency.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hunt Ban Challenged
description: Pro-hunt campaigners began legal moves to overturn Parliament's decision to outlaw hunting with dogs beginning in February. The Countryside Alliance, a coalition of pro-hunting and outdoors groups, said it believed that the Parliament Act, the legislation used to push through the ban late Thursday, was invalid. The act has been invoked just four times since it became law in 1949. Hunters are threatening to ignore the ban altogether. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Violence Surges Through Central and Northern Iraq
description: AGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 20 - Violence surged through central and northern Iraq on Saturday as a tenacious insurgency led by Sunni Arabs kept up relentless assaults in a string of major cities, from Ramadi to Falluja to Baghdad.

title: OHIO IS SUING FANNIE MAE FOR SECURITIES FRAUD
description: Fannie Mae, the home mortgage company, was sued yesterday for securities fraud by the attorney general of Ohio, who accused the company of manipulating its earnings to inflate artificially the price of its common stock. The suit was filed on behalf of the Ohio Public Employees Retirement System, the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio and the Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation, according to the attorney general, Jim Petro. Mr. Petro was seeking class-action status for the suit, which would enable him to proceed on behalf of investors who held Fannie Mae shares during the period of the suspected fraud. Franklin Raines, the chief executive of Fannie Mae; and its chief financial officer; and its controller were named as defendants in the suit, which was filed in United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio in Columbus. Brian Faith, a Fannie Mae spokesman, declined to comment on the suit. Fannie Mae is based in Washington.

title: National Briefing | West: California: A Fight Over Logging In Sierra Nevada
description: The state's attorney general threatened to sue the Bush administration if a newly approved federal land management plan for the Sierra Nevada is not revised to reduce the amount of logging in the mountains. The attorney general, Bill Lockyer, a Democrat, accused the Bush administration of a "full-speed retreat from environmental protection." He said the plan, which covers 11.5 million acres, would increase commercial logging, endanger wildlife habitat, reduce water quality and weaken grazing restrictions. The Bush administration has defended the increased logging as a way to reduce fire danger. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Swift Satellite To Be Launched Today
description: After technical delays, two hurricanes, a tornado and last-minute rocket problems, NASA said that it expected to launch Swift, a satellite designed to shed light on mysterious flashes coming from the depths of the cosmos, today from Cape Canaveral, Fla. Swift got its name from its ability to position itself rapidly to record images of the flares and their afterglow so scientists can determine their origin. Called gamma-ray bursts, these phenomena are the most powerful explosions in the universe other than the big bang, the theorized beginning of time and space. The $250 million satellite and mission are a joint effort of NASA, Britain and Italy. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

Both the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera typically rotate their programs nightly, so the stagehands start dismantling the previous night's show at 8 a.m. They work through the day's rehearsals, and then they set up for the evening performance, which ends between 10 and 11 p.m.

title: Yehuda Amichai: Posthumous Fragments
description: Not long before Yehuda Amichai died in September 2000, his papers were deposited at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale University. On a wintry day last year I traveled to New Haven to meet Chana Amichai, his widow and executor and sharer in all things, in that hushed shrine to writing and reading, so as to have a look at some of the boxes that held the poet's literary remains. We found a rich mess of notes and jottings, a treasury of first thoughts and first words that brought the uninhibited mind of a great poet fiercely to life. What follows are translations from the inspired scraps in just one of the boxes.

title: 'Facing Poverty With a Rich Girl's Habits'
description: QUEENS in the early 80's struck me as the Wild West. Our first home there was the upstairs of a two-family brownstone in Woodside. It was a crammed, ugly place, I thought, because in South Korea I had been raised in a hilltop mansion with an orchard and a pond and peacocks until I entered the seventh grade, when my millionaire father lost everything overnight. Gone in an instant was my small world, made possible by my father's shipping company, mining business and hotels. Because bankruptcy was punishable by a jail term, we fled, penniless, to America.

description: The first time Jin Auyeung heard LL Cool J's "Mama Said Knock You Out," he fell in love. It was the mid-90's, the latter years of hip-hop's golden age. But Jin was about as far from the hip-hop nation as you could get. He was 12 years old, growing up in North Miami Beach, the son of hard-working young immigrants from South China who owned a strip-mall Chinese restaurant. Before discovering LL Cool J, his musical tastes consisted of New Kids on the Block and, he says, "a lot of Michael Jackson."

title: Beyond 'Call It Sleep': New Immigrant Classics
description: FOR past generations, the bedrock accounts of the immigrant experience in New York described the lives of newcomers from Eastern Europe and carried titles like "Call It Sleep," by Henry Roth (1934), "A Walker in the City," by Alfred Kazin (1951) and "World of Our Fathers," by Irving Howe (1976). In the last quarter century, however, the literary melting pot has been spiced with fresh voices from Korea, Cuba, Mexico, Russia and beyond, even as the dreams and struggles they chronicle echo those of their predecessors.

title: Fix Today's System First

Even the fare increases that have been postponed would have been only a modest down payment on the huge bill to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINTZ, WALTER
description: MINTZ--Walter. Died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday, November 16, 2004 after a long illness. He was the dearly loved husband of Sandra Earl Mintz. Born February 23, 1929 in Vienna, Austria the son of the late Maximillian and Ilse Schueller Mintz, he came to the United States with his family in 1938. After attending public schools in the Bronx, he graduated from Reed College in Portland, Oregon in 1950, and then did post-graduate work in economics at Columbia University. He was an Associate Editor at Barron's before he began his career in the investment business at Shearson Hammill Co. in 1956. There, he was the Director of Research, 1962-69, and Executive Vice President of their Investment Division, 1965-70. In 1970, he co-founded Cumberland Associates, an investment management company in New York. He retired as a Managing partner from that firm in 1982, remaining a special limited partner. Mr. Mintz was a Trustee of Reed College for 33 years, 1971-2003. He was Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, 1991-98, and Chairman 1998-2002. He established the Walter Mintz Economics Scholarship for students, and co-sponsored a Chair in Economic History. In New York, he was a Trustee of The Manhattan Institute, 1990-2003, and served as Vice Chairman, 1994-2003. He was also on the Boards of Merrill Lynch Phoenix Fund and Federal Security Trust, 1982-2001; on the Board of the Citizen's Union Foundation, 1985-2003, and was a member of the N.Y. Society of Security Analysts, where he served on their Board of Directors, 196975. In addition to his wife of 33 years, he is survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Marjorie and Dr. Joseph K. Perloff, and their two daughters, Nancy and Carey, all of California. Services were privately held, but it is hoped that all who knew him will set aside some time to remember his great ability to think and reason fairly; his enjoyment of life and his work; his good nature, compassion and generous spirit. He cherished his friends and was grateful for them.

title: Message in a Bottle
description: Nalgene Bottle It's not so unusual for a product designed for one audience to get adopted by another one. Think of gentlemanly Burberry becoming a hip-hop fashion staple, Viking ranges meant for restaurants crossing over into domestic use or Jeeps and Hummers driving straight from their origins on rugged battlefields into every neatly paved suburb of America. But it is a bit unusual for this to happen twice. The official story of the Nalgene Outdoor bottle began more than 50 years ago when a Rochester chemist created a line of polyethylene lab equipment. It was good, solid stuff. Then some outdoorsy scientists and eventually even Boy Scouts started using some of the bottles to tote water and other things on hikes and camping trips. And thus the first leap: selling bottles to a whole new customer base.

title: The Price of Oil
description: It has been decades since painting was the center of the modern art universe, but you might not know it from current prices for new works. Paintings at commercial galleries in Chelsea rarely dip below $2,000, though you may find less expensive ones at cooperative galleries like Blue Mountain and First Street. At the high end, works by blue-chip artists can exceed $500,000. But there's plenty available for four and five figures, as this selection of paintings for sale right now suggests. KEN JOHNSON

description: IF every film has a moment at which it was truly born, the time arrived for "Beyond the Sea" at 3 p.m. on Oct. 1, 1999, at L'Ermitage Hotel in Beverly Hills.

title: Super Trees
description: ON a fenced-in lot contaminated by mercury in Danbury, once the site of several hat factories, Jack Kozuchowski is singing the praises of some scrawny cottonwood trees. It is chilly out and drizzling rain, but the city's environmental chief seems not to notice, so excited is he about the potential of these saplings.

title: Treated Like Gentry in Scotland
description: PART of the appeal of a country-house hotel is the illusion that it's not a hotel at all, just a large, well-run home staffed by an ad hoc family. Unlike your own, these are relatives you can abandon without a care, but it still pays to consider your options.

title: Who's the Longest of Them All?
description: IN the never-ending debate over whether size matters, enter two unlikely contestants from opposite sides of the country: Long Island, 118 miles long, and Whidbey Island, in Washington, a mere 45 miles long. At stake are bragging rights to being the longest island in the contiguous United States.

title: The Poetry Symposium
description: The Book Review recently asked a handful of poets and critics to respond to this question: What book of poetry, published in the last 25 years, has meant the most to you personally -- the book you have found yourself returning to again and again? We asked them not to select reissues, or volumes of a poet's "selected" or "collected" work. Here are their responses:

title: Fine Crafts in India Go the Way of Fairy Soap
description: NEW DELHI - DEPENDING on one's viewpoint, the advance of the global luxury trade is either an inevitability or a cause for gloom. Four centuries ago the British East India Company arrived on the Indian subcontinent to establish an export business in rare spices, silks and cotton. It did not take long before the company reversed the flow and began importing first goods, then culture, then government to a vast captive market in India.

title: High Maintenance for High Fashion
description: Luxury clothing deserves luxury care, say Gwen Whiting and Lindsey Wieber, the 28-year-old fashion enthusiasts behind the Laundress, a collection of high-end cleaning and care products for high-end clothes. Their line is divided into two categories: detergents (soaps for whites, darks, delicates, swimwear, cashmere and baby clothes) and fabric care (stain solution, wrinkle spray, odor remover, static guard, ironing water, starch and fabric conditioner). Each product comes in a choice of scents like citrus, lavender, cedarwood oil and amber. Prices in both categories range from $4 for a 2-ounce travel-size flask to $18 for a 32-ounce bottle. The line is available at Malia Mills in New York (212-625-2311) and Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Music for the Animals
description: Music for the Animals TODAY -- A chamber music concert with musicians from the New York Philharmonic at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, will benefit the Artemis Project, which pays for spaying and neutering stray animals and for other veterinary services. The concert begins at 3. Suggested donation is $20. Information from: (917)648-6020.

title: Fix Today's System First
description: Commuters in the New York area are expected to sigh with relief now that proposed fare and toll increases have been cut back from horrific to unwelcome. That lukewarm news, however, obscures a far more important point. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority still faces a $436 million deficit this fiscal year, and that shortfall could triple next year. Even the fare increases that have been postponed would have been only a modest down payment on the huge bill to come.

title: PHOTO-OP
The Unmistakable Allure of Long Island's Early Wine
description: IF you momentarily forgot that Thursday is Thanksgiving, the signs plastered in wine merchants' windows provide a seasonal reminder: "Le Beaujolais nouveau est arriv." But why turn to France for wines made from grapes picked just weeks ago?

title: Where Everyone Is the Teacher's Pet
description: Cherry Hill - EACH night, all around the state, as porch lights click on and dogs beg to be walked, people are scurrying home from work, skipping supper and leaving their children in the clutches of the baby sitter. All for the sake of education.

title: Do-It-Yourself Denim
description: The perfect pair of jeans is not always a matter of cash. Sometimes a little handiwork makes all the difference. With this in mind, J. Crew has come out with the Personalize-It Kit, a neatly boxed patch set designed to help repair and embellish worn bluejeans. The kit ($40 at www.jcrew.com) includes patches in Italian silks, English tweeds and Liberty of London prints, as well as sewing needles, how-to cards, grosgrain ribbons and embroidery flosses in multiple colors. There are also two sheets of sandpaper, for accelerating wear and tear on knees, thighs and seat. Even the illusion of a perfect backside, it seems, requires a modicum of elbow grease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SINGER, RUTH (SHAPIRO)
description: SINGER--Ruth (Shapiro). On November 18, 2004. Widow of the late Max Singer and longtime companion of the late Louis Cantor, both attorneys. Much beloved mother of Stephanie and Lise, grandmother of Gillian Wander, mother-in-law of John DeGroat and sister of Beatrice Fischer, Jack Shapiro and Francine Ellmann. Ruth was an accomplished sculptor, the President of the New York Browning Society, a lover of language, wit, conversation, art, poetry and song. Treasured aunt, great-aunt and friend. She will be sadly missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Sunday, 11:15 a.m. at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Wafting in the Cafe, Smoke of an Argileh, (It's Hookah to You)
description: Of the several cafes along Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, where Arab immigrants and Arab-Americans gather, the Arabesque Cafe and Bazaar draws a consistently younger crowd of card-players and argileh (hookah) smokers.

title: When a Video Game Stops Being Fun
description: CHARLES DICKENS himself would shudder, I should think, were he to see the way young adults are put to work in one semimodern corner of our economy. Gas lamps are long gone, and the air is free of soot. But you can't look at a place like Electronic Arts, the world's largest developer of entertainment software, and not think back to the early industrial age when a youthful work force was kept fully occupied during all waking hours to enrich a few elders.

The movie has reignited one of the oldest debates about child-rearing and society: competition versus coddling, excellence versus egalitarianism.

title: 'Where Is Home, If the Place You Come From No Longer Exists?'
description: WHAT does it mean to be from a place that is no longer on the map? My homeland, the Soviet Union, disintegrated in late 1991, a scant three years after my family had managed to escape its anti-Semitism and lack of opportunity. As an immigrant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, with a funny haircut and even funnier clothes, I tended to worry more about fitting in than the place where those clothes had come from.

title: Sichuan Signature for a Chinese Kitchen
description: YONKERS - HUNAN Village, despite its name, has branched out into Sichuan, with the installation of a new chef. Although old favorites still dot the menu, serious diners should be prepared to discover a few new tastes. The key to dining here is first to confer with the owner, Paul Chou, or with one of his helpful servers. Always searching for new ingredients, Mr. Chou is passionate about food and is dedicated to inventiveness, a much prized tradition in Chinese kitchens. It has been said that the art of Chinese cooking is the art of mixing, or combining careful proportions of whatever ingredients happen to be at hand. Hunan Village mixes with the best of them.

description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 20 - Through 12 holes on Saturday, Annika Sorenstam's temper was running as hot as the Florida sun. Her three-stroke lead had disappeared. She had yet to make a birdie. The third round of the season-ending ADT Championship had become a grind for her, and a lesser player may have failed to regroup.

description: The Montreal director Franois Girard has worked in film ("The Red Violin," "32 Short Films About Glenn Gould"), opera (a critically acclaimed "Oedipus Rex" with the Canadian Opera Company) and theater. description: The classical Greek word for poet means "maker"; its Latin counterpart, "vates," also means "prophet," implying not craft but spirit or inspiration. Readers since antiquity have asked whether true poetry comes from diligent artifice, or from powers outside the poet's control. The best poems, now as ever, evidence both: they are at once inventions and discoveries.

title: The Other National Conversation
description: Prayers of petition (for oneself) should not be conflated with prayers of intercession (for others, in sorrow, need or sickness). It should be apparent that if prayers of intercession are presumptuous (because a just God has already resolved to take the action prayed for), then so are personal ministries of voluntary service or charitable donations (because they may usurp God's plans). Further, prayers of petition (for ourselves or for those so close to us that their sorrows and needs afflict us as well) should not be confused with letters to Santa Claus. Instead, they are an acknowledgment that we have done all we can, it has not been enough and help is needed.

description: THE top reason successful applicants to the University of Connecticut decline to attend, according to a recent university survey, is because there "is nothing to do at Storrs."

title: The 2004 Vintage, Made by Many Hands
description: CUTCHOGUE - HER hands slick with juice, Alicia Morataya gently cradled a plump cluster of deep purple grapes in one hand and flicked off a few withered berries with the other. Then she snipped the cluster off the vine and dropped it softly into the nearly full bin at her feet. Continuously bent at the waist, she stepped sideways, flicking and snipping and dropping until she reached the end of the row. Bins piled high with cabernet franc grapes lined the grass alley behind her.

title: Lessons in Civics, And Indian Point
description: GREENBURGH - WITH notebooks and legal pads at the ready, and neatly photocopied documents and binders in front of them, the group who gathered not long ago at the Greenburgh Town Hall looked like any other serious-minded panel planning a forum on a compelling civic issue. In this case it was whether closing Indian Point would really make Westchester safer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, HAZEL K.
description: JOHNSON--Hazel K. June 8, 1919-October 2, 2004. Died at home in Manhattan of lung cancer. Pianist and organist, musicologist, teacher, improviser and (on occasion) composer of music to accompany modern dance. B.A., 1941, Western College, Oxford, OH; M.A., Brooklyn College. She is survived by her sister Annabelle Garetz of California, and by numerous nephews, nieces and grandnephews, and a grandniece. As announced in the initial, much more complete death notice, which appeared in the New York Times on Sunday, October 17, 2004 and is included in the Times' Web archive: a Memorial Service will be held 2:00 PM, Saturday, December 4, 2004 at Church of the Holy Apostles (Episcopalian), 296 Ninth Avenue (at 28th Street), NY, NY 10001 (212-807-6799), with reception to follow at the Church. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made in her name to Church of the Holy Apostles, or to the charity of your choice.

title: States' Tactics Aim to Reduce Drug Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 - Alarmed at soaring pharmaceutical costs, states are trying a wide range of new tactics to curb spending on prescription drugs for Medicaid recipients, public employees, prisoners and other residents, bringing them into lobbying combat with the drug industry.

title: Maria Clifford, Brad Van Lenten
description: Maria Luisa Clifford, the daughter of Raymond Clifford of St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., and the late Margherita Clifford, was married on Friday to Brad Allen Van Lenten, the son of Francesca Van Lenten of Paterson, N.J., and Bruce Van Lanten of Shohola, Pa. The Rev. Patrick J. Scott officiated at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Pompton Plains, N.J.

title: 'Second Space': The Captive Body
description: SECOND SPACE New Poems. By Czeslaw Milosz. Translated by the author and Robert Hass. 102 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $23.95.

title: In the Path of the Buddha
description: THE Buddha (circa 563-483 B.C.) was not depicted in human form for some 400 years after his death. He was represented, instead, by various symbols, like a wheel, a shrine, a tree and footprints adorned with the marks of his divine nature. These footprints became a popular symbol across the Buddhist world for his earthly presence, and continued to be made and revered after images of him became widespread.

title: Incentive Program Is Putting Doctors Where the Need Is
description: After finishing her medical residency four years ago, Dr. Teresa Chan headed straight for the job she had always wanted: working as a family doctor serving a poor immigrant population at a Lower East Side health clinic.

title: A Thriving Mosque, Built on a Dream
description: The Albanian Islamic Cultural Center in Tompkinsville, Staten Island, founded by immigrants from Kosovo, is one of the city's largest mosques.

title: Copenhagen
description: Copenhagen is the largest city in Scandinavia, so it seems a natural showcase for the classical Nordic virtues: cool beauty and elegant restraint coupled with a firm shunning of pretension. The city shows none of the easy arm-waving affability and public passion of Mediterranean parts, and heaven knows there's precious little of that southern heat. But time spent here takes us other places as well -- to a culture that fights its own inner demons of self-control and cold efficiency, a culture that adores full-speed-ahead innovation and, especially, the warmth of emotional closeness.

title: Men of the Cloth
description: As a wearer of bespoke suits, I was appalled at the picture in your feature on men's suits (Style, Nov. 7). If the puckers in the suits worn by Duncan Quinn and Thom Browne were not bad enough, what kind of tailoring is Browne trying to evoke with those high-water pants? I'll stick to my own no-name-recognition tailor, who would go out of business if that was the best he could do.

title: Henry Clay Hated It. So Does Bill Frist.
description: Washington - "Half of official Washington is here to see democracy's finest show, the filibuster. The right to talk your head off! The American privilege of free speech in its most dramatic form!" -- A reporter in the climactic scene of "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington," 1939.

title: Corrections

title: Yanks Hesitant About Martnez
description: The Yankees often telegraph their off-season strategy months in advance, sending signals to the rest of baseball that a certain free agent is all theirs. But in the case of starter Pedro Martnez, the Yankees seem hesitant.

title: The New Guy
description: James Levine has finally arrived as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, prepared to restore the luster some feel it lost in its later years under Seiji Ozawa and to revitalize its programming with a healthy dose of contemporary music. Joe Mader talked to audience members about the prospects for Mr. Levine's regime on Nov. 11 at Symphony Hall in Boston, before and after a concert that featured a war horse (Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony) and a challenge (the Boston Symphony premiere of Elliott Carter's "Symphonia: Sum Fluxae Pretium Spei").

title: Playland And Profit: Firm Seeks A Marriage
description: A FIXTURE on the edge of Long Island Sound since 1928, Playland is home to a beach, pool, boardwalk, skating rink, miniature golf course and nature sanctuary. But the heart of the operation is the nation's only municipally owned and operated amusement park, a popular relic that has been a money loser for Westchester County for years.

title: Who's Afraid of Kmart and Sears? Not Target
description: LET'S assume that the merger of Kmart and Sears is exactly what it's being sold as: a way to combine the remaining strengths of two well-known but struggling retailers. Sears can extricate itself from shopping malls and join the exodus to large stand-alone stores, called "big boxes" in the industry. Kmart can resurrect its sullied image by bringing in some of Sears's popular brands like Craftsman tools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARRISH, MICHAEL
description: PARRISH--Michael. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Eva Alonzo and Manuel Parrish and father-in-law of John. Adoring grandfather of Steven and Porscha. Graveside service today, 10AM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale NY. For information, contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 718-377-7300.

title: 'Janet & Me'

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 - Toward the bottom of the 16-inch stack of paper called the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2005 is a list of grants for communities in Alaska: $950,000 for a recreation center and $150,000 for a botanical garden in Anchorage, $300,000 for a senior center in Fairbanks, $1 million for housing upgrades in the Kenai Peninsula, $900,000 for an aquarium in Ketchikan, $525,000 for a quarry upgrade in Nome and many more.

title: Road Trip From Glitter to Grandeur, and Back
description: Driving at night with the top dropped on our rented claret-red Chrysler convertible, we are swept up in the lights and music, the carnival air of the Las Vegas Strip. My wife, Bich Nguyen, and I love a good road trip -- even got engaged on a cross-country drive -- and we've come to this part of the Southwest for the first time, to experience the promise of the open road on an 800-mile loop around the Grand Canyon. But first we're cruising America's new Main Street, where everything's for sale and the catchier the view the sooner you'll spend your money.

title: 'A Lifetime of Living Half a Life'
description: IMMIGRATING to New York from Athens, my father promised, would make us rich. As a boy, I never fully believed him. Still, I welcomed the fantasy, not so much because I yearned for more toys or better food than my working-class parents provided me in Greece, but so that they might stop fighting.

title: The Vivaldi Hunters
description: FOR someone who composed one of the world's best-known musical scores (the contemptibly familiar "Four Seasons"), Antonio Vivaldi is a surprisingly little known composer. Only a small part of his output is performed. Much is lost. And much of what we ought to know about him remains buried at the back of cupboards in old European libraries, gathering dust.

title: Skeleton Found in Chimney Is Named and Tied to Theft
description: The police in Bridgeport said they believed a five-year-old skeleton found in the chimney of a Salvation Army Store on Nov. 11 was that of a man attempting to commit burglary.

title: Killer of Journalists Sentenced to Death
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 20 - An Afghan man was sentenced to death in a Kabul court on Saturday for his part in the killing of three foreign journalists and an Afghan photographer in November 2001 shortly after the fall of the Taliban.

title: Earned Run Average? Some Haven't Earned It and Are Only Average
description: The recent major league general managers meetings in Key Biscayne, Fla., ended up being the equivalent of most Barry Bonds at-bats: enticing home run potential, but ultimately little to connect with. No big trades, no big signings, no specifics on them whatsoever. But there was plenty of subtle gamesmanship as team officials assessed this winter's crowded class of free-agent pitchers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASPER, PAULA F.
description: CASPER--Paula F. In her 99th year -- her beauty, intel ligence, refinement and wisdom defy description. She was a gift to all who knew and loved her. Anita Kahn and Lionel Arond

title: 'No One Cared If I Kissed Girls'
description: IT still amazes me that when I am away from New York, the angles of me cry out for the subways, the impolite service industry and the streets teeming with cultural insanities. After a week in Johannesburg making metaphors into theater, or 10 days in Sydney teaching the poetics of writing the self, I can't wait to get back to Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Labor Chiefs Press El Salvador for Killers of Teamsters Organizer
description: Gilberto Soto, a union organizer in New Jersey, was so upset by the wages and working conditions of truck drivers in Central America that when he went home to visit his mother in El Salvador and celebrate his 50th birthday this month, he added a week to his vacation to go to ports to see about unionizing them.

description: COLLECTED PROSE By James Merrill. Edited by J. D. McClatchy and Stephen Yenser. 737 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: Turning Brawny Action Drama Into Sensitive Soap Opera
description: TO learn why J.J. Abrams has recently won a reputation as one of the most exhilarating storytellers in television, see the fourth episode of "Lost," the new hit castaway series Mr. Abrams co-created. The show follows the survivors of a plane crash on a tropical island, and at first it seems to feature the instantly recognizable types you'd expect in any ensemble drama, or any television show whatsoever. There's the stout-hearted hero, the plucky girl, the malcontent, the adorable child. But then there's Locke, a balding, middle-aged loner with a suitcase full of hunting knives and a penchant for making creepy pronouncements about the providential nature of the crash. He's the what -- the half-unhinged survivalist, perhaps?

description: UHLFELDER--Elaine B., 78, died at her home in New York City on November 17, 2004. Adoring wife of the late Martin; loving mother of Jill Uhlfelder and Merri Kotcher and mother-in-law of Irwin; proud grandmother of Brett and Jeffrey; devoted sister of the late Stanley Blacker; and caring aunt, sister-in-law, and friend. She will be greatly missed by many. Private graveside service. Family will receive friends at Elaine's apartment on Sunday and Monday from 1 PM to 8 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to The Chemotherapy Foundation. Mom, you will always be in our hearts.

description: By turns stately or scathing, exquisite or stark, Anthony Hecht, who died last month at 81, wrote poems of indelible distinction.

title: The Flu Hunters
description: Your article gave scant coverage to the difficulties in producing a human vaccine effective against the latest avian flu. Flu vaccines are produced in embryonated chicken eggs, which are difficult to use for H5N1 avian flu because normally the virus will kill the embryo before a fluid usable for vaccine production is made. Developing and testing new approaches, especially by inexperienced companies, would take many months, perhaps years.

description: IF Peter Sellers were still alive, he would be horrified by two of the season's most pervasive fashion trends. And they aren't the trench coats and tweed hats favored by Inspector Clouseau.

description: Carol, a 59ish-year-old friend, called to propose a camping and kayaking adventure in the Pacific Northwest.

description: GELBERG--Frederick. In memory of a man who combined the highest ideals, the keenest intellect and a piercing wit with a great heart and abounding love. A year may have passed, but we miss you more than ever. With much love, Terie and your family

title: A World Apart on China's Silk Road
description: The pounding drums drew me into the alley. Stepping off the main street, I saw an old man with a thick beard and a white skullcap sitting in front of a shop, banging an insistent, Arab-sounding rhythm on a hand drum. Next to him, a younger man with thin stubble kept up a keening wail, like a snake charmer, on a tiny flute.

description: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 21 - Voters across Ukraine returned to the polls today in the run-off presidential election between two candidates who virtually tied in the first round of voting last month, and who represent two very different courses for a nation bridging Russia and the West.

title: Spend $150 Billion Per Year to Cure World Poverty
description: Daphne Eviatar's article (Nov. 7) states that despite tremendous amounts of research, "there's little agreement on when or whether aid works." Nevertheless, Jeffrey Sachs wants to spend $150 billion per year on foreign aid. That is like going to a new automobile dealer and plunking down thousands of dollars without knowing when or if the car's engine will start. I wonder if Sachs is that carefree when spending his own money.

description: Along the No. 7 subway line, which travels between Times Square and Flushing, Queens, and has arguably the most ethnically diverse ridership in the city.

He spent the rest of his afternoon worshiping at a mosque in Brooklyn and strolling along the tree-lined streets south of Prospect Park.

description: THE fickle index finger of fashion may be most popularly identified with the spectacles that take place twice a year in New York, Milan and Paris. But for a truer model of the favor-of-the-month -- the crushing wheel that decrees who and what is in or out -- the contemporary-art auctions at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips have no peer.

title: A Lot of Brass: 76 Trombones, and More
description: Woodbridge - ONE morning a while back, Steve Dillon answered a knock on the door of his inconspicuous place of business here, and a Welshman politely asked if he was open. Mr. Dillon said yes. Then, as he looked on in amazement, 50 members of a brass band from Wales filed off a bus and into his store.

description: BAZ Luhrmann does not have an arch bone in his body: he embraces the garish cornucopia of a century and more of popular culture with a frank romanticism that is disarming and sometimes a little alarming, finding ever more sophisticated ways to be nave. His new television spot for Chanel No. 5, a tribute to the golden glory of Nicole Kidman, is a two-minute distillation of the essence of Luhrmannism, a concise, affecting prcis of just about everything he has done so far in movies and on the stage.

description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 20 - The chase is down to one race. After a season that began in February, the Nascar Nextel Cup title will finally be claimed. But in some ways, it matters little who captures the Ford 400 at Homestead-Miami Speedway on Sunday or the Cup as the points champion for the year, be it Kurt Busch, Jimmie Johnson, Jeff Gordon, Dale Earnhardt Jr. or Mark Martin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GANZ, RUTH LEONE
description: GANZ--Ruth Leone on November 16 in Long Branch, NJ, aged 85. Ruth Leone was born in New York City on December 15, 1918. She was a graduate of Ursinus College and the New York School of Social Work. Married Walter Ganz on May 17, 1947 and lived in Washington, DC where she was a social worker until her daughter Diana was born in 1949. A second daughter, Claudia, was born in 1958. The family moved to Englewood, NJ in 1960 where Ruth was active in community affairs until 1974 when Ruth and Walter moved to Aspen, Colorado. In 1989 Ruth moved to Santa Fe, NM to be with her daughter Diana who died in 1992. Ruth then moved to Long Branch, NJ. Her marriage to Walter ended in 1994. She is survived by her daughter Claudia of New York City, sister Anjette Scheiman of Palm Beach, Fla., a sister Vivien Leone of New York City and her ex-husband Walter of Santa Fe, NM. Ruth will be remembered as a highly ethical person, dedicated to important social causes and deeply devoted to the members of her family.

title: A First Snow, A First Dance
description: High School 555 in Long Island City, Queens, also known as Newcomers High School, has about 1,000 students, more than 95 percent of whom came to the United States in the last three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONE, EDWARD T.
description: CONE--Edward T. The trustees, staff and artists of The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey mourn the passing of Edward T. Cone, whose generosity made so much art and beauty possible for so many.

title: High Road
description: An eclectic mix of shoes is seen in Paris, right, and New York, left. The platform wedge is a favorite in both cities. The debate over 1930's round toe vs. 1950's pointed toe goes on. New York kicks up its heels in fur and rhinestone for evenings. High style in late 1940's Paris is echoed in ankle-high designs.

title: Following The Path Of Buddha
description: KATONAH - THE Buddha (circa 563-483 B.C.) was not depicted in human form for some 400 years after his death. He was represented, instead, by various symbols, like a wheel, a shrine, a tree and footprints adorned with the marks of his divine nature. These footprints became a popular symbol across the Buddhist world for his earthly presence, and continued to be made and revered after images of him became widespread.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 26 of Arts & Leisure today about the central characters in the three "CSI" television series misspells the surname of the creator of "CSI: Crime Scene Investigation," who is an executive producer of the shows. He is Anthony Zuiker, not Zuicker. The article also omits the given name of another executive producer and misspells her surname. She is Ann Donahue, not Donohue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINTZ, FAY (SHELDON)
description: MINTZ--Fay (Sheldon). Widow of the late New Jersey Superior Court Judge, Nelson K. Mintz, died on November 13 at her winter home in Palm Beach, Florida. Born in New York October 14, 1907, to Herbert J. and Rose L. Kirshner, she graduated from N.Y.U. in 1927 and in 1928 married her first husband, Sam Sheldon, and moved to Texas. After being widowed in 1963, she married her second husband, Judge Mintz, in 1966. She is survived by her son, Roy G. Sheldon, and his wife, Lynne, of Dallas, Texas; two nephews, William J. Levitt, Jr. and James R. Levitt, three grandchildren, six greatgrandchildren and the extended Mintz family.

title: James Is Earning His Wings
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 18 - LeBron James surged about 10 feet from the basket, grabbed the pass and levitated -- the top of the ball nearly level with the top of the backboard. For a moment, he was suspended in the rare air between prodigy and superstar.

title: Iraq Schedules National Elections for Jan. 30
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 21 - Iraqi electoral officials announced today that they had set a date of Jan. 30 for the country's first democratic elections despite a sharp rise in violence in the last month and threats of a boycott by Sunni Arab leaders.

title: Elana Monosson, Brad Fullmer
description: Elana Sokol Monosson, a former sales manager, and Brad Fullmer, a major league baseball player, are to be married today at the Auberge du Soleil, a hotel in Rutherford, Calif. Kimberly A. Thompson, a California marriage commissioner, is to officiate.

title: Park Views and a Fancy Shower Available at the San Remo
description: LIKE a leaf pressed between the pages of a book and come upon again years later, a 4,000-square-foot apartment that recently went on sale at the San Remo on Central Park West has been preserved with few changes since the majestic apartment building, designed by Emery Roth, went up in 1930. The apartment is being sold by the family of Nadia Jaglom, who lived there since about 1940 and died recently, shortly before her 105th birthday, according to Kirk Henckels, the director of Stribling Private Brokerage.

description: Weeks

title: Zambian Salaries
description: To the Editor: Like Jill Abramson, who wrote "In Zambia, Luxury Above the Torrent" (Oct. 24), my wife and I also were uncomfortable with the obsequious hospitality at the Royal Livingstone hotel in Zambia on our trip there last year. Our uneasiness turned to alarm when an employee pleaded for a tip, saying she and her children were hungry.

title: Main Street, N.J.
description: ON Halloween, Washington Street -- effectively the Main Street of Hoboken -- is so throbbing with people that, except for the costumes, it resembles the famous pictures of Manhattan on V-J day. Little kids, teenagers, grown-ups -- dressed as the Flintstones, superheroes and princesses -- fill the streets, grabbing candy from bowls held by local merchants. A Chinese restaurant hands out fortune cookies. A grown woman dressed as a pumpkin talks on her cellphone. A parade, with numerous clowns and a Grim Reaper, delights the crowd, as lunchers sitting at outdoor cafes look on.

title: Bed, Bath and Alaa
description: Azzedine Alaia's new hotel provides "what a hotel cannot offer"- the pleasure of having your own pied-a-terre without any of the responsibilities. The five-story town house, known only by its street address, comprises three self-contained apartments. It adjoins the maverick designer's rambling private domain in the Marais, which houses his atelier, warehouse and showroom, as well as his own living quarters and his boutique, open to those who know where to find it.

title: Irish Leader's Unexpected Embrace of Socialism Is Causing a Stir
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 20 - After 10 years at the helm of Ireland's dominant political party, Prime Minister Bertie Ahern marked the occasion recently with a surprising revelation -- a political coming out of sorts -- that has had Ireland in a spin.

title: Take His Wife. Please.
description: Late-night comedy writers had more than a week to make jokes about Yasir Arafat, whose death was forecast for many days before he died on Nov. 11. But how do writers make fun of a man while he's on his deathbed -- and how do they produce new jokes day after day, as their subject lingers? The answer may have less to do with Mr. Arafat than with his wife, President Bush and Uday and Qusay Hussein.

title: 4 Babies at Once? Now That's Stress
description: I had in-vitro. Usually for three weeks, you stay at home, then you can go back to work. But in my fourth week I started bleeding. The doctor said, "You are pregnant with four," and, "You are going to have to stay home, or you are going to lose them."

Benjamin (Robert). Loving grandmother of John S. and Richard L. Benjamin and proud greatgrandmother of Scott Benjamin. Services private.

title: First the Mass, Then the Fellowship
description: After a formal three-hour Mass on Sunday mornings, the congregants of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, whose services are held at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights, retreat to upstairs classrooms. There, they speak in Amharic -- the national language of Ethiopia -- study the Bible, share news from home and break bread.

description: Nancy Larrick, an educator whose poetry anthologies and widely used parent's guide helped introduce generations of children not only to reading, but also to literature, died on Nov. 14 in Winchester, Va. She was 93 and lived in Winchester.

title: 'Sliding Up a Rabbit Hole Into Wonderland'
description: IF you applied today's world headlines to this microcosmic city, it would be easy to imagine a quilt torn to shreds. What exists, instead, is a city of complex fabrics: the Chinese in Little Italy, the Colombians in Jackson Heights. This is not to say ethnic conflicts don't exist on many levels here; polka dot and kente cloth do clash. But there's as much to be said for the fine threads of daily exchanges between all these communities that hold this city together.

title: A Drinking-Water Plan By E.P.A. and Airlines
description: In response to tests conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency this summer that raised questions about the quality of drinking water on passenger aircraft (which is also used to make coffee or tea), the E.P.A. has reached agreements with 12 airlines to perform more tests and adopt new disinfection procedures for water systems.

title: Homes on the Range
description: WHITE PLAINS - SINCE 1948, countless golfers have taken their turns hitting golf balls by the bucketload onto the broad, grassy fields of the Westchester Golf Range here on Dobbs Ferry Road. Now the popular range, which neighbors and loyal customers rallied to save from becoming the site of Greenburgh's new town hall two years ago, is set to give way to new homes.

description: I wasn't terribly upset about the "Monday Night Football" spectacle featuring Eagles receiver Terrell Owens and a towel-clad Nicollette Sheridan. What grabbed my attention was that it upset Tony Dungy, the coach of the Indianapolis Colts.

title: The Incredible Pietro
description: The Yonkers Board of Education has a new senior accountant. His name is Pietro Barberi. He is one amazing -- and mysterious -- civil servant.

title: Who Lost Ohio?
description: 5:30 a.m. One of the worst days of Steve Bouchard's 36 years on the planet began, as it would end, in a bleak, second-floor banquet room on Main Street in Columbus. Someone must have thought the exposed brick walls and copper piping would give the room a contemporary feel, but the effect was undone by a sad little mirror ball overhanging a miniature dance floor. "This is what I'm talking about," Bouchard said, sipping from a takeout coffee cup and gesturing at the lights. "Doesn't this just bring you back to your Studio 54 days?" It was Election Day in Ohio, and a jumbo flat-screen TV had already been wheeled into place for the Democrats who would gather here, some 15 hours later, to watch the presidential returns come in.

title: Imagining How Powell Might Still Have a Job
description: WASHINGTON - COLIN POWELL'S taste in verse runs to naughty calypso and Broadway lyrics, not John Greenleaf Whittier, the 19th-century Quaker abolitionist and poet who famously wrote: "For of all sad words of tongue or pen, the saddest are these: 'It might have been!"' But it seems probable, as he ends his tenure as the 65th secretary of state, that Mr. Powell would second that emotion.

title: Descent of Ivory Coast
description: For more than three decades after gaining independence in 1960, Ivory Coast was West Africa's greatest economic success story. Now the country is tearing itself apart in ways that threaten to spread havoc and refugees across an already ravaged region. The world needs to look at why, and take urgent steps to contain this tragedy.

description: Montclair - A GOOD independent bookstore is a revelation and a seduction, an oasis in the cultural desert that serves up an idiosyncratic eternity of books. There is literary magic, too, in the requisite cobwebs and lit-grit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENACH, SONIA THEA (NEE EISENSTADT)
description: BENACH--Sonia Thea (nee Eisenstadt). Died on November 18, 2004, following her heroic battle with Alzheimer's. She is survived by her loving husband of 56 years, Bob, children Wayne and Michele, Jana and David, four granddaughters and two greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be on Sunday, November 21, at 11 am, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

Oransky and Dr. Stanley H. Oransky of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Kopi Saltman is to officiate at the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: Cell Connections Head Out to Sea
description: ADAM SHARPLES, a technology consultant in Manchester, England, was on the second evening of a weeklong Mediterranean cruise on the Island Escape last month when, on the way to dinner, he glanced at his cellphone and saw something peculiar: a text message from a friend, saying he had made it safely to Kuala Lumpur.

title: Long Island, Rethought
description: What's happening on Long Island? Drive around, and everything still looks pretty much the same: house, driveway, house, driveway. Deli, nail salon, pizza, Chinese. Navigator, Explorer, Explorer, Suburban.

title: At Barred Building, a Festering Issue
description: MOUNT VERNON - FOR the 80 families recently evicted from an unsafe apartment building on West First Street and South Ninth Avenue here, crumbling plaster and leaky bathroom fixtures had been the norm all along, and Mayor Ernest D. Davis said last week that despite the city's awareness of those conditions, officials had been reluctant to turn the residents out onto the street.

title: In the War Zone, It Won't Be the Day to Diet
description: But what happens to the leftovers?

title: Perpetuating Stereotypes About Women and Athletics
description: Impressionable children all over America were led to believe last week that N.F.L. security was not the airtight shield it had been made out to be. Imagine the pre-adolescent shock when it was revealed that a towel-clad temptress could stalk a certified football star -- on game night, in prime time -- within the sanctity of his private dressing domain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANLY, WILLIAM
description: MANLY--William. March 14, 1932--November 6th, 2004. Artist of Olive, NY and Myrtle Beach, SC. Lovingly remembered for gentle strength and luminous paintings.

title: Gaming
description: Interrogated this year by U.S. investigators in his Iraq prison cell about prewar U.N. inspections, Tariq Aziz quoted Saddam Hussein as having told his manipulative Higher Committee in 2002, " 'These people are playing a game with us -- we'll play a game with them.' "

title: Dominique De Palma, Anton Srdanovic
description: Dominique De Palma and Anton Srdanovic were married yesterday at SS. Cyril & Methodius Church and St. Raphael's Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Ivica Majstorovic, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Masterpiece Around the Corner
description: Correction Appended

title: Reaching the Ruins Of Yucatn by Rail
description: Until recently, traveling through the Yucatn Peninsula in search of Maya ruins usually required long trips through the jungle in passenger vans or buses. Now there is Expreso Maya, a shiny train with four air-conditioned passenger cars, each equipped with 64 reclining upholstered seats, along with a dining car and a club car stocked with books about the area's history and culture.

title: Some Executives Can't Take a Hint
description: CQ">Walt Disney Company shareholders might have done a double take when their chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, testified in court last week about the brief tenure of his friend, Michael S. Ovitz, as company president. Investors are suing Disney's directors for giving Mr. Ovitz $140 million as they pushed him out the door 14 months after they had hired him.

title: The Magic Mix That Is Trinidad
description: Here, try a bite of this," says Piero Guerrini, holding out a Chinese wax apple. It's small as a plum and has a light, almost ethereal taste. It's far more delicate than the other fruits Guerrini had offered my wife, Louise, and me during the impromptu fruit tastings at his beachfront hotel. (I can much recommend the abui, with pulp as dense and sweet as custard.) I so looked forward to Guerrini's unannounced appearances at our breakfast table, with his exotic fruits and sharp knife, that I suspect my first response to a knife-wielding attacker will now be to salivate.

title: The Picnic That Never Was
description: PHOTOGRAPHS may correspond to the way things actually look in the world, but optical precision is not the same thing as reality. In the art world, the truth-telling capabilities of photography are tethered less to fact than to ideas about perception, emotion and cultural evolution. If documentary work shows us that life may be stranger than fiction, recent conceptual photography counters that fabrication may be truer than life.

title: Seven Ways to Save on Taxes (Just Don't Wait Until 2005)
description: BECAUSE tax rates have declined on investment income, it is easy for investors to think that taxes aren't a big deal anymore -- and that traditional year-end tax moves are less important than they were in the past.

With a flagpole out front and handsome potted evergreens, it fits right in with its neighbors, Nico's Barbershop on one side and a 40's era two-family clapboard house on the other.

title: Mrs. Chippy, R.I.P.
description: Karori Cemetery, in a suburb of Wellington, New Zealand, is a pilgrimage site for enthusiasts of the heroic age of Antarctic expedition. It contains the graves of two members of Sir Ernest Shackleton's ill-fated 1914 Endurance expedition, from which all the crew were rescued. Two of the survivors, Thomas Orde-Lees and Henry McNish, known as Chippy, are buried there. Orde-Lees was the supply officer. McNish was the expedition's carpenter, best known for the fact, commemorated on his headstone (where his name appears as "McNeish"), that he was one of the five men who accompanied Shackleton in a 22-foot-long open boat on its 800-mile voyage through the South Atlantic to South Georgia Island in search of help. Indeed, the argument can be made that it was McNish who made the voyage possible, since it was he who refitted the boat for its remarkable ordeal.

title: Some Executives Can't Take a Hint
description: Walt Disney Company shareholders might have done a double take when their chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, testified in court last week about the brief tenure of his friend, Michael S. Ovitz, as company president. Investors are suing Disney's directors for giving Mr. Ovitz $140 million as they pushed him out the door 14 months after they had hired him.

Ludicrous as it sounds, 66 ABC affiliates revolted against their own network and refused to broadcast "Saving Private Ryan." The reason: fear. Not fear of terrorism or fear of low ratings but fear that their own government would punish them for exercising freedom of speech.

title: The Costume Designer
description: When dressing actors for a movie, Jill Newell, a costume designer, thinks of clothes in sociological, not style, terms. "I love getting immersed in a subject and building characters," said Ms. Newell, a 34-year-old Brooklynite, whose credits include "Raising Victor Vargas," "Love Liza," "Undertow" and "Shall Not Want," coming next year and starring Maggie Gyllenhaal. "To find the most authentic pieces," she said, "I shop where I think the characters would shop." For "Saving Face," a coming Chinese-American film starring Joan Chen, Ms. Newell scoured the Flushing Mall in Queens.

I'm just doing my part to tell them that I appreciate their service. Perhaps when they return, I can swap this magnet for one that says "Welcome home!"
