title: a special issue
description: NEW YORK is being re-formed, and its face is increasingly foreign. Today, about 40 of every 100 New Yorkers were born abroad, a percentage unmatched since the 1920's. Yet, although much is written about the cultures, problems and impact of todays immigrants, their own voices are often but a murmur in the city's din. Here are the stories of 10 transplanted New Yorkers, all under 40, told from their own personal, often poignant, perspectives, as well as voices culled from a dozen immigrant gathering places around the city. When this modern surge of immigrants reinvents New York, as did their Irish, Jewish and Italian forebears a century ago, it is words like these that will be their Hester Street, their Lower East Side, their history, their myths.

title: 'Second Space'
Improving Provisional Ballots
description: One of the brightest spots in this year's election was the nationwide debut of the provisional ballot. In 2000, many voters were turned away if their names were not on the rolls, even if they should have been. This year, any voter whose eligibility was in doubt had the right to cast a ballot whose validity would be determined later. This was a major improvement, but provisional ballots were still less effective than they should have been because of misguided rules at the state level. Congress and the states should fix the flaws in the system.

title: Postcards From Iraq
description: Of all the images I saw on a short visit to Iraq last week, two stand out in my mind. One was a display that the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, in the Sunni Triangle, prepared for the visiting chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Richard Myers. It was a table covered with defused roadside bombs made from cellphones wired to explosives. You just call the phone's number when a U.S. vehicle goes by and the whole thing explodes. The table was full of every color and variety of cellphone-bomb you could imagine. I thought to myself that if there is a duty-free electronics store at the gates of hell, this is what the display counter looks like.

I especially enjoyed the cultural cognitive dissonance of passing through a town called Gnaw Bone. This was during a decade of first, culture shock, then, enduring affection, and finally, a sense of exile in the "heartland."

His national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, was viewed as a realist rather than an ideologue; she made a compelling case that the United States could not afford to tie up its military in nation-building efforts because that would "degrade the American capability to do the things America has to do."

title: Chatter Bus
description: On the noisy $10 Chinatown bus from New York to Boston, the girl behind me spent the entire four hours on her cellphone, telling the same inane story to five different people. I wanted to ask her to stop, but I didn't know if I should, considering the price of the ride and that I don't mind noise in general, just her nasal, repetitive noise. What should I have done? Justine Van Der Leun, New York You should have grabbed her phone and pummeled her with it mercilessly while screaming: "Shut up! Shut up! Shut up!" No, no. You can't do that. You should simply have grabbed her phone and thrown it out the window. And reveled in the cheers of your fellow sufferers.

title: The Other National Conversation
description: Jim Holt's essay (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 7) questions the presumption of those who pray to God for favors. I heartily agree with him, if by favors he means "life upgrades," luxuries slipped to the insiders in some cosmic club. But what could be presumptuous about asking for a glass of water when you are terribly thirsty? Life is hard; for most of the praying folks I know, that activity is as essential as food, drink and sleep.

description: Dan Brown's art-historical thriller "The Da Vinci Code" has been a best seller for 20 months. Christian groups have denounced it; Lebanon has banned it; and now Bart D. Ehram, chairman of the department of religious studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, has written an entire book disputing the novel's claims of historical veracity. He talked with Lisa Paul Streitfeld about his "Truth and Fiction in the Da Vinci Code: A Historian Reveals What We Really Know about Jesus, Mary Magdalene and Constantine" (Oxford University Press).

title: Godard's Metaphysics of the Movies

Divided into three chapters or kingdoms, after Dante's "Divine Comedy," the film principally centers on two Jewish women. One has traveled from Israel to Sarajevo in order to witness reconciliation. The other, a Russian Jew engulfed in grief, sacrifices herself in the name of peace. This leads her into paradise, which is guarded by American Marines.

The tiny shop, on the third floor of a Manhattan town house, is packed with simple and beautiful toys: hand-sewn soft-sculpture dolls ($15 to $18), sculptured wooden rattles ($12), hand-painted play swords and shields ($16 to $18) and colonial dress-up outfits ($85). At 1045 Madison Avenue (79th Street, 212-288-3383), the store is based on Rudolph Steiner's Waldorf method of education, which stresses creativity and independent thinking.

In the title poem Williams describes crossing paths with a young black man: "It occurred to me to sing back 'I'm not a nice person either' but I couldn't come up with a tune / Besides I wouldn't have meant it nor he have believed it both of us knew just where we were."

title: Inside the List
description: VERSE, NO CHORUS: Thanks to Brad Pitt and the movie "Troy," Reuters has reported, the best-selling poet in England this fall is Homer. In this country, that honor arguably goes to Billy Corgan, whose first book of poems, "Blinking With Fists," has been bouncing happily around the Times extended list (available on the Web) for several weeks, rising as high as No. 24. People are not buying Billy Corgan's book because they are mistaking him for Billy Collins, the winsome former poet laureate. They are buying "Blinking With Fists" because Corgan, who led the influential band Smashing Pumpkins during the 1990's, still has a following -- he can seem like a geeky, gothy, brainiac version of Kurt Cobain. Corgan's free verse is the kind of stuff that, if you're skimming through looking for a line or two to ridicule, won't let you down ("I miss you already / Starting for home / The zombies keeping / All of it for themselves"). But at its best, "Blinking With Fists" is vivid and angular and not much worse than many first books of poems that arrive with heady praise from the poetry world's burghers. In "Lost Gray," Corgan writes: "Stir, the crow cackle / Collar high / The angles black against the sides / Splitting in 2's we swing clubs / Old fog rolls and hugs / Back slappin' / Paying dues for crackjaws." I'm not sure I know what that means, but it beats the oracular utterances in Jim Morrison's poems. Corgan is at work on his first novel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAINE, PETER S.
description: PAINE--Peter S. aged 95, of 240 South Beach Rd., Hobe Sound, FL died, peacefully after a massive stroke, at his seasonal home Boquette Farm in Willsboro, N.Y., the town where he was born. Services and interment were private. A memorial celebration of his life will be held next summer. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Ellen Lea Paine, a son, Peter S. Paine, Jr. of Willsboro, a sister, Francisca Paine Irwin, three grandchildren and five great grandchildren. He was the retired CEO of Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, and a long time director of the Irving Trust Company, Consolidated Edison and Continental Insurance Company. He also served as President of the Museum of the City of New York and as Chairman of The Juilliard School of Music. He was a Board member of Lincoln Center and a trustee of the Astor and Bodmin Foundations, and of Fort Ticonderoga. He was as committed to the conservation of the farms and forests of his native Champlain Valley as he was to the social and economic well being of the area. His efforts led to the conservation of 10,000 acres of working farms and forests and nature preserves, plus some 16 miles of shoreline. A kind gentleman with a sparkling wit, he will be deeply missed by his family, colleagues and friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Juilliard School, the Adirondack Nature Conservancy, Fort Ticonderoga, or the Nature Conservancy of Florida.

This led to publications which continue to be highly regarded. As a teacher, Mervyn was ins piring, astute and assiduous. Mervyn had a deep interest in the visual arts. He found enormous pleasure in walking through Central Park to his beloved "Met" where he spent many happy hours. His "Pasticcio," below, a 23-foot column that incorporated ancient and contemporary stone fragments as a playful tribute to architecture itself, was built in 1818 as part of Soane's home in Lincoln's Inn Field, London, and dismantled as unsafe in 1896. As part of the renovation of the home, now Sir John Soane's Museum, the column -- inspired by Soane's favorite building, the Temple of Vesta in Tivoli, Italy -- has been reassembled at a cost of nearly $300,000, with missing pieces meticulously recarved. The column now stands in the building's Monument Court on its original Moorish capital, decorated with garlands and rosettes, topped by a cast-iron element culminating in a pineapple. PAM KENT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIMPANARO, SYLVESTER ''TIMMY.''
description: TIMPANARO -- Sylvester "Timmy." March 1, 1933-November 13, 2004. It was never Sylvester, always just Timmy. To his family and his friends (he had hundreds of friends) always just Timmy. Everyone who knew and loved Timmy will miss him too much to explain. Over time empty places in our lives get filled in with daily obligations and the gentle sifting of time. But there will always be a place that can be filled with memories of Timmy. Just Timmy. Timmy was the son of Rose and Sylvester Timpanaro, Sr. He grew up in Astoria, Queens, joined the Army after high school and was a combat infantryman in the Korean war. Timmy found his life's work in the film production industry. He rose to become the head of the optical division at EUE Screen Gems. He then became president of TVC Productions and later was an executive VP and general manager at Rhinoceros Productions. After a distinguished career lasting 42 years, Timmy retired to his home in Amagansett, Long Island, in March of 2003. Timmy suffered sudden heart failure on November 13, in Amagansett. He is survived by his beloved wife Abby (nee Sheridan) and his cherished children, Denise Borgia, Patricia Riess, Cindy Connolly, Michael Timpanaro and James Timpanaro. He is also survived by his much loved older brother George. Timmy also leaves behind 14 grandchildren who were the joy of his life. Mass was held at 10 am, Wednesday, November 17, at Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton.

title: Arts, Briefly; Contract Harmony in Philadelphia
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra and its musicians, right, said yesterday that they had reached final agreement on a contract after a bitter labor dispute. The new three-year contract calls for a reduction in the number of full-time jobs, something the players had strenuously opposed in public, and a salary freeze for the first year. According to a statement by the orchestra, the number of permanent players and librarians will drop from 109 to 103 during the term of the contract, and then bounce back to 106 at the end of it. The orchestra stressed that there would be no reduction of forces on stage for concerts.Minimum weekly salaries will rise to $2,200 by the contract's end, compared with the current level of $2,000, which the orchestra said kept it competitive. The musicians will also be contributing more toward their health benefits and agreed to add more Sunday concerts. The contract is in line with those at other major American orchestras that have settled with musicians in recent weeks; a number have had some sort of wage freeze and higher health care costs for the members. The Chicago Symphony also had a temporary reduction in permanent positions. The Philadelphia contract is retroactive to Sept. 20, when the old pact expired. Negotiations were tense, and Mayor John F. Street stepped in to mediate. A tentative agreement was announced on Nov. 16, and the musicians and management worked out the details before the contract was ratified by the musicians this weekend. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Arts, Briefly; Sculpture Meets Dance
description: Martha Graham once said that she could have done nothing without the set and prop elements created for her dances by the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. "Always he has given me something that lived on stage as another character, another dancer," Graham said. His sets for nine of Graham's dances will be on view in "Noguchi and Graham: Selected Works for Dance," an exhibition that opens on Dec. 2 and runs through May 1 at the Noguchi Museum in Long Island City, Queens. Produced in collaboration with the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance, the exhibition includes about 35 objects intended to be danced on or around as well as films of the dances, archival photographs and ephemera, and drawings and sketches by Noguchi that suggest the evolution of his designs for Graham and their influence on his other projects. JENNIFER DUNNING

title: Computers as Authors? Literary Luddites Unite!
description: For some people, writing a novel is a satisfying exercise in self-expression. For me, it's a hideous blend of psychoanalysis and cannibalism that is barely potent enough to overcome a series of towering avoidance mechanisms -- including my own computer. Writers and computers nowadays are locked in such an enduringly dysfunctional embrace that it can be hard to tell us apart. We both rely heavily on memory, for instance. We are both calculating, complex and crash-prone. And like Hebrew National hot dogs, we both seem to answer to a higher power: writers, according to Plato, were divinely inspired; computers have Bill Gates.

title: At a Gallery in Lhasa, Tibet Joins Art World
description: LHASA, Tibet - Judging from their work, the Gedun Choephel Artists' Guild might be just another garden-variety group of painters struggling to make names for themselves in any city you can think of. Their artwork, displayed in a small gallery owned by the group, shows the hallmarks of contemporary art everywhere: abstract symbolism, veiled social commentary, mixed-media expressions of postmodernism. But in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, this co-op of 10 Tibetan and two longtime-resident Chinese painters is the beginning of something bigger: a bold attempt to remake a culture bound by centuries of tradition and hemmed in by narrow stereotypes.

title: Radio Tags for Pharmaceuticals
description: Although it is usually a mistake to rely on technical fixes to solve a serious social problem, a new technology for tracking products could help immensely to squelch the counterfeiting and theft of prescription drugs. The promising radio-frequency identification technology got a boost last week when the Food and Drug Administration announced new moves to promote it and three drug companies said they would tag some of their most popular drugs with radio-frequency devices in pioneering efforts to thwart counterfeiters. If all goes well, the technology could come into widespread use on pharmaceuticals after 2007 and might ease the way toward importing cheaper prescription drugs by undercutting dubious claims that such imports would be too risky.

title: The Heckler's Code

It was Friday night after a tough week. They didn't want to go to the movies or opera and sit quietly for a couple hours. They wanted to imagine themselves as the stars on the court of friendly strife. They wanted to be uninhibited, to jump up and down, to watch others do what they wished they could do. They wanted to be the sixth man, the home-court advantage, part of the game. They wanted to help their team win.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Thomson Enters ContentGuard Deal
description: The European Commission is not automatically halting its investigation into a plan by Microsoft and Time Warner to take over the antipiracy specialist ContentGuard, a spokesman said, despite the arrival of a third merger partner, Thomson of France. Thomson announced plans to take a one-third stake in ContentGuard. The move would dilute the influence of Microsoft and Time Warner over ContentGuard. The European Commission said one of its main concerns about the deal was that it could allow Microsoft to take effective control of the merged entity. With a third equal partner this becomes impossible. However, the commission will continue with its investigation of the deal until it is officially notified about Thomson's inclusion, said Jonathan Todd, the commission's competition spokesman. Thomson's investment adds a "European-headquartered partner that will make this important technology more accessible," Bill Gates, above, Microsoft's chairman, said in a statement. Paul Meller (NYT)

When Mr. Schwartz took over as president two years ago -- recruited from the Palladin Capital Group -- Gordon Brothers still did more than 50 percent of its business counseling stores on ways to eliminate goods that had not sold. Now less than 20 percent of Gordon's business is liquidation. During the last three years, the company has acquired or started more than a dozen companies and converted $12 billion of assets into cash. Tracie Rozhon (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo's 3rd-Quarter Loss Widens
description: TiVo Inc., a maker of digital video recorders that can pause and replay live television, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter loss widened to $26.4 million as it spent more on marketing. The net loss expanded to 33 cents a share in the period that ended Oct. 31, from $7.39 million, or 11 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. The loss was smaller than the average estimate of 44 cents a share from 15 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue fell 11 percent, to $38.3 million from $43.3 million, TiVo said. Shares of TiVo, which is based in Alviso, Calif., fell 12 cents, to $5.88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, CY
description: COLEMAN--Cy. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of its beloved friend, the renowned American composer and pianist Cy Coleman, on November 18, 2004 in New York City at the age of 75. Mr. Coleman was a deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for most of his life. An accomplished and classically trained pianist who made his Carnegie Hall debut at the age of 7, Cy Coleman's musical journey led him to the world of jazz and, of course, to the Great White Way. He was one of this country's greatest and most honored songwriters, with such immortal standards as "Witchcraft", "The Best is Yet to Come", "Big Spender", "I've Got Your Number", and "Hey, Look Me Over" to his credit. His Broadway scores included "Sweet Charity", "City of Angels", "The Will Rogers Follies", "On the Twentieth Century", "I Love My Wife" and "The Life", to name but a few. Cy Coleman was always at home at the Steinway, and to hear him play was a real joy and, for us, inspiring. Though our lives have been forever enriched by his music, his generous and jaunty persona will be sorely missed by us all. To Shelby and Lilly Cye, we extend our love and our heartfeld condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: A Singer Confronts Colombia's Pain
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Nov. 22 - Soldiers in wheelchairs, maimed by land mines, eagerly waited in Bogot's wide central plaza, just the kind of fans whose pain the Colombian rocker Juanes sings about. Two blocks away, in a colonial-style hotel, Juanes was on edge. He may be Latin America's hottest singer-songwriter these days, a soulful poet with electric guitar whose politically charged lyrics have won acclaim for capturing the nihilism and outrage of Colombia's long civil conflict, but on a recent day he nervously strummed his guitar and paced the hallways as fans gathered outside.

The scholar and the traveling ethnographer seem utterly natural together.

title: Ukraine: Looking for a Fair Vote Count
description: The choice facing Ukrainian voters on Sunday, in the second round of their presidential election, was about as clear as choices get: East or West. In the shorthand of the race, Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovich was pro-Russian, and his opponent, Viktor Yushchenko, the head of the opposition and a former prime minister, was pro-Western. President Vladimir Putin of Russia openly threw his support to Mr. Yanukovich, and the West not quite so openly threw its weight behind Mr. Yushchenko. But the outcome of the election seemed less important than how fairly it was conducted. If a nation as sharply divided and as strategically important as Ukraine showed it could handle a hard choice, wouldn't democracy throughout the former Soviet empire benefit?

title: Fighting Erupts in West Sudan Despite Accord

title: National Briefing | West: California: Peterson Jury To Remain
description: The judge in the trial of Scott Peterson, who was convicted on Nov. 12 of killing his pregnant wife, Laci, turned down a request by Mr. Peterson's lawyers to have a new jury determine whether he should be sentenced to death. The judge, Alfred A. Delucchi, also ruled that the penalty phase would remain in Redwood City and begin on Nov. 30. Testimony was to begin on Monday but the judge granted another week for the lawyers to prepare. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VANE, SIR JOHN, FRS
description: VANE--Sir John, FRS. The Fellows of the Biotechnology Study Center, NYU School of Medicine, mourn the death on Friday, November 19th of Sir John Vane, D.Phil., FRS in Farnborough, Kent, UK. Sir John, a founding Fellow of our Center, was most recently founding director of the prestigious William Harvey Research Institute in London. He was perhaps the most distinguished pharmacologist of his day (1927-2004), receiving the Nobel Prize in 1982 for his work on prostaglandins. He discovered prostacyclin, a protective factor for blood vessels, and went on to show that aspirin-like drugs inhibit the COX 1 and COX 2 enzymes that form prostaglandins. By explaining how low doses of aspirin prevent clots, strokes and heart attacks, he made aspirin one of the most common drugs used to treat and prevent heart disease. Sir John's work also led to captopril, the first of a widely used family of medicines called ACE inhibitors. His discoveries may have saved more lives than any since the polio vaccine; they have revolutionized the treatment of cardiovascular disease. Sir John was a bubble in the lab, a scholar at heart, and a gentleman in the world of science. Colleagues and competitors will miss his wit as much as his wisdom. We extend our deepest sympathy to Lady Daphne Vane, to Nikki, Mandy, and their families. Gerald Weissmann for the Fellows of the Biotechnology Study Center of NYU School of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTROVE, PAUL STUART
description: OSTROVE--Paul Stuart. We sadly mourn the death of our beloved husband, father and friend, who died on November 21, 2004, at the age of 73 after a long and valiant struggle with cancer. Paul will be remembered as warmhearted, generous and outgoing. He made everyone feel comfortable and welcomed in his presence. Until the latter stages of his illness, he enjoyed life to the fullest. Paul was co-owner of Paul Stuart, The Clothing Company, started by his father, Ralph Ostrove. The original store, which opened in 1938, was named after Paul when he was still a boy. Although Paul was formerly in charge of buying and clothing operations, he was best known as the heart and soul of the store. He had a friendly and unpretentious manner that endeared him to everyone. His customers, a great many of whom became personal friends, will sadly miss being greeted and hugged by "the sweet guy at the top of the stairs." He never forgot anyone's name or suit size, a remarkable talent given the multitude of people he knew. He began working at the store while he was in high school and always knew that he would go into the family business. After graduating from Colby College in 1953, Paul was in the Army for two years and then began his lifetime work at Paul Stuart. He was an overseer for Colby College from 1994 to 2003, an active member of the Lymphoma Research Foundation, and a member of the North Shore Country Club in Glen Cove, N.Y. Paul was an avid sportsman who especially loved golf, squash and skiing. He is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Estelle. They were about to celebrate their 50th anniversary in 3 weeks. He is also survived by his loving children and their spouses, Gail and Robert Kantor, who live in New York, Michael, who represents the third generation at Paul Stuart, and Lisa Ostrove, David and Lily Ostrove, who live in California, his eight wonderful grandchildren, Danielle, Jason, Zachary, Drew, Ryan, Daniel, Emma and Sophie, his sister Barbara Grodd, his brotherin-law and business partner of many years, Clifford Grodd, and several nieces and nephews. He will be terribly missed by everone who knew and loved him. He will be in our hearts and memories forever. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 81 St at Madison Ave on Wednesday, November 24th at 9:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Paul's memory may be made to the Lymphoma Reserch Foundation, 111 Broadway, 19th floor, New York, N.Y. 10006.

title: Arts, Briefly; Hezbollah Television in France
description: France's public broadcasting regulator last week granted Al Manar, an Arabic-language television station run by the Lebanon-based militant Islamic group Hezbollah, the license it requested to continue broadcasting through a satellite operator into France and many other parts of Europe. Al Manar had come under fire from CRIF, the Representative Council of Jewish Institutions in France, which had complained of anti-Semitic programming. The Audio-Visual Higher Council granted Al Manar the license with a warning that it would be considered violated if the channel broadcast hate messages as it had in the past. The council's director told the group in a letter accompanying the license, "Your signature on this license implies that that you formally renounce broadcasting such programs on a signal using a satellite subject to French law." Al Manar issued a statement saying it "has no problem with French laws and is ready to abide by the legal requirements to broadcast on French airwaves." The United States State Department has listed Hezbollah as a terrorist organization. HLNE FOUQUET

Six teenagers were arrested on Nov. 18, but just one, Ryan Cushing, 18, of Huntington, was charged with throwing the turkey. He was released Saturday on $250,000 cash bail. title: Arts, Briefly; More Berlin Building Blues
description: The ambitious $2 billion renovation of Berlin's historic Museum Island hit a stumbling block last week when an official panel recommended to Parliament that the government abandon plans for a new entrance building to the complex. A new building with restaurants, restrooms and a check room was designed by the British architect David Chipperfield, below, to lead visitors into the complex, on an island in the Spree River in the former Communist east side of the city. Dropping the project would save the cash-strapped federal government $170 million. The recommendation was rejected by the federal culture minister, Christina Weiss, who said the new entrance building was needed to accommodate visitors. "Those who question the arrangement of visitor flows on Museum Island prevent the museums from entering the 21st century," she said in an interview with the newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. Museum Island, which was built in the 19th century and is famous for its Pergamon Altar from Turkey and the Ishtar Gate from Babylon, was badly damaged during World War II, and restoration began only after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Parliament is to vote on the fate of the entrance building in the next few months. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

description: In percent

title: Despite Defect, G.M. Keeps Selling S.U.V.
description: DETROIT, Nov. 22 - Joram Rauchwerger, a 56-year-old postal worker in Tulsa, Okla., recently broke his 22-year-old vow never to buy another car made by General Motors. To say the least, he regrets the decision.

title: The Handbag? Total Knockoff. The Price Tag? All Too Real.
description: It is as much a rite of the New York holiday season as sidewalk Santas or crowded Fifth Avenue sidewalks: the proliferation of hawkers selling counterfeit products like the fake Fendi handbag, the replica Rolex watch and the pirated DVD.

title: Thick, Dreamy Sounds Anchored in Rich Melody
description: Drenched in reverb, its vocal harmonies confounded by electronic pitch transposers, its songs blowing up into big, woolly clouds, the music of Animal Collective has no reason to work.

title: Q & A
description: Growth at Your Fingertips

title: Corrections
description: The About New York column on Nov. 6, about holders of honorary New York City police commissioner badges, included an erroneous report from a police spokesman about Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly. He has indeed presented a badge during his current tenure -- to Michael Stern, a philanthropist.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Locusts Swarm South
description: Swarms of pink locusts have filled the skies of southern Israel, but crop-dusting planes sprayed insecticides, and officials were describing the invasion more as a nuisance than a biblical plague. Millions of locusts have been working their way through the Middle East, and after passing through Egypt, they descended on Israel's Red Sea resort of Eilat over the weekend, stripping trees and gardens of vegetation. But round-the-clock spraying has protected large agricultural lands in the south with no serious crop damage, according to the Agriculture Ministry. Locusts are considered kosher under Jewish dietary laws, Israeli newspapers noted, and one, Yediot Aharonot, consulted chefs for recipes that included deep-fried locusts on a bed of eggplant jam and apricot paste. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: The Face of Nature Changes as Art and Science Evolve
description: Artists and scientists, so the story goes, glare at each other across a cultural divide. The scientist coldly hacks nature into pieces. The artist is unwilling to do the hard work necessary to understand how the world works.

title: Rare Weapon to Hunt Deer
description: The rifle that killed five Wisconsin hunters and wounded three more on Sunday was an SKS 7.62-millimeter semiautomatic assault weapon not normally used in hunting animals.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 3 Phone Concerns Win Navy Contracts
description: Verizon Wireless, Cingular Wireless and Nextel Communications were each awarded $20 million contracts yesterday to outfit United States Navy personnel stationed domestically with cellphones, voice minutes and wireless data plans for the next 12 months. Organizations at the federal, state and local government level now account for about 2.1 million of Nextel's 14 million overall subscribers, in part because of Nextel's walkie-talkie-style services known as push-to-talk, the company said. Verizon Wireless is a joint venture of Verizon Communications and Vodafone. Cingular is a joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth.

title: Now the Main Event: David Stern vs. Billy Hunter
description: WE'VE gone round and round the implications of last Friday's brawl in Auburn Hills, Mich., with very few conclusions. This much is certain: The next five months will define Billy Hunter's tenure as the executive director of the N.B.A. players union.

title: Software Firm to Name New Chief Executive
description: Computer Associates International is expected to announce today that its new chief executive will be John Swainson, an I.B.M. executive with strong technical and sales credentials but who is untested in leading a business the size of Computer Associates, which has 15,000 employees.

title: That Shocking Night in the N.B.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONEN, GERTRUDE
description: DONEN -- Gertrude. Loving wife, mother and grandmother. Survived by daughters Marcia and Doreen, son-inlaw Joseph, grandchildren Michael and Sarina. Pure of heart, she will always be with us.

title: HERSHEY WILL ACQUIRE MAUNA LOA MACADAMIA NUT
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation, the No. 1 chocolate maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Corporation from the Shansby Group, a private equity investment firm, for $112.4 million plus assumed debt of $17.6 million. The acquisition is expected to add to Hershey's earnings in the first 12 months and to close in the fourth quarter, said a spokeswoman for Hershey, which is based in Hershey, Pa. Mauna Loa of Hilo, Hawaii, has annual sales of about $80 million and a 40 percent share of the market in macadamia nuts. Acquiring it will help Hershey add macadamia nuts and nut-based confections and cookies to its line of products.

title: Powell Sees Israel Committed to Aiding Palestinian Vote
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 22 - Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said Monday that he had won a commitment from Israel to let Palestinians living in Jerusalem take part in elections in January and to ease conditions in the West Bank and Gaza so that they can more easily vote there as well.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Board Passes West Side Rezoning
description: The City Planning Commission voted 10 to 1 yesterday to approve the Bloomberg administration's ambitious plan to rezone the far West Side of Manhattan for large-scale development. The plan, opposed by community groups, provides for up to 26 million square feet of commercial development, 13,600 apartments, parks and a $1.8 billion extension of the No. 7 subway line. The rezoning is linked to a plan for a $1.4 billion football stadium for the Jets and one for a $1.4 billion expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. It now goes to the City Council, where a lengthy debate is expected. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Thousands of Ukrainians Refuse to Accept Election Results
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 23 - Mass demonstrations against the preliminary count of the presidential election in Ukraine expanded today in the capital, as the opposition candidate and official loser, Viktor A. Yushchenko, declared himself the winner and tried without success to force the Parliament to invalidate the official results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DICKSTEIN, JUDITH (AKA J.D. JONES)
description: DICKSTEIN--Judith (aka J.D. Jones). Died in a vehicle accident November 20, in Montpelier, VT. Devoted sister to Laurie and Barry Siegel; aunt to Jodi Zgodny and Matthew Wood; great-aunt to Jordan and Dylan Zgodny; stepsister to Dennis Gilbert and Pam Gittleman. The free-est of free spirits; she wrote her own music, traveled her own paths, lived life in her own way to the fullest. Memorial service Friday, November 26, 10 am, at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Doctors Without Borders, USA, Inc., New York, NY.

title: 2 Agencies Bought In Separate Deals
description: Two agency acquisitions were announced yesterday.

title: Between Novels, Her Motto Is Safety First
description: THE first part of Karen J. Greenberg's post-9/11 moment was typical. She moved out of Manhattan and bought a house in Connecticut. The second part was more unusual. She began writing a novel about Sarah, the wife of the Biblical patriarch Abraham, whom she imagined had a long affair with the Egyptian pharaoh before returning to Abraham.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mizuho Profit Falls
description: The Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's largest bank, reported that net profit for the six months ended in September fell 8 percent, to 234 billion yen ($2.27 billion), as earnings from bond trading slid and a tax benefit ended. Mizuho, however, raised its profit forecast, saying it was making progress in shedding bad loans. Mizuho said it expected net profit of 440 billion yen for the year ending March 31, compared with 407 billion yen last year and an earlier estimate of 330 billion yen. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Hollywood Shakeout
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 - Suspicion simmered and confusion reigned in the palm-potted halls of the Four Seasons Hotel on Monday, as the heated business of promoting holiday and Oscar-season movies was mixed with uncertainty over what publicist represented what movie star or filmmaker and for how long.

title: Pudgy Pooches and Owners Can Shed Pounds Together
description: Couples who exercise together, experts have always said, are more likely to stick to a fitness plan than those who go it alone. But a new study, offering a twist on the old-fashioned buddy system, has found that people looking for a sidekick need look no further than their pudgy pets.

title: Food Without Fear
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y. - Now that the bloom is finally off the Atkins diet rose, now that the instinct to, say, make a pure of potatoes feels slightly less suicidal, let us take a moment to realize that, when it comes to food, Americans have the tendency to lose all reason. With the same collective head-scratching that goes on when we look back at the big hair and shoulder pads of the 80's, we would do well to ask: What were we thinking?

title: National Briefing | Washington: Rise In Hate Crimes
description: Nearly 7,500 incidents were classified as hate crimes in the United States in 2003, an F.B.I. report found, with more than half of them motivated by racial prejudice. Intimidation and vandalism were the most frequently reported hate crimes, the report showed, though there were 14 murders. Six of those murders were among more than 1,200 incidents based on sexual orientation, the report said. The overall number of incidents last year, 7,489, was slightly higher than the previous year. The F.B.I. data was drawn from thousands of local, state and federal law enforcement agencies. John Files (NYT)

title: Flying Cheaper
description: FLYING CHEAPER -- Companies in the United States are paying the lowest average air fares for their employees since 1999, according to data from Eclipse Advisors, an American Express subsidiary that compiles a survey called the Business Travel Monitor. The reason is the intensifying competition between low-cost carriers and major carriers, and its pressure on popular routes, Eclipse said. The average one-way fare paid for a business trip on a basket of domestic routes studied by researchers was $217 in the third quarter, down 10 percent from the period a year earlier. Philadelphia provides one example of the impact of low-cost carriers; Southwest Airlines started operating there in May against US Airways. In the third quarter, the average fare for a business trip in Philadelphia fell 40 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shell Assets To Decline
description: The assets of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group will drop by $4.7 billion and net debt will increase by $200 million when it adopts international accounting standards in 2005. The bulk of the asset reduction comes from changes in the way Shell's pension plan holdings are recorded, the company said. The European Union has asked about 7,000 companies to use international accounting standards by 2005. At Shell, the changes will have no impact on strategy or cash flow, but net income will drop by $100 million in 2004. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: American Airlines Delays Delivery of 54 Jets
description: American Airlines, the world's biggest carrier, has delayed the deliveries of 54 planes from the Boeing Company to save $2.7 billion in spending over the next six years.

title: Man Swinging Light Fixture Killed by Police in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn man who frequently had seizures that sent him running into traffic was shot and killed by police officers early yesterday morning when he swung at them with a light fixture, the authorities said.

title: Saratoga Center Cited for Mismanagement
description: The Saratoga Performing Arts Center's decision in February to end the New York City Ballet's 40-year summer residency was flawed and indicative of generally poor management that includes overpaying the center's top executive, according to a preliminary state audit to be released today. The board of the arts center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., known by its acronym, SPAC, "needs to take a more active, independent and public role in the center's day-to-day management and decision-making," says an executive summary of the audit, a copy of which was obtained yesterday by The New York Times.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OFF -- Crude oil fell on speculation that mild weather in the Northeast will build heating supplies and that slower economic growth may ease demand. In New York, crude for January delivery fell 25 cents, to $48.64.

description: "A concerted and forceful program of election-day fraud and abuse was enacted with either the leadership or cooperation of governmental authorities."

description: MSG Networks and Time Warner Cable agreed yesterday to extend negotiations on a new contract until Jan. 20 to maintain the availability of the MSG Network, Fox Sports New York and the Metro channels to 2.3 million cable subscribers in New York and Bergen County in New Jersey, the companies said yesterday. The interim deal was brokered by Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general.

description: A third team of scientists has now reported a seemingly simple discovery on Mars: its atmosphere contains methane.

description: The Oracle Corporation said yesterday that it was at an impasse with PeopleSoft Inc., signaling that the two software makers will wage a proxy battle to resolve Oracle's $9.2 billion takeover bid.

title: Neighbors Urge Iraq to Keep Working for Stability
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Nov. 23 - The United States and the government it installed in Baghdad joined with Iraq's Middle Eastern neighbors and the world's larger powers today to support Iraq's transition to democracy, attempting to quiet often bitter international wrangling prompted by the American invasion.

title: Ex-Senator Gets Week's Delay on Jail Ruling
description: Just two hours before he was to return to prison, former State Senator Guy J. Velella was given another week of freedom when a State Supreme Court judge said yesterday that she would need a week to consider whether a mayoral panel acted legally in ordering him back to jail.

title: Freed U.N. Workers in Afghanistan Said to Be in Good Health
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 23 - Three United Nations workers who were held hostage in Afghanistan for more than three weeks were said to be in good health today after their release in what appeared to be an orchestrated handover.

title: Codey Gives Report of Talk With Bloomberg
description: TRENTON, Nov. 22 - Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey said on Monday that he had met with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to discuss some of their common goals -- including attracting more money from Washington for homeland security costs -- and two competing ones: the New York Jets and the New Jersey Nets.

title: Condemned to Get Stuck With the Bill
description: GUY J. VELELLA, New York's most talked-about felon, missed his date with the jailer yesterday. The well-bought former state senator was supposed to return to Rikers Island, but a state judge let him remain free while the case is argued some more.

title: PREMIER CLAIMS HE'S THE WINNER IN UKRAINE VOTE
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 22 - Ukraine approached a political stalemate on Monday, as vote counts of the presidential runoff election indicated that Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich had won but international observers alleged systemic voting abuses and the opposition candidate refused to accept defeat.

title: Congress Urges Ouster of 2 Regulators
description: Congress urged the Bush administration yesterday to replace the director and deputy director of the agency that regulates Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the largest sources of money for home mortgages.

title: Patterns: Pain and the Downsized Brain
description: People with chronic back pain showed measurable shrinkage of their brains when they were given M.R.I. scans, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Study Finds Savings in Medicare Drug Benefit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - A new study confirms that the drug benefit being added to Medicare will provide significant help to elderly people with low incomes or very high drug costs. But, it says, one in four people who sign up for the benefit will have to spend more of their own money for prescription drugs.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ISELIN, BEATRICE
description: ISELIN--Beatrice. Age 92. Of New Rochelle, N.Y. On November 21, 2004. Devoted wife of the late Harry J. Iselin. Beloved mother and motherin-law of Joan and Ari De-Levie, Diane and Ralph Heiman, and David and Audrey Iselin. Loving grandmother of Sharon, Rena, Julie, Wendy, Marc, Tammy, Josh and Alex. Great grandmother of Rachel, Sophia, Eliana, Ben, Ethan, Maddy, Jessie, Jeremy, Aiden, Samantha, Zachary and Brooke. She had a lifelong commitment to her family and Judaism.

description: Correction Appended

title: Charles Joins Fray Over Himself
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 - In an unusual departure from the tradition of regal silence, Prince Charles fought back on Monday against accusations by a government minister who called his views on education "old fashioned" and "out of time."

title: Citing Cancer, Chief Resigns at McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest restaurant chain, announced yesterday that Charles H. Bell was resigning as chief executive to focus on his battle with cancer, and would be succeeded by James Skinner, the vice chairman.

description: 'SECRET HISTORY OF THE CREDIT CARD' Frontline, PBS, tonight (9 in most cities; check listings)

title: Advertising Revenue Rises for Newspapers
description: Advertising revenue for newspapers rose 3.8 percent in the third quarter, to $11.3 billion, from the period a year ago, according to the Newspaper Association of America in Vienna, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRONE, HAROLD ARTHUR
description: CRONE--Harold Arthur. Died November 22 in Boca Raton, Florida. He was born January 2, 1915 in New York and was a fourth generation New Yorker. Mr. Crone was a proud US Navy combat veteran of World War II. He had a distinguished career in retailing including serving as President of the Hecht Company in Washington DC. After retirement, he volunteered with the International Executive Service Corps in Chile and Taiwan. He is survived by his son, Lawrence Crone and daughter, Penny Crone, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: National Briefing | Washington: 'Other Race' Stays On The Books
description: Congress has barred the Census Bureau from eliminating a racial category used almost exclusively by Hispanics in 2000. Census officials had hoped to eliminate the "some other race" category from the 2010 questionnaire to encourage Hispanics to choose from among five standard racial categories -- white, black, Asian, American Indian or Alaska native -- and one for natives of Hawaii and the Pacific Islands. But Hispanic groups, supported by Representative Jos E. Serrano, Democrat of New York, argued that the change would ignore the evolving views of race across the country as immigration from Latin America has surged. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINNEY, JOHN W.
description: FINNEY--John W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John W. Finney, associated with The Times from January 28, 1957 until December 31, 1987.

title: More Iraqi Army Dead Found in Mosul; 2 Clerics Slain
description: MOSUL, Iraq, Nov. 22 - A leading Sunni cleric was killed in a drive-by shooting in the northern city of Mosul on Monday, and American military officials in the city discovered the bodies of at least four more Iraqi Army soldiers killed by gunshots to the head.

title: Shoulder Surgery Is Set for Yanks' Sheffield
description: Gary Sheffield was the Yankees' best player last season, a runner-up for the Most Valuable Player award despite a separated left shoulder. But he struggled in the final four games of the championship series against the Boston Red Sox, going 1 for 17 as the Yankees collapsed. The shoulder pain may have finally worn on him.

description: Correction Appended

description: Want to guard your child from violent imagery? Watch out for those nursery rhymes.

Tom DeLay's Power

title: Ovitz Was Odd but Diligent, Former Disney Officer Says
description: GEORGETOWN, Del., Nov. 21 - In 1995, Stephen Bollenbach, then chief financial officer of the Walt Disney Company, welcomed Michael S. Ovitz, its new president, by telling him, "I won't report to you."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAKOFF, LOIS CUDWORTH
description: DIAKOFF -- Lois Cudworth died on November 18 at the age of 61 after a long battle with cancer. She held degrees in comparative literature from City College and Columbia University and a JD from Brooklyn Law School. She practiced personal injury law for three years and then joined the State Court system where she served as a court attorney and the law secretary to several Appellate Division justices. Most recently she has been the law secretary to Justice Shirley Werner Kornreich. She is survived by her husband Harry Diakoff of New York City and her parents, Richard and Rita Cudworth of San Antonio, Texas. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Dances Patrelle, PO Box 6802, NY, NY 10128 or to Doctors Without Borders (1-888-392-0392). A memorial service is planned for January 9.

title: Building a Brand by Not Being a Brand
description: Some people seek their calling. For others, like Dov Charney, it is bred in the bone. "I think I was born a hustler," said Mr. Charney, the fast-talking founder of American Apparel, the rapidly expanding youth-oriented T-shirt chain. "I like the hustle. I like selling a product that people love. It's nice when a girl tries on a bra or a tie-dye T-shirt, and it's, 'Ooh, I love it,' " he said, affecting an ecstatic moan.

title: AIDS Infections Reach Record High, U.N. Says
description: AIDS virus infections have reached a record high in the world this year, and the number of women with H.I.V. has risen in every region of the world, the United Nations said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stagehands In Contract Talks
description: Officials from the Broadway stagehands union and the League of American Theaters and Producers, which represents most of Broadway's producers, were still negotiating late yesterday on a new contract. The stagehands, without a contract since Sept. 1, are seeking a three-year deal with yearly wage and benefit increases of 3 to 4 percent, said a spokesman for the union, Local One of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees. The union membership has given its approval to strike, despite a deal with the Nederlander Organization, which owns and operates nine Broadway theaters. Jesse McKinley (NYT)

title: Brawl Evokes Real Story of N.B.A. and Its Fans
description: IF the global marketing miracle known as the N.B.A. has finally come to face the fragile rapport it has with its core audience at home in the United States, let it be said that the Palace of Auburn Hills was the appropriate setting to look in the mirror.

title: Bobcats May Drop Advertising Campaign
description: An advertising campaign for the Charlotte Bobcats scheduled to begin this week could become a casualty of Friday's brawl in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: Krispy Kreme Tumbles Into the Red
description: It was a bad day yesterday for the doughnut maker Krispy Kreme, a Wall Street darling just a year ago.

title: The Neediest Cases; After Boot-Camp Stay, a Job And a New Start in College
description: Stephen Bedoya-Rey, 17, was in the living room of his family's Queens apartment. He sat with his mother, holding her hand -- a gesture that would have been hard for mother or son to imagine not so long ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STARRAG-HECKERT HOLDING, Rorschacherberg, Switzerland, a supplier of machine tools, said it would cut about 17 percent of its work force after reporting a loss and lower demand.

title: Nuclear proliferation : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
Paid Notice: Deaths   HUGHES, JAMES E.
description: HUGHES--James E., of Stony Brook, N.Y., born May 1913 in Clayton, Missouri, son of Samuel Wheeler Hughes and Emma Eugenia Berry Hughes, passed away November 21, 2004. Associate and Partner of Coudert Brothers, an international law firm, from 1935-1985. Member of its Management and Executive Committees for thirty years and head of its corporate department. Retired member of the Boards of the MortonThiokol Corporation and Coty International. Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Mills College of Education 1963-1968 and member of the Board 1948-1968. Former member and Chair of the Board of the Far Brook School, Short Hills, N.J. Former member of the Board of the Mannes College of Music. Survived by his wife of 64 years, Elizabeth Buermann Hughes and his four children and their partners, James E. Hughes, Jr. and Jacqueline Merrill; Peter B. and Agneta Hughes, Elisabeth Ellen and Robert Templeton, Barbara Ann and Robert Gibson. Also survived by eleven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren and their spouses and fiances, and four greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Setauket Presbyterian Church, 5 Caroline Avenue, Setauket, Long Island on Friday, November 26 at 2:00 P.M. The family has requested that no flowers be sent and that in lieu contributions be made to The Far Brook School, 52 Great Hills Road, Short Hills, New Jersey 07078 or to the Food Pantry, a project of the Port Jefferson Ecumenical Outreach, checks should be made to Mary Ann Bell at 1 Stony Hill Road, Port Jefferson, N.Y. 11777.

title: Shostakovich, Lonely at the Core
description: The bleak and terrible moonscape of Shostakovich's later years was there to hear on Saturday at Carnegie Hall as Gidon Kremer and his Kremerata Baltica played the Chamber Symphony, the Violin and Piano Sonata and the 14th Symphony on an appropriately gloomy evening.

title: Trauma: For Medics, an Airway Quandary
description: Accident victims with brain injuries who were given breathing tubes by ambulance crews before they got to the hospital were four times as likely to die as a result of the accident as those given the tubes later, a new study finds. They were also more likely to suffer neurological problems.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Call for Improvements In Detecting Harmful Drugs America needs a better system to detect harmful effects of drugs that are already on the market, and that system should be independent of the Food and Drug Administration and the drug industry, medical researchers and journal editors said.

title: Rolling Back Women's Rights
description: Dispensing with legislative niceties like holding hearings or full and open debate, President Bush and the Republican Congress have used the cover of a must-pass spending bill to mount a disgraceful sneak attack on women's health and freedom.

title: For Mother and Child, a Lurking Danger
description: Obstetric researchers have done much in recent years to increase the safety and success of pregnancies among all women of reproductive age, even those approaching the end of their ability to conceive.

title: CITIGROUP WILL SELL TRUCK LEASING UNIT TO G.E.
description: Citigroup, which has been shedding equipment-finance units, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its business that provides lending and leasing to the trucking industry to the General Electric Company for about $4.4 billion. Citigroup, based in New York, said it would record a gain of about $90 million from the deal. GE Commercial Finance, the business-to-business financing unit of General Electric, said it would keep the group, CitiCapital Transportation Financial Services, in Dallas and add 600 workers. General Electric, based in Fairfield, Conn., has said it will buy companies it thinks can help push profit growth to at least 10 percent annually, including leasing and business financing. Profit at GE Commercial Finance, which already oversees the world's biggest aircraft lending business, is forecast to rise by 10 percent or more in 2005, Michael Neal, the unit's chief executive, said at an Oct. 26 investor meeting.

title: Union and Pacers to Fight Suspensions
description: The repercussions from the basketball brawl last week in Auburn Hills, Mich., were felt on three fronts yesterday.

title: Beneath the Harbor, It's Dig or Else
description: It is nearly 3 a.m., and traffic on the Bayonne Bridge is so light that this link between New Jersey and Staten Island looks almost like some rural river crossing. Yet from down beneath the graceful steel-arch span, in a spot illuminated by the moonlight, comes an angry roar, followed by a tremendous rumble. The Beast of the Kill Van Kull is out feeding again tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARRY, NATALIE NEE LASHER
description: PARRY--Natalie nee Lasher. Predeceased by her adoring niece Marjorie Fisher Bahr. Survived by loving and devoted sisters Shirley Fisher and Dorothy Nortman. Dearest Natalie, we miss you. Services private.

title: Thousands Near 9/11 Attack Reported Ill Effects, U.S. Says
description: Correction Appended

title: UPS WORKERS STAGE A WALKOUT IN CANADA
description: United Parcel Service said yesterday that 3,800 drivers and sorters had walked off the job in Canada, shutting down most of its operations in the country. The strike, the first against United Parcel in Canada since 1991, affected about 1 percent of the company's 360,000 employees. A spokeswoman, Cristina Torelli, said ground shipments in transit would be delivered by nonunion workers. Pickups were halted three days ago. United Parcel, based in Atlanta, would not disclose the issues that led to the strike or the potential loss in revenue from the walkout. No new talks were scheduled.

title: More Iraqi Army Dead Found in Mosul; 2 Clerics Slain
description: MOSUL, Iraq, Nov. 22 - A leading Sunni cleric was killed in a drive-by shooting in the northern city of Mosul on Monday, and American military officials in the city discovered the bodies of at least four more Iraqi Army soldiers killed by gunshots to the head.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Desperate Housewives' Returns to Top Spot
description: "Desperate Housewives" wasn't broadcast on Nov. 14, when ABC showed "American Music Awards," an annual special. But the hit series stayed in the news because of its eyebrow-raising promotion on "Monday Night Football," in which an apparently naked Nicollette Sheridan, below, a star of the show, jumped into the arms of the Philadelphia Eagles receiver Terrell Owens. Back on the air this week, "Desperate Housewives" easily won the Sunday night ratings race for ABC (along with "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition"), according to the Nielsen overnight ratings. The network's dominance at 9 p.m. continues to mean weakened ratings for "Law & Order: Criminal Intent," and failure for the WB's "Mountain" and Fox's "My Big Fat Obnoxious Boss." Also troubling for Fox is the slide of "Arrested Development" since its premiere two weeks ago. Though the Emmy-winning show continues to do better than it did last year, on Sunday night it lost a third of the audience of "The Simpsons," which preceded it. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAY, ARTHUR A., M.D.
description: GRAY--Arthur A., M.D. The staff and physicians of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System and Forest Hills Hospital are greatly saddened by the passing of Arthur A. Gray, M.D., the senior vice president and chief of staff at Forest Hills Hospital. Dr. Gray was a trusted physician, administor, colleague and friend to the hospital, its staff and physicians for 28 years. As a tribute to Dr. Gray's leadership and the legacy he leaves, Forest Hills Hospital is naming its Orthopedic program in his memory. In addition to his leadership positions at Forest Hills Hospital, Dr. Gray was an orthopedic surgeon, and served as a shareholder and board member of the Queens Long Island Medical Group. He also served the North Shore-LIJ Health System on many committees, focusing on such issues as medical leadership, quality management, strategic planning and community services. Dr. Gray's leadership at Forest Hills Hospital dates back to 1976, when it was known as LaGuardia Hospital. The highest-ranking physician within the administration at Forest Hills Hospital, Dr. Gray helped develop the hospital's medical staff membership and chaired the hospital's Performance Improvement Coordinating Group focusing on quality. In 2003, he was awarded the Lawrence Scherr, MD Award for Medical Excellence in recognition of his leadership in developing the hospital's medical and surgical programs. He graduated from the Howard University College of Medicine and earned his residency in orthopedics at Harlem Hospital. He is survived by his mother, Ida Gray, his wife, Sigrid, two daughters Nicole and Heather, a sister, Pamela, and a brother, Victor. Michael Dowling President & CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System Robert Hettenbach Executive Director Forest Hills Hospital

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bonds Issued In Housing Incentive
description: The New York City Housing Development Corporation yesterday approved the first bonds to be issued as part of a new financing plan. The plan gives property owners more incentives to stay in the Mitchell-Lama program, which provides housing for tens of thousands of low- and moderate-income families. The bonds cover refinancing and repair of 46 developments with more than 9,000 units. In all, the plan is aimed at protecting 27,000 apartments in 80 buildings in all five boroughs, and is part of Mayor Michael R. title: John Vane, Nobelist Who Helped in Deciphering Aspirin, Dies at 77
description: Dr. John R. Vane, a British pharmacologist who shared a Nobel Prize for clarifying how aspirin works and helping to expand its use, died on Friday in Farnborough, England, the University of London reported. He was 77 and had been in failing health since he underwent heart surgery two years ago.Dr. Vane's research with aspirin, already the most widely used drug in the world, also helped advance new therapies for heart and blood vessel disease and contributed to the development of two classes of widely prescribed drugs, the cox-2 inhibitors for pain and inflammation and the ACE inhibitors in blood pressure.

title: STEEL PARTNERS II WITHDRAWS BID FOR GENCORP
description: Steel Partners II, a hedge fund based in New York, said yesterday that it had withdrawn its $17-a-share offer for the rest of GenCorp, a spacecraft-parts maker, to evaluate other investment options. GenCorp, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., rejected the offer on Nov. 15, calling the price inadequate and saying it would proceed with plans for a public offering of 7.5 million shares at $16 each. The general partner of Steel Partners wrote in a letter to the GenCorp board that GenCorp's sales of stock and debt would reduce the value of shareholders' stakes because of underwriting fees and "unnecessary premiums GenCorp is paying to repurchase its existing debt." The letter said that Steel Partners would evaluate all options including a proxy contest to gain board representation, selling some or all GenCorp shares or renewing the purchase effort.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS on Monday
description: The CBS lineup won every hour of Monday night, according to the Nielsen overnight ratings. Its sitcoms "Everybody Loves Raymond," right, and "Two and a Half Men" were particularly dominant, with "Two and a Half Men" building on the audience of "Raymond" in both total viewers and the coveted 18-to-49 age group. On ABC, "Monday Night Football" did not benefit from news coverage of last week's "Desperate Housewives" publicity stunt -- its viewership was on the low end of average for the New England Patriots' victory over the Kansas City Chiefs. At 10 p.m., CBS's "CSI: Miami" reached 21.93 million viewers, making it, as usual, the most-watched program on Monday. During the same time period, the third and final installment of NBC's "25 Million Dollar Hoax," in which a young woman fooled her family into thinking that she had won the lottery, attracted a much larger audience than its two previous episodes. Last Wednesday's episide of NBC's "LAX," the airport drama starring Heather Locklear and Blair Underwood, was probably its last. The network chose not to order any more episodes of the hourlong show, which had been moved from its initial time slot on Monday at 10 p.m. to Wednesday at 8 p.m. Last week's show was the 10th of a 13-episode order. NBC will fill the slot with specials for the next three weeks, beginning with tonight's "Tim McGraw: Here and Now," which the network had already scheduled. KATE AURTHUR

title: A Quintessence of Chicken Soup
description: Thomas Keller's French Laundry chicken stock is a simple but exemplary expression of his cooking philosophy, which avoids masking the natural flavor of high-quality ingredients. Mr. Keller is the chef at the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif., and at Per Se in New York. The stock is clear and delicate, tasting lightly of chicken and vegetables, so that it can perform as the base for a soup or pilaf, to be seasoned as the cook wishes. Simmer it with chicken legs or just reduce it slowly, and the flavor will intensify. It has none of the harsh, oversalted taste of some popular brands of canned stock and is more balanced than the fresh stock I bought at a fancy-food store. A 16-ounce container is $4.29 at Whole Foods.

Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Boston Scientific Buys Exclusive Rights To Stent Drug
description: Boston Scientific, which makes coronary stents coated with a drug called paclitaxel, said yesterday that it had acquired exclusive worldwide rights for such use of the drug from Angiotech Pharmaceuticals. Stents are metal cylinders, often coated with drugs, that are inserted into blood vessels to keep them from reclosing after doctors clean out obstructions. Angiotech, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, had licensed both Boston Scientific and privately held Cook Inc. to use paclitaxel in a variety of stents. After Cook dropped plans to develop a coronary stent to compete with Boston Scientific's best-selling Taxus, Angiotech paid it $25 million to clear the way for an exclusive license to Boston Scientific. Under the agreement announced yesterday, Boston Scientific will pay Angiotech $14 million for the right to sublicense paclitaxel in the coronary market and increase its Taxus royalty rate by one percentage point. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Minister Says Berlusconi Would Lose Early Elections
description: The country's European affairs minister, Rocco Buttiglione, warned that Prime Minster Silvio Berlusconi would lose power if he carries through on his threats to resign and call early elections over his plan to cut taxes. "If Berlusconi goes to the country, it would be a disaster," Mr. Buttiglione said, according to Agence France-Presse. With polls showing dropping support for his governing coalition, Mr. Berlusconi has been pushing to enact a tax cut, as he promised in his 2001 election campaign. But he has run into opposition from his coalition partners, who have questioned where, in a tight budget, the money would come from. In a column in the newspaper Il Foglio, Mr. Berlusconi repeated his threat to resign if tax cuts are not enacted. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Grasping Extraordinary Evil Through the Very Ordinary

title: Arts, Briefly; New Director for City Opera
description: The New York City Opera has appointed a new executive director, Jane M. Gullong, right, promoting her from the job of director of development. Ms. Gullong replaces Sherwin M. Goldman, who the opera said has been assigned full time to the task of finding the company a new home.Paul Kellogg, City Opera's artistic director, said that mission had become so unwieldy that Mr. Goldman needed to devote all his time to it. "This is Sherwin's real passion," he said. "To make a deal is a very long job. You have to deal with agencies in the city and community interests and so on. It just takes forever."Mr. Goldman will move into the offices of the architect Hugh Hardy at the beginning of the year, Mr. Kellogg told the staff in a memorandum. In a telephone interview, he denied that the move was a result of a personality clash between Mr. Goldman and the opera's chairwoman, Susan L. Baker. "This is one of those rumors that got out," he said. "It's just not so." Mr. Kellogg said a further reorganization of the administration was in the offing.Ms. Gullong, 59, has been the opera's director of development for a decade. Before that, she was director of Arts International, a cultural exchange organization, and administrative director of the Municipal Arts Society. She previously was involved in fund-raising for the New York Shakespeare Festival and Lincoln Center. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITNEY, GIFFORD COCHRAN
description: WHITNEY--Gifford Cochran, 54. Sailor, artist, craftsman; beloved father of Harry Payne Whitney III, husband of Francine Douwes Whitney and dear son of Alexandra Ewing Whitney and the late Harry Payne Whitney, died suddenly on Friday, November 19, 2004. He is also survived by his brother Cornelius Scollay Whitney, his nieces and nephew Alexandra, Rose, Leila and Josiah; his sister Nancy Marie Whitney and his in-laws, Francoise and Caissa Douwes. Memorial service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th St, Tuesday, December 7 at 5 o'clock pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in the name of Gifford Cochran Whitney to the Scholarship Fund at the Allen-Stevenson School, 132 East 78 St, NY, NY, 10021.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Santam Predicts Profit Rise
description: Santam, the biggest South African property and casualty insurer, said full-year profit might jump as much as 90 percent as claims declined and investment income rose. Profit before one-time items and good will amortization and earnings per share will probably rise "between 70 and 90 percent," the company, which is based in Cape Town, said in a statement to the JSE Securities Exchange.

title: A Cup of Joe in Providence
description: The Coffee Pot tournament this weekend in Providence, R.I., has the potential to grow into a showcase for teams with less visibility than the region's powerhouses.

title: H&R BLOCK REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS OF $52.2 MILLION
description: H&R Block, the nation's biggest tax preparation company, said yesterday that in the quarter ended Oct. 31 it had loss of $52.2 million, or 32 cents a share, from declining profit in its mortgage division. The loss, in the company's fiscal second quarter, was in contrast to net income of $10.4 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier, H&R Block said. The average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been a 16-cent loss. H&R Block's tax-preparation business makes money only in the months ahead of the April 15 tax filing deadline. Earnings from mortgage lending, the company's second-biggest business, declined as rising interest rates reduced profit from selling loans to other companies. H&R Block is based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: An Oklahoma Version of Guns vs. Butter
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 23 - The Oklahoma Legislature considers guns and the workplace a good mix. This year, it approved by an overwhelming margin a law allowing employees to keep firearms in locked vehicles on company property, making Oklahoma the envy of pro-gun groups throughout the United States.

description: For as long as I've been writing for the Times, one company has consistently created clever, well-priced products-and I've never reviewed them.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 23 - As fans and pundits plunged into a fourth day of dissecting the player-fan brawl that shook the sports landscape last weekend, the man at the center of it all took refuge in a radio studio.

title: Brush Up on Your Cognacs and Armagnacs
description: Everything is a warm amber at the Brandy Library, 25 North Moore Street (Varick Street), including the lighting and the satin frocks of the waitresses who climb library ladders to pull bottles from the shelves. Flavien Desoblin, a former bar manager, and his partners offer Cognac, Armagnac, Calvados, non-French brandy, bourbon, whiskey and rum, a choice of 800. Most are under $20 a pour, but some are more than $200. They also have wines and cocktails, like a Havana, made with dark rum, sherry and lemon, which I sipped with Michael Mango's cocktail food and desserts. Brandy Library is open 4 p.m. to 4 a.m. daily.

title: A puzzle of sexual obsession
Food Imports Close to Matching Level of Exports, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - Next year, for the first time in nearly five decades, the United States could import as much food as it exports, the Department of Agriculture said. Until now, the United States exported more food than it imported. One out of every three acres in the United States is planted for export and agriculture has been one of the few economic sectors that produced a predictable trade surplus.

title: Paul Ostrove, 73, the Name Behind the Paul Stuart Clothing Store, Dies
description: Paul Stuart Ostrove, the executive vice president who suavely presided over the selling floor of the Madison Avenue clothing store that was named for him, died on Nov. 21 at his home in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 73.

description: The Solaris/Lakota Sioux Indian Dance Theater brought Native American culture and legends to Symphony Space on Sunday afternoon. "Cokata Upo! 'Come to the Center,"' its production under the auspices of the World Music Institute, began with tales of the creation of the world, continued by commenting on the troubled present and offered hopes for cultural renewal.

title: Minaya and Randolph Hire Most of Mets' Coaching Staff
description: Willie Randolph has never managed before and has coached only in the American League, so when the Mets hired him earlier this month, he acknowledged that he had to surround himself with assistants who had more experience.

title: Powell Says U.S. Will Not Accept Final Tally in Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 - With international pressure mounting on Ukraine, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States could not accept its recent election results. He urged President Leonid Kuchma not to use force against the sprawling crowds in Kiev streets protesting the official outcome.

description: Dr. David J. Graham, the drug safety reviewer who denounced his employer, the Food and Drug Administration, before a Congressional panel last week, said yesterday that he feared being fired and had sought legal help from a group that protects whistle-blowers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Landing For Helicopter
description: A Police Department helicopter had to make an emergency landing on Monday night at the Wall Street heliport, but officials said the problems were not serious and the helicopter was later flown back to its base. "It was never in danger of crashing," Deputy Commissioner Paul J. Browne said yesterday. The Augusta 15 helicopter landed about 10:30 p.m. because of what officials believe was a software problem with a computerized stabilization system, called the Stability Augmentation System. The aircraft can fly safely without the system, Mr. Browne said, but technicians took a software package from another aircraft and installed it on the damaged helicopter. The craft then returned to its base at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, where technicians were examining the problem, Mr. Browne said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRY, KIM
description: BARRY--Kim, died tragically on November 20, 2004. Kim was a Fellow during 1997-1998 in the Arthur Garfield Hays Civil Liberties Program of New York University School of Law. She was an especially gifted student and performed her duties in the Hays Program with great distinction and extraordinary generosity. It is sad beyond words that Kim cannot continue her altruistic and loving life as a public interest lawyer. We shall never forget her. Norman Dorsen Sylvia A. But for the most part, regardless of whether they were French, Spanish, American or Australian, the rich, complex and full-bodied wines we tasted were extremely food-friendly.

title: As if the Pilgrims Had Sailed From Provence
description: At Marseille in the theater district the chef, Andy D'Amico, is serving turkey in a distinctly South of France style: in a bouillabaisse. Here is how you could do the same with leftovers this weekend: First, make a stock by simmering the carcass, stripped of meat, about 90 minutes, with some onions, fennel, leeks, celery, garlic, carrots, orange peel and thyme sprigs in about 12 cups of liquid: white wine, chicken stock, 12 crushed canned plum tomatoes and water. Strain into a clean pot. In a saucepan heat some olive oil, add a few pinches of saffron threads, some crushed fennel and cumin seeds and a quarter cup of pastis or other anise spirit. Add it to the stock. Season with salt and pepper.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Prosecutor Says Governments Shield War Criminals
description: Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor at the international tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, told the Security Council that 20 people indicted for war crimes were still at large, with many of them living freely in Serbia, Bosnia and Croatia, shielded by networks of supporters and government leaders who were resisting cooperating with the Hague-based court and in some cases tipping off the suspects to attempts to apprehend them.
