title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Regulators Seek More Data From WPP
description: The WPP Group, the marketing and advertising company, must supply more information to European Union regulators about its plan to buy the Grey Global Group. The European Commission said WPP's notification of its $1.52 billion planned purchase of Grey Global, an ad company based in New York whose clients include Procter & Gamble and Mars, was incomplete. The commission, the union's regulatory arm, had been due to rule on the deal by Nov. 26. WPP and Grey "continue to cooperate fully with the commission services," it said in a statement. The company would not comment further.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Caesarean Birth Rate Rises
description: A record 1.13 million births in the United States last year were Caesarean deliveries, a government report has found. The rate of Caesareans, 27 percent, has increased by a third since 1996, partly because more women are requesting elective Caesareans, or planned surgical deliveries, according to the report, from the National Center for Health Statistics. The report also found that the birth rate for women ages 35 to 44 rose by more than 5 percent last year, the first time that births to women over 40 topped 100,000 in a single year. The birth rate among teenagers fell for the 12th straight year. John Files (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Wilson Criticizes U.S.
description: At the unveiling of a Paris exhibition of theater memorabilia, the Texas-born avant-garde director Robert Wilson thanked France for supporting his career and attacked arts financing policies in the United States. "We lack a sound cultural policy," Mr. Wilson said at the Fondation Pierre Berg-Yves Saint Laurent. "Believe it or not, as a taxpayer in the state of New York, my tax dollar for the most part cannot go to support anyone outside the state of New York. How provincial can we be?" Mr. Wilson praised the French people for their support of the arts and said that it was in the French city of Nancy that he got his big break in theater with the 1971 show "Deafman Glance." "The French discovered my work," he said. "I had no idea that I would ever work in the theater or have a career in the theater." The exhibition has drawings and and other plans from his recent show at the Comdie Franaise, an adaptation of Fontaine's beloved Fables. The exhibition will be up through July. HLNE FOUQUET

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - A new report from the Central Intelligence Agency says the arms trafficking network led by the Pakistani scientist A.Q. Khan provided Iran's nuclear program with "significant assistance," including the designs for "advanced and efficient" weapons components.

title: Quake Planning Leads to California Building Boom
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. - When the Northridge earthquake devastated Los Angeles County in 1994, St. John's Health Center, a private Catholic hospital in this seaside community, suffered such extensive damage that an entire wing had to be torn down. The most severely damaged of the 23 hospitals that had to suspend some or all services after the quake, St. John's was forced to close for nine months.

World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Police Officers Lynched
description: Three federal intelligence agents were lynched by an angry mob in the southeastern section of Mexico City last night. Two of the agents were beaten to death and their bodies were set on fire in front of cameras that broadcast the images live on national television. One agent, identified as Edgar Moreno Nolasco, was rescued and rushed to the hospital. The commissioner of Federal Preventive Police said the agents had been investigating drug trafficking. The area is considered one of the most violent in the city, and in recent years residents have been known to lynch suspected delinquents rather than turn them over to the police. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Iraq's New Court Finds Itself on Trial
description: WEST POINT, N.Y. - The worst kind of hypocrisy is the sort that pretends to stand on principle. The latest example is the failure of the United Nations, our European allies and nongovernmental groups to support Iraqi efforts to bring Saddam Hussein and his henchmen to justice.

description: Forget for a moment that a new wing of the New York Hall of Science in Queens is opening today. Or that within its 55,000 square feet of exhibition space, illuminated by daylight filtered through translucent fiberglass-clad walls, it is possible to arm wrestle someone in Anchorage, Alaska, using the Internet. Or to watch a golden orb spider weave its web. Or to sample the scent of a meteorite. Or even to find an indoor supervised play area that looks like a preschool in a park.

For Bonbons With a Bijou Attitude
description: Debauve & Gallais is the newest entry in New York's crowded field of chocolate shops, with a branch of its Parisian boutiques now open at 20 East 69th Street. As befits a former purveyor to French royalty, the shop looks like a place to find a bauble to wear, not to nibble. But then many of the praline and ganache-filled bonbons in dark chocolate come dusted with gold leaf. They arrive weekly from Paris. Rami Sambath, far left, runs the shop, and Franois Belizare, left, is the marketing director. Upstairs is a tiny salon for sampling chocolates, including the exquisite flat discs called pistoles, some scented with orange. Assortments are around $84 a pound.

title: An Airbus in-your-face challenge
Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Court Orders Judge To Recuse Himself
description: A state appellate court in Brooklyn ordered a State Supreme Court justice yesterday to stop presiding over a State Senate race in Westchester County that is still too close to call. Judge Francis A. Nicolai has overseen the arduous counting of paper ballots in the race between the Republican incumbent, Nicholas A. Spano, and Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democratic county legislator. In its order, the four-judge appellate panel declined to explain its decision. Lawyers for Mr. Spano had argued that Judge Nicolai, a Democrat who just won a decisive victory in his own judicial race, had a conflict of interest because his name appeared on the contested ballots that he would have to accept or reject. The case will now be reassigned to another state justice. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Suspect In Prosecutor's Slaying Is Killed
description: The police in Caracas fatally shot a lawyer wanted for questioning in the car-bombing death last week of Danilo Anderson, a state prosecutor who was investigating opposition figures who supported a coup against President Hugo Chvez in 2002. When investigators approached the lawyer, Antonio Lpez, on a bustling downtown street, a gunfight erupted and he was killed, said the interior minister, Jesse Chacon. The authorities later raided Mr. Lpez's home and said they found high-powered weapons and explosives. Officials did not provide details about his suspected ties to the car bombing. Juan Forero (NYT)

description: Suddenly, the nation's most dysfunctional state legislature has become a nest of "reformers." The last election undoubtedly convinced a few of New York's docile legislators that something had to be done. For some, that means real reform as soon as possible. Others want big reforms, so big they can't be expected from Albany soon. Still others, the most devious of them all, want something called reform, as long as nothing much changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, CY
description: COLEMAN--Cy. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of its beloved friend, the renowned American composer and pianist Cy Coleman, on November 18, 2004 in New York City at the age of 75. Mr. Coleman was a deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for most of his life. An accomplished and classically trained pianist who made his Carnegie Hall debut at the age of 7, Cy Coleman's musical journey led him to the world of jazz and, of course, to the Great White Way. He was one of this country's greatest and most honored songwriters, with such immortal standards as "Witchcraft", "The Best is Yet to Come", "Big Spender", "I've Got Your Number", and "Hey, Look Me Over" to his credit. His Broadway scores included "Sweet Charity", "City of Angels", "The Will Rogers Follies", "On the Twentieth Century", "I Love My Wife" and "The Life", to name but a few. Cy Coleman was always at home at the Steinway, and to hear him play was a real joy and, for us, inspiring. Though our lives have been forever enriched by his music, his generous and jaunty persona will be sorely missed by us all. To Shelby and Lilly Cye, we extend our love and our heartfeld condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: LOCKHEED'S CHIEF TO ADD ROLE OF CHAIRMAN IN APRIL
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the nation's biggest military contractor, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Robert Stevens, would also assume the role of chairman in April upon the retirement of Vance Coffman. Mr. Stevens, 53, became chief executive in August after Mr. Coffman, 60, retired as chief executive after 37 years with Lockheed. The company, based in Bethesda, Md., said Mr. Coffman would remain chairman until April.

title: Killer in 'Preppie Murder' Case Is Arrested
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., who served 15 years in prison for killing an 18-year-old woman in a case that became known as the "preppie murder," was released on bail today after his arrest Tuesday night on charges of drug possession and driving with a suspended license.

title: With Less Swagger, Spurrier Returns to SEC
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 23 - Steve Spurrier's swagger was not quite so pronounced when he arrived Tuesday at Williams-Brice Stadium to be introduced as the football coach at the University of South Carolina. His words came without the same cocky self-assurance he displayed in 12 seasons as coach at Florida.

title: Breaking the Motherhood Drama With a Drama on Motherhood
description: Two things stood out about the Wednesday matinee crowd blowing into the Cherry Lane Theater in the West Village last week. One, it was only 11 o'clock in the morning. Two, among the 170 or so theatergoers descending from chartered buses or air-kissing friends in the lobby, there was not a single man in sight. Pure estrogen in the house.

title: Mideast peace : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BASF Plans Job Cuts
description: BASF, the chemical maker, will cut about 10 percent of its work force at the company's largest site in Ludwigshafen, Germany, over the next three years to save costs. Based on an agreement with the works council, the number of jobs, currently 35,604, will be reduced without firings to about 32,000 by the end of 2007, and is to remain at that level until 2010. The job reductions came as a further step in BASF's efforts to cut costs at Ludwigshafen by 450 million euros ($589 million) by mid-2005 to "improve the competitiveness of the world's largest chemical site over long term," the company said. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: WORLD WRESTLING POSTS 74% DECLINE IN PROFIT
description: World Wrestling Entertainment, which produces televised wrestling shows, said yesterday that net income for the quarter ended Oct. 29 declined 74 percent to $4.5 million, or 6 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., also said that revenue fell 11 percent, to $83.9 million, from $94.4 million in the quarter in 2003. World Wrestling blamed falling attendance, saying that the average at North American events was approximately 3,800 during the quarter, compared with approximately 4,500 in the 2003 quarter. Other negatives were that pay-per-view sales missed expectations and that advertising revenue fell by almost half, the company said.

title: Rival Family Beat Gambinos to Payoff in Prison Job, Witness Testifies
description: The Gambino crime family had so much control over several New York construction unions in the 1990's that its bosses were annoyed when they were cut out of a $22 million building contract for the federal prison in Brooklyn, a former Gambino member testified in federal court yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Holidays But Bolsheviks' Day Is Scrapped
description: The Parliament took its first step to abolish the Nov. 7 holiday that commemorates the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917. Despite pleas by the Communist Party, Parliament voted overwhelmingly to replace the holiday with a new one on Nov. 4 commemorating the uprising against Polish domination in 1612. The legislation, which still requires two more votes, would also cut two other holidays but would extend the New Year's holidays to 5 days, from 2, and the overall number of holidays to 12, from 11 now. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONSOR, MOLLIE (NEE WIENER)
description: CONSOR--Mollie (nee Wiener) 92, loving wife of Robert (deceased). Passed away peacefully on November 22, 2004. She is survived by her children Harvey and Yvette Consor and Helaine (Arthur, deceased) Friedman and grandchildren Glenn and Gwen Consor, Jill Consor, Lisa Consor and Jarrett Behar and David Friedman. Mollie was a devoted daughter and wife, a deeply loved mother and dearest friend to her grandchildren. She resided in Long Beach for over 60 years and was a tireless worker for Temple Israel, Hadassah, B'nai B'rith and Long Beach Hospital. Mollie was held in high respect by all who came to know her. May she rest in peace with her beloved Bob. Services Wednesday 10:30am at I.J. Morris Inc., 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, N.Y. 516-486-2500. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery. Donations may be made to Hadassah in her memory.

title: Piano Presented Modestly With a Chamberish Feel
description: Andr Watts opened his three-concert series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday by offering a self-effacing counterbalance to the grandiose series title, "The Art of Andr Watts." For this first installment, he performed as a chamber music pianist, in collaborations with David Shifrin, the clarinetist; Paul Neubauer, the violist; and Georg Schenck, a pianist.

title: Knicks Make a So-So Climb Into First Place
description: The Knicks do not have a winning record, and they have not received much respect during this young N.B.A. season. But now they have something four other teams in the Atlantic Division would love to own: sole possession of first place.

title: A Reporter-Anchor Who Blazed a Trail of His Own
description: He has fought presidents and hurricanes, network suits and the turn in television news toward the frivolous and sometimes tawdry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAY, DR. ARTHUR
description: GRAY--Dr. Arthur. Those of us at HIP Health Plan of New York who knew Dr. Arthur Gray are deeply saddened by his passing. When we think about Dr. Gray and the time we spent with him, both as a colleague and friend, a true testimonial is the celebration of his life. He was a gentleman and a gentle man. He was good, kind, caring and thoughtful. He was personable, and was enjoyable to spend time with because of his wide interests and knowledge. Above all, Dr. Gray was dedicated to his work. He was widely admired for his ethics and wise counseling. Although Dr. Gray did not work for HIP Health Plan, he kept a close working relationship with HIP and HIP benefited from his experience. He was an exceptional orthopedist associated with the Queens/Long Island Medical Group, where he was also a member of the Board of Directors, and the North Shore University Hospital at Forest Hills, where he was Senior Vice President for Medical Affairs and Chief of Staff. Perhaps the essential factor in celebrating the life of a physician, especially this physician, Dr. Arthur Gray, is to observe that his patients knew that he cared about them, and that so many of them thrived under his care. We extend our profound sympathy to his beloved wife, Sigrid, and to his daughters, Nichole and Heather, and other members of Dr. Gray's family. Anthony L. Watson, Chairman & CEO Daniel T. McGowan, President & COO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Campaign Against Drunken Driving
description: Most mayoral news conferences feature scores of reporters and several television cameras crammed into a room with the mayor, his staff and numerous V.I.P.'s. But yesterday, with little fanfare, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood with four women, unknown to most New Yorkers, in the parking lot at City Hall and quietly affixed a red ribbon to the antenna of the S.U.V. that ferries him about town. Children of three of the women were killed by drunken drivers, and the fourth woman's brother-in-law was killed by one. The ribbon is part of the Tie One On for Safety campaign of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, to get motorists to affix a red MADD ribbon to their cars as a visible pledge to drive safely. Mr. Bloomberg said, "We are not going to tolerate drunk driving," and told the half dozen onlookers who stood in the windy lot that there was really little more he could say. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Marriage (Well, Domestic Partnership) of Food and Fun
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. - "EAT, drink and be Mary." No misspelling here; this is the slogan of Hamburger Mary's Bar and Grille, a restaurant chain openly and ambitiously oriented toward gay and lesbian diners.

title: Giving Poor Children a Chance to Study Hard, Long and Late
description: WILMINGTON, Del. - SOMETIME around 6:30 on a Monday night last September, Byron Bailey left the rectangle of packed dirt that passes for a play area in the Riverside housing project here. He was due back at his middle school, Nativity Prep, by 7 for the mandatory two-hour study hall, and he didn't want a check mark for arriving late.

title: Questions Are Seen onMerck's Stance on Vioxx
description: For all the risks associated with Merck's arthritis and pain drug Vioxx, the company has always pointed to one virtue: Vioxx was less likely to cause ulcers or stomach bleeding than cheaper over-the-counter medications like Advil or Aleve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUGHES, JAMES E.
description: HUGHES--James E., of Stony Brook, N.Y., born May 1913 in Clayton, Missouri, son of Samuel Wheeler Hughes and Emma Eugenia Berry Hughes, passed away November 21, 2004. Associate and Partner of Coudert Brothers, an international law firm, from 1935-1985. Member of its Management and Executive Committees for thirty years and head of its corporate department. Retired member of the Boards of the MortonThiokol Corporation and Coty International. Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Mills College of Education 1963-1968 and member of the Board 1948-1968. Former member and Chair of the Board of the Far Brook School, Short Hills, N.J. Former member of the Board of the Mannes College of Music. Survived by his wife of 64 years, Elizabeth Buermann Hughes and his four children and their partners, James E. Hughes, Jr. and Jacqueline Merrill; Peter B. and Agneta Hughes, Elisabeth Ellen and Robert Templeton, Barbara Ann and Robert Gibson. Also survived by eleven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren and their spouses and fiances, and four greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Setauket Presbyterian Church, 5 Caroline Avenue, Setauket, Long Island on Friday, November 26 at 2:00 P.M. The family has requested that no flowers be sent and that in lieu contributions be made to The Far Brook School, 52 Great Hills Road, Short Hills, New Jersey 07078 or to the Food Pantry, a project of the Port Jefferson Ecumenical Outreach, checks should be made to Mary Ann Bell at 1 Stony Hill Road, Port Jefferson, N.Y. 11777.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Toy Safety Warning
description: Federal officials urged Americans to think about toy safety this holiday season, reporting that the deaths of 11 children under age 15 were caused by hazardous toys in the past year. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said most of the deaths occurred when children aspirated or choked on small toys like balls, balloons or game pieces. The commission estimated that 155,400 American children were treated for injuries caused by toys in 2003; it noted, however, that this was a decrease of nearly 23 percent since 2001. John Files (NYT)

description: EARLY in my marriage, determined to prepare a family Thanksgiving myself, I planned dinner for 26. I ordered a whopping 37-pound turkey. In my eagerness and anxiety, I bought and cooked masses of food.

title: Lawmakers' Pet Projects Lay Deep Inside $388 Billion Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - The $388 billion spending bill approved by Congress in the last few days is a cornucopia full of money designated for specific highway projects, locks and dams, parks, libraries, airports, museums, zoos, hospitals, schools and universities in every corner of the country, from the northernmost reaches of Maine to the southern tip of Texas and the most remote islands of Hawaii.

title: Isaac Newton in the Kitchen
description: PALO ALTO, Calif. - ANY absent-minded scientist can let a saucepan of milk boil over. But it takes a true genius to do it twice in 20 minutes.

title: Holiday Tyranny Will Win in the End
description: For all you fancy-schmancy snobs who jet off to St. Bart's for the holidays, "Christmas With the Kranks" has an important message, and you'd better pay attention. If you shirkers refuse to stay home and celebrate Christmas like the rest of us, we don't want you in our community.

title: A.I.G. Will Accept Monitor and Pay $80 Million to Close Inquiries
description: American International Group, the world's leading insurance company, has agreed to accept an independent monitor and to pay about $80 million to settle investigations into the sale of insurance that was used by companies to manipulate their earnings, people briefed on the investigations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, IRVING H.
description: LEVINE--Irving H. Congregation Rodeph Sholom is deeply saddened by the death of Irving H. Levine. Irving was a devoted husband to Lillian and beloved father of Robert N. Levine, our Senior Rabbi, and Scott and Sheree Levine. He is also survived by his daughters-in-law, Gina Stahl Levine and Alice Geller, his brother Aaron and sister Charlotte Rome and his seven grandchildren, Judah, Ezra, Maya, Kate, Sarah, William and David. The funeral will be held in Springfield, MA on November 24 at 1PM at the Harold R. Ascher & Son Memorial Chapel. There will be a memorial service at Rodeph Sholom on Wednesday, December 1 at 5:45PM. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Clergy, Board of Trustees, Staff and Members of Congregation Rodeph Sholom

title: Stagehands Reach Deal on Contract
description: After an all-night negotiating session, Broadway's stagehands and producers reached an agreement early yesterday on a new three-year contract. The deal is the latest between producers and the theater industry's three major unions, effectively assuring labor peace on Broadway at least through the spring of 2007.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Plans New Wi-Fi Venture
description: SBC Communications will provide high-speed wireless Internet access at Barnes & Noble stores and Avis Rent a Car System airport business centers for three years. SBC, based in San Antonio, is selling wireless fidelity, or Wi-Fi, at about 600 of Barnes & Noble's 663 stores, it said yesterday. The service, which lets customers surf the Web on laptop computers and personal digital assistants, will also be available next year at 88 of 1,000 United States locations of Avis, which is owned by Cendant.

title: Corlies Smith, Editor of All-Star Authors, Dies at 75
description: Corlies Smith, a New York book editor who in a 50-year career published an all-star list of writers, from Muriel Spark and Jimmy Breslin to William Trevor and Calvin Trillin, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: City Council Overrides Veto of Bill on Motorized Scooters
description: City Council leaders pushed through legislation yesterday that establishes tough new penalties for those who sell or use unlicensed motorized scooters, saying that the current ban on the scooters does not go far enough to stem a growing problem.

title: Carve the Pumpkin, Eat the Squash
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y. - ON a recent bright autumn day, every available surface in Amy Goldman's kitchen here was lined with bulbous, warty, ridged and long-necked squashes in shades of red, gold, orange, green, ivory and even blue. Some were solid colored, others mottled or striped. All are Ms. Goldman's passion.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Verizon To Buy Licenses From Ntelos
description: Verizon Wireless has agreed to buy wireless licenses in Pennsylvania from Ntelos Inc. for $15.5 million. The agreement includes spectrum licenses in the Harrisburg, Lancaster, Reading and York areas, which cover a population of 2.1 million people. Verizon Wireless, which already operates in Pennsylvania, expects the transaction to close in the second quarter of 2005, a spokeswoman, Nancy Stark, said in a telephone interview. Verizon Communications, based in New York, owns 55 percent of Verizon Wireless; the Vodafone Group of Britain owns the rest.

title: Finding Empowerment in a Tragic Death
description: It's only a desk, a glass of water and a microphone, but when this familiar combination, perched on top of a platform is rolled onstage at the end of Nilaja Sun's charming "Blues for a Gray Sun," theatergoers may suffer pangs of sadness.

title: Two Yanks Expect to Stay
description: Based on general discussions with the Yankees, Alan Nero, who represents the free agents Miguel Cairo and John Flaherty, said he believed the two would return next season. Flaherty, a 37-year-old backup catcher, wants to continue playing. Cairo, 30, earned a starting role at second base last season. Nero said that although the Yankees had not defined their plans, Cairo expected to start again.

title: WAL-MART WILL ALLOW UNIONS AT ITS STORES IN CHINA
description: Wal-Mart Stores, which is opposed to trade unions for its 1.2 million workers in the United States, will allow them for its employees in China, where restrictions on foreign retailers are expected to loosen. "Should associates request formation of a union, Wal-Mart China would respect their wishes and honor its obligation under China's Trade Union Law," the company said yesterday in a statement. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., is competing with Carrefour of France and Metro Group of Germany as China prepares to allow foreign retailers to open as many stores as they like, starting on Dec. 11. Wal-Mart plans to open up to 15 stores in China next year, for a total of 58, Joe Hatfield, Wal-Mart's chief executive for Asia, said in a Nov. 2 interview.

title: Brooklyn Boy Falls as Screen Gives Way
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn boy was critically injured yesterday when he fell out a second-floor window and landed headfirst on a concrete drive, Fire Department officials and neighbors said.

title: Airbus Plans Midsize Long-Distance Jet
description: TOULOUSE, France, Nov. 23 - The fierce rivalry between Airbus and Boeing, which has already ignited claims of unfair trade practices on both sides of the Atlantic, seems likely to heat up further, with signs that Airbus will build a competitor to Boeing's new midsize jetliner, the 7E7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARGEOTES, SHARON
description: MARGEOTES -- Sharon on November 22. Born November 4, 1964 in South End On Sea, in the United Kingdom. She attended St. Martin's College of Art in London. She leaves her son Alex, and her husband James, her mother Patricia Keep, sister Susan and her husband Jack Tropper, nephew Max, her brother Phillip Cawdery, and nephew Adam and niece Gabriella. Sharon will be deeply missed by all those she touched so deeply. We all love you dearly and will feel you in our hearts always. Memorial service Monday, November 29th, at 3:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: A Mother Deported, and a Child Left Behind
description: In April of last year, when her mother dropped by federal immigration headquarters in Manhattan to complete some paperwork, 8-year-old Virginia Feliz became part of a growing tribe of American children who have lost a parent to deportation.

title: A Very Haitian Story
description: MIAMI - On Sunday, Oct. 24, United Nations troops and Haitian police forces launched a military operation in Bel-Air, one of the poorest and most volatile neighborhoods in Haiti's capital, Port-au-Prince. Their stated goal was to oust armed gangs, some of which are still loyal to Haiti's deposed president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: When the Keyboard Is Merely an Option
description: You need much more than excellent technique to perform George Crumb's "Makrokosmos," 24 fantasy pieces for amplified piano in two volumes, written in 1972-73. As the pianist Margaret Leng Tan demonstrated on Saturday night at Zankel Hall, you must also be a physically flexible and focused actor.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Wednesday with an article about Thanksgiving stuffing misstated the residence of Maureen Stein, who was shown cooking her sausage stuffing. It is the Upper East Side of Manhattan, not Queens.

title: For an Old Hospital, New High-End Uses
description: A developer who faced resistance and skepticism when he announced plans to convert a 1970's-era psychiatric center in the Bronx into a modern, suburban-style office park seems to have been vindicated. Another major tenant has taken a long-term lease, and plans are being drawn up to build more offices there.

title: In Congress, Growing Doubts on Spending Process
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - The power of the purse has always been the ultimate power of Congress. But the way Congress is exercising that power is causing a ruckus on Capitol Hill, where members of both parties say the system for financing the government is broken.

title: Without Rather, CBS Can Get a Fresh Start, Some Say
description: For some veterans of CBS News, the departure of Dan Rather from the network's evening newscast represents a kind of coda on a long, sad song of decline from greatness.

title: INSIDE
description: White House Seeking Compromise on Spy Bill The White House held out hope that a compromise could be reached on legislation to overhaul American intelligence. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld vowed his support for President Bush's position and denied he had exerted his influence to scuttle the bill to protect the Defense Department's budgetary powers over intelligence.

title: Despite Growing Unrest, Ukraine Certifies Winner in Election
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 24 - In defiance of Western leaders and amid growing popular unrest on the streets, the government of Leonid D. Kuchma, the outgoing president of Ukraine, ignored reports of widespread electoral fraud and certified his prime minister today as president-elect.

description: The discount airline EasyJet said that its second-half profit rose slightly from a year ago, but that it expected a challenging winter ahead. Pretax profits were 62.2 million ($115.6 million), up from 51.5 million a year ago. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: A Paean to Tofu in a Japanese Pub
description: ARTISANAL and tofu are not two words I normally think of together, but artisanal tofu is what they showcase at En Japanese Brasserie, which essays the brave and, to my mind, quixotic challenge of casting tofu as the most refined of delicacies and rarest of dramatic events. Tofu does not merely appear on the En menu. It is given advertised, neatly spaced show times, much like a killer whale at Sea World.

description: Dan Rather announced yesterday that he would step down next year as anchor and managing editor of "CBS Evening News." The move came two months after he acknowledged fundamental flaws in a broadcast report that raised questions about President Bush's National Guard service.

description: FALLUJA, Iraq, Nov. 24 - United States marines and Iraqi soldiers today discovered the empty home of Abdullah Janabi, the insurgent leader of this city's mujahedeen council, and his bomb-laden mosque, where they found a massive supply of weapons that dwarfed any of the hundreds of caches yet found, military officials said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 'Santa' Cuffs Himself To Buckingham Palace
description: Buckingham Palace again became a target for fathers' rights protesters when a man wearing a Santa Claus outfit climbed atop the palace's main gates and chained himself to a lamppost for two hours. The police arrested the man, David Pyke, but were first forced to bring in a hydraulic lift and use bolt cutters to snap his handcuffs. "It's an appeal to Her Majesty the Queen to put the father back into Father Christmas," said a spokesman for the protest group, Fathers 4 Justice, which contends that custody laws favor women. In September, another member of the group donned a Batman costume, climbed over the palace gates and onto a ledge, where he stood for hours. Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDELMAN, ISIDORE S., M.D.
description: EDELMAN--Isidore S., M.D. On November 21, 2004. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Loving father of Arthur and Joseph Edelman, Susan Edelman Bleckner and Ann Korchin, stepfather to Tina Springer - Miller. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Service Wednesday 10 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Snookering the Taxpayers
description: It is called a snooker clause in legislative parlance -- a last-minute insert into a dense and hurried midnight bill that, if ever disclosed after passage, always leaves legislators shocked, shocked at how such an undemocratic bit of mischief ever came to be. "No earthly idea how that got in there," said Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader, after the impenetrable, 14-inch-thick omnibus budget bill turned out to have a provision giving Congressional chairmen and staff members entree to Americans' tax returns without regard to privacy protections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERT, GERALD
description: SILBERT--Gerald, age 82. With great sadness but knowing he is at peace, the family of Gerald Silbert announce his passing on November 22, 2004 during his final battle with Alzheimer's disease. Loving and devoted husband to Ramie (nee Jasper) for over 60 years, adoring and loving father of Terry, son of the late Herbert and Mollie Silbert, brother of Robert Silbert MD and his wife Phyllis; uncle of Joanne and Tom, Donna and Kevin, Joellen and Tracy; great-uncle of six. Beloved brother-in-law of Rita Nelson. Funeral services will be held at The Park Avenue Synagogue, Madison Avenue and 87th St., on Wednesday, November 24, at 9:30am. Shiva will be observed at the Silbert home, Wednesday through Sunday, 1-3pm and 7:30-9pm. Contributions may be made to The American Technion Society, Women's Division, 55 E. 59 St., NY NY 10022 or The Park Avenue Synagogue. SILBERT--Gerald. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Gerald Silbert of New York, an outstanding friend of Israel and the Jewish people. Devoted husband of Ramie Silbert, who is honorary president of the ATS Women's Division and a member of the national Board of Directors, Mr. Silbert was a brilliant attorney with the firm of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz and Mendelsohn, and shared his wife's decades-long devotion to the ATS, the Technion and Israel. Technion Guardians who reached the highest level of support, the Silberts have provided generously for numerous Women's Division priorities, including medical engineering projects and faculty development. They are responsible for the Ramie and Gerald Silbert Molecular Bacteriology Research Facility, the Women's Division Ramie and Gerald Silbert VIP Lounge, and the Silbert Scholarship Fund. Through Mr. Silbert's efforts, the Rashi Foundation, of which he was a trustee and legal counsel, became a major Technion supporter, also at the Guardian level. In recognition of the couple's long-term, vital support, the Silberts were both awarded honorary Technion fellowships. We extend our sincere condolences to Ramie Silbert, daughter Terry Silbert and the entire Silbert family. The American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Ilse Blumenfeld, Women's Division President Natalie Lyons, Women's Division Chair Gloria Neimark, Women's Leadership Director SILBERT--Gerald. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of Gerald Silbert, an Honorary Vice President. We extend to his wife Ramie and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President SILBERT--Gerald. We shall treasure the times spent with our dear friend, mentor and fearless leader--Jerry. Rosalie, Marty and Nita, and Mel and Pearl

title: Book Adds Layers of Complexityto the Schindler Legend
description: An authoritative new biography of Oskar Schindler, the German businessman who saved more than 1,000 Jews from the Nazis, clashes sharply with his idealized portrayal in the Oscar-winning 1993 Steven Spielberg movie "Schindler's List" and the 1982 historical novel by Thomas Keneally that inspired it. The Schindler who emerges in this latest account -- based on interviews with Holocaust survivors and newly discovered papers, including letters stored in a suitcase by a mistress -- is far more flawed than the one depicted in the movie and novel. Even so, scholars say, the fresh revelations about Schindler's darker side cast his moral transformation and heroism into starker relief.

title: Citing Terror Issues, Britain Plans ID Cards
description: LONDON, Nov. 23 - Invoking a global threat of terrorism, the British government announced plans on Tuesday to introduce national identity cards for the first time since the World War II era. An opposition legislator said the government wanted to create a "climate of fear" in advance of elections expected next year.

title: Inflation and Interest Rates
description: If the Federal Reserve Board were free to manipulate interest rates solely in response to business conditions, it would make sense to stand pat in December, and avoid a rate hike despite recent signs of inflation. Unfortunately, Alan Greenspan, the chairman, doesn't have that kind of flexibility these days. Raising interest rates looks like the more prudent route -- even though stagnating wages could really use a little help right now.

description: Pushed by a substantial increase in gasoline prices, the Canadian Consumer Price Index rose by 2.3 last month, Statistics Canada said. The inflation rate compares to a 1.8 percent increase during September. Statistics Canada attributed most of the gain to a 20.3 percent increase in gas prices compared with a year earlier in the month. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Rejects Peterson Petition
description: A state appeals court in San Francisco rejected a petition by lawyers for Scott Peterson to order a new penalty phase in his murder trial. On Nov. 12 a jury in Redwood City found Mr. Peterson guilty of killing his pregnant wife, Laci, and it is scheduled to consider his sentence next week. A Superior Court judge, Alfred A. Delucchi, had denied the lawyers' request on Monday, leading to their appeal. Mr. Peterson's lawyers are now expected to ask the state's Supreme Court to intervene. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: EL PASO RETURNED TO PROFIT IN LATEST QUARTER
description: The El Paso Corporation, owner of the nation's biggest network of interstate natural gas pipelines, yesterday posted earnings of $16 million, or 3 cents a share, for the second quarter, the company said. That was in contrast to a restated loss of $2.07 a share a year earlier. Second-quarter earnings for the company, based in Houston, were delayed while it awaited completion of an accounting review required after it disclosed last February that its oil and gas reserves had been overstated.. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the revised estimate of oil and gas reserves, which has prompted shareholder lawsuits against the company. Shares of El Paso rose 4 cents, to $9.78.

title: 1929:Clemenceau Dies at 88 : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO

title: Leaders at Talks in Egypt Urge Support for Political Resolution to the Turmoil in Iraq
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Nov. 23 - American and Iraqi officials joined Iraq's Middle Eastern neighbors and the world's largest powers on Tuesday to call for international support for Iraq's transition to democracy starting with elections in January, in an attempt to quiet often bitter wrangling prompted by the American-led invasion.

description: One hundred fifty-seven New York City schoolchildren are spending their third year in the third grade after being held back under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's new retention policy, city education officials said yesterday.

title: Rafael Eitan, 75, Ex-General and Chief of Staff in Israel, Dies
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 23 - Rafael Eitan, a former Israeli Army chief of staff and government minister who was reprimanded after Lebanese Christian allies of Israel massacred Palestinian refugees in 1982, drowned on Tuesday after being swept into stormy seas. He was 75.

description: The brawl that erupted last week at a basketball game in Auburn Hills, Mich., has prompted extensive soul-searching about the role of aggression -- on the part of athletes and fans -- in sporting events.

title: White House Seeks Deal to Save Stalled Intelligence Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - The White House held out hope on Tuesday that a compromise could be reached on legislation to overhaul American intelligence, as Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, who has been accused of working secretly to scuttle the bill, vowed his support for President Bush's position.

title: Sheffield Surgery Delayed
description: Right fielder Gary Sheffield was scheduled to have arthroscopic surgery on his separated left shoulder yesterday, but the Yankees said the procedure was postponed until next week. The team said weather problems kept Sheffield from getting to Birmingham, Ala., for the operation. Tyler Kepner

title: Nafta, Redux

Back in 1993, Bill Clinton doled out promises to everybody and their mother to get the North American Free Trade Agreement passed, while President Bush in 2001 had his Congressional allies actually hold a vote open for an extra 23 minutes so they could force a weeping North Carolina congressman to abandon his textile constituency and give the president the single-vote margin he needed for trade negotiating authority.

title: Martin Malia, 80, Soviet-Era Skeptic, Dies
description: Martin Malia, a historian of Soviet Communism who persistently challenged the prevailing notion of that system's durability, died last Friday in a convalescent home in Oakland, Calif. He was 80 years old.

Six months ago, there was no home, as Theresa Bell and her four daughters lived with her mother in a one-bedroom apartment in Plainfield, taking turns eating at the kitchen table, sharing beds and couches, or sleeping draped across chairs.

title: DEERE'S INCOME ROSE FIVEFOLD IN THE FOURTH QUARTER
description: Deere & Company, the world's biggest maker of agricultural equipment, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit surged fivefold as farmers took advantage of higher income and tax breaks to replace aging tractors and combines. Net income for the quarter ended Oct. 31 increased to $356.7 million, or $1.41 a share, from $70.6 million, or 27 cents, a year earlier, Deere said. The company, based in Moline, Ill., was expected to earn 99 cents a share, the average estimate of 16 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Farm-machine sales rose 35 percent, to $2.7 billion in the quarter, helped by higher shipments and prices, a weaker dollar and a tax provision expiring next month that lets farmers write off a higher percentage of equipment purchases sooner.

From sports to news programs, on networks and local stations, Ron Artest's angry storming into the boozed-up crowd at the Palace of Auburn Hills has become an indelible part of sports history.

Their stated goal was to oust armed gangs, some of which are still loyal to Haiti's deposed president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

The area earned its fearsome reputation as a haven for thieves, killers, crime families and terrorists, as well as insurgents who fled Falluja before the fighting started there.

title: With No More Parents to Conquer, He Wept
description: There comes the moment in the career of many directors when they are compelled to tell the story of a great man in whose life they seem to see a glimmer of their own image. Francis Ford Coppola had Preston Tucker, the automotive innovator who tried and failed to challenge Detroit in much the same way as the filmmaker took on Hollywood, while Martin Scorsese and Mel Gibson each had Jesus. Now Oliver Stone has Alexander the Great, the Macedonian tyrant who cut a bloody swath through the ancient world to no obvious end other than, if Mr. Stone's big, blowsy movie is to believed, get away from his kvetch of a mother.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Royal Philips To Cut Costs
description: Roy-al Philips Electronics, Europe's largest maker of televisions and CD players, plans to save about 500 million euros ($654 million) annually in three to four years by reorganizing administrative and support functions. The company, based in Amsterdam, did not specify whether job cuts will be part of the measures, which are intended to come on top of 1.1 billion euros in savings reached by the end of last year, said a spokesman, Jayson Otke. The chief executive officer, Gerard J. Kleisterlee, above, has revived profit at the company by cutting more than 50,000 jobs after losses in 2001 and 2002. In October, the company reported its biggest quarterly profit since the final three months of 2000, helped by higher sales of semiconductors and LCD screens.

title: CABLEVISION TO BUY 5 SATELLITES FROM LOCKHEED MARTIN
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it would buy five satellites from the Lockheed Martin Corporation for as much as $740 million to expand its Voom satellite TV service. Cablevision, based in Bethpage, N.Y., said this week that its Rainbow DBS unit is buying the satellites to expand Voom's capacity for high-definition channels to more than 5,000 from its current 39. Voom, with 26,000 subscribers, is trying to break into a market dominated by EchoStar Communications and the DirecTV Group, the biggest satellite TV operator with 12.1 million customers. In a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Cablevision did not say how Rainbow DBS would finance the satellites beyond a payment of $48 million from cash on hand.

title: CENDANT TO FRANCHISE DAYS INN HOTELS IN RUSSIA
description: The Cendant Corporation, the nation's largest travel and real estate services company, said yesterday that it would franchise Days Inn hotels in Russia and the other countries of the former Soviet Union. Cendant, based in New York, said Days Inn would open more than 45 hotels over the next five years in the former Soviet states, as well as in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The closely held Hermitage Hospitality, based in Moscow, will develop the hotels. The new hotels are expected to generate more than $195 million in revenue in the first five years, Cendant said. Shares of Cendant rose 33 cents, to $22.33.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 - Congress approved a short-term spending bill on Wednesday providing money for much of the federal government through early December after Republicans failed to win agreement to kill a disputed provision standing in the way of an overall spending measure.

title: Unnatural Abundance
description: Amherst, Mass. - Few Americans over the age of 30 escaped from high school without encountering Jennie Augusta Brownscombe's 1914 painting "The First Thanksgiving" in their American history textbooks. Reproduced in thousands of lithographs, it depicts the post-harvest gathering of Europeans and Indians in 1621 as a momentous transition, a kind of cultural passing of the baton. Suffused in celestial light, a vigorous New Order serenely takes over from the diminished indigenes.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS's Tuesday
description: For the second Tuesday in a row, CBS drew the largest overall audience, but NBC came in first in the all-important 18-to-49 demographic. Across the board, viewership was down during this holiday week, but "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" continued its strong run in the 10 p.m. hour for NBC. According to Nielsen's overnight ratings, an audience of 15.2 million watched "SVU" on Tuesday; the New York City detective show is drawing an average of 1.4 million more viewers than last season. At 9 p.m. CBS's new installment of "The Amazing Race" retained nearly all of its audience from the show's premiere last week; 11.43 million people watched two best friends from Queens be eliminated because of delays caused by inept stick-shift driving. During the same time period on Fox, the medical diagnosis drama "House," which had it series premiere last week, came in fourth place with an audience of just over 6 million. KATE AURTHUR

title: Hormel Profit Falls in Quarter as Costs Erode Gains in Sales

description: Royal Ahold, the world's third-largest retailer, had a wider quarterly loss as sales and profit dropped at its main business, the American supermarket unit that includes the Stop & Shop and Giant chains. The net loss swelled to 166 million euros ($218 million) in the third quarter, from 100 million euros a year earlier, the company, based in the Netherlands, said. Ahold had costs for asset impairments and buying a stake in a joint venture. The chief executive, Anders C. Moberg, above, is consolidating operations at Stop & Shop and Giant and selling the Bi-Lo and Bruno's Supermarket chains.

description: American Funds and Edward Jones & Company are among the financial firms that have been asked to provide information to regulators conducting an examination into sales and disclosure of 529 plans, the savings accounts for college.

description: The Wake Forest basketball team returned all its starters and six other lettermen from a team that finished 21-10 last season and reached the Round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Dutch Try to Thwart Terror Without Being Overzealous
description: AMSTERDAM, Nov. 18 - His telephone was tapped, his apartment was watched and many of his friends were already behind bars, so the Dutch authorities were not surprised by evidence that it was Mohamed Bouyeri, a Dutchman of Moroccan descent, who murdered the filmmaker Theo van Gogh in broad daylight one morning this month. Yet they had been powerless to stop the crime.

title: Tape Condemns Sunni Muslim Clerics
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 24 - An audiotape was posted on the Internet on Wednesday in which a man identified as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the Jordanian terrorist leader, condemned the Sunni Muslim clerical establishment in Iraq for abandoning the Iraqi resistance movement in the face of the American military offensive in Falluja and other Sunni cities.

title: Delta to Pursue Note Swap to Try to Avoid Bankruptcy
description: Delta Air Lines, the third-largest United States airline, said yesterday that it had failed to persuade enough intermediate and long-term bondholders to exchange debt and would proceed with a short-term bond exchange to help avoid filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Safeco Receives California Subpoena
description: The Safeco Corporation, a home and auto insurer based in Seattle, said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from California's attorney general, Bill Lockyer, as he investigated price-fixing and sales practices.

title: AIR PRODUCTS AND PRAXAIR POST OCTOBER SALES GAINS
description: Air Products & Chemicals, the nation's biggest producer of industrial gases, and Praxair, the second largest, said yesterday that October sales rose from a year earlier because of increased demand for gases used to make electronics and to refine crude oil. Air Products, based in Allentown, Pa., said sales increased by 12 percent last month, while Praxair, based in Danbury, Conn., reported a 15 percent rise. Shares of Air Products rose 88 cents, to $56.96, yesterday and have gained 25 percent in the last year. Praxair shares increased 34 cents, to $44.73, and have risen 30 percent over the last 12 months.

title: In My Next Life

title: G.E. TO ACQUIRE IONICS FOR $1.1 BILLION
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Ionics Inc. for $1.1 billion in cash to take advantage of rising demand for water purification and treatment in developing countries. Investors in Ionics, which is based in Watertown, Mass., will receive $44 a share, a 48 percent premium over the company's closing price on Tuesday. General Electric, based in Fairfield, Conn., said the purchase would add desalination and filtration to its industrial water treatment business. G.E. said it would now be able to accelerate research on water-purification technology while expanding financing for customers of Ionics in China and the Middle East. Shares of General Electric fell 17 cents, to $35.64. Ionics surged $13.53, or 45.5 percent, to $43.28.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Flat Tires By The Dozen
description: On what was already one of the most congested days of the years on the city's roadways, a piece of metal on the Williamsburg Bridge made the trip into Manhattan longer for some drivers last night. The metal, which was lying in a Manhattan-bound lane of the bridge after 9 p.m., punctured the tires of passing cars, the police said. Dozens of cars suffered flat tires and waited on Delancey Street for repairs, the police said. The police said it appeared likely that the metal had fallen from the bridge, but a spokesman for the City Department of Transportation said there were no bridge repairs scheduled last night. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Says Shares Will Not Be Delisted
description: Nortel Networks said in a regulatory filing yesterday that the New York and Toronto Stock Exchanges had indicated that they had no plans to delist its shares. Because Nortel has still not filed its 2003 results or offered full financial statements for the current year, the company could face removal from the two exchanges. The company also said that it would not restate revenues for fiber-optic equipment with embedded software, after discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Christina Warren, a spokeswoman for the company, said that other, unspecified revenue reporting issues remain under review. The company, based in Brampton, Ontario, said earlier this month that several billion dollars worth of revenues might be restated. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Fair Housing
description: Faced with ruinous prison costs, elected officials who were once concerned only with keeping prisoners behind bars for as many years as possible are now worrying about how to keep them from coming back to jail once they finish their sentences. The clear consensus is that ex-offenders need permanent addresses to land jobs, stabilize their lives and stay out of trouble. But a new report from Human Rights Watch, entitled "No Second Chance," shows that ex-offenders with families are routinely barred from public housing -- the only housing most can afford -- for indefinite periods, even when their criminal records do not include drug dealing or the serious violent crimes that Congress had in mind when it passed exclusion laws.

title: MEANWHILE : Chacun  son got, or, why we eat turkey
Lynchings of Policemen Ignite Outrage at Violence in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 - This city seemed in a state of shock on Wednesday as people struggled to come to grips with the scenes of lawlessness captured on television as an angry mob lynched two police officers -- beating them and burning them alive -- while hundreds of officers surrounded the area but failed to intervene.

title: Giants Autofocus for Eagles and Owens
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 24 - This is the week of the season when every Giants defensive back needs to have shoulders as sturdy as snowplow blades. But safety Gibril Wilson reported Wednesday that he still had only one good shoulder.

title: Microsoft Says 2 Former Foes Don't Have to Retract Evidence
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 24 - Microsoft will not demand the withdrawal of evidence submitted against it in a European antitrust case by two parties that have since dropped their support for the case, a spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Hmm, Interesting Home Design. Does It Come in a Double-Wide?
description: The Retreat, designed by the architectural partnership Buckley Gray Yeoman in London, is a mobile home for the design-conscious. It is made up of two 10-by-20-foot rooms, one for living, one for sleeping, which are separated by a decked courtyard and linked by a glazed corridor. The wood-and-steel house, which is on wheels for transportation purposes but is intended to remain permanently on a single site, costs $70,000 in Britain. It is being adapted to meet American mobile home standards, and the firm hopes to make it available in the United States by the middle of next year. Information: www.retreathomes.co.uk or 011.44.207.033.9913.

title: Restaurateurs Face Charges After Sting for Bribery
description: City investigators have charged the operators of six restaurants in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens with paying bribes to undercover agents posing as health inspectors, the authorities said yesterday, in the second such sting operation in two years that was aimed at the restaurant industry.

title: Despite Mixed Data, Economists See Growth
description: Orders for durable goods, or items made to last at least three years, decreased 0.4 percent in October after a 0.9 percent gain in September, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Louvre Gallery Restored
description: After a three-year restoration, the Louvre's sumptuous Apollo Gallery, below, will reopen on Saturday. The 6,500-square-foot ceremonial gallery, a model for the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles, was restored at a cost of $6.8 million, mostly paid by the French oil giant Total. A team of the more than 60 architects, radiologists, chemists and carpenters worked to restore paintings by Le Brun and Delacroix, sculpture by Thomas Regnaudin, Balthasar Marsy and Franois Girardon, as well as the gallery's vaulted 50-foot ceilings, tapestries, stucco and elaborate gilded woodwork. Begun by Louis XIV in 1661 under the direction of the architect Louis Le Vau, the hall was not completed until 1851. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, CY
description: COLEMAN--Cy. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the untimely passing of its beloved friend, the renowned American composer and pianist Cy Coleman, on November 18, 2004 in New York City at the age of 75. Mr. Coleman was a deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for most of his life. An accomplished and classically trained pianist who made his Carnegie Hall debut at the age of 7, Cy Coleman's musical journey led him to the world of jazz and, of course, to the Great White Way. He was one of this country's greatest and most honored songwriters, with such immortal standards as "Witchcraft", "The Best is Yet to Come", "Big Spender", "I've Got Your Number", and "Hey, Look Me Over" to his credit. His Broadway scores included "Sweet Charity", "City of Angels", "The Will Rogers Follies", "On the Twentieth Century", "I Love My Wife" and "The Life", to name but a few. Cy Coleman was always at home at the Steinway, and to hear him play was a real joy and, for us, inspiring. Though our lives have been forever enriched by his music, his generous and jaunty persona will be sorely missed by us all. To Shelby and Lily Cye, we extend our love and our heartfeld condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Pilot In Crash Was Warned
description: The pilot of a chartered private jet that was to have carried former President George Bush to a speaking engagement was warned that the aircraft was flying too low two minutes before it crashed on Monday, federal investigators said. The National Transportation Safety Board said there was no indication the pilot had acknowledged the transmission by air traffic controllers. The 12-passenger Gulfstream G-1159A clipped a light tower before crashing three miles short of Hobby Airport at Houston, where Mr. Bush was to have boarded. The Harris County medical examiner identified the dead, all Texans, as the pilot, Milford Dickson, 67, of Terrell; Michael DeSalvo, 62, of Fort Worth, the co-pilot; and Kristi Dunn, 54, of Addison, the flight attendant. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Ukraine Premier Is Named Winner; U.S. Assails Move
description: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 24 - The government of Ukraine on Wednesday ignored reports of widespread government fraud in Sunday's election and certified the current prime minister as president-elect, moves Secretary of State Colin L. Powell swiftly condemned. With unrest growing on the streets here, the declared loser called for a general strike and a new election.

title: UNITED ASKS COURT TO TERMINATE LABOR CONTRACTS
description: United Airlines formally asked a federal bankruptcy court yesterday for permission to terminate its labor contracts with six unions. The airline, which said this month that it planned to take the action, is seeking to cut its labor costs by $725 million a year, on top of cuts worth $2.5 billion that it negotiated last year. Next month, United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, will have been under bankruptcy protection for two years. In the court filing, United attributed the move in part to the rise in jet fuel prices, saying it would spend $1 billion more than it expected for fuel in 2004 and $7 billion more than it planned through 2010. United also said it wanted to impose a temporary 4 percent pay cut on its workers, beginning in January. Without the cuts, United said it would be unable to maintain adequate cash, meet the terms of its bankruptcy financing, or become a "competitive and sustainable" airline. A hearing on United's request is set for January. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Hylsamex To Build Indiana Plant
description: Hylsamex, Mexico's third-largest steel maker, will invest $7 million to build a plant in Indiana. Starting in August 2005, the plant will manufacture panels for refrigeration rooms, made up of two steel sheets separated by a foam layer. The company expects the plant's sales to reach $40 million a year, Rafael Rubio, Hylsamex's deputy director of economic studies, said in a telephone interview from his office in Monterrey. The company has increased its sales and net profit this year as the price of steel and the demand for it have increased. Hylsamex's stock, the best performer among the 33 stocks in the Mexico stock index, rose 60 centavos, or 2.1 percent, to 29.6 pesos ($2.62), its highest level since August 1999.

title: Mayor Vetoes Bill to Expand Public Funds in Certain Races
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a campaign finance proposal yesterday that sought to increase the amount of public money available to political candidates facing wealthy, self-financed opponents as early as next year's election.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Berenson Release Weighed
description: The Inter-American Court of Human Rights is preparing to rule on whether a New Yorker jailed in Peru for collaborating with leftist rebels should be freed. The prisoner, Lori Berenson, 35, was sentenced in 2001 to 20 years for helping Tupac Amaru rebels in their war against the government in the 1990's. Having expended all appeals in Peru, she is now relying on the Inter-American Court, based in San Juan, Costa Rica, to order her release or call for another trial, based on the defense's assertions that the evidence used against her is tainted. Juan Forero (NYT)

description: The French government announced an accelerated plan for the partial privatization of lectricit de France, the heavily indebted power monopoly, saying that it aimed to sell as much as 30 percent of the company next year. The sale, which will probably take the form of a public offering of shares, could raise 8 billion to 11 billion euros ($10.5 billion to $14.4 billion), for the French treasury and suggests a market valuation for the whole company of around 40 billion euros. But the plan still faces vigorous opposition from leading labor unions representing the utility's 112,000 employees in France. Nicola Clark (IHT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arraignment In Blackmail Case
description: Three men were arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday on grand larceny charges in a blackmail case involving a videotape that a lawyer said showed an altercation between a National Basketball Association player and a rapper in a New York club. Prosecutors said Santos Joubert and Jason Pabon of the Bronx and Rodrigo Sanchez of New Jersey had asked the player, Carmelo Anthony of the Denver Nuggets, for $3 million for the video, which was recorded in September by a surveillance camera at Babalu, a Manhattan nightclub. The tape showed Mr. Anthony in an altercation with a rapper known as Sugar Ray, said Larry Bronson, the lawyer for Mr. Sanchez. The lawyers indicated they would fight the charges. title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Judge Rejects Recount Bid
description: A federal judge in Toledo rejected a bid by third-party candidates for a recount of presidential ballots in Ohio before the state certifies final Election Day results. The judge, James G. Carr, ruled on Tuesday that the state must be given until Dec. 6 to complete its official count before any new recount begins. State elections officials have been checking the vote and sorting out which of hundreds of thousands of provisional ballots to count. Representatives of the Libertarian and Green Parties argued that a delay for a second recount would not leave enough time to tally the votes before the Ohio Electoral College meets in mid-December. President Bush won the state by an estimated 136,000 votes. Albert Salvato (NYT)

"Americans seem to enjoy the Englishness of our brand," said Peter Marston, the store's founder and owner. English willow furniture (chairs, left, are $375 each) and a wire work table ($1,815) can be ordered in the 42 colors of the company's paint range. (Paints are $20 a liter.) Greenhouses, pool houses and other glass buildings can be custom ordered. Marston & Langinger is at 117 Mercer Street; www.marston-and-langinger.com or (212) 965-0434. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Undermining the Pell Grants
description: Daunted by soaring costs, as many as a quarter of low-income students with grades and test scores that make them prime college material no longer even apply to college. This is bad news at a time when skilled jobs are moving abroad and a college diploma has become the minimum price of admission to the new economy. The Bush administration, however, has actually made this problem worse by cutting the federal Pell grant program, which was developed to encourage poor and working-class students to pursue higher education.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Suit Rejected In Radiator Case
description: New York police officers acted legally when they arrested a couple who had chained their 15-year-old daughter to a radiator for more than two months to keep her from taking crack cocaine, a jury in the Bronx decided late Tuesday. After deliberating for two hours, the jury rejected a suit brought by the parents, Maria and Eliezer Marrero. They had sought $900,000 from the city, claiming they were wrongly arrested on Sept. 13, 1991, after a visiting nurse reported to a child abuse hot line that their daughter, Linda, was chained in their apartment. The parents said they were desperate and had received no help from city agencies with their daughter. Charges against the couple were dropped in November 1991. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Patterns That Look Familiar, Until You Notice the Spiders
description: 'Every time a nice wallpaper comes out you immediately see it everywhere," said Louise Body (below), an artist and designer who has found a way around this pitfall of mass production. Ms. Body, 30, creates one-of-a-kind wallpapers by screen printing images of her own drawings and photographs and finishing each piece with a few strokes of her paintbrush, so that no two will be exactly the same. Her muted color palette gives the wallpapers a vintage feel, but even those with familiar motifs, like butterflies and birds, turn out on closer inspection to include unusual elements. "From a distance it looks like a traditional pattern, but when you get up close you find lots of little things like spiders hanging from roses," she said.

description: The Ramco-Gershenson Properties Trust, an owner of 70 shopping centers in 13 states, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy seven shopping centers for $138.3 million to add properties in parts of Florida where new construction would be difficult. Ramco-Gershenson, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., said the purchase included the assumption of $54.5 million in debt. title: 3COM AND PC-TEL TO END SUITS OVER PATENTS
description: The 3Com Corporation and PC-Tel said yesterday that they had agreed to end patent-infringement lawsuits over modem technology. Each company agreed to license the other's modem-related patents that were part of the litigation, which began in March 2003. PC-Tel will also supply certain wireless software and antennas to 3Com, the companies said. PC-Tel, based in Chicago, said it would record as revenue this quarter the $3.2 million it had set aside in case it lost the 3Com lawsuit. Shares of 3Com, based in Marlborough, Mass., rose 7 cents, to $4.60, while PC-Tel shares rose 11 cents, to $8.26.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Hobbit' House Protected
description: The former home, right, of J.R.R. Tolkien on the outskirts of Oxford, England, where he wrote "The Hobbit" and much of the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, has been given special protection by the British government's Heritage Department. Tolkien wrote his epic novels in the drawing room of the 1920's house at 20 Northmoor Road, where he lived for 17 years in the 1930's and 40's. The house was built for Basil Blackwell, the famous Oxford bookseller, and the only alteration was made by Tolkien, then a professor of English language and literature at Oxford, who removed a wall to open up the study and drawing room where he wrote. The building's new status guarantees that any further alterations will be subject to permission from government planning bodies. The eight-bedroom house was purchased in September for a reported sum of more than $2.8 million and is privately owned. PAM KENT

title: Herodias's Unhinged Mind, and That's Just the Easy Part
description: In purely emotional terms, Mahler's Fifth Symphony is sufficiently hefty to deserve a concert program all to itself. But at today's ticket prices, orchestras feel understandably sheepish about presenting, as a full program, a work lasting just over an hour. This is rough on conductors, not only because the Fifth demands to be led with unrelentingly bold strokes, but also because the work does not sit happily with other scores. You couldn't possibly open a concert with the Mahler Fifth and then play anything else. And as the closing work that it must be, the Fifth sweeps away anything performed before it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 14 Years For Spying
description: A court in Siberia sentenced a physicist to 14 years in prison after a jury found him guilty of espionage on Nov. 5, official news agencies reported. The jury found Valentin V. Mr. Danilov argued that the information he gave the company was from public sources. Mr. Danilov was acquitted in a previous jury trial but the Supreme Court ordered a second trial. title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: India's Wireless Game Market Expands
description: India's booming wireless game market will continue to expand, generating annual revenue of $336 million by 2009, according to new data released this week. That figure is a major jump from the $26 million expected for this year. The Indian mobile game business currently makes up about 5 percent of the global wireless market, but it is growing fast, market researcher In-Stat/MDR said in its study. The market encompasses a half-dozen major game developer companies and four service providers offering games to their subscribers. C.D.M.A. and G.S.M. networks register an average of 220,000 downloads a month, the researchers said. "The growth of this market sector has attracted publishers, developers, animators, musicians and content providers, and is also stimulating the development of innovative business models," Clint Wheelock, director of In-Stat/MDR's wireless research group, said yesterday. In-Stat/MDR said that because software services are a booming business in India, the country is emerging as an important market in the next big wave of mobile multimedia -- both for software developers and consumers.

description: DAVE HOLLAND, "RARUM: SELECTED RECORDINGS" -- (ECM). The jazz bassist and bandleader Dave Holland has recorded with ECM records for more than 20 years, documenting everything from the loose, folkish 70's masterpiece "Conference of the Birds," to his collaborations with the saxophonist Steve Coleman and his growing affinity for odd-metered funk vamps, to his current project, a highly calibrated big band. In the "Rarum" CD series, ECM asks band leaders to choose samplings of their own work; Mr. Holland's turns out to be one of the best, one of the keys to what's become important in the last 30 years of jazz. BEN RATLIFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JORDAN, DR. LOUIS H., PHD.
description: JORDAN--Dr. Louis H., PhD., former Associate Dean of the Graduate School of Business, Fordham University passed away on November 23, 2004 at the Eddy-Ford Nursing Home in Cohoes, N.Y. He was 82 and preceded by his wife of 40 years, Carolyn Maureen Jordan. Dr. Jordan was born in Owassa, Alabama on January 1, 1922, the son of Reverend Isaac Newton and Bertha Jordan. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II as a Forward Observer for the 392 Field Artillery, 42nd Infantry (Rainbow) Division in the European Theater of Operations. Later served as Aide de Camp to General Mark Clark during the Austrian Occupation until 1947 when he left the Army at the rank of Captain. Dr. Jordan graduated from Auburn University in 1947 with a BS in Accounting, received his MBS from Northwestern University in 1951, and finally his PhD in Accounting from Columbia University in New York City in 1954. He married the former Carolyn Maureen Carter of Yonkers, NY on June 2, 1956. They settled in Yonkers and raised two sons, Louis, Jr. and Mark. In his professional life, Dr. Jordan was Associate Professor of Accounting, Tulane University, 1955-1960, Professor of Accounting, Columbia University, 1960-1975, Professor of Accounting and Associate Dean of the Graduate School of Business, Fordham University, 1975-1988. Dr. Jordan served as a visiting Professor at Robert College, Istanbul, Turkey 1966-67, 1970-71, and The Irish Management Institute, Dublin, Ireland. He also served in various consulting positions to include Westinghouse Corp, Touche Ross, and Price Waterhouse. Dr. Jordan is the co-author of "Accounting: An Analysis of Its Problems" 2-volume, 1963, 64. Dr. Jordan was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. Dr. Jordan is survived by his two sons, LTC Louis H. Jordan, Jr. of Tucson, AZ and Mark S. Jordan, Esq. of Delmar, NY. Dr. Jordan has three grandchildren, Kristopher, Alexandra, and Christine. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Saturday & Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church on Monday, Nov. 29 at 10 AM.

title: Greatest Hits, Reissues And Compilations; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: PAVEMENT: "CROOKED RAIN CROOKED RAIN" -- (Matador). Current indie-rock owes a lot to Pavement, a band from Stockton, Calif., whose songs sound perpetually unfinished. Stephen Malkmus's vocals are bleary, tempos fluctuate, instrumental lines dangle like loose threads. Yet the songs on "Crooked Rain Crooked Rain," originally released in 1994, are just right, pondering music and celebrity, friendship and sex, hipness and heart. Its ramshackle structures are fully thought out, spiking melodic California rock with punk's messiness. "Crooked Rain Crooked Rain" was acutely self-conscious, looking over its shoulder at a more polished album by a far more popular California band, the Eagles' "Hotel California," but it also sounds unguarded in all its mixed emotions. The reissue is a double album that adds B-sides from singles, stray album tracks and a second CD of unreleased material that's surprisingly strong: rough demo versions and stray songs from 1993 and a live 1994 BBC performance that proclaimed, "Gettin' cooler but I'm out of of the loop." JON PARELES

Singing familiar songs, most of them upbeat, she leaves no note unadorned: little quavers, big sobs, strident vibratos, touches of raspiness, breathy whispers, as if she's trying to be both Mariah Carey and Faith Hill. She makes her vocal efforts over arrangements with synthetic horns that sound like karaoke tracks, and the result, for all its determination to impress, sounds less like a celebration than an outburst of holiday hysteria.
