title: The Listings; VEGA STRING QUARTET
description: Chamber music craves intimate spaces, its magic too often dissipating when the distances are large. That's not a problem at Bargemusic, where the concerts take place on a real converted barge moored in the East River. With seats for just 125, it is one of the smallest and most inviting places in New York to hear a string quartet outside of your own living room -- and the only concert hall that offers gently bobbing views of Lower Manhattan. Tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon, the Vega String Quartet (above) performs two of the loveliest works of the chamber music literature: Beethoven's Quartet Opus 132, with its famously breathtaking slow movement, and Mozart's Clarinet Quintet, a sublime conversation among strings and solo clarinet (played by Ethan Sloane). The locally based Vega Quartet has roots in China, where three of the four players attended the Shanghai Conservatory. Advanced reports suggest a promising young ensemble prepared to give vigorous performances. The group's two concerts are prefaced with a recital tonight by a switch-hitting string player (violin and viola) and college freshman named David Aaron Carpenter. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday afternoon at 4, Fulton Ferry Landing, under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $35 to $40; students, $25.) JEREMY EICHLER

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Military Desertion Attempt Turns Deadly
description: A soldier committed suicide after he and his twin brother tried to desert the military. The twin brothers, armed with automatic rifles, fled their garrison in Solnechnogorsk, north of Moscow, and settled in a cafe. The pair were discovered by two police officers whom they shot dead. They then intercepted a vehicle, fled to a house and took hostages. After a siege that lasted for several hours, one of the brothers shot himself. The other was captured by the police. The brothers came from the Chelyabinsk region in the Ural Mountains and had served one-and-a-half years of a two-year conscription. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Holiday Albums; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: "A LITTLE DARLIN' CHRISTMAS" -- (Koch). Little Darlin' was the small Nashville label that gave the world Johnny Paycheck, through a series of phenomenally good singles and albums in the 1960's; there are still some surprises in its vaults. Most of this Christmas CD features the singer Bobby Helms (famous for his late-50's hit "Fraulein"), working tepidly through standards like "Silver Bells" with good hard-country arrangements. But Paycheck's four tracks at the end, recorded in the 60's for a Christmas album that never panned out, are the pearls. In his songs about women and alcohol, Paycheck traded on a passive-aggressive mixture of contempt and shame; incredibly, he extends the same emotions to Christmas. "If it's not too much trouble/please hurry home on the double/we prayed the same prayer the last 24 days," he sings in one song, while the steel guitars weep. "The Santy Claus down at Sears/said those kids need that mom of theirs/and told them you'd be home by Christmas Day." BEN RATLIFF

title: Holiday Albums; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: "MAYBE THIS XMAS TREE" -- (Nettwerk). This is the third installment of the "Maybe" franchise, which matches holiday songs with alt-rock acts. The Polyphonic Spree contributes a typically light-headed (and mildly irritating) choral version of "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)"; this must be one of the only bands capable of making a Christmas chestnut sound more Christmasy. Ivy does an effective, faux-vintage "Christmas Time Is Here," but the easy winner is Death Cab for Cutie's version of "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)," with Ben Gibbard sighing lyrics that capture one of the most popular holiday spirits: self-pity. KELEFA SANNEH

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ban Lifted On Nocturnal Viewing Of Taj Mahal
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the country's most famous tourist attraction, the Taj Mahal, should be open for night viewing for the first time in 20 years. The court ruled that as part of festivities celebrating the 350th anniversary of the construction of the domed, white marble mausoleum in the northern city of Agra, visitors should be allowed to visit the monument five nights a month, around the time of the full moon. Tickets must be purchased 24 hours in advance. The ban on night viewing was imposed in 1984 at the height of Sikh militancy when it was feared that the building could come under attack. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Holiday Albums; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: BEACH BOYS: "CHRISTMAS WITH THE BEACH BOYS" -- (Capitol). It's all of the Beach Boys' Christmas album from 1964, plus later recordings from 1977; half-baked, cornball and orchestra-drenched as much of it is, the CD will trigger rec-room television memories, with songs like "Frosty the Snowman," the weeper "Blue Christmas" (sung as a solo vocal by Brian Wilson) and "I'll Be Home for Christmas." There is, however, a killer "Auld Lang Syne," with the best Beach Boys harmonies money can buy. That, and a few public service announcements for toy drives. BEN RATLIFF

title: Greatest Hits, Reissues And Compilations; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: BRITNEY SPEARS, "GREATEST HITS: MY PREROGATIVE" -- (Jive/Zomba). What's louder than a lump of coal, and much, much shinier? Ms. Spears's new greatest-hits collection, featuring three unreleased songs and (if you buy the limited-edition version) a bonus disc of remixes, all housed in a gleaming silver cardboard case -- it's, um, her most reflective release so far. Listening to her hits all at once, you may be struck by the seductive severity of Ms. Spears's music: the beats are sharp as tines, the lyrics are filled with evocations of fear and control, the voice projects nothing you might mistake for warmth. Her current single is "My Prerogative," produced by Bloodshy & Avant (who also produced "Toxic"): while tabla drums flutter around her, Ms. Spears reduces the two-note chorus to a flat -- and very effective -- snarl. The same duo produced the two other entertaining new songs, "I've Just Begun (Having My Fun)" and "Do Somethin'." Most of the remixes cheerfully clatter along, but Jacques Lu Cont's eight-mint version of "Breathe on Me" slowly reveals a different, more hypnotic charm. KELEFA SANNEH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROZMAN, JOSEPH
description: ROZMAN--Joseph, 90, November 24, 2004, in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved husband of 64 years of Bunny (deceased), cherished father of Carol (Stephen) and Barry (deceased), honored fatherin-law of Marjorie, proud grandfather of Deborah, Jonathan, Aliza, Avi, and Dani. A resident of Woodmere, NY, for more than 50 years, Joe was a strong advocate and generous supporter of Jewish education and values. He was a past President and Chairman of the Board of Congregation Sons of Israel of Woodmere, trustee of the Brandeis School of Lawrence, a founder of the Woodmere Educational Fund, and a trustee of Boys Town of Jerusalem. In 1975 he was honored with the 19th Annual Louis Marshall Memorial Award of The Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Joe was a graduate of New York University and built a highly successful textile converting business, Louis Rozman & Co, in New York City, before embarking on a second career in commercial real estate in Manhattan. A quiet man of great dignity, Joe's inner strength set an extraordinary example for all who knew him.

title: Holiday Albums; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: FRANK SINATRA: "THE CHRISTMAS COLLECTION" -- (Capitol). Christmas albums are the essence of populuxe -- the term coined by the writer Thomas Hine to describe luxury culture made for the everyguy who takes his leisure time seriously. So why bother with the other stuff -- why not go straight to the king of populuxe? Recorded between 1957 and 1991 (a wobbly "Silent Night"), including tracks from the 1964 album "The Twelve Days of Christmas" and a 1957 television Christmas special with Bing Crosby, the album shows a guy who has no holiday anxiety; he's there to ameliorate it, baby. BEN RATLIFF

description: WILLIE ROSARIO, "ATIZAME EL FOGN" -- (Universal Music Latino). This year Universal Latino has released six albums by the salsa band leader and timbales player Willie Rosario that had never before been on CD, all originally recorded in the late 70's and early 80's by the Top Hits label. Mr. Rosario, who is Puerto Rico-based, evolved his group sound in the late 60's; as Eddie Palmieri's had been based on trombones, his was based on baritone saxophones and trumpets. "Atizame el Fogn" is hardcore salsa from 1982, rhythmically hard-punching, with three vocalists, including Gilberto Santa Rosa, who has since become the standard of quality in salsa singing; the other five reissues, including "From the Depth of My Brain" and "El Rey del Ritmo," are recommended, too. title: The Listings; 'RAGHUBIR SINGH: RETROSPECTIVE'
description: The photographer Raghubir Singh (1942-1999) spent as much time in London, Paris and New York as he did in his native India. But India kept pulling him back: it was the primary subject of his extraordinary photographs, 45 of which from the 1960's through the 1990's make up this mini-retrospective. Although his early model was another great photographer of India, Henri Cartier-Bresson, whom he met in 1966, Singh struck out in his own direction by using color photography, disparaged at the time, rather than black and white. More than a dozen books followed, each focused on different parts of urban and rural India; the images in this show are drawn from them. The documentary-style vision that emerges is neither sugarcoated, nor abject, nor controllingly omniscient. As in "Rameshwaram, Tamil Nadu," above, India is seen from behind heads in a crowd, through reflections in car windows or pools of monsoon rain. People notice the camera and move on; they are in the middle of life, in a vast country that is, like every country, constantly changing and resisting change. If images of ultramodern corporate India are missing they would surely have found their way eventually into Singh's panoramic India picture: a cultural portrait in which unsentimental realism is a form of love. (Sepia International, 148 West 24th Street, Chelsea, through Dec 30; free.) HOLLAND COTTER

title: Greatest Hits, Reissues And Compilations; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: GEORGE STRAIT, "50 NUMBER ONES" -- (MCA Nashville). This enthralling collection brings together 22 years worth of hits by Mr. Strait, along with a new song, "I Hate Everything," which hit No. 1 on Billboard's country charts this fall. Over the years, Mr. Strait's producers made small changes to reflect the times (lots of reverb on the drums in the 1980's, for example), but Mr. Strait's own warm, slightly melancholy style barely changed, whether he was cracking gentle jokes about former lovers ("All My Ex's Live in Texas," 1987) or telling a mournful love story ("I Can Still Make Cheyenne," 1996). Mr. Strait often adds a subtle quaver or pause, echoing the emotions in the lyrics without quite acting them out -- this restraint, this disinclination to become a character, helps explain why he has lasted so long. Only one complaint: it seems the record company edited some of these songs to make them fit; that's no way treat a 51-hit wonder. KELEFA SANNEH

title: In Phoenix
description: PHOENIX is finally rising. For years, the city sulked in the shadow of sexier 'burbs like Scottsdale, but now it's enjoying a culture boom -- with a young, raw arts scene, well-cooked food and world-class spas. Despite the rumor that "it's a dry heat," the weather is generally pleasant from October to April, and yes, it does rain. If so, ditch the outdoor activities and head to the Heard Museum where, for $7 admission, you can see an expansive collection of Indian art. (The museum shop is also the best place in town to buy gifts.) With a citywide light-rail system still years away, you'll need to rent a car to get around, but Phoenix is built on a grid, so even a first-time visitor won't have trouble navigating. AMY SILVERMAN

description: "NOTEKILLERS" -- (Ecstatic Peace). The Notekillers were a squally, no-vocals band from Philadelphia whose discography consisted solely of a single from 1980. Sonic Youth's Thurston Moore, an early fan, arranged this CD retrospective, and it's astonishing. Full of unreleased recordings (otherwise it would be very short indeed), the disc captures the trio making a racket that's ferocious yet surprisingly sprightly. While the rhythm section churns furiously, David First peels off a series of scrambled guitar lines, precise even when he's improvising. His diagonal riffs are marvelously untraceable (Surf-rock? New-wave? Heavy metal? Free jazz? Serialism?), and somehow these dense compositions inevitably come out sounding like party music. It's clear this band ranked with any of New York's much-celebrated no-wave acts. KELEFA SANNEH

title: The Listings; 'TWELVE ANGRY MEN'
description: White guys are all over the place on Broadway this fall. What's that? Nothing new? Perhaps true, but this fall they seem to be dominating the stages in unusually large numbers, whether it's the sweet middle-aged lovers at the center of the revival of "La Cage aux Folles" or the cadre of German bureaucrats surrounding Willy Brandt in Michael Frayn's "Democracy." And speaking of democracy, it's probably not necessary to look to the theater these days for angry white guys, but if you didn't get enough of them over the past, oh, 18 months or so, there are a dozen tearing up the stage at the American Airlines Theater these days. Indeed, the carefully contained ire parceled out in neat portions in "Twelve Angry Men" is oddly comforting after all the free-floating white-guy angst of recent months. It's actually soothing to watch the waves of aggression build and subside in Jury Room 2A (above from left, Kevin Geer, Tom Aldredge, Mark Blum, Peter Friedman and Boyd Gaines). Reginald Rose's schematic dramaturgy may be hopelessly square, but Scott Ellis's collectively superb cast softens its blunter edges. And how often do you get the chance to witness justice being done in a little over 90 minutes? (This weekend's schedule: tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m., American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300. Tickets:$46.25 to $86.25.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

description: "MESSIAH REMIX" -- (Cantaloupe Music). Bits of Handel drift through an electronic wilderness on "Messiah Remix," which assigned 11 electronic composers from classical and pop spheres to transfigure the oratorio. Sampled and looped, filtered and speed-shifted, it's "Messiah" as it might flicker through a modern-day musician's subconscious; Dalek sets a rapper atop Handel's string chords for the album's most conventional gambit. Whether the excerpts are recognizable, as in Phil Kline's chopped-up "Hallelujah!" and Paul Lansky's misty "Post-Pastoral," or dissolved into atmosphere, as in Laeticia Sonami's hovering "Overture on Ice" and Scanner's "Insulation Mix," something of the oratorio's reverence still comes through. While Aaron Neville does offer a sincere Christmas prayer, most of the other tracks -- including Art Neville's title song, a recipe set to a New Orleans mambo -- treat Christmas as one more excuse for a good time, with plenty of local color. description: ARTHUR RUSSELL: "WORLD OF ECHO" -- (Audika). Arthur Russell, who died in 1992, was an introverted cellist in love with outgoing pop music; in the late 70's and early 80's, he created ferociously imaginative disco singles like "Kiss Me Again" and "Go Bang," and they are what his reputation largely rests on. But he put more of himself into the music, which eventually became an obscure LP called "World of Echo." Like Joo Gilberto, he wanted to create a music that was so quiet and intimate it constructed its own highly sensitized fantasy world. Using bits of written melody and long rhythmic improvisations for his soft crooning, accompanied by his own percussively played, fuzzed-up and echoed-out cello, he made something deeply mysterious, original and beautiful. The reissue of the album comes with extra unreleased tracks, as well as a DVD containing films of Russell performing a few of its pieces. BEN RATLIFF

title: The Listings; MOE
description: Even before Phish played its final concerts in August, Moe was eagerly positioning itself as a successor for the position of America's top jam band. That means an endless tour, though Moe is taking a month off the road after its two shows this weekend at Roseland. Formed in 1990 in Buffalo, Moe has been performing nationwide since the mid-1990's, playing long, freewheeling jams on songs that look back to the Band and the Allman Brothers and over their shoulders at the Dave Matthews Band. Moe had its moment on a major label, Sony, announcing itself with a 1996 single, "Meat," that ran more than 46 minutes. But jam bands tend to focus on performing rather than making radio hits and selling huge numbers of albums, and Moe has since returned to an independent label, its own Fatboy. Moe has the typical strengths and weaknesses of jam bands. It's long on vamps and short on songs, with adequate vocals that are quickly overshadowed by nimble, exuberant instrumentals. Moe's gift is spinning plentiful music from a minimum of material. The pleasure of its songs has far less to do with their two-chord foundations than with the constant flux of the jams they lead to, with two-guitar dialogues and a beat that can evolve from a countryish bounce to driving Southern rock to gospel to funk. "Just do the things that come to you/ And you"ll always be true," the band sings in "Blue Eyed Son," and that's just what happens with Moe onstage. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-1224; tickets are $27.50.) JON PARELES

title: Greatest Hits, Reissues And Compilations; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: "SACRED STEEL INSTRUMENTALS" -- (Arhoolie). Before Robert Randolph became a regular on the jam-band circuit, the folklorists of Arhoolie Records went to churches to find performers in the tradition called sacred steel, which makes steel guitar the lead instrument in gospel songs. The sliding notes of lap steel and pedal steel guitars can sound like trombones, singers, bells or birdcalls as they make notes wriggle and chords hover in the air. As church music, sacred steel performances often include singers praising the Lord. But "Sacred Steel Instrumentals," which sifts through Arhoolie's catalog, leaves the proselytizing to the strings. It's rangy and eloquent music, and players like Sonny Treadway, the Campbell Brothers, Aubrey Ghent and Mr. Randolph turn familiar songs -- "Just a Closer Walk with Thee," "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" -- and lesser-known ones into jaunty performances that go skidding and whooping toward an affirmation of faith. The album weaves minisuites of carols, jigs and reels. Piano often makes the arrangements sound like a parlor gathering, and the women add plenty of Celtic touches to familiar songs. It's a cozy album that becomes luminous whenever Heidi Talbot sings, in a voice that's both awestruck and tender. JON PARELES

description: "SANTANA" -- (Columbia Legacy). Santana's debut album, "Santana," arrived in 1969 like a thunderbolt of Latin rhythm. On its first album, Santana showed more of its beginnings as a blues band than it would in later years, but the album set the template for a long career to follow: conga-driven instrumentals that surged behind the jabs and wails of Carlos Santana's guitar solos, like "Jingo" and "Soul Sacrifice," and radio-ready songs about the perfidy of women like "Evil Ways." The extra disc of the reissue includes some tepid "original studio sessions," but they're followed by the performance that would put Santana on the map: a set from the Woodstock Festival in 1969 that still simply burns. title: Holiday Albums; In a Wide Holiday Groove, From Sinatra to a Remixed 'Messiah'
description: "DO THEY KNOW IT'S CHRISTMAS?" -- (Mercury). Apparently it's a new tradition: every 20 years, Britain's biggest stars will convene to fight famine in Africa by re-recording this awful song. (Visit www.BandAid20.com to download it, for a fee.) Coldplay's Chris Martin gets the opening line ("It's Christmastime, there's no need to be afraid," he intones, with Radiohead's Thom Yorke tinkling a piano behind him); Joss Stone leads a small choir in posing the clueless, condescending question, "Do they know it's Christmastime at all?"; Bono returns to rasp the climactic line, "Well, tonight thank God it's them instead of you." But it's Dizzee Rascal who really shines, rapping a pair of nimble new couplets. Still, who but a grinch -- or a pop critic -- would complain about a song that will raise so much money for such an unimpeachable cause? KELEFA SANNEH

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Bank Tightens Monetary Policy
description: The Bank of Mexico tightened its monetary policy for the eighth time this year, pushing up local interest rates to counter rising inflation expectations. The central bank increased the amount of its money market liquidity restriction, or "corto," to 63 million pesos ($5.6 million) from 57 million ($5 million). The corto is the part of credit the bank supplies each day at double interest; by increasing the amount, the bank puts upward pressure on short-term interest rates. The central bank cited "surprisingly high" inflation in the last three months, with pressure from some agricultural prices in the core index.

The woman, a 43-year-old translator of German origin who holds American citizenship and is identified only as Michaela T., has been living in Canada for some time and was detained in September while visiting her parents in Germany. Kirsten Grieshaber (NYT)

title: Steamy Times Come to Chinese Films
description: Early in Zhang Yimou's "House of Flying Daggers," the hero, Jin (Takeshi Kaneshiro), unsheathes a sword to slice the buttons off a showgirl's robe. This scandalizes onlookers despite the setting -- a brothel. Later, the drunken Jin pulls the dancer to the ground, flips her over and tears her dress.

title: Asbury Park Man Is Arrested in His Son's Starvation Death
description: An Asbury Park man wanted in the starvation death of his 14-month-old son was arrested yesterday on charges of manslaughter and child endangerment.

title: Arts, Briefly; Long Sweeps
description: Because of the presidential election at the beginning of the month, this year's November sweeps were were adjusted to go through Thanksgiving, so the holiday's television line-up featured mostly original programs, not the usual reruns. As usual on a Thursday, it was a CBS sweep, according to Nielsen's overnight ratings, with new episodes of "Survivor," "CSI" and "Without a Trace" winning every hour. At 10 p.m., NBC came in second with "The Seinfeld Story," a retrospective on the series. On Wednesday night, NBC won the overall ratings competition every hour, but ABC's three-hour "Bachelor" finale drew the 18-to-49 crowd. With this sixth installment of "The Bachelor" over, the third "Bachelorette" is set to begin in January, with Jen Schefft, a viewer favorite, searching for a boyfriend after her breakup with the third "Bachelor," Andrew Firestone. Wednesday's most-watched program was NBC's "Law & Order," which edged out CBS's "CSI: NY." KATE AURTHUR

title: In Annual Rite, Shoppers Mob Holiday Sales
description: Surrounded by hundreds of shoppers grabbing bargain-priced flat-screen television sets and portable music players early yesterday morning, Jill Mulhere was trying to figure out what happened to her shopping cart, heaped with presents, at the Best Buy store in Paramus, N.J. She had paused to look at just one more deal -- an Allegro DVD-VCR combination for $59.99 -- before joining the long checkout line.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Indecision Over Dalai Lama
description: Russia appeared to reverse a long-standing policy by granting a visa to Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, only to reverse itself within hours. The president of Kalmykia, a southern Russian republic where roughly half the residents are Buddhist, had invited the Dalai Lama earlier this month. But the trip, which would be his first to Russia since 1992, has been delayed because of diplomatic wrangling over the visa, a reflection of Russia's sensitivity toward offending China, which considers the Dalai Lama a renegade political leader. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

He was 82.

description: Employees representing 4 percent of the work force of Canada Post, the government-owned letter carrier, have threatened to strike by Dec. 8 unless they receive improvements in health benefits and job security.

Emergency services officials set up a shelter for the displaced, many of them from a low-income neighborhood that has been repeatedly inundated by high water. Some houses had four feet of water inside, officials said; they warned that additional rain would extend the damage. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: SCOTTS PLANS REORGANIZATION AND NAME CHANGE
description: The Scotts Company, maker of Miracle-Gro plant food and Turf Builder fertilizer, said yesterday that it planned to reorganize into a holding company and change its name to promote its top two brands. Scotts, based in Marysville, Ohio, said in a regulatory filing that shareholders would receive one share of the new company, to be called the Scotts Miracle-Gro Company, for each Scotts share they own. Scotts said the change would allow it to showcase the Miracle-Gro and Scotts brands as it prepares to make acquisitions and sell brands that are not performing well.

Several retailers, including some who had advertised early openings for Christmas shopping, reported hundreds of customers waiting in long lines and thousands of dollars in lost sales as workers drilled through the locks and removed them. Most of the stores were able to open by midmorning. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Iran's Lonely Crowd
description: Tehran - When Friday Prayer here finishes at about two o'clock in the afternoon, hundreds of worshipers parade toward waiting buses east of Tehran University, shouting canned rhetoric against America and Israel, defining themselves by their animosity toward others. Watching this ritual, one cannot help but ask a soul-searching question: "How can such a small minority of vocal people -- totally orchestrated worshipers and their security guards -- set the agenda for a nation of 70 million people?"

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Mercedes Earnings May Fall
description: DaimlerChrysler, the world's fifth-largest carmaker, said the dollar's decline against the euro would reduce the earnings of the Mercedes-Benz division, adding to the woes of the luxury-car unit. "We weren't prepared for the dollar to be at this level," Thomas Weber, the management board member responsible for research, said in Frankfurt on Thursday. "It will influence the results at Mercedes and 2005 won't be an easy year." Earnings at Mercedes Car Group plunged by half in the third quarter as American sales fell. The carmaker spent money to improve quality, which suffered with the debut of new electronics in cars, said J.D. Power and Associates. Mercedes's market share in the United States dropped to 1.2 percent in the first nine months from 1.3 percent amid competition from Bayerische Motoren Werke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROZMAN, JOSEPH
description: ROZMAN--Joseph, 90, November 24, 2004, in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved husband of 64 years of Bunny (deceased), cherished father of Carol (Stephen) and Barry (deceased), honored fatherin-law of Marjorie, proud grandfather of Deborah, Jonathan, Aliza, Avi, and Dani. A resident of Woodmere, NY, for more than 50 years, Joe was a strong advocate and generous supporter of Jewish education and values. He was a past President and Chairman of the Board of Congregation Sons of Israel of Woodmere, trustee of the Brandeis School of Lawrence, a founder of the Woodmere Educational Fund, and a trustee of Boys Town of Jerusalem. In 1975 he was honored with the 19th Annual Louis Marshall Memorial Award of The Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Joe was a graduate of New York University and built a highly successful textile converting business, Louis Rozman & Co, in New York City, before embarking on a second career in commercial real estate in Manhattan. A quiet man of great dignity, Joe's inner strength set an extraordinary example for all who knew him.

description: Cingular Wireless, the nation's largest mobile-telephone operator, said yesterday that it would sell some airwave rights and customers to the Alltel Corporation for $170 million to satisfy government conditions on its purchase of AT&T Wireless Services. Cingular, a joint venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, said it would sell AT&T Wireless operations in parts of five states, including Texas, and radio spectrum in three states. The sales would "meet a substantial portion" of the conditions set by the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission for approval its $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless, the company said. Cingular, which is based in Atlanta, still must sell some airwave rights in Dallas, Detroit and Knoxville, Tenn., and assets in four smaller markets, a spokesman said.

World Briefing | Africa: Equatorial Guinea: Jail Terms In Coup Plot
description: A court convicted dozens of people linked to an abortive coup against Equatorial Guinea's autocratic government last March, but stopped short of imposing the death penalty. The alleged leader of the coup's advance military team, the South African mercenary Nick du Toit, received a 34-year prison sentence; other accused foreign mercenaries were sentenced to between 14 and 24 years in jail. Observers said the absence of death sentences may have been intended to help Equatorial Guinea in its bid to extradite Mark Thatcher, the son of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who is accused of helping finance the plot. Mr. Thatcher has denied the charge; whether South Africa, which opposes the death penalty, will turn him over to Guinea authorities is unclear. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: The Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group, the insurance broker, said that its chief executive, Steve P. McGill, had left the company and that profit this year would be lower than expected. The chairman, Ken A. Carter, will succeed Mr. McGill, who has been chief executive since July 2001. Profit before tax, good will and exceptional items will be 100 million ($189 million), down 12 percent from a year ago, the company said. World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Officials Ban Newsweek
description: Officials banned the Nov. 22 issue of Newsweek magazine, saying it contained blasphemous remarks, and ordered the forfeiture of all copies, state-run news media reported. An article on the life of the Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh set off outrage in the country, with leading Pakistani newspapers saying it was biased and upsetting to Muslims. Mr. van Gogh was killed Nov. 2 and a suspected Islamic extremist of Moroccan descent has been arrested. The Newsweek article, headlined "Clash of Civilizations," carried an image from Mr. van Gogh's movie "Submission," which showed verses from the Koran inscribed on the bare back of a woman. description: Shares of the biopharmaceutical company Genta fell yesterday after the company said that a cancer drug it was testing failed to meet its intended goals in clinical trials. Genta, based in Berkeley Heights, N.J., said that the drug, Genasense, did not delay the progression of multiple myeloma as expected. Multiple myeloma is a cancer of white blood cells. Genta shares fell 38 cents, or 23 percent, to $1.27. Genta said it would provide more details of the clinical trials on Dec. 4, at a meeting of the American Society of Hematology in San Diego.

title: Quiet Time
description: Riyadh, Saudi Arabia - In September, I was waiting for a CBS news crew to come to my home here to prepare for my interview with Ed Bradley of "60 Minutes." As I waited for the crew, I started reading the morning papers, and I was surprised to learn that the Saudi cabinet had issued a stern warning to public employees against talking to the news media, domestic or foreign, with the intention of criticizing the government's policies or programs. I work for a public institution, King Saud University, so I should consider myself one of those warned..

title: Arts, Briefly; A 'Butterfly' for Japan
description: When in Japan, think Japanese. That's the approach the New York City Opera is taking when it travels to Tokyo and Nagoya in May as part of the American cultural program at the 2005 World Exposition. On the bill is something Japanese, or close to it: "Madama Butterfly," Puccini's tragic love story about an American naval officer and a former geisha. Although popular in Japan, "Butterfly," whose Asianisms were largely a figment of Puccini's imagination, is an opera that American companies often shy away from performing there, said Matthew Price, an executive assistant to the company's artistic director, Paul Kellogg. The conductor will be Atsushi Yamada, a businessman turned musician who is the first Japanese conductor to perform with the company. Audiences looking for a traditionally Western grand operatic spectacle won't find it in Mark Lamos's pared-down production, which has aqua-toned stairs and translucent shoji screens framing the stage and a fleet of naval ships suspended in the air. "Ours is a contemporary interpretation, more attuned to a spare and internal Japanese sensibility," Mr. Price said. "At least we hope it will come across that way." KATHRYN SHATTUCK

title: Arts, Briefly; Aga Khan Awards
description: Temporary housing built from earth-filled sandbags and a tilting disc shaped library in Alexandria, Egypt, are among the seven winners of this year's Aga Khan Award for Architecture. The recipients of awards, which are presented every three years and amount to a total of $500,000, are to be announced today in Delhi, India, by Prince Karim Aga Khan (below). The prize recognizes projects that attain architectural excellence "while reflecting the values of the primarily Muslim societies the projects are intended to serve." The other winning projects are a village primary school fashioned from compressed-earth bricks in Gando, Burkina Faso; the restoration of Al-Abbas Mosque near Asnaf, Yemen; a revitalization program for the Old City of Jerusalem; the B2 House, a modern structure on a traditional terraced site in Ayvacik, Turkey; and the giant twin Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Snohetta, the Norwegian firm that designed the library in Alexandria, was recently chosen to design a cultural building at ground zero in New York. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Arts, Briefly; Museum Thefts, Again
description: Thieves have struck again at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, making off with 15 Meissen porcelain figures (top right) worth nearly $4,000 each. This theft follows two in London museums last month, when $100,000 in Chinese jade was taken from the Victoria and Albert and 15 small pieces of Chinese jewelry were stolen from the British Museum. In each case the thieves pried open cabinets while the museum was open to visitors; the police believe the Meissen porcelain was taken around 1 p.m. on Wednesday. The Victoria and Albert says the first theft led to a security review: the number of guards on patrol was immediately doubled, and a newly commissioned security system was to be installed on Monday. "This is a great blow," said Mark Jones, the museum's director, "and, sadly, we have no option but to close the Ceramics Galleries until new systems are in place." Police are investigating a possible link among the crimes. PAM KENT

description: The unemployment rate fell in October to its lowest level since December 2002 as the country's recovery continued to trickle down to the labor market, the government said. title: A Foreboding Thaw
description: By the end of the 21st century, the search for the Northwest Passage -- a quest that has consumed many lives and fostered many legends -- will seem nearly unimaginable. The northern route across the Arctic Ocean from the Atlantic to the Pacific is most likely to be plain sailing in summer, a continent of ice having been swept away by the effects of global warming. That may sound like good news, but it's not. A study of arctic warming, commissioned by the Arctic Council, paints a grim picture. The northern polar region is heating up faster than are other areas of the planet. As the ice melts, enormous volumes of cold, fresh water will be released into the oceans with consequences that are hard to predict.

title: Lunch Box Outside the Box
description: From the moment a child is born -- and sometimes for months before -- the things start to accumulate. Shortly thereafter the things begin to break, or to wear down, or to grate on the nerves, or to require new batteries of nonstandard size. So much of the gear children require seems designed to frustrate. Why can't a car seat be installed without a 45-minute consultation with an instruction booklet? Why do the seams of a lunch box resist cleaning? Why can't a school notebook be both durable and light? When well-designed items come to market, they are swept off the shelves; such is the hunger for something that works. The BabyBjorn carrier, for example, an elegant, simply-stitched, cotton contrivance, revolutionized the way parents travel with their children, combining mobility with cuddling. A smaller version of JanSport's hugely popular backpack gave children a sense of independence and parents a free hand. It ought to be simple, so we asked a number of award-winning industrial, architectural and product designers to fix some of childhood's design flaws. While some of their creations incorporate fantasy, the designers have conformed to one fundamental maxim when designing for children: mixing fun with functionality.

title: Hardcover Fiction
Pay for No Play?
description: Every day an unkempt man stands outside the grocery store I manage, singing and playing guitar for tips. His playing is monotonous, his voice is a foghorn and customers have complained. Another area store paid him to keep away. Now he's "ready to make a deal" with our store -- in effect, threatening us with more loud attempts at Neil Young songs until we submit. What should I do? Troy Bond, Seattle As long as this fellow is singing and playing for tips, he is a busker, albeit an annoying busker, and you should do nothing. That's the way it goes in a free society. The Constitution protects even inept singers. (Legal scholars refer to this as the Ashlee Simpson rule. Or perhaps they don't.) But when he requests money not for his singing but for his silence, he transforms himself from troubadour to extortionist, and you should not succumb to his dissonant threats.

title: Hey, Mom, Is It O.K. If These Guys Market Stuff to Us?
description: In a way, the coming marketing campaign for Ozon, a family restaurant, began more than a year and a half ago, in the spring of 2003, when Patrick Benasillo met Chris McKee at a marketing conference called Kid Power, held in Orlando, Fla. Benasillo, the president of Studio D, a company in New York that designs and manufactures logos and signs for retail stores, had just attended a talk by McKee, a partner at the Geppetto Group, a New York marketing firm. McKee had discussed the appeal of fictional characters like Harry Potter and, more broadly, how kid culture had saturated consumer society to the extent that it was becoming the central creative marketing force of our era. This is indeed what McKee usually talks about. He says things like "The lifestyle of kids for the first time in history is something we study." Or "Kid culture has become the most intriguing kind of culture around." In conversation, he tends to pile up the ideas before you, drawing on children's music or comics or (most often) the films of Pixar -- "Toy Story," "Finding Nemo," "The Incredibles" -- as examples of the intermingling of kid and adult cultures, a phenomenon that to him suggests children are becoming far more sophisticated about products and entertainment at the same time as adults (he calls them kidults) are increasingly reveling in youth-based content. "Is it just that the kids want to be older," McKee asks, "or is it that adults want to stay younger longer?" When Benasillo heard McKee talk like this, he sought him out in Orlando and introduced himself. Then he told him what he had been working on.

description: Over the last decade, Charles Food, a convenience store in the West Village, has become locally famous for its gregarious night clerk, Eunho Lee. Mr. Lee, a 50-year-old Korean immigrant, makes elaborate, personalized hats out of paper plates bearing messages like "Peace, Love, and Happiness 2004," and "Sue, You Are So Beautiful," and calls himself the Deli Lama, which in turn is what everyone else calls him. The Deli Lama favors skimpy polyester shorts and often can be found on the sidewalk outside of the store, either hanging upside down from the street sign or sinking a golf ball into an imaginary hole. Serving as a combination tourist attraction, town crier and neighborhood North Star, the Lama is one of the area's most beloved institutions.

title: Maybe He's Returning To Capone's Hideaway
description: New Jersey doesn't have Geraldo Rivera to kick around any more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINE, JACK W.
description: FINE--Jack W. February 22, 1914-November 23, 2004 in Boynton Beach. Most recently of Stuart, Florida, formerly of East Meadow, LI and New York City. Predeceased by wives Helen Letica and Helen Tuck and brothers Jules and Dr. Albert Fine. Survived by first wife Fannie Epstein, daughters Susan Hochberg and Maxine Bochnia, grandchildren Michael and Rachel Bochnia and Sarah Hochberg Luijpers (Patrick) and greatgranddaughter Arielle. Also, by stepsons Dr. Gregory Letica, Nick Letica (Terri) and Paul Tuck (Barbara) and stepdaughters Iris Nystrom and Marcia Elfand and by five step - grandchildren. Jack's passions as a youth were his political activism, his business Franklin Rapid Dart, the study of the piano and his family. Later on came his love of golf, world travel and the beauty of gardening and living in Florida. Still later he was devoted to chairing and fundraising for the Martin County Literacy Council and the Lyric Theatre. Presently a private family gathering is planned. When plans for a memorial service are completed they will be published in the Stuart, Florida area newspapers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALY, SYBIL GILMORE
description: HEALY--Sybil Gilmore. Died November 23, 2004, aged 93, in California. Born in Brooklyn March 15, 1911, she lived most of her life in Babylon, Long Island. She was much loved by her sister Ruth Stevenson, daughters Sharon Healy and Sybil Pagnamenta, grandchildren Carla, Anthony, Robin and Zoe, cousin Mary Gilmore Thomas, her nieces and nephews and a large extended family. Memorial mass, Friday, December 3, 10:45, St Joseph's RC Church, Babylon. In lieu of flowers, donations to Southside Hospital, Bay Shore or Good Samaritan Hospital Baxter Guild, West Islip.

title: Chair Persons
description: When David Gordon and Valda Setterfield start clambering on black metal folding chairs in Mr. Gordon's new production of Eugne Ionesco's play "The Chairs," which runs Wednesday through Saturday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater, longtime theatergoers may think they're having a bout of dj vu. Mr. Gordon, 68, and Ms. Setterfield, 70, at right, partners in life and art, have been playing around with these props for decades. It started in 1974, when Ms. Setterfield's dance career seemed in jeopardy after a car accident. Mr. Gordon thought he could help her by choreographing something with an entirely new vocabulary. The result, "Chair," was the first of many works, for her and for others, featuring metal folding chairs. Last weekend Sylviane Gold visited their SoHo loft to talk to Mr. Gordon about his fetish. They sat in black metal folding chairs.

title: Broker Sells Citi Habitats, Then Buys City Habitat
description: ANDREW HEIBERGER sold his real estate brokerage company, Citi Habitats, to the Corcoran Group last June. The sale price was never disclosed, but some indication of the sale's salubrious effect on his personal finances may be gleaned from the fact that two weeks before the deal was announced, he signed a contract to pay $8.1 million for a five-story town house in the East 60's, near Lexington Avenue.

title: Jill and Jill Live on the Hill, but One Must Boil the Water
description: MY straight male friends don't believe it when I tell them, but it happens. I'll be lunching with some women who are grousing about their husbands: perfectly nice guys who will never just listen to their problems but always have to solve them, who won't write a thank-you note -- even to their own mothers -- and who give their child one bath and think they deserve a medal. At some point these women look wistfully in my direction and say, "I'd be a lesbian too, if I could!"

title: Iran Reasserts Its Right to Enrich Uranium as Standoff Persists
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 27 - Iran's foreign minister said Saturday that Iran had every right to keep, for research purposes, some centrifuges that could be used to enrich uranium, an indication that a standoff on the country's nuclear program may not be easily resolved.

I stayed there in my dreams from that moment on. No matter how hard & fast reality tried to catch me, I always managed to return to heaven in my dreams if only for a second." - Charlotte, New York, Summer 2000 And, lovely one, rest assured that never, not even for a moment, are you not in our thoughts and in our dreams. Your father, your mother and your brothe

description: If the Knicks have not yet found the ability to crush teams at will, they have at least discovered how to win even when their minds wander and their discipline disappears.

Formally known as F.M.I. 3-07.22, and titled "Counterinsurgency Operations," it was distributed to all branches of the military in October.

title: Inside the List
description: WOLFE HUNT: Tom Wolfe's new novel, "I Am Charlotte Simmons," enters the fiction list this week at No. 3. It had to run a gantlet to get there; critics have blasted away as if the book were a varmint on literature's manicured front lawn. Wolfe, who is 74, says he is taking his reviews in stride. "When you're my age, there's two ways to find out if you're still alive," he told The Boston Globe. "One is to feel your pulse. The other is to see if you're having a fight with somebody." Nearly all of Wolfe's 13 books have made the Times list, beginning with "The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby," which had a two-week ride in 1965. (Of his two previous novels, "The Bonfire of the Vanities," published in 1987, made the list for 56 weeks, and "A Man in Full," published in 1998, hung on for 19.) Wolfe may be taking some consolation in the fact that his occasional antagonist, John Updike, did not make the fiction list this fall with "Villages," his elegiac 21st novel. Updike's fiction was once a regular presence on the Times list. Of his first 14 novels, only one -- "Of the Farm" (1965) -- did not land on this page. Since 1992, however, Updike has published seven novels and only one of them, "In the Beauty of the Lilies" (1996), made an appearance here.

title: Something Big in the Backyard Grows
description: IN the spring of 2002, when Adam Beckman and his wife, Wendy Dorr, bought a brick town house in the heart of Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, they thought they'd found the perfect home. "We thought we could maybe be here for 30 years, raise kids here, send them to the local school," Ms. Dorr said one day recently as she sat in the sitting room of her house, at 151 Bergen Street between Hoyt and Bond Streets, her year-old daughter, Lucy, wriggling in her lap.

description: Depending on your point of view, Napoleon Bonaparte was a great civilizer who brought order and justice to Europe or a power-mad imperialist willing to spare no suffering to achieve his ends. To Alexis Suchet, he was above all a good manager.

Not that he didn't give back as good as he got, he says, displaying a well-scarred fist. Back then, in the 1960's and 70's, the beat cop was the law, working without radio or supervision, and his domain was known as Tiger Bay, a bleak warren of tenements, brothels and bars strewn around the dilapidated port of Cardiff.

After a screening, a visiting Dutch director fielded questions from the crowd. One fellow piped up, asking, "What does it feel like to make a foreign film?" While some of us choked on our crackers and hoped the moment would pass, fast, the director gamely tried to answer the guy, figuring maybe there was a real question buried in there somewhere. I left the gathering deeply embarrassed for my compatriot.

title: CAMDEN RANKED MOST DANGEROUS CITY
description: Camden is the most crime-ridden city in the nation, according to the annual rankings released by Morgan Quitno last week. Camden, above, rose from third in last year's rankings, this year beating out Detroit, which fell to second. Trenton was ranked the fourth most dangerous city of its size, between 75,000 and 100,000 residents. New Jersey cities were among the safest as well. Brick Township was ranked the second safest city and Dover Township the 10th. The rankings cover cities with more than 75,000 people and take into account six crime figures: murder, rape, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary and auto theft. Robert Strauss

Game makers are aggressively marketing to children as young as 3, while researchers report what parents already know: that children as young as 8 and 9 are asking for adult toys, like cellphones and iPods, rather than stuffed animals or toy trucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARK, GEORGE JOHN ''JACK''
description: CLARK--George John "Jack" and LaJean Avery--Died on Wednesday, November 17, in an automobile accident a mile away from their home of 40 years in New Canaan, Connecticut. LaJean Avery was born in Aberdeen, South Dakota, on July 23, 1923, and raised in Huron, South Dakota. After attending Carleton College, she worked for the State Department in Athens, Greece, as part of the postWorld War II Marshall Plan reconstruction of Europe. Jack Clark was born in Springfield, Massachusetts on January 18, 1925. After undergraduate work at Yale University and graduate work at Harvard, he went to work for the Greek government in Athens, where he met and married LaJean. Upon returning to the United States, the Clarks lived in Arlington, Massachusetts, Bethesda, Maryland and La Paz, Bolivia, while Jack worked for the International Monetary Fund. In 1964 he joined First National City Bank (now Citigroup) and the family moved to New Canaan, Connecticut. Jack spent 26 years at Citigroup, working in international finance and retiring as an Executive Vice President. LaJean earned her Masters in Special Education from Fairfield University and returned to work teaching special education and directing the special education department at the New Canaan High School for over a decade. Jack retired in 1990 and LaJean in 1991. During the last 14 years of their lives they spent a great deal of time with their children and grandchildren, traveling extensively around the country and the world, and enjoying gardening, swimming, birdwatching, fine dining, and other activities at their house in New Canaan. They are survived by their three children: Constance of Coral Springs, Florida; Catherine of Great Barrington, Massachusetts; and Christopher of Wayland, Massachusetts; and eight adoring grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan on December 10. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Birdcraft Museum, Audubon Society of Connecticut, at (203) 259-0416.

title: The Modernist Nursery
description: Several Sundays ago, behind their vintage 1950's open-plan modernist house tucked into the hills of Oakland, Calif., the Pfeiffer family sat on their back stairs -- modern jungle gym in front of them, Eames chairs behind, no molded plastic in sight -- planning a new treehouse. Melissa Pfeiffer, 33, is the founder of Modernseed, a year-old store selling modern furniture, fashions and accessories for kids, and Eric Pfeiffer, 35, is a contemporary-furniture designer, and theirs is the kind of home that inspires house envy, particularly if you're one of those parents who vowed not to let the house fill up with plastic junk and then saw exactly that situation come to pass, first with the musical vibrating bouncy seat, and then the doorjamb Bumper Jumper and then a gift of a multicolored plastic Fisher-Price train set that became your daughter's absolute favorite possession.

But perhaps even hard-core curmudgeons will agree that 2004 has been great fun, thanks in large part to the vociferous Southern hip-hop stars kind enough to take over the pop charts. Over the past year, radio stations across the country have been hijacked by a string of rebel yellers -- Petey Pablo (North Carolina), Lil' Flip (Houston), Young Buck ("Cashville," Tenn.), T.I. (Atlanta), Juvenile (New Orleans), Trick Daddy (Miami) -- bearing one exhilarating hit after another.

title: The U.S. Has a Powerful Team, With a Little Help From Russia
description: Members of the all-grandmaster fourth-place team in the 36th Olympiad were all born in Russia before their families migrated to the United States. In that respect, the one culture carried over to the other. Ever since Lenin's day, chess has had a high standing in Russia. Although grandmasters there economically outclassed other professions, they were grudgingly considered privileged personages. Lenin's motivation was not to create a new class but to teach the populace to read; if you are to educate yourself in the Ruy Lopez, the Queen's Gambit, and the Sicilian Defense, you have to learn to read what they are all about.

title: Transported
description: THESE days I find myself, regularly and happily, in the midst of the clutter of New Yorkers you find on the bus. I particularly savor the times when all of us, riders and driver, seem of one purpose: A woman in a tailored suit and a man in slouchy pants stand together, commiserating about the traffic. Old and young, sitting side by side, laugh at a curbside altercation between a spandex-clad Rollerblader and a deliveryman on a rusty bicycle. A young white man jumps up to give his seat to an elderly black woman. It all seems so natural, like something that always was and always will be.

title: Electronic Voting 1.0, and No Time to Upgrade

title: The 21st-Century Cinephile
description: As a true cinephile, and the co-owner of a small film distribution company, I found that Manohla Dargis's essay (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 14) reinforced the idea that my living room has become the best repertory house around. With the advent of the DVD and my letterbox TV, I can watch a double feature of Wong Kar-wai's "2046" (with the help of my multiregion DVD player) followed by John Waters's "Desperate Living." In a sense, I am my own programmer of that theater. Where else am I going to be able to watch a beautiful version of Hitchcock's "Notorious"? Certainly not at a repertory house, as they have indeed vanished.

description: MYERS--Nathaniel Charles, Jr. died Thursday, November 25, 2004 in Asheville, NC. Born in Manhattan in 1928 he was a longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY. title: 'All in the Dances'
description: IN 1987 I WENT TO LINCOLN CENTER TO WATCH New York City Ballet dance Concerto Barocco, a ballet by George Balanchine set to Bach's Two-Violin Concerto. I knew the music well, having played one of the solo parts in high school, but except for an isolated Nutcracker seen on a college trip to New York, Barocco (as dancers and regular balletgoers call it) was my first Balanchine ballet. Indeed, I hadn't seen very many ballets of any kind, nor was I much impressed with the ones I had seen. So far as I could tell, they consisted for the most part of thin women in white skirts pretending to be birds, fluttering through elaborately costumed pantomime shows whose quaint plots were too silly to take seriously. I didn't know a lot about Balanchine, but I'd just seen a TV documentary about him that led me to believe that his dances were different, so I decided to give Concerto Barocco a try, in much the same spirit of adventure that might have led another person to go to the Museum of Modern Art, or to a jazz club.

The Arditti String Quartet, the British new-music ensemble for which the work was written, brings it to Zankel Hall on Saturday, and the Daedalus Quartet, a young American group, presents it at Weill Recital Hall on Dec. 10.

title: The Albany Fumble

That is what New York's State Legislature and Gov. George Pataki do with alarming ease. They hand out benefits or require laudable changes in programs, for schools or pension plans or health benefits. Then when the check arrives, Albany's politicians are fumbling in their pockets for their share of the tab.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: CAPT. NATHAN ALGREN is a drunken wreck at the beginning of Edward Zwick's stirring epic THE LAST SAMURAI (2003). A Civil War hero reduced to doing promotional talks for Winchester rifles, Algren (Tom Cruise) agrees to take a lucrative overseas job offer. Asked to train the Japanese Army in the ways of modern warfare so they can defeat the Samurai, he answers, "For 500 bucks a week, I'll kill whoever you want." But in the first battle, the Samurai take Algren prisoner, quietly teach him about honor and give him back his soul. When Algren says, "Every soldier has nightmares," his new best friend (Ken Watanabe) replies, "Only one who is ashamed of what he has done" -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:35 a.m. on HBO.

Under the provisions of Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law, the company will be allowed to restructure its credit and reorganize. The refinancing is expected to shave $500 million from its accumulated debt. title: Constructing a Teen Phenom
description: If you were to compose a scouting report on the young baseball player Tommy Winegardner, it would note his strong throwing arm, the impressive balance and footwork he displays as an infielder and the beginnings of what the pros would call "pop" in his bat -- a budding ability to hit the ball with authority. But no one would say that he looks, at first glance, like the next Ken Griffey Jr. or Roger Clemens. At 14, Tommy is 5-foot-6 and about 145 pounds. He is still a little soft-looking in the way that many mid-teenage boys are, but his hard work in the weight room has started to build muscle definition, and his mother has changed her way of cooking -- more lean meats and chicken, less starch and fat -- to complement his physical training. He is just an average runner at present, but a more supple body might help make him faster. One thing Tommy has no control over, of course, is his eventual height, but everyone with an interest in his baseball career is eagerly anticipating a pretty good growth spurt, and with some good reason, since his father is 6-foot-2. "You can't put your finger on how big a kid's going to get," said Tommy's coach, Ken Bolek, "but if he gets as big as his father, I think we'll all be very happy."

title: What Is an American Movie Now?
description: As both a filmgoer and a writer trying to make my way into film, I don't share Hirschberg's limited view of American cinema. Alexander Payne's new film, "Sideways," is, she says, "essentially a foreign film made in America." Except that it's not; it's an American film made by an American in America. Why does "Shrek 2" count as American but "Sideways" does not? Looks a lot like diversity to me. Contrary to some assumptions, being creatively honest and satisfying the audience are not mutually exclusive. The makers of "Shrek 2" and "Sideways" have both proved this through their own voices, both while making "American" films.

title: Total Television
description: CBS won the official ratings race during the first full week of the November sweeps, averaging 15 million viewers per prime-time hour, followed by NBC (11.3), ABC (10.4), Fox (7.3), WB (3.8) and UPN (3.7). But what about the 45 million or so other people, on average, who were watching television? Here's another way of looking at the ratings for that week: instead of ranking the broadcast networks, we've ranked the media conglomerates that own them -- and nearly every other outlet on your TiVo grid. The easy winner, predictably, was Viacom, owner of CBS and UPN as well as the MTV cable networks. But other high finishers, like Time Warner and Liberty Media, may be names that television viewers don't normally think of while cruising channels. (For each company, we added up the average viewers for all of the networks and cable channels in which it has a controlling interest; joint ventures were divided evenly among the owners. Only networks whose numbers are made public by Nielsen Media Research, and which met the company's minimum reporting standards, were included.) MIKE HALE

title: A Torture Report Compels Chile to Reassess Its Past

But even before the findings are formally made public, the graphic, wrenching report is forcing Chileans to reassess their past and recalibrate their political attitudes. The 1,200-page document covers the period from the coup of Sept. 11, 1973, that installed Gen. Augusto Pinochet in power through 1989, when military rule was about to give way to a democratic civilian government. It concludes that during the dictatorship, especially in the first phase, "torture was a policy of the state, meant to repress and terrorize the population."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, DR. GERALD J.
description: FRIEDMAN--Dr. Gerald J. Beloved husband of Dorothy, died peacefully at home on Thursday, November 25, at the age of 91. Son of the late Abraham and Flora, and brother of the late Samuel J. and Estelle Gervis. He received his BS at NYU College of Arts and Sciences, and his MD from NYU School of Medicine at the age of 24. His specialties in diabetes and metabolism, endocrinology and internal medicine generated many published articles in leading journals including pioneering texts in nutrition and diabetes. He held various positions at Beth Israel Hospital including Chief of Medical Intensive Care Unit, Chief of Diabetes and Metabolism, and served two terms as President of the Medical Board. He served as National Director of Medicine for United Parcel Service for 37 years until his retirement in 1992. He was the recipient of many awards, served on numerous professional boards and held associate professorships at NYU School of Medicine and Mount Sinai. After retiring, he made many philanthropic contributions and named the Gerald J. and Dorothy R. Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University, and endowed chairs in Nephrology at Tufts, in diabetes at Beth Isreal Medical Center, and in Alzheimer's at NYU Medical Center. He was a longtime member of Brotherhood Synagogue Congregation in New York and served many terms as President. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Service private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Bollywood Confidential
description: While I appreciated Suketu Mehta's love letter to Bollywood and share his passion, I felt he was too rosy in his assessment of the relationship between Hindi film and Indian politics. In 2001, "Gadar" ("Revolt") became a massive hit, far surpassing other films like "Lagaan," with its secular viewpoint making it more palatable to Western viewers. "Gadar" tells the story of an Indian Sikh who, to save his kidnapped wife, rampages through Pakistan, leaving the dead bodies of more than a hundred Muslim bad guys in his wake. Since then, a wave of hyperviolent films, often with anti-Pakistani and anti-Muslim themes, have hit Indian cinemas. Seeing "Gadar" in a packed moviehouse in India, with hundreds of young men yelling with delight as the body count rose, was the most disturbing filmgoing experience of my life.

title: The Jewel Case
description: The Hopi kachina spirit that broods over Tony Hillerman's 17th series mystery, SKELETON MAN (HarperCollins, $25.95), is quite as fearsome as the Navajo skinwalkers and shape-shifters that haunted the Indian tribal lands of the Southwest in previous novels. But unlike those purely malevolent spirits, the Skeleton Man (or Death Kachina, as he is also known) performed a mixed blessing for the earliest humans by guiding them out of the underworld, where they were immortal, into the light of the "glittering world" and taught them not to be afraid of death. In his masterly reworking of this powerful myth, Hillerman creates a kachina for contemporary times -- a hermit who lives in a cave at the bottom of the Grand Canyon and dispenses diamonds ("the symbol of greed," according to one wary recipient) that can corrupt anyone who mistakes their cold glitter for true light.

title: Food Writing: Restaurant Rows
description: JANE GRIGSON'S idea of a great meal was one taken at a friend's kitchen table: restaurants weren't much her thing. But this late, great English cookery writer once told me about going out for a test meal with Mimi Sheraton, then the restaurant critic of The New York Times. She was dumbfounded when Sheraton, a pioneer of the critics-in-disguise movement, donned a wig. They do things differently in Britain, where few newspapers have budgets large enough to enable a critic to eat twice in a restaurant, let alone scarf down the half-dozen test meals Sheraton might digest before praising or damning a single mouthful. In London, there's no need for disguises -- some papers even run photographs of their restaurant critics -- because a restaurant will rarely see those critics more than once.

title: Tweens 'R' Us
description: When John Broadus Watson sternly told the many readers of his "Psychological Care of Infant and Child" (1928) not to have a baby unless they could give it a room of its own, little did he know what lay ahead: tweens -- those 8-to-12-year-old sophisticates with wallets -- waltzing into stores like PBteen, Delia's, Justice and Dry Ice, where they annually spend several hundred dollars each to decorate their sanctums with privacy doorbells, "Jet Setter" headboards, catcher's-mitt-shaped chairs, locker-look-alike dressers and fake-fur computer covers. But of all people, Watson perhaps should have seen it coming. The renowned behaviorist was also vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency and a spokesman for the idea, then novel, that marketing is not just about peddling products that people need; it's also about creating a society of consumers ever eager for more. Famous for claiming that any child, conditioned early enough, could be turned into anything -- "a doctor, lawyer, artist, merchant-chief and, yes, even into beggar-man and thief" -- he left a key vocation out. If shopper had been on his list, it would have been a prescient boast.

title: The Terrorist As Auteur
description: In the context of filmed beheadings, Ignatieff concludes that we still have the choice to decline our enemy's invitation deeper into the darkening vortex of anything goes. More likely -- and sadly -- we are already there. Whether by firebombing in aerial raids or mutilation by knives, the death of innocent civilians should disgust us equally. Consider this: Is it the filmed act itself that constitutes a more repugnant form of barbarism, or is it that such war imagery dared to puncture our mission of liberation? What's more, if we could compress all those killings we cleanly record as "collateral damage" into a single picture of carnage, I would bet Ignatieff would have a hard time determining which image reached deeper into his moral void.

title: Sugar Fixed

Despite the jaw-dropping complexity of some of his wire and thread works, it's the art made with edible materials -- the Mona Lisa in peanut butter and jelly, the "Last Supper" in chocolate syrup -- that has attracted the most attention. Two such works, "Big James Sweats Buckets" and "Valicia Bathes in Sunday Clothes," at right, from 1997, appear in the exhibition "Retratos: 2,000 Years of Latin American Portraits," opening on Friday at El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan. Both are from the six-part "Sugar Children Series," which he first drew in granulated sugar on black paper -- his own brand of Pointillism -- and then photographed. Ted Loos spoke with Mr. Muniz about how to hang sugar on a gallery wall.

description: PHILLIPS--Lynn, Jr., my dad, died Saturday, November 13th. Red Smith of the NY Herald Tribune described dad as "A pleasant man, cheerfully friendly, handsomely and quietly dressed, impeccably scrubbed and barbered." He was that and much more. A loving husband and father, he and my mom Mary made their home on E. 57th St. for more than 50 years. During WW II Dad served in the Army signal corps; he spent his career in sales and marketing. Known for his quick wit, he loved to make people laugh. He excelled on both the piano and the backgammon board. Dad moved to Florida after mom died in 1991. There he was blessed with two special relationships: one with his caretaker Patty Brigham, the daughter he never had, and one with Marge Bazin, the romance of his final years. He is survived by my wife Kathie and me (Mike), his brother Chick, his grandchildren Lisa, Pam, Amy and Brian and his great grandchildren Kevin, Ashley and Brian. A future service will be held in NYC.

title: Risky Business
description: Virgin Flasher V7 Cellphone Teenagers are widely seen as the toughest sell for marketers. Anyone who has ever been a teenager can probably guess one big reason: Adults have no idea what teenagers want, and their attempts to crack the code are often embarrassing. But marketers are not going to leave teenagers alone, because as a segment they are irresistible. Think, for example, about cellphones and other wireless technologies. Even the most clueless grown-up probably has some idea that cellphones are integral to current youth culture. Yet it does not necessarily follow that teenagers have the same wants and needs as other mobile-phone users.

"Shrek 2" not only teaches children to overlook the differences but also to embrace them -- and parents who share the experience may get a new take on "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner?"

title: 'Gilead': Acts of Devotion
description: TO bloom only every 20 years would make, you would think, for anxious or vainglorious flowerings. But Marilynne Robinson, whose last (and first) novel, ''Housekeeping,'' appeared in 1981, seems to have the kind of sensibility that is sanguine about intermittence. It is a mind as religious as it is literary -- perhaps more religious than literary -- in which silence is itself a quality, and in which the space around words may be full of noises. A remarkable, deeply unfashionable book of essays, ''The Death of Adam'' (1998), in which Robinson passionately defended John Calvin and American Puritanism, among other topics, suggested that, far from suffering writer's block, Robinson was exploring thinker's flow: she was moving at her own speed, returning repeatedly to theological questions and using the essay to hold certain goods that, for one reason or another, had not yet found domicile in fictional form.

title: Arts, Briefly; Wales Center Opens
description: Last month Wales was invisible: the country was inadvertently left off the official map on the cover of a European Union annual report, causing a minor furor. Over the weekend, however, Wales established itself firmly on the international cultural map with the opening of its long-awaited Wales Millennium Center, a $200 million complex on the waterfront overlooking Cardiff Bay. Designed by the Percy Thomas Partnership, the center includes a 1,900-seat theater for opera, theater and dance and was constructed using local materials, like recycled slate and hardwood; its texture and unusual shape have given it the nickname the Armadillo. Opening events involved appearances by a roster of international artists, many of Welsh origin, including the operatic star Bryn Terfel, the crossover singers Charlotte Church and Michael Ball, as well as tributes to the singers Shirley Bassey and Gwyneth Jones and the actors Sian Phillips and Richard Burton. The first full season at the center begins on Thursday with the Welsh singer and comedian Max Boyce and a play, "The Good, the Bad and the Cuddly." PAM KENT

title: Arts, Briefly; Humanities Prize
description: The Library of Congress will award its second annual $1 million Kluge Prize for lifetime contribution to the humanities to two scholars of religion, the American historian Jaroslav Pelikan, above right, and the French philosopher Paul Ricoeur, right. The prize, to be awarded on Wednesday, recognizes work in anthropology, philosophy, history and the study of religion, for which there are no Nobel prizes. Mr. Pelikan, 80, was the Sterling Professor of History at Yale, the highest academic honor there. His most acclaimed work, "The Christian Tradition: A History and Development of Doctrine," helped to integrate the story of the Eastern Christian tradition into the overall history of Christianity. Mr. Ricoeur, 91, held the chair of general philosophy at the Sorbonne during the 1960's and the chair of the divinity school at the University of Chicago through the 80's. His works, including "Finitude and Culpability," "Freud and Philosophy: An Essay on Interpretation" and "Time and Narrative," contributed to the development of hermeneutics, the study of the interpretation of texts. The winners were selected by a five-member panel of scholars and will share the money. The award was conceived by James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, and financed by the philanthropist John W. Kluge, who gave the library $73 million in 2000 for library projects, including the prizes and a new scholar center. Last year's recipient was the Polish philosopher Leszek Kolakowski. JOHN FILES

title: The Line of No Return

I have been in line since 4 a.m. Some of the people in front of me spent the night under a tent opposite the embassy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Car Hit At Scene Of Death

The police said the officers' car was struck about 1:30 a.m. by Lawrence Mahon, 33, of Prospect-Lefferts Gardens. The two officers inside and one standing on the street were injured. Mr. Mahon was arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said. The police identified the dead man as Rafael Phillips, 54, of Cypress Hills but had not found the vehicle that struck him. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, DR. GERALD J.
description: FRIEDMAN--Dr. Gerald J. Beloved husband of Dorothy, died peacefully at home on Thursday, November 25, at the age of 91. Son of the late Abraham and Flora, and brother of the late Samuel J. and Estelle Gervis. He received his BS at NYU College of Arts and Sciences, and his MD from NYU School of Medicine at the age of 24. His specialties in diabetes and metabolism, endocrinology and internal medicine generated many published articles in leading journals including pioneering texts in nutrition and diabetes. He held various positions at Beth Israel Hospital including Chief of Medical Intensive Care Unit, Chief of Diabetes and Metabolism, and served two terms as President of the Medical Board. He served as National Director of Medicine for United Parcel Service for 37 years until his retirement in 1992. He was the recipient of many awards, served on numerous professional boards and held associate professorships at NYU School of Medicine and Mount Sinai. After retiring, he made many philanthropic contributions and named the Gerald J. and Dorothy R. Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University, and endowed chairs in Nephrology at Tufts, in diabetes at Beth Isreal Medical Center, and in Alzheimer's at NYU Medical Center. He was a longtime member of Brotherhood Synagogue Congregation in New York and served many terms as President. He will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Service private. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Arts, Briefly; It's 'Housewives' Again
description: "Desperate Housewives" is on a winning streak for ABC. The saucy, twisty soap opera draws more viewers each week, and Sunday was no different, as an audience of 27.04 million watched the mysterious doings on Wisteria Lane. Last week's episode teased that one of the suburban residents would be killed, and indeed, Paul Young, the angry widower, murdered Martha Huber, the snoopy blackmailer. The episode also featured Felicity Huffman's character hitting rock bottom with her Ritalin habit and considering suicide. ("So you got addicted to your kids' A.D.D. medication," Teri Hatcher's character said as she comforted her. "It happens.") ABC came in first among the 18-to-49 age group, and "Boston Legal," which follows "Desperate Housewives," also earned its highest ratings of the season, according to the Nielsen overnights. But in this sweeps season, CBS beat ABC on the overall average with its strong regular lineup of "60 Minutes" and "Cold Case" and the original movie "When Angels Come to Town," with Peter Falk and Katey Sagal. In a distant third-place finish, NBC broadcast two movies: "Shrek" and an original musical production of "A Christmas Carol," starring Kelsey Grammer. KATE AURTHUR

title: A Life Knocked Off Balance by National Acclaim
description: THERE are noisy renovations in progress at the novelist Lily Tuck's well-appointed Madison Avenue apartment, a setting as elegant and genteel but, at least temporarily, as discombobulated as she is. Winning the National Book Award for fiction has thrown the silver-haired Ms. Tuck, 66, into a spasm of dislocation worthy of one of her fictional heroines. Through four novels and a collection of short stories, she has specialized in what happens, or does not, to a woman's powers of reinvention when she finds herself marooned in a strange or exotic environment. Usually, strange men figure prominently.
