title: DUPONT AND SYNGENTA SETTLE SEED TECHNOLOGY DISPUTES
description: The DuPont Company, a producer of corn seed, and Syngenta, a maker of crop chemicals, said yesterday that they had settled two-year-old disputes over seed technology patents. DuPont's Pioneer Hi-Bred unit will receive commercial licenses to Syngenta patents on Herculex and YieldGard insect-resistant corn traits, Dupont said. Syngenta has halted a practice that Pioneer contended caused inappropriate acquisition of proprietary genetic material, the companies said. Syngenta, based in Switzerland, continued to pursue its contention in a trial that began yesterday in federal court in Wilmington, Del., that units of the Dow Chemical Company and the Monsanto Company were violating patents on its insect protection products. DuPont is based in Wilmington.

title: Free the Academic Drug Tests
description: Academic medical centers represent the top rung of medical research in this country and are widely thought to be impartial and independent. So it is disheartening to find them signing restrictive contracts with pharmaceutical companies that allow the companies to dictate what drug testing data can be openly discussed and published. The manufacturers of drugs and medical devices are already under increasing pressure to list all of their clinical trials and results in public databases. Now academic medical centers will need to clean up their own practices to help prevent suppression of information about the safety and efficacy of drugs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Baby Found Bleeding In Foster Home Dies
description: A 3-week-old boy, who was found yesterday morning bleeding from the nose in the foster home where his young mother lives in Queens, died shortly after, the authorities said. The baby, Cristian Liz, was taken from the home on 179th Street in St. Albans about 6 a.m. to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. An autopsy was to be performed today by the city medical examiner. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dalai Lama Arrives
description: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader, arrived for a three-day visit, his first since 1992. His arrival in Elista, capital of the republic of Kalmykia, near the Caspian Sea, where half the population is Buddhist, came as a surprise after the Foreign Ministry wavered for months over granting him a visa and flip-flopped as recently as Friday. Wary of offending China, which accuses the exiled Dalai Lama of being a separatist intent on fighting for an independent Tibet, the Foreign Ministry has stipulated that the visit be solely pastoral. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Group To Challenge Presidential Tally
description: A group led by the Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to challenge the outcome of the presidential race in Ohio, saying election irregularities must be investigated before the state completes its final vote count on Dec. 6. Mr. Jackson, president of the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, told more than 100 ministers in Cincinnati that the State Supreme Court must set aside President Bush's 136,337-vote victory in Ohio and called for a federal investigation into what he called questionable vote tallies in several counties. Mr. Jackson also said he supported a plan by the political activist group Alliance for Democracy to ask the State Supreme Court to declare a new winner or to order a recount of the votes. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: BFI CANADA WILL PURCHASE IESI, TRASH HAULER IN TEXAS
description: BFI Canada, the trash hauler, said yesterday that it would buy the IESI Corporation, another trash-hauling company, for 1.1 billion Canadian dollars ($927 million) in equity and debt. BFI, based in Toronto, estimated that the acquisition would increase its customer base by 84 percent. IESI, based in Fort Worth, hauls trash for both residential and commercial customers mostly in the South and the Northeast. BFI operates in Canada's four most populous provinces. While complete details of the transactions were not revealed, BFI would acquire 100 percent of IESI's common shares. Current IESI shareholders will ultimately own 39 percent of the merged operation. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Prosecutors Challenge Credibility of Translator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SNOW, ROBERT M.
description: SNOW--Robert M. Died on November 27, 2004, at age 74. Beloved husband of Rosemary. Loving father (with Judith Schwamm Snow) of Erica Arbron, David and Selena Snow, Harvey-Skip Snow and Linda and Barrett Gross. Proud grandfather of Travis and Eric Snow, Alyson and Jake Arbron, Peter and Emily Gross and Zoe Ford Snow. Esteemed step-father of Justin and Pauline Freen. Cherished brother of the late Selig and Charles Snow and brother-in-law of Bernice and Deanna Snow. Beloved uncle and cousin to all of his family. Bob graduated from Brooklyn Law School in 1953 and served in the Air Force Judge Advocates Office during the Korean War. He was a developer and manager of real estate in his working years, but his passion was the ocean. Bob spent the last 25 years of his life sailing, fishing and living on the water. His children and grandchildren all cherish their time on boats, rivers and docks with Gramdpa Bob. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Cancer Society. title: National Briefing | Washington: City Museum Closes
description: The City Museum of Washington, created last year to chronicle local history, has closed. During planning and fund-raising, museum organizers said they expected more than 100,000 visitors each year, but the museum drew about 36,000 in its first 15 months. The museum struggled to find its place among the many national museums in the city; it also charged $5 for admission in a city where most museums are free. About $20 million was raised for the project, officials said. Most of it went toward setting up the museum and restoring the Beaux-Arts building that housed it. John Files (NYT)

title: F.D.A. APPROVES GIVEN IMAGING'S CAMERA IN A PILL
description: Given Imaging said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had approved use of a new camera in a pill as a tool for diagnosing diseases of the esophagus. The combination camera and radio transmitter, called PillCam, is about the size of a large vitamin pill. Given, based in Israel, said that the device snapped about 14 pictures a second for about 20 minutes after it was swallowed. PillCam software translates the transmitted data into a color video displayed on a computer monitor. PillCam is being marketed as a less invasive alternative to endoscopy, a procedure in which a camera mounted on a long plastic tube is inserted in the throat after a patient is sedated. Given said that the approval released a $10 million progress payment from Ethicon Endo-Surgery, the Johnson & Johnson subsidiary that has rights to distribute and market PillCam everywhere except Japan. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Another Reason to Love Netflix
description: As longtime readers know, I'm a big fan of Netflix. It's mail-order DVD rental service, so brilliant in execution that it ought to win some kind of Genius Business Plan Award. You pay a flat monthly fee of $12 or $18 a month (the price recently dropped, if you can believe that). In exchange, you get to pick out two or three DVD's from Netflix's library of 25,000 titles. They arrive by mail; you watch 'em and send 'em back in a prepaid mailer. You can churn through a dozen or more movies a month, or you can keep the same three lying on your TV for six months. Either way, all you pay is that fixed monthly fee, with no return deadlines or late fees.

description: I remember all too well the agony of postsurgical starvation: nearly five days elapsed after my Caesarean section when the hospital refused to give me anything but ice chips. All the while I was trying to nurse two big babies with nothing but an intravenous glucose solution to sustain me. But the nurses held firm. I had not yet passed gas or had a bowel movement.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Teenager Can Serve Probation At Home
description: Lionel Tate, the teenager freed in January after a court overturned his life sentence for killing a playmate at age 12, can return to his mother's home while he serves probation, a judge decided. Mr. Tate, now 17, had been living with another family after he was arrested in September and accused of being out late at night, in violation of his probation terms. The family said that visits by probation officers were too stressful and requested that he be removed. The playmate, Tiffany Eunick, 6, died of injuries suffered in July 1999 while she was visiting Mr. Tate's home. Two years later, a jury convicted him of kicking, slamming and stomping her to death. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Songs You Think You Know Get a Whole New Slant
description: When the Rolling Stones recorded "19th Nervous Breakdown" nearly 40 years ago, it came across, like many of the band's early hits, as a stinging putdown of the bourgeois treadmill and its stresses. To hear the same song slowed up, its lyrics articulated, by the singer Baby Jane Dexter at Helen's Supper Club in Chelsea on Friday evening, was to discover a different song: flippant, witty and far less impatient than the original, which roared through town like a speed-fueled motorcyclist thumbing his nose.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon Squeaker In Parliament
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's shaky government coalition survived three no-confidence votes in Parliament, though the opposition managed a strong showing. The government has become increasingly fragile since losing its parliamentary majority over the summer, and in two of the ballots yesterday, those opposing it won more votes than those supporting it, by counts of 51 to 49 and 50 to 47. It was the first time Mr. Sharon's government had come up short in such a vote. However, at least 61 of Parliament's 120 members must vote against the government for it to fall. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAHANEY, JAMES L., MSGR.
description: TAHANEY--James L., Msgr., a priest of the Diocese of Brooklyn, who touched the lives of many through his priestly ministry, died of complications of Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) on November 28, 2004 at Ozanam Hall Nursing Home. Msgr. Tahaney grew up in St. Teresa Parish, Woodside, NY. He graduated from Bishop Loughlin High School, Bklyn in 1955 and from Iona College in 1959. He attended Immaculate Conception Seminary, Huntington, and was ordained a priest for the Brooklyn Diocese on June 1st, 1963. In 1971 he received an MS ED from St. John's University and later pursued professional studies at Iona College and in Rome. His first assignment was to St. Mary Mother of Jesus Parish in Bensonhurst, Bklyn. In 1972 he became Director of the Diaconate Program in the Diocese and continued in that capacity for about 15 years. During this time he resided in St. Patrick's Parish, Bay Ridge. Other assignments included St. Andrew's Parish, Bklyn, St. Mary, Star of the Sea, Far Rockaway and Immaculate Heart of Mary in Bklyn. Msgr. Tahaney is survived by his sisters, Sr. Catherine and Sr. Anne, Dominican Sisters of Sparkill, Alice, Mary O'Malley and Margaret Dunleavy and her husband Hugh as well as nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Visitation at Immaculate Conception Center, 7200 Douglaston Pkwy, Douglaston, NY, Tuesday, 7-9 PM and Wednesday, 2-5 PM. Mass of Transferal, Immaculate Conception Center, Wednesday, 7:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial of Immaculate Conception Center, Thursday, 10:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Dominican Sisters of Sparkill or the PSP Foundation. For further information call Lynch Funeral Home at 718-784-1525

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sybase And I.B.M. Reach Marketing Pact
description: Sybase, which has long had an exclusive arrangement with Sun Microsystems, plans to announce today an agreement with I.B.M. to market and support Sybase's relational database software for Linux on I.B.M.'s OpenPower servers. I.B.M. and Sybase, long competitors in the corporate database market, will jointly market and support Sybase's program, focusing initially on sales to financial institutions where Sybase already has a stronghold. The agreement is unusual for Sybase because it represents the first time the company has struck a partnership for its Linux database with any company other than Sun. For I.B.M. it is significant because I.B.M.'s own relational database software, DB2, is a direct competitor to the Sybase program. I.B.M., which already offers the DB2 database for OpenPower, said yesterday that the arrangement with Sybase would expand what it is able to offer its server customers. The new program, called the Sybase Adaptive Service Enterprise for Linux on the I.B.M. OpenPower Platform, will be available in the first quarter of 2005, the companies said. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; A Nice Round Number
description: It looks as if The Threepenny Review made every one of its deadlines. With its new edition, to be published tomorrow, the literary quarterly celebrates both its 100th issue and its 25th year. Threepenny, based in Berkeley, Calif., and still run by its founding editor, Wendy Lesser, below, has remained independent -- unconnected to a university or foundation -- while publishing essays, reviews, fiction, poetry and commentary by a distinguished roster of writers that includes J.M. Coetzee, Margaret Drabble, Amy Tan, Dale Peck, Nadine Gordimer and Seamus Heaney. On Dec. 7 the journal will celebrate with a free reading at New York University's Hemmerdinger Hall, with, among others, the former United States poet laureates Louise Glck and Robert Pinsky, and Cynthia Ozick, who makes her Threepenny debut in issue No. 100. FELICIA R. LEE

description: GOOTNICK--Mark. Devoted husband of Susan (nee Friedlander). Beloved father of Cindy Hollander and fond father-in-law of Len. Cherished son of Marilyn (nee Bloom) and the late Martin. description: The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that it would spend $300 million in cash to buy Definity Health, a smaller health technology company specializing in health plans that allow consumers leeway in directing their medical spending.

title: Five in Texas Are Accused of Reporting False Trades
description: Five former traders were indicted yesterday in Houston on charges of reporting false trades to industry newsletters to manipulate natural gas prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHELLEY, SARAH O'HARA
description: SHELLEY--Sarah O'Hara. In Branford November 22, 2004. A twenty three year survivor of breast cancer, of 24 Thimble Farms Rd., Branford. She was born March 9, 1937 in Englewood, NJ, daughter of the late Robert Sydney and Katharine Drayton O'Hara. Beloved mother of Katharine Brockie Hurley (Mike) of Manchester, NH; Anne B. Fields (Lee) of Lake Mary, FL; and Sarah Traphagen Bishop (Drew) of New London, CT. Adoring grandmother of Stephen, Matthew, Katie Wright, Kevin and Hannah Hurley, and Faith Bishop. Survived by former husband Charles G. Shelley of Guilford, CT. Also survived by brothers, Robert S. O'Hara, Jr. (Bonnie) and Peter D. O'Hara (Mercer). A Memorial Service will be held Friday December 3, 2004 at 11:00 AM in Trinity Episcopal Church, 1109 Main St., Branford, 06405. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, donations may sent to The Restoration Fund of Trinity Church at the above address. For info W.S. Clancy Memorial Funeral Home, 504 Main St., Branford www.wsclancy.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, ALEXANDER B.
description: SMITH--Alexander B. The John Jay College of Criminal Justice mourns the loss of Professor Emeritus Alexander B. Smith, J.D., Ph.D. A member of the original faculty, first Dean of Studies and first Chair of the Division of Social Sciences, he advised Presidential and Congressional Commissions on troubled youth and drug abuse. Published widely in the criminal justice field, he continued to teach, do research and write until his recent death at age 95. On behalf of the College Community, President Jeremy Travis extends condolences to his wife, Jennie, daughter Lynn Smith-Ary and son-in-law Zander Ary.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Atari Names Chief Executive
description: Atari, which makes video games, has named a board member and former music executive, James Caparro, as chief executive and president, effective immediately. Mr. Caparro, 52, who has been a member of Atari's board since February 2002, succeeds the chairman and chief creative officer, Bruno Bonnell, as chief executive. Mr. Bonnell, 45, is chairman and chief executive of Infogrames Entertainment, Europe's biggest video game maker, which owns about 60 percent of Atari. The move will allow Mr. Bonnell to focus on creating games, as Mr. Caparro will take over the daily running of the company and address bad reviews and game delays, Edward S. Williams, an analyst with Harris Nesbitt, said. Atari has been coping with greater-than-expected competition, which has prompted it to reduce its forecasts for December sales and 2005 revenue. Atari shares rose 6 cents, to $1.97.

title: Videotapes Show Grisly Scenes at Kosher Slaughterhouse
description: An animal-rights group released grisly undercover videotapes today showing cows in a major kosher slaughterhouse in Iowa staggering and bellowing in seeming agony long after their throats were cut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JERVIS, HERMAN
description: JERVIS -- Herman. Lawyer and educator. Died peacefully November 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old. Predeceased by his first wife Dorothy Bing and his second wife Eleanor Dudley. Beloved father of Steven and Robert, father-in-law of Susan & Kathe, grandfather of Alexa Jervis, Lisa Jervis, Katharine Seizer, and Jeffrey Seizer, great grandfather of Daniel Jervis Racz. Stepfather of Carol, Eleanor, Deborah, Diana, Jennifer, and Barbara. Devotedly cared for by Ianthe Sobers. Graduate of the Ethical Culture School, Columbia College, and Columbia Law School. Former chairman, Board of Governors, Ethical Culture Schools; former president, Board of Trustees, Booth Library, Newtown, Connecticut. Memorial gifts may be sent to Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 Central Park West, NYC 10023. A memorial service will be held Friday, December 3rd, at 3:00 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

description: "There was never even a thought that the court would say, 'A pox on you both.' What people should know is that getting a divorce is not a slam dunk."

title: Albany Study Finds Ethics Flaws in Sale of Rights to the Erie Canal
description: ALBANY, Nov. 29 - A state authority's deal to sell the rights to develop private land along the Erie Canal to a developer for $30,000 was plagued by favoritism and illegal ethical lapses, according to a report by the state attorney general and a gubernatorial appointee.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Nichols Admitted Bombing Role
description: Terry L. Nichols, in secret plea bargaining with state prosecutors during his trial last year, admitted his involvement in the 1995 bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building even as he publicly denied any role, The Oklahoman reported. In a signed statement, Mr. Nichols acknowledged helping Timothy J. McVeigh construct the bomb that killed 168 people and destroyed the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, but said he had no prior knowledge of the target or of any other co-conspirators. Prosecutors said they believed Mr. Nichols was not forthcoming and rejected the plea attempt. Federal and state juries convicted Mr. Nichols, 49, of murder; he is serving two life sentences. Mr. McVeigh was executed. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: The cool-edged chic of a new Hong Kong
Bhopal Victims Not Fully Paid, Rights Group Says
description: BANGALORE, India, Nov. 29 - Almost 20 years after the world's worst industrial disaster, a gas leak from a Union Carbide pesticide factory in Bhopal that immediately killed 7,000 people and sickened several thousand others, the victims are poorly compensated and the companies have gone unpunished, a new study by Amnesty International said on Monday.

title: Another Shoe Drops on the Subject of Airport Security
description: WE have been hearing a lot from women who object to the way they are being handled, literally, at airport checkpoints. The chorus of protests from women about what they strongly regard as inappropriate body pat-downs has been loud, sustained and persuasive.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Intelsat Loses Satellite
description: The satellite operator Intelsat said that it had lost contact with one of its satellites and that as a result, a $3 billion takeover deal agreed upon in August could fall apart. The company's IA7 satellite, which serves the United States, Canada and South America, had a "sudden and unexpected electrical distribution anomaly" on Sunday, the company said. A consortium of four private equity firms led by Apax Partners plan to buy Intelsat, but they now have the right to walk away from the deal, Intelsat said. The private equity participants had not made a decision by yesterday evening. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Glimmers of Sanity in Ukraine
description: After days of escalating confrontation, there were encouraging signs yesterday that the crisis over Ukraine's botched presidential election might be headed for a peaceful, made-in-Ukraine solution based on both the rule of law and the continued territorial unity of this politically divided nation of 48 million. That would be the best possible outcome, and one that Ukraine's neighbors, from Russia to the European Union, should fully support.

title: Ronald L. Plesser, 59, Lawyer, Is Dead
description: Ronald L. Plesser, a privacy lawyer who helped ease access to government records and shape policy on access to personal e-mail messages, customer databases and other innovations of the electronic age, died on Nov. 18 at Washington Dulles International Airport. He was 59 and lived in Washington.

title: Think Small in Iraq
description: Washington - With the Bush administration, the Iraqi government and Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the religious leader of the country's Shiites, insisting that national elections must proceed as scheduled in late January, and a coalition of Sunni Arabs saying they should not, it seems more likely that the voting will be delayed, discredited or both. But a train wreck can be avoided: by delaying national elections while holding votes for provincial governments wherever possible, an acceptable compromise may yet be found.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the evolving tradition of homecoming kings and queens reversed the identities of two women at the University of Washington who were designated winning "royals," chosen without regard to gender as an expression of change. Emi Nomura Sumida was at the right, with Glorya Cho alongside her.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Annual Coat Drive Begins
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg encouraged New Yorkers yesterday to drop off their "gently used" coats at police precincts and elsewhere around the city, as part of the 16th annual coat drive of New York Cares, which hopes to collect and distribute 70,000 of them. Through Dec. 31, coats can be left at any police precinct, day or night, as well as Pennsylvania Station, Grand Central Terminal (in the Graybar Passage), the Port Authority Bus Terminal (Main Concourse, 42nd Street entrances), branches of Washington Mutual Bank and Janovic Plaza Stores. Especially needed are men's coats in large sizes. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Hopes Fade For Miners
description: Rescuers said it was unlikely that coal miners trapped by a gas explosion in central Shaanxi Province had survived. By last night, the bodies of 50 miners had been found and 110 remained missing, the New China News Agency said. Newspapers said that smaller explosions shook the mine days before the blast and that mine officials threatened to suspend miners who refused to continue working. Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Judge To Take A New York Break
description: Baltasar Garzn, Spain's crusading investigative judge, is planning to take a leave of absence next year to teach in New York, the newspaper El Mundo reported. The newspaper did not identify the institution. A spokeswoman for Mr. Garzn said he would make no comment on the report. Renwick McLean (NYT)

description: The Goldman Sachs Group yesterday promoted Suzanne Nora Johnson to vice chairman, three years after she took over the firm's investment research division with the job of eliminating potential conflicts of interest with investment banking.

description: PARIS, Nov. 30 - Despite its firing of Tyler Hamilton, its leader and the winner of a disputed gold medal at the Olympic Games in Athens, the Phonak team has lost its appeal to be included in bicycle racing's reorganized structure, officials said today.

title: The Subtle Art of French 14th-Century Song
description: With their exquisite refinement and their ability to compress large landscapes of thought and emotion into small and immaculate packages, the love songs of the Burgundian courts resemble the brilliant illuminated books of their day. The comparison was made both implicitly and explicitly in Sunday's performance by the Ferrara Ensemble, part of the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church. The program, "Trs Riches Heures: Gothic Music for the Valois Dukes," took its name from a legendary book of hours.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Gets $780 Million Under Airport Lease
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey paid $780 million to the city yesterday as part of an agreement to continue leasing Kennedy and La Guardia Airports until 2050. The payment included $500 million in rent and interest dating back to January 2002. Under the agreement, the authority's annual lease payments to the city increased to $93.5 million from $3.5 million, the mayor's office said. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: States' Rights Defense Falters in Medical Marijuana Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - The effort by advocates of the medical use of marijuana to link their cause to the Supreme Court's federalism revolution appeared headed for failure at the court on Monday.

title: W.H.O. Official Says Deadly Pandemic Is Likely if the Asian Bird Flu Spreads Among People
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 29 - A pandemic of human influenza could kill up to 100 million people around the world in a worst case, a World Health Organization official said Monday, significantly raising the agency's earlier estimates of the potential number of deaths in such a catastrophe.

title: 100 days : The grim ordeal of France's hostages
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Beef Accord Expected
description: Foreign Affairs Minister Pierre Pettigrew predicted that President Bush, when he visits Ottawa today, would offer a timetable for allowing Canadian cattle across the border, closed since last year when a Canadian cow was found to have mad cow disease. "We've been given signals that the president will be proposing a timetable that could be less than six months," Mr. Pettigrew said. The ban has been an irritant to relations, especially among ranchers who say Canadian cattle are as healthy as American cattle. Prime Minister Paul Martin will offer President Bush a dish of Alberta beef at an official dinner tonight. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: J.M. SMUCKER CO., Orrville, Ohio, the maker of jellies and jams, said that it would sell its industrial bakery ingredients business to Baldwin Richardson Foods Co., Chicago, and that it would sell its dairy ingredients business to Sabroso Co., Medford, Ore., a distributor of fruit products. Terms for the transactions were not disclosed. The company also said that it would close a factory in Salinas, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, ANNE
description: MARCUS--Anne. November 28, 2004, in her 94th year. A proud graduate of Hunter College, she taught mathematics for many years at Ellenville (NY) High School. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Marcus and mother of Kuni Yavneh and David Marcus. Grandmother of Tenli and Naomi Yavneh, and Gregory and Eugene Marcus. Greatgrandmother of eight. Sister to Ruth Bendiner, Shirley Marcus and the late Carl Marcus. Services private.

title: New York City Needs $5.6 Billion More to Run Schools, Panel Says
description: An extra $5.6 billion must be spent on New York City schoolchildren every year to give them the opportunity for a sound, basic education, which they are guaranteed under the state constitution, a court-appointed panel has found.

description: Some stressful events seem to turn a person's hair gray overnight.

description: In a unanimous vote yesterday, the trustees of the City University of New York named Stephen B. Shepard, the editor in chief of Business Week, as dean of the university's new graduate journalism school.

title: Body of NBC Official's Son Is Believed Found in Crash
description: The body of a teenager believed to be the son of Dick Ebersol, the chairman of NBC Sports, was found yesterday in the wreckage of a corporate jet that exploded on Sunday after crashing into a fence during takeoff at the Montrose, Colo., airport.

title: Airbus's Midsize Challenge to Boeing; Board Backs the 8,600-Mile-Range A350, in Direct Competition With 7E7
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 29 - For the last few years, Airbus and Boeing have been engaged in an all-out fight -- selling not just different aircraft, but different visions of air travel. Now, this black-and-white battle is suddenly turning a bit gray.

title: HALLIBURTON ASBESTOS SETTLEMENT WINS APPROVAL
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that a bankruptcy judge had approved a $1.5 billion settlement of asbestos claims involving two of its subsidiaries and more than 150 insurance companies. Judge Judith Fitzgerald of United States Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh approved the settlement between insurers and the Halliburton units, DII Industries and Kellogg Brown & Root, the company said. The approval clears the way for Halliburton to complete a $4.8 billion plan to settle all current and future asbestos claims. The settlement resolved a dispute between Halliburton and insurers over liability and came after decades of litigation and two years of mediation, Halliburton lawyers said when Judge Fitzgerald tentatively approved the agreement on Nov. 18.

title: Arts, Briefly; Music Prize to Tsontakis
description: One of the biggest monetary prizes in classical music composition, the Grawemeyer Award, has been won by George Tsontakis for his Violin Concerto No. 2. Mr. Tsontakis, 53, was born in Astoria, Queens, and is on the faculty of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado. His concerto was given its premiere last year by Steven Copes, the violinist, and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Miguel Harth-Bedoya. The award, for $200,000, is administered by the University of Louisville in Kentucky and past recipients have included John Adams, Pierre Boulez, Gyorgy Ligeti and John Corigliano. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULVANEY, DR. EILEEN G. (NEE O'KEEFE)
description: MULVANEY--Dr. Eileen G. (nee O'Keefe). Died Monday in Long Beach. Born in Queens, N.Y. November 18, 1930. She lived most of her life on Long Island including Manhasset, Garden City and Long Beach. She was a graduate of Mount St. Vincent Academy, Tuxedo Park, and Marymount (Manhattan) College. In her 40's she became a special education teacher, receiving a Master's Degree from Adelphi University and a Doctorate from Hofstra University. She taught at the Henry Viscardi High School in East Williston, and was an adjunct professor of special education at the Adelphi Graduate School of Education. After retiring she continued to work at Adelphi as a clinical educator. Survivors include her sons, James of Long Beach, Patrick of Sacramento, CA., their father, James of Rockaway Beach, daughter-in-law, Barbara Fischkin, and grandsons Daniel and John all of Long Beach. She is additionally survived by her uncle, Dr. John O'Keefe, brother Paul of Dallas, TX, and sister Dorothy of Asheville, N.C. A wake will be held today from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 445 East Meadow Ave., East Meadow, NY. A service will be held Wednesday at the funeral home at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Surfer's Healing, a registered charity providing recreational programs for autistic people: 2001 Corte Cardelina, San Clemente, CA 92673, (949) 728-1000.

title: Blurring the Line Between Bling and Forever
description: Good jewelry used to be the domain of Tiffany and Harry Winston, and of men -- half guilty, half proud -- buying presents for their wives. In a way, it still is. A blue box from Tiffany still counts for a lot; you wouldn't turn your nose up at a rock from Winston. And if your stocking holds a diamond pav flower pin from JAR, the Paris jeweler, you know your ship has finally come in.

title: BLACKSTONE TO BUY NHP, A BRITISH NURSING HOME GROUP
description: The private equity firm Blackstone Group will buy a British nursing home group, NHP, for 563.5 million ($1.06 billion). NHP, which has 355 homes and more than 17,000 beds in Britain, said in September that it had been approached by a possible buyer. Blackstone, based in New York, is paying 260 pence for every share of NHP. Blackstone said that the price was a 12 percent premium to the stock price in September. NHP is based in Surrey, England. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: With its stock plunging and its ability to thrive as an independent company uncertain, the drug giant Merck has adopted a plan that could give its top executives big bonuses if the company is taken over.

Money-Shifting Uproar Shakes World Jewish Congress
description: The World Jewish Congress is in turmoil, two decades after the billionaire Edgar M. Bronfman Sr. rescued it from crushing debts and propelled it to remarkable successes.

title: Wal-Mart Asks Court to Remove Suit's Class-Action Status
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the world's biggest retailer, asked an appeals court yesterday to overturn a ruling allowing 1.6 million women workers seeking billions of dollars in back pay to sue the company for discrimination as a group.

description: A front-page article yesterday about clinical drug testing at academic institutions misstated the percentage of government funds for such tests that go to 40 of the nation's 125 medical schools. It is 75 percent, not 90.

title: Arts, Briefly; Sundance Announces Festival Offerings
description: The Sundance Film Festival announced yesterday the lineup of 16 features and 16 documentaries for its festival, in January, in Park City, Utah. The documentaries include "Enron: Rise and Fall," about the disgraced Texas company, and "Shakespeare Behind Bars," about actor inmates in a Kentucky prison. The feature films include "Lonesome Jim," right, an entry by the actor and director Steve Buscemi about a downwardly mobile young man who moves back in with his parents, and "Ellie Parker," a comedy by Scott Coffey about a young woman's struggle for an acting career in Hollywood. The entries were chosen from 2,613 submissions from around the world. This year for the first time the festival will also award prizes for dramatic features and documentaries from abroad. SHARON WAXMAN

title: Two Brothers Shot, One Fatally, in Ambush on a Queens Street
description: Two brothers were shot yesterday, one fatally, near their Queens home by a man who appeared to have been lying in wait, officials said.

title: Annan Says His Son's Payments Created a 'Perception Problem'
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday that he had not known that his son had continued receiving payments until February of this year from a Swiss inspection company being investigated for suspected fraud and abuses in the oil-for-food program in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOKOSZKA, SOPHIE (CAROL)
description: KOKOSZKA--Sophie (Carol). On November 28, 2004. Beloved wife of Edward. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM with service Friday 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIVLIN, MOSHE. RONALD S.
description: RIVLIN--Moshe. Ronald S. Lauder, Russell F. Robinson and the Jewish National Fund Family mourn the passing of Moshe Rivlin, KKL/JNF World Chairman from 1976 to 1997. Mr. Rivlin was called the King of the Forest. A seventh generation Israeli, he was a man of vision and one of Israel's true pioneers. May the memory of his lifetime's work live forever.

title: Death Toll for Journalists in Philippines Keeps Rising
description: MANILA, Nov. 29 - The killing was swift and brazen. The gunman walked up to Allan Dizon, who was standing at the roadside in front of a shopping mall, and fired three shots. The gunman then casually walked to a motorcycle and sped off. Mr. Dizon died in a hospital two hours later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBLATT, AARON, DDS
description: GOLDBLATT--Aaron, DDS, November 27, beloved husband of the late Florence (nee Hoffman) for 53 years; caring father to Susan Wolk (Larry) and Michael Goldblatt (Lana); devoted grandfather to Adam and Daniel Wolk, dear brother of Jack (Ethel) Goldblatt & Bea Goldblatt; resided and practiced dentistry in Monroe, NY for over 30 years. An accomplished sculptor and artist, Aaron was a "top drawer" "gentle man" who cherished his Florence, family, many dear friends and the beauty in the world around him. Contributions to Jewish National Fund in lieu of flowers. Services Wednesday, December 1, 10:30 A.M. Temple Beth El, 314 N. Main St., Monroe, New York. Interment in Cedar Hill Cemetery, Middle Hope, NY. For information Quackenbush Funeral Home, 117 Maple Avenue, Monroe, NY.

title: Review Finds Weaknesses in Program to Curb Smoking
description: An independent review of the New York State Department of Health's $50 million program to reduce smoking found that it has repeatedly failed to spend all of the money available and has been unable to devise an advertising strategy to encourage people not to smoke.

Campbell, the state's environmental commissioner, said yesterday. The ship's owner, Tsakos Shipping and Trading SA, is required to pay for the cleanup. Jason George (NYT)

title: Four Studios Give Backing to a Format for DVD's
description: TOKYO, Nov. 29 - A group of companies led by the Toshiba Corporation made a major advance in the effort to define a new DVD standard as Paramount and three other Hollywood studios announced on Monday that they would release films in the group's high-definition DVD format by the end of next year.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 12 at Police Station in an Iraqi Town
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 29 - A suicide bomber rammed his car into a group of policemen waiting to collect their salaries on Monday morning west of Ramadi, killing 12 people and wounding many others in the latest attack on Iraq's security forces, officials at the Interior Ministry said.

title: A Spreading Hazard for Deer and Elk (and Hunters)
description: With hunting season in full swing, game hunters are anxious to fill their freezers. But as chronic wasting disease spreads through populations of deer and elk in some states, hunters are finding that their quarry may not be safe to eat.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cingular To Sell Spectrum Licenses
description: Cingular Wireless said yesterday that it would sell wireless-spectrum licenses to MetroPCS for $230 million as part of the company's regulatory obligations from its merger with AT&T Wireless Services. Cingular, an Atlanta-based joint venture of SBC Communications and BellSouth, said it agreed to sell licenses for 10 megahertz of spectrum in Dallas and 10 megahertz in Detroit to MetroPCS, a privately held company based in Dallas.

title: Arts, Briefly; Piano to Design Gardner Addition
description: The Italian architect Renzo Piano has been selected to design a new building for the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, the museum announced yesterday. The new structure, to be built next to the landmark building, right, will double the museum's space and triple its room for special exhibitions. The Gardner, which opened in 1903, has long struggled with conservation and expansion issues. "When Mrs. Gardner created the museum and its original endowment, she couldn't possibly have envisioned the challenges the museum would face in 100 years from the perspective of conservation and public duties," Jack Gardner, chairman of the museum's board of trustees and a great-great-nephew of the founder, said in a statement. Built from 1899 to 1901, the museum was modeled after a 15th-century Venetian palazzo and has more than 2,500 works in its collection, including paintings by Rembrandt, Raphael, Botticelli, Degas and Sargent. A spokeswoman for the museum said the new building is expected to cost $60 million or more. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Abuse Victim Tries to Pierce a Legal Shield
description: TRENTON, Nov. 29 - In a case brought by a man who says he was sexually abused as a pupil at a boarding school that tolerated pedophiles on its staff, the New Jersey Supreme Court was urged on Monday to revisit the legal protection of nonprofit organizations from negligence lawsuits.The case raises accusations against former staff members at the American Boychoir School in Princeton, N.J., that date from the 1970's. Some former students came forward years later, after the sexual abuse scandal involving Roman Catholic priests in Boston, to report abuse at the Boychoir School.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, ALFRED W., M.D., S.T.D.
description: MURPHY--Alfred W., M.D., S.T.D. of White Plains. Died November 28, 2004. He was born October 20, 1921 in the Bronx to the late Mary (Frawley) & Edward Murphy. He received a B.S. from Manhattan College, graduated from Long Island College of Medicine in 1946 and received a doctorate of Sacred Theology from Catholic University. Dr. Murphy was a child Physcharist and was the medical director of the Peekskill mental health center and an associate professor at NY Hospital. Dr. Murphy formerly served as a Diocesean Priest and was later a Dominican Medical Missionary in Pakistan. He also served as a physician in Haiti. Dr. Murphy successfully spearheaded the effort to have the international Catholic Physicians admitted into the United Nations as a non-government organization. He was a veteran of the US Navy. He was also a member, and past president, of the Catholic Physicians Guild of NY. He was also a member of many Irish Cultural and historical organizations. He was a member of Our Lady of Sorrows Church in White Plains. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth (McLoughlin), whom he married in 1972. In addition to his wife, Dr. Murphy is survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces & grandnephews and four great grand nieces & nephews. He is predeceased by a brother Edward and a sister Marie McGowan. Visiting hours are Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home in White Plains, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605. Mass of Christian burial is Wednesday 10 AM at Our Lady of Sorrows Church. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Money on Their Minds

Still, nearly a quarter of the planners said they expected to book more travel next year than they did this year. On the other hand, 21 percent said they planned to reduce the number of days of their meetings to save money over the next three years.

description: The penalty phase of the Scott Peterson murder trial will begin today in Redwood City after the State Supreme Court turned down a petition to empanel a new jury in Los Angeles. The petition was filed with the court last week by Mark Geragos, a lawyer for Mr. Peterson, after similar requests were denied by a Superior Court judge and a state appeals court. Mr. Geragos argued that Mr. Peterson, who was convicted on Nov. 12 of killing his pregnant wife, Laci, could not get a fair sentencing in Redwood City because of public sentiment there against him. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STONE, LYUDMILA
description: STONE -- Lyudmila. Passed away November 28, 2004 after a year-long bout with cancer. Beloved daughter of Dr. Zoya Tsukerman and the late Dr. Izyeslav Tsukerman. Dear wife of Andy Stone. Loving mother and motherin-law of Anna and Albert, and best-friend of Mishka. Mila was a person of quiet warmth, strength, and compassion, qualities consistently lived in every facet of her life. These were especially reflected in her involvement in charitable and humanitarian organizations. Throughout her life many sought her council and few were disappointed by her honest, compassionate and forthright advice. Never one to boast about her own hard earned success, she was a modest woman who loved making others happy. She skied, played Mah Jong, and took much joy in entertaining in her home. Mila put her family above all else and we are forever grateful for her profound contemplative generosity. Mila's serenity in approaching her untimely death will forever serve as an inspiration to family and friends. She will be missed and fondly remembered by all those whose lives she touched. Services will be held Tuesday, November 30, 2004 at Wandy Memorial Chapel, 1841 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, NY 11746 at 1PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Colon Cancer Alliance, 175 Ninth Ave, New York, N.Y. 10011 or the American Cancer Society 800-ACS-2345.

The company would bid 1.5 billion euros ($2 billion) to take over MobilTel, the Austrian daily Die Presse said. The company is competing against Deutsche Telekom of Germany, Vodafone Group of Britain and the Canadian investment company TIW.

title: STANLEY WORKS IS ACQUIRING A SECURITY AND LOCK COMPANY
description: Stanley Works, the maker of hand tools, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Security Group, which manufactures medium and high-security locks and provides security installation and repair services, to add more security products. Stanley said that it would pay about $49 million in cash and $7 million in notes for Security Group and for Cal-Dor Specialties, a distributor of Stanley products in El Cajon, Calif. Stanley, based in New Britain, Conn., did not specify the cost of each company. The acquisitions together would add 3 cents to 4 cents a share to earnings in 2005, Stanley said. The Security Group comprises two companies: Sargent & Greenleaf, of Nicholasville, Ky., a lock manufacturer; and SafeMasters of Silver Spring, Md., which provides mechanical and electronic access control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DORSKIND, ALBERT
description: DORSKIND--Albert. To my loving brother, Albert, you showed me the way, you stood beside me growing up, and you guided and encouraged me. Your vision and enthusiasm brought so much to so many. Always with dignity and humility, your accomplishments changed the very face of the entertainment industry, and your wisdom inspired all of those whose lives you touched. Although we lived 3000 miles apart, it was always family when Dotty and I were together with you and Sue, whether for dinner or a vacation trip or countless hours on the phone. Bruce, Glenn and Cheryl, and their two children, Nicole and Joelle, knew how very special it was to have you and Sue (and DeeDee, Jimmy, and Mary) in their lives. They are each wiser souls for the times they shared with you. While you will be remembered for your brilliance and your countless accomplishments, I will always miss the guidance you gave me, the wonderful things you did for countless sick and less fortunate people, and, most of all, the times we shared with each other these past 79 years. With much love, Bob

title: Protecting the Whistle-Blower
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that raises important issues about who is covered by antidiscrimination law. An Alabama girls' basketball coach lost his position in 2001 after complaining that his team was being discriminated against. He sued under Title IX, the federal law prohibiting sex discrimination in schools receiving federal funds. The school argued, in response, that the coach was not part of the class that Congress intended to protect with the law. The court should hold that he is covered by Title IX, because he is alleging that he lost his position as a result of sex discrimination.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BT Group Forms Net Entertainment Unit
description: The BT Group has formed an entertainment division to offer movies and television programs over the Internet, becoming the latest former phone monopoly to seek new revenue from the media industry. The unit will enter into licensing agreements with makers of games and films, offering downloads to BT's high-speed Internet customers, the London-based company said yesterday. BT, Britain's largest phone company, joins Royal KPN of the Netherlands in offering television on the Web. Phone companies are seeking new sources of sales as their fixed-line businesses shrink. TeliaSonera, based in Stockholm, has said it plans to start the service this year. BT's chief executive, Ben Verwaayen, speaking at a Financial Times conference in London yesterday, said the benefits of beaming live television using the company's network were "hard to understand," costing billions of pounds a year. Offering stored downloads -- a so-called on-demand service -- was more economical, he said. BT's entertainment business, which will start on Jan. 1, will be led by Andrew Burke, currently director of value-added services at BT Retail. The new unit will be part of BT Retail, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOCHBERG, RITA
description: HOCHBERG--Rita. On November 28, 2004. After a long illness surrounded by her family. Adored wife of Irwin, beloved mother of Mitchell, Richard & Jonathan. Loving mother-in-law of Suzan and Stacy, Cherished Bubbe of Isabelle, Julia, Jordan, Ethan and Sabrina, loving sister-in-law of Sybil Barer and sister of Martin Tausner. She committed her time and energy in support of American Jewry and the State of Israel. She served on the Boards of U.J.A.-Federation of New York, Project Renewal-Hatikvah, N.Y. Association For New Americans, and Open University of Israel. She was a Hadassah Life Member and former chairman of the Great Neck ORT Chapter. She devoted her life to her family, especially her five grandchildren who meant so much to her. Her dedication to family and tzedakah will forever live on through her children and grandchildren. She will be missed dearly by so many and her memory will eternally remain in the hearts of all of us that loved her so much. The funeral was held Monday November 29, 2004 at Congregation Kneses Tifereth Israel, 575 King Street, Port Chester, NY. Interment followed at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Friends of the Open University of Israel or to the Rita Hochberg Fund at Westchester Medical Center to support the nurses in the Intensive Care Unit. HOCHBERG--Rita. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rita Hochberg, beloved wife of Irwin, former chairman of the board & long time leader of UJA-Federation, whose unparalleled commitment and generosity touched many Jewish causes worldwide. A cherished partner in her husband's philanthropic leadership efforts, Rita lived an exemplary life filled with love for her family, the State of Israel, and the Jewish people, passing on to her children a dedication and commitment to strengthening our ability to serve those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Irwin; their children: Mitchell and his wife Suzan, Jonathan and his wife Stacy, and Richard; their five grandchildren; and the entire Hochberg family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. HOCHBERG--Rita. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved wife of Irwin Hochberg, Chairman of its National Campaign Advisory Board and former National Campaign Chairman. She was a widely respected Jewish communal leader in her own right and a devoted supporter of the Israel Bonds program. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Irwin and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joshua Matza President and CEO Burton P. Resnick Chairman of the Board Michael Siegal Vice Chairman of the Board Bobbie Goldstein Nat'l Campaign Chairman Joel Gutterman National Campaign Director HOCHBERG--Rita. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Rita Hochberg, beloved wife of Irwin, a Vice Chair of ADL's National Commission. Rita joined Irwin in his support of ADL's agenda and shared his passion and commitment for the well being and security of Israel and the Jewish people everywhere. We extend our sincerest condolences to Irwin, his sons and the entire family. Barbara B. Balser, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director HOCHBERG--Rita. All of us at Bloom Hochberg & Co. mourn the death of Rita Hochberg, the wife of our esteemed senior partner, Irwin. The mutual love and respect Rita and Irwin showed for each other was always there, and always heart warming. We pray Rita's memory will give her family strength during this sad and difficult period. The partners and staff of Bloom Hochberg & Co. HOCHBERG--Rita. Barbara and I, together with our parents and children, mourn the death of our friend Rita Hochberg. Rita's enthusiasm for life and her philanthropic work were inspirational. When she fell ill, her courage and Irwin's devotion showed us, by example, how to deal with adversity. She will be sorely missed. Myron Bloom HOCHBERG -- Rita. The Trustees, Officers and Staff of The Caroline and Joseph S. Gruss Life Monument Funds mourn the passing of Rita Hochberg, wife of our devoted board member, Irwin Hochberg. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Martin D. Gruss, Chairman Jason G. Cury, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNHART, SPENCER D.
description: BARNHART--Spencer D. Age 66. Beloved husband of Mickey. Dearest father of Jennifer Fozo (Michael). Loving son of Kirk Richardson. Services were held Detroit, MI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENSON, LAURALEE TRENT
description: STEVENSON -- Lauralee Trent. Died after a short illness on Friday, November 26. She was a 32-year resident of New York City, after traveling the world as the wife of an Air Force Officer, Maj. Gen. John D. Stevenson, deceased. Born in Lynchburg, VA, she was a graduate of Gunston Hall in Washington, D.C., attended Randolph-Macon Woman's College, and received her B.A. and M.F.A. degrees from Hunter College. Her book, "Confederate Soldier Artists: Painting the South's War," was published by White Mane in 1997. She was a founder of Air Force Village, a retirement facility, and was active with the Soldiers, Sailors, and Airmens Club, the English Speaking Union, the Blue Ridge School Foundation, the Colonial Dames, the United Daughters of the Confederacy, the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Huguenot Society of America, the New England Society and the Leukemia Society. She is survived by her daughters, Martha Stevenson Olson of San Diego, CA and Trent Stevenson Colbert of Wilmington, NC and son, Jed Stevenson of Brooklyn, NY, and by five grandchildren. Memorial service 111 E. 87 St. 2PM Friday November 3,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SABRIN, ALMA (NEE ROSSI)
description: SABRIN--Alma (nee Rossi), 86, of Manhasset and Westhampton Beach died peacefully November 23, 2004. Adored wife of the late Dr. George Sabrin. Beloved mother of Russell, Douglas, Amy and Pamela; dear mother-in-law of Evans and Carole. Inspirational grandmother of Adam, Michael and Lucy. Born in Torrington, CT, Alma was a scholar and athlete who graduated top of her class. She then achieved honors at Mt. Sinai School of Nursing, including receiving a Guggenheim Fellowship and a teaching appointment. Former President of the Manhasset School Community Association and the Manhasset Student Aid Association, Alma also enjoyed working over 15 years in the guidance office of Manhasset H.S., leading to retirement. A lifelong advocate of civil rights and equal opportunity in education, Alma was a role model for many. Intelligent and beautiful, compassionate and generous; an extraordinary person with boundless energy and a talent for bringing out the best in everyone. The care, wisdom and grace she selflessly bestowed as nurse, teacher, wife, mother, hostess, aunt, in-law, leader, friend, will be cherished forever by the countless many who will never forget her. Service Sunday, December 5, 11 AM at Fairchild & Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in memory of Alma Sabrin to St. Labre Indian School, Ashland, MT, 59003 or Manhasset Student Aid Association, PO Box 255, Manhasset, NY 11030.

title: Pennington Aims to Make Return This Weekend
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 29 - Chad Pennington, the Jets' injured quarterback, said Monday that he would resume full practices with the first team this week and that he had recovered enough from a strained rotator cuff to play against Houston on Sunday.

title: Mayor Denies Racial Motive in Criticism of the Garden
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he had never given a thought to racial politics or to the ethnic origins of his potential adversaries when he complained about the hiring of an ally of Fernando Ferrer to help fight against a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan. He added that he hoped the owners of Madison Square Garden, who made the appointment, would stop protesting the stadium in the name of holiday harmony.
